headline: Review: ‘Marie’s Story,’ a Tale Similar to Helen Keller’s
text: A deaf and blind girl is saved by a consumptive nun in “Marie’s Story,” a saccharine sister to Arthur Penn’s “The Miracle Worker” (1962) from the French director Jean-Pierre Améris.

headline: Review: In ‘Maya the Bee Movie,’ a Young Dreamer Escapes the Hive Mentality
text: “Maya the Bee Movie” is a sweet, colorful animated story aimed at young children. Let’s just hope no actual bees watch it.

headline: Review: ‘Natural Resistance,’ a Documentary on the Italian Wine Industry
text: “Natural Resistance” returns its director, Jonathan Nossiter, to the subject of his 2005 documentary, “Mondovino.” That film examined the effects of globalization on the wine industry, a business that might seem like a haven of elitism and individuality — hardly a trade susceptible to homogenization.

headline: Germany Is Accused of Helping N.S.A. Spy on European Allies
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government is fending off allegations that the German secret service helped the United States to spy on European partners and companies, nearly a year after Ms. Merkel expelled the top American spy in a rare display of anger over revelations of widespread United States intelligence operations in Germany.

headline: Jameis Winston Is No. 1 in N.F.L. Draft as Talent Trumps Worry
text: CHICAGO — Jameis Winston, the star quarterback from Florida State who played under a swirl of controversy, was chosen first over all in the N.F.L. draft by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on Thursday.

headline: Chicago Said to Be Choice Over New York as Obama Library Site
text: CHICAGO — Chicago can breathe a sigh of relief: New York City will not be home to the Barack Obama Presidential Library and Museum.

headline: Social Media Punished as Results Fall Short
text: A trio of social media stocks is getting pummeled this week, a sign that Wall Street may be unwilling to overlook missteps at some of its Internet darlings.

headline: Review: ‘Reality,’ an Absurdist Comedy of Dreams and Movie Nightmares
text: The indecipherability of “Reality,” the latest absurdist deathtrap from Quentin Dupieux (“Rubber,” “Wrong”), begins with its title: “Reality” is actually the name of a girl (Kyla Kenedy) who spots a blue VHS tape inside the guts of the hog her father has shot. A hog ingesting a videotape — or even the continued use of tapes — makes as much sense as anything else in this sardonic, self-devouring comedy, in which dreams, movies within movies and reality (such as it is) mix.

headline: Republic of Congo Signals a Turn in Poaching Fight
text: WASHINGTON — Denis Sassou-Nguesso, president of the Republic of Congo, smiled broadly as he set fire to more than five tons of illegally hunted elephant tusks this week in Brazzaville, the nation’s capital.

headline: Rules Change on I.R.S. Seizures, Too Late for Some
text: Under mounting pressure, the Internal Revenue Service and the Justice Department have announced in recent months that they will no longer use a law designed to go after drug dealers and terrorists to seize the bank accounts of small business owners who are not suspected of criminal activity. But Lyndon McLellan, the owner of a convenience store in rural Fairmont, N.C., where catfish sandwiches go for $2.75, is still trying to recover the $107,702.66 — his entire business bank account — that was seized by the I.R.S. last summer.

headline: Attacks on U.N. Force Add to Unrest in Mali
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Armed groups in the north of Mali have, over the last week, attacked each other as well as United Nations peacekeepers and Malian soldiers — underscoring the country’s fragility as it tries to emerge from several years of political instability and jihadist revolt.

headline: Apple, IBM and Japan Post See Profit in the Old-Age Market
text: Japan is an incubator of aging. More than other countries, it is a graying nation. Twenty-five percent of its population, or 33 million people, is age 65 or older, more than double the global average.

headline: Bill to Speed Approvals for Drugs Is Cut Back
text: WASHINGTON — Legislation that would have accelerated the pace of federal drug approvals in a way that critics said threatened to erode patient safety was formally released this week, in a scaled-back version with many of the most controversial provisions left out.

headline: Medicare Releases Detailed Data on Prescription Drug Spending
text: The heartburn drug Nexium — whose advertisements have long been ubiquitous on television — was prescribed to 1.5 million Medicare patients in 2013, for a total cost of more than $2.5 billion, the largest amount spent on any drug prescribed through the government program, according to data released by Medicare officials on Thursday.

headline: U.S. Said to Give Warren Weinstein’s Family Ransom Advice
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly two years before Warren Weinstein, an aid worker kidnapped by Al Qaeda, was inadvertently killed in an American drone strike, the F.B.I. gave his family guidance about paying a ransom of $250,000 to the militants who were holding him, United States officials said on Thursday.

text: Congressional lawmakers, already conflicted about an impending nuclear deal with Iran, are increasingly angry over the incarceration of American citizens in that country, where at least three are imprisoned, including one held for more than three and a half years.

headline: Giants Draft Ereck Flowers, Not the Offensive Lineman They Wanted
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Perhaps no unit on the Giants has been a greater liability in recent seasons than the offensive line. The Giants have struggled to run the ball effectively and have failed to protect quarterback Eli Manning, a combination that has contributed mightily to the team’s 13-19 record in the last two seasons.

headline: Under Threat Because of His Words, a Charlie Hebdo Writer Continues to Speak Out
text: Like the people who stopped for coffee or missed a train connection on Sept. 11, Jean-Baptiste Thoret is alive because he was late getting to work in Paris one day in January. He is the film critic for Charlie Hebdo, a satirical magazine. That morning, two armed brothers forced their way into its offices. They killed 12 people; five others were killed in a later, coordinated attack. Among the dead were cartoonists thought to have drawn images offensive to some Muslims, a building porter, a man stopping by the office for the first time, police officers and shoppers in a kosher supermarket.

headline: Police Board Clears Driver in Freddie Gray Case; No Officers Have Been Convicted
text: Prosecutors dropped all charges against three officers awaiting trial. Three other officers had already been acquitted.

headline: New Owner for The Moscow Times and Vedomosti
text: MOSCOW — A Finnish media company on Thursday said it would sell its one-third stake in Vedomosti, Russia’s most influential business newspaper, as well as ownership of The Moscow Times, the country’s only English-language daily, to a Russian buyer.

headline: Obama Pledges to Defend Democrats on Trade Deal
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday made a personal plea to a group of congressional Democrats to support a far-reaching Pacific trade deal even in the face of political peril, promising them during a two-hour meeting at the White House that he would defend and campaign for lawmakers who risked their jobs to back him.

headline: Richard Suzman, 72, Dies; Researcher Influenced Global Surveys on Aging
text: Richard M. Suzman once chased a Nobel-winning psychologist through a Washington rainstorm, as a scientific meeting was breaking up, to whet the psychologist’s interest in a new project. In the middle of the night, Dr. Suzman liked to email social scientists, urging them to take immediate action on a project. Other times, an email or phone call would all but order a researcher to apply for a grant.

headline: Jozef Paczynski, Inmate Barber to Auschwitz Commandant, Dies at 95
text: Jozef Paczynski, a Polish Army captain who spent much of his five-year imprisonment in Auschwitz as the personal barber to Rudolf Höss, the Nazi death camp’s commandant, died on Sunday in Krakow. He was 95.

headline: North Korean Diplomats Disrupt Human Rights Panel
text: A United Nations panel on North Korean human rights abuses, organized by the United States delegation at the organization’s New York headquarters, briefly degenerated into shouting and disorder Thursday when three North Korean diplomats disrupted the event to deliver a statement denying any wrongdoing in their country. The diplomats interrupted North Korean defectors who were testifying about the deprivations they said they had endured. The United States ambassador, Samantha Power, threatened to call in United Nations security guards to evict the North Korean diplomats, but they left after about six minutes. Ms. Power said  that the North Korean diplomats had been invited to speak but only after the defectors had spoken, “and unfortunately, as you heard, the delegation chose instead to try to drown out the testimony of these panelists.” She also told the defectors, “It must be chilling for those of you who have been subjected to the terror of the regime to be confronted with bullying and disruption and the kind of behavior that we saw today.” North Korea has become increasingly angry over actions by the United Nations during the past few years, most notably a human rights report that described much of the country as a large penal colony and called for possible prosecution of North Korean leaders at the International Criminal Court. The United Nations Security Council has tightened sanctions against North Korea because of its nuclear weapons and missile tests. The North Korean authorities have accused the United States of orchestrating such actions as part of what they call an American plot to destabilize their country.

headline: Review: Mating-Season Mood Swings in ‘Two Gentlemen of Verona’
text: For those of you who had been wondering if spring had decided to skip New York this year, there has been a confirmed sighting of that elusive season at Theater for a New Audience’s Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn. Fresh sap, tickling breezes, blushing blooms — yep, they’re all in evidence. So is the tendency of emerging specimens of human fauna to seize the day as if it were made exclusively for mating.

headline: They’ll Help You Out

headline: Clashes in Philadelphia as Freddie Gray Protest Neared Highway

headline: Port Authority Delays Picking Builder for a Terminal at La Guardia

headline: Jury Finds Mistakes, Not Widespread Fraud, at Seedco Job Agency
text: A former director for a nonprofit agency, which previously settled federal charges of making fake job placements to collect $1.6 million in “performance payments,” made mistakes but did not engage in a widespread pattern of fraud, a jury in Manhattan found last week.

headline: Indiana Governor to Approve Needle Exchanges to Fight H.I.V.
text: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana has said he will sign a bill allowing cities and counties to create needle exchange programs if they are experiencing an outbreak of H.I.V. or hepatitis C because of intravenous drug use.

text: After five days of deliberations, jurors on Thursday said they could not reach a decision in the most serious charge against Kahton Anderson, who was 14 when he fired a gun on a Brooklyn bus and killed a 39-year-old father last year.

headline: Clippers Force a Game 7 Against the Spurs
text: SAN ANTONIO — The Los Angeles Clippers were under duress, on the brink of elimination against the defending champions. So their 102-96 victory over the San Antonio Spurs on Thursday night was something to savor, at least until they began the process of focusing all over again.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Starz) GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY (2014) A motley crew of baddies, led by Peter Quill (Chris Pratt), a heavily armed professional scavenger, join forces to stop a crazed warrior from taking over the universe in James Gunn’s interstellar western, based on the Marvel Comics characters. The cast includes Zoe Saldana as Gamora, a green, mean killing machine; Dave Bautista as the brute Drax; Glenn Close as a space-age Hillary Rodham Clinton; Bradley Cooper as the voice of the raccoon Rocket; and Vin Diesel as a gorgeous tree called Groot, who nibbles his own tender sprouts. Oh, yes — and a blue orb that has incited the mayhem in the first place. “That there’s a palpable directorial sensibility in ‘Guardians of the Galaxy,’ along with other signs of genuine life, helps separate this latest Marvel cash grab from a lot of off-the-rack movie cartoons,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Here, a pulse, wit, beauty and a real sensibility have been slipped into the fray, alongside the clockwork guffaws, kabooms and splats.” She added: “The story may be confusing and generic by turns, but if you shake off the bonds of narrative coherency it’s liberating letting the weird words — Yondu, Necrocraft, Sakkaran — just slide right past you, much like the zigzagging, exploding 3-D spaceships. What sticks are the fantastical landscapes, the beautiful creature designs and the actors delivering lively performances, even with strata of makeup and digital wizardry.”

headline: Verne Gagne, Wrestler Who Grappled Through Two Eras, Dies at 89
text: Eighth Avenue traffic was disorganized, pedestrian traffic was jammed for blocks north and south, side doors at Madison Square Garden were torn from their hinges as the crowd stormed the entrances. It was the largest crowd at the Garden in 25 years — larger than for championship fights, rodeos, tennis matches or the circus.

headline: Ideology and Integrity
text: The 2016 campaign should be almost entirely about issues. The parties are far apart on everything from the environment to fiscal policy to health care, and history tells us that what politicians say during a campaign is a good guide to how they will govern.

headline: The Nature of Poverty
text: Lately it seems as though every few months there’s another urban riot and the nation turns its attention to urban poverty. And in the midst of every storm, there are people crying out that we should finally get serious about this issue. This time it was Jon Stewart who spoke for many when he said: “And you just wonder sometimes if we’re spending a trillion dollars to rebuild Afghanistan’s schools, like, we can’t build a little taste down Baltimore way. Like is that what’s really going on?”

headline: What Old Nazis Make Us Remember
text: BERLIN — THE trial of Oskar Gröning, the 93-year-old “accountant of Auschwitz,” began last week in the German city of Lüneburg. Mr. Gröning is charged with complicity in the murder of at least 300,000 people. At least once during the summer of 1944, according to his accusers, when thousands of Hungarian Jews arrived by cattle car at Auschwitz-Birkenau, he stood at the exit ramp, watching as the passengers were divided into those to be put into forced labor and those to be killed instantly.

headline: How to Hold the Baltimore Police Accountable
text: Update 11:34 AM ET: In a surprise announcement, the state attorney of Baltimore, Marilyn J. Mosby, said this morning that she had found probable cause to file homicide, manslaughter and misconduct charges against police officers in the death of Freddie Gray. The prosecutor said that officers had arrested Mr. Gray without grounds, violated procedure by transporting him unsafely in a police van and had repeatedly failed to get him medical attention. The death, Ms. Mosby said, is believed to be the result of a fatal injury to Mr. Gray while he was riding in the van.

headline: Picking Up the Tab for Low Wages
text: It is hard to overstate the extent to which work no longer results in a decent paycheck and a rising standard of living in this country. The portion of the economic pie that goes to working people is currently near the smallest on record, in data going back to 1947. Similarly, the gap between worker pay and labor productivity has widened since the 1970s. In a healthy economy, wages and productivity would rise in tandem, but in recent decades, productivity gains have flowed increasingly to executive compensation and shareholder returns, rather than wages.

headline: American Beauty, Wherever It’s From
text: The Whitney Museum of American Art reopens on Friday in a new building, in a new neighborhood, offering a new chance to chew over an old question. What is American art, exactly?

headline: The Pressures on Today’s Students
Black Culture Is Not the Problem
text: BALTIMORE — IN the wake of the Michael Brown shooting and subsequent unrest in Ferguson, Mo., commentators noted the absence of black representatives among Ferguson’s elected officials and its police leadership. headline: Q. and A.: Francis Fukuyama on China’s Political Development
text: Francis Fukuyama’s widely read essay “The End of History?” — published just before the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 — posited that Western liberal democracy may turn out to be the endpoint of political development. So when Mr. Fukuyama laid out what he considered the weaknesses of the American political system in a new book last year, “Political Order and Political Decay,” the Chinese state news media immediately asserted that he had altered his views and now considered state capacity, like that of China during the last 35 years of rapid economic development under Communist Party rule, as more important for a country’s prosperity than democracy.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Teenager Is Rescued From Rubble Five Days After Nepal Earthquake

text: The intimidating wish list flaunted by discriminating house hunters in the Hamptons is nothing new. These shoppers are like diners who blithely order dishes nowhere in sight on the restaurant menu: Their sense of entitlement is accompanied by a desire for a totally customized experience.

headline: Speedy Drug Approvals Have Become the Rule, Not the Exception

headline: This Summer’s Action Heroes Are Several Shades of Gray
text: Summer is supposed to be the season of youth, when the over-25 quadrant surrenders theaters to wisecracking cartoons, thumb-sucking comedies and action franchises based on toys, comic books, amusement park rides. This is when the big studios make most of their money with Krypton-proof titles like “Transformers: Age of Extinction,” and their year-round obsession with pandering to the kids reaches fever pitch. In the movie world, summer starts the first weekend in May, which this year meant the release of “Avengers: Age of Ultron,” with those youngbloods Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, Scarlett Johansson and — the 50-year-old Robert Downey Jr.

headline: Brooklyn Girl Injured in a Fire That Killed 7 Siblings Is Said to Be Recovering
text: A Brooklyn girl who was badly burned and whose seven siblings died a month ago in a fire has been released from the hospital, and according to a family acquaintance, she is walking, speaking and, in a sign of her resiliency, smiling.

headline: A Woman-Led Law Firm That Lets Partners Be Parents

headline: 1915: Zeppelins Grow Like Falstaff’s Men in Buckram

headline: Advice From a Shoe Expert, Steve Taffel of Leffot
text: Leffot, a high-ceilinged boutique in Greenwich Village specializing in classic men’s footwear, has occupied the corner of Christopher Street and Gay Street since 2008, when the proprietor Steve Taffel opened it with his wife, Hiroko Taffel, a year after he left Prada. Displayed amid the black walls are swatches of suedes and leathers (for custom design) and about 70 pairs of shoes from traditional makers like Alden and Edward Green. The shop also offers hats, socks, belts and wallets. Here, Mr. Taffel provides an insider’s view on how to dress your feet for warm weather.

headline: Today in Politics: Time and Distance Might Lessen Familiar Argument Against Clinton

headline: Re: Her Majesty’s Jihadists
text: It was, in the words of Mika Brzezinski on “Morning Joe,” “revelatory”: In her April 19 cover story, Mary Anne Weaver reported that more British Muslims had joined Islamist militias like ISIS and the Nusra Front than are serving the British Army.

headline: How Doing Nothing Became the Ultimate Family Vacation
text: Before having a child, my wife and I had always prided ourselves on being travelers and not tourists. We liked out-of-the-way places; my research often took us to absurd locations like the Democratic Republic of Congo near rebel-held territory or old Khmer Rouge bases on the Thai-Cambodian border. We hated anything that smelled of a prepaid vacation package and we generally avoided hotels, preferring guesthouses or staying in locals’ apartments.

headline: New York City From a Pint-Size Perspective
text: Until my 8-year-old granddaughter, Emilia, and I pretended to be tourists in New York, it had honestly never occurred to me that Times Square might be the nicest neighborhood in the city. At the places where out-of-towners go, I was struck by how many young employees of these attractions asked us if we were enjoying ourselves, if we were having fun. More surprisingly, they seemed genuinely interested in our replies. They appeared to have been hired for their humorous, friendly dispositions.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Frans Masereel’s ‘The City’
text: I found it 20 years ago on a secondhand bookstore’s discard table, the sort of lucky accident that befalls only a prepared mind. It was a paperback 1972 Dover edition of a work originally published in Munich in 1925: “The City,” by Frans Masereel, a wordless novel made up of 100 woodcuts. The yellowed and slightly water-stained cover bore a blown-up reprint of one of the many indelible urban tableaus that I was about to view for the first time — images that I somehow instantly recognized, even anticipated.

headline: ‘Once’
text: Once, when I came home from school after being taunted on the playground for having a black mother and a white father, I climbed onto my parents’ tall bed and lay between them. It was a raft, and the world around us fell away as we drifted there. Saskia Hamilton’s poem carries me back to that moment as if speaking to my own particular experience. It’s one of poetry’s great gifts to show us ourselves through the intimate voice of another.

headline: How to Write a Romance Novel
text: Romance novels end happily. Try another approach, and you’ll anger a lot of readers, says Jayne Ann Krentz, who has written more than 150 books, including 50 consecutive New York Times best sellers. Hero and heroine might spend hundreds of pages kept apart by war, vampires, apocalypse or any number of other exhausting obstacles, but by the end, they must be together in a way that suggests long-lasting love.

headline: The Amazing New Thing
text: A never-ending cycle of wanting the latest gadgets.

headline: Wasting Less of Africa’s Harvest in Order to Prosper
text: Last year, Tanzania had exciting news: a bumper harvest of corn. But even as farmers were celebrating — corn is a staple eaten at almost every meal — much of the crop had already been spoiled, having grown moldy or been infested by insects and rodents. The problem was that farmers lacked the capacity to store food safely. Even the government’s national reserve system had run out of space to hold the overflow.

headline: A Collected Home for Inger McCabe Elliott
text: Inger McCabe Elliott, a former photojournalist for Life and a textile designer, lives in a 1914 co-op on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

headline: What Happened When I Joked About the President of Ecuador
text: President Rafael Correa delivers the sabatina, his address, every Saturday. But I had something else to do that morning. By the time I got home at noon, people had written to me on Twitter, saying that I was going to jail. There was a photo of the president during the sabatina, and on the screen behind him was my logo and a photo of my memes. I’ve always posted satirical political memes on my Facebook page, about the government, about the opposition.

headline: 2 Indicted in George Washington Bridge Case; Ally of Christie Pleads Guilty
text: After a 16-month federal investigation into the George Washington Bridge lane closings scandal, a judge in New Jersey unsealed indictments against two people close to Gov. Chris Christie, outlining a conspiracy made with a third confidant to exact political vengeance against a mayor for not endorsing the governor’s re-election.

headline: The Bridge Scandal, Explained
text: Q. What actually happened?

headline: Macedonia Indicts Opposition Leader Who Denounced Graft
text: WARSAW — Macedonia’s main opposition leader has been formally indicted on charges of wiretapping and antigovernment activities after months of political turmoil, prosecutors said this week.

headline: Morning Agenda: Greenberg Still in the Ring
text: GREENBERG STILL IN THE RING | In 2005, Maurice R. Greenberg was forced to resign from American International Group under the shadow of an accounting scandal, which he is still battling in court as he gets ready to turn 90 on Monday. And Mr. Greenberg is also the driving force behind a four-year-old lawsuit claiming the federal government unconstitutionally seized A.I.G.’s assets during the financial crisis. “Few people would choose to spend their golden years surrounded by lawyers, facing subpoenas and hostile cross-examination. Yet, if anything, Mr. Greenberg seems to have been energized,” James B. Stewart writes in his Common Sense column.

headline: Hogan Fund-Raiser for Christie Comes at a Bad Time
text: When it was scheduled, the May 1 fund-raiser was cast as the glorious reunion of two valiant political allies, Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: Everything I Know About Journalism in 395 Words
text: On Wednesday night, I taught my last class of the semester at the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism and my last class there, at least for now. (I will be teaching an opinion-writing class at the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism in the fall.)

headline: Paris in the Springtime, in New York
text: MY breakfast this morning was a perfect croissant. I hadn’t realized such a thing existed in New York until a Parisian pointed me in its direction.

headline: Tom Hardy on Life as the New Mad Max
text: LAS VEGAS — Tom Hardy’s mug — oversize, pouty-lipped, bedroom-eyed in the key of Paul Newman — was plastered all over the elevator banks at Caesars Palace here. But at a Starbucks on the casino floor, amid the hypnotic dings and blinkety lights, hundreds of people swirled around as he ordered coffee, barely giving him a second — or even a first — glance.

headline: 1940: College Head Offers a Million for Capture of Hitler Alive
text: NEW YORK — A $1,000,000 reward for the capture of Adolf Hitler and  his delivery alive, uninjured and unhurt, to the League of Nations during the month of May, today [May 1] was offered by Samuel  H. Church, eighty-one-year-old president of the Carnegie Institute, on behalf of that organization.

headline: That Lovin’ Feeling
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Even at the Top, Making Plans for Life’s ‘Third Chapter’
text: WHEN Sherry Lansing, the former chairwoman of Paramount Pictures, decided to end a 40-year career in the rough-and-tumble of Hollywood, the question she faced was where to direct all the energy and drive that had propelled her to the top of the industry.

headline: ‘Jurassic World’ Does Its Own Dinosaur Modifications
text: After three films in the “Jurassic Park” series, it looks as if the scientists who tinkered with genetics to bring back dinosaurs still haven’t learned their lesson. They’re back in “Jurassic World,” due June 12, to engineer a new dinosaur, the Indominus Rex. ”Jurassic World” takes place 22 years after the first film, now with a fully functioning park. Because of low attendance, park officials have opted for a genetically modified creature to join some of the familiar ones. Chaos, of course, ensues. Returning are the velociraptors, which generated chills in Steven Spielberg’s 1993 original and in the sequels. But in “Jurassic World,” they have more individual moments — and even take to a bit of training.

headline: Floyd Mayweather Jr.’s Fashion
text: Mr. Mayweather has become boxing’s singular fashion plate, developing a ring-wear style perhaps best described as Louis Vuitton-meets-Liberace.

headline: As Floyd Mayweather Jr. Steps Into Ring, He Turns It Into a Catwalk
text: When Floyd Mayweather Jr. steps into the boxing ring at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas on Saturday to fight Manny Pacquiao, the first question on most viewers’s minds — including the estimated three million pay-per-viewers — will be, of course, who will win.

headline: The Director Paul Feig Prepares ‘Spy’ With Melissa McCarthy
text: BUDAPEST — Melissa McCarthy was standing in an ersatz C.I.A. office here, on a soundstage a few miles outside the city. With a curly wig and a fake case of pink eye, she was shooting a scene opposite Jude Law for their new movie, “Spy,” as the director and screenwriter, Paul Feig, looked on.

headline: Bernanke and the Inflationistas
text: Ben Bernanke delivers a righteous smackdown of the Wall Street Journal editorial page:

headline: Naming a New York Building
text: For as long as developers have been building apartment houses in New York City, they have been giving these buildings names — sometimes a historic reference, sometimes a lofty aspiration and sometimes a developer’s own name.

headline: Shake Off the Winter!
text: TIMES INSIDER — Have April showers succeeded in bringing May flowers? It depends heavily on where you live, but this month we are shaking off the winter doldrums for real. The puzzles for the month of May will get your senses tingling and enjoying the newly warm weather. To wind things up for the month, we will celebrate the most important woman in your life.

headline: Police Fire Tear Gas and Water Cannons at Istanbul Protesters
text: ISTANBUL — Riot police officers used tear gas and water cannons to disperse hundreds of protesters who took to the streets of Istanbul on Friday, defying a government ban on May Day celebrations in Taksim Square.

headline: Stuff We Liked
text: The Upshot has been fascinated with the value of college educations, so we took particular interest in the Brookings Institution’s novel ranking of colleges. It came up with a way to rate a set of two-year and four-year colleges by how much more of a salary you’d expect to get by going to a particular one. Some of the technical ones, as expected, got high marks, but its analysis also cited schools like Carleton College and Washington and Lee University.

headline: Health Insurance Deadline Passes for Most, but There Are Exceptions
text: THE last chance to sign up for health insurance this year under the Affordable Care Act passed on Thursday, when an extended deadline for enrollment expired.

headline: What’s On This Week Around The World
text: Rome

headline: Verbatim: Rubio’s Take on the Food Pyramid
text: — Senator Marco Rubio, when asked Friday if he, like his potential rival for the Republican presidential nomination, Jeb Bush, was also on the Paleo diet.

headline: 3 Ways Nepalis Are Using Crowdsourcing to Aid in Quake Relief
text: In the wake of the 7.8 magnitude earthquake that hit their country over the weekend, many Nepalis at home and abroad have found a new way to help — as digital volunteers, spending hours hunched over their laptops, using crowdsourcing technologies and social platforms to participate in the relief effort.

headline: 6 Baltimore Police Officers Charged in Freddie Gray Death
text: BALTIMORE — Baltimore’s chief prosecutor charged six police officers on Friday with a range of crimes including murder and manslaughter in the arrest and fatal injury of Freddie Gray, a striking and surprisingly swift turn in a case that has drawn national attention to police conduct.

headline: Killing Them Softly, at the Supreme Court
text: Most of the rest of the world has moved on from the death penalty, in some cases long ago. But here in the United States, in the year 2015, in the most august courtroom in the land, nine esteemed jurists sat around for an hour and soberly debated the best way to kill someone quickly, painlessly and — perhaps most important — bloodlessly.

headline: Topical Fiction
text: OYE WHAT I’M GONNA TELL YOU

headline: ‘Academy Street,’ by Mary Costello
text: Named for the street on which its central character, an Irish immigrant, finds her New York home, this debut novel from Mary Costello deepens and magnifies the distinctive style evident in her 2012 collection “The China Factory.” There, the inner worlds of her often isolated protagonists were examined in short, tight sentences that refused to discriminate between the scars of the dramatic and those of the banal.

headline: ‘The Fair Fight,’ by Anna Freeman
text: Writing any novel involves decisions. In historical novels, these decisions can be agonizing, since readers of this genre are particularly unforgiving. Language? Tense? Voice? Such choices made, you’re still left contemplating Henry James’s dispiriting judgment that in historical fiction “the real thing is almost impossible to do, and in its essence the whole effect is as nought.”

headline: ‘The Battle of Versailles,’ by Robin Givhan
text: All fashion is spectacle. The industry looks forward, not back — which can make it difficult to imagine a moment before this one, when celebrity-lined fashion shows are live-streamed, a dress can be preordered by a woman in Dubuque the same week it debuts on the runway, and style bloggers are walking advertisements for young designers. There was a time, however, when the fashion world was more firmly rooted in the tradition of haute couture. The story of that change centers on one spectacular evening in November 1973, as told in Robin Givhan’s “The Battle of Versailles.”

headline: ‘Manchu Princess, Japanese Spy,’ by Phyllis Birnbaum
text: Yoshiko Kawashima was, at first glance, a winning figure. Described by The New York Times in 1933 as “a picturesque film-drama figure, half tomboy, half heroine,” she was often called the “Joan of Arc of the Manchus.” It was the fulfillment of a childhood dream. Riding to school on horseback, Kawashima imagined herself as a new Joan, restoring her people to their rightful glory.

headline: ‘The Thunder of Giants,’ by Joel Fishbane
text: Anna Swan, born in Nova Scotia in 1846, shares Joel Fishbane’s novel with Andorra del Alandra, born a half-century later in the Pyrenees principality for which she is named. Anna was a historical figure, Andorra is entirely fictional. Both women immigrate to America, and both are discovered by talent scouts. Anna becomes a featured act in P. T. Barnum’s American Museum in New York, while ­Andorra heads for Hollywood. Neither woman actually yearns for the stage, but their career choices are limited. Both Anna and Andorra are almost eight feet tall.

headline: Jeffery Deaver’s ‘Solitude Creek,’ and More
text: Starring in a Jeffery Deaver thriller isn’t all it’s cracked up to be. Despite their sterling reputations, his sleuths are in constant danger of being outclassed by their preternaturally cunning adversaries. This is what happens in SOLITUDE CREEK (Grand Central, $28) when Kathryn Dance, an agent with the California Bureau of Investigation, takes on Antioch March, a newfangled killer who likes to scare people into causing their own deaths. “He plays with perceptions, sensations, panic,” Dance discovers, leaving the actual killing to his victims themselves.

headline: Review: ‘The Herd,’ Rory Kinnear’s Drama About Family Friction
text: CHICAGO — The drama of family discord has been such a staple of the American theater that a curtain rising upon a suburban living room almost automatically makes us settle in and wait for the fireworks to start. But the British can squabble and stew, stiff upper lips be damned, quite as well as the rest of us, as is illustrated by “The Herd,” a lively and moving comedy-drama by the British actor Rory Kinnear making its United States premiere at the Steppenwolf Theater here.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE WRONG ENEMY: America in Afghanistan, 2001-2014, by Carlotta Gall. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) Gall, The New York Times’s Afghanistan bureau chief and correspondent between 2001 and 2011, details the missteps that exacerbated the violence there, and highlights Pakistan’s role in sheltering leaders of the Taliban and Al Qaeda. In NO GOOD MEN AMONG THE LIVING: America, the Taliban, and the War Through Afghan Eyes (Picador, $18), Anand Gopal lays bare the war’s murky intricacies through the lives of three Afghans: a Taliban commander, a tribal strongman and a village housewife turned senator.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Miuccia’s Museum Opens
text: The Fondazione Prada opens the doors to its first permanent exhibition space on May 9th.

headline: Waiting on Line for Free Preschool
text: Margaux Laskey works in Cooking at The New York Times, and over the next 24 hours, she and her husband, Scott Garapolo, will take turns waiting in line to register their 3-year-old daughter for a free preschool program in Jersey City Heights.

headline: That Kid Belongs on Broadway
text: Tony Award-nominated actors on the moment they knew they were destined for the stage.

headline: Pension Funds Can Only Guess at Private Equity’s Cost
text: Partnership agreements outlining private equity firms’ practices are as closely guarded as the recipe for Coca-Cola.

headline: The Washington Senators: A Monument to Bad Management
text: In the fall of 1924, the Washington Senators won their first World Series, over the New York Giants. But it would also prove to be their last.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: MY STRUGGLE: Book 4, by Karl Ove Knausgaard. Translated by Don Bartlett. (Archipelago, $27.) This is the fleetest, funniest and — in keeping with its adolescent protagonist — most sophomoric of the volumes translated into English thus far.

headline: Inside the List
text: Marlon and Me: With her Nobel Prize and her graven prose and a leonine profile as stately and imposing as anything on Mount Rushmore, Toni Morrison can come across as frankly a bit intimidating — the woman has authority. Add to that her four-decade career writing brilliant and often despairing novels about the black experience in America, and it’s no wonder interviewers frequently want her to proclaim about race relations or the latest tragedy playing out on the nation’s television screens. Morrison — whose new novel, “God Help the Child,” hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 5 — sometimes obliges them. “People keep saying, ‘We need to have a conversation about race,’ ” she told The Telegraph last month. “This is the conversation. I want to see a cop shoot a white unarmed teenager in the back. And I want to see a white man convicted for raping a black woman. Then when you ask me, ‘Is it over?,’ I will say yes.” (Almost 20 years ago, I heard Morrison read from an early draft of her novel “Paradise,” and when an audience member asked if the gains of the civil rights movement might herald an imminent end to racism, Morrison paused and slowly shook her head. “I am not optimistic,” she said.) But there is a less foreboding, more playful side to Morrison as well: The critic John Leonard once reported that she liked to chat with Fran Lebowitz about Court TV, and she told The Telegraph that Marlon Brando used to call just to recite her work: “I still have his number in my iPhone! How could I erase that?”

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Calories, Gluten and a Fat-Melting Drug
text: Take the Quiz

headline: The Prado and a New Royal Museum Duel Over Paintings
text: MADRID — A royal battle is simmering here.

headline: Daniel Loeb Takes Stake in Yum Brands
text: The billionaire investor Daniel S. Loeb is making a bet that Yum Brands is “turning the page” on its troubles in China.

headline: Antipasto Is the Overture to Breezy Italian-Style Entertaining
text: An Italian meal begins with the antipasto. Meant to awaken the palate and stave off initial hunger pangs, it could just be a simple platter of sliced cured meats and a few olives.

headline: Student Loan Facts They Wish They Had Known
text: The problem with a lot of the advice that teenagers and their families get about higher education debt is that it’s totally, utterly bloodless.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Life of Saul Bellow’
text: This week, Sam Tanenhaus talks about Zachary Leader’s new biography of Saul Bellow; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Emily Bazelon discusses Jon Krakauer’s “Missoula”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Ben E. King, Soulful Singer of ‘Stand by Me,’ Dies at 76
text: Ben E. King, the smooth, soulful baritone who led the Drifters on “There Goes My Baby,” “Save the Last Dance for Me” and other hits in the late 1950s and early 1960s, and as a solo artist recorded the classic singles “Spanish Harlem” and “Stand by Me,” died on Thursday in Hackensack, N.J. He was 76.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Life of Saul Bellow’
text: This week, Sam Tanenhaus and Emily Bazelon.

headline: After the Fair Leaves Town
text: Structures built for global events sometimes live second useful lives — and sometimes not.

headline: Food and Culture Through the Years
text: How food has been portrayed in world’s fair exhibits since 1851.

headline: Ignacio Mattos Shares a Few of His Favorite Things
text: The chef behind Estela discusses influential food, books and art in anticipation of the James Beard Awards this Monday.

headline: For the Mayweather-Pacquiao Winner, a Bevy of Belts
text: LAS VEGAS — By now, even people who do not follow boxing know that two men named Manny Pacquiao and Floyd Mayweather Jr. are due to fight an important match here on Saturday. But does anyone — boxing fans included — know what they are fighting for?

headline: What to Do When a Large Financial Failure Starts With a Bank
text: An important feature of the Dodd-Frank regulatory overhaul is Title II’s orderly liquidation authority. It is this authority that is supposed to put an end to bailouts by providing regulators with a “third way” that avoids either Lehman Brothers’ unplanned bankruptcy or American International Group’s unplanned bailout.

headline: Marilyn Mosby, Prosecutor in Freddie Gray Case, Takes a Stand and Calms a Troubled City
text: BALTIMORE — Shortly before she became the youngest top prosecutor in any major American city, Marilyn J. Mosby, a daughter and granddaughter of police officers, had tough words about how the nation’s criminal justice system had handled mistreatment of black men by the police.

headline: Tear Gas Breaks Up Protests in Istanbul
text: Riot police in Istanbul on Friday fired tear gas and water cannons into crowds of May Day protesters, who had attempted to defy a ban to gather in the city’s Taksim Square.

headline: The Philosophy of Warren E. Buffett
text: Lawrence A. Cunningham, a professor at George Washington University and former corporate lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, has written numerous books including, most recently, “Berkshire Beyond Buffett: The Enduring Value of Values.”

headline: Nonbanks Target Single-Family Rental Investors
text: Financing options for real estate investors have been expanding as nonbank lenders step in to fill what they see as a lucrative void.

headline: Prices for Private Residence Clubs Slow to Recover
text: SEVEN years after prices for private residence clubs and other fractional developments collapsed, the value of a small slice of paradise is still far from recovered.

headline: DuPont’s Battle With Nelson Peltz May Confound Shareholders
text: In the battle over DuPont’s future, it all comes down to point of view.

headline: El Kabeir Scratched From Kentucky Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — El Kabeir, a standout in New York prep races at Aqueduct Racetrack, was scratched from the 141st  Kentucky Derby on Friday afternoon because of an injury to his left front foot.

headline: The Escalation of Boxing Purses
text: The fight between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao on May 2 will be the richest boxing match in history with the purse totaling more than $200 million dollars. A look at the rising paydays for boxers over the years.

headline: A Film Series Celebrates 3-D and Its Glasses
text: Is it in 3-D? Movie audiences ask that question a lot, sometimes in anticipation, sometimes in annoyance. After its increase in popularity in the 1950s, then another surge in the 1980s,  the use of contemporary 3-D picked up again in the early 2000s and seems like it’s here to stay. In the series “3D in the 21st Century,” BAMcinématek is looking at the most recent resurgence, showing films both highbrow (“Pina”) and low (“Jackass 3D”) to demonstrate the many ways the technology enhances storytelling.

headline: Nuclear War? No, Twitter War
text: Whatever the benefits of social media, it does have a way of bringing out the worst in some people, propelling them to engage in snarky and highly personal attacks as a way of gaining attention.

headline: Mixed Verdicts in Second Trial of Aleynikov, Ex-Goldman Sachs Programmer
text: For the second time in five years, prosecutors have prevailed over Sergey Aleynikov, the former Goldman Sachs programmer accused of stealing confidential computer trading code from the bank. The first time it took a federal jury just hours to convict; this time it came after more than a week of deliberation and an accusation of “food poisoning” and avocado tampering in a state court jury room.

headline: Marco Rubio Courts Right on Iran and Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Marco Rubio, who described the possibility of his becoming president as “an increasingly optimistic hypothetical,” spent Friday morning answering questions both immediate and, yes, hypothetical at the National Review’s ideas summit.

headline: Goat Cheese Strata Gets an Update
text: A goat cheese strata may sound like the kind of recipe published in women’s magazines from the 1980s, right next to the article telling you how to rectify your home perm gone wrong. Both of which you’d probably rather forget.

headline: Bitcoin Comes Out of the Shadows and Into Wall Street’s Sights
text: At the end of a panel discussion at the Inside Bitcoins conference in New York this week – billed as the largest such event in the world – a supporter of the cryptocurrency pointed to one of the three lawyers discussing Bitcoin’s struggle for mainstream acceptance.

headline: Exclusive | Nuits Mansion, Irvington, N.Y.
text: An Italianate villa, once home to John Jacob Astor III, is poised to enter the market at $14.75 million.

headline: A Mansion Where an Astor Lived
text: An attention-getter since its appearance in 1853 along the Hudson River, an Italianate villa known as Nuits in the Westchester village of Irvington, once home to John Jacob Astor III, is poised to enter the market with a price tag of $14.75 million, making it one of the highest priced properties in the Rivertowns. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the house has more than 20 rooms and was last listed in 2012 for $11.75 million, but remained in the hands of the present owner, Martin W. Dolan, an investment banker.

headline: In Late Night Appearance, Michelle Obama Dishes on Daughters
text: Michelle Obama dished to David Letterman, the late-night television host, on Thursday about dealing with a sulky teenaged daughter in the White House.

headline: Long-Unheard Harlem Renaissance Opera Coming in June
text: “Voodoo,” a long-unheard opera by the pioneering African-American composer and Harlem Renaissance figure H. Lawrence Freeman, will return this June to New York, where it had its premiere in 1928, for a pair of concert performances that will be recorded.

headline: A Sports Fan’s Guide to a Delicious Saturday
text: A fan’s guide on what to watch and what to eat and drink on the biggest sports Saturday in years.

headline: Just Back From the Miss Dior Exhibition Opening, Kate Young Shares Her Sun-Searching Travels
text: The stylist, whose new eyewear and optical designs for Tura hit stores this month, offers T an exclusive look at her recent trips to Puerto Rico, Upstate New York and Beijing, China.

headline: David Wildstein’s Plea Agreement in Bridge Lane-Closing Scandal
text: The former Port Authority official and a high-school friend of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey pleaded guilty at the United States District Court in Newark to conspiracy to commit fraud and “conspiracy against civil rights.”

headline: A Ringside Seat
text: It’s easy now. Well, relatively easy. Not the writing, but getting your copy to your newspaper’s office. If you’re a sports reporter at ringside for a big fight, like the Floyd Mayweather Jr.-Manny Pacquiao extravaganza on Saturday night, you set up your laptop, type your words into the keyboard, move your mouse on the screen, click-click, hit “send,” and moments later, your article appears on a screen in your office. What a wonderful world.

headline: Indictment Against Baroni and Kelly in George Washington Bridge Scandal
text: Bill Baroni, the former deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and Bridget Anne Kelly, a former deputy chief of staff to Gov. Chris Christie, were charged with multiple counts of conspiracy.

headline: Guggenheim Closes for the Afternoon as Workers’ Advocates Escalate Protests
text: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum closed to the public on Friday afternoon after a few dozen protesters descended on the museum and unfurled a red banner that read “Meet Workers’ Demands Now” in the crowded lobby.

headline: Summer 2015 Movie Releases: A Look at What’s Coming
text: A listing of films releasing this summer.

headline: Homicide Charges in Gray Case Announced
text: Marilyn J. Mosby, the state’s attorney for Baltimore, said that Freddie Gray’s arrest was illegal and that there was probable cause to file manslaughter charges against the police officers involved.

headline: Watch the Trailers: 14 Movies Coming This Summer
text: A quick guide to standouts of the summer movie season.

headline: Bulls, Healthy for a Change, Face a Diminished Cavaliers Team
text: The Chicago Bulls of recent years have risen or fallen with Derrick Rose. A seeming championship trajectory earlier in this decade went wrong primarily because of his injuries. Now he is healthy again, and the Bulls have advanced to the N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference semifinals to face the Cleveland Cavaliers, who have a serious injury issue of their own.

headline: Midtown Condo With Views for $30.68 Million
text: A sprawling aerie on the 53rd floor of One57, the sky-piercing condominium that has attracted demigods of international business and finance, sold to a mystery buyer, one seemingly versed in the teachings of a much higher power, for $30,683,372.50 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Ignacio Mattos Shares a Few of His Favorite Things
text: In the originality of his cooking, Ignacio Mattos manages to be both a chef’s chef — as evidenced by the precise technical execution required for many of his best dishes — and a populist who delivers bold yet comforting flavors. Mattos’s biography doesn’t do justice to the playfulness, inventiveness, technical skill and earthy appeal of his food, but does provide a little context: He was born and began his career in Uruguay, moved to San Francisco to work at legendary restaurants (and de facto cooking academies) Chez Panisse and Zuni Café, and then relocated to New York to establish himself at Il Buco.

headline: Indictment of David Wildstein
text: The former Port Authority official and a high school friend of Gov. Chris Christie was indicted on two conspiracy counts. He pleaded guilty.

headline: Chuck Close and Cindy Sherman Donate Works for Met Opera Benefit
text: It is a little like a bake sale, but one that offers works by famous artists instead of snickerdoodles. The Metropolitan Opera, which has been struggling financially in recent years, announced Friday that 14 major visual artists — including Chuck Close, William Kentridge and Cindy Sherman — have donated artworks for the company to sell to raise money.

headline: Andreessen Horowitz, Deal Maker to the Stars of Silicon Valley
text: Since its founding in 2009, Andreessen Horowitz has become a top Silicon Valley venture capital firm by adhering to a simple mantra: It’s all about the talent.

headline: New Oil Train Rules Are Hit From All Sides
text: Ending months of uncertainty and delays, federal regulators on Friday unveiled new rules for transporting crude oil by trains, saying the measures would improve rail safety and reduce the risks of a catastrophic event.

headline: The Enduring Hunt for Personal Value
text: Why does Michael Phelps keep returning to a brutal training regimen in the pool, long after he’s achieved every imaginable accolade as a swimmer? Why do men who have earned hundreds of millions of dollars, even billions, work relentlessly to earn even more, long after it could possibly make any material difference in their lives? Why does a substantial group of politicians with no remote chance of being elected president feel compelled to traverse the country campaigning 18 hours a day for more than two years?

headline: What I Love | Sandra Brown
text: The author of ‘Lethal’ and ‘Mean Streak’ unwinds in a soothing space on the Upper West Side.

headline: For Sandra Brown, Suspense Writer, an Island of Calm
text: Sandra Brown wasn’t thrilled with the white protea, but there it was, part of a standing order of floral arrangements that fill her Upper West Side pied-à-terre whenever she and her husband, Michael, come north from their Texas home. You’ll find flowers in every room there, as well.

headline: Sorry, Etsy. That Handmade Scarf Won’t Save the World.
text: IN her memoir, “Loretta Lynn: Coal Miner’s Daughter,” Ms. Lynn remembers the thrill of receiving her first “store-boughten” dress from a social services agent when she was around 7. It was blue with pink flowers and “dainty little pockets.”

headline: Mark Ronson’s Hit ‘Uptown Funk’ Adds Five Writers
text: Mark Ronson’s song “Uptown Funk” has been the biggest pop hit of the year, logging 14 weeks at No. 1 with a sound that evokes 1970s and ’80s acts like the Time and Cameo.

headline: The End of California?
text: ANGELS CAMP, Calif. — IN a normal year, no one in California looks twice at a neighbor’s lawn, that mane of bluegrass thriving in a sun-blasted desert. Or casts a scornful gaze at a fresh-planted almond grove, saplings that now stand accused of future water crimes. Or wonders why your car is conspicuously clean, or whether a fish deserves to live when a cherry tree will die.

headline: Review: A New-Music Concert by the Orchestra of the S.E.M. Ensemble
text: “Reductio ad absurdum!” Thomas Buckner pronounced, in stentorian voice, at one point in “AACM50,” a momentous new-music concert on Wednesday night at the Bohemian National Hall. It was just one of many lines of text, most of them sung, in the premiere of “Kingmaker,” by Roscoe Mitchell. But the phrase — best known as a rhetorical device — bore sly implications for the piece, composed for baritone (Mr. Buckner), saxophone (Mr. Mitchell), orchestra and choir.

headline: Nepal’s Helter-Skelter Urbanization and Lax Enforcement Contribute to Quake’s Toll
text: Many structures that collapsed in Katmandu were part of a reckless building boom in recent decades, aided by government indifference and corruption.

headline: More Excuses on the Patriot Act
text: Software designers have a term — “minimal viable product” — to describe early versions of things like iPhone apps that they can rush to market. The idea is to get something out and refine it as they go along. That’s the argument being made for a measure in Congress that would modify the Patriot Act to make it somewhat harder for the government to conduct mass surveillance of Americans without regard to whether they committed any misdeeds.

headline: At Long Last, a Kentucky Derby Only About the Horses
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — This is an altogether different Kentucky Derby. It hasn’t been hijacked by bombastic owners. There has been no need to manufacture story lines. No, for the first time since I have been coming here, the horses are the genuine stars and there is a sense that the 141st running of America’s signature race is going to be one for the ages.

headline: The Distinct Californication of Paris Photo L.A.
text: This weekend, the third edition of the art fair is expected to attract 20,000 people to the Paramount Pictures Studios in Hollywood.

headline: Readers Respond On Unrest in Baltimore
text: Readers responded with compassion and anguish, but also a strong thread of criticism, to two op-ed articles following the death in police custody of 25-year-old Freddie Gray, and subsequent protests in Baltimore.

headline: The Fall of the Cherry King
text: On his desk, Arthur Mondella kept jars of the glossy-red fruits, Dell’s Maraschino Cherries, that seemed to make everything else possible: the yacht, the Porsche and the Rolls-Royce, the Rolexes, his daughters’ tuitions, the loans — often forgiven — to the workers he’d given second, third and fourth chances. On the wall, he had mounted a large television to keep watch over the business he had helped build since childhood.

headline: UKIP Has Changed Britain’s Conversation. Now It Needs a Big Win.
text: RAMSGATE, England — As word spread that Nigel Farage was on his way for a stroll through this faded seaside town, tensions began to flare.

headline: The Inevitable Spectacle of Mayweather vs. Pacquiao
text: Every once in a while, in these latter days since boxing receded from the cultural center, a fight temporarily reverses that history by catching the attention of the general public and becoming, as the TV announcers say, “bigger than boxing.” Then it’s not just that two boxers are going to fight. It’s more like two celebrities are going to fight — Drake vs. Lionel Messi, say, or Angelina Jolie vs. Angela Merkel — and we’re in luck because the celebrities in question happen to be atavistically good with their hands. Intimate familiarity with the craft of fist fighting has declined steeply in America and other rich countries since the mid-20th century, but what the spectacle of boxing has lost in daily resonance it has partly gained back in the form of esoteric old-school cachet.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Avengers: Age of Ultron,’ ‘Iris’ and ‘Welcome to Me’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Avengers: Age of Ultron,” “Iris” and “Welcome to Me.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Welcome to Me’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Welcome to Me.”

headline: Just Back From the Miss Dior Exhibition Opening, Kate Young Shares Her Sun-Searching Travels
text: While most New Yorkers have been lamenting the lack of sunshine, the stylist Kate Young has been chasing it around the world. She and her husband, Keith Abrahamsson, co-founder of the Greenpoint record label Mexican Summer, left their Brooklyn home to celebrate her birthday and their 10-year wedding anniversary in Puerto Rico. “It was heaven,” Young recalls. “Easy to get there, amazing food, good surfing and beautiful rooms.” They also spent some time at their house upstate in Ruby, N.Y., when “the weather finally felt like spring. Our friends Kyle Creane and Gaines Peyton came for the weekend with their kids. We pretended we were camping and cooked over the bonfire and lazed around in hammocks.” And then, for the Miss Dior exhibition that opened yesterday at the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art, Young flew to Beijing with her friend Natalie Portman, the face of Miss Dior. “We went to Shanghai last year — it’s really interesting to see the differences and similarities between the two cities,” Young says. “The Forbidden City is epic, and there are really beautiful parks. The pollution is mind-blowing, though, and I’ve been wearing that mask almost constantly.” She’s also been almost constantly wearing a pair of sunglasses from her spring/summer 2015 collection for Tura, which will be available later this month at shopbop.com ($250 – $350). In the above slide show, she shares exclusively with T a diary of her recent travels.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Iris’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Iris.”

headline: U.S. Auto Sales Jumped in April, Again Led by S.U.V.s and Pickups
text: Auto manufacturers nearly across the board reported strong April sales gains in the United States, powered by the continued rise in sales of pickup trucks and crossover sport utility vehicles.

headline: UKIP Leader’s Candidacy Divides a Town
text: Nigel Farage, the leader of the U.K. Independence Party, visited Ramsgate, England, last week during his campaign for a seat in Parliament. He faces both strong support and opposition there.

headline: Review: ‘Avengers: Age of Ultron’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Avengers: Age of Ultron.”

headline: A Game 7: Spurs-Clippers Series Deserves Nothing Less
text: SAN ANTONIO — Doc Rivers had two large problems. Seconds into the fourth quarter at AT&T Center on Thursday night, Glen Davis of the Los Angeles Clippers sprained his left ankle and hopped several times on one leg in apparent agony before tumbling like an industrial-size sack of potatoes.

headline: New Albums By Zac Brown Band and Tyler Farr
text: Joe Coscarelli and Jon Caramanica discuss records from country dissenters and what, if anything, country’s borders mean anymore.

headline: Cleveland Indians Have Home-Field Advantage on Recycling
text: CLEVELAND — Well before the start of a Cleveland Indians game at Progressive Field, as players warmed up on the jewel-green field, it was business as usual in the garage behind left field for C. L. Gholston, a dishwasher.

headline: Marco Rubio Makes Generational Case for His Presidential Bid
text: WASHINGTON — One of the most devastating lines of Senator Marco Rubio’s presidential kickoff was an implicit rebuke of two of his potential rivals: Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Democratic candidate for president, and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Life of Saul Bellow’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Sam Tanenhaus reviews Zachary Leader’s “The Life of Saul Bellow: To Fame and Fortune, 1915-1964.” Mr. Tanenhaus writes:

headline: What an Android Update May Get You
text: Q. My old Nexus 7 tablet has a message saying I can update to Android 5.1. Will this fix the problems with sluggishness I’ve been having with Android 5.0?

headline: Austerity and British Inflation
text: Tony Yates responds to Simon Wren-Lewis with a sort-of kind-of defense of the turn to austerity in 2010; I want to weigh in briefly, then turn to a point he reminds me of.

headline: Popcast: New Albums By Zac Brown Band and Tyler Farr
text: It’s beginning to seem like the dissenters have squarely conquered the center of mainstream country. Artists who seemed outré and boundary-pushing a few years ago – Luke Bryan, Jason Aldean, Florida Georgia Line, and so on – are now the genre’s biggest stars, much to the chagrin of an earlier generation that still refuses to mix hip-hop into its country.

headline: Style on the Gold Carpet
text: Some of the best looks from the first day of the N.F.L. draft Thursday night in Chicago.

headline: At the N.F.L. Draft, Fashion Takes the Field
text: If Emily Blunt’s harried assistant in “The Devil Wears Prada” perfectly embodied fashion’s standard approach to looking one’s best when she bragged about being just a stomach flu away from her goal weight, D. J. Humphries proves football has the opposite problem.

headline: Jets Fans at N.F.L. Draft Find Less to Boo About in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — The Jets’ checkered history with first-round draft picks is no secret. Neither is their fans’ frustration, which usually manifests in a flurry of boos inside the draft hall each spring.

headline: An Artisan Marketplace Celebrating the Spirit and Style of Topanga Canyon
text: Tucked deep in Topanga Canyon, Calif., high above a frog-filled creek, sits the small cabin the photographer Heather Culp calls home. Since moving to the neighborhood from Taos, N.M., almost two years ago, Culp has fully embraced the ethos long associated with Topanga’s stretch of winding highway. Hers is a warm, relaxed, salt-of-the-earth spirit that calls to mind small-town hospitality — a vibe that’s very much at the core of her current work alongside artist and fellow Topanga dweller Carly Jo Morgan. This weekend, the two L.A. natives and New York expats roll out the second installment of their Mercado Sagrado, a market, music festival and experience-based art gathering taking place in the SoCal hills.

headline: Nepal’s Fast Urbanization and Lax Enforcement Add to Quake’s Toll
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Bikash Suwal, a lithe, tanned Nepali trekking guide, has climbed the 18,805-foot Yala Peak in the towering Himalayas. But since a powerful earthquake rocked Nepal a week ago, he has been afraid to climb the stairs to the rented rooms he shares with five family members.

headline: President Obama on Freddie Gray Charges
text: The president commented on the filing of homicide, manslaughter and misconduct charges against police officers in the death of Mr. Gray.

headline: ‘It Don’t GTMO Better Than This’
text: Debi Cornwall took home a collection of bizarre souvenirs from her time photographing Guantánamo Bay.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Long Beach, N.Y., and Hopewell, N.J.

headline: Enchiladas, Tostadas and Tacos
text: Lightness is not an attribute usually associated with enchiladas, the most comforting of Mexican tortilla foods, writes Martha Rose Shulman. But these enchiladas, filled with a mix of blanched seasoned chard and succulent diced chayote squash and covered with a classic cooked tomatillo salsa, are both light and incredibly satisfying.

headline: Naomi Campbell on Screen, John Mayer’s Watch Watch and Bianca Jagger’s Legendary Entrance
text: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: U.S. Ambassador to Turkey Says, ‘We’re All Blonde’
text: ISTANBUL — The United States ambassador to Turkey “went blond” this week in a post on Instagram that poked fun at the mayor of Ankara, Turkey’s capital, who had made sexist remarks about an American government spokeswoman on Twitter, calling her a “stupid blonde.”

headline: Who Is Tesla’s Home Battery For?
text: Late Thursday, Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, said the company will starting selling the batteries that are used in its luxury cars for use in homes and businesses. The home versions of the batteries, called Powerwall, will cost $3,000 for a 7 kilowatt-hour model and $3,500 for a 10 kilowatt-hour model. The company will sell larger batteries to businesses and utilities, which could use them to store power from solar panels, windmills and other sources during off-peak hours to use during peak hours. (Tesla says its prices do not include the cost of an inverter and installation.)

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties include co-ops in Carnegie Hill and on the Upper West Side, and a townhouse in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

headline: A Funeral, Protests, Riots and Rebuilding: Chronicling Unrest in Baltimore
text: Twenty-three years ago this week, as a young reporter for The Los Angeles Times, I covered the riots that devastated Los Angeles after a jury acquitted four police officers in the beating of Rodney King. After spending much of the last 10 days in Baltimore, I can’t help wondering: Has nothing changed?

headline: Bernie Sanders Has a Better Fund-Raising Start Than Republican Counterparts
text: The three Republican senators who are running for president — Ted Cruz, Rand Paul and Marco Rubio — all boasted about raising $1 million in their first 24 hours as candidates. But they have nothing on Bernie Sanders.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: At These Weddings, Forget the Rice, Bring Sneakers
text: At 7 a.m. one day last August, Paul Donnelly, Laura Oliver and 40 others ran a five-kilometer race. Later, they attended an awards ceremony and drank Gatorade. Then they showered, changed into dressy attire and went on to the day’s main event: the wedding of Mr. Donnelly and Ms. Oliver.

headline: The Blue Boy
text: T contributing editor David Netto visits “The Blue Boy,” Thomas Gainsborough’s iconic 18th-century masterpiece, at the Huntington Art Gallery in San Marino, Calif.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: Six Officers Charged in Baltimore
text: The suspended police officers were charged in the death of Freddie Gray.

headline: Munich Museum Is Another Step in Acknowledging the City’s Nazi Past
text: MUNICH — The Nazis first displayed their overt hunger for power in lock-step parades through Munich’s elegant Königsplatz. Today, against the backdrop of imposing neo-Classical buildings, the striking white form of the city’s new Documentation Center for the History of National Socialism appears oddly misplaced. It is too simple, too clean.

headline: The Search for New York Philharmonic’s Next Maestro
text: Early in 2001, during the final phase of the New York Philharmonic’s hapless, embarrassingly leaky three-year search to find a successor to Kurt Masur as music director, the players of the orchestra were granted unusual input into the deliberations. The discussions led to the appointment of Lorin Maazel, then 70, a last-minute candidate. In retrospect, there may have been drawbacks to giving the players so much say.

headline: Big Day in Sports
text: It is simply the biggest sports Saturday in years.

headline: ‘La Sylphide’ Is Taking Flight at New York City Ballet
text: “Yesssss!” Peter Martins yelled with relish, as he pulled a scarf out of a caldron and brandished it overhead. “Wipe the floor with him!” Mr. Martins was enthusiastically demonstrating a moment in his new production of “La Sylphide,” when the witch Madge gives a poisoned scarf to the hero James. Two dancers, watching nearby, laughed. “He is so enjoying this,” one said to the other.

headline: The Distinct Californication of Paris Photo L.A.
text: With nearly 200 art fairs on the international cultural calendar, it’s no surprise that art-world denizens have a case of fair fatigue. Paris Photo L.A., however, seems to have the cure for what ails them. Expecting 20,000 people for its third year at Paramount Pictures Studios in Hollywood this weekend, it is an art fair that feels like entertainment, with a location that strikes the magic balance between convention center and amusement park.

headline: Pictures of the Day: United States and Elsewhere
text: United States and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Eve Risser, Van Hunt, Casey J and William Basinski Exceed Boundaries
text: Eve Risser

headline: May 1, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from the United States, South Korea, Yemen and Burundi.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: With Bridge Case Charges, a Cloud Descends on Christie’s White House Hopes
text: In an era of maddeningly careful politics, Gov. Chris Christie rocketed to national stardom as brazenly incautious. His excesses defined him: the scorching rants, the seductive oversharing, the caustic insults and endless public feuds.

headline: Chase Website Issue Said to Be Caused by Heavy Customer Use
text: Customers of JPMorgan Chase’s consumer bank were unable to log into their accounts online for several hours on Friday.

headline: Strait of Hormuz Once Again at Center of U.S.-Iran Strife
text: The Strait of Hormuz, the slender waterway that connects the Persian Gulf to the rest of the world and is a critical conduit in the global oil supply chain, has again become a point of contention for Iran and the United States — just as they are trying to reach a nuclear accord.

headline: Southern California’s Best-Kept Art Secret
text: Thomas Gainsborough’s 18th-century painting “The Blue Boy” is an iconic example of Grand Manner portraiture, and is considered an epitome of the form — instantly recognizable, it has been referenced in films from “Ghostbusters II” to “Django Unchained.” Perhaps surprisingly, given its stature as an English masterpiece, “The Blue Boy” — along with its sister painting, Thomas Lawrence’s “Pinkie” — resides in the Huntington Art Gallery in San Marino, Calif., home to the largest collection of British full-length Grand Manner portraiture in the world. When “The Blue Boy” was bought by Henry Huntington for over $700,000 in 1921, it was the most expensive painting ever sold — and its move to California sparked plenty of controversy. In the above video, the Huntington’s chief curator of European art, Catherine Hess, takes T contributing editor David Netto on a private visit to “The Blue Boy” and discusses its unique legacy.

headline: American Dream? Or Mirage?
text: ECONOMIC inequality in the United States is at its highest level since the 1930s, yet most Americans remain relatively unconcerned with the issue. Why?

headline: Rand Paul Says Comment About Baltimore Was Misinterpreted
text: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky drew widespread criticism this week for sounding indifferent and flip when he said that he was glad his train had not stopped in Baltimore as the city was erupting in racially fueled chaos.

headline: Kindred Spirits, Five Years in the Making
text: When Stephanie Cate walked into Winston Bao Lord’s Georgetown home for a party five years ago, he had already been named to a People magazine list of the country’s up-and-coming men that included the actor Bradley Cooper. And Mr. Lord had been selected by The Washingtonian as one of the capital’s most stylish men.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Loretta E. Lynch is finally sworn in, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan visits Washington and another senator enters the presidential race.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Loretta E. Lynch is finally sworn in, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan visits Washington and another senator enters the presidential race.

headline: The Rise of Emoji on Instagram Is Causing Language Repercussions
text: At 30, I am still considered a millennial. Yet unlike many in my age group, for years I was stubborn about one very popular, unimportant activity: I disliked using emoji in my text messages.

headline: Souvenirs From the Guantánamo Bay Gift Shops
text: Near the end of a recent visit to the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base, the photographer Debi Cornwall noticed some curious souvenirs in a gift shop. She bought them, took them home and photographed them. This project was considerably simpler than her previous one — which appeared on The Times’s Lens blog last year — documenting the base’s recreational spaces, which involved abiding by a 12-page list of things she couldn’t photograph and submitting her memory cards to the scrutiny of military escorts. She even developed her film negatives under their watch.

headline: Andre Kertesz, Watching From Above
text: From his window perch, Mr. Kertesz captured candid moments where his subjects were unaware the master photographer was watching them.

headline: New Zealand’s Contribution to the Venice Biennale: A Library and an Airport, Transposed
text: “I like that it’s hard to see — you have to show your passport to even get to the installation,” says the artist Simon Denny of his pavilion representing New Zealand at this year’s Venice Biennale. “I think that adds another layer to the clandestine world of contemporary intelligence.” Denny is not referring to the intellectual world of contemporary art, but rather to intelligence with a capital I — the big data harvested by the N.S.A. and its international equivalents, which Denny’s new work addresses.

headline: A Final Column
text: It is tough to write one’s final column. But I must pay particular tribute to Alan Truscott. We first met in 1971, when I was 19. Ceri Evans and I won a junior event in London for which the prize was a trip to New York to play in the Fun City Regional. Alan organized our tour, including arranging for us to be invited to a Long Island country club where all the local bridge experts were given the run of the club, then, after a huge buffet dinner, we played in a duplicate with a club member. (Evans and I finished second and third, causing a small stir.)

headline: A.I.G. Considers How to Act With Sifi Tag
text: If there is a path leading out of the realm of “systemically important financial institutions,” the American International Group may already be on it, the insurer’s chief executive told securities analysts on Friday.

headline: Oh, Those Clever Librarians and Their #Bookface
text: How complicated can it be to take a photograph of a book cover for the purpose of posting it on Instagram? Fairly complicated, particularly for those trying to create an image in what has become known as “bookface” style.

headline: The End of Gaydar
text: In the wrong context, being asked if you’re gay is like pulling back the shower curtain in the morning and finding a census taker scribbling frantically on his clipboard. You think: Why now? Why so close to my loofah?

headline: Breakthrough Performances of the Summer Movies Season
text: ‘The Diary of a Teenage Girl’

headline: Times Journalist Ellen Barry Answers Readers’ Questions on Nepal
text: Almost a week after an earthquake struck Nepal, killing more than 6,250 people and devastating villages, a rescue operation continues, and tens of thousands of people remain displaced in Katmandu alone. Ellen Barry, the South Asia bureau chief for The New York Times, recently spent five days reporting on the damage and loss of life there. She answered readers’ questions on Friday during a Facebook Q. and A. on the situation on the ground and how people can help.

headline: Review: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Returns for Season 2
text: Few actresses are more fun to watch than Eva Green when she’s in her warrior-princess mode, and Showtime’s “Penny Dreadful” takes full advantage of this fact. Playing an intrepid Victorian monster hunter who communes with the dead and is, inconveniently, semi-possessed by a nasty Egyptian goddess, Ms. Green throws her huge eyes open wide and writhes, jerks and gibbers with spine-tingling grace and gravity. If there were a factor that measured the convergence of sexy, scary, silly and self-aware on television, her performance would top the chart.
