headline: How Loaded Is the Word ‘Thug’? Readers React
text: Lela Moore is a news assistant and comment moderator.

headline: Ally of Christie Pleads Guilty
text: The U.S. attorney for New Jersey announced the guilty plea of David Wildstein for conspiring to cause traffic jams around the George Washington Bridge. He also announced the indictment of two others.

headline: ‘I, Too, Am America’ Shares Snapshots From Workers Living on the Edge
text: “You are not dressed if you don’t have your smile on” commands the sign in a Popeyes fried chicken restaurant in Kansas City, Mo. In front of it, a man in an apron, half-smiling, stands over the fryer with a basket of chicken in his tattooed hand.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Review: ‘Trisha Brown: In Plain Site,’ on Spring Street
text: Trisha Brown, one of the founding figures of postmodern dance in the 1960s, choreographed her last work in 2011. Since then, the dance company that bears her name has found ways to keep her work before the public. In its latest project — “Trisha Brown: In Plain Site” — the troupe selects items from her multidecade repertory for specific locations; each of these events will be named for its setting.

headline: Amid Katmandu’s Earthquake Wreckage, Hints of a Shift to Safer Construction
text: In the world’s crowded earthquake zones, from the Himalayas to the Pacific Northwest, every community faces enormous challenges in designing for inevitable, but unpredictable jolts.

headline: Los Angeles and Its Booming Creative Class Lures New Yorkers
text: It started with Instagram. Or maybe it ended with Instagram. Last fall, Christina Turner, a fashion stylist in Brooklyn, was dreading another New York winter in her cramped, lightless Greenpoint, Brooklyn, apartment while gazing longingly at the succulent gardens and festive backyard dinner parties posted on social media by her friends in Los Angeles.

headline: Foreign Diplomats Try to Track Down the Missing in Nepal
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — The thousands of foreigners who were in Nepal when the earthquake struck have mostly been found, but hollow-eyed diplomats here still clutch lengthy lists of the names of those who remain unaccounted for.

headline: It’s Me or the Dog
text: The night my girlfriend discovered she wouldn’t be my only bedfellow, she was baffled. “Where I come from, you only sleep with a dog in your bed if you’re single, or your central heating is broken,” she said upon finding Whisky, my 15-pound terrier-spaniel mix, settled in comfortably for the night, her head resting daintily on my pillow.

headline: Review: City Ballet’s New Gods and Duos
text: Adrian Danchig-Waring, who made his debut as Apollo on Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater, didn’t need to be told he had big slippers to fill. The two Apollos of recent seasons at New York City Ballet have been superlative: In Robert Fairchild, there is a raw, athletic exuberance and in Chase Finlay, a cool, unassailable polish. With both unavailable — Mr. Fairchild is performing on Broadway in “An American in Paris,” and Mr. Finlay is recovering from an injury — two new dancers are getting a shot at the lead in George Balanchine’s “Apollo,” the oldest work in the company’s repertory. (On Tuesday, Zachary Catazaro takes over.)

headline: Women Turn Tables on Online Harassers
text: About 24 hours after joining Tinder, Ashley Brincefield, 31, a management specialist for customs in Port Tobacco, Md., began getting creepy messages. Married men propositioned her for sex. Guys lashed out if they didn’t get a reply in a timely fashion. Various men sent naked selfies.

headline: Making Room (on the Web) for Daddy
text: A few years ago, when Avi Moskowitz wanted advice about which highchair, stroller and car seat to buy for his first child, he didn’t turn to Consumer Reports or let his wife handle the research. He posted on Daddit, a part of the social networking site Reddit that was formed in 2011 to meet the growing demand of fathers seeking their own cozy corner of the web.

headline: Why We’re Honoring Charlie Hebdo
text: AN organization that champions dissidents must embrace dissent in its ranks. Over the last week, PEN American Center has been criticized by many writers, including some of our members, over our decision to present our PEN/Toni and James C. Goodale Free Expression Courage Award to Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical magazine that was the target of a murderous attack in January. The heated debate proves the relevance of groups devoted to freedom of expression. It also demonstrates that in an open society, well-intentioned people with shared values can interpret and weigh principles differently.

headline: There’s No Easy Way to Get Inside Alicia Vikander’s Head
text: With her dainty features eerily detached from her silicone skull, Alicia Vikander, as Ava, the alluring fembot in the sci-fi fantasy “Ex Machina,” is a wonder of radical engineering. So it may have been apt, if not downright predictable, that during her stay in New York last week she would visit an exhibition of experimental design at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Women in Military Cite Retaliation After Assault Complaints
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly two-thirds of women in the military who filed sexual assault complaints last year said they faced retaliation, according to a Pentagon report released on Friday.

headline: The Psychologists and the Torturers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vows | Song and Support
text: Dr. Linda Marie Daniels and Dr. Lisa Lynn Paine initially bonded while trying to impersonate James Brown and Luciano Pavarotti, and that bond has strengthened over an appreciation for serving others.

headline: Hundreds Protest in Manhattan Against Police Brutality and Income Inequality
text: Protesters marched in the streets of New York City on Friday night to bring attention to police brutality and income inequality, two days after dozens of demonstrators were arrested.

headline: A Shared Act and a Common Purpose
text: One evening in January 2010, Lisa Lynn Paine believed she had found the perfect person to be the James Brown to her Luciano Pavarotti.

headline: Laszlo Jakab Orsos, Cultural Curator, and His Sunday Routine
text: You know that tender melancholy that seeps unbidden into the last hours of the weekend? Yes, you do. Laszlo Jakab Orsos, director of the PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature, was trying to put his finger on it the other day. “There is this unspoken sense that behind the walls everyone is preparing for the ordeal of the next week,” he said, from his apartment in Brooklyn Heights. “You feel that anxiety somehow. Best-case scenario is when you’re home with a nice red wine, listening to music, and then a friend calls and you talk about life.” The festival comes to New York May 4 through 10, and Mr. Orsos, who is either 50 or 51 (“that’s a larger philosophical question,” he said), will be responsible for herding more than 100 writers and artists from around the world. After which a little swoony melancholy and red wine might not seem so bad.

headline: Clinton Loyalist Joins Priorities ‘Super PAC’
text: A longtime leading operative for Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton will join Priorities USA Action, the dominant “super PAC” that will seek big-ticket donations to finance what is expected to be the long and expensive presidential campaign of Mrs. Clinton.

headline: 30th Street Guitars, a Shop of Good Vibrations
text: To the uninitiated, the anonymous blocks surrounding Pennsylvania Station might seem an odd place for a quirky music shop like 30th Street Guitars.

headline: Guitars Galore
text: When Matt Brewster opened 30th Street Guitars in Midtown Manhattan, he envisioned a friendly, low-key sales and repair shop without snobbery and pretense.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Fashion and Art
text: The fashion world could use the energy displayed during the 10-day preview of the new Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: Fashion and Art at the New Whitney Museum
text: The fashion world could use the energy displayed during the 10-day preview of the new Whitney Museum of American Art on the West Side below 14th Street. Many guests exhibited an uncorraled style of dress. The building, with its vistas and terraces overlooking the city, is a revelation.

headline: A Psychiatric Center’s Art Gallery
text: Two good reasons to visit Queens Village are the Living Museum, featuring work mostly by the Creedmoor hospital’s outpatients, and Rajdhani, an Indian restaurant.

headline: Evening Hours | Benefits and a Memorial
text: Remembering John B. Fairchild, a fashion pioneer.

headline: The Living Museum, on the Creedmoor Campus in Queens, Puts Patients’ Work on Display
text: The rambling campus of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, where Lou Reed was treated and Woody Guthrie died, is home to an unbridled collection of contemporary art, though finding it among the nearly century-old buildings takes some mettle. Once you enter the gates at 80-45 Winchester Boulevard, ask someone to direct you to a faded-brick edifice framed by beribboned trees and ghostly white sculptures.

headline: Mexican Helicopter Shot Down, Killing 3 Soldiers
text: MEXICO CITY — A Mexican military helicopter was shot down Friday in southwestern Mexico, killing three soldiers and wounding several others during an outbreak of violence in the region that left banks and gas stations ablaze and residents hunkering indoors, military and regional officials said.

headline: Parting for Women’s World Cup, but Hopefully Not for Good
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — This is an exciting year for women’s soccer, especially in the United States. While everyone awaits the Women’s World Cup in Canada this summer, it is also Year 3 of the National Women’s Soccer League.

headline: Tidal, Music Streaming Service, Seeks Footing After a Stumble
text: As a celebrity-studded, headline-grabbing product release, Jay Z’s unveiling of Tidal was about as big as could be.

headline: Giants Move Up in N.F.L. Draft to Take Alabama Safety Landon Collins
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A prized football recruit in high school and an all-American safety at Alabama, Landon Collins always dreamed of being a first-round selection in the N.F.L. draft. Collins attended the N.F.L.’s nationally broadcast first-round extravaganza on Thursday, eager to leap on the stage when his name was called.

headline: Silent Seashores
text: GLOUCESTER, Mass. — AS the spring days lengthen, shorebirds have begun their hemispheric migrations from South America to nesting grounds in Canada’s northern spruce and pine forests and the icy Arctic.

headline: Dean Skelos, New York Senate Leader, and His Son Are Said to Face Arrest Next Week
text: Dean G. Skelos, the leader of the New York State Senate, and his son are expected to be arrested on federal corruption charges next week, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Responding to Suffering by Counting the Omer
text: PHILADELPHIA — One morning last week, Lance Laver went to visit a dying friend. Mr. Laver is Jewish and his friend is a retired Episcopal priest, and they had formed a bond over nearly a decade of working together here on an annual interfaith walk for peace.

headline: A Secret Warrior Leaves the Pentagon as Quietly as He Entered
text: WASHINGTON — ASKED what he is looking forward to, Michael G. Vickers, who retired this week as under secretary of defense for intelligence, answered without hesitation: “Sleeping.”

headline: Enlisting Bystanders to Fight Online Abuse
text: Harassment remains a big problem on social networks; according to a Pew survey, 40 percent of Internet users have experienced it in some form.

headline: A New Jet Once Wished He Were Smaller. Now Opponents Do.
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — One of the seminal moments of Leonard Williams’s life occurred when he was 13.

headline: U.S. Liable in New Orleans-Area Flooding
text: The federal government must pay for some of the flooding damage from Hurricane Katrina caused by failures of the hurricane protection system in the New Orleans area, a judge ruled Friday.

headline: Russia Assails West Over Yemen
text: In an outburst of diplomatic finger-pointing, Russia on Friday blamed the West for blocking a Security Council statement that sought “humanitarian pauses” in the Saudi-led airstrikes on Yemen to allow the delivery of food, fuel and medicine. Emerging from an emergency session of the Council, the Russian ambassador, Vitaly I. Churkin, said Yemen was running out of food and medicine and sharply suggested that the United States, which supports the bombings, is responsible for their humanitarian consequences. Russia had proposed a statement that would be unenforceable, and not legally binding. “If you can’t agree to a motherhood and apple pie statement, what can you agree on?” he said. The criticism was in sharp contrast to Russia’s response to efforts by Western countries over the last couple of years to force the Syrian government, which Russia supports, to allow aid convoys into rebel-held areas. In a statement, an American official said Washington supported the idea of a humanitarian pause and was working with its Saudi allies to facilitate the delivery of aid.

headline: Baltimore’s Mood Shifts From Grim to Elated After Charges Are Announced
text: BALTIMORE — The crowd of African-American residents and activists pooled around Marilyn J. Mosby, the state’s attorney in Baltimore, expecting disappointment. But as she announced that charges would be filed against all six officers involved in the arrest of Freddie Gray, jubilation and shock rippled from one cluster of friends to another.

headline: Pedro Martinez Tells His Story
text: The transformation of Pedro Martinez — from ferocious competitor to baseball sage — is now complete. In the last few months, Martinez, the former star pitcher for the Boston Red Sox and four other teams, has analyzed the postseason for TBS, been elected to the Hall of Fame on his first try, joined MLB Network and, this week, become an author. The intellect behind the fire is on regular display.

headline: Walking a Fine Line in Promoting a Trade Deal
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama defends the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a far-reaching agreement to tear down trade barriers between the United States and 11 other nations, he often argues it would cure the ills inflicted on American workers by trade pacts of the past, particularly the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: Live From the Morgue: Reporter’s Notebook
text: HOUSTON – I remember being in a journalism class at Fresno State University in central California as everyone sat in silence, stumped. The professor had asked us the simplest of questions.

headline: Hillary Clinton Courts the Democratic Left, but Is Pressured to Take Progressive Stands
text: WASHINGTON — Months before Hillary Rodham Clinton started delivering Democratic primary voters a liberal-minded message about a “stacked deck” in favor of the wealthy and the need for criminal-justice reform, she met quietly at Esca, a Mario Batali restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, with four powerful labor leaders.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lone Bellow, Angel from Montgomery
text: You know how sometimes you find yourself watching and listening to a clip over and over, because it does something for your soul?

headline: Reviews: Works by Rebecca Davis and Milka Djordjevich, and Lyon Opera Ballet
text: Bloowst Windku

headline: Eat, Drink and Be Merry, Like the French?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Battle for Eyes Is Waged via New N.F.L. Players’ Ears
text: CHICAGO — It was a moment that all company executives crave: a celebrity wearing their product on prime-time television.

headline: Officers Facing Charges Find Themselves on an Unfamiliar Side of the Law
text: BALTIMORE — The six suspended Baltimore police officers charged Friday in the death of Freddie Gray are a mix of veterans and recent recruits, of varying ranks and assignments. Three of them are black and three of them are white.

headline: Rolf Smedvig, Trumpeter in the Empire Brass, Dies at 62
text: Rolf Smedvig, a virtuoso classical trumpeter who helped found the Empire Brass, a renowned quintet whose repertory extends from the Renaissance to the Jazz Age, died on April 27 at his home in West Stockbridge, Mass. He was 62.

headline: Report of an Inquiry Into a Former President Rattles Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s political establishment was shaken on Friday by the news that federal prosecutors had opened an influence-peddling inquiry into the business activities of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former president who presided over Brazil’s emergence this century as a leading power in the developing world.

headline: Lounge Performer, Nearing 100, Has 88 Keys to the Good Life
text: On a recent Sunday, as a mother and her son ate brunch at the upscale Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan, they did a double take to stare at an older gentleman playing spirited lounge-style piano to the otherwise empty dining room.

headline: A Bill’s Surveillance Limits
text: Bipartisan legislation passed by the House Judiciary Committee would reauthorize mass surveillance programs revealed by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, but impose new limits on them. Although it does not limit the government’s authority to collect information overseas, including data on telephone and email records, if passed the bill would:

headline: Why the N.S.A. Isn’t Howling Over Restrictions
text: WASHINGTON — For years after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, even as the National Security Agency fiercely defended its secret efforts to sweep up domestic telephone data, there were doubters inside the agency who considered the program wildly expensive with few successes to show for it.

headline: Clash Over Frozen Embryos
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Path to Citizenship for Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Money for the National Institutes of Health
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Indictment Details Plotting in New Jersey Bridge Scandal
text: Bill Baroni, Bridget Anne Kelly and David Wildstein waited for the first day of school.

headline: Suspect Is Identified and Arrested in a Manhattan Rape From 1995 After a DNA Match
text: A man trailed a 25-year-old woman from a movie theater in the West Village and then forced her at knife point into the vestibule of a nearby building. He raped and robbed her and then vanished, court papers say. But doctors at the hospital she ran to collected the assailant’s DNA.

headline: Alex Rodriguez of Yankees Ties Willie Mays With 660th Home Run
text: Alex Rodriguez, the Yankees’ lightning rod slugger, hit his 660th home run at Fenway Park on Friday night, tying him with Willie Mays for fourth on baseball’s career home run list.

headline: Where Chamorro is Spoken
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Rules are made to be broken. If this puzzle by Barry C. Silk had a theme, that’s pretty much what it would be.

headline: William Pfaff, Critic of American Foreign Policy, Dies at 86
text: PARIS — William Pfaff, an international affairs columnist and author who was a prominent critic of American foreign policy, finding Washington’s intervention in world affairs often misguided, died on Thursday in a hospital here. He was 86.

headline: Marty Napoleon, 93, Dies; Jazz Pianist Played With Louis Armstrong
text: Marty Napoleon, a jazz pianist best known for his many years with Louis Armstrong, died on April 27 in Glen Cove, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: Bernie Sanders Yells His Mind
text: Our topic today is: Bernie Sanders for president?

headline: After 660, There Are Bigger Numbers in Sight
text: So Alex Rodriguez has now hit 660 home runs, as many as the great Willie Mays and a total surpassed by only Barry Bonds, Hank Aaron and Babe Ruth. Rodriguez was supposed to get a $6 million bonus from the Yankees for this, but now he may not. An arbitrator may well decide.

headline: Governor Christie’s People
text: No matter how Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spins the George Washington Bridge scandal as he eyes a run for president, one thing should be clear: These are his people, charged with a conspiracy to exact revenge against a local mayor by closing lanes to one of the world’s busiest bridges.

headline: Louis Armstrong, the Real Ambassador
text: March marked the 50th anniversary of Louis Armstrong’s historic tour behind the Iron Curtain, as the Soviet bloc was then called. The second stop on the tour was East Berlin, where, on March 22, 1965, he and his All Stars played a memorable two-hour concert. The concert was broadcast on German television and radio; a few years ago, a condensed version found its way to YouTube. More recently, the Louis Armstrong House Museum got ahold of the entire thing, and on Thursday, it held a screening at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens.

headline: Hawks Eliminate Nets in Game 6
text: The last big Barclays Center cheer of the 2014-15 season occurred between the third and fourth quarters on Friday night, when the Nets’ troupe of older dancers, the NETSational seniors, joined forces with their adolescent counterparts, the Brooklyn Nets Kids, to perform a spirited number at midcourt.

headline: On a Stage for High Drama, Alex Rodriguez Belts No. 660
text: Fenway Park is the site of so much history for Alex Rodriguez, a polarizing figure in baseball but an especially antagonistic one here.

headline: Edward Chambers, Early Leader in Community Organizing, Dies at 85
text: Edward T. Chambers, a lapsed seminarian who succeeded Saul Alinsky as leader of Mr. Alinsky’s social justice foundation, advancing his radical agenda of community organizing and grounding its progressive objectives in the Gospels, died on April 26 at a nursing home near his home in Drimoleague, Ireland. He was 85.

headline: Floyd Mayweather Jr., a Champion in the Ring, Is Something Very Different Out of It
text: LAS VEGAS — Boxing is admirable in its primal beauty. The best fighters are ferocious athletes, tacticians with the endurance of marathon runners.

headline: Miuccia’s Museum Opens
text: The Fondazione Prada — the art branch of the legendary fashion house — opens the doors to its first permanent exhibition space in Milan this month. Housed in a converted 1910s distillery reimagined by the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas, the 10-building complex will feature the work of the American artist Robert Gober, the cheeky Surrealist best known for manipulating everyday objects: warped bathroom sinks without faucets or drains, disembodied wax-colored legs with real hair. A selection of Gober’s new and old works occupies the top three floors of the “Haunted House,” now clad in 24-karat gold leaf.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Speaks of His Regrets (a Few) and Willie Mays (the Greatest Ever)
text: BOSTON — Hours before he matched Willie Mays’s career home run total with a laser into the seats above the Green Monster on Friday, Alex Rodriguez tried to distinguish himself from the Hall of Famer in his sights.

headline: Emphasis in N.F.L. Draft Is on Passing Game and Defending It
text: CHICAGO — The fireworks of the first night of the N.F.L. draft, with its red-carpet treatment for top prospects and a prime-time television audience, gave way to the more mundane rhythms of wheeling and dealing.

headline: Matt Harvey Leads the Mets to a Bounce-Back Win Over the Nationals
text: Giving a professional athlete a nickname can be a fruitless endeavor if it is done hastily or without any serious thought. Only the ones that speak to an athlete’s character or persona ever seem to stick. And it helps if the name plays off pop culture.

headline: Lovely Maria Wins Kentucky Oaks
text: Lovely Maria won the 141st Kentucky Oaks by two and three-quarter lengths against Shook Up at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky., in an emotional finish for Kerwin Clark, her 56-year-old jockey, and Larry Jones, her trainer, who nearly lost his life in a riding accident last April.

headline: ‘Umberto D.,’ a Triumph of Neorealism
text: Italy was adrift and in flux right after World War II, and the neorealism brand of filmmaking was a result. Directors focused on upheaval and economic hardship, generally using nonprofessional actors. A classic of the genre, Vittorio De Sica’s “Umberto D.,” is being shown Friday at 7 p.m. at the New-York Historical Society as part of a series called Justice in Film.

headline: Going From Broadway to Racing’s Biggest Stage
text: Inside a Manhattan office, perched high above Broadway, two passions intersect.

headline: Report Shows Mixed Picture for Mets’ Finances
text: With a 16-8 start, the Mets are hoping to make their fans forget about their dismal recent history and look toward a future filled with postseason appearances. Sure, they have lost four of their last six, but they are still in first place in the National League East.

headline: Rory McIlroy Escapes Elimination at World Golf Championships
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The World Golf Championships match-play event was tweaked this year to guard against the early exits of marquee players. The single-elimination format was replaced by round-robin play, which guaranteed that each player in the 64-man field would be around for at least three matches.

headline: Rangers Try to Match Toughness of Capitals
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The physical tone adopted by the Washington Capitals against the Islanders in the first round of the playoffs has continued against the Rangers in the second.

headline: Joel Ward’s Rare Feat for the Capitals
text: The Washington Capitals’ Joel Ward scored with 1.3 seconds left on Thursday night to win Game 1 against the Rangers, his third career game-winning goal in the playoffs. He most memorably netted the winner in overtime of Game 7 against the Boston Bruins in 2012. According to Elias Sports Bureau, Thursday was the third time a winning goal had been scored in the final two seconds of an N.H.L. playoff game.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) DRAFT DAY (2014) Sonny Weaver Jr. (Kevin Costner), the beleaguered general manager of the Cleveland Browns, tries to rebuild his flailing team by choosing from among a Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback (Josh Pence), a gold-hearted linebacker (Chadwick Boseman) and a troubled but gifted running back (Arian Foster) at the N.F.L. draft. But first there’s some wheeling and dealing to be done. Frank Langella plays the Browns’ imperious owner; Denis Leary is their bellicose coach; and Jennifer Garner is the executive in charge of salaries — and of Sonny’s affections. “Mr. Costner handles it all with his usual gruff grace, allowing you to entertain the possibility that he might be a jerk or a loser just long enough to be gratified when he turns out to be a great guy in every way,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Ivan Reitman film. “He has a knack for making born winners look like underdogs, and for making you root for him at his most brazenly manipulative. I don’t really buy ‘Draft Day’ — it’s a shallow and evasive movie, built more around corporate wish fulfillment than around reality — but I have to say that it sells itself beautifully.”

headline: Alex Rodriguez: A Continual Stir
text: From when Alex Rodriguez broke into the majors in 1996 to his retirement in 2016, he has been unable to escape the bizarre and controversial stories that seem to follow him on and off the field.

headline: Opposite Styles Attract; Ability to Adapt Is the Key
text: LAS VEGAS — The playbook on fighting Floyd Mayweather Jr. usually goes something like this: Apply relentless pressure. Throw combinations. Cut off the ring. Make him fight every minute of every round.

headline: Corrections: May 2, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “For years and years, victims of police violence in our city, overwhelmingly black people, have sought justice for their loved ones to no avail. This is an historic moment.”

headline: City Ballet
text: Ashley Bouder, Taylor Stanley and members of New York City Ballet in “Square Dance.” Choreography by George Balanchine/George Balanchine Trust

headline: Lovely Maria Wins Kentucky Oaks, Capping Comeback for Injured Trainer
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Lovely Maria won the 141st Kentucky Oaks by two and three-quarters lengths against Shook Up on Friday at Churchill Downs in an emotional finish for Kerwin Clark, her 56-year-old jockey, and Larry Jones, the filly’s trainer, who nearly lost his life in a riding accident in April 2014.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from an abandoned stable in the Bronx to the aftermath of the earthquake in Katmandu.

headline: Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, Gives Birth to Baby Girl
text: LONDON — Lo, and it came to pass at last on Saturday morning, unto Kate, who was late, a child was born — a baby girl, who will be fourth in line to the British throne.

headline: After Thousands Rally in Baltimore, Police Make Some Arrests as Curfew Takes Hold
text: BALTIMORE — This beleaguered city took on a festive, almost celebratory feel Saturday as thousands of people of all ages and races rallied peacefully in front of City Hall to call for an end to police mistreatment of black men, but also an end to the curfew imposed by Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake amid riots set off by the death of Freddie Gray, who sustained a fatal spinal cord injury in police custody.

headline: Poverty Policy Truths
text: Last year was the 50th anniversary of the War on Poverty, and the date provoked a flurry of studies correcting some widespread myths; perhaps most notable was an enlightening report from the Council of Economic Advisers.

headline: The Most Exciting (Fill in the Blank) in Sports
text: They call the Kentucky Derby the most exciting two minutes in sports, and it is hard to argue. The gate opens, and after 120 seconds or so of thundering hooves in front of 150,000 fans, a horse and jockey have become immortal, while some bettors have won or lost a small fortune.

headline: South Korean N.Y.U. Student Is Reported Arrested in North Korea
text: HONG KONG — North Korea said Saturday that a man it identified as a South Korean student at New York University had been arrested and charged with illegally entering the country.

headline: When a Commercial Tenant Isn’t Welcome
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: A Portrait of the Sandtown Neighborhood in Baltimore
text: Freddie Gray lived in Sandtown-Winchester, a crime-ridden Baltimore neighborhood that has been depressed for decades.

headline: Baltimore Prosecutor Faces National History of Police Acquittals
text: With an unexpectedly speedy and sweeping announcement on Friday of charges against six police officers in the death of Freddie Gray, Baltimore’s chief prosecutor sent an unmistakable signal that the days when police misconduct drew a wrist slap are over.

headline: Third Horse, International Star, Is Scratched From Kentucky Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The Kentucky Derby lost its third starter in as many days when International Star, the Louisiana Derby winner, was scratched Saturday morning. According to the owner Ken Ramsey, the colt appears to have an abscess or bruise in his left front foot.

headline: F.E.C. Can’t Curb 2016 Election Abuse, Commission Chief Says
text: WASHINGTON — The leader of the Federal Election Commission, the agency charged with regulating the way political money is raised and spent, says she has largely given up hope of reining in abuses in the 2016 presidential campaign, which could generate a record $10 billion in spending.

headline: Variety: A Hazy Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — When I was a young mother, one of the more alarming suggestions my parents gave me when The Girl developed a cold and was up screaming all night was to add some brandy to her bottle. The old school logic there was that it would make it easier for her to sleep, which would, in turn, help her healing process and, more importantly, help her exhausted mother get some sleep. I never took them up on the idea, but I have to say that, after doing this puzzle, their suggestion sounds fairly benign.

headline: Star Lacrosse Player’s Move From Midfielder to Attacker Raises Her Profile, and Hofstra’s
text: On the first day of practice with her new team, Shannon Smith had an idea. Barely into her tenure as the women’s lacrosse coach at Hofstra, Smith saw a sophomore midfielder with the athleticism and ability to have a greater impact. All she had to do was persuade the player, Brittain Altomare, that making a major change would make her a major player.

headline: Hints of Normalcy in Katmandu, but Rebuilding Lies Ahead
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — After spending eight days living in a tent in this city’s Tudikhel Park, Bikesh Karki and his family decided, like tens of thousands of others, to pack up and go home.

headline: Yankees Say They Aren’t Obliged to Pay Alex Rodriguez $6 Million Bonus
text: BOSTON — A little more than 12 hours after Alex Rodriguez tied Willie Mays for fourth on baseball’s career home run list, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman made it clear that the team would not be paying him a bonus for doing so.

headline: As Blackpool F.C.’s Failures Grow, So Does Fans’ Displeasure
text: BLACKPOOL, England — Judge us at the end of the season, not now, Karl Oyston wrote to the supporters of Blackpool F.C. last August. A week before the season, Blackpool had only eight players on its books and no goalkeepers, and Oyston, the club’s embattled chairman, had some explaining to do.

headline: That Two-Foot Putt? Nothing to Concede
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Bubba Watson’s opponent was eyeballing a three-foot par putt on Wednesday, and Watson was eyeballing his caddie, Ted Scott. It was the opening day of the World Golf Championships match-play event at Harding Park and Watson, unsure if he should concede the putt to Miguel Ángel Jiménez, asked Scott for his opinion.

headline: Voice From Past Adds Its Timbre to Floyd Mayweather Jr.-Manny Pacquiao Fight
text: The world welterweight title bout on Saturday between Manny Pacquiao and Floyd Mayweather Jr. had two links to the storied boxing announcer Don Dunphy. His son Bob directed the joint HBO-Showtime pay-per-view broadcast. And HBO’s Jim Lampley, who credits Dunphy with inspiring his ringside work, delivered the blow-by-blow call.

headline: Reinvigorating The Chicago Defender, a Historic Print Voice
text: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr. held up a copy of The Chicago Defender, the city’s storied black newspaper, its cover plastered with photos of two dozen black men killed by the police. The headline read, “Wake Up: There’s No Justice for Black Men.”

headline: In Algeria, Entrepreneurs Hope Falling Oil Prices Will Spur Innovation
text: ALGIERS — Algeria, a country that depends on energy for 97 percent of its exports and two-thirds of its government revenue, is facing an economic crisis precipitated by the plunge in oil prices. And that is just fine with Toufik Lerari and Marhoun Rougab, entrepreneurs who see it as salvation for the rest of the Algerian economy.

headline: The Performance Art of Résumés
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Making Machines Work
text: Sean Hopkins, 26, is a reliability engineer at the design and manufacturing company Dyson. He is based in Chicago.

headline: Dave Goldberg, Half of a Silicon Valley Power Couple, Dies at 47
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Dave Goldberg, the chief executive of SurveyMonkey and the husband of Sheryl K. Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, died on Friday night. He was 47.

headline: Brooklyn Tenants Receive a Judgment in a Heating Dispute
text: On Jan. 25, the Metropolitan section published an article tracing the tortuous progress of an ordinary heating complaint in Brooklyn Housing Court. The case, involving two buildings in Crown Heights, was nothing complicated: There was a clear record of complaints to the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, and of inspectors issuing citations for inadequate heat or hot water. Lawyers on both sides said that compared with other cases in Housing Court, this one was moving quickly. Translation: At the time of the article, it had been going on for more than a year.

headline: Jonas Hiller, a Goalie for the Flames, Faces a Familiar Challenge
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Last April, goalie Jonas Hiller sat at his stall in the Anaheim Ducks’ dressing room, staring into the distance and breathing heavily, the loneliest man in a crowded room.

headline: Mario Calmi, a Teaching Golf Pro, Makes Time to Fish and Eat Well
text: On Monday, Mario Calmi stood at the North Woodmere Golf Course driving range, where he is the head professional, and gripped the shaft, aimed and swung.

headline: Spirit of the Skaters
text: The photographer Melissa Cacciola set out to capture skateboarders ‘energy in a static way. The result is “Flip It and Reverse It,” a series of 35 portraits.

headline: Highfliers, Sitting Still
text: Melissa Cacciola doesn’t skateboard, but she has long marveled at the brash physicality of thrill-seekers hurtling themselves along New York City sidewalks, streaking through space and piercing the urban landscape on a board with wheels.

headline: Baltimore Taught Me About Hope
text: “GO ... go. Sonja — go!”

headline: Mathematicians and Blue Crabs
text: BALTIMORE — IN Tom Stoppard’s play “Arcadia,” the mathematician Valentine tries to predict how the grouse population on an estate changes from year to year. He does this by using old shooting records as data, under the assumption that the number of grouse killed annually is proportional to the size of that year’s population. His goal is to create a mathematical formula that takes any year’s population as input and gives the next year’s population as output.

headline: From ‘Hamlet’ to Hillary
text: IF Hillary Clinton goes the distance, she may have Shakespeare to thank.

headline: What Black Moms Know
text: I FEEL sorry for the others. You know those mothers: the highly informed, professionally accomplished — usually white — women who, judging by the mommy blog fodder, daytime TV, and new parenting guides lining store shelves, are apparently panicking all day, every day, over modern child rearing and everything that comes with it. They feel compelled to praise their kids, but fret the dosage. They worry about pesticides; this year’s best birthday-party theme; enrichment summer camps; preparing Johnnie for college admissions in 2025 (it’s never too early); and, of course, the biggie — keeping their kids happy.

headline: I Was Raised by Psychotherapists
text: Being the child of psychotherapists is no fun. For one thing, you are surrounded by books with titles like “The Anatomy of Melancholy” and “I’m OK — You’re OK.” What other families call love is known in yours as “attachment theory.” You are both over-scrutinized by your parents and in competition for attention with their patients, whose problems are often more pressing (and always more lucrative). Your parents are paid to listen to other people cry. The only upside is that it is very easy to get your friends’ parents to feel sorry for you, and that their pity sometimes takes the form of free candy.

headline: The Medical Bill Mystery
text: I CONFESS I filed this column several weeks late in large part because I had hoped first to figure out a medical bill whose serial iterations have been arriving monthly like clockwork for half a year.

headline: Our Police Union Problem
text: FOR decades now, conservatives have pressed the case that public sector unions do not serve the common good.

headline: What to Keep Secret in a Secret War
text: IF you were reading the two sentences by themselves, you might be surprised they appeared in the same newspaper.

headline: Star-Crossed on a Hawaiian Mountaintop

headline: After the Mayhem, Politics as Usual
text: Colorado is now reliving, in the trial of James Holmes, the 2012 shooting at a movie theater in Aurora in which a military-style assault rifle was used to murder 12 people and wound 70. Yet even in this painful moment, the new Republican majority in the State Senate seeks to repeal one of the gun safety laws enacted after the massacre.

headline: Another Chance for Teens

Heckman argued in 2011, “we overinvest in attempting to remediate the problems of disadvantaged adolescents and underinvest in the early years of disadvantaged children,” when the potential gains are supposedly the largest.

headline: Stumbling Into a Wider War
text: It should come as no surprise that the United States and its coalition partners are discussing widening the war against the Islamic State beyond the borders of Iraq and Syria. Wider wars have become almost habitual in recent years, as military conflicts have expanded with little public awareness or debate. President George W. Bush’s “war on terror” began in Afghanistan, then moved to Iraq and elsewhere. Fourteen years after the Sept. 11 attacks, President Obama is still deploying American troops and weapons to fight Al Qaeda and other extremists in far-flung parts of the world, including Pakistan.

Bratton, who wrote the book’s introduction.

headline: It’s Not Just About ‘Quality of Life’

Paramedics managed to revive him, but not before his lungs, kidneys and brain were severely damaged by the lack of blood flow. The prognosis was grim. A neurologist in the intensive care unit said the best possible outcome would be life in a persistent vegetative state.

headline: Disabled and Facing More Challenges in Afghanistan
text: Thousands who were disabled while fighting for the Afghan government are overwhelming the resources available.

headline: Maimed Defending Afghanistan, Then Neglected
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — Saheb had a problem: His left leg had been blown off by a Taliban bomb and he could not afford a prosthesis. He also had a solution: His 11-year-old daughter, Noor Bibi, whom he sold last year for $3,000 to pay for a new leg. Saheb is among the tens of thousands of soldiers and policemen who have been wounded fighting for the government in the country’s long-running civil war. Faced with inadequate or nonexistent official support, many are resorting to desperate measures to survive.

headline: British Media Endorsements in the 2015 Election

headline: ‘Hard Earned’ Documents the Plight of the Working Poor
text: “Last week I had one of those days where I woke up and just realized where I was at in life,” Emilia Stancati says. “I’m 50 years old and tired of carrying trays and running and getting up at 4 o’clock in the morning, and tired of always depending for my money on how other people feel about me.” But when asked her dream, this Chicago waitress, who toils at two restaurants, responds, “I just want weekends off.”

headline: Colum McCann Work Is Set in Motion
text: The Irish writer Colum McCann may be primarily a novelist, but he knows dance, too: His 2003 novel, “Dancer,” is a tasty fictionalized biography of Rudolf Nureyev and reveals a curiosity for, and attraction to, the artful ways of the body. Mr. McCann is credited with the libretto of “Writing Ground,” which receives its New York premiere this week when the San Francisco troupe Alonzo King Lines Ballet visits the Joyce (accompanied by a second New York premiere — “Concerto for Two Violins”). Mr. McCann traded prose for poetry to better suit dance’s ungraspability; his words will be printed in the program but aren’t spoken — the soundscape is a compilation of sacred chants from a rainbow of world religions. Since 1982, Mr. King’s company has practiced his distinct brand of balletic Neo-Classicism — fervent, fluid and bearing the marks of myriad cultures. Arriving from California, it’s liquid from a parched land. (Tuesday through next Sunday, 175 Eighth Avenue, 212-242-0800, joyce.org.)

headline: Review: A Zany Version of the Romance ‘Ernest Shackleton Loves Me’ in New Brunswick
text: Wildly quirky in its contemporary style and tone, “Ernest Shackleton Loves Me” is an intrepid new musical at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick. Inspired by a true story and set within the frame of a fantastical romance, the musical relates one of the most amazing exploits of the last century. This year marks the centennial of the real-life, nearly two-year adventure, that involved a thwarted expedition, a ship wrecked by ice and an indomitable hero, Ernest Shackleton.

headline: Livestock Farming Is Changing Agriculture on Long Island

Although the adjacent fields were still frosty and fallow, the flock of about 145 Icelandic sheep, a heritage breed prized for its fleece, milk and meat, would soon be grazing on the green pasture of the 28-acre farm.

headline: ‘Improvisations’ Concert Series Unites Subversive Musicians

The New Haven-born guitarist and bassist has, during the four decades in which he has toiled in the minefields of avant-garde music, purposely tripped a wire or two, challenging concepts widely associated with the music, prime among them free improvisation.

headline: Katonah Museum of Art Celebrates Its Anniversary, Its Architect and Its Town
text: It’s hard not to feel flummoxed by “Studio Unhinged,” a massive, site-specific installation by the artist Chris Larson at the Katonah Museum of Art. In a wonky conglomeration of rough-hewn chambers, corridors lead nowhere, fluorescent lights flicker and floors become walls. (Or are the walls actually floors?) Visitors who stand at a particular corner will find a wooden staircase leading down to a littered work space and simultaneously, impossibly, up to an adjacent room.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (Showtime) PENNY DREADFUL Drawing on characters from 19th-century literature and historical events like the Jack the Ripper murders, the series begins a second season as Vanessa Ives (Eva Green, above) is haunted by macabre occult images conjured by the mysterious Evelyn Poole (Helen McCrory). Ethan Chandler (Josh Hartnett), meanwhile, decides to leave London in the aftermath of the massacre he committed at the Mariner’s Inn. The Creature (Rory Kinnear) pressures Dr. Frankenstein (Harry Treadaway) to resurrect Brona (Billie Piper). And Sir Malcolm (Timothy Dalton) returns to London to encounter a new evil. Mike Hale, writing in The New York Times, called the show “the best of its kind on TV right now.”

headline: Everyday Life in Katmandu
text: This week’s video, by Jonah M. Kessel, captures the beauty and cultural vibrancy of Katmandu, the capital of Nepal. It was shot on assignment for the New York Times travel section, just one month before the latest earthquake struck.

headline: Queens Man Charged With Assault and Attempted Murder in Shooting of Officer
text: With a loaded handgun tucked into the waistband of his bluejeans, the authorities said, Demetrius Blackwell walked the familiar blocks near his home in Queens Village on Saturday.

headline: Japanese American Museum Acquires Internee Artifacts
text: The Japanese American National Museum in Los Angeles has acquired a collection of artifacts that Japanese-Americans produced while in internment camps during World War II. A planned auction of about 450 pieces last month, at the auction house Rago in Lambertville, N.J., was canceled amid global social media protests.

headline: In Baltimore, National Guard Pullout Begins as Citywide Curfew Is Lifted
text: BALTIMORE — In a pair of gestures on Sunday that suggested that this riot-scarred city was staggering toward normalcy, the National Guard began to pull its troops from Baltimore, and the mayor lifted a curfew that, after several days of relative calm, had come under mounting criticism.

headline: Abducted as an Infant, Revisiting It as an Adult
text: “You wrote a story about me in 1994,” the voice on the phone said, “but I lost the clipping. Could you send me another copy?”

headline: In Skunk Cabbage Growth, Watching Spring Spring
text: It’s easy to see why this season is called spring when you track the explosive growth of skunk cabbage in the Hudson Valley. Some fascinating background on this wetland plant is here and here.

headline: Nepal’s Bureaucracy Is Blamed as Earthquake Relief Supplies Pile Up
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Relief supplies for earthquake victims have been piling up at the airport and in warehouses here because of bureaucratic interference by Nepalese authorities who insist that standard customs inspections and other procedures be followed, even in an emergency, officials with Western governments and aid organizations said on Sunday.

headline: Nonprofit’s Chief During Its Fall Seeks $1.2 Million Payday, and Outrage Ensues
text: Over the past four months, most of its multimillion dollar government contracts and its poor and disabled clients have been handed over to new agencies. Its employees have scattered, with some in new positions, some still unemployed and others struggling to get by in jobs that pay less than they once earned.

headline: After Protest Over Award, Neil Gaiman and Art Spiegelman Agree to Be Table Hosts at PEN Gala
text: Neil Gaiman, Art Spiegelman, and Alison Bechdel are among writers who have agreed to be table hosts at the PEN American Center gala on Tuesday, replacing those who dropped out to protest the presentation of the group’s “freedom of expression courage award” to the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo.

headline: Start-Ups Try to Challenge Google, at Least on Mobile Search
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Europe’s competition regulator filed antitrust charges against Google on the belief that the company’s search business had become so powerful that it was pretty much impossible to compete with. But do not tell that to Bobby Lo.

headline: Duck Dynasty Musical to Close After Brief Run
text: After taking flight very briefly, “Duck Commander Musical,” the Las Vegas musical about the Robertson family of “Duck Dynasty” fame, will close its doors on May 17.

headline: An Engaging Call Elevates Welterweight Title Bout Above Distractions
text: Early on, it appeared that the HBO/Showtime broadcast of the welterweight title fight between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao would sink under a sea of hype and celebrity gazing. The host, James Brown, sounded overwhelmed by the atmosphere and marketing when, soon after 9 p.m. Eastern, he said, “This is the Super Bowl, the World Series, Final Four, World Cup and Kentucky Derby all rolled into one 12-round fight.”

headline: Ashley and JaQuavis Coleman: Kiss Kiss Bang Bang
text: Urban fiction, or street lit, has been snubbed by the publishing industry and scorned by black intellectuals. Yet these authors may just be the most successful literary couple in America.

headline: Shakespeare’s Globe Gets New Director, Emma Rice
text: LONDON — Emma Rice, the co-artistic director of Kneehigh, a spectacle-based theater company headquartered in Cornwall, England, will take over as the next artistic director of Shakespeare’s Globe in the spring of 2016, the theater announced.

headline: Anti-Police Protest in Israel Turns Violent
text: TEL AVIV — A protest on Sunday by thousands of Ethiopian-Israelis and sympathizers against police harassment and brutality turned by nightfall into a chaotic and unusually violent confrontation with the police in the center of Tel Aviv.

headline: Dave Goldberg Was Lifelong Women’s Advocate
text: Even as a high school student, Dave Goldberg was urging female classmates to speak up. As a young dot-com executive, he had one girlfriend after another, but fell hard for a driven friend named Sheryl Sandberg, pining after her for years. After they wed, Mr. Goldberg pushed her to negotiate hard for high compensation and arranged his schedule so that he could be home with their children when she was traveling for work.

headline: Al Qaeda Branch Claims Responsibility for Bangladeshi Blogger’s Killing
text: The leader of Al Qaeda’s branch in the Indian subcontinent has published a video claiming responsibility for the death of Avijit Roy, an atheist Bangladeshi-American blogger who was killed by a group of men with machetes on Feb. 26 as he was leaving a book fair in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

headline: Indian Soldiers Killed in Militant Ambush in Nagaland
text: NEW DELHI — At least eight Indian soldiers were fatally shot by separatist militants in the northeastern state of Nagaland on Sunday, according to the police. The killings took place in the afternoon when a truck carrying soldiers was ambushed by militants from a faction of the Nationalist Socialist Council of Nagaland in the Mon district.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of May 4
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Relief Supplies Are Delayed in Nepal
text: Relief supplies for earthquake victims have been piling up in Nepal’s capital because of government interference, Western officials say.

headline: ‘Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2’ Falls Just Shy of a Zero Percent Rotten Tomatoes Rating
text: LOS ANGELES — Studio movies, even exceptionally bad ones, almost always eke out an upbeat review or two. Last year, not one wide-release film received a zero percent score on RottenTomatoes.com, which aggregates reviews.

headline: Relief Supplies Are Delayed in Nepal
text: Relief supplies for earthquake victims have been piling up in Nepal’s capital because of government interference, Western officials say.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Admirer of Scandinavia, Stands Firm on His Ideas
text: Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent, isn’t afraid to be attacked for his admiration of Scandinavian government programs, like health care and education.

headline: U.S.- Japan Alliance
text: Rolling out the welcome rug.

headline: Quiet Bats and a Flub Send the Mets to Another Loss
text: A week and a half ago, the Mets were the hottest team in baseball, having won 11 straight games. Citi Field was shedding its longstanding reputation for being desolate for much of April, attracting boisterous fans who, having been roused from their hibernation, were championing the ballpark as the home of the best pitching staff in the major leagues.

headline: Earnings From Tesla; Volkswagen’s Annual Meeting
text: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

headline: ‘Avengers’ Dominates Weekend Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Avengers: Age of Ultron” took in $187.7 million over the weekend in North America, a staggering total that nonetheless fell slightly below Hollywood’s expectations, as major sporting events siphoned away viewers.

headline: English Ensembles Crown a Festival of Early Music
text: Carnegie Hall’s groundbreaking early-music festival Before Bach, a varied and eventful journey, ended on Friday evening more or less where it had begun on April 7, in the young but ebullient world of 17th-century Italian opera.

headline: Review: Meredith Monk Ends Carnegie Hall Run With Mystery and Mastery
text: The composer, performance artist and vocal wizard Meredith Monk has been weaving her strange magic in a series of concerts at Carnegie Hall this season, where she has been composer in residence. On Saturday she concluded this run, billed as a celebration of 50 years of work created and performed in New York. Addressing the audience in the sold-out auditorium of Zankel Hall, she said her aim that night was above all to thank and celebrate the musicians who have traveled and performed alongside her.

headline: ABC No Rio Fondly Recalls the Saturdays of Its Gritty Youth
text: Destruction is a New York tradition. There was the beloved Pennsylvania Station, designed by McKim, Mead & White; destroyed in 1963. The Solomon’s Temple of punk rock, CBGB, that couldn’t be saved from closure in 2006; replaced by an upscale fashion boutique. The Frank Lloyd Wright-designed Hoffman Auto Showroom at 430 Park Avenue; disemboweled by developers in 2013. The list goes on and on.

headline: Relative of Cinderella
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Welcome to a new edition of Pedantic Mondays. Don’t panic, this is not a regular feature. It’s always easy to play Monday morning quarterback, but if this had been my idea — and I am fully aware that I didn’t think of it first — I might have approached it a bit differently.

headline: Review: ‘Electronic Africa’ Pushes Dance Rhythms to a Breakneck Speed
text: Nozinja, a South African producer and D.J., started a chant during his set at Villain in Williamsburg on Friday night: “One! Eight! Nine!” That was for 189 beats per minute, the frenetic pace of the dance music he has pioneered, Shangaan Electro. “You must be ready to dance!” he shouted. A heartbeat that fast would be tachycardia.

headline: Review: ‘Frontline’ Looks at Missteps During the Ebola Outbreak
text: Heartbreaking stories from the Ebola outbreak are familiar by now, although that doesn’t make them any easier to hear, and a “Frontline” installment being broadcast on PBS on Tuesday night has its share. But it also has something less familiar: Officials acknowledging that they could have done a better job of responding to the crisis.

headline: Review: ‘9-Man’ Is More Than a Game for Chinese-Americans
text: Basketball isn’t the only sport being played on urban asphalt. A less visible game, but one just as important culturally to those who play it, is profiled Tuesday night on the World Channel in an absorbing documentary called “9-Man.”

headline: China, Pursuing Strategic Interests, Builds Presence in Antarctica
text: HOBART, Tasmania — Few places seem out of reach for China’s leader, Xi Jinping, who has traveled from European capitals to obscure Pacific and Caribbean islands in pursuit of his nation’s strategic interests.

headline: Meet Mago, Former Heavyweight
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — Mago is in the bedroom. You can go in.

headline: Review: ‘Six Rounds of Vengeance,’ in Vegas, No Actual Boxers Necessary
text: There are curved scimitars and long broadswords in the Vampire Cowboys’ “Six Rounds of Vengeance” at the New Ohio Theater. Also arrows, pistols, homemade grenades, fists of steel, an ancient Egyptian dagger and what sounds a lot like a chain saw.

headline: David Cameron and Ed Miliband Enter Final Straight in British Election
text: LONDON — They are a remarkable contrast: David Cameron, 48, the red-cheeked toff who went to Eton and belonged to snooty clubs; and Ed Miliband, 45, the gawky, adenoidal, agnostic son of a Marxist Jewish refugee and historian.

headline: Review: ‘The Wright Brothers’ by David McCullough
text: A lot of books about the Wright Brothers are written for children. Maybe that’s because these two aviation pioneers are better known for their work than for anything personal, and because inventing the first viable airplane is more exciting than anything else about them. Or because the Wrights’ asceticism and single-mindedness sound so uncomplicatedly heroic.

headline: The GHE20G0TH1K in Brooklyn
text: Scenes from the party at the Brooklyn Night Bazaar in Williamsburg.

headline: 40 Busy Years Later, Paul Allen, a Microsoft Founder, Considers His Creation
text: SEATTLE — Looking at Microsoft’s sprawling product line and 118,000 or so employees, it’s easy to forget that the company started with one modest product made by two ambitious people.

headline: Review: The GHE20G0TH1K Party Says It Is Flicking On the Lights
text: For about six years, the GHE20G0TH1K party has been one of New York’s most essential and least predictable night-life institutions. These semiregular shows have captured and disseminated a fantastical world where dance floor-based musical subcultures from underrepresented communities — juke, ballroom house, dark hip-hop, and much more — could coexist, making for a coalition of the overlooked.

headline: City Ballet to Present ‘La Sylphide,’ a Romantic Ballet Standard
text: Leave this world behind. All choreography takes us on a trip, but where? It’s curious that in the Romantic ballets of the 19th century the journey takes us into the risky terrain of unconfined nature. Into the woods!

headline: Safety on Fire
text: There are over 80,000 chemicals in use today. The story of TRIS, removed from children’s pajamas in the 1970s, illustrates just how hard it is to regulate chemicals, or to even know if they’re safe.

headline: A Flame Retardant That Came With Its Own Threat to Health
text: If you closely examine your living room couch, your favorite easy chair or your child’s car seat, the odds are strong that you will find upholstery that is filled with polyurethane foam treated with a chemical flame retardant. Some may find that comforting: Isn’t it desirable to hold an accidental fire at bay, one caused by, say, a burning cigarette or faulty electrical wiring? But studies show that many flame-resistant chemicals loom as potential health menaces, associated with cancers, memory loss, lower I.Q.s and impaired motor skills in children, to name a few woes. Isn’t it just as desirable, some would also say, to keep such substances out of people’s lives?

headline: Long Before British Vote, Financiers Weigh In
text: LONDON — No political party in Europe has done more for hedge funds and bankers in recent years than the British Conservatives.

headline: Ben Carson Says He’ll Seek 2016 G.O.P. Nomination
text: Ben Carson, a retired neurosurgeon who has never held elective office, said on Sunday that he would seek the 2016 Republican nomination for president, joining the party’s fast-growing field.

headline: Moving West Side Books: A Sequel
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Official Rebuts Republican Claims on Benghazi Attack in ‘The Great War of Our Time’
text: WASHINGTON — The former deputy director of the C.I.A. asserts in a forthcoming book that Republicans, in their eagerness to politicize the killing of the American ambassador to Libya, repeatedly distorted the agency’s analysis of events. But he also argues that the C.I.A. should get out of the business of providing “talking points” for administration officials in national security events that quickly become partisan, as happened after the Benghazi attack in 2012.

headline: Top Talent Makes for More Dazzling Triple Crown
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — American Pharoah did what so many had hoped he would in the 141st running of the Kentucky Derby. Besides merely win, he lived up to his promise. The colt showed he could stalk and pounce. He proved that when challenged in the stretch he could out-will and outrun a tough rival.

headline: Slow Rebound for a Bridge in Brooklyn Whose Bounce Became Worse
text: It was supposed to be the coolest little bridge in New York City. Designed by the winner of a MacArthur “genius” grant and built at a cost of $4.1 million, it zigzagged just 400 feet down from Brooklyn Heights to the waterfront, bouncing slightly underfoot and adding a touch of rustic adventure to the bustling Brooklyn Bridge Park.

headline: For-Profit Colleges Face a Loan Revolt by Thousands Claiming Trickery
text: Brittany Prock of Merit, Tex., had a longstanding dream of becoming a detective. To pursue her ambition, she enrolled in the criminal justice program of Everest University Online, operated by Corinthian Colleges, one of the nation’s largest for-profit education companies.

headline: Christie’s Grip on Republican Politics in New Jersey Shows Signs of Slipping
text: At the height of his political celebrity, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey persuaded dozens of Democratic officeholders to back his 2013 re-election campaign. The implied transaction seemed simple: Support a well-liked Republican and win a measure of good will from him, perhaps even some acclaim by association.

headline: Mummy Displayed in Hungary Sets Chinese Villagers in Pursuit of Lost Icon
text: YANGCHUN, China — One day in March, Lin Yongtuan was on his lunch break scrolling through the news on his phone when a story with an interesting photo caught his eye. Researchers in Europe had made a remarkable discovery: the nearly 1,000-year-old mummified body of a monk encased in a statue.

headline: Rhapsody, a Lofty Literary Journal, Perused at 39,000 Feet
text: Last summer at a writers’ workshop in Oregon, the novelists Anthony Doerr, Karen Russell and Elissa Schappell were chatting over cocktails when they realized they had all published work in the same magazine. It wasn’t one of the usual literary outlets, like Tin House, The Paris Review or The New Yorker. It was Rhapsody, an in-flight magazine for United Airlines.

headline: Competitive Environment Complicates Decisions About Head Injuries
text: Ali Krieger has a lot on her plate this year. As a defender for the United States women’s national team, she is weeks away from the start of her second World Cup. And as one of the most prominent members of the National Women’s Soccer League, she is helping build an audience for her team and the fledgling league.

headline: World Science Festival Announces Schedule
text: The stars will be out at the World Science Festival at the end of May, in multiple senses of the word. The actor Alan Alda, the authors Diane Ackerman and David Quammen, and three renowned scientists, Brian Greene, Edward Witten and Steven Weinberg, will be among those to appear at the five-day festival, which also includes a night of stargazing in Brooklyn Bridge Park.

headline: Remembering Craig Allen
text: One of the fiercest roller hockey players on the streets of New York City in the 1970s died on April 26. He was remembered at an annual reunion on Saturday.

headline: Tribute for a Roller Hockey Warrior Who Broke the Color Barrier
text: Hockey is not exactly known as a city game, but played on roller skates, it once held sway as the sport of choice in many New York neighborhoods.

headline: As Vice Moves More to TV, It Tries to Keep Brash Voice
text: The live music at the Vice Media party on Friday shook the room. Shane Smith, Vice’s chief executive, was standing near the stage — with a drink in his hand, pants sagging, tattoos showing — watching the rapper-cum-chef Action Bronson make pizzas.

headline: Yemeni Fighters Trained in Persian Gulf Are Said to Join Saudi-Led Mission
text: MUKALLA, Yemen — Yemeni fighters who are believed to have received training and weapons in the Persian Gulf entered combat around the southern city of Aden on Sunday, joining with militiamen who are battling Houthi rebels, according to local militia fighters in Aden.

headline: Rangers Have Their Hands Full With Alex Ovechkin
text: It was hard enough for the Rangers to deal with Sidney Crosby in the first round of the postseason. They turned back Crosby and his Pittsburgh Penguins teammates in five games, but all four of the Rangers’ victories were by the same, taut 2-1 score, and two of them came in overtime. Crosby was a constant nemesis, and the Rangers were glad to say goodbye to him in the handshake line after Game 5 and move on.

headline: Long-Term Data on Complications Adds to Criticism of Essure Contraceptive Implant
text: When a new contraceptive implant came on the market over a decade ago, it was considered a breakthrough for women who did not want to have more children, a sterilization procedure that could be done in a doctor’s office in just 10 minutes.

headline: Campaign Coverage via Snapchat Could Shake Up the 2016 Elections
text: During the 2008 presidential race, two online upstarts, Politico and The Huffington Post, elbowed their way onto the rope line and, for better or for worse, helped change the way campaigns were covered. In 2012, it was BuzzFeed’s turn. The site that specialized in cute kittens and funny lists turned up at the Iowa caucuses and sped up the news cycle even further, flooding Twitter feeds with tidbits from the trail.

headline: The Formaldehyde Fight
text: The E.P.A. is close to imposing restrictions on the use of the chemical in wood products. But the furniture industry, with the help of some members of Congress, has been trying to get the proposed new rule scaled back. Here is a look at that effort.

headline: The Uphill Battle to Better Regulate Formaldehyde
text: WASHINGTON — A decade after emergency trailers meant to shelter Hurricane Katrina victims instead caused burning eyes, sore throats and other more serious ailments, the Environmental Protection Agency is on the verge of regulating the culprit: formaldehyde, a chemical that can be found in commonplace things like clothes and furniture.

headline: Criminal Complaint Against Demetrius Blackwell
text: A Queens man was charged in the shooting of a police officer on Saturday.

headline: Decades After a Famous Shot, the Fall Guy Is Still Recovering
text: Eras apart, we have a renewal of the rivalry between the franchises of Jordan and James.

headline: Ben Carson on the Issues
text: Ben Carson, a retired pediatric neurosurgeon, announced Sunday that he is running for the Republican presidential nomination. A Fox News commentator, he is a fierce critic of President Obama’s health care law, calling it “the worst thing that has happened in this nation since slavery.” Here is where he stands on some of the biggest issues of the 2016 campaign.

headline: G.O.P. Hopefuls Now Aiming to Woo the Middle Class
text: WASHINGTON — The last three men to win the Republican nomination have been the prosperous son of a president (George W. Bush), a senator who could not recall how many homes his family owned (John McCain of Arizona; it was seven) and a private equity executive worth an estimated $200 million (Mitt Romney).

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Recap: Call Him Swordcatcher
text: Here be spoilers and snakes.

headline: What Ben Carson Would Need to Do to Win
text: Ben Carson has entered the race for the Republican nomination for president. Here is a look at what he will need to do if he hopes to win.

headline: Behind the Yankees: Their Best Days, and A.L. East Foes
text: BOSTON — When the baseball season ended at Fenway Park two Octobers ago, Koji Uehara threw the final pitch to David Ross. The winning pitcher was John Lackey, and the most valuable player of that World Series was David Ortiz. All of them were at least 35 years old.

headline: Clippers and Chris Paul Survive the Spurs With Trust, Toughness and Resolve
text: LOS ANGELES — On Saturday night, after nearly three hours of unscripted theater, Chris Paul wore an unconventional ensemble to his news conference.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ Recap: I Can’t Take Another Failure
text: Season 6, Episode 21: “Don’t Fail”

headline: Review: My Morning Jacket Stays True to Its Strengths on ‘The Waterfall’
text: Lyrics about openness, flow and mind-body dualism, along with cavernous reverb and heavy-foot midrange tempos, resonate on the band’s new album.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Auto sales were up more than 4 percent in April, compared with April 2014. Midsize and compact crossover S.U.V.s — which are built on car frames instead of truck frames — saw large gains, far outselling midsize traditional S.U.V.s and large traditional S.U.V.s.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Avoids Discussing Cashman’s Stand on Bonus
text: BOSTON — The day after General Manager Brian Cashman stated that the Yankees had no intention of paying Alex Rodriguez a $6 million bonus for tying Willie Mays for fourth place on the career home run list, Rodriguez did little more than shrug.

headline: Hispanic Group Brings New Voice in Washington to Coveted Demographic
text: As both political parties make Hispanic voters a focus in 2016, a group working to ensure that “voices of Latinos are reflected at every level of government” will host its first major conference in Washington on Monday.

headline: Effort to Strip Pensions From Corrupt New York Officials Stalls
text: Weeks after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo declared victory on new ethics laws, one measure — to strip pensions from corrupt public officials — has stalled in the New York Assembly because of objections from unions representing public employees.

headline: Not Your Average Pickup Game: Sandlot Action at North Carolina Draws Elite Talent
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Chris Rich, awaiting word from Anson Dorrance, glanced at his phone and made an announcement.

headline: Plainclothes Officers in New York Find Danger in Recognition
text: For most city residents, the New York Police Department’s elite anticrime officers are invisible observers, prowling the streets in unmarked cars and civilian clothes in a bid to stop felony crimes before they start.

headline: Texas Police Kill Gunmen at Exhibit Featuring Cartoons of Muhammad
text: Two gunmen were killed after they opened fire Sunday evening outside an event hosted by an anti-Islam group in Garland, Tex., featuring cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, local officials said. According to the authorities, the two assailants shot a security guard and were, in turn, shot and killed by police officers.

headline: Joseph Lechleider, a Father of the DSL Internet Technology, Dies at 82
text: In the late 1980s, Joseph W. Lechleider came up with a clever solution to a puzzling technical problem, making it possible to bring high-speed Internet service to millions of households. His idea earned him a place in the National Inventors Hall of Fame as one of the fathers of the Internet service known as DSL.

headline: Democratic Party Is Without a Nominee in a Brooklyn Assembly Race
text: The race to replace New York State Assemblyman Karim Camara, who announced in January that he would be stepping down from his seat to join the governor’s office, was supposed to be a leisurely stroll.

headline: Tournament’s New Format Begets Unexpected Ending
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On a raw Sunday morning at TPC Harding Park, a voice cut through the marine layer like a foghorn after Rory McIlroy dispatched his opponent, Paul Casey. It was their first hole of the day and the 22nd of their suspended quarterfinal.

headline: Uncertainty on Long Island Sound
text: The Mamaroneck Beach & Yacht Club has sought for years to build seasonal apartments on the grounds. That may still happen, but the club is up for sale.

headline: Iran Nuclear Talks Open a Tangled Path to Ending Syria’s War
text: UNITED NATIONS — Wearing pinstripes and a pince-nez, Staffan de Mistura, the United Nations envoy for Syria, arrived at the Security Council one Tuesday afternoon in February and announced that President Bashar al-Assad had agreed to halt airstrikes over Aleppo. Would the rebels, Mr. de Mistura suggested, agree to halt their shelling?

headline: Word of the Day | consonance
text: consonance • \ˈkän(t)-s(ə-)nən(t)s\ • noun

headline: The Quest for Transgender Equality
text: Being transgender today is still unreasonably hard, but it is far from hopeless. This is the first in a series of editorials looking at the challenges ahead.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 9:30 P.M. (CBS) DAVID LETTERMAN: A LIFE ON TELEVISION When he retires on May 20, Mr. Letterman, above, will have reigned over 6,028 late-night talk-show broadcasts across 33 years — more than any other host. This salute, M.C.’d by Ray Romano, mines Mr. Letterman’s video vault to present his interviews with world leaders, sports figures and stars in entertainment, as well as his show from Sept. 17, 2001, his first after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: After Eight-Run Lead, Yankees Lean on Bullpen to Finish Off a Sweep
text: BOSTON — If, as David Ortiz suggested earlier this season, the Red Sox-Yankees series are not as salty as they used to be, then a little spice was added back to the rivalry Sunday night.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Q&A: Keisha Castle-Hughes on the Tao of the Sand Snakes
text: This post contains spoilers for Sunday’s episode, “The Sons of the Harpy.”

headline: The Best and Worst Places to Grow Up: How Your Area Compares
text: Children growing up in some places go on to earn more than they would if they had grown up elsewhere.

headline: 时尚交汇点 — 韩国首尔弘大
text: 在韩国首尔的弘大地区，插图画家权米娜说，她的风格受到嘻哈风和双性化的影响。

text: NEW YORK

headline: 租个外国人帮忙卖楼
text: 在这个短片中，中国房地产开发商雇佣普通外国人冒充名人，借此推动疲软的房地产销售。

headline: 慢动作先生
text: 约翰·基钦医生放弃了体面的工作以追求自己的激情：即在加州圣地亚哥太平洋海滩的人行道上滑旱冰。他称自己为“慢动作先生”。

headline: Why the New Research on Mobility Matters: An Economist’s View
text: Hundreds of studies have demonstrated that the odds of economic success vary across neighborhoods. The far more difficult question is whether that’s because neighborhoods nurture success (or failure), or whether they just attract those who would succeed (or fail) anyway.

headline: Andre Kertesz, Watching From Above
text: The word “surveillance” is often loaded with heavy connotations that spark concerns about privacy lost to everything from government eavesdropping to video cameras on every street corner. But what if that word was paired with the story and photographs of the Hungarian photographer Andre Kertesz?

headline: The Polk Family’s Quest for a Better Life
text: WOOD DALE, Ill. — Latonya Polk knew by the early summer of 2012 that she and her family had to leave their home in one of Illinois’s most violence-prone suburbs, outside Chicago.

headline: An Atlas of Upward Mobility Shows Paths Out of Poverty
text: In the wake of the Los Angeles riots more than 20 years ago, Congress created an anti-poverty experiment called Moving to Opportunity. It gave vouchers to help poor families move to better neighborhoods and awarded them on a random basis, so researchers could study the effects.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “The data show we can do something about upward mobility. Every extra year of childhood spent in a better neighborhood seems to matter.”
