headline: Crying ‘Gotcha’
text: If there is one thing politicians agree on, it’s that there are no bad answers, only “gotcha” questions. Whenever reporters, being reporters, ask something unwelcome, or surprising, or even just dumb — any kind of query that requires a politician to say something a politician would prefer not to say — that’s a “gotcha.” The victims are not pleased.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Is Irked by a Subway Delay
text: The email, blunt and to the point, popped into City Hall aides’ inboxes at 12:17 p.m., and the subject line said it all: “2 problems today.”

headline: The Empty River of Life
text: In the last episode of “Our Man in Tehran,” Thomas Erdbrink traveled to Isfahan to see how Iranians confront the country’s drought. He also answered readers’ questions, below, about the government’s environmental policies and the prospects for dealing with the country’s lack of water.

headline: Bentonville, Ark., Hosts a Film Festival Without a Movie Theater
text: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — It makes sense that the fate of this quintessential company town is being plotted in a conference room just a mile from Walmart headquarters. But what Trevor Drinkwater and his lieutenants are plotting is cultural, artistic and urban. In other words, something less stereotypically Walmart.

headline: Fire Raged, They Played On, and the Photo Still Beguiles
text: GILL, Mass. — The photograph, nearly 50 years old, is a social media favorite, a perennial entry on top-10 lists of strange-but-true sports images. And it is certainly strange. Fans watch a football game from the stands as a building burns behind them, failing to look even mildly alarmed at the flames shooting out and the black smoke billowing into the sky.

headline: Wisconsin, Politics and Faith Bind Scott Walker and Paul Ryan
text: DELAVAN, Wis. — Who could have guessed in the mid-1980s, at a pair of otherwise forgettable McDonald’s restaurants some 20 miles apart, that two bushy-haired teenagers working the burger grills would become Wisconsin’s most powerful Republicans?

headline: Rural Indiana Struggles to Contend With H.I.V. Outbreak
text: AUSTIN, Ind. — She became addicted to painkillers over a decade ago, when a car wreck left her with a broken back and doctors prescribed OxyContin during her recovery. Then came a new prescription opiate, Opana, easily obtained on the street and more potent when crushed, dissolved in water and injected. She did just that, many times a day, sometimes sharing needles with other addicts.

headline: How Green Are You?
text: Sometimes trying to go green has its trade-offs. To save energy and reduce light pollution, New York City is considering dimming the lights on its iconic night skyline. What trade-offs do you make in your life to try to reduce your environmental footprint?

headline: Venezuela’s Economy Suffers as Import Schemes Siphon Billions
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The weed whackers were $12,300. Each.

headline: ‘PEN 6’ Exercise Freedom to Dissent
text: This week, Jack Shafer reviews David K. Shipler’s “Freedom of Speech: Mightier Than the Sword.” In the days just before this issue went to press, free speech made headlines in the literary world when six writers (Francine Prose, one of our Bookends columnists, among them) publicly withdrew their support for PEN America Center’s decision to present its annual Freedom of Expression Courage award to the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo. Islamic extremists murdered 12 staff members of the newspaper in Paris on Jan. 7. Shafer, who writes about the press for Politico, was unfazed by the dissent within PEN.

headline: Economic Growth in Eurozone Appears to Be Gaining Momentum
text: PARIS — It may not be at escape velocity yet, but the European economy is definitely picking up steam, an official forecast showed on Tuesday, as low oil prices, favorable foreign-exchange rates and central bank stimulus added momentum to a modest recovery.

headline: ‘Freedom of Speech,’ by David K. Shipler
text: Free speech martyrdom ain’t what it used to be in these United States.

headline: ‘Look Who’s Back,’ With a Resurrected Adolf Hitler
text: E. M. Forster makes a limitlessly useful distinction, in “Aspects of the Novel,” between the novelist and the historian: “The historian,” he explains, “deals with actions, and with the characters of men only so far as he can deduce them from their actions.” On the other hand, “it is the function of the novelist to reveal the hidden life at its source: to tell us more about Queen Victoria than could be known, and thus to produce a character who is not the Queen Victoria of history.”

headline: ‘The Quartet,’ by Joseph J. Ellis
text: When and how did the United States ­become a nation? This question is the core of “The Quartet.” In his customary graceful prose, Joseph J. Ellis, the author of such works of popular history as the prizewinning “Founding Brothers,” argues that the United States did not become a nation with the Declaration of Independence in 1776. Rather, he says, American nationhood resulted from the creation, ­adoption and effectuation of the United States ­Constitution.

headline: Anti-Tax Group Wastes No Time Targeting Mike Huckabee
text: Mike Huckabee’s longtime nemesis, the anti-tax group Club for Growth, is bringing the welcome wagon for his entry into the 2016 Republican presidential primary — with a $100,000 ad buy denouncing his record.

headline: New York Today: Mourning an Officer
text: Good morning on this hazy Tuesday.

headline: HSBC Profit Up Slightly on Market Uptick in First Quarter
text: LONDON — The British bank HSBC said that its profit rose slightly in the first quarter as it benefited from increased market activity, particularly after a “difficult” fourth quarter.

headline: Texas Attacker Left Trail of Extremist Ideas on Twitter
text: WASHINGTON — Counterterrorism officials on Tuesday were studying the electronic trails left by two men killed by a police officer as they shot at a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest in Texas, looking for any direct ties to the Islamic State extremist group in Syria. The group praised the gunmen in a statement as “soldiers of the caliphate,” the unified Muslim land that it purports to be building.

headline: This Is My Brain on PMS
text: Two days before my period, having just decreased my dose of bupropion from 150 to 100 milligrams, I am in the throes of some record-breaking premenstrual syndrome. I’d rather not discuss it. I feel like a traitor admitting that PMS lays me flat — women have been fighting for decades to shake our image as hysterical, chocolate-wolfing slaves to the moon cycle. But PMS is as much a part of my depression as gray skies, insomnia, and difficult writing days. About five years ago, after reading my journals with a therapist (we were trying to identify patterns in my depression), she gave me a diagnosis of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) — basically, brutal PMS.

headline: What Hollywood Can Teach Us About the Future of Work
text: Recently I visited a movie set. It was the first day of production, and I arrived just as the sun was coming up, but already, around 150 people were busy setting up that day’s shot in an abandoned office building. Crew members were laying electric cables and hanging lights. The cinematographer was in one corner with his team, discussing how the sun’s rays filtered through the window blinds. Carpenters were putting the finishing touches on a convincing prop elevator — I pushed the call button and waited, until I finally realized it was a fake.

headline: Mike Huckabee and the Continuing Influence of Evangelicals
text: The religious right remains the largest voting bloc in the Republican Party, and that gives Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, the potential to play a big role in the presidential nominating contest.

headline: Today in Politics: Clinton to Call for a Path to Citizenship
text: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. The Senate is still snagged on its Iran measure. The itinerary of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey takes him far from the George Washington Bridge, and Hillary Rodham Clinton is traveling to Nevada to talk about overhauling the immigration system, an issue that has tripped her up in the past.

headline: South Korean N.Y.U. Student Held by North Says He Wanted to Make a Point
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean student at New York University who is being held by North Korea said in an interview broadcast on Tuesday that he had entered the reclusive country intending to be arrested, and that he had hoped to bring about better relations between the two Koreas by doing so.

headline: Unanswered Questions
text: Nothing is more frustrating to a reader than a story that leaves an obvious question unanswered. Sometimes the writer and editor know the background so well that they forget to include all the basics. Sometimes a crucial fact can’t be learned on deadline; in that case, we should say so clearly, so readers don’t go back and forth through the story wondering how they missed it.

headline: In Performance: Peter Sarsgaard of ‘Hamlet’
text: This week’s video features Peter Sarsgaard as the title character in a new production of “Hamlet” from the Classic Stage Company. In this scene Hamlet is buoyed by the night to seek revenge against Claudius, and wonders how to confront his mother about her hasty remarriage. “Now I could drink hot blood,” he says, “and do such bitter business as the day would quake to think on.” The show is at Classic Stage through Sunday.

headline: Morning Agenda: Big Paychecks Despite Tough Year
text: BIG PAYCHECKS DESPITE TOUGH YEAR | Last year, the hedge fund industry had returns of only 3 percent on average, according to HFR, a firm that tracks the industry. But the top 25 managers still managed to earn $11.62 billion in compensation in 2014, according to an annual ranking to be published on Tuesday by Institutional Investor’s Alpha magazine, Alexandra Stevenson writes in DealBook.

headline: Shanghai Enacts Curbs on Business Dealings of Officials’ Relatives
text: HONG KONG — Responding to calls by President Xi Jinping to rein in corruption in China, Shanghai has enacted strict rules to keep the spouses and children of top local officials from entering private business and profiting from their government connections.

headline: Rand Paul’s Donations Show His Small-Town Appeal

headline: Veg-O-Matic Egonomics
text: All successful researchers have gigantic egos. If they didn’t — if they did not have, at the core of their being, a frightening level of intellectual arrogance — they would never have had the temerity to decide that they had insights denied to all the extremely clever scholars who preceded them. And it takes even more egotism to persist in the face of all the people who will, in fact, tell you that your insight is trivial, it’s wrong, and they said it in 1962.

headline: Bank of America Hires Technology Banker Chris Cormier
text: Bank of America has hired Chris Cormier, a specialist in helping companies in the technology, media and telecommunications sectors go public, as a managing director, the firm announced on Monday in an internal memorandum.

headline: Stephen Curry as Best Player? Sure. Most Valuable? Maybe Not.

text: Mike Huckabee, a former Republican governor of Arkansas and preacher who has announced his run for the presidency on Tuesday, has been outspoken on a range of matters, particularly foreign policy and social issues like same-sex marriage. Here are his stances on important issues.

headline: Returning the Spoils of World War II, Taken by Americans
text: As the Allies stormed through Germany in 1945, museum officials in Dessau scurried to hide their art treasures in a nearby salt mine, where they would soon be discovered by American soldiers.

headline: At the Met Gala, Cher and Marc Jacobs Make a Dream Duo

headline: 1940: The Danger of Independence
text: NEW YORK — While the United States Commissioner to the Philippines conferred in Tokio with Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita, hoping for an improvement in strained Japanese-American relations, the New York Herald Tribune today [May 5] forecast that the Philippines’ independence in 1946 might be a ‘‘dangerous thing.’’ Commenting on the State Department’s refusal to intervene in the Philippine Assembly’s decision to restrict immigration, which was aimed at Japan, the editorial declared that the influx of Japanese immigrants has continued into the Philippines for years, and that their tradesmen have penetrated into the most remote villages to replace the customary Chinese merchant. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 6, 1940

headline: 1965: Santo Domingo Fight Flares
text: SANTO DOMINGO — The Organization of American States peace mission today [May 5] announced that opposing factions in the Dominican Republic had formally agreed on a cease-fire. But only hours after the agreement was signed, sharp gunfire broke out again in various parts of this capital city. Official military sources said four Americans were wounded and there were unverified reports that at least four U.S. soldiers were captured by the rebels. — New York Herald Tribune, European edition, May 6, 1965

headline: What Mike Huckabee Would Need to Do to Win
text: Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, has entered the race for the Republican nomination for president on Tuesday. Here is a look at what he will need to do to win.

headline: Hotel Review: Vault Karakoy in Istanbul
text: Doubles start at 169 euros in low season ($180 at $1.07 to the euro), 239 euros in high.

headline: Two Premises on Poverty and Culture
text: The last time I followed certain of my colleagues into an argument about poverty, economics and culture, it took several thousand words to find my way back out. This time I’m going to try a briefer intervention, stressing again that I think conversations about policing are a more productive response to what’s happened in Baltimore than leaping up a level to the persistent right-left argument about the welfare state. But since that debate is happening no matter what, it might be helpful to describe a framework in which I think these arguments should take place, because quite often the two sides can’t even decide on where the argument should start. So here, for your consideration, are two premises about the last fifty years of American history.

headline: Readers’ Turn: Why Location Is Important
text: Each Tuesday, The Upshot’s newsletter will feature a selection of comments from an article that resonated with our readers in the past week.

headline: Review: Chamber Music Society Performs Ligeti’s Trio
text: Every student who aspires to a career in classical music should be able to do what the pianist Jeremy Denk did on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall. I’m not just talking about playing beautifully, as he did in works by Beethoven and Ligeti for a program with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: Nicola Sturgeon, Not Running in British Election, May Yet Prevail
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Nicola Sturgeon was late getting to her burgundy helicopter. It had taken her 45 minutes to traverse the 50 yards between the medieval church and the high street — and not just because of her perilous-looking designer heels.

headline: Restaurant Report: Kazerne in the Netherlands
text: On paper, the plan for Kazerne must have sounded pie-in-the-sky: renovate a beat-up, cavernous building in the center of Eindhoven, a southern Dutch city in the midst of a reawakening. Transform it into a restaurant-slash-showcase for design and technology. Throw in meeting spaces, a design shop and lodging.

headline: Astros Start the Season Revamped and on Top
text: With more than a month gone in the baseball season, there is an unexpected team at the top of the standings: the Houston Astros, long a major league doormat. A 2-1 loss to the Texas Rangers on Monday night ended a 10-game winning streak, but Houston still has the best record in the American League, 18-8 heading into Tuesday’s games.

headline: The Most On-Theme Red Carpet Looks at Last Night’s Met Gala
text: Guests of last night’s Met Gala, reliably the most exciting red carpet each year, were asked to dress in line with the Costume Institute’s “China: Through the Looking Glass” exhibition. As usual, a small crop of models and actresses showed up in classic black anyway (shout-out to the Olsen twins and Miley Cyrus, chic as ever) — but we celebrate the guests who did the beauty of the Far East justice. Here are the standouts.

headline: Details of HP Lawsuit Against Autonomy Executives Emerge
text: LONDON — New details emerged on Tuesday in Hewlett-Packard’s $5.1 billion lawsuit against two former top executives at Autonomy, the British data intelligence company that HP acquired in 2011 for $11 billion.

headline: Burundi Court Backs President’s Bid for Third Term
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Burundi’s constitutional court on Tuesday approved President Pierre Nkurunziza’s bid for a third term, brushing aside more than a week of deadly protests and the refusal of the court’s deputy president to sign its ruling. The dissenting justice has fled to neighboring Rwanda.

headline: Lawmakers in France Move to Vastly Expand Surveillance
text: PARIS — At a moment when American lawmakers are reconsidering the broad surveillance powers assumed by the government after Sept. 11, the lower house of the French Parliament took a long stride in the opposite direction Tuesday, overwhelmingly approving a bill that could give the authorities their most intrusive domestic spying abilities ever, with almost no judicial oversight.

headline: What’s the Best Book That’s Been Made Into a Great Movie?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Alice Gregory and Charles McGrath discuss the best literature that’s succeeded on the big screen.

headline: Mediterranean Shipwreck Kills 40 Before a Rescue
text: ROME — A rubber boat crowded with migrants deflated and foundered in the Mediterranean, and as many as 40 people apparently drowned before an approaching merchant ship could reach them, witnesses told the humanitarian group Save the Children on Tuesday.

headline: Sierra Leone’s Hidden Ebola Outbreak
text: Sheri Fink, a New York Times reporter, recounts her discovery that Sierra Leone’s outbreak started much earlier than the official story suggests. An exclusive video by the PBS series “Frontline.”

headline: Tracing the Ebola Outbreak, Scientists Hunt a Silent Epidemic
text: Scientists are using blood samples collected throughout the Ebola outbreak to map the virus’s spread from country to country by tracking tiny mutations in its gene sequences.

headline: Walkabout: Resistance to Airplane Cockpit Cameras
text: Watchful Eye After the recent presumed suicide crash of a Germanwings flight, a movement is underway to have video cameras installed in cockpits — but pilot unions are against the idea. (The Wall Street Journal)

headline: Verbatim: Huckabee Formally Enters 2016 Race
text: — Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, telling an audience of supporters in Hope, Ark., that he is running for president.

headline: Cloudy Skies
text: Inspired by “The Observer’s Book of Weather” by Reginald M. Lester, published by Frederick Warne & Co. Ltd, 1962.Part of a series of paintings from books, by Leanne Shapton for T Magazine.

headline: Migrants Rescued From Dinghy at Sea
text: A video showing migrants in an overcrowded rubber dinghy in the Mediterranean scrambling to reach a line lowered to them from a vessel on Sunday.

headline: Review: ‘All Dancing! All Singing! Irving Berlin in Hollywood,’ a Lighter-Than-Air Revue
text: Who remembers “The Piccolino,” an Irving Berlin novelty from the 1935 movie musical “Top Hat”? This giddy production number, a playful attempt to initiate a dance craze like the Continental and the Carioca, rhymes the title with “casino,” “bambino,” “vino” and “scallopino.”

headline: Mu Ramen
text: The ramen shop finds a new home in Long Island City, Queens, following a nine-month absence.

headline: Restaurant Review: Mu Ramen in Long Island City, Queens
text: Before telling you how impressed I am by the new Mu Ramen in Long Island City, Queens, I want to clear up my role in the demise of the first Mu Ramen.

headline: Goncourt First Novel Prize Is Awarded to Kamel Daoud of Algeria
text: PARIS — The Académie Goncourt on Tuesday awarded the Algerian novelist Kamel Daoud its 2015 prize for best first novel, for “The Meursault Investigation.” The book is a retelling of Albert Camus’s 1942 classic “The Stranger” from the perspective of the brother of the Arab man killed by that novel’s protagonist, Meursault.

headline: Behind the Dateline: ‘Kathmandu’ Becomes Times Style
text: Philip B. Corbett is the associate masthead editor for standards and oversees The Times’s style manual.

headline: Democrats Plan Six Presidential Debates, Starting This Fall
text: The Democratic National Committee said Tuesday that it would sanction six debates in the current presidential nominating fight, holding at least one in each of four early-nominating states: Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina and Nevada.

headline: Sophisticated Crepes to Sweeten Mother’s Day
text: In the early days of my career, I had a catering service in Austin, Tex., called Breakfast in Bed. It was my first claim to fame. With 24 hours’ notice, I would deliver omelets and crepes to homes all over Austin.

headline: Google Pushes Advertisers to Smaller Screens
text: Google has spent the last few years tweaking its search engine for mobile screens. Now it is trying to get advertisers to join in.

headline: How to Live It Up in Austin, the Simon Miller Way
text: Last week, the bicoastally produced brand Simon Miller — developed between its New York showroom and its Los Angeles denim studio, using textiles from Japan — landed smack in the middle of the continental U.S., down South, on a business trip of sorts. “To kick off our trip to Austin, we hosted our Indigo Market at By George, our favorite shop in Austin,” says Daniel Corrigan, the label’s co-creative director. “For this, we created a world of indigo including vintage Japanese artifacts, indigo textiles and garments, Simon Miller lifestyle product, such as indigo hemp blankets and Kahoko x Simon Miller indigo rugs, along with an assortment of Simon Miller Spring ’15 product.” But the trip wasn’t all work, as anyone who has ever attended South by Southwest or spent a weekend on Sixth Street would guess. Corrigan and Jake Sargent, the other creative director at Simon Miller, “loved the music scene and bar culture in Austin,” he says. “It’s like nowhere else, always something going on.” In the above slide show, the duo share snapshots of their adventures in Texas’s capital, where they sipped margaritas, shopped for vintage treasures and cacti, went for a swim (or two) and just couldn’t get enough brunch.

headline: Young African Migrants Caught in Trafficking Machine
text: ZAWIYAH, Libya — The no-money-down offer was too tempting for the children to resist.

headline: Northern Ireland Unionists Hope for Power Gain in British Election
text: CARRICKFERGUS, Northern Ireland — Ambling around this seaside town on a sunny afternoon, Sammy Wilson greeted smiling constituents like long-lost friends ahead of this week’s British general election.

headline: In ‘Misbehaving,’ an Economics Professor Isn’t Afraid to Attack His Own
text: The economist Richard H. Thaler has written a sly and somewhat subversive history of his profession.

headline: John Kerry Makes Unannounced Visit to Somalia
text: Secretary of State John Kerry made a brief but symbolically significant stopover in Somalia on Tuesday, becoming the highest-ranking American official to visit the war-ravaged country since a disastrous foray by American forces more than 20 years ago.

headline: Daniel Clowes’s ‘The Complete Eightball’ Comes Out Next Month
text: When Daniel Clowes started his comics series Eightball in 1989, it was miles away from the superhero fare that then dominated comics (and still does). With an acrid storytelling voice and a clean, spare drawing style, Mr. Clowes used Eightball — which usually contained four or five unrelated short stories per issue — to skewer pop culture, spin surrealistic horrors and sympathetically portray youth adrift.

headline: Jury in Etan Patz Trial Again Says It Is Deadlocked
text: The jury in the Etan Patz murder trial ended its 15th day of deliberations on Tuesday without reaching a verdict, after sending a note to the judge earlier in the day saying it was deadlocked.

headline: Air Ambulances Offer a Lifeline, and Then a Sky-High Bill
text: Clarence W. Kendall, a rancher in Pearce, Ariz., was moving bales on top of a haystack when he fell eight feet and struck his head on the corner of a truck below. His health insurance covered most of the cost of treating the head trauma caused by the accident.

headline: ‘Hero,’ a New Work in Florence, Pays Tribute to Michelangelo’s ‘David’
text: ROME – Until mid-September, visitors to the Accademia Gallery in Florence will be able to see two Carrara marble statues of David for the price of one.

headline: New York to Adopt a Uniform Bar Exam Used in 15 Other States
text: New York State will begin using a standard bar examination given in 15 other states next summer, making it the largest state so far to adopt what amounts to a national credential for lawyers, the state’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, announced on Tuesday.

headline: Review: ‘Hold Still,’ Sally Mann’s Memoir, Reveals a Photographer’s Rich Life
text: There aren’t many important memoirs by American photographers. I wish especially that, along with Robert Frank and Diane Arbus, Walker Evans had left one behind. How good was Evans’s prose? He once described James Agee’s sartorial style as “knowingly comical inverted dandyism.” He added: “wind, rain, work and mockery were his tailors.”

headline: The Chat: Mike Huckabee’s Presidential Announcement, Instantly Analyzed
text: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, perhaps best known as a Fox News talk show host until recently, on Tuesday became the latest Republican to announce he would run for president. Over instant messages during the speech, two correspondents for The New York Times analyzed Mr. Huckabee’s remarks. Here, lightly edited, is their full chat.

text: I thought Richard White of West Hartford, Conn., had a solid idea. He wrote to me this week, as follows:

headline: Video Review: Slugging Through the Mud to Find the Best S.U.V.s
text: YEARS ago, my friend Roger asked me for advice about buying a sport utility vehicle. His two needs were being able to drive his pregnant wife to the hospital after a cataclysmic earthquake and intimidating other drivers. My suggestion? A psychotherapist.

headline: Driven | A Mud Test For the Best S.U.V.
text: How do you choose the best S.U.V.? Test drive, test drive, test drive. And a little mud doesn’t hurt.

headline: A Mother’s Cookbook Shares More Than Recipes
text: The last full sentence I heard from my mom was around Easter. “You better call Michael,” she said.

headline: It Now Looks as if the Economy Shrank in the First Quarter

headline: Isiah Thomas Is Back at Garden in Surprising Role: President of Liberty
text: The strange Madison Square Garden world of James L. Dolan and his complicated relationship with Isiah Thomas became a whole lot stranger Tuesday with the announcement that Thomas had been hired to run the W.N.B.A.’s Liberty franchise as team president, one with an ownership stake.

headline: New York City’s Libraries Need Money
text: New York’s public libraries want about $1.5 billion from the city over the next 10 years so they can fix their buildings, which are old, crowded, falling apart or lacking in things they need to be useful in the 21st century, like electrical outlets. They also want more operating money, $378 million, up from about $320 million, to improve programs and services in the coming fiscal year and to stay open longer — a basic indicator of library-system vigor in which New York lags embarrassingly behind Chicago, Los Angeles, Dallas, Phoenix, Philadelphia, San Antonio and San Diego. And the city’s suburbs. And Albany.

headline: Click Here for the Beach

headline: Kerry Meets With Somali President
text: Secretary of State John Kerry met with President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud of Somalia during an unannounced visit to the country on Tuesday.

headline: At Sohn Conference, Masters of Moves Recognize the Good Ones

Ackman, the founder and chief executive of Pershing Square Capital Management, and Ian Bremmer, the president of the Eurasia Group, are used to commanding center stage and charming crowds. But on Monday afternoon at the annual Sohn Investment Conference, they stood transfixed just off the main stage at Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center, watching something they had never seen before.

headline: 80-Hour Work Week? This is How She (or He) Does It
text: Call it faking, or call it flexibility by omission, but sometimes the answer to the question “how does she do everything” is “she doesn’t.” Or at least, not exactly the way you think she does.

headline: At This New York Hotel, They’ll Remember Mama
text: There may be no better portrayal of the complicated bond between mother and child than the classic cult film “Mommie Dearest,” which starred Faye Dunaway as Joan Crawford and Diana Scarwid as her adopted daughter, Christina.

headline: ‘News’ From the Republican Campaign
text: If you’re waiting for a Republican to give a good reason for running for president other than a desire to run against Hillary Clinton (or really against Bill Clinton’s memory), Mike Huckabee’s candidacy announcement today will disappoint.

headline: What You Get for … $550,000
text: This week’s properties include a contemporary in New York’s Catskills, an adobe house in New Mexico and a townhouse in Virginia.

headline: A Feistier Mike Huckabee Than in 2008
text: It has been more than eight years since former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas announced his first presidential bid, making his plans known in an interview with Tim Russert on NBC‘s “Meet the Press.” While he did not reveal any big policy shifts in announcing his second bid in Arkansas on Tuesday, the differences, including a festive rally and feistier rhetoric, reflect a changed world and a more experienced candidate.

headline: Astronomers Measure Distance to Farthest Galaxy Yet
text: Leapfrogging backward in time to when the universe was apparently feeling its oats, a group of astronomers reported Tuesday that they had measured a bona fide distance to one of the farthest and thus earliest galaxies known.

headline: A Five-Bedroom Townhouse in Dublin
text: Recently restored and retaining period details, the house, in the Ballsbridge neighborhood, is on the market for $2.76 million.

headline: Lady Gaga’s Stylist Shares the Making of Her Custom Balenciaga Met Gala Look
text: Brandon Maxwell recounts every detail of the making of her showstopping ensemble, complete with personal, behind-the-scenes images before last night’s red carpet.

headline: A Mother’s Day Gift That Benefits More Women Than Just Mom
text: A package on Mom’s doorstep from Eu’Genia Shea, a company launched two months ago by the former Wall Street analyst Naa-Sakle Akuete, is a thoughtful Mother’s Day gift for reasons both practical and symbolic. Yes, pure shea butter is among the best all-natural moisturizers — a luxurious present for a woman who’s surely earned a little pampering. (Plus, it works wonders on stretch marks, though you didn’t hear it from me.) But Eu’Genia’s backstory makes the gift all the more sweetly fitting. Akuete founded the company with, and named it after, her own mother, who is herself an entrepreneur: She runs the company that supplies Eu’Genia with its shea nuts. It’s a girl-power operation all the way down: Eu’Genia works with all-female cooperatives in northern Ghana, providing above-average wages and job training to the workers who harvest the nuts — many of whom are mothers themselves.

headline: Havana at Night
text: To wander through the dimly lit streets of Old Havana after dark is to enter a world of shadows, silhouettes and half lit faces.

headline: Worker at Manhattan Construction Site Falls Down Elevator Shaft and Dies
text: A worker at a construction site for a luxury hotel in Midtown Manhattan fell down an elevator shaft on Tuesday, plunging hundreds of feet to his death, the police said.

headline: International Star Will Miss Triple Crown Races With Injury
text: International Star, who was scratched the morning of the Kentucky Derby with the hope that he might compete in the Preakness or the Belmont Stakes, will instead be sidelined until at least the fall with a chip in his left front ankle that will require surgery.

headline: Benjamin F. Logan, Engineer by Day and Bluegrass Fiddler by Night, Dies at 87
text: On weekdays, Benjamin F. Logan worked as a mathematician and electrical engineer at AT&T Bell Laboratories in New Jersey. On nights and weekends, he donned a 10-gallon hat and took to the stage as a pre-eminent bluegrass fiddler.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Nepal, Burundi, Australia and Ukraine.

headline: De La Soul’s Kickstarter Campaign Raises $600,874
text: Twenty superfans of De La Soul, the old-school hip-hop trio, recently paid $300 each for a schmoozy Skype video chat with the group. Another spent $1,500 on a vintage boom box from one member’s “personal collection.” But this wasn’t a charity auction. Instead, these perks — and many more — were offered in exchange for financial support as the act raised money to make its eighth studio album.

headline: Pictures of the Day — May 5, 2015
text: Photos from Nepal, Burundi, Australia and Ukraine.

headline: Stan Smith, Accidental Sneaker Icon
text: In the 1960s, when Stan Smith was a tennis star at the University of Southern California, players wore canvas shoes. Americans preferred Converse, Smith recalls, and Australians favored the Dunlop Green Flash, with its zigzag sole promising sure-footedness on grass. In 1971, when Smith was the No. 1 player in the world, Adidas approached him about endorsing a fleeter alternative: the first leather tennis shoe, which had first been marketed seven years earlier and was originally named for the French pro Robert Haillet. They struck a deal that landed a sketch of Smith’s face on the model’s tongue.

headline: Even the Stars at the Met Gala Get Star-Struck
text: Imagine, for a moment, that you were at Monday night’s Met Gala, and Larry David was your date. It wouldn’t have taken long to feel that you had traveled back in time and ended up in an episode of “Seinfeld.”

headline: Dave Goldberg Mourned by Charmed Leaders of Tech and Poker Buddies
text: STANFORD, Calif. — For a few hours on Tuesday, Silicon Valley stopped rushing headlong into the future.

headline: Review: ‘The Realization of Emily Linder’ Is a Comedic Drama About Approaching Death
text: “The Realization of Emily Linder” features a measure of wit and a moderately intriguing plot, but cringes and crying mark the best moments of the show.

headline: Berenice Abbott, Writing Her Own History
text: The expanded archives of the pioneering photographer Berenice Abbott detail not just the range of her eye, but also the obstacles she confronted and overcame.

headline: Juventus Serves Notice That It Belongs in Mix for the Title
text: TURIN, Italy — Massimiliano Allegri does not have Carlo Ancelotti’s three Champions League titles or his seemingly limitless payroll or his squad of stars like Cristiano Ronaldo and Gareth Bale and Toni Kroos.

headline: Review: ‘The Floatones,’ Making Song and Sense of Life and Nonsense
text: Very nearly unclassifiable and utterly delightful, “The Floatones,” Jim Neu’s fantastical, irrational Zen koan of a musical, returns to La MaMa about 20 years after its premiere there. Four characters, named for the actors who portray them, stand on a bare stage chanting mottos and jingles and riddles that make no sense except when they do.

headline: Living in Flatbush, Brooklyn
text: The sprawling neighborhood is economically and socially diverse, and offers a wide variety of housing stock.

headline: Germany, Too, Is Accused of Spying on Friends
text: BERLIN — About 18 months ago, Chancellor Angela Merkel was the wronged American ally whose cellphone number was among data sucked up by American intelligence as it kept watch on Europeans.

headline: What the Debate on Inequality Is Missing
text: The United States economy is one of the most effective on earth in terms of generating new wealth. But for all the wealth it generates, it does an exceptionally dismal job at sharing it broadly among Americans.

headline: The Nepal Earthquake’s Lingering Impact
text: Ten days after the quake survivors were trying to reclaim whatever possessions they could salvage from the rubble, and mourning victims just now found.

headline: Treadmill May Be Riskiest Machine, but Injuries From It Still Rare
text: WASHINGTON — The death of David Goldberg on a treadmill while on vacation in Mexico was tragic, untimely and a shock to those who knew him.

headline: ‘Labor Games’ Is a Brilliantly Absurd TV Game Show
text: This would have been an interesting moment in television game-show evolution even without the show that is having its premiere Wednesday night on TLC. But that debut elevates it to near historic status. “Labor Games” may be simultaneously the most brilliant and the most head-shaking game-show idea ever.

text: Max Brallier didn’t have very realistic career goals as a child.

headline: Review: ‘I Am Big Bird’ Tells Caroll Spinney’s Story
text: The world’s most famous giant bird has a human performer inside it, and it turns out that this nearly anonymous fellow has interesting stories to tell. There’s the one about the puppeteer who was almost part of a space-travel disaster. There’s the one about the guy who wanted to quit the job he was born to do practically before he had started it.

text: The musings, observations and procrastinations of T’s critic at large Jody Rosen.

text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: The Met Gala and Its After-Parties, as Captured on Instagram
text: The Met Gala and its after-parties were rife with Instagram material this year. Celebrities mingled with fashion designers and scenesters at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and at various New York City hot spots. Hair came down, selfies were taken and poses were struck. Handy cameras were there to capture it all.

headline: Senate Passes Cost-Cutting Budget Plan
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate gave final approval Tuesday to the first joint congressional budget plan in six years, ratifying a 10-year blueprint that would cut spending by $5.3 trillion, overhaul programs for the poor, repeal President Obama’s health care law and ostensibly produce a balanced budget in less than a decade.

headline: Americans’ Views on the 2016 Presidential Campaign and the Issues
text: See what Americans think about Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Republican candidates and issues like the health care law and same-sex marriage.

headline: How the New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 30 to May 3 with 1,027 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 868 said they were registered to vote.

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on the 2016 Presidential Campaign and the Issues
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton is now viewed more favorably and as a stronger leader than she was earlier in the year despite weeks of scrutiny about her ethics, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Appeal Survives Scrutiny, Poll Says
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to have initially weathered a barrage of news about her use of a private email account when she was secretary of state and the practices of her family’s foundation, an indication that she is starting her second presidential bid with an unusual durability among Democratic voters.

headline: Detective Accused in Assault Expected Mayhem in Bikers’ Tour, Colleague Testifies

headline: Charlie Hebdo Editor Seeks to Distance Newspaper From Anti-Islam Causes

headline: A Conversation With Gary E. Handel
text: Mr. Handel, 60, is the founding partner and president of Handel Architects, a design firm perhaps best known for its work on the National September 11 Memorial, where the World Trade Center twin towers once stood. The company, which Mr. Handel founded in 1994, is involved in dozens of big projects around the world, including the Greenpoint Landing development in Brooklyn.

headline: Lynch Visits Baltimore in First Official Trip as Attorney General
text: In her first official trip as attorney general, Loretta E. Lynch went to Baltimore on Tuesday, offering similar words of praise and reassurance to factions that have often had very different views on recent clashes there.

headline: Alexander Rich Dies at 90; Confirmed DNA’s Double Helix
text: James Watson and Francis Crick worked out the spiral structure of DNA in 1953, but they were not proved right until Dr. Alexander Rich used X-rays to produce a distinct image of the famous double helix in 1973. After he saw it, Dr. Watson phoned Dr. Rich to thank him; it was the first good night’s sleep Dr. Watson had enjoyed in 20 years.

headline: Jeeps, Repaired in Recall, Catch Fire, Prompting New Inquiry
text: Auto safety regulators are investigating a recall last year of some 895,000 Jeep and Dodge S.U.V.s with sun visors that can short-circuit and ignite after some of them apparently caught fire even after being repaired.

headline: Bankers and Regulators Voice Fears on Bond Market Volatility
text: Wall Street chieftains, huge investment firms and top bank regulators are all sounding the same alarm.

headline: F.E.C. Data Shows Campaign Fines Hit Record Low in 2014
text: WASHINGTON — Penalties levied by the Federal Election Commission for campaign finance violations have plummeted to record lows even as political spending has soared, according to newly released data from the agency.

headline: Ellen Albertini Dow, Actress, Dies at 101; Rapping Granny in ‘Wedding Singer’
text: Ellen Albertini Dow, who found acting success in her 70s and portrayed feisty grandmothers in the hit film comedies “Wedding Crashers” and “The Wedding Singer,” stealing the show in that one when she rapped onstage, died on Monday in Los Angeles. She was 101.

headline: Dollar’s Rise Lifts Imports and Widens Trade Gap
text: A roof-raising trade gap in March highlighted concerns that the rise of the dollar against other currencies was weakening the economy, chipping away at the ability of American manufacturers to compete abroad while encouraging more imports to fill retailers’ shelves.

headline: U.S. Licenses Ferry Service to Operate Cuba Route
text: MEXICO CITY — Ferries carrying Cuban and American passengers could soon be sailing between Miami and Havana for the first time in more than 50 years, after the Treasury Department on Tuesday issued licenses to at least two companies as part of a thaw between the Cold War foes.

headline: Dean Skelos, New York Senate Leader, Stands Firm Despite Calls to Resign
text: ALBANY — If State Senator Dean G. Skelos was trying to keep his mind off his legal troubles, Tuesday was probably the wrong day to do it here.

headline: Transgender Resources
text: The Trevor Project

headline: Palestinians’ Unpaid Electric Bills in the West Bank Thicken Tension With Israel
text: TULKARM REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — Like many Palestinians in this forlorn jumble of concrete buildings, Fakhriya Zeidan labored to recall when she last paid her power bill: maybe in 2001?

headline: Now, Spotlight Turns to AT&T-DirecTV Deal
text: Just three months after Comcast announced its $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable last year, its rival AT&T announced a $48 billion takeover of DirecTV.

headline: Patachou, French Singer With a Habit of Snipping Neckties, Dies at 96
text: Patachou, a Parisian chanteuse who “built a reputation on an offbeat name, a penchant for guillotining men’s ties and the fact that she does not look, act or croon like Édith Piaf,” as The New York Times put it in 1958, died on Thursday at her home in Neuilly-sur-Seine, outside Paris. She was 96.

headline: An Actor Takes His Portrayal of La Guardia Far Beyond Broadway
text: The actor who would become Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in a few hours sat in his living room, the windows framing a sparkling spring landscape of the Central Park Reservoir and the Upper East Side. The fat suit that would help transform the actor, Tony Lo Bianco, into New York’s 99th mayor had been folded into a large suitcase nearby.

headline: Grass-Roots Push in the Plains to Block the Keystone Pipeline’s Path
text: ROSEBUD INDIAN RESERVATION, S.D. — In early 2010, the South Dakota government gave its blessing to a Canadian company seeking to move crude oil in a pipeline beneath the American heartland. Opposition had been minimal.

headline: Review: John Raymond, Uncovering the Possibilities of the Familiar
text: The emblematic gesture on “Foreign Territory,” an impressive new album by the trumpeter John Raymond, could be summed up by a track called “Deeper.” It’s an original composition based on familiar chord changes — for a songbook standard, “How Deep Is the Ocean?” So, it’s the sort of thing that jazz musicians have been doing more or less since the beginning. Which means the difference is in the details.

headline: A Gun From Georgia Is Linked to a New York Officer’s Death, Again
text: Early one October morning in 2011, two masked men with gloved hands smashed their way into a roadside pawnshop in rural Georgia, fleeing with 23 handguns.

headline: A National Discussion About Policing, and a Reminder in New York of Its Dangers
text: Perched at Guetteline Vasme’s bedroom window on Saturday evening, two of her grandsons peered out at the commotion of anxious, rushing police officers on their street in Queens Village. Ms. Vasme has lived on 214th Street since 1977, staying there through retirement from Verizon and her own four children going and coming.

headline: High in the Himalayas, a Search After the Nepal Quake Yields Grim Results
text: BARPAK, Nepal — In this village high above a picturesque valley that lies at the epicenter of the earthquake that flattened much of the country, residents are still finding bodies.

headline: Sleepless Nights as a Struggling Tiger Woods Recalls His Father
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The cheese on the burgers served in the clubhouse was sharper than Tiger Woods’s game Tuesday. Playing TPC Sawgrass for the first time since winning the Players Championship two years ago, Woods found two fairways and three water hazards in nine practice holes.

headline: James Dolan Gives an Executive Another Shot, Deserved or Not
text: James L. Dolan, owner of the New York Knicks, a semiprofessional basketball team, has decided to get into the business of raising reputations from the ashes.

headline: Al Jazeera America, Its Newsroom in Turmoil, Is Now the News
text: Nearly two years ago, Ehab Al Shihabi, the chief executive of Al Jazeera America, took the stage at the Aspen Ideas Festival and proposed something grand: An American cable news station that would be thoughtful, probing and smart.

headline: Donovan, Staten Island Prosecutor, Wins Congressional Seat Grimm Held
text: The Staten Island district attorney, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., whose office investigated the chokehold death of Eric Garner in a struggle with the police last year, easily won a special election for the House of Representatives on Tuesday, according to unofficial results.

headline: Police Struggle With Loss of Privileged Position
text: WASHINGTON — Early this year, Megan E. Green, a St. Louis alderwoman, met with officials of a local police union to discuss a proposal for a civilian oversight board that would look into accusations of police misconduct. After Ms. Green refused to soften her support for the proposal, the union backed an aggressive mailing campaign against her.

headline: Tom Cotton’s Procedural Move Interrupts Smooth Sailing for Iran Bill
text: WASHINGTON — It was, for a moment anyway, the Senate in its platonic ideal. Bipartisan legislation to give Congress a voice in any nuclear agreement with Iran soared, over White House objections, through the Foreign Relations Committee and onto the Senate floor, a rare glide path to successful compromise.

headline: Saudi Arabia: Yemeni Rebels Attack
text: Rebels in Yemen struck a border town in Saudi Arabia with mortar and rocket fire on Tuesday, damaging buildings and leading the national airline to cancel flights to the area. The attack on the town of Najran near the Saudi southern border was the first direct assault on an inhabited area in the kingdom since Saudi Arabia and its Arab allies began bombing the rebels, known as Houthis, in Yemen in March.

headline: Noted Quartet
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Hands up if Joe Krozel and Will Shortz fooled you with this one, at least at first glance.

headline: Review: ‘ToasT’ Where Words Are a Cellblock’s Weapon of Choice
text: Watch out for the boys in Cellblock D. They may appear less threatening than some of the other Attica prison inmates in the tumultuous year of 1971. But these guys are packing poetry. Try messing with one of them, and before you can say “Jean Genet,” he’ll have pulled a loaded metaphor on you.

headline: A Path to Citizenship, Hillary Clinton Says, ‘Is at Its Heart a Family Issue’
text: LAS VEGAS — For months, Latino activists frustrated by President Obama’s inability to overhaul the immigration system have pressed Hillary Rodham Clinton about what she would do differently.

headline: Rare Inning of Offense Holds Up for Mets Against Orioles
text: It had been 21 innings since any Mets player had experienced the rubbery sensation of home plate under his feet. But once they finally scored, in the fourth inning Tuesday night, it seemed to alleviate the angst that clung to the ball club like globs of pine tar throughout the weekend.

headline: Iran: Rights Advocate Is Arrested
text: Iranian security forces arrested a prominent human rights activist, Narges Mohammadi, on Tuesday, the reformist Baharnews website reported. Ms. Mohammadi is one of the best-known activists remaining in Iran. For more than a decade, she has worked with the Defenders of Human Rights Center, founded by the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Shirin Ebadi. This week, Ms. Mohammadi, who has been sentenced to prison terms before for her work, was scheduled to appear in court in connection with a new case filed against her. A request for a delay in that case was denied, leaving her lawyer no time to study the charges against her, Baharnews reported.

headline: U.S. Offers Millions in Rewards for Information on ISIS Leaders
text: The State Department announced multimillion-dollar rewards on Tuesday for information leading to the whereabouts of four Islamic State leaders. The department’s Rewards for Justice program is offering up to $7 million for information on Abd al-Rahman Mustafa al-Qaduli, up to $5 million each for Abu Mohammed al-Adnani and Tarkhan Tayumurazovich Batirashvili, and up to $3 million for Tariq Bin-al-Tahar Bin al Falih al-’Awni al-Harzi. According to the department, Mr. Qaduli is a senior Islamic State official who originally joined the Qaeda affiliate in Iraq, Mr. Adnani is an official Islamic State spokesman, Mr. Batirashvili is a battlefield commander in northern Syria, and Mr. Harzi is the group’s leader for the region along the Syria-Turkey border. A $10 million reward had already been offered for the group’s top leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

headline: New Mexico: Deal Is Reached to Reopen Nuclear Waste Plant
text: The United States Department of Energy agreed on Tuesday to spend $73 million to improve the transportation and handling of nuclear waste stored in Carlsbad, where a leak exposed 17 employees to radiation in February 2014. The Waste Isolation Pilot Plant, overseen by the Energy Department, has been closed since then. The agreement, forged with the New Mexico Energy Department, allows the plant to reopen. It also includes improvements to roads and infrastructure in and around Los Alamos National Laboratory, where a drum of plutonium waste erupted last year in an underground dump. The agreement relieves the federal agency from facing $54 million in civil penalties levied against it by the State of New Mexico.

headline: Review: ‘Let Us Now Praise Susan Sontag,’ by Sibyl Kempson
text: In the giddily frantic semi-solo show “Crime or Emergency” and the untranslatable Halloween chiller “Ich, Kürbisgeist,” the playwright, performer and director Sibyl Kempson distinguished herself as one of the most distinctive and delirious writers working downtown. So you had to be excited when Ms. Kempson, a graduate of Mac Wellman’s M.F.A. program at Brooklyn College and an associate of the celebrated experimentalist group Elevator Repair Service, announced that she was creating a company of her own, 7 Daughters of Eve Thtr. & Perf. Co.

headline: Chirlane McCray Promises Millions of Dollars for Mental Health and Social Service Programs
text: The speaker stood behind the lectern, a cadre of aides and commissioners in tow, shifting gamely to Spanish toward the end of her prepared remarks.

headline: Working Families Candidate Diana Richardson Wins Brooklyn Assembly Post
text: The candidate for the small, progressive Working Families Party decisively won a four-way special election for New York State Assembly in Brooklyn on Tuesday night, a strong showing for the labor-backed group.

headline: Rangers’ Scoring Machine Needs Recharging
text: WASHINGTON — The most remarkable thing happened to the Rangers on Tuesday at Verizon Center. Rick Nash stationed himself at the top of the crease, fought off a check and, with a deft flick of his stick, redirected a point shot into the net.

headline: Fresh Bat Awaits, but Yankees Have All They Need Against Blue Jays
text: TORONTO — Gregorio Petit and Jose Pirela, each carrying a bat in his hand, were engaged in friendly conversation late Tuesday afternoon as they walked from the batting cages back to the clubhouse here.

headline: Sister of Marine Veteran Imprisoned in Iran Asks Red Cross to Visit Him
text: The sister of Amir Hekmati, the Marine veteran from Michigan who has been imprisoned in Iran more than three and a half years, asked the International Committee of the Red Cross on Tuesday to visit him in Evin Prison in Tehran, one day after she said that Mr. Hekmati had resumed a suspended hunger strike out of despair over the apparent paralysis in his appeal.

headline: What Happens When You Give Linda Rodin Some Crayons
text: In this new series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment illustrate their responses to a brief questionnaire, revealing their favorite things, darkest secrets — and how they see themselves and the world around them.

headline: The Beatrice Inn Shares a Recipe From Its Secret, Off-Menu Tribute to In-N-Out Burger
text: The Beatrice Inn — Graydon Carter’s West Village follow-up to the Waverly Inn — is many things: a downtown power spot; a celebrity rookery (Demi Moore, Karlie Kloss, Kristen Wiig and Michael Keaton have all been spotted there recently); a place to get a decent martini. It’s about as far as one can get from “burger joint,” and yet, this May, in honor of National Hamburger Month, chef Angie Mar is creating a secret burger menu, offering a dry-aged lamb burger ($38), a black truffle burger with duck egg ($52) and a smoky “Animal Style” burger ($28), in honor of In-N-Out (the L.A. fast-food chain that famously keeps its “Animal Style” option off-menu, and whose burgers are served as a late-night snack at Mr. Carter’s annual Oscar bash).

headline: Ponchos With Panache
text: A wanderer’s wardrobe for the urban adventurer.

headline: A New Skincare Line Aims to Cut Through the Clutter
text: You could say that Kal Vepuri, an entrepreneur and e-commerce investor, and Lauren Hoffman, a former Kiehl’s product developer, have a typical boy-meets-girl story, but with a tech twist. In their case, an introduction by a mutual friend led to a business match made in heaven, and their new “baby” is Onomie, a direct-to-customer beauty brand launching online tomorrow. The name is a variation on the classic spelling of the suffix “-onomy,” which means “body of knowledge.” As Vepuri explains, “We’re about intelligent women and intelligent beauty.”

headline: IBM and Facebook in Marketing Partnership
text: Personalized marketing — the product pitch or message that really hits its target, the right person at the right time — is the much-discussed ideal in advertising and sales.

headline: Word of the Day | decoy
text: decoy • \ˈde-ˌkȯi, di-ˈ\ • noun and verb

headline: After Protests, Charlie Hebdo Members Receive Standing Ovation at PEN Gala
text: Two members of Charlie Hebdo, the French satirical magazine, took the stage to a thundering standing ovation at PEN American Center’s literary gala on Tuesday night, capping a 10-day debate over free speech, blasphemy and Islamophobia that started in the cozy heart of the New York literary world and spread to social media and op-ed pages worldwide.

headline: International Star Is Sidelined Until Fall
text: International Star, who was scratched the morning of the Kentucky Derby with the hope that he might compete in the Preakness or the Belmont Stakes, will instead be sidelined until at least the fall with a chip in his left front ankle that will require surgery.

headline: Van Gogh Painting Is Star During Sotheby’s Auction
text: On Nov. 1, 1888, Vincent van Gogh set up his easel in an ancient Roman necropolis in Arles, France, and painted an avenue of stone sarcophagi lined by towering poplars aflame with the colors of autumn.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (Pivot) GARDENERS OF EDEN Kristin Davis (“Sex and the City”) travels to the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust in Kenya, where conservationists are battling the poaching of elephants for the illegal ivory trade while rescuing orphaned offspring that are eventually returned to the wild. (Above, an orphan visiting a Trust keeper, Benjamin Kyalo.) She also examines the elephant’s role in maintaining the habitats that support it and other species.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “The smugglers are very creative. Once the smuggler gets the children to Libya, the parents have no option but to send money, because there is no return.”

headline: Leftist Party’s Win in Alberta May Affect Future of Oil Sands
text: OTTAWA — With an economy dominated by the oil industry and a conservative, free-market political tradition, Alberta has long been cast as the Texas of Canada. But on Tuesday, not only did the province’s voters put the Progressive Conservative Party out of power after 43 years, they elected a government from the far left of Canada’s mainstream political spectrum.

headline: Berenice Abbott, Writing Her Own History
text: Laid out on the counter were portraits of the famous and the nameless, unpretentious wedding pictures, grandiose industrial architectural details, midcentury American scenes and close-ups of a brain, a wrench and a creepy-crawler. Next to them, a few yellowed notes. One, signed by the French writer Jean Cocteau, declared: “She exposes her delicious memory. She is a chess game between light and shadow.”

headline: How to Solve the E.R. Problem
text: BACK in 2009, a big selling point of health care reform was the idea that expanding insurance coverage would increase Americans’ access to preventive and primary care and decrease the unnecessary use of emergency rooms, saving billions. President Obama said it this way: “One of the areas where we can potentially see some saving is a lot of those patients are being seen in the emergency room anyway, and if we are increasing prevention, if we are increasing wellness programs, we’re reducing the amount of emergency room care.”

headline: Catholicism Undervalues Women
text: Like a Pringles vendor sounding an alarm about obesity, Pope Francis fashioned himself a feminist last week.

headline: Germany, the Green Superpower
text: BERLIN — A week at the American Academy in Berlin leaves me with two contradictory feelings: one is that Germany today deserves a Nobel Peace Prize, and the other is that Germany tomorrow will have to overcome its deeply ingrained post-World War II pacifism and become a more serious, activist global power. And I say both as a compliment.

headline: Open Up, Europe! Let Migrants In
text: LONDON — THOUSANDS of people drown trying to reach Europe — an estimated 1,250 did so in April alone. By denying desperate people the opportunity to cross borders legally, European governments are driving them to risk death.

headline: Curbing Abusive Patent Lawsuits
text: Congress is once again trying to reform patent law to reduce the number of frivolous lawsuits that have made a mockery of the protections the government grants to inventors. This time lawmakers seem much closer to legislation that could become law.

headline: An Opening for Afghan Peace Talks
text: The talks between representatives of the Afghan government and the Taliban in Qatar over the weekend were a breakthrough of sorts. It has long been apparent, including to American generals who have spent more than a decade leading the fight in Afghanistan, that political reconciliation presents the only possibility of a solution to the conflict. While the two days of meetings produced modest progress and a productive tone, they were just a new and tentative start of what is likely to be a long and risky process.

headline: Women Who Choose Engineering
Société Générale and Crédit Agricole Results Beat Market Expectations
text: PARIS — Société Générale and Crédit Agricole, two of France’s largest banks, on Wednesday reported stronger first-quarter results as the European economy picked up steam and the European Central Bank began a program of aggressive stimulus.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Pine Ridge Indian Reservation Struggles With Suicides Among Its Young
text: In “Pine Ridge Indian Reservation Struggles With Suicides Among Its Young,” Julie Bosman reports on a suicide crisis on a reservation.

text: Below, several paragraphs from the May 4 article “Intertwining Celebrities and Fashion at the Met Gala.”

headline: Flatbush, Brooklyn, a Fit for Many Tastes and Budgets
text: When Faiz Osman, 29, leaves his Flatbush, Brooklyn, apartment each morning, he said, he looks up Bedford Avenue “to see grand old Victorian homes, then I walk toward Flatbush Avenue and it feels really urban, with lots of different people.”

headline: Scene of Iraqi Massacre Becomes Shiite Pilgrimage Site
text: TIKRIT, Iraq — The concrete platform at the river’s edge is festooned with flowers and streaked with blood. Along a back wall are photographs taken from a video of the horror that unfolded here last year: a procession of Shiite men, shot in the head one by one by Islamic State fighters and shoved into the waters of the Tigris.

headline: Candidates Fight Over Abortion, but Public Has Surprising Level of Harmony
text: If you listen to party leaders, you might think that the nation is hopelessly divided on abortion. Recently, for example, three presidential candidates — Mike Huckabee, Rand Paul and Hillary Rodham Clinton — addressed the issue in very different ways.

headline: Yoko Ono and MoMA, Together at Last
text: Yoko Ono was about to burn a painting.

headline: Mike Huckabee Seems to Be Going His Own Way on Social Programs
text: Mike Huckabee drew roaring cheers from supporters on Tuesday as the latest entrant in a sprawling field of Republican presidential candidates by declaring himself the guardian of so-called entitlement programs, warning, “Let them end their own congressional pensions, not your Social Security!”

headline: Two Retail Veterans Take Aim at Amazon’s E-Commerce Reign
text: SAN FRANCISCO — There are two ways for start-ups to take on Amazon, the reigning monarch of American online shopping.

headline: Big Names in New York Real Estate Figure Into Skelos and Silver Cases
text: Dean G. Skelos, the Republican majority leader in the State Senate, was a featured guest at a Sept. 19, 2012, luncheon of the Real Estate Board of New York at the organization’s Art Deco office tower in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: As Oculus at World Trade Center Opens, So Does a Neighborhood
text: Santiago Calatrava’s Oculus, that unearthly winged structure taking form at the World Trade Center, will open to limited pedestrian traffic in June.

headline: What’s Your Perfect Family Vacation?
text: Last weekend’s Travel section was devoted to family travel, with ideas from driving the California coast to spending 36 hours in Key West to exploring Atlanta.

headline: ‘Speak Now,’ by Kenji Yoshino
text: At weddings these days, it’s rare to hear the warning “Speak now or forever hold your peace” directed at anyone who can show “just cause” why the couple shouldn’t be married. When Kenji Yoshino and his husband were married in 2009, however, they asked the judge who officiated to include the line in the ceremony. It was a reminder, Yoshino says in his new book, that many Americans feel they have just cause to object to any marriage between two people of the same sex.

headline: An Unexpected Death Rattles the Fitness Community
text: The recent death of the tech executive Dave Goldberg, reportedly during a treadmill workout on a vacation, has saddened and rattled the fitness community. The death of Mr. Goldberg, the chief executive of SurveyMonkey and husband of Sheryl Sandberg of Facebook, has left many people wondering if the exercise itself might have triggered a serious health event. Was it a heart attack? Another health problem? An unfortunate accident?

headline: Afghan Judge Sentences 4 to Death Over Mob Killing
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four men were sentenced to death by an Afghan judge on Wednesday for the mob killing of a woman who had been falsely accused of burning a Quran. But the judge released many of the 49 defendants in the case and delayed verdicts for 19 police officers who were also charged.

headline: Bird Flu: Our Plague Reporter Weighs In
text: Every time I write about an epidemic — Ebola in 2014, swine flu in 2009, H5N1 avian flu in 2004-6, SARS in 2003 — I have to gauge whether I’m adding to the panic, calming the panic, or maybe underplaying something that calls for a little panic, meaning a more vigorous effort to stamp it out.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: 干旱的北京如何办冬奥

headline: New York Today: Back to the Future

headline: Zenefits Raises Money (Again), Landing $4 Billion Valuation
text: Zenefits, a fast-growing software-as-a-service start-up in Silicon Valley, announced on Tuesday that it had raised $500 million, valuing the company at $4 billion.

headline: E.U. Commission Opens Antitrust Inquiry Into E-Commerce Sector
text: LONDON — European officials on Wednesday opened an antitrust investigation into whether large technology companies were impeding competition in online shopping, the latest in a string of inquiries in Europe focused on the web’s biggest players.

headline: Germanwings Co-Pilot Is Said to Have Rehearsed Steps for Crash
text: PARIS — Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot suspected of deliberately flying a German airliner into the French Alps, appears to have rehearsed preparations for the plane’s fatal dive during an earlier flight on the day of the crash, the French authorities said in a preliminary report published on Wednesday.

headline: The Civil War Veterans of London
text: In 1915, 50 years after Appomattox, the London Branch of Civil War Veterans counted 115 members. The list can be found in Harvard’s Houghton Library, and it provides the names, addresses, ages and length and general location of the service of all its members. One man, listed only as E. Munro, was reported as being 105 years old. Presumably, there were many other veterans who made their way to Britain after the war, who had either died by 1915 or had never bothered to join the branch.

headline: Let’s Make Food Issues Real
text: There is some talk about the food movement’s winning. I’m not even sure such a thing as a food movement exists.

headline: Sex, Drugs and Poverty in Red and Blue America
text: In the fall of 1969, Merle Haggard topped the Billboard country charts for four weeks with “Okie from Muskogee,” the song that quickly became the anthem of red America, even before we called it that.

headline: Today in Politics: Clinton Has Weathered Early Storms, Poll Suggests
text: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where the Senate has passed a budget, and is thinking about giving some help to the United States bourbon industry. Hillary Rodham Clinton heads to California to raise some cash and might be breathing a little easier since controversies have seemed to gain little traction with voters.

headline: Should Britain Change the Way It Elects Its Leaders?
text: If parliamentary representation was based on a party's national vote totals, would that lead to a more representative government?

headline: Tragedy in the Mediterranean: Learning About Europe’s Immigration Crisis
text: Thousands of people are fleeing the Middle East and Northern Africa for the shores of Europe this spring because of unrest in their home countries, and many aren’t surviving the trip.

headline: Preliminary Report on the Germanwings Flight 9525 Crash
text: The report shows that the co-pilot rehearsed the plane’s fatal dive during an earlier flight, repeatedly setting the aircraft’s altitude to 100 feet on the day of the crash.

headline: When Britain Goes to Vote, European Union May Feel the Results
text: LONDON — In a grueling and largely uninspiring campaign, politicians in Britain have struggled to convince voters that Thursday’s general election really matters.

headline: Nepal, Before and After the Earthquake
text: Confronting nature’s extremes on Everest and in Katmandu.

headline: A Sauce Worth Mastering
text: Here is the magic flavor of spring in my Brooklyn kitchen: béarnaise sauce, a golden velvet of butter and egg yolk enlivened by the faint aromas of anise and pine. It tastes like the first sunny day after months of chill. We nap asparagus with it, blanket burgers and steaks and salmon in it, use it as a dip for fried or oven-roasted potatoes. The sauce’s richness improves virtually everything it touches.

headline: Wickr Adds a New Chief Executive and a Nonprofit
text: Wickr, the free messaging app, is scheduled to announce on Wednesday that it is splitting into two businesses.

headline: David Foster Wallace Film Will Open BAMcinemaFest
text: “The End of the Tour,” about a Rolling Stone writer’s encounter with David Foster Wallace, and “Queen of Earth,” the second pairing of indie filmmaker Alex Ross Perry and star Elisabeth Moss, are among the highlights of the seventh annual BAMcinemaFest, organizers announced Wednesday.

headline: What Should I Do About a Nanny Who Drinks?
text: The ethicists answer reader questions about a questionable child-care provider and bending a park’s leash laws.

headline: What Should I Do About a Nanny Who Drinks?
text: Last April, I hired a woman to take care of my then-8-month-old daughter. The references she gave me all spoke highly of her, though only one family seemed to know her well. Fast-forward three months. I come home one evening, and the nanny is not yet back with my daughter. When she arrives, half an hour late, she is visibly intoxicated and reeks of alcohol. I immediately fire her after getting a verbal admission that she was drinking. I later found out that the nanny was previously fired by another family for being drunk on the job. The nanny lives with her 10-year-old son in my neighborhood, where many people use a local email list to seek out nannies. I know that she responds to these email ads, and I have just found out that she currently has another job with a family, but I don’t know who the family is or how to contact them. My husband does not want me to post anything on our local email list, for fear of retribution. I am losing sleep that this woman is still taking care of children, and I am also worried about her son’s safety. What can I do that does not put my family at risk but does not make me feel complicit? NAME WITHHELD

text: The pieces may be coming together for SAP, though it is still not clear what they might amount to.

headline: Chinese Drone Maker DJI Gets Lift From Accel Investment

headline: What Do Baseball Players Want Parents to Do During the Game? Nothing

When he coached his son’s baseball team, he wrote a letter to parents, called “ the Matheny Manifesto,” about how he hoped they would support their children during the season.

headline: Jeb Bush Is Failing to Impress Iowa Republicans, Poll Shows
