Enshrined amongst the library’s texts is a precious collection of first editions of books that, over the course of the centuries, were officially banned by the Catholic Church and placed in its Index Librorum Prohibitorum. These volumes include works by Machiavelli, Copernicus and Erasmus, as well as Voltaire’s “Candide” and Jonathan Swift’s “A Tale of a Tub.” The collection, which includes the very first Index of banned books compiled by the Church in 1559, is what inspired the artist Ileana Florescu’s new show, “Libri Prohibiti,” which opens at Angelica Library next week.

headline: Politics Are Set Aside as Thousands Mourn Officer Brian Moore
text: SEAFORD, N.Y. — This time, politics was not on display at a funeral for a fallen New York City police officer. No officers turned their backs to Mayor Bill de Blasio and no one voiced support for protests that have riven communities from Ferguson, Mo., to Baltimore.

headline: Prime Minister Cameron’s Victory Speech
text: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said he would bring the country together and “govern as a party of one nation, one United Kingdom,” in his victory speech on Friday.

headline: Britain’s Labour Leader Miliband Resigns
text: Ed Miliband, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, offered his resignation on Friday a day after Thursday’s general election.

headline: The Benefits and Caveats in Physical Challenges for Charity
text: SEAN MALONEY had an ambitious plan: to be the first stroke survivor to bicycle from San Francisco to New York via a circuitous route that would take him down the West Coast and across Texas. It would be over 5,000 miles.

headline: Top Economist Sees Clinton Money Machine as Problematic
text: Questions surrounding foreign donations to the Clinton Foundation are beginning to fester beyond the usual conservative critics who hope to derail the presidential hopes of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: How to Use Siri, Google Now and Cortana Voice Commands
text: Q. I ask the Google app on my phone only about the daily weather forecast, but how does it compare to the Siri program for the verbal instructions it understands?

headline: Shirley Jackson’s ‘Life Among the Savages’ and ‘Raising Demons’ Reissued
text: When “Life Among the Savages,” a collection of warm and funny magazine pieces chronicling the ups and downs of Shirley Jackson’s household, was first published in 1953, Jackson was already a well-known writer — of a rather different kind. She had made headlines five years earlier with “The Lottery,” which attracted attention not only for its shocking content, but also for the vehemence of the response it provoked. Many were unsure whether this tale of ritual stoning in an American village was fact or fiction; some railed at The New Yorker for printing such barbarism; others just wanted to know what on earth it meant. Jackson, who had already published the novel “The Road Through the Wall” (1948), about murder and suicide in a small California town, sealed her macabre reputation with her next two books: “The Lottery” (1949), a collection of often suspenseful short stories, and “Hangsaman” (1951), a coming-of-age novel about a college student who suffers a mental breakdown.

headline: Concern for Business Leaders as Cameron’s Win Edges Britain Closer to E.U. Exit
text: David Cameron’s re-election as Britain’s prime minister increases the risk that the country will quit the European Union in the next few years. Although this is still not a probability, the possibility will concern business, as an exit would degrade Britain’s access to by far its largest market.

headline: When Mother Leaves the Room
text: Every year on Mother’s Day the lists appear: Bad Mothers in Fiction, Monstrous Mothers in Literature, 10 Worst Mothers in Books We Love. There are a few Most Wonderful lists, but these mothers are not from books generally recognized as great or enduring works. The two most famous are Caroline Ingalls in “Little House on the Prairie” and Marmee in “Little Women” — it’s a bonnet thing perhaps, though a good straw poke does not save Mrs. Bennet in “Pride and Prejudice” from the charge of foolishness. This makes you a bad mother too, apparently. Perhaps there should be an exam. Who could pass it? To be ordinary in any way — weak, fallible, occasionally drunk or desiring, all of these make you a liability to your fictional children’s fictional well- being. Thank goodness reality is not like that.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Use Polarizing? Site Begs to Differ
text: For years, political scientists and social theorists have fretted about the Internet’s potential to flatten and polarize democratic discourse, Farhad Manjoo writes.

headline: Embracing Squid in Its Many Forms
text: It’s funny that people who are normally squeamish about eating oddball food have no problem with squid.

headline: Tax Documents: What to Shred, and What to Keep
text: THE income tax filing deadline is, thankfully, receding on the calendar. And while most people would prefer to move on to other, more pleasant activities, now is a good time to consider how you save your tax returns and other financial documents.

headline: To Cameron, the Tory Victor, Now Go the Headaches
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron, having achieved a smashing and unexpected outright victory in Britain’s general election, heads into his second term facing severe challenges to his nation’s identity and place in the world: how to keep the United Kingdom in the European Union and Scotland in the United Kingdom.

headline: 1915: Roosevelt Remarks on Lusitania
text: NEW YORK — The Herald obtained an interview with Colonel Roosevelt in the Court Room in Syracuse, where he was attending the trial of the libel suit brought against him by Mr. William Barnes, whom he lately called a ‘‘boss.’’

headline: ESPN Is Splitting With Bill Simmons, Who Offers an Uncharacteristic Word Count: Zero
text: When Bill Simmons learned on Friday morning that his nearly 15-year-old relationship with ESPN was over, he responded with something uncharacteristic: silence.

headline: The Mysterious Persistence of the Cronut
text: The line begins about a third of a block into Spring Street and still regularly wraps around the corner up Thompson Street. One morning last week, on the second-to-last day of the month of Strawberry Rhubarb and Thyme — otherwise known as April; the flavor changes every month — a man named Thao stood at the front of the neatly assembled crowd. He was visiting from Vietnam, and had arrived at 5:30 that morning. At 7:36 a.m. there were 35 people lined up, including a baby in a stroller. The line was nearly half a block long. In the middle of the procession stood an older, serious-looking man named Greg Ingram, who was in town on business from Atlanta. “If people are still lining up, there must be something about it,” Ingram said. But also: “What else are you going to do at 7 in the morning?”

headline: 1940: Confidence Vote in Britain
text: LONDON — The Chamberlain government obtained such a narrow vote of confidence late tonight [May 8] at the end of a two-day debate on the Norwegian debacle that it was believed in some political quarters that the Prime Minister might go soon to King George VI and offer to step down. The vote on the division was 281 for the government, 200 against it. One hundred and thirty-two members abstained.

headline: Baltimore Case Is Full of Conflicts, Lawyers for Officers Contend
text: BALTIMORE — Lawyers for the six Baltimore police officers charged in connection with the death of Freddie Gray unleashed a personal and professional broadside on Friday against the prosecutor who brought the charges, accusing her and her office of being riven by conflicts of interest and alleging that she had betrayed professional standards.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Golf, Memory and Food Cravings
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Stuff We Liked
text: We like it, of course, when an Upshot feature gets lots of attention — and our analysis and visualization of a new study on the importance of where a child grows up certainly did. We also liked how Emily Badger over at Wonkblog took the same study and applied her own analysis to the case of Baltimore for a very readable article.

headline: With Berlin Philharmonic Vote Looming, Mariss Jansons Stays On in Munich
text: The invisible primary being waged before the players of the Berlin Philharmonic meet Monday to elect their new chief conductor and artistic director continues apace: Mariss Jansons, who had been thought to be a possible candidate, announced Friday that he had agreed to remain as chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra until 2021.

headline: Patrick Lynch, Police Union Leader, Faces Election Fight
text: In early January, mutiny broke out within the upper ranks of the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association, the city’s largest police union. At a monthly meeting, at a catering hall in Queens, a cabal of senior delegates confronted the union’s president, Patrick J. Lynch, with a defiant declaration: It was time to end his distracting battle with Mayor Bill de Blasio and refocus his attention on his members.

headline: Aftermath of Pakistan Crash
text: Video shows the aftermath of a helicopter crash in Pakistan on Friday that killed foreign dignitaries, with initial reports suggesting it crashed into a school while attempting to land.

headline: Watching Maya Plisetskaya
text: The great Bolshoi ballerina Maya Plisetskaya died on Saturday at 89. I saw her only once, in 1988, at a gala in her honor in Boston; an announcer proclaimed the priceless words: “And now Maya Plisetskaya will dance her immortal Dying Swan” — which she validated by dancing it twice. And that’s what many people remember her for, the number of times her Swan would dance and die. (One colleague remembers her dancing it six times in a row.)

headline: Idina Menzel to Tour in ‘If/Then’
text: Idina Menzel is hitting the road.

headline: ‘Adult Onset,’ by Ann-Marie MacDonald
text: Do our more modest northern neighbors talk about the Great Canadian Novel? After all, they have big geography there too — the mountains, the prairies. “Always in view was the vastness of what in most countries would be called a sea but in Canada was known simply as ‘one of the Great Lakes,’ ” the Canadian writer Ann-Marie MacDonald writes in her big, troubling and brave new novel. Books like hers have a continental sweep: The writer amply stocks them with people and ideas, with all she knows. Spare, quiet perfection isn’t the aim.

headline: On the Job
text: THE BAREFOOT LAWYER

headline: ‘The Lost Child,’ by Caryl Phillips
text: At age 57, Caryl Phillips is seen by many as the father of Afro-British fiction. Phillips was born on the island of St. Kitts in 1958, but as an infant he left with his parents during the mass migration of people from the Caribbean islands — still colonial subjects ­­— to Britain in the 1950s. Immigration has been a key topic in Phillips’s work from his very first novel, “The Final Passage” (1985). His first two novels were fairly straightforward in style and structure, but with his third, “Higher Ground” (1989), Phillips introduced the more ambitious and unconventional approach he has used ever since. Rather than tell one linear story, these later novels bring together several independent narratives set at different places on the globe and at different moments in time. The stories are linked by theme and situation as opposed to setting and plot.

headline: ‘Where Women Are Kings,’ by Christie Watson
text: Not all children love magic. Seven-year-old Elijah, the central character in Christie Watson’s second novel, has a scar on his forehead and more on his body. And he is convinced he has a wizard inside him. This isn’t fun, and the magical power it involves is a pernicious, festering force, endangering everyone around him. Or so Elijah believes.

headline: ‘Smart Money,’ by Andrew Palmer
text: In 2012, The Economist published a 14-page special report on financial innovation entitled “Playing With Fire.” It opened with the line “Financial innovation has a dreadful image these days.” The goal: rehabilitate that image.

headline: ‘Romantic Outlaws,’ About the Lives of Mary Wollstonecraft and Mary Shelley
text: They had it all. When they eloped, 16-year-old Mary Godwin and 21-year-old Percy Shelley had everything artists could desire: genius, beauty, literary pedigree, aristocratic inheritance, Mediterranean villas, famous friends, fearless admirers, freedom and — above all — faith in free love.

headline: ‘Firstborn,’ by Tor Seidler
text: “The glint of wolves’ eyes in the night is a chilling sight. If I’d been wingless, I would have been terrified.” That’s Maggie, the lively magpie who narrates Tor Seidler’s artful and affecting new novel, “Firstborn.” As it turns out, those eyes belong to wolves who, improbably, become her family. Together, led by the fearless Blue Boy, wolves and bird journey to the remote Lamar Valley in Yellowstone National Park where, they hear, an abundance of food awaits them. In the valley — where gray wolves were reintroduced 20 years ago, nearly a century after hunters drastically reduced their numbers — they will birth pups, raise and lose progeny, challenge other wolf packs and re-­examine their loyalties to themselves and one another.

headline: ‘Hermit of the Jungle’ Guards a Brazilian Ghost City Rich in History
text: AIRÃO VELHO, Brazil — SHIGERU NAKAYAMA, the guardian of this ghost city in the Amazon rain forest, gazes at the Rio Negro, a vast blackwater tributary. From some angles, it looks less like a river than a sea, spurring him to remember Japan.

headline: Sara Pennypacker’s ‘Meet the Dullards,’ and More
text: Despite the efforts of story-time subversives as varied as Jo March, Tom Sawyer, the Mad Hatter, Madeline, Eloise, Ramona Quimby, the Cat in the Hat, Willy Wonka and the Stinky Cheese Man, ­namby-pambyism has for generations been a scourge of children’s literature. The impulse to force-feed kids the bookish equivalent of steamed spinach is unlikely ever to fade, though our notions about what that should be continue to evolve. But in recent years an opposing virus has also infected the nursery library. You might call it peepee-poo-ism: the anxious, overeager impulse to engage children on what we adults think of as their own terms, lest they believe us uncool — or worse, and more to the point, old.

headline: ‘I Will Always Write Back: How One Letter Changed Two Lives’
text: In a suburban Pennsylvania classroom in 1997, a life-altering moment: Caitlin Alifirenka, “a typical 12-year-old American girl,” more interested in what she “should wear to school” than what she “might learn there,” chooses a pen pal from Zimbabwe. Caitlin has never heard of Zimbabwe, but the name, “exotic, and difficult to pronounce,” intrigues her.

headline: ‘Ben Draws Trouble,’ ‘How to Draw a Dragon’ and ‘My Pen’
text: The trouble with drawing is that it’s fun. Almost too much fun. Drawing can become uncontrollable, a force you can barely handle. Children know this and give in; adults knew it once, but forget. For children a notebook for math class can easily transform into a sketchbook for art. Lines, shapes and colors become little masterpieces at the margins of the page. How can one stop? Why should one stop? There’s seemingly no choice in the matter. The drawing has to come out.

headline: ‘Black Dove White Raven,’ by Elizabeth Wein
text: Historical fiction, especially historical fiction for young adults, presents many challenges for a writer, not least of them this one: While history is decidedly political, novels are decidedly not political treatises. To ignore the politics of history is naïve — and what novelist wants to be that? On the other hand, objectivity is an undesirable trait in a literary work. Point of view is very serious business.

headline: ‘Lost in the Sun,’ by Lisa Graff
text: The title of this simple yet soulful novel refers to a fly ball that drifts over the head of a Los Angeles Dodgers center fielder, leaving the book’s sixth-grade narrator (and obsessive Dodger fan), Trent Zimmerman, in a confused rage. “He had it,” Trent whines. “If he’d just shifted even a little, he would’ve caught it easy.”

headline: Gordon Korman’s ‘Masterminds,’ and More
text: What happens during summer vacation has a lot to teach us about children and reading. Librarians and teachers are very aware of the “summer slide.” This friendly-sounding phrase describes the loss of reading skills during the long break. After two months of not reading, a student experiences a gap in learning that, by the time she reaches middle school, might add up to a two-year lag in skills. We also know that children who choose reading as a leisure activity will do well on those dreaded tests of comprehension, vocabulary and reading speed.

headline: ‘Bone Gap,’ by Laura Ruby
text: The goddess Demeter had a daughter, Persephone, who was abducted by Hades, the lord of the underworld. In her daughter’s absence, Demeter let the world go barren out of sorrow and anger. Anyone who had a dog-eared copy of the D’Aulaires’ illustrated “Book of Greek Myths” has a handle on Persephone.

headline: ‘Listen, Slowly,’ by Thanhha Lai
text: Literature in English for children and young adults offers few books about Vietnam and even fewer about the Vietnam War. Walter Dean Myers’s 1988 novel “Fallen Angels” explored the costs borne by American soldiers sent to Vietnam with little knowledge about where they were and less about why they were there. The book deglorified war, exposing the sharp irony of sending young men, not yet old enough to vote and often marginalized by race or socioeconomic status, to defend ideals of democracy. They fought a war filled with “hours of boredom, seconds of terror”; if they came home again, it was not as angel warriors, but as fallen angels.

headline: ‘Ms. Rapscott’s Girls’ and ‘The Girl With the Glass Bird’
text: Who can resist a good boarding school novel? The literary tradition dates back as far as the mid-19th-century “Tom Brown’s School Days,” by Thomas Hughes, and Frances Hodgson Burnett’s 1905 classic, “A Little Princess.” These beloved stories shunt the parents aside without (necessarily) killing them off, leaving children to discover their own mettle. Two new boarding school tales for middle-grade readers offer fresh approaches — one whimsical and magical with a dose of gentle social satire, the other a whodunit of sorts, with a taste of international intrigue.

headline: ‘An Ember in the Ashes,’ by Sabaa Tahir
text: “An Ember in the Ashes” presents a ­vicious empire that has subjugated several cultures, including the once learned Scholars. “Usually, the Empire raids in the heat of the day,” we are told. “The soldiers want Scholar mothers and children to watch. They want fathers and brothers to see another man’s family enslaved.” One Scholar, Laia, is so desperate to free her imprisoned brother that she becomes a slave and a spy at Blackcliff, an imperial academy where young men (and one other young woman, Helene) train to ­become the ­Empire’s soldiers. We also meet Elias, the son of the school’s commander. Appalled by the Empire’s rule, he wants to run away, but the announcement of a competition changes his plans. If Elias wins, he will become emperor. And only if he competes, the imperial ­magicians tell him, will he attain a true moral freedom.

headline: 15 European Opera Houses to Offer Free Online Streaming
text: A free showing of Verdi’s “La Traviata” will be streamed live from Madrid’s Teatro Real on Friday, inaugurating a new program backed by the European Union in which some of Europe’s top houses will stream performances free to make opera more accessible.

headline: Inside the List
text: Smiley’s People: Jane Smiley’s new novel, “Early Warning” — it enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 10 — is the middle volume of a trilogy that started last year with “Some Luck,” covering a century in the life of an Iowa family at the rate of a chapter per year. This installment takes the characters from 1953 through 1986, introducing a new generation and letting them contend with milestones like the Vietnam War, Jim Jones’s seductive Peoples Temple and the early days of the AIDS crisis. In some hands the conceit could have felt gimmicky or forced, a kissing cousin to “Forrest Gump” or Billy Joel’s “We Didn’t Start the Fire.” But reviewers so far have been largely impressed, comparing Smiley to the giants of 19th-century literature. (“America’s Tolstoy,” ruled Christobel Kent in The Guardian.) Smiley also keeps an eye on her forebears, if more humbly. “Trollope would sneer,” she told one interviewer last year, after announcing she was about done with the trilogy’s 1,300 pages. In the same profile, she remembered with approval the motivational note — “Nobody asked you to write this novel” — that a former classmate kept taped to her typewriter. “What we do as writers is voluntary, so don’t complain,” Smiley said, recalling how inspired she was by an exhibit of hand-­corrected page proofs at the Balzac museum in Paris. “It’s good to see what it meant to be a popular author in the middle of the 19th century,” she said. “When you see how hard Balzac worked, you’ll never complain again.”

headline: Missouri Lawmakers Limit Revenue From Traffic Fines in St. Louis Area
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — Missouri legislators have agreed to a proposal that would sharply limit revenue from traffic fines in municipalities across St. Louis County, where heavy fines and ticketing helped inflame unrest after the killing of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer here last year.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Middle-East Role Model: His Brother?
text: There’s a bit of controversy today about a remark that Jeb Bush, Republican presidential contender, made about his brother, former President George W. Bush, at a meeting on Tuesday in Manhattan.

headline: Bookshelf: This Is How We Roll
text: New picture books include “The Bus Is for Us!” and “The Red Bicycle.”

headline: Bookshelf: Dig It
text: New picture books include “The Potato King” and “If You Plant a Seed.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THERE IS SIMPLY TOO MUCH TO THINK ABOUT: Collected Nonfiction, by Saul Bellow. Edited by Benjamin Taylor. (Viking, $35.) The nonfiction shows the same strengths as the novels: a dynamic responsiveness to character, place and time.

headline: Scottish Nationalists Rejoice in Big British Election Win
text: PAISLEY, Scotland — When the results were in last September and the Scottish National Party  lost its bid for Scotland’s independence, a spirited young separatist, Mhairi Black, walked past local officials of the Labour Party who were clapping sarcastically and goading her. “Better luck next time,” they said.

headline: Highlights at This Weekend’s Echo Park Craft Fair
text: This weekend, stylish and creatively inclined Angelenos will flock by the thousands to the Echo Park Craft Fair. The biannual event is a showcase for L.A.’s thriving scene of independent designers and artisans, and for a certain type of Los Angeles aesthetic that fuses the handmade and earthy with sophisticated modern design. (We imagine there will be some overlap with last weekend’s Mercado Sagrado fair.) Visitors can shop for Modernist-inspired ceramics (Mt. Washington Pottery; BZippy & Co.), unusual cacti (The Cactus Store), jewelry and objets such as rocks from the L.A. River wrapped in strands of leather (Matthew Ready), ideal for decorating their (real or imagined) Craftsman bungalows.

headline: In Alex Rodriguez’s Big Moments, Yankees Start to Look Small
text: I live in what I call the New York Yankees historical baseball district.

headline: On England’s Coast, Thomas Hardy Made His World
text: It was in Lulwind Cove, an inlet on England’s south coast, that the dastardly Sergeant Troy took an impromptu swim in “Far From the Madding Crowd,” Thomas Hardy’s 1874 novel about an uncommonly independent Victorian woman and her suitors. The water in the cove was “smooth as a pond,” Hardy wrote, until Troy “swam between the two projecting spurs of rock which formed the pillars of Hercules to this miniature Mediterranean,” whereupon he was swept out to sea and presumed drowned, only to make a dramatic reappearance — this being a Hardy novel — at a most inconvenient moment.

headline: National Sawdust, a New Concert Hall, to Open in Williamsburg in October
text: The transformation of a century-old sawdust factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, into a new music center is nearly complete: organizers said Friday that the hall, National Sawdust, would open this fall and host three concerts in the New York Philharmonic’s Contact! series.

headline: China and Russia Honor WWII Relations
text: President Xi Jinping of China met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday, a day before the 70th anniversary celebration of Victory Day in Moscow.

headline: Paperback Row
text: ON THE RUN: Fugitive Life in an American City, by Alice Goffman. (Picador, $16.) This is a closely observed study of the criminal justice system’s impact on life in a poor black Philadelphia neighborhood. Goffman, a sociologist, spent six years in a community she calls 6th Street, documenting the routine police stops, raids and beatings that young men navigate. “The level of detail in this book and Goffman’s ability to understand her subjects’ motivations are astonishing,” Alex Kotlowitz wrote here.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘A God in Ruins’
text: This week, Tom Perrotta discusses Kate Atkinson’s “A God in Ruins”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Ruth Franklin talks about Shirley Jackson; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘A God in Ruins’
text: This week, Tom Perrotta and Ruth Franklin.

headline: ‘Sounds Like Music: The Films of Martín Rejtman’ at Lincoln Center
text: “Sounds Like Music: The Films of Martín Rejtman,” a retrospective of work by the Argentine filmmaker at Lincoln Center, Wednesday through May 19, will culminate with a weeklong run of his newest film, “Two Shots Fired,” a comedy about a 16-year-old boy, Mariano, who survives self-inflicted gunshot wounds to his stomach and head. Although he suffers from auditory disturbances, he is otherwise barely injured. From the seemingly unmotivated suicide attempt, the absurdist movie radiates outward to observe the foibles of family members and friends, who like Mariano, act on impulse.

headline: Yve Laris Cohen at the Kitchen
text: In the work of Yve Laris Cohen, choreography often takes the form of construction: walls and floors being built, transported, taken apart. Traversing the worlds of dance and visual art, Mr. Laris Cohen is interested in their architectural spaces, the nature of black boxes and white cubes. Recently at St. Mark’s Church, he assembled and disassembled, over several nights, a portable stage belonging to New York City Ballet.

headline: Carnegie Hall Has Big Week Planned
text: Lovers of great orchestras, opera singers and pianists may want to claim a seat at Carnegie Hall for three consecutive nights this week. On Thursday, Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the superb young music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, brings that storied ensemble to the hall for Nico Muhly’s “Mixed Messages,” Beethoven’s Third Piano Concerto (with the eminent Emanuel Ax as soloist) and Rachmaninoff’s rhapsodic Third Symphony. (8 p.m., Thursday, 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: Isabella Boylston on Treasuring ‘Giselle’ and Trusting Herself
text: Some years are so full of happy transformation that they seem conjured from a fortuneteller’s hopeful reading. In 2014, the ballerina Isabella Boylston had one of those years. She danced her first Giselle, magnificently, with American Ballet Theater and was promoted to principal soon after. She got married. “He’s not a dancer,” Ms. Boylston said, flashing a smile. “He works in finance.” And she performed as a guest artist at the Mariinsky Ballet and the Royal Danish Ballet. “You show up, and they’re expecting you to be this prima ballerina,” she said. “So you just have to fill the shoes.”

headline: Pop Music Catches Up to Shamir
text: NORTH LAS VEGAS, NEV. — On the small patio at the far-from-it-all apartment here that the singer Shamir shares with two friends, an ashtray sat on a small table, though you could barely see it underneath the lava flow of cigarette butts erupting out of it. He was perched on a high chair, puffing his way through a Maverick, lamenting the disarray, and also passing the buck.

headline: Monitoring the Metropolitan Opera’s Vital Signs
text: In news reports over the past year, the Metropolitan Opera has come across as an ailing patient, its costs and revenues spiraling in opposite directions. While many observers agree that the company’s financial model is unsustainable, at least in the long term, there’s far more disagreement about the quality of its performances. At the beginning of the 2014-15 season, which ends on Saturday, I resolved to take the Met’s artistic temperature by attending, as I never had before, all of the operas it presented — 26 this year — at least once each and often more. I tried to catch notable newcomers and cast changes, to move beyond the premieres and big stars to see how things are faring on those ordinary nights that are an opera house’s lifeblood.

headline: Freddie Highmore on ‘Bates Motel’
text: Season 3 of A&E’s “Bates Motel,” which has its finale Monday night at 9, has been transformative for young Norman Bates. And not just figuratively.

headline: Race and Gender in Black and White
text: The South African photographer Zanele Muholi, born in Durban in 1972, specializes in portraiture of a particular kind: Almost all of her subjects are members of South Africa’s lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex communities. Early on, combining political activism and art, she began in 2002 documenting hate crimes against gays. In 2007, she initiated the portrait series, which is ongoing and forms the centerpiece of “Zanele Muholi: Isibonelo/Evidence” at the Brooklyn Museum, her largest solo show in the United States.

headline: Della Mae and Kris Davis Release New Music
text: Della Mae

headline: The Economy and the British Election
text: Just a reminder: The overwhelming evidence for US elections is that they are not judgements of an administration’s overall performance — they are driven by the rate of growth just ahead of the election, as in the chart above (taken from Larry Bartels.) (Any pointers to UK-specific work along the same lines would be welcome.) I’ve also put in the closest growth number I could get to the one Bartels uses for the US, taken from the ONS.

headline: The Curious Case of Negative Interest Rates
text: Anthony Scaramucci is founder and co-managing partner of global investment firm SkyBridge Capital and host of the television program “Wall Street Week.”

headline: B.B. King, in Hospice Care at Home, Is Focus of Court Battle
text: B.B. King, the esteemed bluesman, who at 89 is currently in hospice care at his home in Las Vegas, will for now remain under the guardianship of his longtime manager, Laverne Toney, despite claims of abuse by three of Mr. King’s children, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Stop-Go Austerity and Self-Defeating Recoveries
text: Sometimes good things happen to bad ideas. Actually, it happens all the time. Britain’s election results came as a surprise, but they were consistent with the general proposition that elections hinge not on an incumbent’s overall record but on whether things are improving in the six months or so before the vote. Cameron and company imposed austerity for a couple of years, then paused, and the economy picked up enough during the lull to give them a chance to make the same mistakes all over again.

headline: In Paris, Craft Cocktails Sidle Up to the Bar
text: PARIS — On the menu at Mabel, a rum-focused bar in the Second Arrondissement, is a section titled “Mabel’s Recommendations.” It lists the names and addresses of nearly 30 other cocktail bars in Paris.

headline: How Labour Gained Votes but Still Lost Seats
text: Thursday’s election in Britain was great for the Conservatives and terrible for Labour — so terrible that Labour’s leader, Ed Miliband, is stepping down. Yet Mr. Miliband has something to brag about: Not only did Labour take a larger share of the vote this week than it did in 2010, but it also improved its vote share by substantially more than the victorious Conservatives did.

headline: Queen Latifah Stars in ‘Bessie’ on HBO
text: Within the first 10 minutes of “Bessie,” HBO’s new biopic of Bessie Smith, we see the blues legend sing, cry, dance, cut a man and kiss, lustily, both men and women. The drinking comes later, but not much. At a party at the home of Carl Van Vechten, the Harlem Renaissance patron and gadfly, a soused Bessie, played by Queen Latifah, belts the anthem “Work House Blues,” to an audience including Langston Hughes, then throws a drink in the host’s face when he uses a racial epithet.

headline: Chinese Debate the Meaning of Alan Mak’s Election to the British Parliament
text: For the first time ever, an ethnic Chinese has been elected to the British Parliament. But the new Conservative Party member for Havant, in southern England, has downplayed that aspect of his victory in Thursday’s general election.

headline: A Rebound in Hiring
text: Employers in the United States added 223,000 jobs in April. Sectors like construction and health care did well, while the oil and gas category fared poorly.

headline: On the French Riviera, Fitzgerald Found His Place in the Sun
text: Unless you happen to be on a billionaire’s yacht requiring a deepwater port or are a paparazzo stalking Leonardo DiCaprio along the Riviera, you might have no reason to find yourself near Antibes or its charming little sister village, Juan-les-Pins, on a summer evening. And that would be unfortunate, because among the legendary diversions of Cap d’Antibes is exploring the rocky playground peninsula on the French Riviera that inspired one of America’s greatest writers.

headline: On Medicare and Assessing the Value of Lung Cancer Screening
text: You smoked for years. Maybe you still do. Now that Medicare promises to begin covering lung cancer screening, should you sign up?

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York City region:

headline: Liberia, Ravaged by Ebola, Faces a Future Without It
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — When a taxi dropped off a man dying of Ebola one evening in June 2014, the Logan Town clinic was defenseless.

headline: New York Archdiocese Will Close 7 More Churches
text: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced on Friday the shuttering of seven more churches as part of the biggest reorganization in its history, a process of parish consolidations that will leave the archdiocese 20 percent smaller than it was last year.

headline: Illinois Supreme Court Rejects Lawmakers’ Pension Overhaul
text: CHICAGO — The Illinois Supreme Court on Friday rejected changes that legislators made to fix a deeply troubled public pension system, leaving the state where it had started — with a significant budget crisis, a vastly underfunded pension program and no plan in sight.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: Families Share Stories of Raising Transgender Kids
text: Roughly a year ago, a California couple posted a video on YouTube about their child, Ryland Whittington.

headline: Nine Rooms in the San Remo for $20.75 Million
text: A nine-room apartment on the 16th floor of the venerable San Remo that was owned for more than three decades by Robert W. Wilson, a hedge fund pioneer and philanthropist, sold for $20,750,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: The Classic, Trendy and Elevated Sides of a White Port and Tonic
text: Rising in popularity along with aperitifs like vermouth and sherry is white port — the drier, bittersweet cousin of red. Mixed with tonic, it makes for an unexpectedly bracing yet refreshing spring cocktail that’s lower in proof than a classic gin and tonic, but with more kick than a wine spritzer.

headline: Ben Carson Bucks G.O.P. and Backs Raising Minimum Wage
text: Ben Carson has adopted many positions that align closely with conservative orthodoxy, supporting a flat tax not to exceed 15 percent and going so far as to urge the elimination of not only the Internal Revenue Service, but also Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: Investors Choose Bojangles’ Over Shake Shack
text: Fried chicken is in and “modern-day roadside” burgers are out — at least on Wall Street.

headline: Anticipating a Crowd, Milan’s Cathedral Undergoes a Restoration
text: For Milan’s Duomo, beauty has its price. The city’s massive Gothic cathedral, on which construction began in 1386, is undergoing a restoration, and the marble that provides its celebrated luster is a particular challenge.

headline: Unless You Are Spock, Irrelevant Things Matter in Economic Behavior
text: Early in my teaching career I managed to get most of the students in my class mad at me. A midterm exam caused the problem.

headline: Post-Election Britain: A Disunited Kingdom
text: LONDON — One of the most anodyne election campaigns in living memory has left Britain with a result that few expected — and one that could transform Britain both internally and externally. This was an election that recast the political geography of Britain. It may redraw the boundaries of the nation. And it raises questions about the future shape of the European Union.

headline: Tony Awards: Getting to Know You
text: Portraits of Tony Award-nominated actors.

headline: The Red Bull Music Academy Festival Arrives
text: The Red Bull Music Academy Festival offers three full-scale genre immersions this week: in dancehall, noise and what might be called avant-garde ambience. The first is free: on Sunday at 1 p.m. at Fort Greene Park, where “Yardcore: Brooklyn Bashment,” savors the connections between Jamaica and New York. It features King Jammy, the Jamaican producer whose collaboration with Wayne Smith on “Under Mi Sleng Teng” gave dancehall a new electronic sound. A six-hour marathon of noise — as assault, experiment, improvisation, torment and catharsis — features Merzbow, Pharmakon, Prurient and Genesis P-Orridge (performing the Psychic TV album “Electric Newspapers”) at 10 p.m. Wednesday at Output, 74 Wythe Avenue, Williamsburg. On Friday, Tri Angle Records celebrates its fifth anniversary with nine acts including Haxan Cloak, Forest Swords and Evian Christ. They’re primarily electronic musicians creating soundscapes that can be darkly immersive and push you around; 10 p.m., 23 Wall Street, redbullmusicacademy.com.

headline: Review: Joan Jonas’s Venice Biennale Pavilion Is a Triumph
text: VENICE — Performance art is a young person’s sport, most often pursued in heat, often accompanied by sensationalism and abandoned as stamina fades. But, at 78, Joan Jonas has avoided all of the above, quietly but determinedly elaborating performance into an immersive multimedia art form that has sustained her for more than five decades.

headline: Hepatitis C Drugs Added to W.H.O. List of Essential Medicines
text: The World Health Organization put five new hepatitis C drugs on its essential medicines list for the first time on Friday, including drugs that cost $1,000 a pill or more in wealthy countries. The new drugs are ground-breaking because they usually cure quickly with minimal side effects.

headline: Tina Fey’s ‘Letterman’ Farewell, Much Ado About the Maxi Dress and What Price Nails?
text: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Pressure on Sygenta From Monsanto Offer
text: Monsanto is heaping pressure on Syngenta.

headline: Art Imitates Life as ‘The Audience’ Gets a New Post-Election Scene
text: LONDON — The Conservatives have won; David Cameron has been called to see the Queen before forming a new government. That happened on Friday morning here, and was to happen again onstage Friday evening in a hot-off-the-press new scene in “The Audience,” which offers a fictional account of the meetings between Queen Elizabeth II and her prime ministers over the 63 years of her reign.

headline: In Time for Memorial Day, Atlantic City Attempts a Turnaround
text: Since it arrived in 1978, casino gambling has been the engine driving Atlantic City’s economy.

headline: First Draft Focus: A High-Flying Celebration for V-E Day
text: World War II aircraft flew past the Washington Monument on Friday, the 70th anniversary of the Victory in Europe. or V-E Day, part of the Arsenal of Democracy Capitol flyover.

headline: Trout Fishing in Iceland
text: The sporting outfitter Frontiers International Travel recently introduced a website dedicated to fishing in Iceland, one of the most highly regarded wild trout and char destinations in the world.

headline: Russia and China Sign Cooperation Pacts
text: MOSCOW — On the eve of a celebration commemorating to the defeat of Nazi Germany, the presidents of Russia and China on Friday signed 32 bilateral agreements designed to highlight the warming of relations between the countries even as Russia’s have soured with the West.

headline: Strained Ties With Israel
text: How will Israel's new government, probably the most right-wing in its history, affect relations with the United States and American peace efforts?

headline: No Comment Necessary: Saving Students From Learning About Evolution
text: Mack Butler, a state legislator from Alabama, has introduced a bill that would “allow public school teachers to help students understand, analyze, critique, and review the scientific strengths and scientific weaknesses of all existing scientific theories covered in a science course.” If you’re confused about what that might mean, Raw Story has found this helpful explanation on Mr. Butler’s Facebook page:

headline: Salman Khan, Bollywood Star, Is Allowed to Remain Free on Bail in India
text: NEW DELHI — A Mumbai court on Friday ruled that the Bollywood actor Salman Khan would be allowed to remain free on bail until it hears his appeal of his conviction in a drunken-driving hit-and-run case.

headline: Australian Football Visits U.S. in Search of Basketball Big Men
text: BRADENTON, Fla. — Jalen Carethers, four weeks removed from his final game as a basketball player at Radford, was at a loss. Sports had always come easily to him, but now he was standing in the middle of a multipurpose field at IMG Academy, cradling an oblong ball in his hands and doing his best to figure out how to make this foreign object fly.

headline: All Aboard: The Luxe Boat
text: Luxurious cruise lines have been around since 1900, when the German designer Albert Ballin created Prinzessin Victoria Luise, but the newly unveiled Regent Seven Seas Explorer is gaining attention, touting itself as the most luxurious cruise ship ever. It is set to make its 14-night maiden voyage in July 2016, from Monte Carlo to Venice, the latest entrant in the busy category of high-end cruises.

headline: Bonding in a Show of Unity
text: New York police officers paid their respects to Officer Brian Moore, who was shot and killed in Queens.

headline: Saudi Arabia Announces Cease-Fire in Yemen
text: PARIS — Saudi Arabia announced on Friday that it would halt its bombing campaign in Yemen for five days beginning on Tuesday, in a sign that it was bowing to international pressure to ease a worsening humanitarian crisis in a country battered by weeks of war.

headline: Democrats Relish Hillary Clinton’s Embrace of Cultural Issues
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s call this week for more expansive action on immigration was the latest in a series of policy statements likely to appeal to her party’s liberal base. But her comments also reflect a growing feeling among Democrats that the political balance on cultural issues has shifted in their favor since her last campaign.

headline: In Venice, Plenty to See Beyond the Pavilions
text: The 56th Venice Biennale officially opens on Saturday, but La Serenissima has already been saturated by the international art world for almost a week — previews, parties and canal-navigating ad infinitum. One absolutely ephemeral and unintentional piece of performance art made headlines when, on Wednesday, acqua alta knocked a pontoon-load of well-heeled guests entering the Fondazione Prada into the water (or was it Miuccia’s ingenious interpretation of a trap door for gatecrashers?). Don’t fret if you missed it; there are plenty of other extra-Biennale highlights scattered throughout the city.

headline: Tempur Sealy Shareholders Vote to Remove C.E.O. and Chairman From Board
text: Spurred by an activist investor, shareholders of Tempur Sealy International voted on Friday to overhaul the mattress maker’s board, including by stripping the company’s chief executive of a director seat.

headline: When a City Stops for Soccer
text: On Sunday, New York will get its own derby when the city’s two Major League Soccer teams, New York City F.C. and the Red Bulls, meet for the first time. So to preview this one, we asked veterans of other derbies to share their memories.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Kate Atkinson’s ‘A God in Ruins’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Tom Perrotta reviews Kate Atkinson’s new novel, “A God in Ruins.” Mr. Perrotta writes:

headline: U2 Prepares to Go on Tour
text: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss U2 and “Songs of Innocence” as the group heads out on a world tour.

headline: The Insurance That Poses a Hidden Threat
text: Another financial crisis is inevitable, the only question is what will ignite it.

headline: Lynch Announces Baltimore Investigation
text: Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch announced Friday that the Department of Justice would open a civil rights investigation into the Baltimore Police Department.

headline: Homemade Pasta
text: Melissa Clark makes fresh pasta with flour, salt, eggs and olive oil

headline: Officials Threaten to Close Mosque Installation at Venice Biennale
text: VENICE — A provocative art installation in the form of a functioning mosque opened here on Friday for prayers, attended by dozens of Muslim worshipers who were outnumbered through much of the day by art spectators crowding the city for the 56th Venice Biennale.

headline: Verbatim: Obama Makes the Case for Trade Pact
text: – President Obama, speaking about the Pacific free-trade pact at Nike headquarters in Beaverton, Ore.

headline: Fresh Pasta, Made Simply
text: The myth that you need to be an Italian grandmother to make great pasta was so ingrained in Anna Klinger that when she went to Italy as a young cook to study the craft, she assumed it would take years to master.

headline: As a Plant Nears Completion, Croton Water Flows Again to New York City
text: Water from the Croton watershed — historically the cradle of New York’s supply — began flowing to taps on Thursday for the first time in seven years, officials announced, as one of the largest construction projects in the city’s modern history neared completion.

headline: ‘More Like a Book Launch’ — The Times’s Push to Build Buzz for Its Nail Salon Series
text: The Times’s series of stories on the abused and underpaid young women who are the employees of New York City’s omnipresent nail salons has hit big since it appeared online Thursday.

headline: Jurors in Etan Patz Case Fall One Vote Shy of a Conviction
text: A judge declared a mistrial in the Etan Patz case on Friday after jurors said for a third time that they could not reach a verdict despite three weeks of deliberation, leaving unresolved a missing-child case that vexed New York City for decades and led to a sea change in the way Americans view the security of their children.

headline: Mother’s Day Brunch
text: Do your home chefs need a little help with Mother’s Day brunch? Martha Rose Shulman offers these delicious crepes you can make in advance, and let the little ones put them together for your well deserved Mother’s Day meal. If your better half is handy in the kitchen, suggest these other delicious recipes to celebrate the day.

headline: On Breast Milk and High-Impact Journalism
text: What is the true afterlife of an article, in readers’ minds and in their actions?

headline: A Reading of “Ruin” by Mark Bibbins
text: An American poet meditates on the short life of actress Candy Darling.

headline: What I Love | Michael A. Clinton
text: The president for marketing and publishing director of Hearst Magazines lives in an apartment filled with mementos of his travels.

headline: In Battle of Ex-Obama Aides in Britain, Jim Messina Bests David Axelrod
text: Two former Obama campaign aides spent the last year going head-to-head as strategists in Britain, with Jim Messina working for Prime Minister David Cameron of the Conservative Party and David Axelrod representing Ed Miliband, who stepped down Friday as the Labour Party leader.

headline: Why the New York Fed Should Not Be Reined In
text: David Zaring is associate professor of legal studies at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: Popcast: U2 Prepares to Go on Tour
text: U2 will shortly begin its next world tour, with a physically damaged lead singer and after the release of “Songs of Innocence,” a record whose influence was, as Jon Pareles puts it, “uncertain.”

headline: At Home With Michael A. Clinton of Hearst Magazines
text: You could call Michael A. Clinton an escape artist.

headline: Mylan’s Too-Harsh Takeover Defense
text: If etiquette counts in deal-making, Miss Manners would not be happy with Mylan’s heated attempt to fight off a $40 billion unsolicited bid by Teva Pharmaceutical Industries.

headline: Making Play Streets Mean Streets
text: In December, two days after Wenjian Liu and Rafael Ramos from the 84th Precinct in Brooklyn were killed in a squad car by a man who had come from Baltimore having declared a violent will toward the police, Mayor Bill de Blasio spoke at a luncheon for the Police Athletic League. The league by then could trace its roots 100 years, having begun in 1914 when Police Commissioner Arthur Woods, an advocate for the poor who worried about the effects of tenement life on children, set about searching for vacant lots that could be converted to playgrounds.

headline: Conservative Party Wins Surprising Victory in Britain’s General Election
text: The result defies pre-election opinion polls that suggested a tight race between the Tories and Labour, and it gives Mr. Cameron a second term as prime minister.

headline: The Immigration Bidding War
text: Hillary Clinton’s big immigration speech earlier this week, in which she endorsed not only comprehensive reform in general but a future executive amnesty that goes where even President Obama’s Office of Legal Counsel said a president can’t legally go, is being greeted by liberal pundits and over-wrought Republicans alike as a potentially brilliant political move, one that puts G.O.P. presidential candidates in a very difficult position, trapped as ever between the need to reach out to Hispanics and the demands of their base. New York Magazine’s Jonathan Chait, for instance, argues that the Republican contenders have been trying to maintain some strategic ambiguity on immigration, which is harder the more explicit Hillary gets:

headline: Russian Court Sentences Ex-Official to 5 Years in Prison in Corruption Case
text: MOSCOW — A Russian court on Friday sentenced a former Defense Ministry contractor to five years in prison after a corruption investigation led to a major shake-up in the ministry and prompted President Vladimir V. Putin to fire Anatoly E. Serdyukov as defense minister in 2012.

headline: Caroll Spinney, Big Bird’s Heart and Soul (and Body)
text: Twenty-five years ago this month, Caroll Spinney, the puppeteer who has played Big Bird on “Sesame Street” since 1969, was invited to sing at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. The occasion was Jim Henson’s funeral.

headline: A Harlem Townhouse, a Sentimental Journey
text: It may not seem so to outsiders, but New York City is really a collection of small towns with residents and businesses connected in the most surprising ways. Just ask David Daniels.

headline: A Club Lingers On
text: The Ziegfeld Club, founded in 1936, outlasted the women it was formed to help. It is ready for an encore.

headline: Rediscovering the Ziegfeld Club and Its Showgirls
text: The mysterious business card was tucked into one of the vitrines at the Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Manhattan, where rare costume pieces from the “Follies,” the revue staged by the impresario Florenz Ziegfeld Jr. from 1913 to 1927, are on display. Bent and coated with dust, it bore the words “The Ziegfeld Club, Inc.” and offered several telephone numbers and an address on Park Avenue.

headline: A Relationship That Has Nothing to Do With Politics
text: Julissa Ferreras, a New York City councilwoman, and Aaron Copeland, an aerospace engineer, were married by Mayor Bill de Blasio at City Hall in Manhattan.

headline: It’s Not a ‘Stream’ of Consciousness
text: IN 1890, the American psychologist William James famously likened our conscious experience to the flow of a stream. “A ‘river’ or a ‘stream’ are the metaphors by which it is most naturally described,” he wrote. “In talking of it hereafter, let’s call it the stream of thought, consciousness, or subjective life.”

headline: It’s Called Love, Not Rocket Science
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York is known for being able to read the political tea leaves, but even he admits that he misread Councilwoman Julissa Ferreras, a Democrat from Queens.

headline: David Cameron’s Challenge
text: A strong showing by an incumbent party usually brings stability and continuity. That, at least, is how the markets read the unexpected and decisive victory by Prime Minister David Cameron’s Conservative Party in Britain’s general election on Thursday. The pound and stock prices had quick bounces. Further down the line, however, this election may prove to be a fateful turning point for British and European unity.

headline: Do a Little Dance, Have a Little Fish
text: At Astoria Seafood, an unusual pairing of market and restaurant in Long Island City, Queens, dancing may break out at any time.

headline: Dancing With the Fishes at a Restaurant in Queens
text: “Let’s dance!” a waitress said one Friday at Astoria Seafood. It was a relatively quiet night, which means the wait for a table was only 25 minutes. The waitress, Elena Faroupos, 56, her eyes glamorously lined with a cheerful shade of green, threw her hands in the air and spun elegantly as Spyro Christakos, the owner, turned up the bouncy, brassy sounds of Greek music from behind the cash register.

headline: Review: Arlo Hill, Always in Love With Loesser
text: The charismatic theater singer Arlo Hill aimed for the bull’s-eye in his Frank Loesser tribute, “I’ve Been in Love Before,” on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room. The 28-year-old performer, accompanied on piano by Rick Hip-Flores, didn’t merely sing the work of the songwriter who turned Broadway on its ear 65 years ago with “Guys and Dolls.” He became Loesser’s champion and surrogate, punching out his songs in the brash, unpretty voice of a scrappy, streetwise rebel against the polite, polished musical theater of Rodgers and Hammerstein.

headline: First Manhattan Condo by a Chinese Developer
text: A 38-story tower rising on a busy block in Midtown is being billed as the first condominium project in Manhattan developed entirely by a company from China.

headline: A Review of StreetEasy’s Mobile App for Apple and Android
text: A little more than a year ago, I reviewed an app called Movement, writing that it was the best service I had found for searching for apartment rentals on the smartphone. That a bootstrapped and relatively flawed app could be the best option spoke to the fact that big players had yet to fully enter the space, and as many could have predicted, Movement’s lead did not last long.

headline: Review: ‘NewYorknewyork @Astor Place,’ a Multilayered Production
text: Stacked books arranged like city blocks fill the diminutive stage of Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater. The book covers are white; there are no titles. Instead, the names of writers are projected against the back wall as a voice reads aloud: Samuel Beckett, Mark Twain, Upton Sinclair, Grace Paley. A feather-slim woman, Mei Yamanaka, winds around the stacks with nimble pliés and razor-sharp turns until her legs and arms turn deadly, and she demolishes the literary landscape. (Make way for e-readers.)

headline: A Loan Modification Program’s Limited Reach
text: A federal inspector is taking the Treasury Department to task for not doing enough to increase participation in the government’s Home Affordable Modification Program, known as HAMP, which helps keep homeowners out of foreclosure. Borrowers having trouble paying their mortgage can apply to HAMP for a loan modification that lowers their monthly payment. So far, about 1.5 million homeowners have received HAMP modifications, about half as many as originally predicted by the Treasury. The department has repeatedly extended the program’s initial December 2013 deadline; HAMP now is scheduled to expire in December 2016.

headline: Obama Speaks at Nike Headquarters
text: The president selected the Oregon site for a speech to promote the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Nike says it will manufacture more products in the United States if the deal is adopted.

headline: What I Missed (Personal and Meta)
text: My new office at the CUNY Graduate Center is small — so is my Princeton office, but it has more shelf space, not to mention enough books stacked on the floor to get me warnings from the fire marshal. So I’m culling my three-and-a-half decade collection drastically. The picture above shows the books I put out to be taken away today, which was day three; the books from the previous two days have already been taken away, and I expect to need all weekend to finish.

headline: Review: ‘The Road of Promise,’ Warning to All About Jews in Germany
text: Anonymity in the performing arts is usually restricted to publicity-shy donors. But on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall, it was the Voice of God that remained elusive, a booming tenor attributed only to “Anonymous” in the program for Kurt Weill’s “The Road of Promise.”

headline: Unbreakable Bonds in the Folds of a Wedding Dress
text: When Olivia Krieger went shopping for a wedding dress last July, she was only 15 years old.

headline: Review: Tectonics Festival New York Takes Wing at a Church Setting
text: In the vast sanctuary of the First Unitarian Congregational Society in Brooklyn Heights on Thursday, with the lights dimmed to a sepulchral shadowiness, the music seemed as simmering and enveloping as a primordial ritual. “Immersion” was the title of the first piece, by Annea Lockwood, but it could just as easily have been applied to the other five works, too.

headline: At Castellano’s House of Music, Instruments to Sell and Stories to Hear
text: John Castellano, 68, who owns Castellano’s House of Music on Staten Island, was segueing between stories — from how he lent amplifiers to Jimi Hendrix, to how he became the only white member of the Chambers Brothers — when a customer began bargaining him down on a 40-watt Marshall amplifier.

headline: The Trophy Life: Winning in Golf Is Only the Beginning
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The moment Martin Kaymer walked into the room Wednesday and saw the crystal trophy seated at the table, he beamed as if he had been reunited with a lost love. At last year’s Players Championship, Kaymer embraced it, posed for photographs with it. He may have even kissed it. And then he traveled home to Germany without it.

headline: Surviving Remnants of the Village of Flatbush
text: Q. Does anything remain from the Village of Flatbush from before the American Revolution, aside from the Dutch Reformed Church?

headline: Airport Security Advances Clash With Privacy Issues
text: BOSTON — At a mock airport in an underground laboratory here at Northeastern University, students pretending to be passengers head through a security exit in the right direction, while a young man enters going the wrong way. On a nearby computer screen, a newly developed video surveillance software program flags the wayward person and sounds an alarm.

headline: Credit Cards With 2% Rebates, While (or if) They Last
text: For years, the holy grail for many seekers of credit card rewards has been a guaranteed 2 percent back on every dollar they spend.

headline: Unvarnished Series on Nail-Salon Workers: Readers Respond en Espanol
text: Esta semana The New York Times solicitó comentarios en español con el fin de reunir las reacciones a un trabajo de investigación, publicado en dos partes, que mostró las condiciones de trabajo de las manicuristas en salones de uñas en Nueva York.

headline: Unvarnished Series on Nail-Salon Workers: Readers Respond in 한국어 (Hangug-ui)
text: 뉴욕타임스 역사상 처음으로 한국어로 기사가 번역돼 독자들에게 소개됐습니다. 동시에 한국어를 사용하는 독자들의 의견을 묻는 것도 뉴욕타임스로서는 첫 시도입니다.이번 기사는 한인사회가 주축이 된 네일 업계를 다루고 있습니다. 그래서 한국어를 사용하는 독자들이 각별한 관심을 보이고 있는 것 같습니다.현재까지 뉴욕타임스에 접수된 한국어 독자들의 의견은 ‘부끄럽다’와 ‘기사가 다소 과장됐다’는 내용으로 팽팽하게 맞서고 있습니다.

headline: Grand Army, a New Seafood Bar in Brooklyn
text: Grand Army, which opened on Tuesday evening in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn, represents the coming-of-age of the neighborhood’s restaurants — a cocktail bar with only small plates, and nothing repurposed in sight. It’s also the coming-of-age of some restaurateurs: Noah Bernamoff of Mile End and Julian Brizzi of Rucola, who teamed up with a longtime Prime Meats bar director, Damon Boelte, to open in what was once the chrome-plated Victory Cafe. (The fourth partner, Daniel Krieger, is a photographer who contributes to The New York Times and other publications.)

headline: Millepied to Take On ‘Vertigo’ at Cannes
text: Dance will be on the program of the official opening of the Cannes Film Festival on Wednesday at the Palais des Festivals. Benjamin Millepied, the director of the Paris Opera Ballet, will present a five-minute piece, set to a section of Bernard Hermann’s music for Alfred Hitchcock’s “Vertigo.”

headline: Unvarnished Series on Nail Salon Workers: Readers Respond in English
text: Reader reaction was incredibly strong to “Unvarnished,” the two-part investigative report by Sarah Maslin Nir that found many manicurists in the New York area endure questionable labor practices and potential health risks in the workplace.

headline: Traces of Ziegfeld’s New York
text: A century ago, Broadway actors spoke of a “Ziegfeld Curse,” because so many of Florenz Ziegfeld Jr.’s famous showgirls came to tragic ends. In the generations since the impresario’s death in 1932, New Yorkers might be forgiven for thinking that there is also a curse on anything to do with Ziegfeld’s memory. His lavish theater on Sixth Avenue was demolished in 1966, and now the owners of the Ziegfeld Theater, the world’s largest single screen cinema, built near the site of the original, have considered closing it, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

headline: Spotify’s Revenue Is Growing, but So Are Its Losses
text: As streaming music has spread around the world, Spotify’s financial picture has remained much the same year after year: rapid revenue growth, with steady losses.

headline: Myrna Blyth, AARP Executive, and Her Sunday Routine
text: No offense to our nation’s capital, but for Myrna Blyth, who lives there Mondays through Thursdays, it is just not home. Home is where she spends her Sundays, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where she has lived in the same huge apartment for four decades. Ms. Blyth, 76, is a senior vice president at AARP and the editorial director of AARP Media. After three years of commuting, she is struck by the differences between the two cities. “There are more people on the street in New York at 10 o’clock on an O.K. evening than there are in Washington on any day but the inaugural,” she said. One draw Washington has for Ms. Blyth is her “adorable 5-year-old grandson,” who lives there, as does her son Jonathan. Her “beautiful redheaded granddaughter” and her other son, Graham, live in Portland, Me. For Mother’s Day, she and Jonathan plan to be in Manhattan together.

headline: U.S. Urges Openness From Hedge Funds, an Industry Not Used to Sharing
text: LAS VEGAS — When John P. Carlin, the head of the Justice Department’s national security division, appealed on Friday to the hedge fund industry to share more information with the government, it was a tough sell.

headline: Review: Pharoah Sanders at Baby’s All Right in Brooklyn
text: The 74-year-old jazz saxophonist Pharoah Sanders played in an unusual context on Wednesday night. He was at Baby’s All Right, the year-and-a-half-old, mostly indie-rock club in Williamsburg, during a slate of bands programmed as a birthday party for the curator, archivist and gallerist Johan Kugelberg, a man with discerning taste and a lot of friends.

headline: New Math for Retirees and the 4% Withdrawal Rule
text: More than two decades ago, Bill Bengen, then a financial planner in Southern California, said he had several anxious clients with the same question: How much can I spend in retirement without running out of money?

headline: What Tom Brady Told Me During Deflategate, and What He Didn’t
text: “I’m always a thinker — I’ve got to outthink them,” Tom Brady told me. It was early January, and I was working on an article for this magazine about “the N.F.L.’s ageless, ruthless, peerless superstar,” as the cover text would read. The New England Patriots quarterback was describing how he had surmounted a history of being overlooked and underestimated. He talked a lot about flouting conventional wisdom throughout his career.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: A Different Shot at the Pros
text: Fifteen athletes gathered in Bradenton, Fla., in April for a three-day scouting combine for the Australian Football League. Curiously, they were all basketball players.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Taking a Stand Solved
text: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve the difficult case of twin sisters who, in the prime of youth, developed a weakness that forced them to use their arms to rise from a chair. Nearly 300 of you wrote in with thoughts on this difficult case.

headline: Bonding in a Show of Unity
text: New York police officers paid their respects to Officer Brian Moore, who had been shot and killed in Queens.

headline: A Hidden Gender Gap for Parents
text: When they become parents, many couples want to share child-care responsibilities equally, says Sarah Schoppe-Sullivan, a professor of human development and family science at Ohio State University. But in a recent study, she found that moms shoulder much more of the additional work when a baby is born — and, perhaps more surprising, that parents aren’t necessarily aware of the discrepancy.

headline: Things to Do in Westchester, May 10 to 16, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: Feedel Band and the Libyans, African Sounds at the Global Beat Festival
text: Vintage 1970s-style funk and ancient Jewish prayers shared the double bill of African music that opened the three-night Global Beat festival at the Winter Garden at Brookfield Place (the former World Financial Center) on Thursday night. It brought together Feedel Band, a Washington group built around musicians from Ethiopia, and the Libyans, a group from Israel that has researched and reconstructed traditional songs from the Jews of Libya.

headline: Grayson Perry Prepares His American Introduction
text: LONDON — “I don’t normally dress up for an interview,” the artist Grayson Perry said, opening the door of his studio. “But I’m going to a Royal Academy council meeting straight afterward.”

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, May 10 to 16, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Pictures of the Day: United States and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the United States, Syria, Ukraine and Britain.

headline: May 8, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from New York, Syria, Ukraine and Germany.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Elton John on Capitol Hill, V-E Day festivities and more.

headline: Frida Kahlo Is Having a Moment
text: She was a genius before she was a refrigerator magnet, an ace manipulator of society and media nearly a century before social media came into existence. Born in 1907, dead at 47, Frida Kahlo achieved celebrity even in her brief lifetime that extended far beyond Mexico’s borders, although nothing like the cult status that would eventually make her the mother of the selfie, her indelible image recognizable everywhere.

headline: Havana Nights
text: To wander through the dimly lit streets of Old Havana after dark is to enter a world of shadows and silhouettes.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Elton John on Capitol Hill, V-E Day festivities and more.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, May 10 to 16, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Debi Mazar’s Talent for Glamour
text: The actress Debi Mazar has often considered the question of what constitutes glamour, and so she had a ready answer as the designer Isabel Toledo zipped her into a tightly fitted black Swiss silk tulle dress frosted with vivid floral embroidery on a recent morning.

headline: Review: New York City Ballet Performs Bournonville Classics at Spring Gala
text: The new double bill at New York City Ballet, choreography by the great Danish ballet master August Bournonville (1805-79), presents the oldest pieces in the company’s repertory. Yet Bournonville’s ideas remain fresh and modern in these dances; and the program shows how today’s performers are challenged, focused and refreshed by them. Apart from one or two over-bright smiles as dancers sail through brilliant series of rapidly beaten jumps, they’re as engaged as if Bournonville himself was watching in the wings. And their steps are stitched, gleamingly and tightly, into their music

headline: A Splashy Entrance by Rihanna Puts Chinese Designers in the Spotlight
text: When Rihanna wore a fur-trimmed yellow satin gown by the Chinese-born designer Guo Pei to the Met Gala on Monday night, it became the talk of Twitter, which erupted with jokey comparisons to omelets and pizzas. Memes using cartoon characters like SpongeBob SquarePants were rampant. “The fashion world pretty much came to a standstill,” Glamour magazine wrote of the “jaw-dropping” cloak, while Time magazine declared that the singer stole the show.

headline: A.J. Jacobs and the World’s Largest Family Reunion
text: A. J. Jacobs, the best-selling author and humorist, was hoping to get former President George H. W. Bush on the telephone for a project involving genealogy. There was only one way to accomplish that, he reasoned: nepotism.

headline: Review: ‘Stockholm, Pennsylvania,’ With Cynthia Nixon, About Life After Release
text: “Stockholm, Pennsylvania” is not your grandmother’s Lifetime movie. Its premise — a woman kidnapped at 4 and kept in a basement for 18 years is reunited with the parents she doesn’t remember — fits the channel’s female-in-extremis profile. But its release pattern is highly unusual: from the Sundance Film Festival in January straight to basic cable in May.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, May 10 to 16, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Angela Simmons Has Her Hands in Everything
text: Age 27

headline: Friday Night Music: San Fermin, Emily
text: An embarrassment of riches this week: a band I didn’t know (DakhaBrakha), new stuff from Lucius, and more. I’ll get there. But after a long period when San Fermin was weirdly lacking in videos showing how great they are live, a bunch have been appearing. And I don’t think I’ve put up a video that features Allen Tate’s fantastic voice. So here we are:

headline: Israeli Identity Among Arabs and Jews
text: Kholood Eid, a child of Palestinian parents, went to Haifa from the United States to explore how Israeli women of different religious and ethnic backgrounds saw themselves.

headline: Evening Hours | Monday Night Dream
text: New York City’s biggest social event of the year and more.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spring Luncheon
text: At the annual event, dress and jacket in blue were favored, as was a dress with a princess line and a flower pattern.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spring Luncheon
text: 1,400 people attended the Frederick Law Olmsted awards luncheon in Central Park, raising $3.6 million. The event honored Anne Harrison and Marty and Michele Cohen. A dress and jacket in blue were favored, as was a dress with a princess line and a flower pattern. Some women wore evening dresses like those with a dipping hem, seen also at a gala in Boston. Fanciful hats abounded.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Nuit de Chine at the Costume Institute: A Sleuth Finds the Formula for a Lost Perfume
text: Nuit de Chine has made a long journey, from a Paris fashion house in 1913 to an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art today.

headline: The Legacy of Etan Patz: Wary Children Who Became Watchful Parents
text: It is there in the quick steps of a woman hurrying up the street in Brooklyn, muttering to herself, “I’m a good parent, I’m a good parent.” She was regretting letting her son run home alone from a restaurant and was rushing to catch up with him.

headline: Nepalese Village, Devastated by Quake, Is Left to Cope as International Attention Shifts
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — There was an unearthly quiet on Friday in Langtang, where the remains of as many as 300 people are believed to be buried under 20 feet of rock and ice that sheared off a mountain during the earthquake that hit Nepal two weeks ago.

headline: Plane Crash on Atlanta Highway
text: A small plane crashed onto an interstate in Atlanta, catching fire and killing all four people on board.

headline: On Mother’s Day, Embrace Embarrassment
text: PARIS — EARLIER this year, I took my kids to see a soccer match in Paris. Along with practically everyone else in the stands, we chanted “Allez les Bleus” — Go Blues — to cheer on the French team.

headline: The Porn Star Sunny Leone’s Bollywood Makeover
text: NEW DELHI — A few weeks ago I went to see a Hindi movie at my local cinema. It was an unremarkable potboiler, a story of thwarted lovers and triumphant love, punctuated with song-and-dance sequences, percussive fisticuffs and the rhythmic hips of a voluptuous heroine.

headline: WWII Aircraft Fly Over National Mall
text: As part of the celebrations on Friday to mark the 70th anniversary of the end of the Second World War, dozens of vintage aircraft from the era flew over the National Mall.

headline: The Labor Picture in April
text: The U.S. economy added 223,000 jobs last month, while the unemployment rate fell to 5.4%, a turnaround from the disappointing performance in March.

headline: Court Ruling on N.S.A.’s Data Collection Jolts Both Defenders and Reformers
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruling that the National Security Agency’s bulk collection of phone records is illegal has scrambled bipartisan efforts to overhaul the program, emboldening those who say the efforts do not go far enough and undermining Senate Republican leaders who want to keep the current program in place.

headline: This Year, Columbia Event Finds Joke Fodder in Sexual Assault Debate
text: With jokes about student protests, a new “sexual respect” requirement and one very famous mattress, a group of Columbia University students early on Friday turned a year of uncomfortable debates about campus sexual assault into fodder for a late-night comedy show.

headline: U.N. Official Accuses France of Delays in Child Sexual Abuse Case
text: UNITED NATIONS — The uproar over allegations of child sexual abuse by French soldiers in Central African Republic spread on Friday, as the United Nations top human rights official accused France of delays in investigating its troops, the United States pressed for an inquiry, and the United Nations faced new scrutiny over the accountability of peacekeepers who exploit civilians they are sent to protect.

headline: White House Moves to Fix 2 Key Consumer Complaints About Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is moving to address two of the most common consumer complaints about the sale of health insurance under the Affordable Care Act: that doctor directories are inaccurate, and that patients are hit with unexpected bills for costs not covered by insurance.

headline: The Police Car Provides a Home on the Job, and a False Sense of Safety
text: The white van matched the description of a vehicle involved in a number of recent robberies, so the two police officers followed, pulling the van over in St. Albans, Queens, that morning.

headline: Dillon Gee Is Out, Noah Syndergaard Is Up, and David Wright Has a Setback
text: The Mets’ pitching has been superb so far in the still-young season, and after six weeks, the team has a comfortable lead in the National League East. But its resurgence has been Metsian: Every time the team seems to be playing well, with momentum going in its direction, bad news follows.

headline: Visa and Visa Europe Are Said to Consider Reunification
text: Visa is in early discussions to reunite with its former European unit, bringing together two businesses that have operated separately for eight years, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: A Wartime Anniversary for Planes and Memories
text: WASHINGTON — The headline act in Washington on Friday was the array of dozens of fighter planes and bombers from World War II that buzzed past the city’s monuments to mark the 70th anniversary of the Allied victory in Europe.

headline: W.H.O. Urges More Care in Naming Diseases
text: No more animal names like swine flu, monkeypox and mad cow. Avoid place names like Spanish flu, Rift Valley fever, West Nile virus, Lyme disease and Ebola (a river in the Democratic Republic of Congo).

headline: Kurdish Leader Agrees to Accept Arms on U.S. Terms in Fight Against ISIS
text: WASHINGTON — The politically charged debate over whether the United States should directly arm Kurdish fighters in their battle against the Islamic State appeared to have been eased on Friday when Massoud Barzani, the president of Iraq’s Kurdish autonomous region, said he was prepared to accept weapons delivery “whatever way the administration chooses.”
