headline: Georgia: Transgender Inmate to Be Transferred
text: The Department of Corrections on Friday gave Ashley Diamond, a transgender inmate and prison rape victim, what a federal judge refused to grant her in April: a transfer to a medium-security prison. The department, which previously maintained that Ms. Diamond was properly placed at Georgia State Prison, transferred her to Jack T Rutledge State Prison after she was touched on the face by another inmate during a group activity and then received a sexually explicit and threatening note from another inmate at a religious service. Ms. Diamond, who has sued corrections officials, charging that they have failed to protect her, had asked the federal judge to order the state to transfer her; he had declined to “second-guess” state authorities. Ms. Diamond, a transgender woman and nonviolent offender, has been housed primarily in men’s maximum-security prisons; her prior stay at Rutledge was the only time during her incarceration that she was not sexually victimized, her lawsuit said.

headline: A Syracuse Lacrosse Team Transformed a Sport, Clung to a Disputed Title and Lost a Trophy
text: The banner still hangs defiantly inside the Carrier Dome, recognizing what many in lacrosse contend was the greatest college team ever.

headline: Confessions of a Major League T-Ball Coach
text: It was an honor, during the off-season, to have been interviewed for a job as a big-league manager of the Tampa Bay Rays. I wasn’t chosen to run their show, so I elected to develop my managerial chops another way. And while I won’t have the luxury of having the Rays’ star third baseman, Evan Longoria, in my lineup, who knows? I may have the future Evan Longoria.

headline: Kevin Na Leaves Yips Behind to Take Share of Lead at Players Championship
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — From his perch in the television tower, David Duval believed he could see inside Tiger Woods’s head on Thursday at the Players Championship. “It looks like he’s thinking about every position through the entire golf swing,” said Duval, who twice supplanted Woods at No. 1 in 1999 for a total of 15 weeks. “That has handcuffed him both physically and between the ears.”

headline: Frustrated Jury in Etan Patz Trial, but No Rancor for the Holdout
text: Three weeks ago, seven men and five women entered a windowless room in a courthouse in Lower Manhattan to decide the fate of Pedro Hernandez, who had confessed to killing 6-year-old Etan Patz decades earlier. After a long trial, they easily dispatched what could have been a vexing issue standing between them and a guilty verdict: the absence of a body.

headline: One Constant for Adam Skelos in a Life of Stumbles: His Powerful Father
text: Adam Skelos jumped from high school to high school, touching down at three in three years. As an employee, he frequently changed jobs and displayed a variable degree of commitment to his work: At least one employer — the re-election campaign of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg — stopped paying him because he stopped showing up for work.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Sets Sights on 3,000 Hits, and a Spot Beside Derek Jeter
text: With No. 661 in the rearview, and the next home run milestone — Babe Ruth’s 714 — well out of reach for the foreseeable future, the next historical marker in Alex Rodriguez’s career is 3,000 hits.

headline: Bryce Petty Is Latest to Board Jets’ Quarterback Carousel
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Turnovers ultimately led to the demise of Mark Sanchez as Jets quarterback. He committed 26 in 2011 — throwing 18 interceptions and losing eight fumbles — before being guilty of the same numbers in the same fashion the following season.

headline: Maurice Flanagan, 86, Dies; Made Dubai a Hub With Emirates Airline
text: Maurice Flanagan, a founding manager of Emirates, the airline that put Dubai on the global map, died on Thursday at his home in London. He was 86.

headline: Ex-Police Chief in Mexico Known for Crackdowns Is Shot
text: MEXICO CITY — The former chief of police in Tijuana and Ciudad Juárez, two border cities that once ranked among the most violent in Mexico but calmed under his tenure, was shot and seriously wound Friday in an attack in Juarez that appeared to be carried out by hit men, the authorities said.

headline: When Humans Declared War on Fish
text: ON Friday we humans observed V-E Day, the end to one part of a global catastrophe that cost the planet at least 60 million lives. But if we were fish, we would have marked the day differently — as the beginning of a campaign of violence against our taxonomic classes, one that has resulted in trillions of casualties.

headline: Too Many People in Jail? Abolish Bail
text: CHICAGO — HOW can we reduce the enormous populations of our country’s local jails?

headline: The Battle for DuPont
text: Though the DuPont Company has been trying to persuade me otherwise, I feel safe in saying that Trian Fund Management is one of the better shareholder activists around. Led by Nelson Peltz, 72, it takes stakes in good companies that, in its view, are struggling operationally. It then seeks board representation, from which vantage point it examines the company from top to bottom and presses the rest of the board to make changes that will raise the stock price.

headline: A Moment to Fix New York’s Housing Laws
text: What a rare opportunity New York has been given, now that the federal prosecutor Preet Bharara has delivered two ferocious kicks to the anthill of Albany, leaving politicians and deal makers dazed and blinking in the light.

headline: Surgeon’s Closing Line
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I’ll tell you exactly what sold me on this puzzle by Kristian House. It was the DOCTOR WHO/BIDET crossing. My day is always made by a reference to the DOCTOR, and the crossing clue for BIDET (“John’s accompanier”) is just fabulous.

headline: The Alamo and Walmart
text: Have you noticed that Utah doesn’t seem to be worried about a military takeover?

headline: Hillary Clinton and the Super Trough
text: Just weeks after her ringing call to “get unaccountable money” out of politics, Hillary Rodham Clinton is reversing course and joining the “super PAC” sweepstakes for unlimited donations from big check writers.

headline: More Assaults on Fair Pay
text: Lawmakers trying to repeal laws that ensure fair pay for workers on publicly financed projects should recall what happened to President George W. Bush. Shortly after Hurricane Katrina hit in 2005, he suspended the law that required contractors to pay the locally prevailing wage on federally financed construction projects. At the time, a truck driver in New Orleans typically made around $9 an hour; an electrician, about $14. Apparently that seemed like too much.

headline: Rookie Andrew Robustelli Brings Familiar Name to Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Andrew Robustelli walked into the Giants’ headquarters and training complex last month, he saw something very familiar.

headline: Obama, Visiting South Dakota, Checks Off 50th State
text: WATERTOWN, S.D. — President Obama checked the final state off his to-do list with pomp and circumstance on Friday as he delivered the commencement address at a community college here, just a bit off the beaten track.

headline: Judge Holds Officers’ Actions in Fatal Shooting Immune, Except for Final Bullet
text: The chaos that surrounded the 2009 death of Mauricio Jaquez, an emotionally disturbed man, in his Bronx apartment, was undisputed: He had threatened his family, and then stabbed with a knife at police officers who had responded, the authorities said. The officers used a Taser and rubber bullets, before shooting him five times with live ammunition, court records show.

headline: Recalling Police Officer at His Funeral
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton spoke at the funeral of Officer Brian Moore, who was fatally shot last Saturday.

headline: Defeat for Matt Harvey, but Not All Is Lost: His Favorite Hockey Team Survives
text: PHILADELPHIA — Matt Harvey had not exactly had a good day at work. He felt off. He struggled stringing together what would normally be typical pitch sequences. He made two critical outs at the plate. He took his first loss in six starts this season. And the Rangers, his favorite hockey team, were heading to overtime in an elimination playoff game.

headline: Craving a Goal, the Rangers Get Two to Beat the Capitals
text: All the Rangers needed was one goal, or else. They had scored twice in their previous nine periods, befuddled by a goaltender stopping pucks like nobody else in these playoffs. They needed it to extend the game, the series, their season.

headline: Australian Teenager Is Accused of Planning Terrorist Attack
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The police on Saturday charged a teenager with planning a terrorist attack after officers found three improvised explosive devices in his home in a suburb of Melbourne.

headline: Andrew Miller Notches 13th Save as Yankees Beat Orioles
text: Since the opening week of the season, Manager Joe Girardi had never acknowledged what was growing more apparent game by game — that Andrew Miller, not Dellin Betances, was the Yankees’ closer.

headline: North Korea Says It Test-Fired Missile From Submarine
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Saturday that it had successfully test-fired a ballistic missile from a submarine.

headline: Derrick Rose’s Buzzer-Beater Gives Bulls a Pivotal Win Over the Cavaliers
text: CHICAGO — As a sustained, deafening roar filled the United Center late Friday night, Derrick Rose jogged the length of the court to the Chicago Bulls’ bench, did a 180-degree leap into the arms of Joakim Noah and rested in his teammate’s embrace for a moment, a blank expression on his face.

headline: Uber Fund-Raising Points to $50 Billion Valuation
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber is fund-raising again.

headline: Rangers Let Henrik Lundqvist Stay on the Ice to Add to His Uncanny Record
text: Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist has been through playoff elimination games so often these last four years, he can probably visualize them in his sleep.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 2 P.M. (FX) WANDERLUST (2012) Jennifer Aniston and Paul Rudd star as Linda and George, out-of-work Manhattanites unable to sell their “microloft” in the West Village. Then they stumble onto Elysium, an “intentional community” in rural Georgia, where good vibrations — and not a little smoke — fill the air. Established decades earlier by Carvin (Alan Alda), now in a wheelchair and battling memory loss, and his hippie friends, the commune is home to a touchy-feely guitar-strumming collage led by Seth (Justin Theroux), a creepy Lothario; and a novelist and nudist (Joe Lo Truglio) who wears the occasional sanitary pouch (like a hairnet, but lower) when he’s crushing grapes for homemade wine. “Part of what gives this movie unexpected resonance is that Linda and George have joined only somewhat voluntarily,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this “mostly funny comedy” from David Wain. “Like other Americans seeking simplicity and maybe a chicken coop out back, they want off the road, at least for a while. There’s something touching about this desire, though Mr. Wain doesn’t let Linda and George fly their freak flags for long.”

headline: Corrections: May 9, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This man did it. He said it. How many times does a man have to confess before someone believes him?”

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Accused of Spying for China, Until She Wasn’t
text: On Monday, Oct. 20, 2014, Sherry Chen drove, as usual, to her office at the National Weather Service in Wilmington, Ohio, where she forecast flood threats along the Ohio River. She was a bit jet-lagged, having returned a few days earlier from a visit to China. But as she headed to her desk, she says, she had no reason to think it was anything other than an ordinary day. Then her boss summoned her.

headline: Legal Marijuana Faces Another Federal Hurdle: Taxes
text: DENVER — Money was pouring into Bruce Nassau’s five Colorado marijuana shops when his accountant called with the bad news: The 2014 tax season was approaching, and Mr. Nassau could not rely on the galaxy of deductions that other businesses use to reduce their tax bills. He was going to owe the Internal Revenue Service a small fortune.

headline: Liberia Is Declared Free of Ebola, but Officials Sound Note of Caution
text: The World Health Organization declared Liberia free of Ebola on Saturday, making it the first of the three hardest-hit West African countries to bring a formal end to the epidemic.

headline: After Wresting Tikrit From ISIS, Iraqis Face Sectarian and Tribal Tensions
text: ALAM, Iraq — The area around the Iraqi city of Tikrit is a panorama of blight, littered with the remnants of battle against the Islamic State: burned-out cars and empty mortar casings, roads made jagged from bombs. At one checkpoint, a militiaman sits with his laptop. At another, there is a pink folder on a table. Inside each are thousands of names of people suspected of being militant fighters or collaborators.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from Central Park to a remote village in Nepal, where a mother mourned the death of her son.

headline: Indonesia President, Joko Widodo, Pardons Prisoners in Papua Province
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The leader of Indonesia on Saturday pardoned five political prisoners in Papua Province as part of an effort to address human rights abuses in the country’s restive eastern region.

headline: Harry Truman’s Extreme Home Makeover
text: If you walked into the White House today, you might think you were entering the mansion whose construction began in the 1790s under the supervision of President George Washington. But in fact, except for the four exterior walls, today’s presidential residence is almost entirely a 1952 imitation of the original.

headline: When Doormen Refuse Deliveries
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Joel Peterson of JetBlue on Listening Without an Agenda
text: This interview with Joel Peterson, chairman of JetBlue Airways and founder of Peterson Partners, an investment firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword Puzzle
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — You have to give Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon credit for at least one thing (actually, we should give them credit for a lot of things, but stay with me here): They really know how to hit the puzzle sweet spot. I don’t think I have ever done a Cox/Rathvon puzzle that I haven’t thoroughly enjoyed.

headline: Thieves Stole Her Money, but Not Her Debit Card
text: The Haggler fears debit cards. They have a direct line to your bank account, which means that a fraudster could drain your savings in a busy afternoon. You would find out only after you visited an A.T.M. and it snickered when you tried to withdraw $20.

headline: The Sweet Science of Syrup
text: Paul Weyant, 30, is a tree tapper for Crown Maple, based in Dover Plains, N.Y.

headline: The Plagiarism Jitters
text: A few years ago, I went out for a night at the opera, right after approving a book review I had written that would soon be sent to the printer, posted on the Internet and generally released into the world.

headline: Veterans Battle for Jobs on the Home Front
text: Recently, in the midst of an effort to persuade store managers to hire veterans, I talked to a human resources executive at a major retail chain. She told me she wanted to do the right thing and hire veterans, but added that she was also concerned by reports that many had returned home with post-traumatic stress disorder and other problems. She worried that a veteran could possibly pose a threat to customers and other employees.

headline: Billionaire Lifts Marco Rubio, Politically and Personally
text: MIAMI — One day in the State Capitol in Tallahassee, Marco Rubio, the young speaker of the House, strayed from the legislative proceedings to single out a lanky, silver-haired man seated in the balcony: a billionaire auto dealer named Norman Braman.

headline: Egyptian Court Upholds Mubarak Verdict
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Saturday reconfirmed a corruption conviction of former President Hosni Mubarak amid signals from the authorities that he may soon be released.

headline: An App That Helps Drivers Earn the Most From Their Trips
text: When Steve Smith began driving for Uber and Lyft several months ago, he concentrated on picking up passengers near his Walnut Creek neighborhood in the San Francisco Bay Area.

headline: Clip From ‘La Sylphide’
text: Sterling Hyltin and Joaquin De Luz of New York City Ballet in August Bournonville’s “La Sylphide,” staged by Peter Martins.

headline: Liberia Conquers Ebola, but Faces a Crisis of Faith
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — It decimated hospitals, schools, families, fortunes and, for many, even their faith.

headline: Fees on Mutual Funds Fall. Thank Yourself.
text: Wall Street is reaping mounting revenue from mutual funds and exchange-traded funds, yet investors are paying lower fees.

headline: Be Direct and Low-Key to Defuse Discord at the Office
text: Unpleasant though it may be, conflict in the workplace is inevitable. In fact, it’s often necessary to get things done. But why is some conflict healthy and constructive, while other disagreements escalate out of control?

headline: Pitcher Serves His Country, Then Aids Cardinals
text: ST. LOUIS — Mitch Harris was 29 years old when he threw his first pitch in a major league game. It was two weeks ago in Milwaukee, and he was stepping into an emergency. The St. Louis Cardinals had just lost their best pitcher, Adam Wainwright, to an Achilles’ injury that would end his season.

headline: Scott Walker Woos South Carolina G.O.P. With Tough Talk on Terror
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. – Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin told Republicans gathered here how the last time he was in town he swung by the local Harley-Davidson shop and picked up a T-Shirt — and before taking the stage, he even tweeted a picture of himself in the shirt.

headline: Bobby Jindal Offers Rare Praise for Hillary Clinton
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. – With Mother’s Day following the Freedom Summit here in South Carolina, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana was able to compliment Hillary Rodham Clinton during a news conference.

headline: Appeal to Dwindling Core Proves Costly for Labour Party in Britain
text: LONDON — The Labour Party’s defeat in Thursday’s British elections was its poorest performance in nearly 30 years.

headline: Jeb Bush Defends Religious Freedom at Liberty University
text: Jeb Bush delivered a forceful defense of religious freedom from a secular government during a speech at an evangelical university on Saturday, deploring the rise of “coercive federal power” under President Obama that he said was seeking to impose progressive dogma on the country’s faithful.

headline: British Actors’ Broadway Run Includes Soccer and Baseball
text: This was not a true day off — the three actors had to perform in a matinee in a couple of hours a few blocks away at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. But it was a holiday for Michael Elwyn, Rufus Wright and Geoffrey Beevers to sit at the bar of Hurley’s Saloon on a recent Sunday morning to watch their beloved Premier League football.

headline: Reader Tips on Finding a Partner Using Indian Marriage Sites
text: India now has more than 1,500 matchmaking sites, giving parents — and potential brides and grooms — thousands of choices to help arrange modern marriages while allowing families to adhere to longstanding traditions regarding caste and religion.

headline: Maryland Women, in Big Ten, Find Exposure for Their Lacrosse Dominance
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — At a morning shootaround on May 1, several hours before her top-ranked team was set to play Ohio State in the semifinals of the inaugural Big Ten women’s lacrosse championship, Maryland Coach Cathy Reese chatted with Kara Lentz, a Big Ten Network broadcaster. Lentz said she would interview Reese that night at halftime if Maryland were ahead or if the game were tied.

headline: Lost in Translation (Personal and Trivial)
text: My office excavations have now dug down to a primitive early level in my history, containing various translations of my first trade book, The Age of Diminished Expectations. The Italians, it seems, wanted to put a Hannibal Lecter spin on it:

headline: See Death as a Triumph, Not a Failure
text: EIGHT years ago, my sister-in-law suddenly died. Soon after, I began research on a book about attitudes toward death in the Victorian period. The more I learned about the practices of the past, the more I regretted not having known about them earlier, when my bereavement began. I found psychological — and even philosophical — reasons to prefer the Victorian celebration of death.

headline: Despite DNA, the Rapist Got Away
text: ROBBINS, Ill. — NATASHA, 14, had just gotten off the school bus after ninth-grade basketball practice one evening and was walking home on a quiet street beside a creek. When she heard footsteps behind her, she thought it was one of her classmates.

headline: What’s the Point of a Professor?
text: ATLANTA — IN the coming weeks, two million Americans will earn a bachelor’s degree and either join the work force or head to graduate school. They will be joyous that day, and they will remember fondly the schools they attended. But as this unique chapter of life closes and they reflect on campus events, one primary part of higher education will fall low on the ladder of meaningful contacts: the professors.

headline: Invite Some Germs to Dinner
text: WITH the recent recalls of millions of gallons of ice cream as well as several tons of hummus, pine nuts, frozen vegetables and various meat products, you might think the American food supply is an unholy mess. It’s not. It’s arguably the safest in the world.

headline: The Roots of Poverty
text: Readers react to a column by David Brooks about the barriers to social mobility.

headline: How Hillary Is Winning
text: AS fleetly as Hillary Clinton vacuums up the money, she piles up the paradoxes.

headline: Beyond the Iran Nuclear Deal
text: President Obama’s meeting with Arab leaders this week is an opportunity to reassure the deeply skeptical Gulf states that America’s engagement and probable nuclear deal with Iran is not a threat but an opportunity for regional stability.

headline: The Suicide of Britain
text: FOR much of European history, empire was the normal political arrangement: Large, polyglot, multiethnic and eventually multireligious, with a monarch on top and a jostling confederation underneath.

headline: How Racism Doomed Baltimore
text: The Baltimore riots threw a spotlight on the poverty and isolation of the African-American community where the unrest began last month. The problems were underscored on Friday when the Justice Department, in response to Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake’s request, started an investigation of the Police Department, which has an egregious history of brutality and misconduct.

headline: John Urschel
text: John Urschel is an offensive lineman for the Baltimore Ravens as well as a mathematician who has had his research published in peer-reviewed academic journals in his free time.

headline: The Real Problem With America’s Inner Cities
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE recent unrest in Baltimore raises complex and confounding questions, and in response many people have attempted to define the problem solely in terms of insurgent American racism and violent police behavior.

headline: Russia Marks Victory Day
text: The Victory Day parade marks the 70th anniversary since the capitulation of Nazi Germany.

headline: Goalie Finds Perspective After Losing Track of a Shot in a Title-Game Loss
text: BOSTON — The locker room door at TD Garden had just closed, and goalie Matt O’Connor, after his final game at Boston University, rose to address his devastated teammates.

headline: Rift Forms in Germany Over Asylum
text: TUTZING, Germany — A bronze statue of St. Joseph, bending protectively over the Holy Family, stands at the center of a bubbling fountain outside the St. Joseph Church in this Bavarian village.

headline: Vows | Ever After, Ever After
text: When some mothers realized cancer might rob them of a long life, they decided to take their daughters wedding dress shopping.

headline: Verbatim: Marco Rubio on Terrorists
text: — Senator Marco Rubio, quoting from the movie “Taken” during a speech Saturday at the South Carolina Freedom Summit Hosted by Citizens United, on his strategy to combat terrorists.

headline: Verbatim: Ted Cruz on the Garland, Tex., Attacks
text: — Senator Ted Cruz, speaking about last week’s attacks in Garland, Tex., during a speech Saturday at the South Carolina Freedom Summit in Greenville.

headline: Denise McCluggage, Auto Racing Pacesetter, Dies at 88
text: Denise McCluggage, a trailblazing auto racer and journalist who shattered stereotypes about women as professional drivers, died on Wednesday in Santa Fe, N.M., where she had lived since the late 1970s. She was 88.

headline: Monsoons Near, Nepal Focuses on Sanitation to Stem Illness After Quake
text: PAUWATHOK, Nepal — After years of intense effort, officials here in rural Sindhupalchok district had persuaded almost all of the nearly 61,000 households to each build a toilet. Then the earthquake struck, destroying most houses — and the very toilets that could have helped stave off the diseases that can run rampant after natural disasters.

headline: Scientists Praise Contributions of Two Dutch Explorers Who Perished on Arctic Sea Ice
text: Ten days ago, the grinding slow-motion rivers of floating sea ice flowing around Canada’s Arctic archipelago claimed the lives of Marc Cornelissen and Philip de Roo, seasoned Dutch polar trekkers combining an adventurous spirit with environmental activism and citizen science.

headline: Rafael Nadal Reaches Madrid Open Final, Gaining Momentum on Clay
text: MADRID — Rafael Nadal is putting his wobbly clay-court season back on track at the Madrid Open as he prepares his bid to win a 10th French Open title.

headline: Rangers’ Desperate Playoff Moments Feel Familiar, as Does Their Relief
text: Still wearing his goaltender’s pads, Henrik Lundqvist leaned back in his locker, exhausted and soaked with perspiration as he replenished himself with fluids.

headline: Battle Tested, Ukraine Troops Now Get U.S. Basic Training
text: YAVORIV, Ukraine — The exercise, one of the most fundamental in the military handbook, came off without a hitch. A soldier carrying a length of rope and a grappling hook ran to within 20 feet or so of a coil of concertina wire and stopped.

headline: Reliable Fill-In Sputters, Along With Yankees’ Offense
text: Even with the Yankees in first place in their division, Manager Joe Girardi understands that his ball club must be handled delicately, given the advanced age of some of his players, the inexperience of others, and the team’s relievers, who have been overworked early in the season.

headline: In the Jury Room, 18 Days of Debate and Disagreement End in a Frustrating Mistrial
text: It was just before 1 p.m. on Friday when 11 jurors who were part of one of the longest deliberations in recent years gave up any hope of swaying the 12th person on the panel.

headline: Jameis Winston Files Countersuit Against Accuser
text: Jameis Winston has filed counterclaims against the woman who accused him of rape, responding to her lawsuit Friday in federal court in Orlando, Fla., by denying the accusations she lodged last month and accusing her of defaming him and attempting to hinder his career.

headline: Obama Calls Elizabeth Warren ‘Absolutely Wrong’ on Trade Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Escalating the fight with his own liberal base, President Obama, in an interview posted online on Saturday, took on Senator Elizabeth Warren, a champion of the left, by suggesting that she was motivated by politics in her battle against his proposed Pacific trade accord.

headline: Happily Fitting Into the (Cheese) Mold
text: There are plenty of ways to get to know Valley Shepherd Creamery, the dairy farm Eran Wajswol established in Long Valley in 2003 to make his sheep, goat and cow’s milk cheeses.

headline: The Cost of Issuing Free Throws
text: The parade to the foul line was nearly endless during Game 2 of the Western Conference semifinal series on Wednesday. Between a strategic attempt by the Los Angeles Clippers to send the Houston Rockets’ Dwight Howard to the line as often as possible and James Harden’s uncanny ability to draw fouls, it was hard to find the action between the free-throw attempts.

headline: True to Spanish Tradition, Despite Its Name
text: The small plate trend started on Long Island over a decade ago, when the Spanish tradition of tapas came into vogue. Nowadays, restaurants are calling their small plates “tapas” no matter the provenance of the cuisine. Viaggio Tapas, despite its name (Italian for journey), is a true Spanish tapas restaurant.

headline: Family History on a Plate
text: Bob Solano was 10 years old when he started working at the Lincoln Lounge, the restaurant his parents owned in Mount Vernon. His job then was to sort the beer bottles.

headline: A Roast, Long-Tested, and Other Reinventions
text: Central Connecticut chicken lovers have been smiling since midwinter, when the husband-and-wife team of K. C. and Jaime Ward opened Rooster Company in the center of Newington. The Wards worked together for years at Bricco in West Hartford, and in conceptualizing a restaurant of their own, they decided to base it on a favorite culinary mainstay. “I bought a small rotisserie,” Mr. Ward said with a laugh, “and practiced for six months in our kitchen.” Now he has graduated to a 21-bird Alto-Shaam model, which he uses to prepare his organic free-range rotisserie chickens.

headline: Review: ‘Elevada’ at Yale Rep Is a Sitcom of a Play
text: Meet Ramona and Khalil, your opposites-attract romcom pairing for the night. Before getting together for drinks, they peruse each other’s online profile. She’s bubbly and quirky; he’s nerdy and sweet. After a bumpy start to their first date, they reach the cute zone, with twists that give their potential coupling something play-worthy to overcome. But because they’re in the hands of Sheila Callaghan, a prolific and whimsically theatrical writer, you can expect something more adventurous than what this first scene appears to offer.

headline: Nice and Naughty, Across State Lines
text: Seven cultural institutions in Connecticut and New York are hosting seven coordinated shows in the months ahead, each addressing one of the seven deadly sins. In addition, a film series is planned.

headline: ‘Ciencia’ With Other Subjects for Latino Children on the East End
text: As the president of the Children’s Museum of the East End, Stephen Long has gotten occasional ribbing by fellow museum professionals from outside the region.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Dolan’s Stewardship Taints Knicks

headline: Seven Museums, Each Offering a Deadly Sin
text: In one of her poems, Emily Dickinson called sin “a distinguished precipice.” With a coming group of art exhibitions, museumgoers can stand on that precipice and look all the way down.

headline: Ben Carson on God, Country, and His Ailing Mom
text: GREENSVILLE, S.C. – Ben Carson, appearing at the South Carolina Freedom Summit here on Saturday, used his first major appearance alongside his rivals since he formally entered the Republican presidential field to focus on economic and fiscal issues, while imbuing his remarks with repeated references to God and faith — and demonstrating the sort of thoughtful, studied way of speaking that he acquired as a neurosurgeon.

headline: 1935 Poem
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s always impressive when a constructor can not only build a puzzle but also fit an entire poem inside. That’s exactly what Jacob Stulberg has done today, although I needed help seeing it.

headline: Suspects in Freddie Gray Case: A Portrait of Baltimore Police in Miniature
text: BALTIMORE — The first police officer Freddie Gray encountered on the morning he sustained a fatal spinal cord injury was Lt. Brian Rice, a seasoned 41-year-old white law enforcement officer who, several years earlier, had his guns confiscated by deputies who took him to a hospital after a worried ex-girlfriend expressed alarm about his well-being.

headline: Transformer Burns at Indian Point; Cuomo Cites Potential Environmental Risks
text: A “transformer failure” occurred at the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan, N.Y., on Saturday, sending plumes of black smoke into the air and raising concerns that the foam used to extinguish the flames could pose an environmental hazard.

headline: A Ziegfeld Club Lingers On
text: The club, founded in 1936, has outlasted the women it was formed to help. It is ready for an encore.

headline: Kenan Evren, 97, Dies; After Coup, Led Turkey With Iron Hand
text: Gen. Kenan Evren, who led a military coup in Turkey and then imposed the harshest repression in his country’s history, leading to his trial and conviction more than 30 years later, died on Saturday in a military hospital in Ankara. He was 97.

headline: Mets’ Top Pitching Prospect Noah Syndergaard Lands, With Time to Get Acquainted
text: PHILADELPHIA — He arrived, found his locker and slipped on his uniform, the one with the last name stretched tightly across his shoulders and around his number like a horseshoe. The clubhouse was quiet, but Noah Syndergaard was early, eager to begin his big-league career as soon as possible.

headline: Republican Hopefuls Push a Muscular Foreign Policy
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — A group of Republican presidential hopefuls gathered here Saturday to advocate a more muscular foreign policy and to criticize the man they hope to succeed for what they described as a weak and misguided approach to international affairs.

headline: Want to Honor Mother’s Day? Take a Selfie.
text: I do not have anyone to buy a Mother’s Day gift for, but let me make a suggestion for those who do — get a selfie with your mom. It will be worth far more than any knickknack or bauble you could ever buy her or yourself.

headline: Medals and Memories for Jewish Veterans From Russia
text: Leonid Rozenberg sat on his walker, his wrists draped over its aluminum arms and his suit lapels dripping with war medals, as a crush of Russians of all ages jostled to get closer. Some offered red carnations, which he slipped into spaces in the frame of the walker. Others carried cameras, or pointed at his gold-and-silver chest, trying to elicit a story.

headline: Contenders Crowd Lead in Deep Field at the Players Championship
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — If the talent pool in men’s golf were any deeper, the winners each week would be speared by frogmen. A day after Jordan Spieth, the 21-year-old Masters champion, bowed out of the Players Championship, Justin Thomas, 22, moved into contention with a 10-birdie performance at the Stadium Course at TPC Sawgrass.

headline: Playing Through Pain Can Be Selfless, as Well as Senseless
text: I watched Friday as delirious Chicago Bulls fans celebrated after Derrick Rose banked in a 3-point shot with no time left to give his team a 99-96 victory and a 2-1 series lead over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: Campus Debates on Israel Drive a Wedge Between Jews and Minorities
text: LOS ANGELES — The debates can stretch from dusk to dawn, punctuated by tearful speeches and forceful shouting matches, with accusations of racism, colonialism and anti-Semitism. At dozens of college campuses across the country, student government councils are embracing resolutions calling on their administrations to divest from companies that enable what they see as Israel’s mistreatment of Palestinians.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Recap: Boogie Woogie Road Trip
text: Season 1, Episode 14: “The Search”

headline: Derrick Rose Is Making Strides in His Return to Form
text: CHICAGO — For a player known for long, sweeping drives to the basket, Derrick Rose has shown a notable ability to navigate a path of small and incremental steps.

headline: Scott Walker Offers Few Details on Planned Israel Trip
text: Gov. Scott Walker, Republican of Wisconsin, has been reserved about commenting on his coming trip to Israel. He has called it a “listening tour,” saying, “we wanted to make it an educational focus, not just a media trip.”

headline: Rare Homer by Juan Lagares Leads Mets to Win Over the Phillies
text: PHILADELPHIA — A backhand stop at short, a quick turn at second and an impressive stretch by first baseman Lucas Duda enabled the Mets to turn a clutch double play in the eighth inning Saturday night and preserve a narrow 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies at Citizens Bank Park.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Catch up on the week’s top stories.

headline: England’s Coach Fired for a Second Time
text: Peter Moores was fired as coach of the England team by the England and Wales Cricket Board, and the former captain Andrew Strauss was given the new role of director of cricket. Moores has lost the job of England coach on two occasions, having initially been fired from the post in 2009 after a conflict with Kevin Pietersen, who was then the captain. Moores’s second spell in charge, which came after he replaced Andy Flower following the team’s 5-0 thrashing in the Ashes in Australia in 2014, lasted just over a year.

headline: Transformer Burns at Indian Point; Cuomo Cites Potential Environmental Risks
text: A transformer fire at the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan, N.Y. sent plumes of black smoke into the air on Saturday and raised concerns that the foam used to extinguish the flames could pose an environmental hazard.

headline: Meghan Zimmerman, Michael Stuart
text: Meghan Elizabeth Zimmerman and Michael Joseph Stuart were married Saturday at the Country Club of York in York, Pa. The Rev. Hayley Vay, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

headline: Julia Erickson and Aaron Ingley
text: Julia Elizabeth Erickson and Aaron Harlin Ingley are to be married Sunday evening at Sodo Park, an event space in Seattle. James G. Kontos, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

headline: Lauren Allen, Zachary Yost
text: Lauren Michelle Allen and Zachary Matthew Yost were married Saturday evening at Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y. Rabbi Aaron Bergman officiated at a ceremony led by Michael Brooks, the former executive director of the University of Michigan Hillel.

headline: Lowena Tam and Raymond Lee
text: Lowena Hai Yan Tam, a daughter of Hai Yan Lu Tam and Siu Hung Tam of Philadelphia, was married Saturday to Raymond Lee, the son of Pei Lu Yang and Douglas Lee of New York. Lewis Chang, a friend of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the groom’s parents’ home.

headline: Alexandra Rosencrans, Nathaniel Abrams
text: Alexandra Gail Rosencrans, a daughter of Charles A. Rosencrans of Washington and the late Cynthia J. Rosencrans, was married Saturday evening to Nathaniel Brave Abrams, a son of Ginny S. Edlavitch of Washington and Michael D. Abrams of Washington. Rabbi Gary Sherman officiated at the St. Regis Bal Harbour Resort in Bal Harbour, Fla.

headline: Leslie Ackerman, Anthony Diaz
text: Leslie Ellen Ackerman and Anthony Diaz are to be married Sunday at Battery Gardens in Manhattan. Raphael Rosenblatt, a cousin of the bride who was ordained as a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate.

headline: Nicole Nemeth, Nirav Seth
text: Dr. Nicole Lea Nemeth and Nirav Subodh Seth were married Saturday at the Buena Vista Estate in New Castle, Del. Pandit Vinod Ravel, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Kimberly Peyser, Gregory Barry
text: Kimberly Alyssa Peyser and Gregory Collin Barry were married Saturday evening at the Hotel Monaco in Washington. The ceremony was led by James A. Peyser, an uncle of the bride, who received authorization from the District of Columbia as a temporary officiant.

headline: Amy Rosenberg, Alexander Bavifard
text: Amy Lauren Rosenberg and Alexander Aidon Bavifard were married Saturday at the Round Hill Mansion, a party space in Washingtonville, N.Y. Lauren Miller, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Kathleen Singer, Francesco Leuthold
text: Kathleen Claire Singer and Francesco Alfred Leuthold were married Saturday at St. Mary Star of the Sea Church in Longboat Key, Fla. Msgr. Gerard Finegan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: A Camping Invitation Turned the Tide
text: Sally Logan Gibson, the daughter of Sarah B. McConnell and Robert R. Gibson of Charlottesville, Va., was married Saturday evening to Ali Nouri, a son of Afagh Kamali and Mohsen Nouri of Portland, Ore. The bride’s father, who received permission to officiate by the Circuit Court of the City of Charlottesville, led the ceremony at Ash Lawn-Highland, the former residence of President James Monroe in Charlottesville. Nilou Nouri, the sister of the groom and a minister with American Marriage Ministries, took part in the ceremony, which included the reading of Persian and American vows.

headline: Karen Silberg, David Richman
text: Karen Shira Silberg and David Philip Richman are to be married Sunday evening at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Rabbi Jessica Minnen is to officiate.

headline: Taraneh Nazem and Ali Kouros
text: Dr. Taraneh Gharib Nazem, the daughter of Susie Gharib and Fereydoun Nazem of New York, was married Saturday evening to Ali Kouros, the son of Avid Kouros and Saeed Kouros of Tehran. William J. Corbett, who retired as the acting village justice of Floral Park, N.Y., officiated at the New York Public Library, where the bride’s father presided over a traditional Persian ceremony in which he offered marital advice and read Persian poetry.

headline: Mara Harwel, Jasper Frank
text: Mara Elliott Harwel, the daughter of Janet K. Welch and George W. Hare of East Lansing, Mich., was married Saturday to Jasper Lowy Frank, a son of Patricia F. Lowy and Daniel H. Frank of New York. Mayme Hostetter, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister, officiated in the Peristyle, a neoclassical pavilion in City Park in New Orleans.

headline: Sometimes, a Little Lie Helps
text: Lauren Elizabeth Freeman and Peter Macy Milligan were married Saturday by the Rev. Jason D. Harris at Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

headline: Leah Hoffheimer, Daniel Broder
text: Leah Friedman Hoffheimer and Daniel Scott Broder were married Saturday at the Valley at Frutig Farms in Ann Arbor, Mich. Rabbi Ilana G. Baden officiated.

headline: Brooke Grossman, Michael Mure
text: Brooke Samantha Grossman and Michael Joseph Mure were married Saturday at the Hatch Interdenominational Chapel at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. The Rev. Enid Kessler of the New Seminary Church officiated, with Rabbi Stuart Paris taking part.

headline: Richmond Ellis II and Thomas Jayne
text: Richmond Bryant Ellis II and Thomas Gordon Jayne were married Saturday by the Rev. Stephen Gerth, an Episcopal priest, at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin in New York.

headline: Eliza Wright, David Rappaport
text: Elizabeth Risher Wright, the daughter of Sallie S. Wright and Robert P. Wright of Houston, was married Saturday to David Geoffrey Rappaport, a son of Margaret F. Rappaport of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Paul M. Rappaport of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Thomas R. Phillips, a retired chief justice of the Texas Supreme Court who is a law partner of the bride’s father, officiated at the home of the bride’s maternal aunt and uncle, Elizabeth and Stuart Smith, in Waco, Tex.

headline: Zoe Hirsch and Brian Zaro
text: Zoe Lynn Hirsch, a daughter of Jane B. Hirsch and Stuart B. Hirsch of Clifton, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Brian Eric Zaro, a son of Keri Zaro and Stuart D. Zaro of Armonk, N.Y. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Lauren Ostling, Benjamin Pensak
text: Dr. Lauren Rose Ostling and Benjamin Henry Pensak were married Thursday at the Mauna Kea Beach Hotel in Waimea on the Island of Hawaii. The groom’s father, Dr. Myles L. Pensak, became a Universal Life minister to officiate.

headline: Sarah Gleich, Seth Lynn III
text: Sarah Beth Gleich and Seth McCormick Lynn III were married Friday by Rabbi Sarah Tasman at the United States Naval Academy Miller Chapel in Annapolis, Md.

headline: Lindsay Scott, Wells Winfrey
text: Lindsay Winfield Scott and Wells Millar Winfrey were married Saturday evening at Stella Plantation, a working plantation and event space in Braithwaite, La. The Rev. Steve Trahan, an Assemblies of God minister, officiated.

headline: Meghan Curtiss, Benjamin Webb
text: Meghan Duff Curtiss and Benjamin Goodall Webb were married Saturday at Carlouel Yacht Club in Clearwater Beach, Fla. The Rev. Ronnie Norman, an uncle of the groom and a Church of Christ minister, officiated.

headline: Julie Stein, Adam Freelander
text: Julie Iris Stein and Adam Nathan Freelander were married Saturday. Rabbi Todd Markley officiated at Cedar Lakes Estate in Port Jervis, N.Y.

headline: Whitney Valins and Terence Tan
text: Dr. Whitney Elizabeth Valins and Terence Perez Tan were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Edwina Townes, a staff member of the New York City clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: You can’t just label this something racial. When you have three African-American officers involved, you’ve got to say: ‘Wait a minute, is there a system in place in which they don’t want to tell on each other? Has it become a routine?’

headline: 4 Arrested After 2 Mississippi Police Officers Are Killed During Traffic Stop
text: Law enforcement officials in Mississippi said Sunday that they had arrested four people after the fatal shooting of two police officers in Hattiesburg, and that two of the suspects had been charged with capital murder.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
text: 3 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO (2011) Daniel Craig stars as a Swedish journalist hired by an industrialist (Christopher Plummer) to investigate the disappearance of his niece 40 years earlier in this adaptation of the Stieg Larsson novel, directed by David Fincher. Rooney Mara, above, in an Oscar-nominated performance, is Lisbeth Salander, the vulnerable yet ruthlessly competent computer hacker who helps him solve the mystery. “She is a marvelous pop-culture character, stranger and more complex than the average superhero and more intriguing than the usual boy wizards and vampire brides,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It has been her fate, unfortunately, to make her furious, uninspiring way through a series of plodding and ungainly stories.” And “despite the slick intensity of Mr. Fincher’s style, his movie is not immune to the same lumbering proceduralism,” Mr. Scott said.

headline: Corrections: May 10, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: An Obama Plan to Stop Foreign Hackers Has Mixed Results
text: Two years ago, the Obama administration announced a new strategy to curb online espionage.

headline: Obama’s Pacific Trade Push Faces a Senate Vote This Week
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s most aggressive and sustained legislative push since the Affordable Care Act faces a crucial first test this week when a divided Senate considers a bill that would grant him accelerated power to complete a massive trade accord with 11 nations across the Pacific Rim.

headline: Houthi Rebels Agree to 5-Day Cease-Fire in Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — Houthi rebels here said on Sunday that they had agreed to a five-day cease-fire proposed by Saudi Arabia that would allow humanitarian relief supplies to be delivered to the country, according to statements carried by a Houthi news agency.

headline: China Cuts Rates to Halt a Slide in Its Economy
text: SHANGHAI — Hoping to shore up a weakening economy, China said on Sunday that it would cut benchmark interest rates for the third time in five months.

headline: 1915: Italy Stands Ready to Enter the Great War
text: MILAN — Despatches from Rome state that Italy’s neutrality is inexorably nearing the end. The ‘‘Agenzia Nazionale’’ says that the last term set by Italy for Austria’s reply expires to-morrow [May 11] at midday. If by that time Austria fails to reply, or the reply is different from what Italy desires, negotiations will be considered as broken off.

headline: 4 Countries Ground Military Transport Planes After Crash
text: PARIS — Four of the five countries that operate the Airbus A400M military transport plane said on Sunday that they were temporarily grounding their fleets after a fatal crash during a test flight near the southern Spanish city of Seville.

headline: Street Artists and a Bottled Water Company Clash Over a Hashtag
text: On its journey from outlaw roots to mainstream acceptance, graffiti has gone from quickly drawn tags inside subway cars to elaborate murals adorning entire sides of buildings. Street art has spread globally, giving color and attitude to urban enclaves, and following a long tradition of urban cool going mainstream, it has been embraced by marketers to promote everything from music and clothing to political causes and charities.

headline: Doctors Group Recounts Migrant Rescue as E.U. Plans Crackdown on Smuggling Rings
text: UNITED NATIONS — Loaded with life jackets, medics and search-and-rescue teams, the ship sailed from port in Malta early last Thursday morning in search of migrants stranded at sea.

headline: Chelsea Handler on the State of Late Night
text: Ms. Handler is the former host of “Chelsea Lately,” which aired on E! The questions and answers below have been edited and condensed.

headline: Seth Meyers on the State of Late Night
text: Mr. Meyers is the host of “Late Night With Seth Meyers” on NBC. The questions and answers below have been edited and condensed.

headline: Venice Biennale Awards Announced
text: VENICE – The envelopes have been opened and the lions held happily aloft. An international jury for the 56th Venice Biennale awarded the Golden Lion for best artist in the fair to Adrian Piper, an American artist living and working in Berlin, whose work has turned a shrewd conceptual eye for more than four decades on questions of race, gender and belonging.

headline: James Corden on the State of Late Night
text: Mr. Corden is the host of the “Late Late Show With James Corden” on CBS. The questions and answers below have been edited and condensed.

headline: Encores! Season Will Feature Sondheim and ‘1776’
text: “Do I Hear a Waltz?,” a musical by Richard Rodgers and Stephen Sondheim, which played 220 performances on Broadway in 1965 and hasn’t been seen in a major New York production since, is coming back — for a long weekend, at least. The show, a romance set in Venice, with a book by Arthur Laurents based on his play “The Time of the Cuckoo,” will close out the 2015-16 Encores! season at City Center.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel on the State of Late Night
text: Mr. Kimmel is the host of “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” on ABC. The questions and answers below have been edited and condensed.

headline: The Evolution of Late Night
text: David Letterman’s departure is in some ways the end of an era in late night television. A look back at the evolution of the format.

headline: As Letterman Moves On, Late-Night Success Is Unmoored From TV
text: It was a typical week for late-night television: On NBC’s “Tonight” show, the host Jimmy Fallon played a catchphrase guessing game with the “Modern Family” star Sofia Vergara, and re-enacted the music video for the 1990 rock ballad “More Than Words.”

headline: Cuomo’s Push to Raise Wages Lifts Spirits of New York’s Fast-Food Workers
text: The fast-food workers converged on Union Square in Manhattan last week, chanting and cheering and celebrating a man who some had viewed as a reluctant champion of their cause: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York.

headline: 1940: Germany Invades Low Countries and Luxembourg
text: A French newsreel from 1940 showing German troops entering Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands. (Ina.fr)

headline: “Avengers: Age of Ultron” Still Tops at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES —In the olden days of movie marketing, extravagant ad campaigns could solve anything. Terrible movie? No matter. Just throw open the promotional flood gates and a sizeable crowd reliably turned up on opening weekend.

headline: Who’s Your Broadway Crush?
text: Helen Mirren, Bradley Cooper, Patricia Clarkson and other Tony Award nominees reveal their crushes of the stage.

headline: Raúl Castro Meets With Pope Francis at Vatican
text: ROME — President Raúl Castro of Cuba visited Pope Francis at the Vatican on Sunday, praising the Argentine pontiff for helping to broker last year’s diplomatic breakthrough between Cuba and the United States while declaring that Francis had inspired him to consider returning to the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Mike Huckabee Defends Endorsement of Diabetes Product
text: Mike Huckabee, the Republican presidential candidate, defended his endorsement of a dubious diabetes remedy on Sunday, telling an interviewer that “if that’s the worst thing somebody can say to me” then “I’m going to be a heck of a good president.”

headline: Networks Fret as Ad Dollars Flow to Digital Media
text: Beginning Monday, television networks will roll out the red carpet for marketers during the annual bazaar known as the upfronts, trying to lure them into committing tens of billions of ad dollars for the coming TV season. If things go well, the networks will sell as much as 75 percent of their advertising time in the negotiations that follow a week of flashy presentations and star-studded parties.

headline: 2 Shot, One Fatally, After Fight Outside Inwood Nightclub, Police Say
text: As the nightclub closed in Upper Manhattan early Sunday morning, an argument broke out among a group of patrons, as it sometimes does. But this time, tensions escalated, and shots were fired, leaving one man dead and another hospitalized.

headline: Nico Rosberg Holds On for Victory in the Spanish Grand Prix
text: Barcelona — The Spanish Grand Prix on Sunday was a throwback to the kind of classic races that Formula One has almost always had at the track in Montmelo, just outside Barcelona: There was little action and little overtaking; the entire race was about strategy, like a game of chess.

headline: Friendships Arising From Boston Marathon Horror Offer Solace
text: BOSTON — Survivors of the Boston Marathon bombings have squeezed into the courtroom on days of great interest, listening to graphic descriptions of their pain while the man who caused it has sat impassively at the defense table. Some have made it their mission to be here as much as they can. Others pay attention only occasionally, while some prefer to ignore the debate over whether the defendant, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, should be put to death for the 2013 attack.

headline: Elizabeth Wilson, Tony Winner With a Foot in Hollywood, Dies at 94
text: Elizabeth Wilson, an actress who distinguished herself onstage, on television and in films like “The Graduate” and “9 to 5” in supporting roles that were often meaty but rarely glamorous, died on Saturday in New Haven. She was 94.

headline: Rand Paul Plays Down Comments on Military Exercise After Mockery
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been mocked by liberal pundits who accused him of fanning conspiracy theories about a military exercise along the Texas border, an event that some on the far right believe is a covert effort to impose martial law.

headline: Uber Funding Talks Highlight the Speedy Pace of Investments
text: Uber raised a total of more than $2 billion from investors in June and December last year — and is now back for another round. The anonymous messaging start-up Yik Yak collected $73.5 million in three financing rounds in seven months, and Zenefits, a human resources start-up, raised more than $580 million in less than two years, with the latest deal done last week.

headline: Pop Cube
text: Scenes from the event at BRIC House in Brooklyn.

headline: Levine Conducts First Double Bill At Met Opera Since 2005
text: It wasn’t long ago that it seemed that James Levine might never conduct a Metropolitan Opera performance again. After suffering a serious spinal injury, Mr. Levine was sidelined for two full seasons starting in 2011; a brilliant and exhaustive career seemed to be in its twilight.

headline: Retailers’ Results, Board Vote at DuPont and Shareholder Meetings
text: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

headline: Michael Pineda Pitches Like an Ace in Dominating the Orioles
text: Early Sunday, Manager Joe Girardi acknowledged that Michael Pineda’s starts were becoming special occasions, befitting a club’s ace pitcher.

headline: The Artful Lodgers
text: A rustic, family-run inn once favored by the likes of Picasso and Matisse, La Colombe d’Or in Provence still offers simple country pleasures — albeit amidst some of the world’s most iconic masterworks, casually bestowed by its famous guests.

headline: Review: ‘LUV: American-Style,’ a Rennie Harris Dance Work
text: As kids and adults settled into their seats at the New Victory Theater on Saturday, rock anthems by Bon Jovi and Guns N’ Roses set the mood. At the same time, projected text informed the audience about the disproportionate incarceration rates of African-American youth. A police officer jokingly arrested an audience member for using his cellphone, and then a hip-hop dance show began.

headline: Eurozone Ministers to Meet Again on Greek Debt
text: BRUSSELS — Finance ministers from eurozone countries were scheduled to meet here on Monday as Greece drew perilously close to running out of money and defaulting on its debt. Still, the likelihood of an imminent deal with the leftist government in Athens continued to look remote.

headline: Review: PC Music and Sophie in a High-Concept Extravaganza at BRIC House
text: Pop means a lot of conflicting things to the label and Internet phenomenon PC Music and to the D.J. and producer Sophie, who shared a high-concept extravaganza at BRIC House in Brooklyn on Friday night as part of the Red Bull Music Academy Festival.

headline: Review: ‘Thought Crimes: The Case of the Cannibal Cop’ on HBO
text: “He’s not a cannibal,” the accused man’s mother says. “He never ate anyone. Isn’t that the true definition of a cannibal, is someone that eats human meat?”

headline: Review: A Peter Eotvos Premiere and Schubert at the New York Philharmonic
text: It takes gumption for a composer to write a one-act opera intending it to be paired with “Bluebeard’s Castle,” Bartok’s chilling one-act masterpiece.

headline: Mets Beat Phillies, Buoyed by Fringes of the Roster
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Mets called up catcher Johnny Monell as the backup to the backup early last week, and not surprisingly, he sat. He waited. He made his team debut Saturday, grounded into a double play and cursed his fate, unsure of when another opportunity might be tossed to him.

headline: I.M.F. and Central Bank Loom Large Over Greece’s Debt Talks
text: Greek leaders have fought fiercely in recent months with politicians from other European countries over relief on Greece’s vast debt load.

headline: NJPAC Announces New Season
text: The Frank Sinatra Centennial train rolls along. The New Jersey Performing Arts Center announced its 2015-16 lineup of more than 120 performances Sunday, including several tributes to Sinatra, who was born in New Jersey in 1915.

headline: Review: Carolyn Montgomery-Forant, Back on the Cabaret Stage With Stories and Laughter
text: Carolyn Montgomery-Forant, a singer, songwriter and humorist who recently returned to the cabaret stage after an extended sabbatical, has the gift of gab. When this smart, complicated storyteller sings, you don’t pay attention to the notes as much as you follow the performance’s conversational flow. Although she has a reasonably strong singing voice, what captures your attention is the clarity and gusto with which she puts her personal stamp on lyrics, whether her own or someone else’s.

headline: Review: Bach, Revisited Series Features Ensemble Signal
text: With its Bach, Revisited series, the Miller Theater at Columbia University says it seeks to prompt a dialogue between contemporary composers and this Baroque master. But recently that conversation has been faltering. Writing in The New York Times, of a concert pairing Bach with the composer Michael Gordon, the critic James R. Oestreich had trouble making out any connection. “How,” he asked, “did the Bach half relate to the Gordon half?”

headline: Shakespeare & Company Caught in Its Own Drama
text: LENOX, Mass. — The trees are finally budding in the Berkshires, and the summer houses, both theatrical and residential, are beginning to stir.

headline: Saudi Arabia Says King Won’t Attend Meetings in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia announced on Sunday that its new monarch, King Salman, would not be attending meetings at the White House with President Obama or a summit gathering at Camp David this week, in an apparent signal of its continued displeasure with the administration over United States relations with Iran, its rising regional adversary.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Ends a Strong First Season
text: It is possible to be a pregnant virgin. That was the starting joke of the CW’s “Jane the Virgin.” The first season will end on Monday, having delivered another miracle: A TV show that taps into the oldest stereotypes about Hispanic-Americans and turns them upside down.

headline: French Fare for New York City Ballet
text: Scenes from New York City Ballet’s all-Balanchine quadruple bill.

headline: In Talks With Merkel, Putin Calls for Improving Relations With Europe
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin used a visit on Sunday by the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, to call for a return to normal relations with Europe, brushing aside the widespread boycott by Western leaders of the huge Victory Day parade on Red Square a day earlier.

headline: Venice Biennale Pavilions for Iraq, Ukraine and Syria Reflect Strife at Home
text: VENICE — When Mosul, Iraq’s second-largest city, fell to the Islamic State in June, members of the Ruya Foundation, an Iraqi nonprofit that set up the country’s pavilion at the last Venice Biennale, considered scrapping all plans for this year’s exhibition. “With all this carnage and death and rape, how could you even think of culture?” said Tamara Chalabi, chairwoman of the foundation.

headline: Review: David Gates Delivers More Havoc in ‘A Hand Reached Down to Guide Me’
text: Malice and goodness duke it out in the dark hearts of David Gates’s characters. The malice comes in endless varieties — conscious, buried, self-destructive, jealous, spiteful, sexual, snobbish, druggie, fiendish and breathtakingly awful, to name only a few. The goodness is more limited. It might as well be. This writer, critic and teacher, whose books until now have included only two scalding novels, “Jernigan” (1991) and “Preston Falls” (1998), and one short story collection, “The Wonders of the Invisible World” (1999), rarely gives it a fighting chance.

headline: China’s Anti-Corruption Campaign
text: Sniffing out the tigers and flies.

headline: A Baltimore Neighborhood, Wary and Healing, Prepares for Preakness Day
text: BALTIMORE — Soon after Candy Thomas moved into a rowhouse one block from Pimlico Race Course a few weeks ago, a neighbor asked her if she was ready for Preakness Stakes weekend.

headline: Review: ‘Major Barbara’ at Brave New World Repertory in Brooklyn
text: There is no Salvation Army center in Brooklyn Heights, but this month you can hear a few of its soldiers beating drums and banging tambourines at the First Unitarian Church on Pierrepont Street. The Brave New World Repertory Theater, dedicated to performing new and classic plays in Brooklyn, has recruited the chapel to stage George Bernard Shaw’s “Major Barbara,” about a Salvation Army officer (Grace Rao) and her munitions-manufacturer father (David Frutkoff).

headline: Review: Serving 4 Helpings of Balanchine, With Thunderbolts and Tornadoes
text: Why don’t we see George Balanchine’s exquisite pas de deux “Sonatine” more often at New York City Ballet? Choreographed in 1975 to Ravel’s three-movement solo piano piece of that name, it’s an intricate, spellbinding vehicle for sensitive dancers. Although Balanchine originally made it for Violette Verdy and Jean-Pierre Bonnefoux as the opening of his Ravel festival, he soon revived it for Patricia McBride and Mikhail Baryshnikov (1979, for City Ballet’s European tour) and later for the radically dissimilar Suzanne Farrell and Peter Martins.

headline: Internet Image File
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — The last time we saw Joe DiPietro, he was cutting up by slicing through a set of theme answers, but today, he’s putting ALL OF himself into his first Monday puzzle.

headline: Cartoon Network Upbeat as Ad Season Begins
text: LOS ANGELES — Few television companies will have a better story to tell advertisers during this week’s “upfront” presentations than Cartoon Network. According to Nielsen, ratings have climbed 16 percent over last year among children 2 to 11 even as its rival Nickelodeon has fallen 31 percent.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of May 11
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

If Bostonians could forgive that transgression to support their political hero, then surely the mysterious loss of air pressure from a few footballs will not alter their support of their favorite sports hero.

text: ST. LOUIS — The first thing Ted Williams told Mike Bryant was that he was late, because he was only 10 minutes early to their practice session. The second thing he told him just may help end the most persistent streak of failure in professional sports: the championship drought of the Chicago Cubs.

headline: Rickie Fowler Outlasts Logjam to Win Players Championship

They had lunch with Fowler, who began the day three strokes off the lead, before his 1:25 p.m. tee time.

headline: Broadcast TV’s Big 4 Review Their Wins and Losses

headline: How Is U.S. TV Changing? Ask Jane
text: Gina Rodriguez was home in Chicago last month when she stopped at a Subway sandwich shop on the way to the golf course with her father. The Hispanic teenager working behind the counter instantly recognized her as the star of the CW Network’s breakout comedy-drama “Jane the Virgin” and said that the order was on the house. Ms. Rodriguez protested, but the girl insisted, telling the actress how inspirational it was to see someone on television who looked like her and grew up in her neighborhood.

headline: Chasing Outbreaks: How Safe Is Our Food?
text: A 1993 E. coli outbreak linked to Jack in the Box hamburgers sickened 700 people and drew new attention to the dangers of food-borne illness. More than 20 years later, how far have we come?

headline: Action and Dysfunction in the U.S. Food-Safety Effort
text: The notion that “a crisis is a terrible thing to waste” is credited to the American economist Paul Romer, who offered the thought a decade ago in a discussion about education. Mr. Romer’s observation has since been echoed in a variety of contexts. It could be applied as well to stewardship of this country’s food supply. Significant measures to keep Americans from being sickened, and sometimes killed, by what they eat have tended to come only after calamity strikes. Even then, in the view of many experts on food safety, the United States has wasted too many crises for comfort.

headline: Russia Tests Distant Waters, Resurfacing Cold War Fears
text: ARDGLASS, Northern Ireland — After a day of fishing in the Irish Sea, Paul Murphy was about to head for home when his trawler, the Karen, suddenly shuddered to a halt.

headline: @_FloridaMan Beguiles With the Hapless and Harebrained

Hustlers and fugitives, million-dollar hucksters and harebrained thieves, Armani-wearing drug traffickers and hapless dope dealers all congregate, scheme and revel in the Sunshine State. It’s easy to get in, get out or get lost.

headline: “Hamilton” Wins Big at Lortel Awards
text: No, “Hamilton” will not win a Tony this year — it will arrive on Broadway too late. Instead, it’s sweeping up just about everything else it’s eligible for, including the Lucille Lortel Awards, which honor Off Broadway works and were announced on Sunday. “Hamilton” took home 10 awards, including for outstanding musical, director (Thomas Kail), lead actor in a musical (Lin-Manuel Miranda), and lead actress in a musical (Phillipa Soo).

headline: Veep Q&A: Anna Chlumsky on Amy’s Meltdown
text: On this week’s episode of “Veep,” Amy Brookheimer (Anna Chlumsky) was infuriated and had finally had enough. Fed up with being frozen out of the loop by yes-woman Karen Collins (Lennon Parham), the manager in the presidential re-election campaign of Selina Meyer (Julia Louis-Dreyfus), she went down in flames in the middle of the convention with an expletive-filled tirade. (“I wouldn’t let you run a bath without having the Coast Guard and the Fire Department standing by. But yet, here you are, running America. You are the worst thing that has happened to this country since food in buckets. And maybe slavery.”)

headline: Rangers Turn Lights Red and Knuckles White, Edging the Capitals
text: WASHINGTON — Braden Holtby lay stretched on his stomach in the crease and stayed there for a moment, looking back over his shoulder, as Chris Kreider let out a tribal scream and embraced his teammates Sunday night. This was unusual, the Rangers beating Holtby with such ease, and he needed time to process what had happened.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: There are thousands of women who are working in this, but no one asking: ‘What’s happening to you? How do you feel?’ We just work and work.

headline: Roxana Baldetti’s Resignation as Vice President Shadows Guatemala Politics
text: MEXICO CITY — The resignation of Guatemala’s vice president has plunged the country’s politics into disarray, with a presidential election in September and the public growing more indignant over corruption.

headline: To Market, to Market with Rob Pruitt
text: From Obama to Marilyn Monroe to — naturally — himself, the artist Rob Pruitt has covered a wide range of subjects and mediums in his lifetime; one of his most prominent works to date is “The Andy Monument,” a 2011 statue of Andy Warhol that spent nearly a year and a half standing proudly in Union Square, near Warhol’s Factory stomping grounds. T caught up with the artist as he prepared a new retrospective at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., “Rob Pruitt 50th Birthday Bash” (this Sunday, May 17, is actually Pruitt’s 51st birthday; shh). The foundation commemorated the exhibition with a private event yesterday, which included an auction of items contributed by members of the Brant family themselves — yes, including the billionaire paper magnate after whom the foundation is named, Peter M. Brant, and his wife, the supermodel Stephanie Seymour; and yes, the offerings include a to-die-for assortment of Seymour’s shoes. Proceeds from the tag sale, which is ongoing throughout the exhibition, will benefit the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College. In the slide show above, Pruitt shared a few of his favorite items up for sale with T; he’ll also select some items later this month to add to his famous eBay page.

headline: How Blue Hill at Stone Barns Transplanted Its Farmhouse Feel Into a Sotheby’s Gallery
text: Michael Moore, Sotheby’s director of events, continually outdoes himself — it’s in his job description. With a three-person team, Moore produces more than 350 American events (and some abroad) for Sotheby’s each year, the crowning jewel of which is the ultraexclusive dinner that precedes the high-profile New York contemporary auction each spring and fall. This year, Moore faced the task of topping last spring’s contemporary dinner, for which Sotheby’s flew in 16 chefs from Noma, the Copenhagen restaurant often cited as the best in the world, and asked them to recreate its dining experience right in Sotheby’s New York flagship on the Upper East Side. (Moore and his team attempted to meet all of the chefs’ requests, no detail too small — one consequence of which was a long, thorough search for just the right river rocks for Noma to serve its langoustines upon.)

headline: Seaport Smorgasburg’s Sleek, New Look
text: This summer, hungry visitors to the Smorgasburg market’s location in Lower Manhattan’s Seaport district will also be able to satisfy their appetite for contemporary architecture. When the gourmet street-dining series opens its outpost there later this month, vendors will prepare and serve meals from a new series of eight semipermanent pods designed and built by the Brooklyn-based firm Guild, as seen for the first time here (pictured inside the company’s studio).

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 11:30 A.M. (Showtime) FRUITVALE STATION (2013) On Jan. 1, 2009, Oscar Grant III, a 22-year-old black father, was shot in the back by a white Bay Area Rapid Transit police officer on a subway platform in Oakland, Calif., his killing captured on cellphone. Ryan Coogler’s feature directorial debut reconstructs the final 24 hours in the life of Mr. Grant (played by Michael B. Jordan, above with Ariana Neal) who, after two stints in prison, had returned to selling drugs after losing his job at a supermarket because of chronic lateness. Octavia Spencer plays his mother and Melonie Diaz the mother of his daughter, with whom he’s trying to stay. Mr. Coogler’s “main intention — and his great achievement, as well as Mr. Jordan’s — is to make Oscar a fully human presence, to pay him the respect of acknowledging his complexities and contradictions,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The radicalism of ‘Fruitvale Station’ lies precisely here, in its refusal to turn a man into a symbol. Nearly every black man, whether or not he is president, tends to be flattened out by popular culture and the psychopathology of everyday American life, rendered as an innocent victim, a noble warrior or a menace to society. There is a dehumanizing violence in this habit, a willed, toxic blindness that ‘Fruitvale Station’ at once exposes and resists.”

headline: Rick Nash Picks Opportune Time to Get Back on Scoreboard
text: WASHINGTON — Rick Nash led the Rangers with 42 goals this season but had yet to find similar success in postseason play. Nash scored just once in the team’s first 10 playoff games and not at all through the first five games of this second-round series against the Washington Capitals.

headline: Wall Street Vampires

For now, however, let’s just note that these days Wall Street, which used to split its support between the parties, overwhelmingly favors the G.O.P. And the Republicans who came to power this year are returning the favor by trying to kill Dodd-Frank, the financial reform enacted in 2010.

headline: Transgender at the C.I.A.
text: The day she nervously told her boss that they needed to talk in the summer of 2012, the young intelligence analyst was mindful of the ordeal of the transgender woman at the Central Intelligence Agency who came before her. The story had become C.I.A. lore. In the late 1980s, a standout senior analyst who became the butt of jokes when she came out resigned after enduring months of cruel glances and crude remarks.

headline: Greater Aims Than Marketing With a Film Starring Green Luxury Apartments
text: The film shows a man in a leather biker jacket and a woman in an oversize black parka leaning against the gunwale of a boat, staring up at the huge icebergs floating by, dressed more for the cobblestones of SoHo than for the shoals of Greenland. The camera captures their amazement at the drifts of glacial beauty. Just then — crack! — both jump as a piece of ice the size of a townhouse cascades into the water.

headline: Raising Paddles in Seattle to Ward Off an Oil Giant

For some of the paddlers, it was a first-time experience, and with the water at 50 degrees and choppy, there were some obvious signs of trepidation.

text: WASHINGTON — All the Navy recovered after Lt. Nathan Poloski’s fighter jet collided in midair with another Navy jet on a training mission in the western Pacific in September were his flight helmet and a few bits of debris. The 26-year-old pilot, who was deployed aboard the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson, died one month before the ship steamed into the Persian Gulf and began launching combat missions against the Islamic State.

headline: The Right Ratio to Engineer a Swim
text: The knifefish doesn’t swim the way a trout or tuna does, waving its tail fin back and forth. Its propulsion comes from one long fin on its belly, and when it swims, the fin, not the body, undulates. A continuous wave passes along the fin, and watching it can be mesmerizing.

headline: New York Today: Sneezing Into Spring
text: Good morning on this motley Monday.

headline: Making It Explicit in Israel
text: In Israel, we are used to hearing that everything is more “complex” than one might think. Situations are typically described as variegated, imprecise or intangible and they seem almost intentionally so. Implicitness — about politics, religion, military actions, and human rights — rules. But I would argue that that situation has changed. In the past year in Israel, things have become clear and precise. Things have become explicit.

headline: Today in Politics: Trade Fight Intensifies as Vote Looms
text: Good Monday morning from Washington, where presidential candidates of both parties have spent the weekend singing their mothers’ praises. Senator Mitch McConnell and President Obama are also starting to feel the love for each other after all these years, while even one of the biggest political donors thinks campaign spending is getting out of control. Trade will be the talk of Congress this week, but with many Democrats resisting a deal, will anything get done?
