text: HONG KONG — A teenager who posted a video criticizing Lee Kuan Yew, the founding father of modern Singapore, was convicted on charges of obscenity and insulting religious feelings by a court in the city-state on Tuesday.

headline: François Hollande of France Meets Fidel and Raúl Castro in Cuba
text: President François Hollande of France has called for an end to the United States trade embargo against Cuba, where he met with Fidel Castro in the first visit by a Western head of state to Havana since the United States announced plans in December to re-establish diplomatic relations with the country.

headline: A.C.L.U. Letter on the Exclusion of Women Directors
text: The organization will ask state and federal agencies to look into what it calls rampant and intentional gender discrimination in recruiting and hiring of female directors.

headline: Entering the Job Market in a Fitful Time
text: Every year, as college graduation draws near, assessments of the job market get personal. Soon-to-be graduates compare their prospects and offers (or lack thereof) to those of their peers. Parents and other relatives start (or stop) worrying about whether their kids may move back home or need other forms of continuing support.

headline: 1915: ‘Too Proud to Fight’
text: SYRACUSE, N.Y. — ‘‘The policy of blood and iron cannot be met efficaciously by a policy of milk and water,’’ declared Mr. Roosevelt to a ‘‘Herald’’ correspondent in commenting on President Wilson’s Philadelphia speech. In his dictation of this statement, the former President spoke slowly and earnestly, apparently with the conviction that he was carrying out a solemn duty in sending this message to the American people in the present crisis.

headline: Exor Increases Bid for PartnerRe to $6.8 Billion
text: LONDON — The Italian investment company Exor raised the ante on Tuesday in its competing bid for the reinsurer PartnerRe, saying it was willing to pay $6.8 billion in cash.

headline: Mary Wittenberg Rose Along With New York’s Race
text: While in law school at Notre Dame, Mary Wittenberg found balance by training with the Fighting Irish men’s cross-country team. When she joined the firm of Hunton & Williams in Richmond, Va., she continued to train at a high level. In 1987, she won the Marine Corps Marathon in 2 hours 44 minutes 36 seconds, qualifying for the 1988 Olympic trials.

headline: Sandra Lee, TV Host and Gov. Cuomo’s Girlfriend, Has Breast Cancer
text: ALBANY — Sandra Lee, the television host and longtime girlfriend of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, said on Tuesday that she has breast cancer and would undergo a double mastectomy this week.

headline: DocuSign Raises $233 Million in Latest Financing Round
text: Investors are wagering that the business of electronic documents has room to grow.

headline: A Taffin Necklace Worth Shouting About
text: As slender and delicate as a cherry blossom, Taffin’s one-of-a-kind topaz and diamond necklace is mounted on a fine wire of flexible 18-karat rose gold that wends around itself in lieu of a clasp. Created by the French-born, New York-based designer James Taffin de Givenchy — nephew of the fashion legend Hubert and a master at reinterpreting rare and antique stones through highly original silhouettes — the piece was designed to resemble an abstract exclamation point. Two Victorian-era pink topazes of slightly different hues — one a 3.5-carat pear-shaped stone, the other a 39-carat oval-cut with mauve undertones — are cradled by 105 diamonds. A pair of craftsmen at the Taffin atelier spent 60 hours hand-mounting the gems into their setting, and the piece’s eventual owner will receive a fitting so that the necklace alights on the collarbone just so — an enviable punctuation mark if ever there was one.

headline: One Killed and 2 Hurt in Staten Island Stabbing
text: By all appearances, Monday night began as a typical one for Damian Yordan, a stocky 18-year-old who was known to friends as Peanut. He was hanging out at his Staten Island home with a few friends.

headline: Daily Report: Verizon to Buy AOL for $4.4 Billion in Cash
text: Verizon Communications said on Tuesday that it would acquire AOL for $4.4 billion in an all-cash deal in which today’s king of mobile phones will acquire the one-time king of media,  David Gelles writes.

headline: Twitter Reacts to Tom Brady’s Suspension
text: The reaction to Tom Brady’s suspension for his role in the deflation of footballs was violently polarized. When a player, celebrity or scholar sent out a Twitter message like “Ridiculous,” it was not always easy to tell if they felt the punishment was way too harsh or way too lenient.

headline: Readers on Restaurant Meals and Beverage Choices
text: Each Tuesday, The Upshot’s newsletter will feature a selection of comments from an article that resonated with our readers in the past week.

headline: Singapore Convicts Boy, 16, of Obscenity
text: The lawyer for Amos Yee, the teenager convicted on charges of obscenity and insulting religious feelings after criticizing Singapore’s former prime minister, said his client would “respect the law.”

headline: Blogger Killed in Bangladesh
text: The Bangladeshi police said Ananta Bijoy Dasha, a blogger who advocated secularism, was killed by four attackers wielding sharp weapons on Tuesday in Sylhet.

headline: Goal of Early Presidential Campaign Web Advertising: Your Email
text: Unless you’re an Iowa, New Hampshire or South Carolina voter or a wealthy political donor, chances are you’re not seeing the 2016 presidential hopefuls in person. You probably won’t even see their TV ads.

headline: Marvel Comics Reveals a Female Thor
text: In October, Marvel Comics introduced readers to a new hero: a female Thor. Since then, the identity of the woman wielding Thor’s mighty hammer has been a secret. But that ends on Wednesday when issue No. 8 of the Thor series, written by Jason Aaron and illustrated by Russell Dauterman, goes on sale in comic book stores and digitally.

headline: Walkabout: Memorial Day Travel; Kid-Free Vacations
text: Surge AAA is predicting that this Memorial Day will be the busiest in a decade, with roughly 37.2 million Americans taking trips of at least 50 miles by automobile, train or plane. The figure would represent a 4.7 percent increase from last year. (The Los Angeles Times)

headline: Joey Alexander, an 11-Year-Old Jazz Sensation Who Hardly Clears the Piano’s Sightlines
text: The cheers rang loud and long for Joey Alexander after he had played his last delicate piano chord in a recent sold-out set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola in Manhattan.

headline: The Rise of Young Americans Who Don’t Believe in God
text: The rise of religious nonbelief is one of the most striking social trends in the United States. My colleague Nate Cohn discusses the trend, with a focus on the recent decline of Americans who identify as Christians, in an article this morning analyzing a large new survey by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Turner Prize Nominees for 2015 Announced
text: LONDON — The artists Nicole Wermers, Janice Kerbel and Bonnie Camplin and the London-based art and architecture collective Assemble are the four nominees for this year’s Turner Prize, the museum group Tate announced on Tuesday.

headline: Peter Gay, Historian Who Explored Social History of Ideas, Dies at 91
text: Peter Gay, a German-born historian whose sense of intellectual adventure led him to write groundbreaking books on the Enlightenment, the Victorian middle classes, Sigmund Freud, Weimar culture and the cultural situation of Jews in Germany, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Chris Christie Offers Plan He Says Will Aid Middle Class
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey returned to the campaign trail on Tuesday in New Hampshire, where he unveiled an economic plan that strikes a theme increasingly common among candidates in both the Republican and Democratic presidential fields: the need to reduce income inequality.

headline: Scott Walker Meets Benjamin Netanyahu During Israel Trip
text: The likely Republican presidential candidate Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin, posted on Twitter this photograph from his meeting with Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister.

headline: Ally Says Jeb Bush Misheard Question on Iraq War
text: A friend and adviser of Jeb Bush said Tuesday morning that the likely 2016 presidential hopeful told her he had misheard a question from Megyn Kelly, the Fox News host, about the war in Iraq, after his response created an uproar of criticism from the left and the right.

headline: AOL, a Digital Pioneer, With Another Chance to Reshape Itself
text: Soon after Tim Armstrong was named chief executive of AOL in 2009, he started reading the management book “You’re in Charge, Now What?”

headline: Steve Montador Had C.T.E.; Family to Sue N.H.L.
text: The brain of Steve Montador, a former N.H.L. player who died in February at age 35, was found to have widespread chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., a disease associated with repeated hits to the head.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Iraq Debacle Gets Weirder [Updated]
text: When a candidate or officeholder says something completely ridiculous, a supporter inevitably claims he or she misheard the question. And so it goes, today, with Ana Navarro, who used to work for Jeb Bush, who used to be governor of Florida, saying he misheard a question about the invasion of Iraq.

headline: Italian Fashion Makes a Bid for Global Leadership
text: In recent years, Milan Fashion Week, which falls third in the Big Four calendar after New York and London and before Paris, has seemed like something of the poor cousin of the tour: tolerated, but increasingly unloved.

headline: Questions About Coffee and Health: We Have Some Answers
text: In an article on Monday, I reviewed the evidence behind coffee consumption and health in an effort to put to rest the idea that coffee is a “vice” or something we all need to cut back on.

headline: Highlights From the 56th Venice Biennale
text: As the sun set on the opening week of the Venice Biennale on Saturday (and both the sunset and the vernissage were quite spectacular), the Golden Lions were awarded to the pavilions and artists chosen by the jury as the best of this year’s batch. The American artist Adrian Piper, long since based in Berlin, took the top honor among the individual artists participating in Okwui Enwezor’s international exhibition “All the World’s Futures.”

headline: Watch Trailers for Fox’s New Fall Dramas and Comedies
text: This week, in the annual tradition known as the upfronts, TV networks make presentations to advertisers in which they unveil previews of new fall shows.

headline: A Spouse Deployed, Still Fighting a Foolish Battle at Home
text: Who has it harder – the one deployed or the one left behind? After 13 years of war, I think it’s a reasonable assertion that the one in harm’s way generally holds the trump card. But there is another side. A friend of mine once said in a Christmas card that her son might be the soldier, but her daughter-in-law and grandchildren were the troopers.

headline: Hollande: End the Cuba Trade Embargo
text: President François Hollande of France called on Monday for an end to the United States trade embargo on Cuba, saying France would work to get the measures repealed.

headline: Fung Tu
text: Modern cuisine rooted in Chinese traditions on the Lower East Side.

headline: Restaurant Review: Fung Tu on the Lower East Side
text: It can’t have been much fun for Jonathan Wu, the chef and an owner of Fung Tu, when Mission Chinese Food set up shop virtually around the corner in December. For his first year in business down in the headwaters of Orchard Street, just off East Broadway’s warren of Fujianese places, Mr. Wu was the only Asian-American chef plundering Chinese traditions to weave a modern cuisine of his own imagining. Then Danny Bowien showed up a couple of blocks away with his kung pao pastrami and his Mylar rainbow wall and his “Twin Peaks” hallway, and fanboys and fangirls turned cartwheels on the sidewalks.

headline: Videos Capture Second Quake in Nepal
text: Witnesses recorded the moment and aftermath of a 7.3-magnitude earthquake that shook Nepal on Tuesday, just weeks after one there killed more than 8,000 people.

headline: AOL’s History of Growth and Decline
text: AOL, the one-time king of media, is a shadow of its former self. Its deal for Time Warner is regarded as the high-water mark of the dot-com bubble.

headline: Senate Democrats Foil Obama on Asia Trade Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Tuesday blocked consideration of giving President Obama power to accelerate a broad trade accord with Asia, a rebuke that the president helped bring on himself.

headline: Verbatim: Harry Reid Scolds the N.F.L.
text: — Senator Harry Reid, a Democrat from Nevada, arguing that the National Football League should act as swiftly to change the name of the Washington Redskins as it did in punishing the New England Patriots and their star quarterback, Tom Brady, after investigating deflated balls in a conference championship game.

headline: Buffalo Wings, Milan Style
text: Chic Milan goes through food trends almost as frequently as it does clothing collections. In recent years, dressed-up hamburgers have been one of the city’s favorite meals. But lately, many Milanese restaurateurs have begun branching out into other forms of Americana, serving up spot-on recreations of such un-Italian recipes as Buffalo wings, apple fritters and pulled pork sandwiches.

headline: James Murphy of LCD Soundsystem to Open a Wine Bar in Brooklyn
text: When a prominent chef heard that James Murphy had decided to open a wine bar in Brooklyn, he nudged Mr. Murphy to compose an online journal about the process.

headline: 1965: Bonn and Israel Seal Relations
text: BONN — West Germany and Israel exchanged letters in Bonn today confirming the establishment of diplomatic relations. A West German government spokesman said the exchange of letters between Chancellor Ludwig Erhard and Israeli Prime Minister Levi Eshkol began the establishment of relations, to be completed shortly by an exchange of ambassadors. — New York Herald Tribune, European edition, May 13, 1965

headline: Israel Says Hezbollah Positions Put Lebanese at Risk
text: TEL AVIV — Viewed from the air, Muhaybib looks like a typical southern Lebanese village — a cluster of about 90 houses and buildings punctuated by the minaret of a mosque and surrounded by fields.

headline: A Player or a Team Seeks an Edge. So What’s New?
text: It was four decades ago — no, the helmets were not still as leathery as the footballs — when, as a high school center and kicker in Louisiana’s humid bayou country, I came to believe that slickness of the ball, more than air pressure, affected firmness of grip and certainty of flight.

headline: Twice-Shot Prey
text: Pierre Abensur has gone from the Alps to Africa, making portraits of hunters alongside their taxidermied prey.

headline: Obama’s Catastrophic Climate-Change Denial
text: MIDDLEBURY, Vt. — THE Obama administration’s decision to give Shell Oil the go-ahead to drill in the Arctic shows why we may never win the fight against climate change. Even in this most extreme circumstance, no one seems able to stand up to the power of the fossil fuel industry. No one ever says no.

headline: Mayweather-Pacquiao Bout Shatters Pay-Per-View Records
text: The May 2 fight between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao was years in the making, and even though both boxers were past their prime, the pent-up demand to see them finally meet in the ring was expected to produce more pay-per-view purchases than any other fight in history.

headline: Sid Gold’s Request Room, a New Piano Bar in Chelsea
text: Headliner

headline: Verizon’s Dumb Pipes Are No Smarter With AOL
text: Verizon’s dumb pipes become no smarter by running AOL through them.

headline: Watch Trailers for ABC’s New Dramas and Comedies
text: This week, in the annual tradition known as the upfronts, TV networks make presentations to advertisers in which they unveil previews of new fall shows.

headline: More in School, but Not Learning
text: A quarter of a century ago, barely half the children of primary school age in sub-Saharan Africa were enrolled in school. By 2012 the share was 78 percent. In South Asia, primary school enrollment jumped to 94 percent from 75 percent over the same period.

headline: U.S. Military Helicopter on Aid Mission in Nepal Is Missing
text: A United States Marine helicopter assigned to the relief efforts in the aftermath of the latest earthquake in Nepal was missing, military officials said Tuesday.

headline: Verizon-AOL Deal Put Together by Boutique Advisers
text: When it comes to big-ticket transactions, boutique investment banks are still claiming their fair share.

headline: Ed Harris and Amy Madigan Join New Group’s ‘Buried Child’ Revival
text: “Buried Child,” Sam Shepard’s Pulitzer Prize-winning family drama, will be staged by New Group next winter, marking the play’s first major production in New York in two decades.

headline: ABC Will Keep Many of Its Freshman Shows, as Well as Longtime Hits
text: There was talk of rejuvenation at the upfront presentations for NBC and Fox upfront on Monday. Both networks introduced an army of new dramas and comedies after several freshmen shows failed for both networks this last season.

headline: The Old Page 1 Meeting, R.I.P.: Updating a Times Tradition for the Digital Age
text: Kyle Massey is an assistant news editor. He has worked at The Times since 1999.

headline: Another Busy Day for Bill Clinton, the Noncampaigning Campaigner
text: Bill Clinton will not (repeat, not) be campaigning for his wife in the early stages of her 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Lawyers With Lowest Pay Report More Happiness
text: Of the many rewards associated with becoming a lawyer — wealth, status, stimulating work — day-to-day happiness has never been high on the list. Perhaps, a new study suggests, that is because lawyers and law students are focusing on the wrong rewards.

headline: British Press on the Hunt for Labour Leader’s Missing ‘Ed Stone’
text: LONDON — The British press on Tuesday was hot on the trail of the “Ed Stone,” the much ridiculed stone tablet — more than eight feet high and weighing two tons — that Ed Miliband, the Labour Party leader, unveiled just before Thursday’s election.

headline: A Cease-Fire in Yemen, but Fighting Is Persistent
text: SANA, Yemen — A precarious cease-fire took effect in parts of Yemen on Tuesday night, in the first negotiated halt to hostilities since Saudi Arabia started a bombing campaign against Yemen’s Houthi rebels in late March.

headline: Where Republican White House Hopefuls Stand on Trade
text: The push to give President Obama “fast track” authority to make international trade deals may be flagging in the Senate, but the issue is sure to persist on the campaign trail among those looking to replace him.

headline: Rohingya Refugees From Myanmar Have Been Persecuted for Decades
text: The refugees fleeing Myanmar, from the Muslim Rohingya ethnic minority, have been persecuted for decades. They have been evicted from their homes and kicked off their land, and attacked by the military and by Buddhist extremists in Rakhine, the western coastal state where they live. Their voting rights were effectively revoked in February. Their government insists that they are in the country illegally, and most neighboring countries refuse to accept them.

headline: A Ballet to Open Versailles’s New Water Theater Grove
text: Yesterday, the new Paris Opera Ballet director, Benjamin Millepied, helped unveil the project with dance.

headline: Ex-Chairman Has Chance to Shake Up Volkswagen, as a Shareholder
text: FRANKFURT — Ferdinand K. Piëch may have been banished from Volkswagen, the carmaker he dominated for more than two decades, but on Wednesday he will have one more chance to be the center of attention — if he chooses.

headline: Investigation Into Deadly Nebraska Prison Riot Yields Few Answers
text: The two prisoners who were killed in a Nebraska prison riot on Sunday appear to have been killed by other inmates, and were serving terms for sex crimes against children, said Scott R. Frakes, director of the Department of Correctional Services. Officials were not sure if they were targeted for that reason, and Mr. Frakes said autopsies were being performed.

headline: Finnish Pancakes With a Side of Canada’s Labor History
text: THUNDER BAY, Ontario — Carved in stone high above the door to the Hoito restaurant here is a motto in Latin: Labor Omnia Vincit — Work Conquers All.

headline: Gertrude Schimmel, First Female New York Police Chief, Dies at 96
text: Gertrude Schimmel, who broke gender barriers in the New York Police Department as one of the first two women to become a sergeant and ultimately the first to be named a chief, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.

headline: Extreme Yearbook
text: To accompany Jon Lackman’s piece on kids in extreme sports, we selected 10 young, and exceptionally accomplished, athletes, interviewing them about their perception of fear, greatest accomplishments, and brushes with danger within their sport. In order to give these kids ‘pro’ treatment, we chose the acclaimed British sports photographer Levon Biss.

headline: A Decade of Top Art Auction Sales
text: The last 10 years have seen a steady increase in the top auction prices for singular works by the most sought-after artists.

headline: Hillary Clinton-Aligned Group Gets Closer to Her Campaign
text: Correct the Record, a group started by David Brock, a staunch ally of Hillary Rodham Clinton, is recreating itself as a stand-alone “super PAC” that has the ability to coordinate with her campaign.

headline: Watch Trailers for NBC’s New Fall Dramas and Comedies
text: This week, in the annual tradition known as the upfronts, TV networks make presentations to advertisers in which they unveil previews of new fall shows.

headline: William Zinsser, Author of ‘On Writing Well,’ Dies at 92
text: William Zinsser, a writer, editor and teacher whose book “On Writing Well” sold more than 1.5 million copies by employing his own literary craftsmanship to urge clarity, simplicity, brevity and humanity, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Bill Gates, Andy Grove and Steve Jobs: The Strategies They Shared
text: In retrospect, things look easy, even obvious. Microsoft, Intel and Apple all rose to dominance as if their fates were inevitable.

headline: Lessons From Mergers Past for the Verizon-AOL Deal
text: Does a modern telecommunications company need to control both the pipes that deliver information to its customers and the stuff that goes in the pipes? Verizon appears to be betting that it does with its proposed acquisition of AOL for $4.4 billion.

headline: Jeb Bush Passes on Iowa Straw Poll
text: The Iowa Straw Poll, a high-profile but sometimes vexing event for Republican presidential candidates, has its first no-show: Jeb Bush, who will instead appear halfway across the country.

headline: After Scandals, Evaluating Pension Funds’ Middleman
text: Placement agents have been maligned, banned and even imprisoned. And yet, pension funds continue to use them. Despite various scandals, however, a new study finds that the better agents in the business just might provide value.

headline: Men in Suits Rob Manhattan Watch Store, Police Say
text: The New York police were pursuing several men who they said robbed a luxury watch store in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday.

headline: A Music Video Made with a Cult Film Heavyweight
text: [Watch the video on YouTube.]

headline: ‘Elon Musk,’ a Biography by Ashlee Vance, Paints a Driven Portrait
text: “We’ve become a nation of indoor cats,” Dave Eggers wrote in “A Hologram for the King” (2012), his existential novel about an American doing IT work in the Saudi Arabian desert. “A nation of doubters, worriers, overthinkers.”

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic’s Contact! Series, With New Compositions From Italy
text: Location, location, location.

headline: Israel Jails Palestinian Who Applauded Militant Attacks on Facebook
text: TEL AVIV, Israel — An Israeli court on Tuesday sentenced a Palestinian for incitement and for supporting a terrorist organization based on Facebook posts that applauded militant attacks, his lawyer said. It was a rare case in which statements on social media were regarded as a crime.

headline: Owner of Anonymous Hackers-for-Hire Site Steps Forward
text: He calls himself an ethical hacker who helps companies and individuals fight back against the bad guys operating online. Over the years, Charles Tendell also has emerged as a commentator in the news media about the threat posed by overseas hackers and is a former co-host of an online radio show about security.

headline: Assessing Size and Flavor of Different Mangos
text: I wanted to compare mangos, and found three different varieties at markets within walking distance of my house: Tommy Atkins, Haden and Ataulfo.

headline: The Car Rental Company Silvercar Adds Locations
text: Silvercar, which has won notice for avoiding the problem of lines at car-rental counters, recently announced plans to add five more destinations to its lineup before the end of year.

headline: Mango Ice Means Summer Is Now
text: May is an in-between fruit month. We’re tired of winter apples, pears and oranges, and summer stone fruits aren’t yet in season, though some varieties are now available in California because of the hot winter. It’s a great time to think about mangos because the varieties that we find in the supermarket are in season. Most are imported from Mexico, Haiti and Central America, and some are grown in Florida.

headline: Missing 13th-Century Painting to be Returned to Owners in Court Settlement
text: In 1977, two London art dealers bought a 13th-century “Madonna and Child” that they believed had been painted by an early-Renaissance master, Duccio di Buoninsegna. Ownership shares were divided among several partners, but in 1986, the work went missing from a vault in Geneva.

headline: Auctionata Announces New Backer
text: Auctionata, an online auction site that broadcasts live streams of sales of art, watches, jewelry and other luxury objects from studios in Berlin and New York, has won a prominent backer as it competes with others trying to sell more and more art via the web.

headline: A Ballet to Open Versailles’s New Water Theater Grove
text: This week, the Château de Versailles inaugurated its newly renovated Water Theater grove with an original 10-minute performance by the new Paris Opera Ballet director Benjamin Millepied’s L.A. Dance Project. “It’s the first ballet in the grove since the time of Louis XIV,” said the artist Jean-Michel Othoniel, whose idea it was to include the company in the celebrations. The four-year project, led by the celebrated French landscape architect Louis Benech, reimagined André Le Nôtre’s long-neglected 18th-century hedged secret garden and outdoor theater as something far edgier, with angular, rusted steel-framed pools and Othoniel’s swirling gold-bead fountains based on the Baroque choreographer Raoul-Auger Feuillet’s shorthand notations of period dances. “It seems absolutely natural that this bosquet as it is now is here,” mused the Versailles president Catherine Pégard, as she sat in the shade of one of the new Japanese angelica trees and proudly took it all in. “It’s a totally contemporary work that is perfectly integrated into the park’s history. So harmonious.” Above is a closer look at yesterday’s show.

headline: Clip: ‘Animals’
text: A scene from the film directed by Collin Schiffli and starring David Dastmalchian and Kim Shaw.

headline: Review: ‘A Queen for a Day’ Excavates Crime Family Secrets
text: Tony Soprano had to go to a psychiatrist for us to hear about his personal problems. In “A Queen for a Day,” Michael Ricigliano Jr.’s high-strung one-act drama at the Theater at St. Clement’s, the secrets come pouring out at a clandestine meeting inside an ugly warehouse on a Sunday morning when Nino Cinquimani (David Proval), a made man, would rather be at Mass.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Nepal, Burundi, Pakistan and Germany.

headline: Kerry Speaks After Meeting With Putin
text: After an earlier meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday, Secretary of State John Kerry appeared with Russia’s foreign minister and spoke about the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: May 12, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Nepal, Burundi, Pakistan and Germany.

headline: Review: Pierre Huyghe Mixes Stones and Water for Roof Garden at the Met
text: Visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Roof Garden this summer might suppose at first that the maintenance crew has been tearing up the terrace’s paving stones in search of a leak. Displaced slabs are stacked next to rectangular cavities exposing underlying dirt where puddles and rivulets have gathered. In fact, the apparent disarray belongs to an installation by the French Conceptualist Pierre Huyghe, an untitled work commissioned by the Met for its annual Roof Garden show. Conceived by Sheena Wagstaff, the Met’s chairwoman of modern and contemporary art, and organized by Ian Alteveer, an associate curator of modern and contemporary art, it’s an intriguing but dry, cerebrally puzzling and disconnected affair.

headline: 3 Somali Natives Who ‘Went Home to Fight’ Plead Guilty to Terror Charges in Brooklyn
text: Hours before jury selection was to start in their trial, three Somali-born men pleaded guilty on Tuesday to conspiracy to support a terrorist group, stemming from their fighting for the Shabab in Somalia.

headline: Review: Kate Soper’s Songs of Sirens and Female Identity
text: It has been heartening, as Meredith Monk’s 50th-anniversary season has gone on, to hear not just examples of her own work but also her continued influence on younger artists. In the extended vocal techniques, the flirting with nonsense, the juxtaposition of levity and melancholy in ensembles like Roomful of Teeth and Carmina Slovenica and events like the Resonant Bodies Festival, Ms. Monk’s fingerprints have been visible.

headline: What You Get for ... $850,000
text: This week’s homes include a Victorian in New Jersey, a Colonial in Alaska and an updated modern in Arizona.

headline: Cystic Fibrosis Drug Wins Approval of F.D.A. Advisory Panel
text: A federal advisory committee on Tuesday recommended approval of a drug from Vertex Pharmaceuticals that might eventually help nearly half of patients with cystic fibrosis.

headline: Gardner Museum Offers New Reward for Item Taken in 1990 Heist
text: Even today at auction, the Napoleonic finial stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston about 25 years ago would not likely fetch more than $10,000, experts say.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: David Letterman Leaves His Successors a Rich Comedic Bequest
text: In the most praised installment of his still-young stint as host of “The Late Late Show,” James Corden crashed a stranger’s home, set up cameras and recorded an entire episode. Mr. Corden called it an “experiment” and CBS promoted the show online as “making late-night history.”

headline: Kremlin Critic’s Posthumous Report Links Russian Soldiers to Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — Members of Russia’s political opposition published a posthumous report by the politician Boris Y. Nemtsov on Tuesday that documented the deaths of 220 Russian soldiers in the fighting in southeastern Ukraine, even though the Kremlin denies being involved in the war there.

headline: For Verizon and AOL, Mobile Is a Magic Word
text: In a memo to employees after announcing that Verizon Communications would buy his company for $4.4 billion, Tim Armstrong, AOL’s chief executive, offered a rhapsodic hymn on a single subject: mobile.

headline: Review: ‘Forbidden Films’ Details Nazi Propaganda
text: “One ticket for ‘Jud Süss,’ please” are not words one expects to hear decades after the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II. But there they are, spoken by a moviegoer shown in “Forbidden Films: The Hidden Legacy of Nazi Film,” an unnerving documentary that considers the legacy of the Third Reich’s propaganda films. Moments later in the same sequence chronicling a rare public screening of the anti-Semitic movie, we glimpse a box-office sign, “ ‘Jud Süss’ sold out,” like some vision from an awful alternate universe.

headline: Venice Biennale Features Mika Rottenberg’s ‘NoNoseKnows’
text: VENICE — Running across a shimmering pearl market smack dab in the heart of the 56th Venice Biennale doesn’t seem particularly odd, given this city’s history as the West’s watery mall for the exquisite and the exotic.

headline: Facing Vicious Debt Cycle, Greece Sprints to Apply Fixes
text: PARIS — By now it has become familiar: Greece warns that it is about to run out of cash, then manages to scrape together enough to avoid defaulting on its debts. A larger catastrophe is averted in the eurozone, and Greece and its creditors return to haggling over whether the country can get more financial aid.

headline: Review: ‘Two Shots Fired,’ Martín Rejtman’s Absurdist Tale
text: The droll, shape-shifting “Two Shots Fired,” the newest movie from the Argentine filmmaker Martín Rejtman (the subject of a current retrospective at the Film Society of Lincoln Center), accomplishes the strange feat of constantly thwarting expectations without ever varying its tone or moving the needle of excitement.

headline: Review: American Ballet Theater Opens Season at Lincoln Center
text: Other cities around the world have more than one major ballet company, but no balletomane delirium compares to that arising from the annual Lincoln Center fever. For four weeks, American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet play simultaneously (Ballet Theater eight performances per week, City Ballet seven) at the Metropolitan Opera House and the David H. Koch Theater. And choosing between the two adjacent houses becomes a crazed annual luxury that makes other ballet scenes look parched. There are loyalists who would never pay a visit to the other company; but for those who attend both, the differences make the world of ballet seem vast and rich. This year’s fever began this week.

headline: Jeb Bush Clarifies Remarks on Supporting Iraq War
text: Jeb Bush sought to tamp down a two-day controversy over comments he made in an interview with the Fox News host Megyn Kelly, in which he suggested that he still supported invading Iraq even with hindsight knowledge about intelligence failures. On Tuesday, he said he had misunderstood her question.

headline: The Detail in Seymour Hersh’s Bin Laden Story That Rings True
text: From the moment it was announced to the public, the tale of how Osama bin Laden met his death in a Pakistani hill town in May 2011 has been a changeable feast. In the immediate aftermath of the Navy SEAL team’s assault on his Abbottabad compound, American and Pakistani government accounts contradicted themselves and each other. In his speech announcing the operation’s success, President Obama said that “our counterterrorism cooperation with Pakistan helped lead us to Bin Laden and the compound where he was hiding.”

headline: Review: In ‘Wayward Pines,’ a Small Town Reveals Its Layers
text: There are remedies for insomnia — Ambien, Lunesta and “Wayward Pines.”

headline: Deal Talks for Here Mapping Service Expose Reliance on Location Data
text: When people look up a company’s Facebook page on their smartphones, the address is overlaid on a digital map provided by Here, Nokia’s mapping unit, which is for sale.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: A Conversation With Joseph P. Beninati
text: Mr. Beninati, 51, is a founder and the managing member of the Bauhouse Group, a development company based in New York and started in 2012. The company’s projects include 515 Highline, a boutique condominium with a wavy facade designed by Soo K. Chan and a high-rise condominium in the Sutton Place neighborhood.

headline: Living In East Brunswick, N.J.
text: Strip malls and commercial towers coexist with scenic recreation areas and a community garden in this multicultural central New Jersey township.

headline: Verizon Wireless and Sprint to Pay $158 Million to Settle Billing Investigations
text: The Federal Communications Commission announced on Tuesday that Verizon Wireless and Sprint had agreed to pay a combined $158 million to settle investigations into millions of dollars of unauthorized charges that appeared on customers’ cellphone bills through a practice known as cramming.

headline: Recent Commercial Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Life on the Edge in Rural Nepal
text: On a steep cliff northeast of Kathmandu, one family is forced to live outside, mourning the dead and worrying that rains from the coming monsoons will create more deadly landslides.

headline: No Charges for Wisconsin Officer in Killing of Unarmed Black Teenager
text: A Madison, Wis., police officer who killed an unarmed black man in March, in one of a spate of similar incidents that have set off protests around the country, will not face criminal charges, a prosecutor said Tuesday.

headline: A Kayak Trip on the Hudson, Ending in Death and an Arrest
text: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — They seemed the picture of love, a handsome couple who doted on their cat, partied with friends at local pubs and paddled the Hudson River in kayaks they stored in their apartment here.

headline: In Post-Election Britain, Talk Turns to European Union
text: LONDON — The issue was barely featured in an election focused on the economy, health and the impact of rising nationalism in Scotland.

headline: New York State Ending Fight on Tappan Zee Bridge Loan
text: New York State officials have ceded to the federal Environmental Protection Agency in a contentious battle over financing of the replacement Tappan Zee Bridge, agreeing not to pursue an appeal after the agency rejected the state’s request for a $511 million low-interest loan.

headline: Liberia’s Military Tries to Remedy Tension Over Ebola Quarantine
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — The chief of staff for the Armed Forces of Liberia, Brig. Gen. Daniel D. Ziankahn Jr., hung up his navy blue suit, put on a bright yellow jersey and shorts, then bounded toward a sandy field.

headline: Bill Simmons Absent From ESPN’s Upfront Presentation
text: Bill Simmons was unseen and unmentioned during ESPN’s upfront presentation to advertisers on Tuesday — as if he had never existed.

headline: London Real Estate Sizzles Off Campus
text: LONDON — Joyce Ge, a student from China who is studying business management at King’s College, pays 880 pounds a month, or $1,310, to live in a pint-size, stylish studio apartment in the far reaches of east London, in a building with roof decks gazing toward the distant city skyline. Her rent covers water and electricity, as well as Wi-Fi and cleaning of common spaces every two weeks.

headline: Jeb Bush, Ana Navarro and the Question That May Have Been Misheard
text: MIAMI — The media’s preferred expert on Jeb Bush’s inner thoughts tried to explain on Tuesday morning the likely Republican presidential candidate’s much discussed remarks to an interviewer that, even knowing what he knows now, he would have authorized the invasion of Iraq.

headline: Oil Industry Asks Court to Block Rail Transport Safety Rules
text: The oil industry is challenging new federal rules intended to improve the safety of oil-by-train transportation, opening the first legal fight in a two-year effort to reduce the risks of moving hazardous materials on railroads.

headline: Rolling Stone Rape Article Results in Defamation Suit
text: An associate dean at the University of Virginia filed a defamation lawsuit on Tuesday against Rolling Stone magazine, which she said portrayed her as the “chief villain” in a discredited article about a gang rape on the university’s campus.

headline: Wells, Brady Investigation Director, Criticizes Report’s Critics
text: The lawyer Theodore V. Wells Jr., who directed the N.F.L.-commissioned investigation into whether Tom Brady and other New England Patriots employees conspired to improperly deflate footballs during last season’s playoffs, vehemently defended the conclusions and the integrity of his report Tuesday.

headline: A Day in the Park
text: People gathered on the lawn in Bryant Park in Manhattan on Tuesday as the temperature climbed into the 80s. The lawn opened officially on Monday.

headline: Barcelona Ushers Resigned Bayern Munich Out of Champions League
text: MUNICH — The drama, such as it was, lasted seven minutes.

headline: Man Sentenced to 23 Years for Stabbing Five in Riverside Park
text: A man who went on a rampage with a broken pair of scissors in Riverside Park in Manhattan and stabbed five people, including a child in a stroller, was sentenced to 23 years in prison on Tuesday.

headline: Cuba Ready to Exchange Diplomats, Raúl Castro Says
text: MEXICO CITY — The United States and Cuba appear to be edging closer to an agreement to restore full diplomatic ties, with President Raúl Castro of Cuba saying Tuesday that his country was ready to exchange ambassadors once it was formally removed this month from the American government’s list of states sponsoring terrorism.

headline: Lundqvist Stretches, Hoping to Extend Rangers’ Run
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The day before the biggest game of the Rangers’ season, Henrik Lundqvist headed onto the ice for practice about 15 minutes early and began his routine. He skated in a big circle, moving his feet in and out, warming up his legs. He crouched down and stretched, contorting his body every which way.

headline: A Narrow Opening for Arctic Oil
text: The Obama administration’s conditional grant of approval to Royal Dutch Shell to drill for oil off the coast of Alaska raises obvious concerns about the damage a major spill could cause to the fragile Arctic environment. But it is hardly a surprise. Shell acquired the lease for just over $2 billion in 2008, and, absent a very good reason, the government felt obliged to approve it.

headline: A Few Items Speak Volumes About the Life of a Father
text: The brothers and I sold our dad’s apartment the other day, and the night before, the broker emailed a reminder that still on the premises were a mirror, a desk lamp and a wooden chair with rolling casters on the legs. Not bad. The man had lived in two Manhattan apartments for the better part of seven decades and just three things were left. At some point, you can’t throw every blessed thing out.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Publicist Loses Round in Lawsuit Over Show’s Travails
text: The Broadway publicist who has been accused of scuttling the star-crossed musical “Rebecca” had several setbacks in State Supreme Court on Tuesday.

headline: Obama Speaks About Poverty and Race
text: The president took part in a panel discussion on poverty at Georgetown University on Tuesday, where he spoke of some of the reasons for wealth inequality and breaking the cycle of poverty.

headline: Steve Kerr Relies on Bad Cinema to Shake Up the Warriors
text: MEMPHIS — As the Golden State Warriors gathered their belongings in the visitors’ locker room at FedEx Forum on Monday night, a staff member announced that the first bus to the airport would depart at 11:50 p.m. The Warriors had evened their Western Conference semifinal series with the Memphis Grizzlies at two games apiece, and they were headed home.

headline: F.B.I. Says It Broke Its Rules in Inquiry of Keystone Pipeline Opponents
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation violated its own guidelines in 2013 when it investigated environmental advocates who opposed the Keystone XL pipeline, the F.B.I. acknowledged on Tuesday.

headline: Inspectors in Syria Find Traces of Banned Military Chemicals
text: International inspectors have found traces of banned toxic chemicals in at least three military locations in Syria, four diplomats and officials said, less than two years after President Bashar al-Assad agreed to dismantle the country’s chemical arsenal.

headline: New York City Marathon Chief Finds Next Step Has Arrived
text: On the day that Mary Wittenberg, the chief executive of New York Road Runners, announced that she was quitting her job after nearly two decades with the organization, she needed a minute to decide what memories she would cherish the most.

headline: Shell’s Record Adds to the Anger of Those Opposing Arctic Drilling
text: When the Obama administration announced on Monday that it would let Shell drill for oil off the Alaskan coast this year if it met certain conditions, environmentalists were outraged — not just by the administration’s decision to allow drilling, but by its decision to give Shell, in particular, the green light.

headline: De Blasio, in Washington, Unveils Campaign to Promote Liberal Causes
text: WASHINGTON — Mayor Bill de Blasio stood with allies from across the country here on Tuesday, making his case that the liberal beliefs that catapulted him to City Hall in New York were about to go national.

headline: As Obama Plays China Card on Trade, Chinese Pursue Their Own Deals
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has toured Nike’s headquarters and busy American ports in recent weeks to try to convince Democrats that rejecting the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a 12-nation trade deal that he envisions as a crucial part of a legacy of national economic revival, will undercut American power.

headline: Passer Filling Brady’s Shoes Set Out to Follow in Footsteps
text: On the night last May when Jimmy Garoppolo was drafted, his personal quarterback coach, Jeff Christensen, had a hunch. He called his son and predicted that Garoppolo would be chosen by the New England Patriots.

headline: Alaska’s Tricky Intersection of Obama’s Energy and Climate Legacies
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s move to open up vast, untouched Arctic waters to oil and gas drilling as he pursues an ambitious plan to fight climate change illustrates the inherent tensions in his environmental and energy agenda.

headline: Wegmans to Open at Brooklyn Navy Yard
text: Not many grocery stores can claim cult followings, certainly not in Brooklyn, where the only options in some neighborhoods tend to be oversize bodegas carrying expired goods or overpriced green grocers full of kale, quinoa and craft beer.

headline: Turning 90, Yogi Berra Is Still a Cherished M.V.P.
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — Upon hearing that his stash of 10 World Series championship rings and three Most Valuable Player Award plaques had been stolen from the museum and learning center in his name on the campus of Montclair State University last October, Yogi Berra responded with his brand of unpretentious wisdom.

headline: F.D.A. Proposal Would End Ban on Blood Donation
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday released its proposal for scrapping a decades-old lifetime ban on blood donation by gay and bisexual men. The proposal was criticized when it was first announced, in December, because men who have had sex with men in the last 12 months would still not be allowed to give blood. The limited prohibition is comparable to rules in many European countries, but critics said it did not take into account modern diagnostic tools that can detect H.I.V. infection as early as nine to 11 days after exposure. The contested part of the proposal remains unchanged in Tuesday’s version, which details the policy and is open to public comment for 60 days before a final decision. In a nod to transgender Americans, the proposal allows donors to report their gender; under current policy, eligibility is determined strictly based on a donor’s sex at birth.

headline: Fire Prompts Renewed Calls to Close the Indian Point Nuclear Plant
text: To protect marine life in the Hudson River, environmental advocates have been calling for the Indian Point nuclear power plant to shut down for several weeks each year beginning in May. This year, they got part of what they wished for — but in a way they would have preferred not to.

headline: Illinois: Chicago’s Credit Rating Is Downgraded
text: Days after the Illinois Supreme Court rejected an overhaul aimed at shoring up the state’s troubled pension system, Chicago, the state’s largest city, saw its credit rating downgraded two levels to junk status on Tuesday by Moody’s Investors Service. The move could mean higher borrowing costs for Chicago, which is wrestling with an underfunded pension system of its own. The State Supreme Court opinion, issued last week, barred the state from lowering pension benefits for public employees under a provision of the Illinois Constitution, but it also raised doubts about the legality of changes Chicago has made to two of its pension funds. Mayor Rahm Emanuel criticized Moody’s downgrade as premature. “While Chicago’s financial crisis is very real and at our doorsteps, today’s irresponsible decision by Moody’s to downgrade the city’s credit by two steps goes far beyond that reality,” Mr. Emanuel said.

headline: Cablevision Ending Bid for Daily News
text: The cable company Cablevision is planning to drop out of the bidding process for The Daily News in New York, according to a person familiar with the deal who was not authorized to disclose details of the negotiations and spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Navy F/A-18 Fighter Jet Crashes in Persian Gulf
text: A Navy F/A-18 Super Hornet fighter jet crashed on Tuesday shortly after it was launched from the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt in the Persian Gulf. The two pilots ejected and were rescued, but the crash, which is now under investigation, underscores the daily risks facing military aviators.

headline: Obama Library Announced in Chicago
text: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago and the chairman of the Obama Foundation, Martin Nesbitt, spoke on Tuesday of the president’s decision to build his library in Chicago.

headline: Judges Close Conspiracy Case Against Argentina’s President
text: BUENOS AIRES — A criminal case against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner was closed Tuesday when federal judges accepted a prosecutor’s decision not to pursue accusations that she had conspired to shield Iranians suspected of planning the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center here.

headline: Alternative to Boeuf or Jambon
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — May is the birthday month of the film actor and director ORSON WELLES, who was born in 1915 and who would have turned 100 years old on May 6 of this year.

headline: Can I Change My Name to Avoid Discrimination?
text: The Ethicists consider what information is, and isn’t, O.K. to leave out on a job application.

headline: Conviction Rates Count More in Chinese Justice Than Innocence
text: WUTIAN, China — It did not matter to the police that the man they seized in August 2013 was nearly 20 years older than the one wanted on fraud charges. Nor were the officers bothered by the fact that his cellphone number and a character in his name differed from those of the suspect, or by his repeated professions of innocence.

headline: Data Disclosure Leads Researchers to End Study of Obesity Drug
text: A study of an obesity drug has ended after the manufacturer released early and ultimately misleading data, researchers said on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Will Remain Tough on Iran, Obama Tells Arab Newspaper
text: WASHINGTON — Ahead of a two-day meeting with senior officials from a half-dozen Persian Gulf countries, President Obama on Tuesday defended his efforts to reach a nuclear deal with Iran, but promised that the United States would not stop trying to prevent Iranian aggression against other nations in the region.

headline: Jeb Bush Says He Misinterpreted Iraq Query
text: Jeb Bush on Tuesday sought to arrest a chorus of criticism from Democrats and some conservatives after he told an interviewer that, knowing what history has since shown about intelligence failures, he still would have authorized the 2003 invasion of Iraq.

headline: Prosecutor in ‘Cannibal Cop’ Case Asks Appeals Court to Reinstate Conviction
text: A prosecutor asked a federal appeals panel on Tuesday to reinstate the kidnapping conspiracy conviction of Gilberto Valle, a former New York police officer who had been accused of plotting online to abduct, torture, kill and eat women.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: You told me that you believed in me, and that was the day I decided to dedicate my childhood to jazz.

headline: Capitals’ Ward Seeks Another Signature Moment in the Postseason
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — In Game 7 of the 2012 Eastern Conference quarterfinals, Washington Capitals forward Joel Ward took a backhanded swing at a loose puck and sent it tumbling past Boston Bruins goalie Tim Thomas in overtime. With that goal, the Bruins, the defending Stanley Cup champions, were eliminated from the postseason, and Ward entered the annals of postseason heroes.

headline: Crew Change on International Space Station Is Delayed
text: Following the failed launch of a Russian resupply rocket, NASA and its space agency partners decided on Tuesday to delay three astronauts’ return from the International Space Station, according to officials.

headline: This Summer, Brooklyn Bazaar Heads to the Bathhouse at Jacob Riis Park
text: Over the last few years, Rockaway Beach in Queens has become a haven for foodies and hipsters in search of tacos, lobster rolls and surf. But to the west along the Rockaway Peninsula, the giant Art Deco bathhouse at Jacob Riis Park, a National Park Service property, stood all but abandoned. Renovation work that began in the 1990s stalled, and then came a one-two punch of Tropical Storm Irene and Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Group Supporting de Blasio’s Agenda Is Said to Draw Interest of Ethics Panel
text: A political group run by close allies of Mayor Bill de Blasio has attracted the interest of a New York State ethics panel, which is concerned that the group could be violating lobbying rules, according to two people familiar with the inquiry.

headline: Seattle Port Votes to Delay Drilling Rigs on the Way to Alaska
text: SEATTLE — The Port of Seattle’s board voted Tuesday to ask that the arrival of Shell’s Arctic drilling rigs be delayed, bowing to a wave of public pressure by protesters and city officials over the company’s plans to drill this summer off the coast of Alaska and use Puget Sound as a home port.

headline: Amtrak Train Derails in Philadelphia, Killing at Least 5 and Injuring Dozens
text: PHILADELPHIA — At least five people were killed and dozens more were injured when an Amtrak train carrying 243 people derailed here on Tuesday, shutting down service in the Northeast region, the authorities said.

headline: Campaign for One New York Memo
text: A letter from the Campaign for One New York, which was created by Mayor Bill de Blasio’s consultants to raise money and attention for his political agenda.

headline: Camp Taji Incident Report Declassified After 12 Years
text: The Iraq Survey Group said that in 2003, more than 20 American soldiers at Iraq’s Camp Taji were exposed to “a carcinogen and poisonous chemical.”

headline: Sharpshooting LeBron James Goes All Out as Cavaliers Top Bulls
text: CLEVELAND — The perfectionist in LeBron James had frowned on the inefficient way he played in the first four games of the Eastern Conference semifinals, the way he dominated the ball, shoveled up contested shots and committed a multitude of turnovers. The pragmatist in James, though, knew the misses and miscues were a necessary byproduct of putting a beat-up team on his back.

headline: Regrets? Yankees Have a Few in Defeat
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — When the Yankees have played well, and even when they have not, they have generally played with veterans’ poise. They have rarely been ruffled or made to look as if they were anything other than calm and in control while rolling up the best record in the American League six weeks into the season.

headline: Noah Syndergaard’s Mets Debut Has Smooth Start and Bumpy End
text: CHICAGO — In his major league debut Tuesday night, Noah Syndergaard faced the Chicago Cubs, a team that not long ago was considered a possible trade destination for him.

headline: Amtrak Train Derails in Philadelphia
text: Amtrak Train 188 crashed in Philadelphia.

headline: North Korea Said to Execute a Top Official, With an Antiaircraft Gun
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The second-highest officer in North Korea’s military was recently executed as a traitor for showing disrespect for the nation’s leader, Kim Jong-un, South Korean intelligence officials told lawmakers here Wednesday.

headline: At Frieze, Artists’ Trash Is Collectors’ Treasure
text: “We probably should have just done what was expected of us and sold standard contemporary art to support Bidoun, but we tend to be at a bit of a right angle to convention,” says the Bidoun senior editor Negar Azimi of the project conceived by the publishing and nonprofit curatorial outfit when it was offered a complimentary booth at Frieze New York this year. “Can you imagine saying no to a Wade Guyton work and taking his shoes instead?” Azimi, and Bidoun’s creative director Babak Radboy, had long been fascinated with the culture of collecting — often at great expense — disposable celebrity ephemera. “Babak has trolled around the Internet looking at the sales of such oddball items as the Justin Bieber hairball, Marilyn Monroe’s chest X-ray, Britney Spears’ pregnancy test or Kurt Cobain’s credit card,” Azimi says. “All fascinating and occasionally terrifying.”

headline: Collared, Sleeved and Oh-So-’70s
text: Polo shirts get the retro treatment this summer with graphic prints, close fits and nostalgic colors.

headline: What Chrissy Teigen Thinks She Looks Like: Kid Rock
text: In this new series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment illustrate their responses to a brief questionnaire, revealing their favorite things, darkest secrets — and how they see themselves and the world around them.

headline: Private Jet Travel Takes Off
text: Private-jet travel has long been synonymous with luxury, but in recent years it’s become something else: big business. The post-Sept. 11 security apparatus and the rise of the one percent have made flying private an increasingly attractive option. First came NetJets, which expanded the clientele beyond plane-owning plutocrats to those interested in part-time shares. Now, on-demand and membership-based apps like JetSmarter, BlackJet and Beacon have proliferated, driving the per-person price of private flights closer to that of commercial first class and making hailing a Learjet as easy as ordering up an Uber. Here, an inside look at one of travel’s fastest growing sectors.

headline: A Rothko Tops Sotheby’s Contemporary Art Auction
text: It was a hard act to follow. Just one day after Christie’s raised $705.9 million from its experimental auction of cherry-picked 20th-century masterworks, Sotheby’s responded with a mainstream evening sale on Tuesday that aimed to remind the art world that there is more than one auction house in New York.

headline: Facebook Begins Testing Instant Articles From News Publishers
text: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Facebook’s long-rumored plan to directly host articles from news organizations will start on Wednesday, concluding months of delicate negotiations between the Internet giant and publishers that covet its huge audience but fear its growing power.

headline: Voters in Arkansas Tourist Town Uphold Anti-Discrimination Law
text: Residents in the small Arkansas tourist town Eureka Springs voted Tuesday to uphold an ordinance to prevent discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity, rejecting an argument by opponents that the measure could harm tourism and force churches to host same-sex weddings and receptions.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 1:20 A.M. (Starz) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Cate Blanchett, above with Peter Sarsgaard, won an Oscar for her role as Jasmine French, a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times after her husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), lands in prison for bilking his clients, leaving her with little more than her pearls, Chanel jacket, Hermès bag and Louis Vuitton luggage. Destitute, in a manner of speaking, Jasmine flies first-class to San Francisco to begin life anew with her sister, Ginger (Sally Hawkins), whose scrappy existence and brutish men Jasmine can barely stomach without self-medicating with vodka and Xanax. Then she meets a diplomatic type (Mr. Sarsgaard) with an appreciation for her decorating talents and designer threads and starts to see light at the end of her dark tunnel. With intimations of Ruth Madoff and Blanche DuBois, this shattered woman is “brilliantly brought to quivering life by Ms. Blanchett,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, in Woody Allen’s “most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since ‘Match Point.’ ”

headline: South Korean Reservist Goes on Shooting Rampage Before Killing Himself
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean Army reservist shot and killed a fellow soldier and wounded three others at a firing range on Wednesday before committing suicide, a Defense Ministry spokesman said.

headline: Moore’s Law Turns 50
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On April 19, 1965, just over 50 years ago, Gordon Moore, then the head of research for Fairchild Semiconductor and later one of the co-founders of Intel, was asked by Electronics Magazine to submit an article predicting what was going to happen to integrated circuits, the heart of computing, in the next 10 years. Studying the trend he’d seen in the previous few years, Moore predicted that every year we’d double the number of transistors that could fit on a single chip of silicon so you’d get twice as much computing power for only slightly more money. When that came true, in 1975, he modified his prediction to a doubling roughly every two years. “Moore’s Law” has essentially held up ever since — and, despite the skeptics, keeps chugging along, making it probably the most remarkable example ever of sustained exponential growth of a technology.

headline: La Guardia Airport: Fix It or Shut It?
The Rohingya Refugees, Adrift
text: Thousands of people, both Muslim Rohingyas fleeing persecution in Myanmar and Bangladeshis seeking jobs in Malaysia, have been abandoned at sea recently in Southeast Asia by smugglers fearing arrest as Thailand cracks down on human traffickers. At least 8,000 people are in peril, yet the Southeast Asian nations off whose shores they drift have been reluctant to save them.

headline: Amtrak Train Derailed Going 106 M.P.H. on Sharp Curve; at Least 7 Killed
text: PHILADELPHIA — An engineer jammed on the emergency brakes just seconds before Tuesday’s fatal Amtrak derailment, but the train — traveling at 106 miles an hour, more than twice the speed limit — slowed only slightly, federal authorities said, before hurtling off its tracks, killing at least seven people and injuring more than 200.

headline: East Brunswick, N.J.: Community Gardens, Parks and Highways
text: Despite the cool spring weather, Elora Gupta and her family were trying to get a jump on preparing their plot in East Brunswick’s community garden on a recent Sunday afternoon. While Ms. Gupta’s husband, Samir, leveled the soil, she sorted through the cucumber, tomato and squash seedlings and their son, Shayan, 15, unspooled the community hose.

headline: Frances Tiafoe, a Rising U.S. Tennis Player, Shakes Things Up On and Off the Court
text: At 17, Frances Tiafoe, one of the most eagerly anticipated new arrivals for American tennis, has shown up on the doorstep of one of the sport’s biggest stages far ahead of schedule.

headline: The $179 Million Picasso That Explains Global Inequality
text: We don’t yet know who agreed to pay $179.4 million for a Picasso in an auction Monday night — or where the money came from, or what motivated that person or persons to spend more than anyone has before for a single piece of art at auction.

headline: Mixing Cuisines, Mexicue Moves Beyond the Food Truck
text: When David Schillace told his friends and family in 2010 that he planned to quit his six-figure-salary job in sales and marketing, cash in his 401(k) retirement plan and start a new career selling a blend of Mexican and barbecue food out of a truck on the streets of Manhattan, there was stunned silence. Then came the tears.

headline: Michael Heizer’s Big Work and Long View
text: GARDEN VALLEY, NEV. — One breezy spring day last month, I drove back here to see Michael Heizer at his desert ranch, a compound bordered by cottonwoods and alfalfa. “If you’ve even been in a field of alfalfa with the meadowlarks and the rabbits and the kingbirds,” he said, “well, that’s a God moment. You haven’t lived until then. It’s what has kept me alive.”

headline: House Approves Revised Measure Banning Most Abortions After 20 Weeks

headline: Do Your Friends on Social Media All Have the Same Political Opinions You Do?
text: Do most of your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat and other social media friends seem to have the same basic beliefs about politics, religion and other ideological topics as you do? How can you tell?

headline: Karachi Attack Kills Over 40 on Bus Carrying Members of Shiite Sect
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — At least 43 people were killed when unidentified gunmen opened fire on a bus in the Pakistani port city of Karachi early Wednesday, police officials said. The gunmen escaped.

headline: ‘Goebbels: A Biography,’ by Peter Longerich
text: The historical landscape is littered with the wreckage of regimes, many of them defeated after long and bloody struggles, but there is nothing in modern European history quite like the destructive fury with which Hitler’s Thousand-Year Reich came to an end. Long after any hope of victory had been extinguished, the government’s supporters kept on fighting, killing not only their enemies, both real and imagined, but also many of their fellow countrymen whose commitment to the cause seemed to waver. And finally they began to kill themselves. Among the scores of Germans who committed suicide in Nazi Germany’s final hours were Dr. ­Joseph Goebbels, minister of propaganda and, since July 1944, “Reich Plenipotentiary for Total War,” and his wife, Magda. Before ending their own lives, they murdered their six children, five girls and a boy; the oldest, Helga, was 12, the youngest, Heide, 4.

headline: How Facebook’s News Feed Will Change on Mobile

headline: Toyota and Nissan Recall 6.5 Million More Vehicles Over Takata Airbags
text: For months, the problem of defective airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata has festered in the auto industry as recalls have mounted and automakers have searched for the reason that the airbags can explode violently, sending pieces of metal into the cabin.

headline: Into the Wild
text: I once ate a picnic in a canoe floating down a river. We were in the Périgord, and had expected the French families in boats alongside us to retrieve carefully made lunches from baskets at midday. But all had brought potato chips and sodas or beer instead. They watched us, benevolently jealous, as we laid out chilled artichokes and mayonnaise, Bayonne ham, tiny walnut-studded sausages, Cabecou cheese, figs, little tumblers and a bottle of rosé in the canoe’s deep middle. The Dordogne is a slow river, but it was intoxicating to eat with such naïve pomp amid the burbles of small eddies and chirping birds, mingling those two basic impulses of human life: the wild and the tame.

headline: ‘The Other Side of the Mountain’
text: After an attempt to return to Olympic glory ended in paralysis, Laís Souza rebuilds her life one movement at a time.

headline: Search for Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet Uncovers Shipwreck’s Remnants
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Search crews looking for a Malaysia Airlines jet believed to have crashed in the southern Indian Ocean have found the remnants of a shipwreck — including an anchor and possibly a ship’s bell — resting on the seabed almost two and a half miles down.

headline: Alison Bechdel Misses Feeling Special
text: You’ve been very well known for a long time among lesbians for your comic strip, “Dykes to Watch Out For.” Now a musical adaptation of your graphic novel-memoir “Fun Home” just opened on Broadway, and last year you won a MacArthur “genius” grant. How does it feel to become suddenly mainstream? I’m so glad it didn’t happen when I was younger, because then it would have been all downhill.

headline: No Justice, No ... Anything

headline: In Cambodia, Along the Path to Something Profound
text: I tiptoed across the wood planks of a wobbly orange boat heading from the riverside town Kampot to the Gulf of Thailand. I burned my bare feet on the shiny outdoor tiles surrounding a Buddhist stupa at Udong, the old capital of Cambodia. Across the country, at the 11th-century ruins of Phnom Banan, I spelunked through deep, damp caverns steeped in legends of magic and superstition. All the way, I followed a Frenchman named Henri. For 16 years and more than 20 trips, he has led me through the heart of this beautiful but knotty country.

headline: Can I Change My Name to Avoid Discrimination?
text: Is it ethical to modify my name on a job application to prevent unconscious bias? For instance, if my name were Samantha, I could apply as Sam, or if my name were Jose, I could apply as Joe, to prevent discrimination based on gender or assumed ethnicity. If it is ethical, up to which point may I modify? A.R., LONDON

headline: Morning Agenda: Mobile Tech Key to AOL-Verizon Merger

Verizon’s $4.4 billion purchase of AOL is “just the latest corporate reaction to a staggering shift in the way people across the globe get their news and entertainment,” he writes.

headline: Shining a Light on Gay-Straight Marriages in China
text: Zhang Beichuan, a medical researcher at the Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University, collects stories about some of the millions of Chinese heterosexuals who are married to homosexuals. Most of these tales involve deception, and sometimes violence and sexually transmitted diseases. But in an email interview this week, Mr. Zhang wondered whether the deception, and the emotional and physical suffering it brings, might — slowly — be diminishing.

headline: With ‘Animals,’ David Dastmalchian Uses His Past to Rewrite His Future
text: Early in the gritty drama “Animals,” a couple named Jude and Bobbie, who live in a car in Chicago, steal CDs from a record shop and sell them for cash to buy heroin. Then they head to a diner to shoot it up in adjacent bathrooms. The movie, written by David Dastmalchian, who lost nearly 50 pounds to play Jude, is fiction, but some of its scenarios came from a time when he was an addict himself.

headline: When Doctors Help a Patient Die
text: The patient was terminally ill. He had decided to end his life under his state’s “death with dignity” law, and his doctor prescribed the medication he would use to do it. But his death was unexpectedly delayed because he drank a large soda before taking the medication — an ordinarily lethal dose — and it apparently interfered with the drug’s absorption. I’ve been told that patients who want to die are now warned not to drink carbonated beverages before or after taking the medication.

headline: 1965: Mrs. Kennedy Stars at Palace
text: LONDON — Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy today made her first public appearance in London since the assassination of her husband — and stole the show from the famed Irish Guards band. Strolling with her two children, Caroline, 7, and John, 4, plus her sister, Princess Radziwill, and the princess’s two children and a pair of dogs, Mrs. Kennedy headed an eye-catching party. Outside Buckingham Palace, she halted to catch the changing of the guard when the crowd recognized her. A palace official hurried out and escorted her inside the palace gates. The Irish Guards band filled the air with music as they marched, but the crowd’s eyes were not on the colorful guardsmen today. — New York Herald Tribune, European edition, May 14, 1965

headline: ‘My Enemy, My Brother’
text: When I first met Zahed Haftlang and Najah Aboud in Vancouver back in 2012, they seemed like any other Middle Eastern immigrants settling into new lives: Zahed was working as a mechanic, while Najah ran a small furniture moving company. But when I sat down with them over cups of mint tea, their story moved me to tears. I’ve been helping them tell it ever since.

headline: Chess Grandmaster Fabiano Caruana Switches Nationality and Will Play for U.S.

headline: Vatican to Recognize Palestinian State in New Treaty
text: JERUSALEM — The Vatican announced Wednesday that it would soon sign a treaty that includes recognition of the “state of Palestine,” lending significant symbolic weight to an intensifying Palestinian push for international support for sovereignty that bypasses the paralyzed negotiations with Israel.

headline: Elie Top: Creating His Own Jewelry Line
text: PARIS — In January, Elie Top, best known as the jewelry designer for Lanvin, introduced Maison Elie Top and its first collection, Mécaniques Célestes.

headline: Reading Is Fundamental Combats ‘Summer Slide’
text: Some of my favorite childhood memories don’t spring from my own childhood at all; they are borrowed from the pages of books. I waited for spring with Frog and Toad, helped deliver Grandmother’s kiss to Little Bear, and walked to school along the beach in Provincetown on The Day the Whale Came to My Town. I had a lovely childhood on its own, but when amended by the tales on my bookshelf, it was all the more rich, filled with mystery, adventure and most important, learning.

headline: Breast-Feeding May Cut Breast Cancer Recurrence Risk
text: A new report suggests that breast-feeding, which has been associated with a reduced breast cancer risk, may have another benefit. In mothers who later develop breast cancer, breast-feeding may reduce the risk of cancer recurrence.

text: Officials from the European Commission and the European Union on Wednesday discussed a proposal to take in thousands of migrants across Europe over the next two years.

headline: Marco Rubio to Outline His Approach to Foreign Policy
text: The Obama Doctrine is a slightly saltier version of “Don’t Do Stupid Stuff.” The Bush Doctrine argued for preventive strikes in the interest of self-defense and national security.

headline: Chris Christie Buys the Iraq Line
text: While Jeb Bush was fumbling around with the question of whether he would have authorized the invasion of Iraq, Chris Christie (the governor of New Jersey who is either thinking about running for president or using that idea to pump up his public image and raise money) did not have that problem.

headline: E.U. Proposes Quota System to Address Migration Crisis
text: BRUSSELS — After months of criticism that it had been too slow and timid in addressing the flood of migrants heading toward its southern shores, the European Union authorities moved on Wednesday to spread the burden of the crisis among member states.

headline: Police Shoot Man Linked to Hammer Attacks
text: The police said the man, shot near 37th Street and Eighth Avenue, might be the person they have been trying to identify as a suspect in several hammer attacks this week near Union Square.

text: The curator Francesco Bonami organized “The Great Wonderful,” an exhibition and auction, with Phillips.
