text: A man was shot by the police on Wednesday morning in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Turquoise: A Complicated Stone
text: Popularized by Turkish traders, embraced by Native Americans and now mined extensively by the Chinese, turquoise varies so widely in color and form that many American Indians say no two stones are alike.

headline: When Kids Fly
text: Young extreme-sports athletes risk life and limb when they play.

headline: Jamie Drake Picks His Favorite Rooms From Four Decades of the Kips Bay Show House
text: Since its inception in 1973, the Kips Bay Decorator Show House, which tasks prominent designers with creating dream rooms for a Manhattan home, has been a yearly tradition beloved in the design community — and in the local one (the Show House benefits the Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club). The rooms included have run the gamut from the ruffled and romantic to sci-fi Blade Runner futurist visions — but are always showstopping. The interior designer Jamie Drake has been to nearly every Show House; this year, he’s a Vice Chair for the event. To celebrate the opening of the 43rd annual edition tomorrow, Drake took a spin down memory lane — with some help from Steven Stolman’s book “40 Years of Fabulous: The Kips Bay Decorator Show House” — to share with T some of his favorite rooms from the Show House’s history (including one of the five he’s contributed so far).

headline: No. 1 Public Enemy of Criminal Justice Reform: The Election
text: For the first time in decades, a consensus is building behind reform of the criminal justice system. But will the 2016 election get in the way?

headline: Jennifer Lopez Plans Run of Las Vegas Shows
text: Las Vegas is stocking up on divas.

headline: Iraq War Remains a Quagmire That Republicans Hope to Avoid
text: Twelve years since the United States invaded Iraq, the war remains a quagmire for Republicans who have an eye on the presidency.

headline: ‘Frontline’ Getting a Change in Leadership
text: “Frontline,” the PBS documentary series, is getting a leadership change for the first time in its 32-year history. The founding executive producer, David Fanning, is stepping down at the end of the month, and Raney Aronson, the colleague he has been grooming for several years, will take over.

headline: Museum Director at Hermitage Hopes for Thaw in Relations With West
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — When the British Museum lent one of the sculptures known as the Elgin marbles to the State Hermitage Museum here last year, the move angered Greece, which wants the sculptures back, and set off a spirited debate about restitution. But it was also a diplomatic coup by one man: Mikhail Piotrovsky, director of the Hermitage and a skilled cultural ambassador.

headline: ‘Tuck Everlasting’ Coming to Broadway in 2016
text: “Tuck Everlasting” is Broadway-bound.

headline: Classical Playlist: Carlos Kalmar, Alexander Lingas and More
text: ‘SPIRIT OF THE AMERICAN RANGE': Piston, Antheil and CoplandCarlos Kalmar, conductor; Oregon Symphony(Pentatone)When the Oregon Symphony made its acclaimed Carnegie Hall debut in 2011, this impressive ensemble won many admirers among New York concertgoers and critics. That the orchestra continues to thrive under Carlos Kalmar, its dynamic Uruguayan music director, is clear from this exciting recording, taken from live performances at its home hall. Piston’s charming, inventive Suite from “The Incredible Flutist,” a ballet, receives a supple, colorful performance. Antheil’s “A Jazz Symphony” (the 1955 version), a piece that can sound slick for all its raucous energy, emerges here as a savvy, audacious score. Best of all is an urgent, superbly played account of Copland’s Third Symphony. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: 36 Hours in Medellín, Colombia
text: Colombia’s second city is fast shedding its controversial reputation. With infrastructure projects that are bringing architecturally exciting libraries and parks to impoverished neighborhoods, and creative methods of transportation, Medellín is one of the most progressive cities in Latin America. Its situation — set in the Aburrá Valley, surrounded by green mountains — is ideal, its weather springlike year-round, and its people outgoing and proud of their city. A wave of construction is going on in most neighborhoods, which are bedecked with posters proclaiming the government’s dedication to innovation and education. After years as the center of Pablo Escobar’s drug operation and decades of related violence, the “city of eternal spring” is looking to the future.

headline: 36 Hours in Medellín
text: The city’s situation — set in the Aburrá Valley, surrounded by green mountains — is ideal, its weather springlike year-round, and its people outgoing and proud of their city.

headline: 36 Hours in Medellín
text: Explore street view, find things to do in Medellín.

headline: Cannes Film Festival Opens With ‘Standing Tall’
text: CANNES, France — In the film that opens the 68th Cannes International Film festival today, Catherine Deneuve plays a French judge who must rule on the fate of a sometimes violent juvenile delinquent. The jurors for the festival competition this year seem to be taking a softer approach.

headline: Jorge Posada Says Alex Rodriguez Doesn’t Belong in Hall of Fame
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Alex Rodriguez’s return from a yearlong suspension for using performance-enhancing drugs has gone swimmingly.

headline: Amtrak Passengers Recall ‘A Crazy Shake,’ Then Metal Tearing, and Chaos
text: Jeremy Wladis was well settled into an evening train home from Washington on Tuesday, a commute he does at least once a week, his tablet, his smartphone, a notebook and pen arrayed in front of him to work.

headline: ‘The Flick,’ a Pulitzer Winner, Retakes the Stage
text: When Annie Baker’s play “The Flick” won the Pulitzer Prize last year, my surprise almost equaled my delight. This smart, subtle, delicately moving drama about the relationships among three low-wage workers at a grimy New England movie theater hardly seemed like the kind of play the Pulitzer judges would honor. Unless, of course, they happened to see it and were caught up in the rapt spell it casts — more than three hours that, no, don’t fly by. (As life doesn’t, really, until it does.)

headline: Stalled Trade Bill Highlights Chasm Between Obama and Congressional Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — It took only a few minutes for President Obama to become a Republican talking point.

headline: McConnell, Siding With Obama on Trade Deal, Describes Unlikely Alliance
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, dryly described his alliance with President Obama over an extensive trade deal as an “out-of-body experience.”

headline: Fighting for History
text: And, I’m on the ground in England, jet-lagged but maybe ready to resume blogging. For today, just a quick thought inspired by two seemingly unrelated comments.

headline: Verbatim: For Biden, Amtrak Is Like Family
text: — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has made the trip from Wilmington, Del., to Washington weekly throughout much of his career, discussing the train derailment overnight in Philadelphia.

headline: Unvarnished Series on Nail Salon Workers: Readers Respond (中文)
text: 我经常去韩国人在Bronxville 开的指甲店，干净、安静、舒心，价格和质量都非常好。而隔街中国人开的店，从里到外都不如意，工具不消毒，服务人员嗓门高，做工糙。不要怪歧视，纽约是自 由市场经济，机会是公平的，国人要审视自己，不要总拿美国最低工资说事。每个新移民都有艰苦奋斗痛苦的经历，但在美国，只要自己努力，比别人多付出一点， 价格稍微低一点，就能成功生存。There is no free lunch. 也许NYT可以再做一篇调查，从美甲顾客角度，体验不同种族人提供的服务，对比一下价格和服务及服务人员的素质和水平，看看“歧视”是否是国人低收入的原因。文中提到的任静”说她“希望学校可以让她摆脱这个令她厌恶的工作”，—- 一个人如果厌恶她的工作，怎么能有良好职业道德和服务质量？这样的工作心态只能让贫穷的人更加贫穷。美国的最低工资制本身就有超福利的不合理性，养懒人。

headline: Collared, Sleeved and Oh-So-Seventies
text: Polo shirts get the retro treatment this summer with graphic prints, close fits and nostalgic colors.

headline: Officials on Philadelphia Train Crash
text: The Philadelphia mayor, the Amtrak chairman and a member of the National Transportation Safety Board discussed the investigation into Tuesday night’s train derailment.

headline: 1940: Rome Press Attacks Allies
text: ROME — Anti-Allied sentiment was whipped up today in official circles, the press and posters. British institutions, as well as the French Embassy, in Rome were guarded to prevent possible demonstrations following the posting of anti-British signs and the dropping by an airplane of 20,000 anti-British leaflets. Groups of students gathered in the Corso Umberto, Rome’s main street, but the police dispersed them. The British Consulate advised British travelers to leave Italy. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 14, 1940

headline: Amiri Baraka’s Play About W. E. B. Du Bois, via Woodie King Jr.
text: Even a relentlessly adventurous producer and director like Woodie King Jr. was bound to reach a breaking point when it came to Amiri Baraka.

headline: A New Marriott App Connects Guests With Hotels
text: Marriott Hotels, the Bethesda, Md.-based brand part of Marriott International, wants to make the interaction between its guests and staff easier and faster with a new addition on its mobile app that’s launching Wednesday. Called Mobile Request, the feature is available to members of Marriott Rewards, the loyalty program for which enrollment is free, and lets them start getting in touch with their property through their cellphones up to 72 hours before they check in.

headline: In an Upper East Side Brownstone, a Century of Italian Art
text: Although interest in contemporary art has boomed to epic proportions in recent years — most recently with the record-setting spring evening auctions this week, where a Picasso painting went for $179 million at Christie’s on Monday night — the Italian curator Francesco Bonami takes issue with the disproportionate lack of attention his own compatriots receive, especially in the United States. “A lot of Italian artists have been overlooked by the critics, and also overlooked by the market,” Bonami says. Consider the exhibition and auction he’s just curated with Phillips, “The Great Wonderful: 100 Years of Italian Art,” to be something of a corrective measure, then — an attempt to get Italian artists the attention they deserve.

headline: “Prohibido” (Forbidden)
text: Aaron Velasquez Mejía, a prisoner at Reclusorio Sur in Mexico City, performing in a national singing competition for prisons in Mexico.

headline: Reflections on Our Sixth Annual Found Poetry Challenge
text: From race in America and the California drought to the Apple Watch and Brooklyn’s Morbid Anatomy Museum, student-poets posting to our Sixth Annual Found Poem Challenge found inspiration in a huge range of Times articles.

headline: Italian Nurse Who Worked in Sierra Leone Tests Positive for Ebola
text: ROME — An Italian nurse who returned from Sierra Leone last week was flown to an infectious diseases hospital in Rome on Wednesday after he tested positive for the Ebola virus a day before.

headline: Finland, Once a Eurozone Point of Pride, Is Now Faltering
text: What a comedown.

headline: With Amtrak Link Unavailable, Travel Plans Come Apart
text: For thousands of people on Wednesday morning, a routine commute between New York and Washington became a mad scramble for a ride after the derailment of an Amtrak train on Tuesday shut down the rail link in Philadelphia.

headline: David Cameron Seeks New Powers to Combat Extremism in Britain
text: LONDON — Stoking the debate over the balance between security and civil liberties, Prime Minister David Cameron pledged on Wednesday to seek broad new police powers to combat the radicalization of Muslims in Britain and to end what he termed “passive” tolerance of extremism.

headline: CBS Says ‘CSI’ Will End Next Season
text: CBS will cancel one of its longest-running and popular shows, “CSI,” next season after a two-hour series finale in late September.

headline: Witness Describes Manhattan Shooting
text: A man who was working in a store at 37th Street and Eighth Avenue on Wednesday described the scene as police officers shot a man suspected of attacking strangers with a hammer.

headline: Martin O’Malley Holds Firm Against Trade Deals
text: Former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland is making a swing through New Hampshire as he mulls running for president, and he did not hold back from sharing his opposition to a proposed trade deal that Hillary Rodham Clinton has yet to take a clear position about.

headline: The Real But Overstated Decline of American Christianity
text: The new Pew survey on religious affiliation in America, released and much discussed around the internet yesterday, paints a portrait of institutional Christianity in retreat, and the continuing rise of what we call the “nones” — people attached to no organized religion — as a major constituency in American life. The pace of both trends is striking: As Notre Dame’s David Campbell, quoted in this Daily Caller piece, points out, given how quickly the non-affiliated population rose in the late 1990s and early 2000s you might have expected a slowing or a leveling off, but instead the trendline is still steep, from 16 percent “none” in 2007 to 23 percent today (and about 35 percent “none” among Millennials). Meanwhile identification with every major branch of Christianity is down in percentage terms, and only evangelical Christianity is seeing its absolute numbers still increase; the black Protestant churches are holding steady, but in Pew’s numbers Catholicism seems to have joined the Protestant Mainline in a kind of demographic freefall.

headline: Before the Renovation: A Glimpse Into The Times’s Newsroom in Washington
text: Andrew Siddons is the office manager in The Times’s Washington bureau.

headline: Private Letters of Prince Charles Released After Long Court Battle
text: LONDON — Private letters from Prince Charles to British ministers that were released Wednesday after a decade-long court battle show the heir to the throne to be polite, persistent and knowledgeable about topics such as the survival of the albatross and the Patagonian toothfish and the state of organic agriculture.

headline: After Lobbying by Obama, Senate Agrees to Vote on Trade Bill After All
text: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders, after personal intercessions by President Obama, reached an agreement Wednesday on a path to grant the president accelerated power to complete a sweeping trade accord ringing the Pacific Ocean — just a day after fellow Democrats had blocked him.

headline: Amtrak Train Derails in Philadelphia
text: Amtrak Train 188 crashed in Philadelphia.

headline: App Smart | Track Your Cycling Data
text: While your eyes are on the road, phone apps like Strava and Road Bike keep track of your cycling data.

headline: Settlements in Foreign Exchange and Interest Rate Cases
text: Citing chat room messages replete with typos, jargon and vulgarities, regulators have fined big banks, accusing them of conspiring to manipulate the foreign currency markets and global interest rates.

headline: Mumford & Sons Is No. 1
text: The band Mumford & Sons scored its second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week, with “Wilder Mind,” its latest release, selling 231,000 copies, according to Nielsen.

headline: House Committee Meets on Rail Safety
text: Representatives Jeff Denham and Bill Shuster urged rail safety reform on Wednesday in a Transportation Committee meeting the day after a deadly Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia.

headline: Defense Secretary Nominates New Army and Navy Chiefs
text: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter on Wednesday recommended Gen. Mark Milley, the head of Army Forces Command at Fort Bragg, N.C., to be the next Army chief of staff, and Adm. John Richardson, head of the Navy’s nuclear program, to be the next chief of naval operations, a senior administration official said.

headline: Ferdinand Piëch, No-Show at Porsche Meeting, Still Casts Long Shadow
text: STUTTGART, Germany — Anyone hoping that the Porsche shareholders’ meeting on Wednesday would turn into an episode of “Family Feud: Billionaire Edition,” would have been disappointed. The Porsche clan’s most controversial member, Ferdinand Piëch, did not show up.

headline: Mimi O’Donnell Seeks Solace in Theater After Philip Seymour Hoffman’s Death
text: She told herself she wouldn’t make a big decision for a year.

headline: Video Feature: Apps for Cyclists Offer Everything but the Flat-Tire Kit
text: Cyclists have been saying it for ages: Two wheels are better than four, for the health of the rider and the environment alike. And with cycling’s popularity on the rise, numerous apps have appeared to support the activity.

headline: William D. Smith Dies at 79; Business Reporter Who Joined Oil Industry
text: William D. Smith, a former business reporter for The New York Times who covered the oil industry then worked for it as a media relations specialist for Exxon during the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989, died on May 2 in Park Ridge, N.J. He was 79.

headline: No. 2 Leader of ISIS Killed in U.S.-Led Airstrike, Iraq Says
text: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi government said Wednesday that the second-in-command of the Islamic State had been killed in an airstrike carried out by the American-led coalition in northern Iraq, a claim American officials said they could not confirm.

headline: President Meant No Offense in Calling Elizabeth Warren by Her First Name, White House Says
text: The White House said Wednesday that President Obama had meant no offense in calling Senator Elizabeth Warren by her first name in an interview, adding that if anyone was owed an apology, it was him.

headline: Canadian Aboriginal Group Rejects $1 Billion Fee for Natural Gas Project
text: OTTAWA — A small aboriginal community in British Columbia has rejected a $1 billion payment for a natural gas project, the latest setback for the Canadian energy industry’s effort to bolster exports.

headline: A Party Stop on the Global Art Crawl
text: W magazine celebrates its Art issue at Ian Schrager’s New York Edition hotel.

headline: Tips for Healthy and Sustainable Hiking
text: To many outdoor enthusiasts the mountains and forests are waking with life again and trails beckon. With the days of summer in plain sight, recalling the cold and snow of winter would be a cruel exercise. But hitting the trail often means entering a place where the effects of winter can be seen well into spring.

headline: Obama Is Said to Choose Chuck Rosenberg as Next D.E.A. Director
text: WASHINGTON — Chuck Rosenberg, a senior F.B.I. official and former United States attorney, has been chosen by President Obama to be the interim director of the Drug Enforcement Administration, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: At N.F.L. Games, Patriotism Can Get Deflated, Too
text: What price patriotism? During N.F.L. football games, giant scoreboard tableaux of military personnel watching in noble close-up are a familiar, stirring sight. But it turns out some of these patriotic moments, far from a charitable offering by football owners, have been paid for by the Pentagon and National Guard as a “Hometown Hero” recruitment drive.

headline: Amtrak Crash and America’s Declining Construction Spending
text: Investigators into the Amtrak crash in Philadelphia are focusing on excess speed, but there is a related issue: the overall condition of Amtrak and the nation’s infrastructure. One of the reasons that American trains should not travel 100 miles an hour in many places is that the state of our rail system — like the state of our bridges, highways and airports — is not good.

headline: Footage of Shooting in Manhattan
text: An assailant pulled out a hammer and chased an officer on Eighth Avenue at 37th Street. He was shot by another officer.

headline: Danaher’s Breakup Plan Eases Sting of Big Acquisition
text: The breakup plan of Danaher’s chief executive, Tom Joyce, takes the sting out of his expensive bid for Pall. The $60 billion dentures-to-lasers conglomerate is not cutting enough costs to justify the $13.6 billion it’s offering for the filter maker. But his surprise decision to voluntarily split Danaher in two dangles the prospect of better value for shareholders. The trick is to deliver.

headline: Exploring Easier Ways to Save More and Cut Risk
text: Your retirement portfolio may be bigger than you realize. At least it would be if all your resources — your salary and home and not just the 401(k) plan at work — were enlisted to accumulate enough wealth to satisfy your needs and wants in old age, some financial advisers say.

headline: Why Stocks Belong in a Retirement Portfolio
text: For years, the trope in retirement planning was to reduce the stock holdings in your portfolio and add bonds as you neared or entered retirement. That advice is being challenged.

headline: Bankruptcy Can Help Seniors Protect Assets
text: After work started to dry up and creditors began calling, George Maxey, 66, a retired nursery owner and plant consultant in Orlando, Fla., wanted his financial peace and quiet back. With his income dwindling, though, Mr. Maxey saw that the debt hole he was digging was only getting deeper, with no end in sight. So he declared Chapter 7 bankruptcy, which liquidates some assets to repay creditors.

headline: Turning to Social Media in Times of Need
text: Frank Vardeman was about to undergo knee surgery in January when, as he recalled, his legs suddenly “turned to wet noodles” that could no longer support him. Tests revealed that the culprit was a large growth entangled in his spinal cord, compressing the nerves that control lower parts of his body. It took two neurosurgeries at a Chicago hospital to remove the mass and 44 days of rehab before Mr. Vardeman, 62, could return to his home in Chesterton, Ind.

headline: For the Love of Animals
text: Linda and Gary Childs go almost everywhere with their “little girl.”

headline: In Cleveland, Young and Old Keep Tempo of Life
text: CLEVELAND — Janet Hall grimaces as she hits an off note on her violin, one of the few heard here at Judson Manor’s Friday afternoon recital, held in the chandeliered ballroom settings of the first-floor lounge of this residence for older people.

headline: Deciding When to Trim Sails to Stay on Water
text: Michael Sears has been sailing for 60 years, since he was 5 years old, and has owned boats for half that time. Today he has a 36-foot Beneteau First 36s7 sloop and a smaller Sunfish racing dinghy.

headline: Setting Records at 80
text: In April, Bill Dodson, 80, competed in the National 100K Championship in Madison, Wis. He finished about 15 hours later to set a national mark for his age group.

headline: Why Older Runners Are Ultrarunners
text: How far will an aging ultradistance runner go?

headline: Guiding Wealthy Retirees on Health Expenses
text: Death and disease don’t discriminate, and that has many high-net-worth retirees worried. They realize fate could determine the quality of their retirement more than their lifetime of planning.

headline: Senator Thomas Carper Got Off Train Minutes Before Crash
text: Senator Thomas R. Carper takes the train home to Delaware nearly every day, looking forward to a good night’s rest in his own bed before returning to Washington in the morning. So he was home watching the news on Tuesday night when he heard that an Amtrak train had derailed about 30 minutes after he gotten off in Wilmington.

headline: Losing Our Religion: So What Do We Teach Our Children?
text: Do you still practice the faith you grew up with? More and more young adults now identify as nonreligious, with no affiliation to any religion, according to a  large new survey by the Pew Research Center.

headline: ‘Lurid & Cute,’ a Novel by Adam Thirlwell
text: “I wish confessions did not ever need to happen. Confessions, it seemed to me, were a total illness of our time.” So says the narrator of Adam Thirlwell’s entertaining and exhausting new novel, “Lurid & Cute.”

headline: Obama Hosts Saudi Princes
text: President Obama met Crown Prince Mohammed bin Nayef and Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, a day before the Gulf Cooperation Council summit meeting.

headline: All White Options for Summer
text: Cleanse your palette with these all white options.

headline: Kabul Hotel Attacked by Gunmen, Leaving 5 Dead
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An attack on a central Kabul hotel late Wednesday by several gunmen left five people dead, including an American, raising the specter of targeted attacks in the capital even as violence has surged elsewhere in Afghanistan.

headline: David Lynch’s Paris Party Club Spends the Summer in the Country
text: Silencio, the pluridisciplinary members-only culture club and labyrinthine party hub in Paris conceived by David Lynch, will migrate its creative community to the Maison de l’Aiguebrun for the summer. Nestled in Bonnieux, in the Luberon region in the south of France, the house was the property of iconic film director Agnès Varda, and has since been handed down to her daughter, Rosalie Varda-Demy, a costume designer and art director (whose father was equally iconic film director Jacques Demy). The idea for opening her personal estate to Silencio came about when Varda-Demy met the club’s directors, Arnaud Frisch and Antoine Caton, at their pop-up in Cannes for the annual Film Festival — for which Varda-Demy has worked for 14 years, doing décor and organizing official dinners.

headline: Krosnick to Depart Juilliard String Quartet
text: The Juilliard String Quartet, one of American chamber music’s most hallowed institutions, will get its first new cellist in over 40 years. Joseph W. Polisi, the Juilliard School’s president, announced Tuesday that Joel Krosnick, a quartet member since 1974, would leave the group at the end of the 2015-16 season, its 70th.

headline: Review: American Ballet Theater Recalls the Wide Range of Its Early Years
text: American Ballet Theater is celebrating its 75th anniversary by presenting a half-dozen one-act ballets from its first decade. Having opened its season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday with three selections, the company followed up on Tuesday with the remainder. This second grouping of three underscored the marvelous range that Ballet Theater offered during those early years: traditional and modern, pure-form and narrative, European and American. It showed the durability of great choreography, even in less than ideal performances.

headline: Cisco’s Profit and Sales Beat Wall Street Forecasts
text: Cisco Systems delivered gains in quarterly profit and sales on Wednesday that slightly surpassed Wall Street’s expectations.

headline: Review: Hubbard Street Dance Chicago Nods to Balanchine
text: Hubbard Street Dance Chicago is a confusing company though it’s easy to see why talented dancers flock to it. They want to perform, and if this group has anything, it’s an abundance of contemporary repertory. Its identity is harder to pin down.

headline: College Student to Jeb Bush: ‘Your Brother Created ISIS’
text: RENO, Nev. — “Your brother created ISIS,” the young woman told Jeb Bush. And with that, Ivy Ziedrich, a 19-year-old college student, created the kind of confrontational moment here on Wednesday morning that presidential candidates dread.

headline: ‘American Ballet Theater: A History,’ a PBS Documentary, Is a Love Letter to a Dance Form
text: A point shoe descends in slow motion, aiming its tip like a dagger as it hits the center of a spotlight. The voice of Jennifer Homans, author of “Apollo’s Angels: A History of Ballet,” gently, almost coaxingly, speaks about the ritual the art form requires, starting with the ballet positions a dancer works through each morning. She says of the daily practice, “It’s a kind of freedom.”

headline: A Party Crawl in the Name of Art
text: A perfect art crawl score might have started last week at the Venice Biennale opening in Italy, followed by the Brant Foundation Art Study Center last Sunday in Greenwich, Conn., the art auctions in New York this week, and the Frieze New York art fair running through Sunday.

headline: China’s Superrich: The Bling Dynasty
text: Forget old money. China’s fabulously wealthy are playing catch-up, learning how to acquire — and use — the trappings of the good life.

headline: ‘O Outro Lado da Montanha’
text: Depois de uma tentativa de retorno à glória olímpica ter acabado em paralisia, Laís Souza reconstrói a sua vida com um movimento de cada vez.

headline: A Home for Pets When Their Owners Are Gone
text: Now that Jim Swaim is in his 60s, he and his wife are asking a very modern question about mortality: Who will care for our pets when we are gone?

headline: Joseph Abboud Provides a Guiding Hand for the Suit Averse
text: It was the summer of, I think, 1997. Had to be. One year before, I had spent those hot weeks in a cold office overlooking Boston Harbor, crunching numbers for a management consulting firm but mostly doing the crossword for as long as I could get away with it.

headline: Verbatim: Marco Rubio, Raúl Castro and the Church
text: — Senator Marco Rubio at the Council of Foreign Relations, responding to the news that President Raúl Castro of Cuba was considering returning to the Roman Catholic Church because of the influence of Pope Francis.

headline: Sally Mann on Her History, Frame by Frame
text: The photographer Sally Mann describes her pictures as “silver poems of tone and undertow,” and they have always seemed designed to stop the passage of things that can barely be slowed: youth, memory, seasons, light, even decay. When she began her first attempt at a piece of sustained writing, “Hold Still,” her memoir published this week by Little Brown, she said she realized with great relief that she had followed the same impulse in her nonphotographic life, letting nary a scrap of paper escape her archival clutches.

headline: Kayak Suspect Said She ‘Felt Good’ Fiancé Would Die, Prosecutors Say
text: Prosecutors at a bail hearing in Orange County, N.Y., on Wednesday said that Angelika Graswald, the woman accused of intentionally drowning her fiancé in the Hudson River last month, had told the police that she tampered with his kayak and had said it “felt good knowing he was going to die.”

headline: Study Asks if Carrot or Stick Can Better Help Smokers Quit
text: WASHINGTON — What would make a smoker more likely to quit, a big reward for succeeding or a little penalty for failing? That is what researchers wanted to know when they assigned a large group of CVS employees, their relatives and friends to different smoking cessation programs.

headline: The Artist Rob Pruitt: Paradox on a Pedestal
text: The twice-yearly opening at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center, a private museum in Greenwich, Conn., founded by the newsprint magnate Peter M. Brant, never fails to draw a fashionable art crowd.

headline: At Nail Salons, Questioning a Beauty Rite
text: Last weekend, all weekend, Kate McKean, 36, struggled with her guilt.

headline: Clifford Ross’s Wave Mechanics
text: This year, May 14 marks the beginning of summer — that is, the summer of Clifford Ross. This Thursday at Ryan Lee Gallery, the noble and light-footed nephew of the late Helen Frankenthaler will showcase two series of silver gelatin photographs from the late ’90s in “The Abstract Edge,” beginning with his “Grain Series,” perhaps the most abstract and spare photographic works in Ross’ expansive but underappreciated catalogue. Evoking the minimal but potent energy of an Ad Reinhardt painting, the photographs display tone and emulsion only, embodying the pure essence of a tumultuous swell while simultaneously dissembling the photographic process. The second and “edgier” half, the “Wave Series,” presents only the whisper of a wave crest and is deeply indebted to Richard Serra. “My aunt created a masterpiece at age 23. I’m on the flip side of that,” says a relaxed Ross in his West Village studio. “She had to live down staggering success. For me, it was a gradual climb to things that were better or more meaningful.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Burundi and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Burundi, Nepal, Afghanistan and the United States.

headline: May 13, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Burundi, Nepal, Afghanistan and the United States.

headline: Uber Lures Top Google Executive and Shifts David Plouffe’s Duties
text: Continuing its quest for top Silicon Valley talent, Uber said on Wednesday that it had hired Rachel Whetstone, Google’s longtime head of communications, to be its senior vice president for policy and communications.

headline: Chief of New York City Marathon Has Goal for All: Great Time, Fast or Otherwise
text: Peter Ciaccia, the new race director of the New York City Marathon, may not know his marathon time (3:15? 3:30?), but he knows how to give a party. Now he will have to determine the existential course of the world’s biggest marathon: Should it be more race or more social event?

headline: A Film Explores Curaçao’s Effort to Become a Caribbean Haven for Coral
text: After months of reporting and planning, a frenetic week of filming in March, and many long nights in the editing suite, 10 Pace University communication students, with guidance from Prof. Maria Luskay and me, have completed “Curaçao’s Coral Challenge – Reviving the Rain Forests of the Sea.”

headline: Watch Trailers for CBS’s New Dramas and Comedies
text: This week, in the annual tradition known as the upfronts, TV networks make presentations to advertisers in which they unveil previews of new fall shows.

headline: Singing to Be Heard, Behind Bars in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — On a wide stage in front of hundreds of people, two salsa singers danced in synchronized steps, belting out a catchy melody accompanied by trumpets, percussion and propulsive Latin montuno chords from an electronic keyboard. The musicians, like the crowd, wore mismatching beige uniforms, and no women were anywhere to be seen.

headline: House Votes to End N.S.A.’s Bulk Phone Data Collection
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved legislation to end the federal government’s bulk collection of phone records, exerting enormous pressure on Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Senate majority leader, who insists that dragnet sweeps continue in defiance of many of those in his Republican Party.

headline: Kendrick Bangs Kellogg: A Retrospective
text: Beyond the Joshua Tree House, a selection of some of Kellogg’s largest works, from California to Japan.

headline: With Tie at Real Madrid, Juventus Bars Door to All-Spanish Champions League Final
text: MADRID — Imagine a mob of people, thousands of them, standing outside an old wooden door. First the members of the pack take turns banging on the door. Then the banging turns to kicking. And then the kicking turns to pounding, as body after body rams ahead only to return with little more than an aching shoulder.

headline: In the DuPont Boardroom Battle, Sizing Up Who Won and Lost
text: The battle between DuPont and Trian was too close to call before Wednesday, with DuPont winning a contest that lasted far too long. In deal-making, though, “winning” a proxy contest may not be the triumphant victory that one thinks it could be. For future shareholder activist battles, there are lessons in the way DuPont and Trian both won and lost.

headline: Review: With ‘One Cut, One Life,’ Ed Pincus and Lucia Small Document His Illness
text: The intensity of life lived in the shadow of a terminal illness is the subject of “One Cut, One Life,” a portrait of the seminal documentarian Ed Pincus in his final years. Filmed by Mr. Pincus and his longtime collaborator Lucia Small, this extremely personal and moving documentary has several layers.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
text: Art everywhere. Dover Street Market has curated a lineup of installations around Frieze New York that includes an IDEA Books Collier Schorr mini-shop consisting of five special prints, rare vintage books and other printed matter. There is also a mise en scene created by the designer Craig Green and the photographer Nick Knight that involves kites and a preview of the gender-neutral men’s wear master’s fall collection. At 160 Lexington Avenue.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: For N.F.L. Stars and Celebrities, There’s No Off-Season
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — On the windowless second floor of the Pink Taco restaurant and bar on Sunset Boulevard, behind an unmarked gray door, a dozen N.F.L. players were warming up for a two-hour workout, attempting to speedwalk with thick blue elastic bands binding their ankles together.

headline: Jeb Bush Declares His Candidacy — Prematurely
text: RENO, Nev. – Whoops!

headline: American Pharoah Draws No. 1 Post in Eight-Horse Preakness Field
text: BALTIMORE — It is a compact field of eight horses for the 140th running of the Preakness Stakes, but perhaps it is the deepest group to contest the second jewel of the Triple Crown in nearly two decades, with the top three finishers in a hard-fought Kentucky Derby entered.

headline: Columbia Examines Its Long-Ago Links to Slavery
text: Daniel D. Tompkins, the sixth vice president of the United States, has long gazed impassively from an oil portrait hanging in the residence of the president of Columbia University, his alma mater. But on a recent afternoon, he might have been tempted to smile a bit.

headline: From Korea, Sheet Masks for Fresh Faces
text: The idea of sheet masks, one of the latest Korean beauty crazes to arrive on these shores, is pretty attractive. Rather than spend hundreds on a professional facial, you wash your face at home, slap on an individually packaged mask (essentially hydrogel, paper, cotton or fiber cutouts doused in “beautifying” solutions), wait 20 minutes and call it a day. In Seoul entire shops are devoted solely to them.

headline: A Promise of Beauty in a Bottle
text: The first time Jenelle Manzi went to CAP Beauty, a natural boutique that opened in the West Village in February, she found a whole section dedicated to beauty products meant to be ingested.

headline: Six Gadgets to Take on a Road Trip
text: Stuck in a car for days? Bring along navigation aids, headphones, broadband access, video and music storage — even access to a remote camera to check on your home.

headline: Narendra Modi and Xi Jinping Aim to Shelve Rifts Amid Economic Courtship
text: NEW DELHI — The days before Narendra Modi left for China, his first visit as India’s prime minister, brought pinprick reminders of the geopolitical rifts dividing the two countries, even while they court each other for an economic charge.

headline: White House and Labor Advocates Praise Move by Facebook for Higher Wages
text: Labor groups and the White House on Wednesday praised Facebook’s plan to require its contractors to pay workers at least $15 an hour and offer paid time off.

headline: A Makeup Cream for 40 Winks (Wink-Wink)
text: Here’s a product that seems tailor-made for dating app hookups: a beauty balm you can sleep in, from the Korean label Dr. Jart. Skin-care gurus will be apoplectic at sleeping in makeup, but the innovation is slick: The tube of Dr. Jart+ BB Night Beauty Balm ($38) dispenses little white spheres suspended in a clear gel; on contact, they break open and disperse a self-adjusting tinted pigment. Sci-fi stuff. On a recent date night with my husband, the gel produced a flattering velvety sheer finish. Though not enough coverage to replace a proper foundation, it was surprisingly transfer-resistant. After a roll around the sack (O.K., just testing clean pillowcases), the cream stayed put, even when layered with moisturizers. Another date night, here we come!

headline: Grip Strength May Predict Heart Attacks and Strokes
text: Grip strength may be a good predictor of the risk for cardiovascular disease.

headline: Judge Denies Group’s Whistle-Blower Standing in Suit Against U.S. Bank
text: A federal judge this week dismissed an innovative lawsuit that had threatened to open a new front in the legal assault on the foreclosure practices of large banks.

headline: Eva Zuckerman, the Original X-Woman
text: Plus: A touch of abstract minimalism for a frock that works at any hour; song titles and lyrics on tees; and more shopping news.

headline: All White Looks
text: Some examples from recent events.

headline: Summer’s Color Forecast: Whiteout Conditions
text: At a pivotal moment in “Ex Machina,” the sci-fi fantasy drawing crowds to the multiplex, Ava, the movie’s saucer-eyed android, sallies into a fine spring day, incandescent in white lace. Alicia Vikander, who plays the electronic temptress (and models a similar dress on the cover of this month’s W), is keenly aware of its evocative powers.

headline: Missouri Passes Anti-Union Bill, but It Isn’t Veto-Proof
text: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — The Republican-controlled Missouri General Assembly on Wednesday approved legislation that would enact a so-called right-to-work policy in the state, but it fell far short of the required number of votes to overcome a likely veto from Gov. Jay Nixon.

headline: Fearing Bangladeshi Blogger Might Claim Asylum, Sweden Blocked Visit That Could Have Saved His Life
text: A Bangladeshi blogger and secular activist who was hacked to death on Tuesday would still be alive if Sweden had not blocked his planned visit to Stockholm this month to celebrate World Press Freedom Day, according to the Swedish chapter of PEN, an international writers group.

headline: In Ukraine, Bones of War Dead Re-emerge to Stir Political Passions
text: LVIV, Ukraine — The calls come in with distressing regularity: A man, out for a walk in the forest, stumbles on a human shinbone; another, digging a basement for a house, finds a skull.

headline: A Police Shooting in Midtown’s Seedier Side
text: Two police officers responded to a 911 call of an assault on Wednesday morning. It turned out to be nothing, and so they left empty-handed, emerging from an office building at 580 Eighth Avenue, between 38th and 39th Streets. It was a sunny, breezy day on a stretch that can look anything but sunny and breezy.

headline: For Lending Start-Up, a Man Who’s Been Through a Few Cycles
text: Through three decades, Jerry Weiss wore coats and ties to the offices where he managed credit risks at the nation’s biggest banks — a 50-story Citigroup tower in Queens and the 60-story Chase Manhattan Plaza in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Bank of England Expects Zero Inflation Rate to Pick Up
text: The Bank of England said on Wednesday that it expected Britain’s inflation rate, which has been stuck at zero for two months, to pick up by the end of the year as the economy gathers steam. The central bank trimmed its economic growth forecast for the year to 2.5 percent, from an earlier estimate of 2.9 percent. But the revision reflects the low growth in the first quarter — 0.3 percent — which was short of the bank’s estimate of 0.6 percent. The inflation rate will rise to 0.6 percent by the end of 2015, the bank predicted. Its policy target is an annual inflation rate of 2 percent, which is deemed a healthy sign of economic growth.

headline: The U.S. Corporate Tax Isn’t That Weird
text: We wouldn’t want to follow North Korea’s lead on tax policy. But what about South Korea?

headline: Some Doubt That North Korea Executed a Top General
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Even to longtime analysts familiar with the unpredictability of the North Korean government, the news was shocking: a top general, the country’s equivalent of a defense minister, who had delivered a speech at an international symposium in Moscow last month, was executed by an antiaircraft gun while hundreds of fellow generals and senior party officials watched.

headline: Program Providing Legal Help to Immigrants Will Expand Beyond New York City
text: New York City’s melting pot has been boiling over in the larger metropolitan area.

headline: Verizon’s Deal for AOL Is a Push Into the Technology of Advertising
text: A new generation of Math Men is taking over the Mad Men of Madison Avenue.

headline: Ed Fouhy, TV Newsman and Promoter of Civic Journalism, Dies at 80
text: Ed Fouhy, a television news executive who won five Emmy Awards, worked at all three major broadcast networks and produced two presidential debates during a 35-year career in Washington, died on Wednesday in Chatham, Mass. He was 80.

headline: Political Turmoil Returns to Burundi as President Seeks New Term
text: BUJUMBURA, Burundi — Under a cloudy sky, Kamaro Pierre recounted passionately how he barely escaped death as a teenager.

headline: Publishers Send Diverse Group of News Articles in Facebook Debut
text: Some felt it would revolutionize journalism. Others thought it might be the beginning of its destruction. But on Wednesday, what readers mostly saw in Facebook Instant Articles, the new format by which news organizations are publishing directly on Facebook, was an eclectic mix of articles rather than a clear signal of what is to come.

headline: Wave Hill Puts Spotlight on Art to Celebrate Its Gardens and Lure Visitors
text: Summer has come early to a public garden in the Bronx: Dragonflies skim over clusters of lily pads in a lush aquatic garden in full August bloom. But only at night.

headline: B Vitamin Is Found to Help People Prone to Some Types of Skin Cancer
text: An inexpensive vitamin can help reduce the occurrence of common skin cancers in people prone to that disease, researchers reported on Wednesday.

headline: One Day After Wreck, Increased Funding for Amtrak Fails in a House Panel
text: WASHINGTON — The bodies had not yet been fully recovered from the Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia before Capitol Hill erupted hours later into its usual partisan clash over how much money to spend on the long-struggling national rail service.

headline: Amtrak Needs Help
text: It may take a while to learn exactly why an Amtrak train speeding out of Philadelphia Tuesday night suddenly derailed on a sharp curve. Whether the train was going too fast or the equipment failed or it was something else entirely, the horrifying accident left at least seven people dead and more than 200 injured on one of the busiest train routes in the country.

headline: Chad: Date Is Set for Ex-President’s Trial
text: Former President Hissène Habré will stand trial on charges of crimes against humanity on July 20 at a special court in Senegal, the court announced Wednesday. It will be the first case to be tried in Africa on the principle of universal jurisdiction, which holds that certain crimes transcend borders, and it has the backing of the African Union. A panel of judges from Burkina Faso and Senegal will preside. Mr. Habré’s prosecution is the result of a campaign began more than two decades ago by some of his former prisoners, supported by human rights groups, who demanded an end to Mr. Habré’s comfortable exile in Senegal, where he fled after he was ousted in 1990. He became president in 1982, receiving weapons and funds from the United States, which sought a counterweight to neighboring Libya. He was indicted in 2013, accused of killing thousands of political prisoners and torturing uncounted others during his eight years in office.

headline: Three Amtrak Victims With a Common Thread: All Were Heading Home to Family
text: PHILADELPHIA — One was a midshipman at the Naval Academy who wanted to become a member of the Navy SEALs. Another was the young chief executive of an education start-up, excited about her new job. A third was a seasoned software engineer helping The Associated Press news service move into video. Another was a banking executive. Still another, an educator.

headline: Uber and Internet Giants Assail New York City’s Plan to Bolster Rules for Car-Hire Apps
text: From the stage of a Midtown Manhattan ballroom last week, Mayor Bill de Blasio indulged in “a little bit of positive bragging” about the success of start-ups in the city.

headline: Christie’s Has Art World’s First $1 Billion Week
text: It was a week the art world had never seen before. For the first time, an auction house sold more than $1 billion of art — over three days at that — a vast outpouring of money that amazed even the wealthy and the celebrities who flocked to the auction floor.

headline: Brother’s Past Proves Tricky for Jeb Bush
text: A young woman berated Jeb Bush in Reno, Nev., on Wednesday for his brother’s bungled war in Iraq, saying it had spawned the group calling itself the Islamic State. “Your brother created ISIS,” she declared. Mr. Bush said he “respectfully” disagreed.

headline: Saudi Arabia Promises to Match Iran in Nuclear Capability
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama began making the case for a deal with Iran that would delay its ability to assemble an atomic weapon, his first argument was that a nuclear-armed Iran would set off a “free-for-all” of proliferation in the Arab world. “It is almost certain that other players in the region would feel it necessary to get their own nuclear weapons,” he said in 2012.

headline: Technology That Could Have Prevented Amtrak Derailment Was Absent
text: For the second time in two years, a passenger train traveling well above its speed limit has derailed, leaving a trail of death and injuries. And for the second time, existing technology that might have prevented the accident was missing.

headline: 5 Big Banks Expected to Plead Guilty to Felony Charges, but Punishments May Be Tempered
text: For most people, pleading guilty to a felony means they will very likely land in prison, lose their job and forfeit their right to vote.

headline: Traces of Chemicals in Syria Add to Pressure on Obama to Enforce a ‘Red Line’
text: WASHINGTON — If President Obama hoped that the danger of chemical warfare in the Middle East receded when Syria gave up tons of poison gas, mounting evidence that toxic weapons remain in the strife-torn country could once again force him to decide just how far he is willing to go to enforce his famous “red line.”

headline: Marco Rubio Casts U.S., and Himself, as Strong Leader
text: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida and a 2016 presidential candidate, offered a robust and muscular foreign policy plan Wednesday, laying out his vision for the use of American power in the 21st century.

headline: Report Sees Alcohol Involved in Secret Service Car Episode
text: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security inspector general has found that two senior Secret Service agents were most likely under the influence of alcohol in March when they drove into an area near the White House where the authorities were examining a suspicious package.

headline: Johnny Gimble, Who Fiddled His Way to Fame, Dies at 88
text: Johnny Gimble, a virtuoso Texas fiddler who played with a roster of country superstars including Bob Wills, Marty Robbins, Merle Haggard, Willie Nelson and George Strait, died on Saturday in Marble Falls, Tex., northwest of Austin. He was 88. His wife, Barbara, said the cause was a stroke.

headline: Somalia Executes 2 Militants Convicted of Assassinations
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The Somali government on Wednesday executed two men convicted of killing four lawmakers and an intelligence officer in a series of attacks, officials said.

headline: Verizon Takes to the Battlefield
text: Meet the new disrupter.

headline: Lose It
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Be careful what you wish for, Will Shortz. Crossword constructors have a perverse sense of humor.

headline: Rachel Rosenthal, Bold Performance Artist, Dies at 88
text: Rachel Rosenthal, a performance artist whose work — fierce, funny, earthy and cantankerous — bemoaned the political and ecological fate of the planet, died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 88.

headline: Jerome Cooper, a Multitextured Jazz Percussionist, Dies at 68
text: Jerome Cooper, a percussionist who played an important role in the post-1960s jazz avant-garde, especially as a member of the influential trio the Revolutionary Ensemble, died on May 6 in Brooklyn. He was 68.

headline: New Review Policy for Migrant Families in Detention
text: Migrant families in detention will have more frequent case reviews to determine if they can be released, Department of Homeland Security officials said Wednesday. Women with their children being held in three family detention centers will have a first review after 90 days and then every two months after that. The immigration authorities will no longer point to a general goal of deterring illegal border crossing as the reason for detaining women and children. But the authorities will continue to place a high priority on deporting or detaining migrants caught crossing the border illegally. Central American women seeking asylum and their children have faced many months in detention while their cases moved through the immigration courts. “The new policy is designed to continually re-evaluate whether detention is necessary” for them, Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said.

headline: Sudden Life: Rangers Advance With Game 7 Win Over Capitals
text: The Rangers and the Washington Capitals had battled for six games — each one decided by a single goal — and well into overtime Wednesday night in Game 7 of their memorable second-round playoff series. What separated the teams at Madison Square Garden was a stunning six-second sequence.

headline: North Carolina: More Seized Assets to Be Returned
text: Federal prosecutors agreed Wednesday to return more than $100,000 that was seized from a rural convenience store owner even though the owner, Lyndon McLellan, was not accused of a crime. The Justice Department announced in March that it would no longer pursue such seizures, a form of civil asset forfeiture based on a pattern of small cash deposits, without a criminal charge or evidence of criminal activity. The prosecutor in Mr. McLellan’s case had expressed displeasure that Congress had been given sealed court filings and offered him a settlement of half his money. Last week, the Justice Department said it would investigate two other prosecutors after one business owner whose assets were seized said he had been punished more harshly after publicizing his case and another said he had been threatened with a felony charge if he did not agree to give up some of his money. This is the third high-profile case that prosecutors have dropped in recent months.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended on Thursday
text: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Lori Fouché | Leading Through Sandy
text: At the helm of an insurance company during Hurricane Sandy, Lori Dickerson Fouché, C.E.O. of Prudential Group Insurance, stresses that when it comes to a crisis, there is no management playbook.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “The first bump, you didn’t know what it was, except that it was something strong. The second, you knew something was wrong. And the third, forget about it, now you’re praying.”

headline: Adam Warren Has Strong Outing, but Signs Point to Return to Bullpen
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Chris Capuano, recovered from a quadriceps injury, is ready to return to the Yankees any day now. Ivan Nova is on track to return next month from Tommy John surgery. Masahiro Tanaka reported no problems with his forearm, which had been strained, after he threw a bullpen session Tuesday.

headline: For One Photographer, Still Lifes as an Act of Rebellion
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: At ICFF, Marble Tables That Transform Jorts Into Design Objects
text: To the average person, T-shirts and jeans are nothing more than everyday wardrobe basics. The artist Sean Knibb has a different point of view. Beginning May 16, the L.A.-based designer will show his latest work, “Casa Canova,” a collection of six hand-carved marble tables featuring motifs of tees and denim shorts. The tables, which took more than 700 hours to create and weigh about 770 pounds each, were conceptualized by Knibb in his Venice, Calif., studio and created by master artisans in Carrara, Italy, using classic 18th-century techniques.

headline: Rock Legend
text: Deep in the desolate heart of Joshua Tree hides a house as otherworldly as the landscape itself.

headline: Piet Hein Eek Brings His Singular Furniture — and a Couple of Friends — to NoHo
text: Piet Hein Eek — whose furniture famously elevates found material into high design — is more than just one of the Dutch scene’s most prominent exports; he’s also an influential curator and “inspire-er,” as David Alhadeff, owner of the design gallery The Future Perfect, puts it. To that end, the top floor of Eek’s vast studio and workshop in Eindhoven (a former Philips lighting factory that also encompasses a restaurant and store) has been christened the Wonder Room and exhibits collaborations, most of them among emerging Dutch talent, that blur the lines between design, fine art and technological innovation. Now, to coincide with New York Design Week (and change), Eek is commandeering the entire Future Perfect storefront in NoHo to create a Stateside iteration of that space. On view and available for purchase are a number of new pieces created in collaboration with some of Eek’s favorite young compatriots — such as a hardware-out “exoskeleton cabinet” by Paul Heijnen and artwork by Marc Mulders — as well as never-before-seen works by Eek himself, including a brass mesh lamp and a burned-and-oxidized steel cabinet. Eek also brought American designers into his Wonder Room mix for the first time via a lighting showcase, featuring such local mainstays as Lindsey Adelman, Bec Brittain and Jason Miller.

headline: A Venture Capital Firm Led by 2 Women Plans to Introduce a Fund
text: SAN FRANCISCO — More than a year after striking out on their own, the founders of Aspect Ventures are preparing a formal introduction of a sizable fund.

headline: Word of the Day | fete
text: fete • \ˈfat, ˈfet\ • noun and verb

headline: Matt Harvey Foils the Cubs, but the Mets End Up Stopping Themselves
text: CHICAGO — The Mets sent Jacob deGrom and Noah Syndergaard to the mound for the first two games of their series against the Cubs, and both struggled in losses.

headline: Derek Stepan Scores a Stunner, but the Game’s Margin Is Not So Surprising
text: It almost had to come to this — another one-goal game for the Rangers after a litany of them in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 9:40 A.M. (TMC) THE DIVING BELL AND THE BUTTERFLY (2007) Jean-Dominique Bauby, a 43-year-old French magazine editor and something of a playboy, had a stroke in 1995 that left him with a condition in which he retained vision, hearing and a functioning mind but was almost completely paralyzed. He told his story in a book that he dictated to an assistant by blinking. In this film from the artist Julian Schnabel, Mr. Bauby is played by Mathieu Amalric; Emmanuelle Seigner is Céline, the longtime partner he has recently left and the mother of his three children; and Marie-Josée Croze is a speech therapist who teaches him to use his left eyelid to communicate. “The phrase ‘triumph of the human spirit’ hovers over ‘The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,’ along with a swarm of other empty, uplifting clichés,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But Mr. Schnabel and the screenwriter, Ronald Harwood, have other themes in mind” — among them, limitation, constraint and incarceration — Mr. Scott said. (Both men were nominated for Oscars.) “Their common subject, however, is freedom, the self-willed liberation of a difficult, defiant individual,” he added, noting that Mr. Schnabel demonstrated this with “imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence, dispensing with narrative and expository conventions in favor of a wild, intuitive honesty.”

headline: Momentum Regained and Order Restored, Warriors Roll Over Grizzlies
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — When the Golden State Warriors come, they do it in waves, as relentless as any tide pulling across the San Francisco Bay. The Memphis Grizzlies are merely the latest to feel the brunt of their momentum.

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: China’s Superrich: The Bling Dynasty
text: The current occupant of the White House can keep the Rose Garden. Somewhere on the other side of the globe, a Chinese billionaire built a replica of the White House with an even better view: of Mount Rushmore.

text: SHERMAN, Tex. — SOMETIMES it appears as if there is a target hanging over Moore, Okla.: Storms seem to find it.

headline: Wow, Jeb Bush Is Awful
text: Let’s discuss Jeb Bush’s terrible week.
