text: To the Editor:

headline: Crisis at Sea
text: One of the world’s most beautiful regions, the seas of Southeast Asia — home to sparkling white beaches and $7,000-a-night beach villas — is becoming a scene of a mass atrocity.

headline: The Changing Role of the Professor
David Letterman Knew How to Talk
text: THE imminent end, on May 20, of David Letterman’s 33-year run as a late-night TV host is a sad event for a number of reasons. Mr. Letterman’s “Late Show” monologues are still the gold standard in an increasingly crowded field. His Top 10 lists remain the most durable running gag in late-night television. (“Top 10 Things Overheard in Hillary Clinton’s Van”: “Polling indicates we should take the Taconic.”) He virtually invented the age of irony, and his self-mocking style has kept him a paragon of cool, even as his competitors have grown younger and his audience older.

headline: Shortcomings of Cybersecurity Bills
text: A series of brazen hacking attacks against companies like Sony Pictures, Target and Anthem have spurred lawmakers in Congress to propose cybersecurity legislation. These bills could help make American networks somewhat less vulnerable to hackers, but they would do so at a cost to the privacy of individuals.

headline: A Tiny Crack in the Russian Ice
text: It is a measure of how low American-Russian relations have sunk that a meeting between President Vladimir Putin and Secretary of State John Kerry that achieves nothing is perceived as good news. But good news it was when they met for four hours in the southern Russian city of Sochi on Tuesday, following talks between Mr. Kerry and the Russian foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov.

headline: The Baltimore Police Dept. Policy for Persons in Custody
text: The Baltimore Police Department issued these revisions to the department’s general order on handling persons in custody on April 3, 2015.

headline: Baltimore Officers Plan to Challenge Prosecutor’s Basic Accusation
text: BALTIMORE — Less than two weeks after six police officers were charged in the arrest and death of Freddie Gray, the officers’ lawyers and supporters have sketched the outline of a defense, taking aim at the substance of some of the most serious accusations, as well as at procedural issues.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Amtrak Train Derailed Going 106 M.P.H. on Sharp Curve; at Least 7 Killed
text: In “Amtrak Train Derailed Going 106 M.P.H. on Sharp Curve; at Least 7 Killed,” The Times reports on what is currently known about the crash.

headline: Chinese Investigators Describe Capture of Panda Killers
text: Given the popularity of giant pandas as attractions both in China and in zoos around the world, it is easy to forget that they still face mortal threats.

headline: Uncertainty Reigns in Burundi After Attempted Coup
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — President Pierre Nkurunziza was back in Burundi on Thursday, news agencies reported, a day after an attempted coup against his government.

headline: Test Yourself | Jay, Bey and a Vegan Food Company
text: Below, several paragraphs from the May 7 article “Jay Z and Beyoncé Want to Put You in a Vegan State of Mind.”

headline: How Myanmar and Its Neighbors Are Responding to the Rohingya Crisis
text: Myanmar and its neighbors see the people of the Rohingya ethnic group and the seaborne trafficking of migrants in the region very differently, complicating the refugees’ plight.

headline: A Bronx Apartment Just Like the One in Manhattan
text: Beth Rosen and Maryann King had every reason to think they would never move again. Since 1981, they had lived in the same building on West 110th Street in Morningside Heights.

headline: 12 Years Later, a Mystery of Chemical Exposure in Iraq Clears Slightly
text: The toxic vapors acted quickly against the Second Platoon of the 811th Ordnance Company, whose soldiers were moving abandoned barrels out of an Iraqi Republican Guard warehouse in 2003. The building, one soldier said, was littered with dead birds.

headline: What Is the Role of Religion or Spirituality in Your Life?
text: How important is a spiritual life to you? Do you identify yourself as a member of a particular religion or spiritual tradition, or are you one of the growing group of young people who consider themselves “nothing in particular”?

headline: Telefónica of Spain Reports Profit Jump From Pending Sale of O2
text: LONDON — Telefónica, the Spanish telecommunications giant, said on Thursday that its net profit in the first three months of the year almost tripled after it benefited from a one-off financial gain from the pending sale of its British division.

headline: ‘Weed the People,’ by Bruce Barcott
text: Bruce Barcott’s title spares the reviewer of a certain age — cured in the smokehouse of the 1960s — from starting with his own weak, drug-related jest. The book has several other virtues. One of which is not focus.

headline: ‘James Merrill: Life and Art,’ by Langdon Hammer
text: Some people are born with a silver spoon, but the poet James Merrill — son of a founder of Merrill Lynch — had whole place settings jammed down his throat. His family was exceedingly rich, with houses in Greenwich Village and Southampton, where an estate named the Orchard became a showplace for weekends and summers. “Broad lawns unrolled on either side of the drive, with huge squat boxwood hedges for sentinels and wistful, champagne-glass-shaped elms shading the gravel circle at the front door,” Langdon Hammer (chairman of the English department at Yale) writes in his eloquent and sympathetic new biography, “James Merrill: Life and Art.” That such great wealth never sapped Merrill’s ambition as a poet seems remarkable in itself. “Jimmy was no less of a competitor than his father,” Hammer notes, “and no less hungry for public recognition.”

headline: The Psychology of Choking Under Pressure
text: Choking, or failing in a pressure-filled situation, is common enough. But the underlying psychology is surprisingly mysterious for such a familiar phenomenon. So scientists at Johns Hopkins University and the California Institute of Technology decided to investigate what happens in the brain of a person who chokes. They recruited 26 men and women to practice playing a mentally taxing video game — which involved moving dots on a screen quickly — while lying down in an M.R.I. machine.

headline: Are You a Risk Taker? Take the Quiz
text: Are you a bit of a daredevil when it comes to taking risks? Or more conservative?

headline: Going Viral: Behind the Digital Strategy for Metro’s Nail Salon Exposé
text: When Sarah Maslin Nir’s two-part investigation of the mistreatment of nail salon workers in New York was published last week, her 13 months of research and reporting saw almost immediate results: On Monday morning, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced statewide measures to protect salon workers.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Death Toll in Philippine Factory Fire Climbs Above 70
text: MANILA — The toll from one of the deadliest industrial fires in Philippine history rose to 72 on Thursday, officials said, as firefighters carried one body bag after another out of the blackened remnants of a slipper factory.

headline: New York Today: Train Crash Snarls Transit
text: Good morning on this crystalline Thursday.

headline: Rohingya Migrants From Myanmar, Shunned by Malaysia, Are Spotted Adrift in Andaman Sea
text: IN THE ANDAMAN SEA OFF THAILAND — A wooden fishing boat carrying several hundred desperate migrants from Myanmar was spotted adrift in the Andaman Sea between Thailand and Malaysia on Thursday, part of an exodus in which thousands of people have taken to the sea in recent weeks with no country willing to take them in.

headline: Let Syrians Settle Detroit
text: Detroit, a once great city, has become an urban vacuum. Its population has fallen to around 700,000 from nearly 1.9 million in 1950. The city is estimated to have more than 70,000 abandoned buildings and 90,000 vacant lots. Meanwhile, desperate Syrians, victims of an unfathomable civil war, are fleeing to neighboring countries, with some 1.8 million in Turkey and 600,000 in Jordan.

headline: Donors Must Find Their Own Lunch at Hillary Clinton Gathering
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign may be wooing donors in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn on Thursday, but there will be no free lunch.

headline: Hotel Review: The Paper Factory
text: Double rooms from $149.

headline: Update: The Multimillion-Dollar Kidnapping Case in Hong Kong
text: The kidnapping case last month of Queenie Rosita Law, 29, granddaughter of the late textiles tycoon Law Ting-pong, has gripped Hong Kong, a city that, despite its low crime rate, has seen a number of sensational abductions over the years targeting some of its richest families.

headline: Restaurant Report: 27 in Miami Beach
text: New restaurants on and around Ocean Drive in Miami Beach — usually housed in the latest branded boutique hotel with big-name absentee chefs, high-priced fusion menus and ’80s décor — are a dime a dozen. Then there’s 27, a spot that opened in November just a few steps, but a world away, from that touristy, neon-dotted strip.

headline: In Barcelona, a New Draw for Design Fans
text: Not so long ago, travelers might have stopped in the Glòries area of Barcelona only if they were stuck in traffic. Three major roads leading in and out of this Spanish city — Avenida Diagonal, Avenida Meridiana and the Gran Via de les Corts Catalanes — converged here at an elevated roundabout, where cars often came to a standstill.

headline: Shopping for Antiques, Finding My Mother
text: ST. PETERSBURG, FLA. — My mother sat next to me on her sofa. She held a brass candlestick like a baton. “Put stickers on the things you’d like to have,” she said. “With your initials. So when I’m gone there’s no confusion.”

headline: The Morning After the Same-Sex Marriage Decision
text: Let’s assume, as I do, that the Supreme Court finds a constitutional right to same-sex marriage when it decides Obergefell v. Hodges sometime next month. What happens next?

headline: The Underground Art of the Insult
text: On March 6, 2014, Aretha Franklin paid a visit to the White House for a special event celebrating “women of soul.” Dressed in a brown fur coat, a sequined black dress and a large, glittery pendant, she strode through a dark red door into the East Room, waving regally at a line of well-wishers who stood to applaud her. Among them was another diva, Patti LaBelle, who reached out to grab Franklin’s hand. With a small, swooping motion, Franklin twisted her body away from LaBelle, evading her greeting, and continued walking. She hardly missed a beat.

headline: The Legal Power of ‘Standing’
text: CHICAGO — It just goes to show the importance of jurisdiction. Recently, the Supreme Court added a new case to its docket for next year, Spokeo v. Robins, which is about a technical question of jurisdiction — when a plaintiff has “standing” to sue in federal court. But the court’s decision to hear a case on that technical issue may have the surprising effect of causing the court to postpone its ruling in Zivotofsky v. Kerry, a major case about separation of powers and foreign affairs that the court is expected to decide any day now.

headline: The President, Fox News and the Poor
text: This week, during a panel discussion on poverty at Georgetown University, President Obama lambasted the media, and in particular Fox News, for creating false, destructive narratives about the poor that paint them broadly as indolent and pathological.

headline: The Last Day of Her Life
text: Sandy Bem, a Cornell psychology professor one month shy of her 65th birthday, was alone in her bedroom one night in May 2009, watching an HBO documentary called “The Alzheimer’s Project.” For two years, she had been experiencing what she called “cognitive oddities”: forgetting the names of things or confusing words that sounded similar. She once complained about a “blizzard” on her foot, when she meant a blister; she brought home a bag of plums and, standing in her kitchen, pulled one out and said to a friend: “Is this a plum? I can’t quite seem to fully know.”

headline: The Confederate Diaspora
text: By early May 1865, a month after Gen. Robert E. Lee’s surrender at Appomattox, most of the remaining Confederate soldiers had laid down their arms. While some Southerners were angry, and others were relieved, nearly all were apprehensive about the future. Many moved west and north; some decided to leave the United States completely.

headline: Montserrat Caballé, Spanish Soprano, Fails to Appear in Court to Settle Tax Case
text: The opera singer Montserrat Caballé failed to appear in a Spanish court this week to settle a tax fraud case, and her lawyer stepped down as her legal representative in the matter.

headline: Is It Wrong to Let Children Do Extreme Sports?
text: Even as Americans have grown more fixated on childhood safety, kids are participating in risky pastimes in ever greater numbers.

headline: When Teaching Comes Cheap for Colleges
text: Are unions the best way for graduate-student instructors and adjuncts to get better compensation and conditions?

headline: Today in Politics: Gulf Leaders to Push Obama for Support
text: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where fans of the local basketball and hockey teams are busy licking their wounds. Republicans are gathering in Arizona for their party’s spring meetings, where the presidential primary debates will be a hot topic, and the International Monetary Fund will soon be in the market for a new top economist. In the meantime, President Obama is hosting some important guests from out of town.

headline: ‘I Like Being Afraid’
text: For some kids, the playground isn’t enough – extreme sports like snowboarding or motocross are the best ways to have fun. But are they safe?

headline: Manchester Festival Appoints New Artistic Director
text: John E. McGrath, the artistic director of the National Theater Wales, will become the chief executive and artistic director of the Manchester International Festival, taking over from Alex Poots, who has led the festival since it began in 2007. Mr. Poots gave the biennial Manchester festival its distinctive identity by programming only new work, and he established it as a major international event. He is leaving after this year’s edition to run a new arts space, Culture Shed, in New York.

headline: Brandon Bostian Agrees to Talk About Amtrak Derailment but May Recall Little
text: PHILADELPHIA — As the death toll from this week’s fatal Amtrak derailment rose to eight, federal investigators on Thursday turned their attention to the train’s engineer — and said that a new analysis of video showed the train quickly accelerated from 70 to 100 miles per hour in less than a minute before it entered a sharp curve and careened off the tracks.

headline: Lori Dickerson Fouché of Prudential on the Limits of Self-Reliance
text: Q. Were you in leadership roles or doing entrepreneurial things when you were younger?

headline: Chinese Police Order Residents in a Xinjiang Prefecture to Turn In Passports
text: BEIJING — Residents of an ethnically diverse prefecture in far northwest China that borders several nations have been asked to hand over their passports to the police by Friday or have the documents canceled, according to a notice circulating online and an interview with an officer on Thursday.

headline: In Israel, Desalinization at the Heart of a Water Revolution
text: A major national effort to desalinate Mediterranean seawater and to recycle wastewater has provided the country with enough water for all its needs.

headline: Morning Agenda: Tempered Penalties for Guilty Pleas
text: TEMPERED PENALTIES FOR GUILTY PLEAS | For banks, a guilty plea in a felony case is the equivalent of a scarlet letter, one that could lead to a revoked license in the worst-case scenario. But for the five big banks that are expected to plead guilty to conspiring to manipulate foreign currency rates, life will go on, “probably without much of a hiccup,” Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write in DealBook.

headline: Sheldon Adelson Receives a George W. Bush Original Painting
text: Sheldon Adelson is the owner of several casinos, hotels and a large bank account. He’s now also the owner of a genuine George W. Bush.

headline: Harry Shearer Is Leaving ‘The Simpsons’
text: It is not looking like an okely-dokely day in the town of Springfield: Harry Shearer, an Emmy Award-winning cast member of “The Simpsons,” who provides the voices of characters like the irritatingly upbeat neighbor Ned Flanders, the billionaire tyrant Mr. Burns and his faithful manservant, Smithers, has indicated that he is parting ways with this long-running Fox animated series.

headline: Jeb Bush Taunts Hillary Clinton Over Not Taking Questions
text: RENO, Nev. — Jeb Bush has a pointed message for Hillary Rodham Clinton: I’m willing to face tough questions. You’re not.

headline: Surrounded by Disturbing Art
text: Read all recent entries and our updated submissions guidelines. Reach us via email diary@nytimes.com or follow @NYTMetro on Twitter using the hashtag #MetDiary.

headline: Martin O’Malley Courts Democrats Before May 30 Announcement
text: Former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland has recently urged Democrats on the left to end any remaining wishful thinking about Senator Elizabeth Warren and to invest their energy in him.

headline: Ireland Makes Arrests and Finds Bombs Before Visit by Prince Charles
text: DUBLIN — Irish Army bomb experts disarmed several potentially lethal devices and the police arrested six men with links to dissident republican groups amid heightened security before next week’s visit by Prince Charles of Britain and his wife, Camilla Parker Bowles, a police spokesman said on Thursday.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Mad Max Fury Road’
text: George Miller narrates a sequence from his film featuring Tom Hardy, Charlize Theron and Nicholas Hoult.

headline: Cloudy Skies, Illustrated
text: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

headline: Joseph J. Ellis: By the Book
text: The historian and author, most recently, of “The Quartet” keeps Plato, Kant, Hume, Locke and Nietzsche on his shelves. “Just looking over at them reminds me that once upon a time I was a very serious young man.”

headline: Teaching Children to Love Bees, Not Fear Them
text: Several years ago, reports of the declining bee population inspired my partner to keep bees in our yard. Her reasons were mainly practical—not only did she want to support the vanishing bees, she hoped our plum trees might increase their yield. But it took less than one season for my partner to fall in love, and over time the number of hives in our backyard has multiplied from two to 10. At my house this week we know that spring has arrived because my 2-year-old points out the window and yells excitedly: “Bees!”

headline: ‘Mad Max: Fury Road’ (With Movie Trailer): George Miller Narrates a Scene
text: It’s been a long road to “Mad Max: Fury Road,” George Miller’s continuation of his postapocalyptic series that began in 1979 with the film “Mad Max,” starring Mel Gibson. Tom Hardy now has the role, but the sparse dialogue and complicated, outrageous action remain. It’s a return to live-action terrain after Mr. Miller directed two animated films, “Happy Feet” and “Happy Feet Two.” In this video, Mr. Miller discusses the meeting of Max and Furiosa (Charlize Theron). In interviews at the South by Southwest film festival in Austin and in New York, Mr. Miller talked about updating the franchise.

headline: Review: ‘Mad Max: Fury Road,’ Still Angry After All These Years
text: Desolate, post-apocalyptic landscapes, zombie-ridden or not, are perennial popular tourist destinations for 21st-century moviegoers and couch potatoes. “Mad Max: Fury Road” is like a visit to a World Heritage site. Some of us — old enough to remember when nuclear Armageddon had not yet given way to climate change as the main source of existential anxiety — harbor a special fondness for the young Mel Gibson as Max Rockatansky, the grieving, aggrieved former cop who motored across the Australian desert in “Mad Max,” “The Road Warrior” and “Beyond Thunderdome.”

headline: With Gas Prices Less of a Worry, Buyers Pass Hybrid Cars By
text: Affordable gasoline is making hybrid car owners rethink their loyalty.

headline: Myanmar Migrants Spotted in Andaman Sea
text: A wooden fishing boat carrying several hundred migrants from Myanmar was seen adrift west of the Thai mainland on Thursday.

headline: Daily Report: Technology Behind Advertising Is at the Heart of Verizon’s Deal for AOL
text: A new generation of Math Men is taking over the Mad Men of Madison Avenue, Emily Steel and Sydney Ember report.

headline: Hillary Rodham Clinton Ups the Super PAC Ante
text: For all the candidates’ grand promises, it turns out the most creative area of the presidential contest so far has been the strategic rush to shift costly campaign duties from budget-tight headquarters to an armada of new super PACs. These groups are free to raise unlimited funds from big-check writers shopping for influence while supposedly operating independent of their candidates. It sounds like a neat trick, and legions of campaign lawyers are working on pulling it off.

headline: In Flight
text: En route from London to Tokyo, a pilot’s-eye view of life in the sky.

headline: Honda Recalls Nearly 5 Million Vehicles With Takata Airbags
text: TOKYO — Honda on Thursday recalled 4.9 million vehicles equipped with airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata, a day after Toyota and Nissan announced similarly vast recalls.

headline: Stephen Curry’s Odd Line Shows a Shift in Warriors’ and N.B.A.’s Game
text: Stephen Curry is the N.B.A.’s most valuable player, but there was one thing he could not do Wednesday night: make a 2-point shot.

headline: Letters: 18 West 11th Street
text: 18 West 11th Street

headline: Bodies Recovered in Manila Factory Fire
text: The Philippine interior secretary and the Valenzuela city fire marshal discussed the recovery efforts on Thursday for victims of a factory fire in Manila.

headline: Greece Rules Out Suing British Museum Over Elgin Marbles
text: Stepping back from a fight with Britain over ownership of the so-called Elgin marbles, the Greek culture minister has declared that Athens will not pursue legal action to settle the bitter, decades-old dispute, despite the advice of international lawyers.

headline: Patriots’ Rebuttal Is Foray Further Into Farce
text: So it has come to this. After four months of speculation and outrage, as well as an investigation costing millions of dollars and diverting attention from what would seem to be more serious matters, the focus of the N.F.L.’s air-pressure scandal has seemingly narrowed to one man — a crass, overweight jokester with a full bladder.

headline: Nissan Recalls Millions of Cars
text: Carlos Ghosn, the chairman and chief executive of Nissan Motor, said the decision to recall 1.56 million cars was “part of the solution” to tackle the trouble over Takata’s defective air bags.

headline: Schumer to Recommend Brooklyn Prosecutor for U.S. Attorney Post
text: Robert L. Capers, a longtime federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, has won the critical support of Senator Chuck Schumer to be the next United States attorney for the Eastern District, which covers Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island.

headline: Plus-Size Market Gets a ‘Pitch Perfect’ Voice
text: The plus-size market, a segment that’s been long overlooked by designers but increasingly insists on getting its due, is getting another boost: a celebrity collaboration.

headline: Hillary Clinton Enlists Bigger-Name Backers in Novel Ways
text: In previous presidential election cycles, campaigns have sent out press releases that screamed the news of endorsements received. In 2008, when Hillary Rodham Clinton was the considered the early front-runner, endorsements were a gauge of support used by reporters and others.

headline: Matthew Weiner, the Creator of ‘Mad Men,’ Prepares for Another Fade to Black
text: It took almost 55 years, but the 1960s are finally over. They ended without our even realizing it, somewhere in the middle of this bifurcated final season of “Mad Men,” after Don Draper and his fellow employees at Sterling Cooper & Partners watched the moon landing and mourned the death of the agency’s gentle co-founder Bert Cooper. When the AMC drama returned a year later, in April, for its final seven episodes, suddenly it was the spring of 1970, and the decade that had defined this show was gone.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: Looking for something to do this weekend?

headline: Why Facebook’s News Experiment Matters to Readers
text: Facebook’s new plan to host news publications’ stories directly is not only about page views, advertising revenue or the number of seconds it takes for an article to load. It is about who owns the relationship with readers.

headline: Russ Feingold Will Run for Senate in Wisconsin
text: Russ Feingold, the liberal Democrat and former three-term senator, announced on Thursday that he will run for his old seat in the United States Senate from Wisconsin.

headline: It’s a Process, Rangers Say, and Sometimes It Takes Seven Games
text: The Rangers take their cues from Alain Vigneault, their stoic coach, who preached “sticking to the process” all season.

headline: The Art of Medicine
text: In 1986, Oliver Sacks was one of 10 doctors who wrote about their lives as both physicians and writers in the Book Review. Sacks contrasted himself with a doctor novelist, saying: “I have no literary aspirations whatever, only the desire to report clinical reality in all its richness.”

headline: Pew and the Three American Worldviews
text: Having offered some cautions about over-interpreting the findings of the latest Pew religion survey, let me throw that caution to the wind and offer a quick interpretation myself. A few times in the past — this old column, this recent post — I’ve played with the idea that we have three major worldviews sharing space in American culture, which you might label biblical, spiritual and secular respectively. (The “spiritual” category overlaps substantially with the “nation of heretics” described in my last book.) Here’s how I tried to sketch this division — in the context of the Christmas story, hence the references — two years back:

headline: Narendra Modi Starts Trip to China With a Burst of Sightseeing
text: HONG KONG — Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India pressed President Xi Jinping of China on border disputes and a yawning trade deficit on Thursday, after Mr. Modi started a trip to China with a burst of sightseeing intended to highlight the ancient ties between the two neighbors.

headline: A Range of Reactions to Airline’s Removal of Autistic Child
text: A United Airlines pilot’s decision to divert a flight to remove a family with an autistic daughter has set off a firestorm online, with some calling for a boycott of the carrier.

headline: Portraits of the Victims: Amtrak Train Derailment
text: At least seven people were killed Tuesday, when Amtrak’s Northeast Regional Train No. 188 derailed in Philadelphia shortly before 9:30 p.m. About a dozen people are still missing. Here are some of the victims who have been identified.

headline: Euro, Clawing Its Way Back, Hits 3-Month High
text: PARIS — As recently as March, the dollar was looking so strong against the euro that the only question seemed to be how soon the eurozone currency would sink to parity.

headline: George Stephanopoulos Acknowledges Giving Money to Clinton Foundation
text: ABC News’s chief anchor, George Stephanopoulos, acknowledged Thursday that he had made donations to the Clinton Foundation in recent years without disclosing those contributions to his employer — even as he reported on the Clintons and their foundation.

headline: Still Hungry, the First-Place Royals Are Looking to Return to the World Series
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — A week or so after it ended, after a pop-up landed in the paws of a Panda, Lorenzo Cain came out of hibernation. He wanted to see the postseason again, to relive the joy ride of the Kansas City Royals. In a way, he still is.

headline: Witness and Police on Kabul Hotel Attack
text: Kabul’s police chief, Gen. Abdul Rahman Rahimi, said investigative teams were looking into a deadly attack at a guesthouse that took place Wednesday night.

headline: Small Packages, Big Fun
text: New picture books include “I Am the Wolf ... and Here I Come!” and “Circles.”

headline: 1915: U.S. Warns Germany of Action
text: NEW YORK — President Wilson’s Note to Germany arraigns the Empire for repeated violation of American rights. It is the final paragraph of the Note that conveys the intimation of ACTION, if Germany does not cease its murderous piracy campaign, that may have the effect on convincing Berlin that the United States will not tamely submit to further outrage. Everyone realizes that with the presentation of President Wilson’s note to Germany last night [May 13], one of the most critical stages in American history has been reached. — The New York Herald, European Edition, May 15, 1915

headline: How to Rebuild After an Earthquake Like Nepal's
text: Experts offer tips on how a country like Nepal can rebuild after an earthquake with whatever materials are available.

headline: Obama Pledges More Military Aid to Reassure Persian Gulf Allies on Iran Deal
text: CAMP DAVID, Md. — President Obama on Thursday offered Saudi Arabia and smaller Arab states new support to defend against potential missile strikes, maritime threats and cyberattacks from Iran, calling his commitment to their security “ironclad” in an effort to allay fears that a nuclear accord will empower Tehran, their main rival in the Middle East.

headline: Rand Paul: George Stephanopoulos Shouldn’t Moderate 2016 Debates
text: A Republican backlash against George Stephanopoulos, the public face of ABC News and the network’s top political anchor, was beginning to build on Thursday after the disclosure that he had made large contributions to the Clinton Foundation in recent years.

headline: Fruit Flies Are Shown to Enter a Fearlike State
text: Whether fruit flies feel anything resembling emotion is hard to determine, but new research suggests they can experience a fearlike state.

headline: Kottu House
text: Sri Lankan street food finds a wider audience on the Lower East Side.

headline: Kottu House Captures the (Good) Spirit of Sri Lanka
text: A devil’s face with goggle eyes and swollen tongue stares from the window of Kottu House. It’s only a vinyl decal, meant to evoke the wooden masks — often flanked by cobras, peacocks or flames — that guard the entrances of Sinhalese homes in Sri Lanka, warding off evil.

headline: The N.H.L.’s Conference Finals Are a Story of Mirror Images and Even Matches
text: The conference finals have been a habit recently for the Rangers and the Chicago Blackhawks, with each reaching the third round three times in the past four seasons. But of the final four teams, the Rangers have gone the longest without winning the Stanley Cup. When the Rangers won in 1994, the Tampa Bay Lightning were two years old and the Anaheim Ducks were one, but each has won a championship since.

headline: Sheldon Adelson Comes to New York, and Presidential Candidates Follow
text: The so-called Sheldon Adelson primary — in which Republican presidential hopefuls have been auditioning for the approval of one of the richest men to play in politics — is coming to New York City in two weeks.

headline: A Crisis in the Heart of Egg Country
text: More than three-quarters of the birds that have died or must be killed nationwide as a result of bird flu are in Iowa, where one in every five eggs consumed in the country is laid.

headline: My Brother’s Peacekeeper
text: My brother’s wife left him and their two young sons to “redefine herself.” She wrote my family members an email saying she would still like to be included in our gatherings and maintain strong relationships with all of us. My brother is a good guy, and we are distraught by her abandonment of him and their children. I have not replied to her email yet. Should I keep quiet or call her out for deserting her family, then expecting my friendship?

headline: Swearing Off the Modern Man
text: The Modern Man has an iPhone 6 Plus and goes to Coachella every year. He’s thinking about starting a blog and has been “like really into standup lately.” He has a favorite microbrewery because he likes his beer really hoppy, whatever that means. He has a fun Twitter feed and interesting theories about what could happen on “House of Cards.”

headline: 1937-1961 | Regrettable Spellings? We’ve Had a Few
text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Egg Farms Hit Hard as Bird Flu Affects Millions of Hens
text: SIOUX CENTER, Iowa — J.T. Dean is facing a gargantuan task.

headline: Safely Costuming ‘Permission,’ a High-Impact Comedy From Robert Askins
text: A couple of months ago, Paloma Young went online and ordered a wide assortment of shaper panties, booty-padded panties, butt lifters and butt enhancers. Ms. Young, an award-winning costume designer, had just signed on to “Permission,” a dark comedy by Robert Askins, whose “Hand to God” is up for the Tony Award for best play. It posed a design challenge like none she had ever experienced.

headline: Reddit Introduces Anti-Harassment Policy
text: Reddit, the popular online message forum, has long been a free-for-all for the collective id of the Internet. A few sacred commandments kept users in check: Thou shalt not spam, thou shalt not post personally identifiable information and thou shalt not break the site.

headline: Greek Finance Minister Lashes Out at E.C.B. Chief
text: FRANKFURT — Yanis Varoufakis, the Greek finance minister, on Thursday once again demonstrated his flair for inflaming the debate about his country’s economic future.

headline: Preakness 2015: Predictions and Analysis
text: The horses for Saturday’s 140th running of the Preakness Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses. The morning-line odds were set by Keith Feustle of Pimlico Race Course.

headline: Viewfinder: Leonard Greco
text: Leonard Greco began assembling and capturing everyday objects to combat his dissatisfaction with his mundane commercial work.

headline: Marco Rubio’s Answers on Iraq a Departure From the Past
text: The question du jour for Republican presidential candidates, it seems, is if they would have authorized the 2003 invasion of Iraq knowing what the nation now knows — that the country did not possess weapons on mass destruction.

headline: A French Film Ingenue Shares Her Provencal Pleasures
text: Rosalie Varda-Demy, the 56-year-old daughter of the French film impresario Agnès Varda and the late director-screenwriter Jacques Demy, once designed costumes for films and theater but now organizes events for the Cannes Film Festival and manages her parents’ catalog. From her mother’s “The Creatures” with Catherine Deneuve, to her father’s “Lola,” featuring music by the acclaimed composer Michel Legrand, there’s much to preserve. “Eight years ago, I began to think that I wanted to share some time with my mother, who’s an incredible woman,” says Rosalie, herself a mother of three grown boys, about the 86-year-old force in her life who’s still showing work around the world. This October, Agnès will debut a new exhibition — photos of Cuba from 1962 — at the Centre Pompidou in October. “She’s done incredible things in her life as a film director and photographer. So I thought I’ll quit my business to share hers with a new generation. She gave me a lot, and I’m giving her a lot now.”

headline: Eight Exhibition-Inspired Courses
text: For its spring benefit, the Museum of Food and Drink asked chefs to prepare dishes inspired by future shows.

headline: Quiz: Which of These ‘Simpsons’ Characters Did Harry Shearer Voice?
text: Which of the characters below did Harry Shearer portray? Do well, and we won’t release the hounds.

headline: Senate, in Reversal, Begins Debate on Trade Authority
text: WASHINGTON — Two days after Democratic senators blocked it, the Senate voted on Thursday to take up legislation that would grant the president negotiating freedom to complete an expansive trade accord with 11 nations on the Pacific Rim, setting off a contentious congressional debate on one of President Obama’s top priorities for his remaining time in office.

headline: Cuomo’s Job Creation Program Is Slow to Take Hold
text: ALBANY — In May 2013, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a program he promised would “supercharge” the state’s economy and take job creation efforts to a level never seen before. He poured tens of millions of dollars into advertising to push the program, Start-Up New York.

headline: The Science Behind the Dress
text: Nearly three months after the infamous blue and black dress (or was it white and gold?) tore the Internet apart, three teams of scientists have provided a closer look at the science behind the viral phenomenon. In their papers, published Thursday in the journal Current Biology, the teams have proposed reasons that different people saw different colors, and what the whole thing means for our understanding of visual perception.

headline: Throwback Thursday | The Times Reports on Prom, 1955-2015
text: It’s prom season, and that means articles about dress decisions, increasingly elaborate promposals, and, of course, the seemingly-annual prom controversy (promtroversy?).

headline: Gunfire Heard in Burundi
text: Residents fled from gunfire in Burundi’s capital, Bujumbura, the day after an army general said a coup had overthrown President Pierre Nkurunziza. It was not clear who was in charge of the country.

headline: Taliban Attack Kills 14, Including American, at Kabul Hotel
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least 14 people were killed in a Taliban attack at a popular Kabul hotel late Wednesday night, when a gunman went room to room killing guests, according to witnesses and Afghan and foreign officials.

headline: ‘Yoko Ono: One Woman Show’
text: A look at the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Piet Hein Eek Brings His Singular Furniture — and a Couple of Friends — to NoHo
text: The Dutch designer collaborated with the gallery The Future Perfect on a takeover of the storefront, featuring his own work and that of his compatriots.

headline: A Good Time for Visa to Take Europe
text: It’s a good time for Visa to charge up overseas. Buying its former subsidiary Visa Europe may cost the American payments company as much as $20 billion. There are plenty of reasons to act now.

headline: Review: In ‘Yoko Ono: One Woman Show, 1960-1971,’ Text Messages From the Edge
text: On the principle that imagining something can make it real, Yoko Ono gave herself a solo exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in 1971. What was the likelihood of the museum’s coming up with the idea on its own? Practically zero. Historically, women were rarely shown there; nonwhite women, never. And, most of Ms. Ono’s work was on a far-out fringe of art-world orthodoxy where, to her cost and our good fortune, she chose, in her early years at least, to stay.

headline: Jeb Bush Says, ‘I Would Not Have Gone Into Iraq’
text: TEMPE, Ariz — After days of sidestepping, Jeb Bush on Thursday offered a definitive answer to the question of whether he would have authorized the invasion of Iraq in 2003 had he known about the intelligence failures at the time.

headline: An Abortion Ban’s Bogus Arguments
text: For the second time in two years, the House  voted Wednesday to pass legislation that would ban almost all abortions 20 weeks or more after fertilization. The bill, called the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, claims that “an unborn child is capable of experiencing pain at least by 20 weeks after fertilization,” though medical evidence does not support this.

headline: Letters to the Travel Editor
text: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.

headline: Watch an Artist Create a Perfect Little Cloud Indoors
text: Berndnaut Smilde’s Frieze Week forecast is cloudy with no chance of anything but art-making. The cheery young Dutchman, who sees himself “as a sculptor, mainly,” has stirred lots of attention for his “Nimbus” series of atmospheric creations, in which he plays weatherman and creates clouds indoors. For centuries, humans have tried to control the atmosphere, and Smilde, who is “not particularly scientific — I have a Lego background,” he says, has managed to hack nature. “Moisture is the main factor, and if it’s cold, that really helps,” he explains. “Other than that, I’m using all kinds of means to create an image and idea.” Mostly, that entails fog machines and squirt bottles filled with water — and “shutting down the fire alarms,” he laughs, “otherwise everybody will get very wet!”

headline: 1965: Cannes Shows ‘Social Realism’
text: CANNES — Two films today [May 14] gave the Cannes Film Festival its first taste of the ‘‘social realism’’ now favored by serious film-makers in most of the underdeveloped countries. Neither film was given much chance of earning a prize, but each in its way had considerable power. In the case of the Egyptian film ‘‘El Haram’’ (The Sin), it was a virtuoso performance by Fatem Hamama as a farm worker falsely accused of murdering an unwanted child. The Bulgarian entry, ‘‘Gorechto Plande’’ (Torrid Summer), gave a touching account of a community’s efforts to rescue a boy whose hand has got stuck in a hole in a bridge. — New York Herald Tribune, European edition, May 15, 1965

headline: Review: In ‘The Film Critic,’ a Snob Is Tripped Up by His Heartstrings
text: Reviewing a pretentious little movie can be like shooting fish in a barrel. Sometimes all you can do is start with a cliché. But sometimes the target in the water looks familiar, as if you were staring at your own glassy-eyed reflection. That is more or less the case with “The Film Critic,” a movie from the Argentine director Hernán Guerschuny whose protagonist is a grumpy middle-aged guy in less than perfect physical condition who writes dyspeptic notices for a big-city newspaper and hates just about everything that isn’t Godard.

headline: Ivy Ziedrich, College Student, Warms to Role as Jeb Bush Critic on ISIS
text: RENO, Nev. — On Wednesday afternoon, just as she sat down to watch TV and eat a corn dog, Ivy Ziedrich’s phone rang. It was her sister in Montana.

headline: For Amtrak Engineer Brandon Bostian, Childhood Passion Became a Career
text: PHILADELPHIA — Growing up in Memphis, Brandon Bostian, the engineer in the fatal Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia this week, loved railroads so much that he made a pilgrimage each Friday during high school to watch the late-night City of New Orleans rumble through town.

headline: With ‘I’ll See You in My Dreams’ and ‘Grandma,’ Hollywood Pays Attention to Older Viewers
text: A survey of recent and coming films will reveal, as usual, a surfeit of sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll. What’s not so usual is the number of people over 70 engaging in sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Republicans Can’t Name a Favorite Living President
text: Asked to pick a favorite living president, many of the likely Republican presidential candidates at the South Carolina Freedom Summit brought up Ronald Reagan, despite the fact that he has been dead for nearly 11 years.

headline: In a First, a Fish Is Shown to Be Fully Warm-Blooded
text: The moonfish, or opah, is the first fish shown to be fully warm-blooded, researchers report in the journal Science. Although some large predatory fish, like tuna, can temporarily warm their muscles or organs, the opah is the only fish that warms its heart. A silvery fish the size of an automobile tire, the opah is found in oceans around the world. To warm its organs, the fish harnesses the heat generated by rapidly flapping its pectoral fins. The heat gives the moonfish a competitive advantage in the chilly waters that it lives in, several hundred feet below the ocean’s surface.

headline: Review Board Notes Rise in New York Police Officers’ False Statements
text: An officer drew his weapon on a bystander holding a cellphone but denied using a racial obscenity. In another case, an officer told investigators that he had not shoved a man in handcuffs, but that the man tripped.

headline: George Stephanopoulos’s Gifts to Clinton Foundation Reinforce G.O.P. Doubts
text: WASHINGTON — Even after more than a decade as an analyst, anchor and public face for ABC News, George Stephanopoulos has never been able to shake the image that many Republicans have of him: Clinton hatchet man.

headline: John Bolton Decides Against Entering Presidential Fray
text: John R. Bolton’s run for president has ended before it had a chance to get started.

headline: A Phantom Offer Sends Avon’s Shares Surging
text: The federal government’s system for filing securities documents may not be as secure as many on Wall Street assume, considering what appears to have been a fake bid on Thursday for Avon Products.

headline: Sienna Miller’s Perfectly Fitted Hourglass Figure
text: The Star: Sienna Miller

headline: Matching Colors Between Display and Document
text: Pictures from photofinishing services may not display correctly on a computer because the colors can be affected by the light in the room and the monitor settings.

headline: Questions for Jeb Bush: Iraq Is Just the Beginning
text: Jeb Bush has been tied in rhetorical knots this week trying to answer whether he would have ordered the invasion of Iraq, as his brother George W. did as president in 2003. On Thursday, Mr. Bush ultimately said that “knowing what we know now,” he would not have invaded.

headline: The Rise of ‘Middle Class’ as an Ordinary American Term
text: “Middle class,” a term as much aspirational as descriptive, may end up as a linguistic flash in the pan.

headline: Naval Academy Honors Amtrak Victim
text: The United States Naval Academy’s superintendent said Thursday that Justin Zemser, the midshipman who died in an Amtrak train derailment, was a talented and highly respected young man.

headline: Court Blocks Spanish Soccer Players’ Plans to Strike Over TV Money
text: A planned players’ strike in Spanish soccer was suspended Thursday by the country’s national court, allowing matches to proceed on schedule this weekend and positioning Barcelona to clinch La Liga’s title Sunday with a victory at Atlético Madrid.

headline: Rosé Wine to Drink This Summer
text: The world loves rosé in summer. And why not? It’s pretty, refreshing and carefree in the best possible way. Yet the public’s easy embrace of rosé often means an uncritical acceptance of anything in pink.

headline: A Look Inside the Kips Bay Show House
text: The annual designer showcase opens at the Arthur Sachs Mansion, with proceeds benefiting the Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club, which turned 100 this year.

headline: Philadelphia Mayor Confirms Crash Toll
text: Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia said Thursday that the remains of an eighth victim of the Amtrak derailment had been found and that all passengers had been accounted for.

headline: ‘Heaven Knows What’ Captures the Hooked and Homeless
text: As Josh and Benny Safdie, the makers of “Heaven Knows What,” strolled through Central Park on a recent spring day, they related the names and routines of park regulars; they rattled off rules that street kids live by. (Don’t stay after 1 a.m.) In Strawberry Fields, Josh indicated the spot where Ilya Leontyev, the inspiration for one of the film’s leads, was found dead last month, at 25.

headline: Scrutinizing an Employee’s Suspicious Sick Day
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: The Freedom of ‘I Do,’ Take Two
text: Andrea Seabrook describes her first wedding, a large affair in 2001 in a historic Episcopal church, as “tasteful,” “beautiful” and “respectable.”

headline: Body Found in Hudson River Is Not Missing Kayaker, Police Say
text: The police in the Town of Poughkeepsie said on Thursday that a body recovered from the Hudson River this week was not that of Vincent Viafore, the 46-year-old man who prosecutors say was killed by his fiancée as the couple kayaked last month.

headline: Text to Text | Making Meaning From the Art in Our Lives
text: As the school year winds down, we’ve created a final Text to Text with questions that we hope follow you into the museums and galleries you visit on vacation this summer.

headline: The Arcane Charms of Mangle Boards
text: Mangle boards, once used by Northern Europeans to smooth laundry after it was washed and dried, are the focus of a new book by an art historian.

headline: The Museum of Food and Drink’s Forward-Looking Menu
text: Last night at Carnegie Hall, a symphony of plates designed by culinary heavyweights filled the bellies — and emptied the pockets — of supporters of the Museum of Food and Drink (MOFAD). In its effort to raise $25 million towards a brick-and-mortar exhibition space in New York, where visitors will be able to eat their way through each exhibition, the organization held its second annual spring benefit (hosted by Questlove and sponsored by T Magazine). The below slideshow of the artful dinner doubles as a road map of what’s to come from from MOFAD: Each of the eight courses was inspired by a forthcoming exhibition.

headline: How To | Make a Thai Chili Cocktail
text: Nico de Soto demonstrates how to make a frothy, egg-based drink off his menu for Mace, a new East Village bar that celebrates spices.

headline: Review: Alex Katz at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise
text: Among the more moving art experiences is seeing a painter excel late in life. Alex Katz, 87, is well known for landscapes and portraits that combine direct perception; wet-on-wet speed-painting and scale; and a distinct merging of Pop Art, abstraction and the plein-air tradition. But now he is having one of the best gallery exhibitions of his career, a display of landscape paintings — lately his surest work — that while seeming to modulate his familiar style have a new, more emotional resonance.

headline: Review: Rosy Keyser, ‘‘The Hell Bitch’
text: ROSY KEYSER

headline: Review: Arthur Ou at Brennan & Griffin
text: In the preface to his “Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus,” from 1921, the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein writes, “Perhaps this book will be understood only by someone who has himself already had the thoughts that are expressed in it — or at least similar thoughts.” The same might be said of Arthur Ou’s current exhibition, which features 14 black-and-white images of contemporary photographers reading passages from the “Tractatus.”

headline: Secret Service Arrests Man After Drone Flies Near White House
text: WASHINGTON — The Secret Service arrested a man who was flying a small drone less than a block from the White House on Thursday afternoon, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Review: Andrew Lord, “at sunset, with snow falling, by starlight”
text: At once bracingly ugly and sensuously beautiful, the recent ceramic sculptures by the British artist Andrew Lord look as if they’d been made by a clumsy but aesthetically sensitive giant. Displayed on three white tables are pitchers in the form of human heads with handles, variously shaped vases and constructions resembling maquettes for fountains populated by little nude female figures. Each retains the marks of its vigorous manual formation in the gouging, impressing and squeezing of the clay. They are glazed in Abstract Expressionist style with the colors brushed, poured and drizzled, creating lively marriages of sculptural form and painterly surface.

headline: NATO Officials Sing ‘We Are the World’ at Summit in Turkey
text: In a scene captured on video by a Turkish news agency, a group of NATO foreign ministers and European officials performed a rousing, after-dinner version of “We Are the World,” the 1985 charity single, after a summit meeting in the resort town of Antalya on Wednesday.

headline: Aaron Douglas Paintings Go to the Met and the National Gallery
text: For many American museums, the Harlem Renaissance painter Aaron Douglas (1898-1979) is an almost Vermeer-like figure, whose shadowy, graphically powerful depictions of African-American themes appear so rarely on the market that when canvases surface, curators pounce. And that is exactly what the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the National Gallery of Art in Washington did recently. Each institution has acquired one of his major paintings, which were sold by a private collector who had purchased them from Douglas himself the year before his death.

headline: The Tyranny of Constant Contact
text: Everything I know about the Internet, I learned from my 87-year-old mother.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand, Burundi and Elsewhere
text: Thailand, Iraq and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Rdio Introduces a Cheaper Limited Subscription for Music Streaming
text: In the latest volley in the music world’s digital price war, Rdio, which competes with both Spotify and Pandora, has introduced a limited subscription version at $4 a month — significantly lower than the industry’s $10 default price.

headline: ISIS Releases a Recording It Says Was Made by Its Leader
text: Amid reports that its reclusive leader had been injured and possibly incapacitated, the Islamic State terrorist group released an audio statement on Thursday that it said was from the man himself, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

headline: May 14, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Follow Lens on Facebook and Twitter.

headline: John Flanagan Trips Over a Climate Issue
text: A day after John Flanagan moved into his powerful new job as leader of New York State Senate, he quickly made news. It was not about his predecessor, State Senator Dean Skelos, the latest Albany politician to be arrested for corruption.  Nor was it about taxes or education or his relations with the mayor and governor.

headline: Hillary Clinton Makes First Visit to Brooklyn Since Announcing Campaign
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday made her first trip to Brooklyn since she joined the presidential race a month ago, visiting her headquarters and taking an unannounced stroll in Brooklyn Heights.

headline: Cannes
text: The best looks from Cannes.

headline: The Garden Is Rocking. Imagine That, Knicks Fans.
text: A dejected Ted Leonsis walked into the freight elevator at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, minutes after his Washington Capitals had been eliminated from the N.H.L. playoffs on an overtime goal by the Rangers.

headline: Beer Week in Paris
text: In celebration of the growing craft beer movement in Paris, the city will play host to the second annual Beer Week from May 22 through May 31.

headline: Amtrak Says Shortfalls and Rules Delayed Its Safety System
text: WASHINGTON — The Amtrak train that derailed in Philadelphia on Tuesday night was equipped with an automatic speed control system that officials say could have prevented the wreck, which killed eight passengers and injured hundreds. But the system, which was tantalizingly close to being operational, was delayed by budgetary shortfalls, technical hurdles and bureaucratic rules, officials said Thursday.

headline: Tiny Macedonia Confronts a Supersize Scandal
text: SKOPJE, Macedonia — An almost surreal scandal involving hundreds of thousands of secretly recorded conversations caught top government officials discussing everything from rigging votes to covering up killings.

headline: Roy Andersson’s Movies at the Museum of Arts and Design
text: You’d probably recognize the work of Roy Andersson even if you haven’t seen his films. His 1970s ads for a Swedish insurance company are quaint classics. In a typical example, a man gets on a pay phone to buy a car policy, while in the background a falling tree destroys the vehicle in question. The mishaps are good for a chuckle, but from these humble origins, Mr. Andersson has gone on to make some of the most elaborate comedic features since the heydays of Jacques Tati and Jerry Lewis.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: Two articles in this series last year, by the author Karen Abbott, copied specific language and passages from several books and papers. In most of these instances, the writer cited the sources in the article’s endnotes. However, copying language from other sources without proper attribution is a violation of Times policy.

headline: Afghans Look Back at Karzai Presidency With Surprising Fondness
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Just seven months after Hamid Karzai stepped down from the Afghan presidency, leaving a tattered relationship with the Americans, a battered economy and worsening security, Afghanistan already seems to be awash with nostalgia for the former president.

headline: Travelers Struggle to Change Plans After Amtrak Derailment
text: A major stretch of rail line remained shut Thursday after Tuesday night’s deadly Amtrak derailment, forcing thousands of commuters to adjust travel plans and generally muddle through an abrupt suspension of train service. The derailment in Philadelphia killed eight people and injured more than 200.

headline: Is Your Child Your Excuse to Buy an Apple Watch?
text: The Apple Watch does exactly what I wanted it to do — but it’s not the killer app for parents. Yet.

headline: Review: Zanele Muholi, a Visual Activist, Presents ‘Isibonelo/Evidence’
text: “Zanele Muholi: Isibonelo/Evidence,” an exhibition of 87 works at the Brooklyn Museum by a South African artist, ends with a celebration. But it begins on a much darker note.

headline: Going Back to the Future for ‘Tomorrowland,’ From Disney
text: Nothing screams bright, shiny future quite like a jetpack. In the film “Tomorrowland,” when Casey Newton (Britt Robertson) enters the gleaming utopia of the film’s title, it’s one of the first things she sees. If you exit a time machine and spot a jetpack, you know you haven’t landed in some postapocalyptic dump. No, you’ve probably arrived in a hope-filled future like the ones promised us in the 1950s, when space colonies were just around the corner and the atom was our friend.

headline: Johnny Depp’s Dogs Face Deportation or Death in Australia
text: Capt. Jack Sparrow has outsmarted Hector Barbossa, Davy Jones, Blackbeard and Lord Cutler Beckett. But he may have met his match with Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce of Australia.

headline: Odd, Old Days in Times Square
text: Andrew Savulich’s photos of 1980’s New York are quirky and off-kilter, like the city itself was before became a sanitized tourist mecca.

headline: Review: Cats Paying Dues Tap and Sing, Don’t Meow
text: The founder and director of an organization called Cats Paying Dues, Andrew Nemr says he encounters a lot of confusion about that name. No, his group isn’t some feline labor union or animal act. It’s a troupe of young tap dancers — “cats” is old jazz slang for hip musicians — and the dues are a kind of apprenticeship. Mr. Nemr wants to pass on some of the knowledge and opportunities he received from mentors like Jimmy Slyde, Gregory Hines and Savion Glover. Cats Paying Dues is a company of hoofers in that jazz tradition.

headline: Review: St. Thomas Choir and Concert Royal Perform Handel
text: If mere mischief can stir boys’ souls and imaginations, what effect might something on the scale of biblical plagues have? You didn’t have to wonder on Wednesday evening, when the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys and the period band Concert Royal gave a rousing performance of Handel’s great oratorio “Israel in Egypt” at St. Thomas Church in Manhattan.

headline: Model Ink
text: Tattoos on and off the runway

headline: Review: Faith No More, Reunited and Reclaiming Its Spot
text: Single-minded sincerity isn’t for everyone. Faith No More, which is about to release “Sol Invictus” (Ipecac), its first new studio album since 1997, has always trafficked in more contradictory impulses, and they were all on display when the reunited band played the first of two sold-out shows at Webster Hall on Wednesday night. The band members (and most of their equipment) were dressed in white and surrounded by bouquets of flowers, while the music was decidedly less angelic.

headline: Two Takes on ‘Imitation of Life’: Exploitation in Eastmancolor
text: “I would have made the picture just for the title,” Douglas Sirk said of his last Hollywood production, “Imitation of Life” (1959). But, newly released on Blu-ray by Universal, along with its original version, directed in 1934 by John M. Stahl, the movie is far more than an evocative turn of phrase.

headline: U.S. Introduces New DNA Standard for Ensuring Accuracy of Genetic Tests
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government opened the door to a new era of genetic medicine on Thursday by introducing a standard way to ensure the accuracy of DNA tests used to tailor treatments for individual patients.

headline: Mark Hogancamp, the Artist as (Imagined) War Hero
text: In Mark Hogancamp’s other life, he is a World War II fighter pilot and the owner of a clubby bar in Belgium, where all manner of international adventurers and baddies congregate. He has an adoring and courageous wife, Anna, and the flirtations of a minx in fishnets, Deja. With the chiseled visage of a Hollywood star, Captain Mark is epically cool.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for May 15-21
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Grateful Dead Fans Replace VW Vans With Jets and the Ritz-Carlton
text: Twenty-seven years ago, Adam Cott and a bunch of his buddies climbed into his 1974 white Opel station wagon, which he had bought from a friend of his father’s for $100, and drove from New Rochelle to Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to take in a Grateful Dead show.

headline: Classical & Opera Listings for May 15-21
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Pitch Perfect 2,’ With Anna Kendrick and More Fat Amy
text: At one point in “Pitch Perfect 2,” for no especially compelling narrative reason, the Barden Bellas, an all-girl a cappella group at a fictional Georgia college, find their way to an underground sing-off hosted by a pajama-clad harmony geek played by David Cross. The other contestants include the Treblemakers, the Bellas’ male counterparts; a highly disciplined German vocal ensemble and some Green Bay Packers. It’s a single-elimination contest with strict rules, and the first category is Songs About Butts.

headline: Theater Listings for May 15-21
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Rick Santorum Says He’s Baffled by Jeb Bush on Iraq
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz — Rick Santorum, the former senator from Pennsylvania who delivered a surprisingly strong performance in the 2012 presidential campaign and may run again in 2016, said Thursday he was baffled by Jeb Bush’s handling this week of a question about the 2003 war in Iraq.

headline: Cubs Rally to Complete 4-Game Sweep of Mets
text: Three weeks ago, Matt Harvey shut down the Yankees on a Saturday afternoon in the Bronx in a game that left the Mets with a 14-4 record and a growing sense that they were becoming the dominant force in New York baseball.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for May 15-21
text: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: In ‘Heartbreak,’ Talk Is Complicated
text: In Ariel Stess’s “Heartbreak” at the Bushwick Starr, a father offers his lovelorn daughter relationship advice. “Have a team-pardner-person,” he says. (Odd pronunciations and spellings are a stylistic hallmark of the playwright’s.) “Support-pardner-person. Listen-pardner-person. Laugh-pardner-person. Adjust-pardner-person. Person-person stuff, pardner-person stuff. Pardner stuff. Be with one yeah.”

headline: Review: John Patitucci Takes His Electric Bass to the Iridium
text: Deep undertow and dazzling technique share a home in the bass playing of John Patitucci, whose prominence as a sideman goes back 30 years. But they aren’t always peaceable cohabitants, or the easiest to bend toward a common cause. Mr. Patitucci proved that point in an otherwise rousing first set at the Iridium on Wednesday night.

headline: Fashion Bonanza for British Designer Patrick Grant
text: Of all the major fashion week cities for men’s wear — New York, London, Milan and Paris — London may have a claim to be the most flexible.

headline: Frieze Art Fair at Randalls Island Park Offers a Bit of Everything
text: With 198 commercial dealers and three nonprofit galleries displaying all kinds of modern and contemporary art under its white, quarter-mile-long tent, the fourth annual New York edition of the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island is a lot for even two critics to cover, but we gave it our best effort. This year offered more opportunities for visitors to participate in specific artworks, and circled back to the careers of overlooked women artists from earlier periods. Here are some things that caught our eyes.

headline: Review: In ‘Animals,’ a Couple in Love With Heroin
text: Every so often, an image in “Animals” will underline the implication of the title: that Jude and Bobbie, the drug addicts whose lives occupy the film’s attention, lead a primal, almost bestial existence. Looking at predatory cats or beluga whales (on television and at the zoos and aquariums of Chicago, where “Animals” was shot), you are invited to notice parallels to the couple’s behavior: their moments of rest and tenderness, their fights and flights, their raw, ferocious need.

headline: Review: At NADA Art Fair, Collecting for Pleasure, Not Status
text: If you like your art fairs of manageable size and relaxed mood, as well as free, with a more-than-respectable level of quality, the fair of the New Art Dealers Alliance, or NADA, is for you. Especially if you don’t have, oh, $179 million, give or take several zeros, to toss around. And also if you thrill to the idea of simply taking art home in a large shopping bag and starting to live with it immediately.

headline: Spare Times for May 15-21
text: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

text: Movies

headline: Benghazi Panel Wants Documents Before Hillary Clinton Testifies
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the House committee investigating the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, said on Thursday that he would not call Hillary Rodham Clinton to testify until the State Department turned over a trove of documents about the episode.

headline: Changing Course, Russia Will Sell Rubles Instead of Buying
text: MOSCOW — The Russian economy is sliding into a recession. Consumers are retreating. Corporate profits are suffering.

headline: 2015’s Most Memorable (Sartorial and Experiential) Exhibitions at Frieze New York
text: The G-force of the global art world ratchets ever upward this year, as Biennale peepers depart Venice en masse and spin around the world to New York for the Frieze Art Fair on Randall’s Island, which opens to the public today. Yesterday, VIPs toured the fair to take stock of offerings by nearly 200 contemporary art galleries from around the world, brought together by the fair’s new director, Victoria Siddall, and its new artistic director for the Americas and Asia, Abby Bangser.

headline: First Draft Focus: Reassuring Persian Gulf Allies
text: President Obama with representatives from the six Arab nations in the Gulf Cooperation Council, at a summit meeting Thursday at Camp David in Maryland.

headline: Pointed Fanfare Over the Year of la Femme at Cannes
text: CANNES, France — Vive les femmes, bébé! The Cannes Film Festival is legendary for the beautiful women who pass across its big, bright screens and down its magic red carpet. This year, though, the festival is also grandly making conspicuous room for women of all kinds, including those rarely deemed good enough to compete for the Palme d’Or: directors. It reserved its opening night slot for Emmanuelle Bercot, touting her film “La Tête Haute” as the first from a female director to be so honored. Diane Kurys had been there, done that back in 1987 with “A Man in Love” — but no matter.

headline: Review: ‘The Edge Becomes the Center’ Explores the Rubble of Rebuilding
text: “Thrive, cities,” Walt Whitman wrote in “Crossing the Brooklyn Ferry,” one of his great love songs to urban life. “Expand” but “Keep your places.”

text: ‘The Big Family Quiz Thing’

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties are one-bedrooms located in Tudor City, Midtown East and Clinton Hill.

headline: For Amanda Green, a Father’s Legacy in Her Lyrics
text: In “The Legacy,” an 11 o’clock number from the 1978 Broadway musical “On the Twentieth Century,” the egomaniacal producer Oscar Jaffee is at the end of his theatrical rope. Fearing financial ruin, he whips out a gun, announces he’s going to kill himself and offers to bequeath his collection of theater memorabilia to his henchmen:

headline: ISIS Advance in Syria Endangers Ancient Ruins at Palmyra
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamic State militants advanced to the outskirts of the Syrian town of Palmyra on Thursday, putting the extremist group within striking distance of some of the world’s most magnificent antiquities.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s homes include a six-bedroom in Chappaqua, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn.

headline: Review: ‘Good Kill’ Stars Ethan Hawke Fighting Enemies Half a World Away
text: Disregard the arguments for and against drone warfare advanced in “Good Kill,” and the movie still makes a persuasive case that our blind infatuation with all-powerful technology is stripping us of our humanity.

headline: Review: In ‘I’ll See You in My Dreams,’ Blythe Danner Seeks Fulfillment
text: To the lengthening list of well-mannered films aimed at moviegoers who have reached an age when, to quote Shakespeare, “the heyday in the blood is tame,” add “I’ll See You in My Dreams,” a modest, quietly touching portrait of an older woman radiantly embodied by Blythe Danner. Her character, Carol, widowed for two decades, is a nice, sensible woman who lives alone in a comfortable Southern California house with her ailing dog, Hazel. When, near the beginning of the movie, she has to have the animal put down, she is briefly grief-stricken.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, May 17 to 23, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra’s Cuba Trip Puts It at the Cultural Vanguard
text: HAVANA — They shimmied with dancers on stilts who greeted them in this old city, where book stalls sell comic-book retellings of the Cuban Revolution. Conservatory students welcomed them with flowers and chamber music. And when a band serenaded them at dinner, a few even got up and cha-chaed.

headline: Things to Do in Westchester, May 17 to 23, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Slow West,’ a Wry Twist on Classic Frontier Fables
text: The surreal frontier fable “Slow West,” written and directed by John Maclean (“Man on a Motorcycle”), is an absurdist deconstruction of classic Hollywood westerns whose 21st-century view of frontier mythology is as sardonic as that of the Coen brothers.

text: When New York City planners unveiled maps charting a 73-block area in the Bronx to be developed with housing, they called it “Cromwell-Jerome.”

headline: Blackstone Buys Minority Stake in Hedge Fund Magnetar Capital
text: The Blackstone Group is taking a minority stake in Magnetar Capital, the $13.6 billion hedge fund run by the former Citadel trader Alec Litowitz.

text: Home for the two Broadway actors is a Manhattan building that has known celebrity, including Cecil B. DeMille and Barack Obama.

headline: Review: ‘Bessie,’ on HBO, Stars Queen Latifah as Blues Singer Bessie Smith
text: “Bessie” is about a blues singer, but what the movie could really use is more soul.

text: In the days since an interview with Fox News, Mr. Bush, the former Florida governor, has sought to clarify his position on the invasion of Iraq.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: No Charges for Engineer in 2013 Fatal Metro-North Derailment
text: The Bronx district attorney’s office said on Thursday that it would not file charges against the engineer who fell asleep on a Metro-North Railroad train in 2013, causing the train to hurtle off the rails in an accident that left four people dead.

headline: Beloved Writing Instruments
text: A closer look at “The Secret Life of the Pencil,” a new exhibition.
