headline: Review: ‘Where Hope Grows,’ a Baseball Career Lost and Relationships Found
text: Not to be flip, but “Where Hope Grows” has the potential to be a decent inspirational film until God shows up.

headline: SummerStage
text: The music series turns 30.

headline: In a Musical Milestone, All the City’s a Stage
text: WHEN the Central Park Mall began hosting musical performances in the 1860s, only classical was permitted. In the 1920s, with the Naumburg Bandshell’s arrival, collars loosened and the sounds of the day — folk, pop, jazz — trickled in. But only in the last three decades, with the rise of SummerStage, the annual festival of largely free shows presented by the City Parks Foundation, has the tradition of live music in the city’s public spaces been truly cemented — and gleefully trampled on.

headline: Summer Theater Festivals: From the Fringes to Center Stage
text: AMERICAN PLAYERS THEATER

headline: Exclusive | 50 Central Park South
text: A two-bedroom condominium on the 33rd floor of the Ritz Carlton Hotel is poised to enter the market at $50 million.

headline: Review: ‘Our Man in Tehran’ Recounts Iran Hostage Crisis Escape
text: It made a darn good Hollywood movie, and the story of how the Canadian ambassador and others helped six American Embassy workers escape Iran in 1980 also makes a pretty watchable documentary. It’s called “Our Man in Tehran,” and if it doesn’t have the slickness of Ben Affleck’s Oscar-winning version of events, “Argo,” it can claim authenticity. There’s nothing like hearing a harrowing tale from the people who lived it.

headline: A Debate Over How Long Democracy Can Wage Battles in Shadows
text: WASHINGTON — When the House voted this week to end and replace the National Security Agency’s once-secret program that collects Americans’ phone records in bulk, it was both an ordinary act of government and a striking exception to post-9/11 national security policy making.

headline: In California Budget Plan, Brown Wins Deal on Tuition Freeze for In-State Students
text: LOS ANGELES — Ending a standoff over whether tuition at the University of California schools would rise, Gov. Jerry Brown said Thursday that he would send millions more dollars to the university system than he had proposed earlier this year, in exchange for a tuition freeze for in-state students in the 10-campus system.

headline: Review: In ‘Know How,’ Teenagers Portray Their Plight in Foster Care
text: Written and acted by young men and women who grew up in New York City’s foster care system, “Know How” tours the mean streets of a rough urban adolescence rarely acknowledged. Originally a musical presented by the nonprofit Possibility Project, the film weaves together tales of five teenagers striving for stability in turbulent settings.

headline: Tony Ayala Jr., Boxer Convicted of Rape, Dies at 52
text: Tony Ayala Jr., a fierce, gifted and troubled fighter who was a rising middleweight contender before a rape conviction sent him to prison, was found dead on Tuesday at his family’s boxing gym in San Antonio. He was 52.

headline: An Airline Investment in Uruguay Becomes a Catch-22
text: It might have been the volcano.

headline: Review: ‘Dark Star’ Peers Into H. R. Giger’s Creative World
text: If you crossed “The Addams Family” with an episode of “Hoarders,” you might come up with something like the documentary “Dark Star: H. R. Giger’s World.” A deferentially admiring visit with the Swiss surrealist artist whose beastie design for Ridley Scott’s “Alien” (1979) earned him Hollywood renown, this disordered portrait seems heavily influenced by its equally jumbled setting.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Review: ‘L for Leisure,’ Vignettes of Graduate Students on Vacation
text: Divided into segments with postcard-ready titles (“Thanksgiving, 1992, Beaumont, TX”; “Summer Break, 1993, Baja, Mexico”), “L for Leisure,” set in the early 1990s, follows graduate students on vacations around the world. The vignettes offer ample opportunities to watch ostensibly smart people behaving stupidly. The conceit, to paraphrase one character, is that grad school is for people who never moved on from high school.

headline: Eight Amtrak Passengers’ Deaths Echo Across the Region and the World
text: Boarding the train in Washington, a commercial real estate broker texted her mother: she was safely in her seat, she said, on her way home to Manhattan. A businessman usually flew for work, but for this quick trip the train seemed more convenient. A Wells Fargo executive had dropped everything for his uncle’s funeral, but had to return to his job. An Italian olive oil and wine salesman preferred to fly, but jumped on Amtrak when his flight arrangements fell through.

headline: Iraqi Who Worked for the U.S. Military Is Arrested in Texas in Link to Islamic State
text: WASHINGTON — An Iraqi man who worked as a translator for the American military before moving to the United States in 2009 was arrested on Thursday in Texas by F.B.I. agents who say he pledged allegiance to the leader of the Islamic State last year and misled them about his travels to Syria.

headline: Review: ‘The Connection,’ a Crime Thriller Retold From a Gallic Perspective
text: So French, and so 1975, the drug-running drama “The Connection” is a riot of cleft chins and tight pants, manicured sideburns and precariously buttoned shirts. Amid these distractions, separating cops from criminals would be challenging enough, even if the proceedings were not 135 minutes long and peppered with look-alikes.

headline: Understanding Southeast Asia’s Migrant Crisis
text: About 25,000 migrants left Myanmar and Bangladesh on rickety smugglers’ boats in the first three months of 2015, according to a United Nations estimate.

headline: Missouri House Speaker Quits Over Texts
text: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — John Diehl, Missouri’s State House speaker, said Thursday that he would resign, one day after the revelation of sexually suggestive text messages that he exchanged with a 19-year-old legislative intern.

headline: Jokes Aside, David Letterman Leaves Behind a Costlier Neighborhood
text: When the “Late Show” first started taping at the Ed Sullivan Theater in Midtown Manhattan in September 1993, the area was “very fringy,” said Rupert Jee, an owner of the Hello Deli on West 53rd Street, around the corner from the theater entrance and next to the stage door and the corporate offices.

headline: Review: ‘In the Name of My Daughter,’ a Family-Business Scandal
text: André Téchiné’s latest film, “In the Name of My Daughter,” a bit like his “The Girl on the Train,” centers on a young woman who hurls herself into an obsessive pursuit, heedless of the consequences as she fulfills a deeper need. Both are also dramas based on true stories, yet Mr. Téchiné uses this fodder not as a fount of titillating scandal but as a chance to portray mysterious urges and passions, which come to feel slightly less mysterious the closer we get.

headline: ‘Every Secret Thing,’ an Unsettling Story of When Babies Go Missing
text: Nothing is creepier than creepy children and teenagers, and the ones in “Every Secret Thing” are first-rate examples. The story may be fictional — it’s based on a Laura Lippman novel — but by the end of this movie you’ll be warier than ever of the local youngsters.

headline: Defying U.S., Colombia Halts Aerial Spraying of Crops Used to Make Cocaine
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The government of Colombia on Thursday night rejected a major tool in the American-backed antidrug campaign — ordering a halt to the aerial spraying of the country’s vast illegal plantings of coca, the crop used to make cocaine, citing concerns that the spray causes cancer.

headline: Duke Energy Agrees to Pay $102 Million for Breaches
text: Duke Energy, the nation’s largest utility corporation, pleaded guilty on Thursday to criminal violations of the federal Clean Water Act for the discharge of coal ash, a potentially toxic waste product, and for a failure to properly maintain equipment at a number of power plants in its home state of North Carolina. The company also agreed to pay $102 million in fines and environmental fees.

headline: Netanyahu’s Coalition Gets Rocky Start With Discontent Over Leadership Posts
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s new government was sworn in on Thursday night after a stormy Parliament session that reflected much broader discontent over the political process that gave rise to the coalition dominated by right-wing and religious parties.

headline: Review: ‘Childless,’ a Film of Connected Monologues, Stars Joe Mantegna
text: There’s solid acting in “Childless,” but mostly there are words — torrents of them.

headline: Witness Accounts in Midtown Hammer Attack Show the Power of False Memory
text: The real world of our memory is made of bits of true facts, surrounded by holes that we Spackle over with guesses and beliefs and crowd-sourced rumors. On the dot of 10 on Wednesday morning, Anthony O’Grady, 26, stood in front of a Dunkin’ Donuts on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan. He heard a ruckus, some shouts, then saw a police officer chase a man into the street and shoot him down in the middle of the avenue.

headline: Review: ‘Echoes of War’ Follows a Confederate Soldier Home
text: If you haven’t had your dose of dourness for the day, “Echoes of War” will provide it in well-acted abundance. It’s a gloomy, somewhat underwritten story of two families just after the Civil War, an exploration of the kind of disruption that lingers after fighting on the battlefield is over.

headline: Barbaro’s Owners Are Back for Another Preakness
text: BALTIMORE — When Gretchen and Roy Jackson settled into their seats to watch the Preakness Stakes on May 20, 2006, they expected to see Barbaro, the brilliant Kentucky Derby champion they bred and owned, take another step toward a Triple Crown that many fans thought was inevitable.

headline: Democrats Balk at Sparing Only Military Spending From Mandated Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Key Democrats on Thursday said they opposed Republican efforts to circumvent broad, congressionally mandated cuts in military spending as lawmakers considered the annual Pentagon budget.

headline: This Week’s Movies | May 15, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Mad Max: Fury Road,” “Pitch Perfect 2” and “I’ll See You In My Dreams.”

headline: Yemen: Al Qaeda Outlaws a Stimulant
text: Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen, which seized control over the port of Al Mukalla nearly a month ago, has barred residents from trading or chewing khat, the leafy green stimulant that has been a habit in that country for centuries, local Yemeni journalists reported Thursday. Armed men were seen confiscating bundles of khat, burning them in bonfires and inspecting the markets for violators. At least five trucks loaded with khat were reported to have been stopped from entering Al Mukalla. The militant group, known as Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, was able to exploit the chaos caused by airstrikes by Saudi Arabia against Houthi rebels to occupy Al Mukalla on April 16. The Houthis, who have received support from Iran, occupied the capital and ousted the president in recent months. The Saudis and Houthis on Thursday accused each other of violating a truce that began Tuesday as a way to provide an opportunity for aid groups to provide food, fuel and medicine to Yemen’s civilians.

headline: Audree Norton, Who Paved Way for Deaf Actors, Dies at 88
text: Audree Norton, a deaf actress whose fight to be cast on a television show in the late 1970s effectively ended her career in the medium but greatly helped the careers of deaf actors who followed her, died on April 22 at her home in Fremont, Calif. She was 88.

headline: Romney vs. Holyfield: ‘I’m Staying Far Away From His Ears’
text: Friday night in Utah — not exactly Las Vegas — the former Republican heavyweight Mitt Romney will face the former heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield in a charity boxing match. The bout will benefit CharityVision, an organization that provides sight-restoration surgery for people in very poor countries around the world. It will not benefit the dignity of Mitt Romney.

headline: Gaza: Dozens Injured at Hamas Camp
text: A huge explosion at a training camp for Hamas militants in northern Gaza wounded more than 60 people, including women and children, on Thursday night, Hamas officials said. The military wing of Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, said in a statement that the blast was caused by an Israeli missile left over from the war last summer. But Iyad al-Buzom, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry in Gaza, described it in a Facebook post more vaguely as an “internal explosion.” Witnesses said the blast, in Beit Lahiya, damaged nearby houses and caused power failures in the area.

headline: Goodell Says He Will Hear Brady Appeal
text: Tom Brady formally appealed his four-game suspension on Thursday for his reported role in the deflation of footballs before the A.F.C. championship game in January against the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: Obama Reviews Talks With Gulf Leaders
text: President Obama recapped a range of topics he discussed with Persian Gulf leaders at Camp David, including the situations in Syria and Yemen and nuclear talks with Iran.

headline: Massachusetts: Jurors Continue Work in Marathon Bombing Case
text: Jurors in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man convicted in the Boston Marathon bombing, on Thursday spent their first full day considering whether he should be put to death or given a life sentence for killing three people and wounding more than 260. The jurors, who had deliberated for less than an hour on Wednesday, have been given a 24-page verdict form and have been instructed to weigh a variety of factors. On Thursday, they passed the court questions about the idea of “aiding and abetting,” and about how they should fill out the verdict form. Mr. Tsarnaev was convicted of 17 counts that carry a maximum sentence of the death penalty; to impose it, the jury must unanimously agree it is appropriate on at least one of the counts.

headline: Ruling in Royalty Case Gives BMI a Victory Against Pandora
text: Last week, Pandora Media won two battles in its long-running war against the music industry, but on Thursday, it lost one — this time over how much it should pay the licensing agency BMI in royalties.

headline: Patrick Kane’s Quick Return and Healthy Scoring Touch Provide a Salve for a City
text: CHICAGO — At practice a couple of weeks into his rehabilitation of a broken collarbone, Chicago Blackhawks wing Patrick Kane knew he was ahead of schedule. He had only just resumed skating, which he could do without pain, and he was juggling the puck on his stick. He was still under strict medical orders not to shoot, but he could not help himself: He glided down the ice and snapped off a wrist shot toward the net. Still no pain.

headline: Harry Potter’s One-Time Crush
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I had a tough time getting started with this puzzle by David Phillips, largely because of the northwest. Mr. Phillips tells us about the construction of this puzzle below, so I’ll just say that I didn’t know INA CLAIRE or K.C. JONES, and was not able to recall DARK ANGEL, so that sector remained fairly empty for a long time.

headline: New York Police Dept. Questioning of Protesters Was Improper, Rights Lawyers Tell Commissioner
text: Five civil rights lawyers have sent a letter to Police Commissioner William J. Bratton saying that the recent questioning of protesters by detectives violated a federal consent decree and was not conducted by the proper New York Police Department division.

headline: When News Comes Knocking: Securing Exclusive Photos of a Police Shooting
text: Jessie Schwartz is a photo editor on the Metro desk.

headline: Pete Rose Comes Out Swinging as an Analyst
text: Pete Rose’s first three days as a studio analyst for Fox Sports 1 this week suggests that he might be terrific — even if he’s not getting dirty or bowling over catchers.

headline: Bank of America Merrill Lynch Opens Private Fund-Raising Arm for Start-Ups
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has set up a group to help companies raise money through private fund-raising, the investment bank announced in an internal memorandum on Thursday.

headline: New York Senate Votes for Bill Allowing Dogs in Outdoor Dining Areas
text: A brush of terrier fur against a patron’s open toes as she sips her morning coffee. A nudge from a rangy German shepherd beneath an outdoor table piled high with croissants. Paws scraping against the sidewalk in pursuit of dropped bits of omelet.

headline: Marine Veteran Held in Iranian Prison Ends Hunger Strike at Family’s Request
text: Amir Hekmati, the Marine veteran who is the longest-held American prisoner in Iran, reluctantly ended his second hunger strike this past weekend after relatives — particularly his terminally ill father — beseeched him to stop, Mr. Hekmati’s sister said Thursday.

headline: David Baril Is Charged With Assault in Manhattan Hammer Attacks
text: The police said on Thursday that they had filed assault charges against David Baril, who was suspected of wielding a hammer in a series of attacks before he was shot by an officer in Manhattan on Wednesday.

headline: Murray Heads to Paris With 2 New Assets: Winning Streak and Belief
text: ROME — Given that clay has been dominated by a single player for the last decade in the men’s game, it is not surprising that a top player is going into the French Open undefeated on the surface this season.

headline: Stan Cornyn, Creative Record Executive, Is Dead at 81
text: Stan Cornyn, an offbeat recording industry executive known both for his unusual promotions and for his album notes, two of which won Grammy Awards, died on Monday at his home in Carpinteria, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Yanks Lose Third Straight as Offense, Like Division Lead, Keeps Fading
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Yankees packed their bags and, they hoped, their offense and enough healthy pitchers, and prepared to board a flight late Thursday night to Kansas City, Mo.

headline: LeBron James Helps Cavaliers Coast Past Bulls Into Eastern Finals
text: CHICAGO — LeBron James is 6 feet 8 inches and 250 pounds of rippling muscle and world-class skill, but to the Chicago Bulls he looked like a mountain they could never scale.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I don’t want to be too overdramatic, but if these people aren’t treated and brought to shore soon, we are going to have a boat full of corpses.”

headline: The New Tattoo
text: Full-color illustration has given way to a playfully personal twist on ink.

headline: A French Bartender Spices Things Up Behind the Bar (and on Video)
text: The French bartender Nico de Soto first grew to prominence at the Experimental Cocktail Club — either the Paris, London or New York locations, he’s worked all three (and created the menu for the Manhattan outpost when it opened in 2012). Now in his own bar, Mace, which opened in the East Village at the end of March, de Soto has drawn upon that broad wealth of sensory experience “inspired by food from everywhere,” he says.

headline: In Its Second Year, Sight Unseen Offsite Promises Double the Fun
text: In the five years since its inception, Sight Unseen — the online hub run by the writers and curators Monica Khemsurov (a T contributor) and Jill Singer — has not only documented new currents in the design world, but defined them. (The site can arguably take credit for the Memphis Group revival currently swirling through the scene.) Last year, during New York Design Week, the duo staged the first edition of Sight Unseen Offsite, a 20,000-square-foot showcase for independent talent which, Singer says, “crystallized for everyone what our aesthetic and point of view is.” This week, that vision is all over town: Offsite has a satellite presence at the Collective Design fair, while the main event has returned for an encore at a new space, opening today and conveniently located a stone’s throw from the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Javits Center.

headline: The Nuns Spoke Out, but the Archbishop Listened
text: When 25 leaders of the largest organization of American nuns met for the first time with Archbishop J. Peter Sartain of Seattle in 2012, after the Vatican appointed him to lead an overhaul of their group, they expected conflict.

headline: Word of the Day | rusticate
text: rusticate • \ˈrəs-ti-ˌkat\ • verb

headline: Christie’s and Phillips Have Auctions With Differing Results
text: Toward the end of a week that saw $2 billion worth of art change hands, the question Thursday night was whether buyers in New York would have the energy — and money — to spend still more as Christie’s and Phillips held auctions that overlapped a bit in time.

headline: Match in Argentina Is Suspended After Attack on River Plate Team
text: BUENOS AIRES — Police and soccer officials in Argentina opened investigations on Friday after visiting players in one of the most anticipated matches of the Argentine soccer season the previous night were attacked with an irritant and the game was halted at halftime.

headline: Five Upper East Side Bedrooms for $21 Million
text: A sprawling five-bedroom apartment at the Marquand, a century-old Beaux-Arts Revival building on the Upper East Side that was converted into luxury condominiums two years ago by the HFZ Capital Group, sold for $21,082,866.25 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 11:45 P.M. (Starz Cinema) FOR NO GOOD REASON (2014) “I really thought what I would do, if I ever learned to draw properly, was I would try to change the world,” the British artist Ralph Steadman explains in Charlie Paul’s documentary about him. So in 1970, Mr. Steadman jetted to New York, where he planned to take a thousand photographs that would inspire the illustrations he couldn’t seem to get quite right. “There was an arrogance missing, there was a wildness missing, there was a rawness missing,” he says of that early work. “It lacked that bite I needed, that real ferocious bite, the thing that would make it noticeable.” Then he received instructions to meet Hunter S. Thompson, not long after his infiltration of the Hells Angels. The weekend became a vicious, drunken nightmare, and he and Thompson went to pieces. Thus, gonzo journalism — in which the writer (and in this decadent collaboration, the illustrator) becomes the story — was born. What would Thompson’s “Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas” be without Mr. Steadman’s ink-speckled and splotched drawings, Mr. Steadman argues. “There is a formal discipline and thematic coherence to Mr. Steadman’s images that his friend’s writing sometimes lacked,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Steadman has frequently aimed to shock, and almost always with good reason.”

headline: B. B. King, Defining Bluesman for Generations, Dies at 89
text: B. B. King, whose world-weary voice and wailing guitar lifted him from the cotton fields of Mississippi to a global stage and the apex of American blues, died on Thursday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 89.

headline: Test Yourself | High Fashion at the Mall
text: Below are several paragraphs from the May 7 article “High-End Culture Comes to Shopping Malls.”

headline: Corrections: May 15, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Anna Kendrick on ‘Pitch Perfect 2’ and Not Trying Too Hard
text: In “Anna Kendrick on ‘Pitch Perfect 2’ and Not Trying Too Hard,” Brooks Barnes profiles the actress.

headline: Missing U.S. Marine Helicopter Is Found in Nepal, Official Says
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — The wreckage of a United States Marine helicopter was found on Friday on a high mountain pass in Nepal, where below-freezing temperatures, raging winds and thunderstorms had made it too dangerous even to recover the bodies.

headline: Odd, Old Days in Times Square
text: Among the denizens of the pre-Disney Times Square was a casually dressed man with unruly white hair sitting in a beat-up Dodge Valiant outside a Howard Johnson’s restaurant. He spent his time listening to a police scanner, which emitted a steady, scratchy stream of reports of gang shootings, car accidents or suicide jumpers.

headline: What Do You Want More From a Career: Happiness or Wealth?
text: A study published this week found that lawyers in public-service jobs who made the least money, like public defenders or Legal Aid attorneys, were more likely to report being happy than lawyers with high-income jobs at corporate law firms. It seems that law students may have to choose between happiness and wealth before starting a career.

headline: After the Amtrak Crash: Preventing Future Derailments
College Sports: That’s Entertainment, Not Education
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kids Who Can’t See Can’t Learn
text: LAST year, I went with a small group of ophthalmologists to a South Bronx middle school to conduct vision exams. One neatly dressed boy had trouble seeing the big E at the top of the chart. He hesitated and made mistakes on the second line, and then put his head down, embarrassed. “I don’t think you can see the chart,” I said.

headline: Jobs in the Inner City
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pope Francis and the Art of Joy
text: In the modern era, Europe has never had fewer practicing Christians. The United States, according to a Pew survey released this week, is trending in the same direction, led by millennials wary of pontifical certainty.

headline: Mentor the Children
End Immigration Detention
text: Of all the malfunctioning parts in the country’s broken-down immigration machinery, probably the most indefensible is the detention system.

headline: The Vatican and the Palestinians
text: The practical effect of the Vatican’s decision to sign a treaty recognizing the state of Palestine is debatable, but it is a symbolic victory for Palestinians who are struggling to keep alive their dream of a Palestinian state, which has been thwarted by the Israeli government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Fraternity of Failure
text: Jeb Bush wants to stop talking about past controversies. And you can see why. He has a lot to stop talking about. But let’s not honor his wish. You can learn a lot by studying recent history, and you can learn even more by watching how politicians respond to that history.

headline: An Invitation to High School Students
One-Week Student Competition | Write a Letter to the Editor, for Publication in the Opinion Section
text: If our recent Student Editorial Contest left you wanting to write more about the issues that matter to you most, here’s your chance.

headline: Modi Calls on China to Rethink Stances That Strain Ties to India
text: HONG KONG — India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, told China’s leaders on Friday that it was up to them to rethink policies that he said had hindered cooperation between the Asian giants.

headline: New Look, British Retailer, to Be Acquired by Brait of South Africa for $1.2 Billion
text: LONDON — Brait, a South African investment firm, said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire a controlling interest in the British retailer New Look Retail Group for 780 million pounds, or about $1.2 billion.

headline: Burundi Government Says It Has Crushed Coup Attempt
text: BUJUMBURA, Burundi — Loyalist police and army officers have crushed an attempted coup in Burundi, the government said Friday. The announcement followed two days of confusion over who controlled the central African country, which has been shaken by weeks of violent protests over the president’s ambitions to stay in office.

headline: Want a Green Card? Invest in Real Estate
text: Like many of her fellow classmates at New York University, Yanchu Zhao has a busy schedule. A college junior, she has a double major in economics and journalism, and juggles classes, an internship and life with roommates in a rental near Herald Square.

headline: From the Quotable Mouths of the Memphis Grizzlies, Straight to Ad-Libbed T-Shirts
text: MEMPHIS — The Western Conference semifinal series between the Memphis Grizzlies and the Golden State Warriors was heating up last week when Tony Allen, the Grizzlies’ hyperkinetic guard, stripped the Warriors’ Klay Thompson of his dribble. In celebration, Allen slapped the court and shouted, for the world to hear: “First-team all-defense! First-team all-defense!”

headline: What You Get When You Blend a Drone and a Gecko
text: There is a wide array of obstacles facing the drone deliveries proposed by Amazon and Google. If the deliveries do happen, however, researchers from the mechanical engineering lab at Stanford University believe they have made a technological leap in the science of the drone’s landing.

headline: Ayelet Shaked, Israel’s New Justice Minister, Shrugs Off Critics in Her Path
text: JERUSALEM — She has been called the Michele Bachmann of Israeli politics, a nod to their shared far-right ideology and striking appearance. She was assigned a bodyguard after a social media post was made to show her wearing a Nazi uniform and accused her of promoting Palestinian genocide. She was belittled by a former minister as the most prominent politician “who could star in a calendar hanging in garages,” prompting even ardent critics to rush to her defense.

headline: Caught in Nepal’s Earthquakes
text: When Daniel Berehulak flew into Kathmandu four days after a 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck Nepal in April, his initial impression was that the damage was not as catastrophic as he had expected. His first days were spent photographing people pulling valuables — televisions and teddy bears and kitchen cupboards — from rubble piles around the city, sometimes carrying them away balanced on their heads. It was a sight that struck him as brave and hopeful.

headline: China Clears Police Officer in Death of Unarmed Man, but Controversy Isn’t Over
text: Once again, the fatal shooting of an unarmed man by a police officer has set off a heated public debate, but this time in China.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: May 15
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from Bryant Park, a funeral of a police officer and an Uzbek birthday party.

headline: Ask Well: Reducing Belly Fat
text: Question:

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Q. and A.: Nicholas R. Lardy on Markets and the State in China
text: China’s biggest companies are still, for the most part, state-owned enterprises, or S.O.E.s. Companies controlled by the Chinese government dominate energy, finance and telecommunications, and they often have better access to capital from state-run banks. But in his latest book, “Markets Over Mao: The Rise of Private Business in China,” the economist Nicholas R. Lardy argues that China’s economic boom has been fueled by private enterprise and policies that have allowed the market to play a greater role.

headline: Artists Respond to B. B. King’s Death on Social Media
text: The pioneering blues singer and guitarist B. B. King, who won over a dozen Grammy Awards and is perhaps best known for the song “The Thrill Is Gone,” died on Thursday in Las Vegas. He was 89.

headline: West Point and the Culinary Institute of America: An Exchange of Experiences
text: We are hard pressed to think of many world-class liberal arts colleges with entire student bodies ambitiously studying and training toward a single profession – and in uniforms that are far from Vassar’s or Columbia’s baseball caps or yoga pants. While the Culinary Institute of America prepares its student chefs for successful careers in hospitality, just across the Hudson River, the United States Military Academy at West Point’s mission is to “educate, train and inspire” its own student body for the profession of arms. The two institutions seem worlds apart, yet conversations over a couple of meals quickly demonstrate otherwise.

headline: Decoding the Enigma of Satoshi Nakamoto and the Birth of Bitcoin
text: It is one of the great mysteries of the digital age.

headline: New York Today: Basking in the Spring Sun
text: Good morning on this temperate Friday.

headline: Bernie Madoff’s Essential Man
text: One morning years ago, an auditor from the firm KPMG paid a visit to Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities’ offices at 885 Third Avenue, the sleek, tubular Midtown office tower known as the Lipstick Building. The auditor informed Frank DiPascali Jr., Madoff’s de facto chief financial officer, that he was conducting due diligence for a major European bank and asked to see a trade ledger — a roster of Madoff’s transaction records — for the investment fund.

headline: How to Fall Asleep
text: “Quality sleep impacts performance profoundly,” says Christopher Winter, a neurologist and sleep consultant to many professional sports teams, including the San Francisco Giants and the Oklahoma City Thunder. Frequent travel across time zones turns their players into what Winter calls “glorified, overpaid shift workers” who are particularly vulnerable to the repercussions of being chronically tired. Winter studied Major League Baseball players and found that 86 percent of those who reported the highest levels of drowsiness were no longer in the league two years later.

headline: ‘The Corn Baby’
text: Poems are made things and, at their best, remake the world for us. The syntax, repetition and alliteration of this poem feel like a kind of bundling – the poet composing the form of the corn baby, sound by sound, word by word. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Flight Paths
text: Displayed on a small plinth in a university museum in the German city Rostock is a famously gruesome exhibit: a stuffed white stork with its long neck pierced by an iron-tipped wooden spear from Central Africa. This unlucky bird survived the attack and flew back to Germany, only to be shot by a hunter in the spring of 1822. Newspaper reports revealed the spear’s distant origin, and the newly christened pfeilstorch, or arrow-stork, was celebrated for solving the puzzle of where German storks spent their winters.

headline: Re: Backed Into a Corner
text: For the May 3 special issue on money, Gideon Lewis-­Kraus told the story of the rise and fall of a Kickstarter company called ZPM Espresso — the “home-­espresso-­machine mega-­failure that came to define the crowdfunding era of specialty coffee tech,” in the words of an aggregator named Sprudge Wire.

headline: Bob Baffert Already Has Only Crown He Seeks: Kentucky Derby’s
text: BALTIMORE — Bob Baffert’s hair remains snowy white, and his eyes still water beneath his ever-present shades. It is a heck of a thing that a horse trainer is allergic to horses. At 62, his mouth moves faster than his legs. Then again, it always has.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Blind Contour Drawing
text: A few years ago, I became unhappy with my drawing style. I had been an enthusiastic doodler since childhood, but my art hadn’t really evolved since then. Every time I sat down to draw, I found myself producing two-­dimensional googly-­eyed cartoon figures (pencils, avocados, dinosaurs, hamburgers, tacos, clouds, whatever) that would raise their tiny stick arms whimsically whenever they needed to speak to one another. It was cutesy and severely limited and — after several decades — excruciatingly boring. I had lost the ability to surprise myself. My visual relationship to the world had atrophied. Occasionally, there were minor coups; a 4-­year-­old would ask me to draw a pirate ship or a dinosaur, then tell me that I was the world’s greatest artist. Eventually, however, they would grow up and change their minds.

headline: Upward Mobility for the World’s Destitute
text: There’s poor, and then there’s ultrapoor. The ultrapoor are almost always women and largely found in Africa, South Asia and to a lesser extent, parts of Latin America. They are most often rural. They work as maids or field laborers, often paid not with wages but in food scraps. They might have just one dress or sari, and must wash a part of it at a time while wearing it, or stay in the river for modesty till it dries.

headline: How Your Hometown Affects Your Chances of Marriage
text: People are less likely to marry if they grow up in certain places, especially liberal ones.

headline: Travel Industry Responds to Rise in Solo Sojourners
text: Vacations have long gone hand-in-hand with company: family bonding, honeymoons, babymoons, bands of oats-sowing college backpackers. Yet today, more and more travelers are going solo — and they’re not who you might expect them to be.

headline: Where to Shop in the Berkshires
text: The town of Great Barrington, nestled in the Berkshires in Massachusetts, has long been a popular weekend destination because of its picturesque setting and proximity to many cultural attractions like the Tanglewood summer music festival. But the area also has a vibrant year-round community of residents, some of them former New Yorkers who have opened a mix of eclectic stores selling everything from housewares to high fashion. Most of the shopping is concentrated on Main Street with a few spots tucked away nearby.

headline: Like Hillary Clinton in ’08, Jeb Bush Is Haunted by Specter of Iraq War
text: WASHINGTON — Eight years after Hillary Rodham Clinton was haunted by her Senate vote to authorize the use of force in Iraq, another leading White House hopeful is struggling with questions about the war.

headline: When Maestros Cry
text: Via Mark Thoma, today in liberal fascism: Apparently I’m part of the liberal speech police, blocking debate on important subjects, because I criticized Alan Greenspan for planning to headline a goldbug conference taking place next to the Fed’s annual Jackson Hole event. And it’s true — I used vicious, undemocratic tactics like calling attention to Greenspan’s record of bad predictions. I even used sarcasm and ridicule. And you know who else used sarcasm and ridicule? Hitler The Piranha Brothers.

headline: Today in Politics: Republicans Head to Iowa to Court Activists
text: Jeb Bush picked a curious week to reveal he would be skipping the Iowa straw poll: just days before he attends a dinner hosted by the straw poll’s sponsor, the Republican Party of Iowa.

headline: Clippers’ Big Collapse Against Rockets Forces a Game 7
text: LOS ANGELES — The confetti was ready to fall from the rafters, like a curtain to the past. The Los Angeles Clippers, finally, were minutes away from overcoming their own history.

headline: Morning Agenda: Hoax Bid for Avon Points to S.E.C. Security Hole
text: HOAX BID FOR AVON POINTS TO S.E.C. SECURITY HOLE | A phantom takeover bid for Avon Products on Thursday highlighted a potential weakness in the federal government’s system for filing securities documents, Matthew Goldstein and David Gelles write in DealBook. A firm calling itself PTG Capital Partners, supposedly a British investment firm, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had offered to buy Avon for $18.75 a share, which caused shares of Avon, which had opened the day’s trading at $6.71, to rise more than $1. The company’s shares closed nearly 6 percent higher at $7.07 even after it was determined that neither PTG Capital nor the firm’s supposed lawyer in the United States existed at the locations given in the regulatory filing and after Avon denied that it had received an offer.

headline: Matisse From Gurlitt Collection Is Returned to Jewish Art Dealer’s Heirs
text: MUNICH — The slide made public in November 2013 showing a painting of a woman wearing a white blouse embroidered with blue, purple and red flowers, with a fan on her lap, was grainy, but its subject was immediately recognizable to Elaine Rosenberg. It showed a priceless Matisse. Her family’s Matisse.

headline: South Korean Leader Voices Alarm at Kim Jong-un’s ‘Reign of Terror’
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s president on Friday warned that the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un’s “extreme reign of terror” and his government’s recent hostilities along the two countries’ disputed maritime border were raising uncertainty on the divided peninsula.

headline: Boat With Hundreds of Migrants From Myanmar Heads Farther Out to Sea
text: LIPE ISLAND, Thailand — A wooden fishing boat carrying hundreds of desperate migrants from Myanmar moved farther out to sea on Friday after the Thai authorities concluded that the passengers wanted to continue their journey, instead of disembarking in Thailand, according to an aid group involved in negotiations over the vessel’s future.

headline: George Stephanopoulos Apologizes to Viewers on Clinton Donations
text: George Stephanopoulos, the ABC News chief news anchor, told “Good Morning America” viewers on Friday that it was a “mistake” for him to donate $75,000 over the last three years to the Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Foundation, and he apologized for not disclosing the contribution.

headline: A ‘Jewish Litmus Test’ Was Unacceptable
text: A Ph.D. candidate at the University of California, Berkeley, David McCleary, wrote to me this week with a complaint about being subjected to what he called “a Jewish litmus test” during a Times interview.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

text: Dear Diary:

text: Singapore

headline: Families Find the Principles That Keep the Business Going
text: PETER GORDON, a member of the family that owns Glenfiddich whisky, has a distinct memory of the workers lined up as he walked into the Scottish distillery in the 1970s. They were waiting for a dram of day-old whisky — the equivalent of a double shot. If they didn’t drink it, they rubbed it into their hands, in the belief that it toughened calluses.

headline: Diane Keaton and Morgan Freeman’s Real Estate Adventure
text: Soon after they married in the mid-1970s, a promising young artist and his schoolteacher wife moved into a rundown two-bedroom apartment on the top floor of a walk-up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. For 40 years, amid canvasses and clutter, it was home sweet home.

headline: B.B. King, Bluesman of Distinction
text: Jon Pareles reflects on the rawness and finesse of B.B. King, whose musical style made him approachable to audiences and propelled him to fame.

headline: Homeland Beckons Immigrants as Retirement Nears
text: THEY came to America from all over the world for many reasons — to make money, to marry, to live in peace. But now, as they face their retirement years, many of these longtime immigrants want to go home.

headline: Chinese Rights Lawyer Detained in 2014 Will Stand Trial
text: HONG KONG — One of China’s best-known human rights lawyers, Pu Zhiqiang, will stand trial in Beijing on charges of inciting ethnic hatred and picking quarrels, prosecutors said on Friday. Their announcement came just over a year after the police detained Mr. Pu, making him one of the most prominent targets of the Chinese Communist Party’s vigorous campaign against dissent.

headline: Daily Report: Unearthing the Enigma of Bitcoin’s Birth
text: It is one of the great mysteries of the digital age.

headline: ISIS Fighters Seize Government Headquarters in Ramadi, Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — In a major setback for the Iraqi government’s efforts to defend its hold on Ramadi, a crucial regional capital, Islamic State militants conquered the city’s government sector on Friday, raising their black flag over the main compound before setting fire to the building, local officials said.

headline: Haruki Murakami’s ‘Strange Library’ and ‘Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage’
text: What’s so beguiling about Haruki Murakami? It’s a question asked by admirers and detractors alike. As with few other authors, the charms of Murakami’s books are difficult to pin down, so completely and gracefully does his work slip past the usual benchmarks of enjoyable literature. His plots are full of interesting incidents, but they build slowly, or not at all, or in a way that’s completely off kilter, rather than following any real discernible arc. Regular readers of Murakami will find him reusing his favorite devices — cats, missing girls, obscure works of music — making them less startling and/or more enduring, depending on one’s point of view. Structurally, his work appears to proceed by instinct rather than by strategy; his use of the third person in “1Q84,” for instance, feels exactly like his vast, samey array of first-person narrators. Murakami’s work brushes up against some grand themes but doesn’t quite tackle them; his best novel, “The Wind‑Up Bird Chronicle,” explores the horrors of World War II, but nobody would describe the book as making a major statement about war. As for his language — well, most of us New York Times readers are receiving Murakami in translation, but even so there’s little to indicate we’re missing some grand linguistics in the original. His language is accessible, plain-spoken, even banal, perhaps purposefully so.

headline: ‘Future Crimes,’ by Marc Goodman
text: There’s a certain type of technology writer who presents himself as a modern-day Paul Revere, breathlessly warning us about all the dangers of our rapidly digitizing world.

headline: Jo Nesbo’s ‘Blood on Snow,’ Read by Patti Smith
text: Meet Olav Johansen, the antihero of Jo Nesbo’s latest thriller, “Blood on Snow.” Olav is a departure from Nesbo’s familiar Harry Hole, the dogged Norwegian police inspector who has selflessly tracked down killers through 10 international best sellers. Olav isn’t a good guy; he’s a bad guy. Sort of.

headline: Toward an Oral Art
text: “I love it when you read to me,” Stephin Merritt croons in “The Book of Love,” that mainstay of moderately alternative bride-and-groom dances. He’s not alone. At some point, almost everyone likes to be read to — at weddings and funerals, where we expect to hear a little tasteful verse; at religious services, where we want to hear a few passages from Scripture; and at bedtime, where we (assuming “we” are preschoolers) would like to hear about Thing One and Thing Two. But until relatively recently, the car and the kitchen weren’t standard venues for listening to a story, poem or novel. That has changed with the well-documented rise of the audiobook, a format in which, as The New York Times has previously noted, publishers “released nearly 36,000 titles in 2013, up from 6,200 in 2010, according to the Audio Publishers Association.” The Wall Street Journal calls audiobooks a “rare bright spot” in the publishing industry, and pins the total market for them at well over a billion dollars.

headline: ‘The Unfortunate Importance of Beauty,’ by Amanda Filipacchi
text: “This is how I’m going to find the man of my dreams,” declares Barb, the narrator of “The Unfortunate Importance of Beauty,” Amanda Filipacchi’s kindhearted meditation on looks, friendship, creativity and love in a superficial world. Barb’s method is unconventional. Cursed with a gorgeousness so extreme that she is constantly being swarmed by irritating suitors, devastated by the suicide of a friend who said her beauty was “painful for me to behold,” she has taken to shrouding herself in a homemade fat suit accessorized with unappealing clothes, fake teeth, color-obscuring contact lenses and a frizzy gray wig. Her disguise makes her feel safe and weeds out shallow men. All men, really. She has not had sex in two years.

headline: Kerry Expected to Bring Up China’s Sea Claims During Visit
text: BEIJING — Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here on Saturday amid rising tensions over China’s expansion of shoals and islets  in areas of the South China Sea claimed by at least three countries.

headline: Cannes-Do: Rodarte Designers Always Wanted to Direct
text: Fashion is playing a bigger role in Cannes this festival season than merely red carpet decoration — though looking at the photos from the South of France over the last two days, it has been something of a banner display for a variety of brands.

headline: Reverse Mortgages, Family Style
text: A mortgage company that specializes in setting up home-purchase loans funded by the buyers’ parents is now creating a vehicle through which siblings can pool their money to help their elders in a similar way.

headline: 1915: Anti-German Riots Dwindle
text: LONDON — Now that the Government’s proposals for the comprehensive internment of enemy aliens of military age are beginning to be enforced, the anti-German excitement in London due to the Lusitania horror has cooled down, and there was only one or two sporadic outbursts yesterday [May 14]. The Metropolitan police began their work of arresting enemy aliens yesterday, but wholesale arrests are being discouraged, as such a procedure would only embarrass the authorities.

headline: Bus Goes Over Hillside in China, Killing at Least 35
text: HONG KONG — A tour bus traveling through countryside in northwest China toppled off a steep hillside in Shaanxi Province on Friday, killing at least 35 people, according to state-run news media. It appeared to be the deadliest traffic accident in nine months in China, where the government has struggled to curtail the danger on roads and highways.

headline: Migrants at Sea, Up Close: Reporter’s Notebook
text: “This is going to be like finding a black cat in a dark room.”

headline: Online Gambling Firm GVC Holdings Makes Bid for Rival Bwin.Party
text: LONDON — The British online gambling company GVC Holdings said on Friday that it had made a takeover proposal for its rival Bwin.Party Digital Entertainment.

headline: Clippers’ History Offers Hope for Game 7
text: The Los Angeles Clippers were up by 19 points in the third quarter. They were up by 12 points with eight minutes to go. But down the stretch they missed 11 straight shots, were outscored, 25-2, and somehow managed to lose to the Houston Rockets in Game 6 of their series on Thursday night. It is hard to call it anything but a choke.

headline: The Case for Black Doctors
text: DURHAM, N.C. — IN virtually every field of medicine, black patients as a group fare the worst. This was one of my first and most painful lessons as a medical student nearly 20 years ago.

headline: Unlike His Brother, George W. Bush Stands by His Call to Invade Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — So Jeb Bush now says he would not have invaded Iraq if he knew then what he knows today. Neither would Chris Christie, Ted Cruz, John R. Kasich, Rand Paul, Rick Santorum or Marco Rubio. In fact, Mr. Rubio said, “Not only would I not have been in favor of it, President Bush would not have been in favor of it.”

headline: 1940: Dutch Troops Lay Down Arms
text: Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands addresses her hopes for her country after German acts aggression, in a speech broadcast in Britain in 1940. (britishpathe.com)

headline: Matthew Weiner On the End of ‘Mad Men’
text: In a special supplement from The Times’s culture desk, Mr. Weiner, the creator of “Mad Men,” discusses the coming conclusion of the series with Dave Itzkoff, a reporter for The Times.

headline: A Hint of Versailles on Central Park South
text: An elegant full-floor apartment that is one of just 12 residences above the Ritz-Carlton at 50 Central Park South — and the only one with parquet de Versailles floors made with hand-hammered German silver over wood — is poised to enter the market for $50 million.

headline: House Passes Military Bill After Fight on Budget Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — House lawmakers on Friday passed a roughly $612 billion annual military spending bill, concluding a week of fighting on issues ranging from congressionally mandated spending caps to immigration.

headline: Republican Presidential Candidates Rally Around Flat Tax
text: No matter how many Republicans end up squeezing onto a campaign stage for the 2016 presidential primary debates, one thing is just about certain: Every one of them will vow to cut taxes. So, with as many as 19 contenders all repeating the same message, standing out from the crowd will be a challenge.

headline: 50 Essential Summer Festivals
text: The weather warms up, the itch of wanderlust rises with the early sun. Here’s a seasonal tasting menu of potential cultural pilgrimages.

headline: American Pharoah Is a Fan Favorite, but Not Vice Versa
text: BALTIMORE — American Pharoah, the winner of the Kentucky Derby, appears to glide over the racetrack, a mark of a supremely gifted thoroughbred. His ability to find yet a higher gear in the homestretch leaves jockeys on opposing horses in awe. And his pedigree — a son of the Derby runner-up Pioneerof the Nile, who is also making a mark in the breeding shed — leaves little doubt that he is a formidable contender to win the Preakness Stakes here on Saturday.

headline: Larry Kramer’s ‘The American People, Volume 1’
text: This book requires some preliminary steeling of the nerves. It’s almost 800 solidly printed pages. The subject is vast and — you wince at the thought — it’s only “Volume 1.” Since this first installment has been 40 years on the way, the older reader’s chances of getting to the end aren’t guaranteed. Nor, you can’t help calculating, are those of an almost 80-year-old author.

headline: ‘The Dig,’ a Novel by Cynan Jones
text: The first word we hear in Cynan Jones’s intense and remarkably compressed third novel, “The Dig,” is “bitch.” It is said of a dead badger sow on the road, as an unnamed man tries to cover up the evidence that she had been tethered during an illegal fight with dogs. “Then he ground his foot down on the leg,” Jones writes, “and stamped over and over, smashing the thin precise line of the wire out of the raw flesh.” The echo of that violent exclamation resonates throughout this powerful book. We move between two strands — one the unnamed badger baiter known as “the big man” and the other, Daniel, a Welsh farmer grieving for his recently dead wife and trying to keep her memory alive as well as their lambs. Thus the novel becomes a kind of diptych about violence, loss and the different ways one can be trapped.

headline: ‘After the Tall Timber’ Collects Renata Adler’s Nonfiction
text: In the first essay in this new collection of nonfiction, Renata Adler writes about the cultural role of her generation. Adler was born in 1938, coming of age after the heroism of World War II and before the antics of baby boomers. “In college, under Eisenhower, we were known for nothing, or for our apathy,” she wrote in 1969. “We are unnoticed even as we spread clear across what people call, without taking account of us, the generation gap.” Neither here nor there, she went on to explain, “we cut across,” and in this function her generation found its purpose: “At a moment of polarization, and other clichés that drain the language of meaning, the continuity of the American story seems to rest just now in us.”

headline: ‘Odysseus Abroad,’ by Amit Chaudhuri
text: The title of Amit Chaudhuri’s sixth novel may use the Greek form of the ancient hero’s name, but the predecessor he’s got in mind for this story of two Bengalis wandering around London isn’t so much the “Odyssey” as it is “Ulysses.” Still, both Homer and Joyce begin the same way: with a young and callow man setting out in search of an absent father. Call him Telemachus, call him Stephen Dedalus. Or call him Ananda Sen, who in 1985 is studying English literature in Britain’s capital and making a bad thing of it. He wants to be a poet, he likes Ted Hughes and Philip Larkin, and he has begun to learn that Shakespeare’s language isn’t so much universal as rooted in English particulars. In a country with India’s weather, “Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day” sounds like an “insult”; in England, it’s a compliment.

headline: ‘The Enlightenment of Nina Findlay,’ by Andrea Gillies
text: Nina Findlay, an inquisitive book editor, and Luca Romano, a passionate wine distributor, are a universe of two. They confide only in each other. Constantly, they touch, they glance, they email and call. They clasp hands as if no one else exists. What Nina and Luca have joined together since childhood no one can put asunder, and the fact that they’re married to other people would be, to them, incidental were Nina’s husband not Luca’s elder brother, Paolo.

headline: Stuff We Liked
text: Here are a few of the things on the web that caught our eye this week.

headline: Indian Premier Discusses Talks in China
text: India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, spoke to reporters in Beijing on Friday after meeting with Premier Li Keqiang of China. Mr. Modi said progress had been made on some issues.

headline: Don Rickles Recalls His ‘CPO Sharkey’ Days
text: Hey, hockey puck: You may know Don Rickles best as that venerated stand-up comic with the tongue of a tiger and the heart of a pussycat, and a career of some 60 years that includes roles in films like “Casino” and the “Toy Story” series.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Coffee, Work Breaks and a Vitamin for Skin Cancer
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Penguins With Parent Problems No. 3: Go Ahead, Lick the Cart
text: What’s this? A Random Penguin! Let it brighten your day, or read more about the Penguins here.

headline: Gotham Chamber Opera Names Edward Barnes Executive Director
text: Gotham Chamber Opera, known for thoughtful productions in unexpected spaces, announced Friday that its next executive director would be someone with ties to both music and theater: Edward Barnes, the producing director of the Collegiate Chorale.

headline: A New Dance by Rebecca Patek at Chocolate Factory
text: The title of Rebecca Patek’s new performance piece is a mouthful: “The Future Was Looking Better in the Past: My Family Herstory: or from religious persecution to american greed to murderous infamy to denial, repression and the slow dissolution into moral confusion, financial ruin and karmic retribution.” In the work, Ms. Patek, a choreographer and performance artist who often confronts disturbing subject matter — her last show involved rape — explores facets of violence, both buried within herself and out in the world. In her premiere, presented by the Chocolate Factory and Abrons Arts Center, she finds inspiration in the vicious 1924 murder of Bobby Franks by Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb. Performed by John Hoobyar, Sam Roeck and Chris Tyler, the work blends material from the murder trial, Patek’s family history and her own imagination: Who were Leopold and Loeb? What were their psychological complexities? What leads to acts of horror? For Ms. Patek, armed with a wry, twisted sense of humor, the answers float somewhere in the subconscious.

headline: TV on the Radio Plays Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: They don’t make bands like TV on the Radio anymore — that’s a cliché, and true, and was equally true in the mid-2000s, when the group burst out of Williamsburg with a howl and a shriek and more clatter than all its neighborhood peers combined. The idea of this group as a going concern is looking increasingly slim — last year it released “Seeds,” its fifth studio album, though the members have been pursuing individual projects.

headline: Isabella Rossellini on the Birds and the Bees
text: Somewhere in the midst of conceptualizing her latest project, Isabella Rossellini imagined herself reciting poetry like the Beats, surrounded by a forest of penises. Soon, she was cavorting onstage with an assortment of phalluses in different shapes and sizes. It wasn’t what you might think.

headline: James Levine Conducts ‘Symphonie Fantastique’ at Carnegie Hall
text: “Berlioz tells it like it is. You take a trip, you wind up screaming at your own funeral,” Leonard Bernstein said about Berlioz’s colorfully macabre “Symphonie Fantastique,” a musical hallucinogenic that evokes an opium-using, heartbroken artist. There is also plenty of emotional tumult in Brahms’s Piano Concerto No. 1, which James Levine will conduct on the same program on Sunday at Carnegie Hall. The pianist Yefim Bronfman — a consummate Brahms performer who combines burly firepower and elegance — will no doubt bring out the wild side of this fiery work with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra as superb partners. (3 p.m. on Sunday, Carnegie Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: ‘Blue Velvet’ at IFC Center
text: It’s a shame David Lynch declined to direct “Twin Peaks,” if and when Showtime resurrects that landmark TV series he created with Mark Frost. More so considering that 2015 represents the 25th anniversary of the show’s introduction. But at least we have IFC Center’s Memorial Day weekend tribute to the director: midnight screenings Friday, Saturday and Sunday of his 1986 breakthrough, “Blue Velvet.”

headline: Carlos Lyra, a Pioneer of Bossa Nova, Reintroduces Himself
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Nearly 60 years has passed since the bossa nova sprang out of this city. For most of the world, that cool, minimalist sound, with its insinuating pulse, still defines Brazil. Inside the country, though, the music is a respected but quaint form of nostalgia. Tourists who seek it out tend to leave disappointed.

headline: Tyondai Braxton Talks About Punk, Percussion and Dad
text: Before Tyondai Braxton, the experimental musician and composer, could complete his new album, “HIVE1,” he had to find himself in a machine. The project, which started as an installation and performance at the Guggenheim in 2013 before making its way to the Sydney Opera House, is built around a warped backbone of uneven percussion — thwacking woodblocks, bursts of pitter-pattering snares — but finds its voice, sans vocals, in the robotic moans and whirrs of a modular synthesizer.

headline: The Good, Bad and Ugly Guide to Donating Clothing
text: Goodwill will take all clothing donations, even if the company rejects them for resale and sends them to be recycled.

headline: Tax-Deductible Clothing Donations Are Great, Except Your Used Socks
text: It is the season of spring cleaning, and if you paid more in taxes than you would have liked last month, you may well be looking to donate as much of your underused clothing as possible.

headline: Columbia Acquires Archives of Arthur Mitchell, Dance Pioneer
text: When Arthur Mitchell was contemplating where his archives should go, he thought about where he grew up and later, with Karel Shook, formed the Dance Theater of Harlem.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: Simple Ricotta Tart
text: Make Melissa Clark’s creamy tart the anchor for whatever seasonal fruit you have on hand.

headline: This Ricotta Tart Is a Canvas for Any Summer Fruit
text: Sometimes the trickiest thing about serving ripe summer fruit for dessert is resisting the urge to do too much to it.

headline: ‘Housebreaking,’ by Dan Pope
text: What so captivates us about the ­American suburbs? In fiction as in life, we’re ­perennially beguiled by their careful advertisement of order and serenity — and by the ugly incongruity of their discontented residents. Dan Pope’s second ­novel, “Housebreaking,” embraces this clash: “All the white houses and green lawns,” one character muses, “the children’s toys lying unattended in driveways. Pretty in a sculpted sort of way, but ­mildly sad. It was an illusion, one that promised happiness indefinitely. But the whole thing could collapse at any moment.”

headline: ‘The Subprimes,’ by Karl Taro Greenfeld
text: Imagine a world in which every liberal anxiety has been realized: a world where business interests have annihilated the greater good, where the environment is in irreversible decline, where the police have been privatized and renewable energy is banned. In this world, honest, hardworking Americans have lost their homes to foreclosure, and you can’t cross state lines without a credit score of 650; the have-nots have been reduced to furtive ­squatting in abandoned real estate developments, where they fear ejection by teams of brutal thugs in the employ of big oil.

headline: ‘One Nation Under God,’ by Kevin M. Kruse
text: Did you ever wonder how “In God We Trust” came to be quoted on every American coin and dollar bill? Or why the Pledge of Allegiance to the most revered symbol of the nation includes an explicit declaration of confidence in the Almighty? Or why the president and members of Congress host a National Prayer Breakfast the first Thursday of each February?

headline: Walter Mosley’s ‘And Sometimes I Wonder About You,’ and More
text: Walter Mosley breaks every rule in the private-detective-story stylebook in his new mystery featuring Leonid McGill, AND SOMETIMES I WONDER ABOUT YOU (Doubleday, $26.95). His New York sleuth’s disorderly domestic affairs keep threatening to overwhelm the crime elements, and a vital piece of the plot isn’t introduced until midway through the book. And when Mosley does wrap things up, he makes no effort to connect any of the multiple subplots.

headline: Inside the List
text: Dead in the Water: “Deal,” Bill Kreutzmann’s memoir of his decades playing drums for the Grateful Dead, is new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 10. The book (written with Benjy Eisen) opens with an anecdote from the late 1980s, when the band finally broke through to mainstream success: Its only Top 40 hit, “Touch of Grey,” reached No. 9 on the Billboard chart; the video was in constant rotation on MTV; and the band sold out a five-night run at Madison Square Garden. The attention, Kreutzmann acknowledges, was a little overwhelming. “We decided to celebrate by getting as far away from it all as possible,” he writes, explaining how he and Jerry Garcia, the singer and lead guitarist, ended up scuba diving in Hawaii one day with their roadie Steve Parish. “It was as psychedelic and far-out as anything we had seen during the Acid Tests, or at Woodstock, or during our strange days wandering around San Francisco during the Summer of Love. And yet, we were sober for this one. After years of persistent pot smoking, psychedelic excesses, alcohol benders, cocaine binges and heroin abuse, scuba diving was going to be our new drug.” It was, eventually — Kreutzmann and Garcia dived together many times over the years, as the rest of the book makes clear. But that first trip didn’t take them as far from fame as they had hoped: Underwater, a scuba instructor swam up to Garcia with a waterproof notepad and asked for his autograph. “Twenty feet below the surface!” Kreutzmann writes. “I nearly spat out my regulator from laughing so hard.”

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: Mounting Evidence of Advantages for Children of Working Mothers
text: Nearly three-quarters of American mothers with children at home are employed. That fact doesn’t necessarily make it any easier for mothers to drop a toddler at day care or miss school plays. The mommy wars might seem like a relic of the 1990s, but 41 percent of adults say the increase in working mothers is bad for society, while just 22 percent say it is good, according to the Pew Research Center.

headline: Broken Windows and American Oligarchy
text: Some years ago I gave a talk to a group of businesspeople — I don’t remember the occasion — and afterward, during the drink and mingle part of the event, had a conversation about executive pay. Quite a few of the businesspeople themselves thought that pay had grown excessive, but what has remained with me was the explanation one guy offered, more or less seriously: it’s all the fault of Monday Night Football.

headline: Carl Icahn Invests $100 Million in Lyft
text: For years, Travis Kalanick, chief executive of Uber, has been the loudest public voice on how ride-hailing start-ups will upend the transportation industry.

headline: Free Range vs. Helicopter Parenting: Get the Facts
text: 1. What are Free Range and Helicopter Parenting?

headline: A New Resource for Biking Routes
text: Megan Ramey’s first bike-related vacation with her husband and their daughter, now 5, helped inspire her to start Bikabout, an online travel resource for everything bicycling, with information on bike-friendly lodging, traveling with bikes, renting them and where to ride them around town, along with tips on culture, etiquette and safety.

headline: Paperback Row
text: IN THE LIGHT OF WHAT WE KNOW, by Zia Haider Rahman. (Picador, $17.) On a September morning in 2008, Zafar, a Bangladeshi mathematician from humble beginnings, shows up at the London home of an old friend, a rogue Pakistani-American banker. Zafar is there to make an unsettling confession, and as his story unfolds, Rahman’s extraordinary novel of ideas roams from London and New York to Islamabad and Kabul as it explores questions of love, belonging, science and war.

headline: Manhattan School of Music to Offer Musical Theater Degree
text: Music conservatories have a reputation for being high-minded purveyors of elite art. Countering this rap, the Manhattan School of Music announced that in fall 2016 it would begin to offer a degree program in musical theater.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: A GOD IN RUINS, by Kate Atkinson. (Little, Brown, $28.) This companion volume to Atkinson’s “Life After Life” is a sprawling, ambitious saga about a family in postwar Britain and a love letter to the men and boys who achieved the victory.

headline: ‘Voices in the Night,’ by Steven Millhauser
text: “I never may believe / These antique fables, nor these fairy toys,” Theseus declares in “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” dismissing the poet who seeks to make something out of an “airy nothing.” The sorcery Theseus deplores is Steven Millhauser’s signature strength, and indeed, at the start of a Millhauser story, there is often a spirit of airiness and wonder as we enter a phantom-haunted town or the Garden of Seven Noble Pleasures. Yet the stories in Millhauser’s spellbinding collection “Voices in the Night” are anchored by dark human yearnings — for perfection, or excitement, or some ungraspable form of fulfillment. These yearnings have a combustible quality, threatening to consume the towns and minds where a pervasive sense of unease provides the tinder.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Future of Work
text: This week, Barbara Ehrenreich discusses “Rise of the Robots” and “Shadow Work”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Andrew Solomon talks about Oliver Sacks’s new memoir, “On the Move”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Future of Work
text: This week, Barbara Ehrenreich and Andrew Solomon.

headline: Amar Ramasar’s Unlikely Path to Becoming a Prince for City Ballet
text: Amar Ramasar was 11 when he first saw ballet. It was a video of the New York City Ballet dancers Heather Watts and Mel Tomlinson, in Balanchine’s radical 1957 ballet “Agon,” the dancers clad in minimal leotards and tights, performing spiky, extraordinary movements to Stravinsky’s astringent score. Mr. Ramasar, an outgoing, talkative boy from the Bronx, knew right away what he thought. “That’s the ballet I want to dance, and that’s the company I’m going to get into,” he said.

headline: Susanna Malkki’s Wide Appeal on Both Sides of the Atlantic
text: A few months ago, during the Los Angeles Philharmonic’s performance of Unsuk Chin’s 2007 opera “Alice in Wonderland,” Susanna Malkki did something you hope a conductor never does while the music is still going: She left the podium.

headline: Hulu Picks Up ‘The Mindy Project’
text: Fox canceled “The Mindy Project” last week but Hulu is here to save the day.

headline: De Blasio Says New York Will Investigate Nail Industry Practices
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Friday that his administration would take steps to address what he called “deplorable conditions” that workers in the nail salon industry confront, including several investigations by New York City agencies and a “day of action” next week to inform manicurists of their rights.

headline: If You’re Older and You Know It, Shake Your Arms
text: I was watching Jane Fonda in the new Netflix show “Grace and Frankie,” in which she plays a woman who has just been dumped by her husband, and I was amazed to see Jane, who is 77, with the universally dreaded Inner Upper Arm Wiggle Waggle.

headline: The Double-Edged Sword of Online Anonymity
text: Reddit, a site whose huge range of sub-communities has long included both the fascinating and the downright repellent, announced Thursday that it would implement an anti-harassment policy.

headline: Marisa Tomei’s Perfect Proportions
text: The Star: Marisa Tomei

headline: Rick Perry Marks June 4 on Calendar for ‘Special’ Announcement
text: The next wave of potential Republican presidential candidates is coming ashore.

headline: Our Man in Tehran Answers Your Questions About Iran
text: Thomas Erdbrink, the Tehran bureau chief for The New York Times, responds to readers’ questions about Iran and his video series, “Our Man in Tehran.” Read more below and submit your questions for Mr. Erdbrink.

headline: ‘Entourage’ Movie to Land in a Transformed, Buttoned-Up Hollywood
text: BURBANK, Calif. — “The ride ain’t over,” declares a poster for “Entourage,” the coming movie version of the hit HBO series.

headline: Friday Night Music: DakhaBrakha
text: I know, it’s early afternoon in NYC, but I’m in Oxford and about to go off for drinks.

headline: Woody Allen on Philosophy, Film and Regrets Over His Amazon Deal
text: CANNES, France — The sun was shining, his latest film, “Irrational Man,” had been well received at its press premiere here, and Woody Allen was in a cheerful mood — musing on death, meaninglessness, Kant’s categorical imperative and how he fears that the series he is developing for Amazon promises to be “a cosmic embarrassment.”

headline: A Much-Needed Rule on Forced Labor
text: Like all controversial legislation, the trade bills making their way through the Senate are filled with provisions that can be hard to keep track of. One important measure that deserves more attention than it has gotten is a proposal to close a loophole that has for decades allowed businesses to import goods made with forced, prison, indentured and other exploitative labor.

headline: ‘Bob’s Burgers,’ After Five Seasons, Remains a Reliable Meal
text: Everybody has a go-to restaurant. It’s probably not the best one around or the trendiest, but it’s the place you can count on to give you a decent meal cordially served.

headline: Rather Than Fight or Flee, Take Responsibility
text: I was in a large meeting at my company, sharing an idea that had occurred to me, when one of my younger colleagues raised her hand and jumped in. “I’m feeling like we’re getting off track,” she said with some impatience. “We have an agenda, and I think we ought to stick to it.”

headline: Works in Progress
text: A very small sampling of the female artists now in their 70s, 80s and 90s we should have known about decades ago.

headline: Caught in Nepal’s Earthquakes
text: While photographing the aftermath of April’s devastating earthquake in Nepal, Daniel Berehulak found himself caught in yet another temblor. “You just react,” he said. “You go. You run.” And then you take pictures.

headline: Brittney Griner and Glory Johnson Suspended 7 Games in Domestic Violence Case
text: Brittney Griner and her wife, Glory Johnson, were each suspended for seven games by the W.N.B.A. on Friday over a domestic violence incident between the two in April.

headline: Don’t Be So Sure the Economy Will Return to Normal
text: It is hard to avoid the feeling that our current economic problems are more than just a cyclical downturn. We know that the economy has gone through some bad times. But what exactly are we experiencing?

headline: First Draft Focus: Mitt Romney and Evander Holyfield Ready to Rumble
text: Romney vs. Holyfield: ‘I’m Staying Far Away From His Ears’

headline: Love, Redeployed
text: A soldier returns from his second tour of duty. Now he and his wife must find their way back to each other.

headline: Home From Afghanistan, and Learning to Be a Couple Again
text: On the day before Thanksgiving, First Lt. Rafael Ramirez, 37, just back from his second deployment to Afghanistan, walked past the welcome-home balloons and stepped into his Bronx apartment.

headline: September 11 Museum Drew 2.7 Million Visitors in First Year
text: The National September 11 Memorial Museum marked its first year of operations on Friday, saying that it hosted about 2.7 million visitors during that period and slightly exceeded attendance projections.

headline: Speaking Out for Shareholders in Corporate Bankruptcies
text: By virtue of the “absolute priority rule” – which I will concede, I have recently argued is poorly named and oversold – shareholders are at the bottom of the heap in a corporate bankruptcy. They get paid only when everyone else has been paid.

headline: Republicans Had Reservations on George Stephanopoulos Before Revelation
text: The Republican National Committee told ABC News that it would not agree to have George Stephanopoulos moderate a debate well before news broke of the anchor’s donations to the Clinton Foundation.

headline: To Iowa G.O.P., Jeb Bush Appears to Be Ignoring the Family Playbook
text: DES MOINES — When Jeb Bush’s lone staff member in Iowa, Annie Kelly, recently telephoned Sherill Whisenand, a chairwoman of the Polk County Republican Party, she got an earful.

headline: Danny Burstein and Rebecca Luker in Morningside Heights
text: When they began looking for an apartment to buy just before their wedding nearly 15 years ago, the Broadway performers Danny Burstein and Rebecca Luker could not have been more clear with their broker: They weren’t interested in seeing anything past 96th Street, and that was that. What with both of them tethered to the theater district, they wanted a short, easy commute to 42nd Street. So nothing doing north of 96th. No deviating from the script.

headline: New Cannes President Sees Role for Festival in a Streaming World
Bond Turmoil Signals a New Era of ‘Return-Free Risk’
text: United States and German government bonds are gyrating as they rarely do. Yields are shooting higher for no apparent reason, and sometimes falling back within hours for equally unclear motives. Such turbulence in the biggest and most liquid bond markets is ushering in a new era. The traditional concept of risk-free returns has been turned on its head.

headline: Review: Yve Laris Cohen’s ‘Fine’ Dissects the Nature of Performance Spaces
text: With a background in classical ballet and a compulsion to reframe the tools of the theater, Yve Laris Cohen has carved out an unusual place as a choreographer. He plays with the materials that make a dance possible — the floors, the walls and, now, the curtains. Part of his practice involves the installation and dismantling of objects. Over the course of three nights of performances at Danspace Project recently, it was a portable stage used by New York City Ballet; at the Whitney Museum of American Art last spring, it was a piece of a wall.

headline: Fall 2015 TV Schedule
text: Here is a look at what shows will be where come mid-September.

headline: Migrants in Rome Try to Recover After Ponte Mammolo Camp Is Destroyed
