headline: Life After Don Draper
text: The final strains of AMC’s “Mad Men” have scarcely faded and already panic has set in: after seven seasons of being held rapt by the machinations of Sterling Cooper & Partners, how will you fill the void? Whatever your reason for watching — the allure of the 1960s, the art of the pitch, the prickly gender relations, the boozy bad behavior or simply the panache of a man in a bespoke suit — we’ve got some ideas for feeding your fix.

headline: Resilient Defenseman Marc Staal Delivers for Rangers
text: Through roller-coaster regular seasons and pressurized playoff games, Rangers defenseman Marc Staal has persevered, battling back from concussions and a serious eye injury to play his steady and forceful brand of defense.

text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to introduce on Monday two new measures in the State Legislature that would give regulators greater authority to punish nail salons that mistreat workers and make it easier for manicurists to acquire licenses.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
text: 4:15 P.M. (Starz Cinema) LOVE IS STRANGE (2014) Alfred Molina and John Lithgow (above right, with Mr. Molina) portray Ben and George, a couple for 39 years who are forced to live apart after their marriage results in the loss of George’s job at a Roman Catholic school and a mortgage they can no longer afford. So Ben moves into the Brooklyn apartment of his nephew (Darren Burrows), his nephew’s wife (Marisa Tomei) and their son (Charlie Tahan). And George takes a spot on the living room couch of his former neighbors (Cheyenne Jackson and Manny Perez), two New York City police officers. Awkwardness ensues. The film’s director, Ira Sachs, “is an especially careful student of the odd rhythms and quiet intensities of couplehood, both gay and straight,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Lithgow and Mr. Molina, seasoned and subtle actors, beautifully capture the small pleasures and petty irritations Ben and George live through, and also their pride at having survived, together, for so long.” Mr. Sachs, he added, “casts an occasional discreet glance backward at the post-Stonewall history of gay men in New York, a complicated chronicle of tragedy, resilience, struggle and fun. But that history nonetheless feels implicit in every frame, infusing what might otherwise be a touching anecdote about real estate troubles and houseguest etiquette with gravity and grace.”

headline: Our Trouble With Trains

The news about the train accident has focused on technological fixes that might have prevented the disaster. The deaths are, however, also rooted in our long love-hate relationship with the railroads. It is this particular history that has served to render our railroad problems so intractable.

headline: ‘The Daemon Knows,’ by Harold Bloom
text: This rounded, wet, weedy, windy earth, with its opposing poles, was born into contraries: Apollo and Dionysus, Talmudist and kabbalist, sober exegete and rapt ecstatic. Harold Bloom, who bestrides our literary world like a willfully idiosyncratic colossus, belongs to the party of rapture. He is himself no Whitman or Melville, no Emily Dickinson or Robert Frost or Wallace Stevens, no Hart Crane or Emerson. And yet he seems at times almost as large as any of these, so vital and particularized is his presence. If, as Emerson claims, the true ship is the shipbuilder, then is the true poem the critic who maps and parses and inhabits it? Can poet and critic be equal seers?

headline: ‘Women of Will’ and ‘Shakespeare and the Countess’
text: Shakespeare and . . . ? Well, whatever you like. It is said that no day goes by without the publication of another book, thesis or monograph on some slice of his life and works. Here come two more, this time linked by the theme of women: “Women of Will,” Tina Packer’s study of “the feminine” in the canon, and “Shakespeare and the Countess,” Chris Laoutaris’s portrait of a vexatious Puritan aristocrat who briefly disrupted the playwright’s career.

headline: Monkeys Provide Clues to How Tool Use Developed
text: Before human ancestors started making stone tools by chipping off flakes to fashion hand axes and other implements, their ancestors may have used plain old stones, as animals do now. And even that simple step required the intelligence to see that a rock could be used to smash open a nut or an oyster and the muscle control to do it effectively.

headline: Morning Agenda: Why Hedge Funds are Closing
text: WHY HEDGE FUNDS ARE CLOSING | Increased regulation, volatile markets and heightened investor scrutiny have prompted hedge funds to close their operations in recent months to focus on managing their own wealth, Alexandra Stevenson writes in DealBook. Shutdowns in the industry are not new – in past years, titans like George Soros and Stanley F. Druckenmiller have closed their hedge funds to manage their own money – but these days, hedge fund managers are complaining about external factors that make it more difficult to make money, like the regulatory changes brought about by the Dodd-Frank Act. For Gideon King, of Loeb King Capital Management, running a hedge fund had just become “too cumbersome,” as he said in January in a letter to investors. “As the endless quest for becoming institutional continues on, the soul of investing might get lost, as the unmitigated compliance processes become cumbersome and interfere with the purity of speculative contemplation,” he wrote.

headline: Dunning-Kruger Economics
text: I’ve mused in the past about a curious phenomenon: the evident preference of many on the right not just for economic hacks, which is understandable, but for incompetent hacks, who keep embarrassing themselves by getting very simple things wrong — who don’t, for example, seem to know how to read economic data, get confused about real versus nominal, are suckers for crank sites like Shadowstats, and so on. And these favorites of the right do it over and over again, apparently so bad at this facts-and-logic thing that they don’t even realize that they don’t know what they’re doing.

headline: North Korea’s Horrors

The 30-something Mr. Kim was said to have fed his disgraced and once-powerful uncle to a pack of dogs for disrespecting him. His latest action, as initially reported by South Korea’s National Intelligence Service, was to have the minister of the armed forces blasted to pieces with an antiaircraft gun, purportedly, among other things, for dozing off while Mr. Kim spoke.

headline: When Birds Squawk, Other Species Seem to Listen
text: MISSOULA, Mont. — In the backyard of a woodsy home outside this college town, small birds — black-capped chickadees, mountain chickadees, red-breasted nuthatches — flitted to and from the yard’s feeder. They were oblivious to a curious stand nearby, topped by a curtain that was painted to resemble bark.

headline: Seeking the Presidency, Bernie Sanders Becomes Facebook Royalty Through Quirky Sharing
text: WASHINGTON — The quotations he posts, rarely pithy, are often sayings he thinks up in the shower. The photographs he puts up sometimes show him frowning, while others show him gazing oddly into the horizon. And he does not seem to care about the importance of videos.

headline: What a Humble Pencil Says About Its (High-Profile) Owner
text: A new exhibition called the “The Secret Life of the Pencil” opens in London this week, thanks to the British creative director Alex Hammond and the photographer Mike Tinney, and aims to reaffirm the classic #2’s status as a powerful emblem of creativity, innovation and critical thinking in the 21st century. Housed in a lofty gallery space inside Paul Smith’s Albemarle store, the show is comprised of vibrant, large-scale images of pencils belonging to some of the world’s foremost creative talents, from iconic photographers to literary luminaries. “We wanted to highlight the beauty and potential of an integral tool that’s essentially in decline,” Hammond says. “David Bailey was the first to donate his, closely followed by Peter Saville and Sir Paul Smith, and we gradually built a portfolio of industry pioneers who still regard the device as an essential medium,” Tinney adds.

headline: A Way to Brew Morphine Raises Concerns Over Regulation
text: All over the world, the heavy heads of opium poppies are nodding gracefully in the wind — long stalks dressed in orange or white petals topped by a fright wig of stamens. They fill millions of acres in Afghanistan, Myanmar, Laos and elsewhere. Their payload — the milky opium juice carefully scraped off the seed pods — yields morphine, an excellent painkiller easily refined into heroin.

headline: Boko Haram Militants Raped Hundreds of Female Captives in Nigeria
text: DALORI, Nigeria — Hundreds of women and girls captured by Boko Haram have been raped, many repeatedly, in what officials and relief workers describe as a deliberate strategy to dominate rural residents and possibly even create a new generation of Islamist militants in Nigeria.

headline: From India,  a Tale Shaped by a Director’s Memories of an Assassination
text: CANNES, France – This year’s cinematic menagerie at the 68th Cannes Film Festival includes a monstrously large flea in “Tale of Tales,” bloody bunnies in “The Lobster” and flocks of sheep in “Rams.” No animal, though, has held the screen as proudly as the Himalayan sheepdog Tommy in “The Fourth Direction” (“Chauthi Koot”), a movie about ordinary people whose lives are shaped by violence in Punjab, the predominantly Sikh state in northern India. Directed by Gurvinder Singh, the movie takes place in 1984, the year Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was assassinated by two Sikh bodyguards.

headline: 1965: De Gaulle Standing by NATO
text: PARIS — President Charles de Gaulle denied today [May 18] that he plans to pull France out of NATO. This followed American press reports that he had informed Washington that he intends to leave the North Atlantic Treaty Organization when the treaty comes up for revision in 1969, or perhaps sooner. Information Minister Alain Peyrefitte said after a cabinet meeting today that the subject had not been discussed and that there is ‘‘no question’’ of it. Pierre Charpy, political editor of the newspaper ‘‘Paris-Presse,’’ reported today that Gen. de Gaulle had summed up his attitude in the following quotation: ‘‘The Atlantic alliance is necessary. France remains strongly attached to it. But the Atlantic organization (NATO) is worth nothing.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European edition, May 19, 1965

headline: Depression Tied to Stroke Risk, Even if Symptoms Ease
text: Studies have shown that depression increases the risk for stroke. Now a new analysis has found that the risk persists even if symptoms subside.

headline: At Cannes, a Greek Filmmaker Explains Move to English-Language Film

Her case had set off a national debate on euthanasia, often called “mercy killing” in India, and helped lead to the legalization of life-support withdrawal.

headline: Republicans Offer No Surprises at Lincoln Day Dinner
text: It is hard to think of an aspect of the quadrennial presidential nominating contests more pointless than the Iowa caucuses. It’s a small state whose population is not representative of really anything. The caucuses that famously start every election year don’t have a real impact on the selection of Iowa’s few delegates to the party’s conventions. And the efforts by candidates to sound folksy and concerned about Iowa’s problems are tedious.

headline: An Investment Lifeboat Drill Now Can Help Weather Future Disaster
text: Calm water makes a lifeboat drill much easier. We aren’t fighting the waves or the fear we feel during an emergency. Still, if the worst happens, and the drill becomes reality, at least we’ve rehearsed. We’ll know exactly what we are supposed do.

headline: Indian Subcontinent’s Quake-Causing Collision Course
text: When an unstoppable force like the Indian subcontinent crashes into an immovable object like the Eurasian plate, the consequences include the tallest mountains in the world and a cadence of earthquakes like the magnitude 7.8 one that struck Nepal last month and a major aftershock in the same region last week.

headline: In Paris, a Place for Coffee, Cycling and Creating a Niche Style Quarterly
text: On a recent Thursday morning in Paris, Kévin Reza cracked a half smile and readied himself for the camera; his urban cycle-wear snug against his lean, muscular frame. The 26-year old professional road cyclist wasn’t posing for a sports magazine but rather for the next issue of Steel magazine, a lifestyle and urban cycling quarterly. And he wasn’t in a photo studio but at the city’s newest concept shop, Steel Cyclewear & Coffeeshop, launched by the magazine’s founder/editor in chief Marc Schmitt (also known as “Sich” from his days as a street artist).

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Finale Renews Spotlight on Creator of ’71 Coke Jingle
text: Bill Backer lives on a farm in Virginia. He raises horses and cattle. When the weather gets cold, he and his wife of more than 30 years head to their small beach house in Florida, where they walk in the sun.

headline: About That ‘Steve Jobs’ Trailer

text: A valuable study published this week in Nature Climate Change projects that exposure to extreme heat in the United States is likely to rise enormously by mid century, driven equally by demographic shifts boosting Sun Belt populations and projected changes in heat waves in a warming climate.

text: Walk through the newly opened private apartment at Sir John Soane’s Museum in London.

headline: A.B.T. Principal Dancer Withdraws From Season
text: Polina Semionova, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, is withdrawing from all of her scheduled performances this season at the Metropolitan Opera House because of an injury, the company announced on Monday, just hours before its 75th anniversary gala performance.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
text: Barcelona, Paris St.-Germain and Benfica clinched their league titles over the weekend, but there are still a few things to play for before the summer break, most notably secondary hardware and first-division survival. The soccer editor Andrew Das, a shameless Ajax supporter, tells you what to watch.

headline: Ex-Captain at Rikers Island Deserves ‘Substantial’ Prison Term, U.S. Says
text: Federal prosecutors want a former Rikers Island captain to be sentenced to a “substantial term” in prison, though less than the 10-year maximum penalty, in a civil rights case that highlighted the failures of New York City’s jails to accommodate the needs of mentally ill prisoners.

headline: Regulators to Hold Hearing on Fiat Chrysler Safety Response
text: In a rare, sweeping move against an automaker, the nation’s top auto safety agency said on Monday that it was trying to determine whether Fiat Chrysler had failed to promptly fix safety defects in millions of recalled vehicles or properly notify owners.

headline: French Officers Acquitted in Deaths That Incited 2005 Unrest
text: PARIS — A French court on Monday acquitted two police officers of charges that they had failed to prevent the electrocution of two teenagers in a suburb of Paris nearly 10 years ago, a tragedy that set off weeks of unrest and violent protests around the country.

headline: TPG’s $8 Billion Drug Sale a Rare Development
text: The latest off-patent drug deal is far from generic.

headline: Skeleton Points to Early Leprosy in England
text: A 1,500-year-old skeleton suggests that leprosy may have spread to England from Scandinavia. The bones of the male skeleton show changes consistent with the disease, scientists have found, including a narrowing of the toe bones and damage to the joints.

headline: Supreme Court Sides With Police in a Shooting, and Against a State on Taxes
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday issued decisions on a police shooting in San Francisco, tax credits for out-of-state income, felons’ possession of guns and prisoner lawsuits.

headline: Scene of the Shootout
text: A shootout among rival motorcycle gangs on Sunday killed at least nine bikers and wounded 18 others.

headline: Vatican Seeks to Quiet Uproar Over Pope’s ‘Angel of Peace’ Remark
text: JERUSALEM — Every word counts in the delicate diplomacy of the Middle East, where negotiators have often resorted to creative ambiguity.

headline: All That Glittered at the Life Ball 2015 in Vienna
text: On the magenta carpet at the 23rd Life Ball, Europe’s biggest H.I.V./AIDS charity event, at the City Hall Square in Vienna, gold was the order of the day: celebrities, models and drag queens galore arrived decked out in glittering frocks, chains, headpieces and body paint to enjoy décor and performances inspired by Viennese Art Nouveau. Charlize Theron, accompanied by her beau Sean Penn, presented her Africa Outreach Project, which aims to curtail the spread of H.I.V.; and Jean Paul Gaultier, who made his legendary debut at the Life Ball 20 years ago, presented a gender-bending retrospective. The photographer Helga Traxler was on hand to capture the action for T.

headline: Text of Axact’s Response to The New York Times
text: Following is Axact’s response to a New York Times article published on May 18 asserting that the Pakistan-based company is at the center of a global network of fake online schools offering unaccredited degrees for money.

headline: Reactions
text: Aging

headline: Driver Testifies About Attack by Motorcyclists on West Side Highway
text: It was supposed to be a fun wedding anniversary for a young couple on a sunny Sunday, a shopping expedition to New Jersey with their toddler, then back to Manhattan for a romantic dinner out.

headline: Spring Symphonies in Prague
text: Spring Symphonies The 70th Annual Prague Spring International Music Festival, founded by the Czech conductor Rafael Kubelik in 1946, runs through June 3, with more than 40 classical music concerts scheduled at 14 venues, including Smetana Hall at the Municipal House, above, throughout the Czech Republic capital. Highlights include the second edition of the Chamber Music Weekend (May 22 to 25), the first appearance of the Orchestra dell’Accademia Nazionale di Santa Cecilia in Prague on May 28, and the American pianist Murray Perahia’s solo recital on May 30.

headline: Belmont Stakes 2015: American Pharoah Eyes Triple Crown Sweep
text: When the Belmont Stakes is run June 6, American Pharoah has a chance to become horse racing’s 12th Triple Crown champion, and the first since Affirmed in 1978. California Chrome was in the same position last year, but finished in a dead heat for fourth. Here is what you need to know going into the race.

headline: As Beyoncé Visits Haiti, Facebook Users Show Skepticism
text: MEXICO CITY — The American Embassy in Haiti wanted to show a notable visitor — in this case, the pop superstar Beyoncé — some of the progress made since the 2010 earthquake. So it did what many people do: turned to Facebook this weekend to ask for advice from the 119,000 people who have “liked” its page.

headline: Review: Heidi Melton Debuts With a Daunting Recital Program
text: Wagnerians look high and low for the Sieglindes, the Brünnhildes, the Isoldes of the future. Wagner’s most prominent roles make awesome demands of stamina, power and subtlety, demands rarely fulfilled. We elevate those who can cope: To any pretender, an Astrid Varnay, a Birgit Nilsson, a Nina Stemme hovers in the ear as an invidious, imposing, inescapable comparison.

headline: Review: Yve Laris Cohen’s ‘Fine’ Tears Down the Wall, and Then Some
text: With a background in classical ballet and a compulsion to reframe the tools of the theater, Yve Laris Cohen has carved out an unusual place as a choreographer. He plays with the materials that make a dance possible — the floors, the walls and, now, the curtains. Part of his practice involves the installation and dismantling of objects. For three nights of performances at Danspace Project recently, it was a portable stage used by New York City Ballet; at the Whitney Museum of American Art last spring, it was a piece of a wall.

headline: ‘Simple Songs’ by Jim O’Rourke Gives and Taunts in Equal Measure
text: JIM O’ROURKE

headline: New York Can Lead the Way to Higher Pay
text: The Fight for $15, a global effort to raise the pay of low-wage workers, has circled back to where it began. Protests by fast-food workers in New York City in 2012 got the movement started, and Gov. Andrew Cuomo has now given the effort its biggest boost so far by announcing the creation of a board to look into raising wages for the state’s more than 180,000 fast-food workers. Its first public meeting will be in New York City on Wednesday.

headline: The Men’s Medium Is Fashion at Frieze New York
text: Stylish guys captured in their finery at the fourth New York iteration of the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island.

headline: Mass Rape in Nigeria: Reporter’s Notebook
text: I have covered Boko Haram for six years. I have written about abductions, beheadings, slaughter. Today’s article about the mass rape of Nigerian women by Boko Haram soldiers who intended to impregnate women as young as 11 years old was among the most challenging.

headline: Review: Lang Lang at the Metropolitan Museum in the Service of Eastern Art
text: Because the Metropolitan Museum of Art has largely redirected its concerts to tie in to its exhibitions, the notion of a recital by the crowd-pleasing Chinese pianist Lang Lang to usher in “China: Through the Looking Glass” made sense, perhaps, on the surface.

headline: Review: Hot Chip’s ‘Why Make Sense?,’ Rooted in Dance Music’s Past but of the Now
text: HOT CHIP

headline: Selected Libya-Related Messages From Hillary Clinton’s Personal Email Account
text: A selection of emails related to memos on Libya sent to Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2011 and 2012 by Sidney Blumenthal, a confidant who worked for the administration of former President Bill Clinton and who at the time was employed by the Clinton Foundation.

headline: What Sidney Blumenthal’s Memos to Hillary Clinton Said, and How They Were Handled
text: In 2011 and 2012, Hillary Rodham Clinton received at least 25 memos about Libya from Sidney Blumenthal, a friend and confidant who at the time was employed by the Clinton Foundation. The memos, written in the style of intelligence cables, make up about a third of the almost 900 pages of emails related to Libya that Mrs. Clinton said she kept on the personal email account she used exclusively as secretary of state. Some of Mr. Blumenthal’s memos appeared to be based on reports supplied by American contractors he was advising as they sought to do business in Libya. Mr. Blumenthal also appeared to be gathering information from anonymous Libyan and Western officials and local news media reports. What follows are descriptions of some of the memos and how they were handled by Mrs. Clinton and her aides.

headline: Clinton Friend’s Memos on Libya Draw Scrutiny to Politics and Business
text: When the Clintons last occupied the White House, Sidney Blumenthal cast himself in varied roles: speechwriter, in-house intellectual and press corps whisperer. Republicans added another, accusing Mr. Blumenthal of spreading gossip to discredit Republican investigators, and forced him to testify during President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial.

headline: Ukraine Says It Has Captured 2 Russian Soldiers
text: MOSCOW — The Ukrainian government said on Monday that it had captured two wounded Russian soldiers in eastern Ukraine and would prosecute them on terrorism charges, prompting a spokesman for President Vladimir V. Putin to repeat the Kremlin’s longstanding denial that any Russian troops had been deployed across the border.

headline: Review: The Met Orchestra’s Season Concludes Under James Levine’s Soaring Baton
text: Two years, almost to the day, after leading the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in a triumphant return to performing, James Levine conducted the ensemble on the same stage on Sunday afternoon. Before that 2013 concert there had been real doubts about whether he would ever conduct again. Grappling with serious illnesses compounded by injuries, he had been absent from any podium for two years.

headline: Prosecutor Plans Retrial in Etan Patz Case
text: The Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., said on Monday that he would press ahead with a new trial for the former store clerk who confessed to murdering Etan Patz in 1979.

headline: At Jack Shainman’s Upstate Space, a Venice Golden Lion Winner Has Room to Spread Out
text: The New York gallerist Jack Shainman loves a fine spectacle, especially when it surrounds one of his artists. This Sunday, El Anatsui’s retrospective show debuted at Shainman’s massive upstate space, The School, where a crowd of more than 1,000 flocked to take in the Ghanaian-born sculptor’s large-scale metal works, along with early painting and pottery projects. Outside, tents offered shade from the afternoon sun and 80-degree weather, as visitors lingered over snacks from local Hudson Valley food trucks stationed on the property.

headline: First Draft Focus: Easing Tensions
text: President Obama visited Camden. N.J., as part of his effort to try to build trust between law enforcement organizations and citizens in minority communities.

headline: In Performance | Dael Orlandersmith
text: In a scene from “Forever,” her solo show at New York Theater Workshop, Ms. Orlandersmith talks about visiting the Père Lachaise cemetery in Paris and finding inspiration in the Doors.

headline: Six Years in, Obama Joins Twitter Universe (but He’s Not Following You)
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is facing a stark new challenge: trying to communicate in no more than 140 characters.

headline: Connecting the Dots, Part II
text: The Times on Sunday published an interactive graphic that looks at how the teams behind some likely and announced candidates are connected to previous campaigns and administrations.

headline: ‘The King and I’ and Queen Elizabeth Have Royal Box Office Showings
text: It’s good to be king (or queen).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Burundi and Elsewhere
text: Burundi and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Study Suggests Dense Breast Tissue Isn’t Always a High Cancer Risk
text: A new study offers help to patients and doctors who are trying to deal with mammogram results that many women consider troubling and confusing: the finding of “dense” breast tissue.

headline: Antibiotics Resurface as Alternative to Removing Appendix
text: Every year, 300,000 Americans with appendicitis are rushed into emergency surgery. Most think that if the appendix is not immediately removed, it will burst — with potentially fatal consequences.

headline: Motivation to Do Things, a Personal Vintage Shopper and a Beauty Resource
text: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: Walkabout: Record Summer Travel; Free Wi-Fi in Spain
text: Growth Airlines are predicting that 2015 will have the busiest summer travel numbers to date, with an estimated 222 million travelers expected in the skies from June 1 through Aug. 31. (USA Today)

headline: YouTube Wrongly Forced to Remove Anti-Muslim Movie Trailer, Appeals Court Rules
text: LOS ANGELES — An anti-Muslim movie trailer that set off protests in 2012 returned to the spotlight on Monday when a federal appeals court ruled that YouTube should not have been forced to remove the crude video from its website.

headline: Many Years of Overlooked Red Flags Catch Up to Stockbroker
text: In most professions, it would take only one or two acts of egregious conduct before troubled employees were shown the door. In the case of one stockbroker who has repeatedly had complaints from investors, it took 69 customer disputes filed over the last 13 years before he was barred from the business.

headline: Rise in Suicide by Black Children Surprises Researchers
text: The suicide rate among black children has nearly doubled since the early 1990s, while the rate for white children has declined, a new study has found, an unusual pattern that seemed to suggest something troubling was happening among some of the nation’s most vulnerable citizens.

headline: Review: ‘One Hand Clapping,’ a Darkly Comic Story of Consumerism
text: Probing the shallow consumerism of the 1950s and ’60s has been a popular pastime of late, but “One Hand Clapping,” at 59E59 Theaters, reminds us that the “Mad Men” culture was mocked practically before it had even fully materialized.

headline: Thierry Frémaux Shapes the Cannes Film Festival Schedule
text: CANNES, France — Each evening, Thierry Frémaux, the director of the Cannes Film Festival, greets stars on the red carpet, smartly dressed in a Brioni tuxedo. But it is his work offstage during the year that makes him one of the most powerful — and scrutinized — figures in the film universe: selecting the films shown here each year.

headline: Wanted in Saudi Arabia: Executioners
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Job seekers in Saudi Arabia who have a strong constitution and endorse strict Islamic law might consider new opportunities carrying out public beheadings and amputating the hands of convicted thieves.

headline: May 18, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Follow Lens on Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Review: The Jamie Foxx Album ‘Hollywood: A Story of a Dozen Roses’
text: JAMIE FOXX

headline: Review: In ‘Do No Harm,’ a Brain Surgeon Tells All
text: As a young doctor just starting out, Henry Marsh watched a neurosurgeon operate on a woman’s brain, going after a dangerous aneurysm that could rupture and kill her. This kind of surgery — taking place several inches inside the patient’s head — was perilous, and often compared, as he writes in his riveting new memoir, to bomb disposal work, “though the bravery required is of a different kind as it is the patient’s life that is at risk and not the surgeon’s.”

headline: Yankees Pitcher Chase Whitley to Undergo Tommy John Surgery
text: WASHINGTON — When Chase Whitley, flexing his right hand, walked off the mound Thursday at Tampa Bay in the middle of the second inning, much as Ivan Nova did in the same place 13 months ago, it was with the expectation that bad news would follow.

headline: Starbucks in Deal With Spotify to Stream Music
text: In the heyday of the CD, Starbucks was a leading outlet for the music industry to sell its new releases. Now, in the age of streaming, the chain of coffee shops has a new partner: Spotify.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: ‘Dance: Movement, Rhythm, Spectacle,’ an Exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art
text: PHILADELPHIA — Though “Dance: Movement, Rhythm, Spectacle” occupies just one large room (arranged to feel like three) at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, it seems to open windows in many directions. Its exhibits range from the 1890s to the 1980s, vividly demonstrating how radically that century brought change to social dance, dance theater and ideas of dance in art. Diversely diverse, the show, which opened this month, offers a panoply of artistic media (photographs, paintings, watercolors, prints, woodcuts, etchings, graphite drawings, lithographs and film), dancers of various races and a huge assortment of dance costumes. Its binding thread? The depiction of movement.

headline: Review: ‘The Flatiron Hex,’ a Delirious Tale With Puppets and Ickiness
text: James Godwin’s deliriously weird puppet show, “The Flatiron Hex,” takes place in a New York only a little different from the one we know and sporadically love: “a maze of ghosts and minor gods, floating in the middle of a toxic swamp.” A postmodern assemblage of the eerie and the icky, it follows Wylie Walker, a plumber, I.T. expert and high-level shaman, as he works to protect the city from a catastrophic storm.

headline: Tunisian President Looks for Help in Sustaining Arab Spring Progress
text: CARTHAGE, Tunisia — The test facing Beji Caid Essebsi, 88, who swept to victory in December in Tunisia’s first free and fair presidential election, might daunt a leader of any generation: to consolidate democratic gains, transform the economy and sustain the lone success story of the Arab Spring uprisings.

headline: Obama on ‘Militarized Gear’ for Police
text: The president, speaking in Camden, N.J., on Monday, announced new policies that will limit military-style equipment being provided to local police forces by the federal government.

headline: Drought Tests California Tourism
text: Disneyland is anything but underwhelming. Its deluxe fountains constantly spout, water rides regularly douse patrons, and plush gardens all lead children, and sometimes adults, to both squeal with delight and break down in tears.

headline: Verbatim: Chris Christie on His Support in New Jersey
text: — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, to Megyn Kelly of Fox News, when asked Monday about a Quinnipiac University Poll showing that his state’s residents, by 65 percent to 29 percent, think he would not make a good president.

headline: Shell Oil’s Cold Calculations for a Warming World
text: Last week, when the Obama administration gave tentative approval to Shell Oil’s plan to return to the Arctic after its disastrous attempt to find oil there in 2012, I found myself thinking of a conversation I had several years ago with a man named Jeremy Bentham. A theater-loving Englishman, Bentham leads Shell’s legendary team of futurists, whose methods have been adopted by the Walt Disney Company and the Pentagon, among others.

headline: Albany Corruption Inquiry Hurts Arizona Company That Hired Dean Skelos’s Son
text: The fallout from a federal investigation into political corruption in Albany has spread to an Arizona company that employed one of the men recently charged.

headline: Chester Higgins’ Homage to Ethiopia
text: Of all the African countries he has visited, Ethiopia holds a special place for Chester Higgins Jr. There, far from the cities, he is able to meditate on the intertwined strands of his life and art.

headline: Charter and Bright House Pursuing Merger Even After Comcast’s Failed Deal
text: Charter Communications announced Monday that it was going ahead with its $10.4 billion deal for Bright House Networks, signaling the start of a new push to consolidate the country’s cable operators.

headline: Greeks Wait and Worry About Next Paycheck, and Their Future
text: ATHENS — His hands smeared with engine grease, Markos Kalfakis once worked with three other mechanics repairing support vans for the city’s electric buses. Now he is the only one left. His salary has been slashed, his taxes have increased, and he struggles to meet the mortgage on his home.

headline: Hundreds Protest in Burundi’s Capital in Defiance of Ban
text: BUJUMBURA, Burundi — Hundreds of protesters took to the streets across the capital on Monday, despite officials’ warnings against demonstrations after a failed coup last week.

headline: New on Snapchat, Music Videos
text: Over the last year, Josh Legg, an electronic musician who performs under the name Goldroom, has noticed a change in how his fans interact with him online. More have turned from Twitter to Snapchat, the mobile app on which short messages digitally self-destruct after a few seconds.

headline: Judy Blume Knows All Your Secrets
text: I read “Are You There God? It’s Me, Margaret,” when I was around 10, hidden, as usual, in a big upholstered chair in a back corner of the house. In one of my favorite scenes, a sixth grader named Nancy is mad at her friend Gretchen, who has just gotten her period for the first time. Nancy thinks Gretchen is not sharing enough of the details, despite a predetermined pact that whoever got hers first would tell the others “absolutely everything.”

headline: Jon Hamm Talks About the ‘Mad Men’ Series Finale
text: Spoilers for the series finale of “Mad Men” follow.

headline: Axact, Fake Diploma Company, Threatens Pakistani Bloggers Who Laugh at Its Expense
text: In an effort to stem the tide of mockery on social networks in Pakistan that followed a New York Times report exposing its role in peddling fake diplomas online, the Pakistani company Axact threatened on Monday to sue a local blog, Pak Tea House, merely for rounding up Twitter reaction to the exposé.

headline: Armenian Church Leader Speaks on Suit to Reclaim Seized Property
text: A lawsuit in Turkey filed by the Armenian Church to recover its ancient headquarters, seized a century ago during the Armenian genocide, is the “first legal step” of a goal to reclaim all Armenian property seized by the Turks, a worldwide leader of the church said Monday.

headline: Moshe Levinger, Contentious Leader of Jewish Settlers in Hebron, Dies at 80
text: JERUSALEM — Moshe Levinger, a firebrand rabbi who spearheaded the modern Jewish settlement in the heart of the ancient and predominantly Palestinian city of Hebron, and who helped spread settlements in the territories Israel conquered in the 1967 war, died here on Friday. He was 80.

headline: Silk Road, Online Black Market, Reduced Users’ Risks, Defense Says
text: The already novel criminal case against Ross W. Ulbricht, the recently convicted founder of the website Silk Road, has taken yet another unusual turn.

headline: Warriors’ Steve Kerr and Stephen Curry Share a Bond Beyond the Arc
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Practice for the Golden State Warriors ended, and the best long-range shooter in N.B.A. history, statistically, took a final shot from the right wing beyond the 3-point arc.

headline: Massachusetts Justices Clear Way for New Trials in Cases Chemist May Have Tainted
text: A ruling by the Supreme Judicial Court on Monday is expected to help untangle parts of the sentencing mess left by the mishandling of drug samples by a state chemist that might have tainted tens of thousands of criminal cases.

headline: Girl, 2, Dies After Being Struck by Falling Piece of Windowsill in Manhattan
text: Workers in hard hats and neon vests on Monday finished erecting a phalanx of pipes and planks outside the Esplanade Luxury Senior Residences on West End Avenue in Manhattan.

headline: Bullet Did Not Strike Windshield of Amtrak Train, Investigators Say
text: PHILADELPHIA — Federal investigators said Monday that a bullet did not damage the windshield of the wrecked engine from last week’s deadly train derailment in Philadelphia, and that they found no evidence to confirm that a projectile broke through the window and struck the engineer.

headline: Many on Wall Street Say It Remains Untamed
text: Wall Street has changed. But perhaps not as much as you would think.

headline: In Egypt, Deplorable Death Sentences
text: Sometime in the near future, Mohamed Morsi, Egypt’s first democratically elected president, could be hanged to death by the state. That would be a profound injustice, considering the sham trial that landed him on death row.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Public Housing Plan to Seek City Aid and More Money From Tenants
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced Tuesday an aggressive plan to shore up New York City’s deteriorating public housing, calling for significant new financial help from the city and for squeezing more revenue out of the housing projects and their residents.

headline: A Player’s All-Clay Schedule Aids His Career, and Knees
text: When a small clay-court event in Tallahassee, Fla., was moved indoors because of incessant rain last season, Jason Kubler pleaded with tournament officials to delay his match to the evening session or the next day, hoping to play outdoors.

headline: ISIS Fighters Seized Advantage in Iraq Attack by Striking During Sandstorm
text: WASHINGTON — Islamic State fighters used a sandstorm to help seize a critical military advantage in the early hours of the terrorist group’s attack on the provincial Iraqi capital of Ramadi last week, helping to set in motion an assault that forced Iraqi security forces to flee, current and former American officials said Monday.

headline: Grizzled Manager Part of a Bygone Era
text: Two members of the fraternity are gone now, two fewer major league managers who also managed in the minors.

headline: The War Over the ‘Waters of the United States’
text: The Environmental Protection Agency, facing strong opposition from some farmers, ranchers and industrial groups, has tried to defend a major proposal aimed at protecting the nation’s drinking water. Here is a look at the dispute and the tactics the agency has used to fight back.

headline: Leafy Refuge in Liberty Park for Residents Annoyed by Construction
text: There is almost nothing neighborly about the neighborhood south of the World Trade Center.

headline: ‘Hamilton,’ ‘You Got Older’ and ‘Invisible Hand’ Among Obie Award Winners
text: The critically acclaimed musical “Hamilton,” which is preparing to transfer to Broadway after a sold-out, celebrity-packed run at the Public Theater, was named the best new American theater work at the 60th annual Obie Awards on Monday night.

headline: Critics Hear E.P.A.’s Voice in ‘Public Comments’
text: WASHINGTON — When the Environmental Protection Agency proposed a major new rule intended to protect the nation’s drinking water last year, regulators solicited opinions from the public. The purpose of the “public comment” period was to objectively gauge Americans’ sentiment before changing a policy that could profoundly affect their lives.

headline: With Triple Crown Possible, Belmont Can Expect a Big Draw
text: Boxing and horse racing occasionally revive from their mainstream slumber with big events: pay-per-view fights and thoroughbreds vying for the Triple Crown.

headline: Prashant Bhargava, Filmmaker of ‘Patang (The Kite),’ Dies at 42
text: Prashant Bhargava, a promising director whose boyhood memories of his uncles’ rivalry inspired his film “Patang (The Kite),” about how India’s largest kite-flying festival united a city ravaged by religious divisions and natural disaster, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 42.

headline: Amtrak Crash Illuminates Obstacles to Plan for Controlling Train Speeds
text: Nearly seven years after Congress instructed the nation’s railroads to install an automatic speed control system by the end of 2015, the crash of a speeding Amtrak train last week has laid bare the industry hurdles, regional rivalries and often dismal economics of rail safety.

headline: Review: Ensemble Studio Theater’s ‘35th Marathon of One-Act Plays’
text: In just two hours, Series A of the Ensemble Studio Theater’s “35th Marathon of One-Act Plays” races from Manhattan to Brooklyn, from a port town in Kenya to the capital of Idaho, from the 1950s to right now. A collection of short works, most Ensemble regulars, this speed-trial evening emphasizes how difficult it is for theater artists to work in miniature and how satisfying when they succeed.

headline: Review: In ‘The Flick,’ Moments at the Movies, but Not on Screen
text: “People always freak out when like, you know, when like art forms move forward,” says Sam, one of the lonely souls working in a run-down Massachusetts movie theater in the wondrous Annie Baker play “The Flick.”

headline: The Mysterious Lady
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Tuesdays are harder than Mondays. That is an unwritten rule of most published crosswords, and the difficulty level is usually ramped up by either including harder entries, or cluing the puzzle in a slightly more difficult way, or both.

headline: Son of Indicted New York State Senator Receives 6-Month Sentence
text: WHITE PLAINS — Among the wide variety of scandals that have gripped Albany in recent years, the past year has seemed to favor family affairs.

headline: An N.B.A. Lottery So Rich, Luck Seems Sure to Favor the Knicks
text: As a former N.B.A. executive, Stu Jackson is familiar with the mood at the annual draft lottery. He has sat on that dais. He has felt the bright lights. Jackson, now an analyst for NBA TV, described it as “the party no one ever wants to go to.”

headline: Bid to Impose Monitor on East Ramapo School Board Meets Resistance
text: A bill that would establish a state monitor for the East Ramapo School District, where a school board dominated by Orthodox Jews has drawn criticism for diverting money from public schools to children in local yeshivas, faces an uncertain future after running into resistance in the New York Legislature.

headline: Missouri: No Charge for St. Louis Officer in Killing
text: Prosecutors in St. Louis will not charge the police officer who fatally shot VonDerrit D. Myers Jr. in October, a shooting that renewed tensions with law enforcement weeks after Michael Brown was killed by an officer in nearby Ferguson. In a report released Monday, Jennifer M. Joyce, the circuit attorney for St. Louis, found that Mr. Myers “produced a gun” during the encounter with the officer, Jason Flanery, who was working an off-duty security detail for a private company. Police had said Mr. Myers, 18, who was black, shot a stolen handgun before Officer Flanery, who is white, returned fire. Prosecutors said in their report that witnesses had seen gunfire coming from both directions and from two guns and that a semiautomatic pistol had been recovered next to Mr. Myers’s body. Mr. Myers’s family disputed the police account and insisted that he had been unarmed. Protesters marched for several nights after the shooting, and some drew parallels between Mr. Myers’s death and that of Mr. Brown, an unarmed black 18-year-old shot by a white Ferguson officer in August. In a statement, Ms. Joyce expressed condolences to the Myers family and called his death “a tragic situation for our entire community.”

headline: Hall of Famer Phil Esposito Links Rangers and Lightning
text: Phil Esposito — unlikely Rangers hero and founder of the Tampa Bay Lightning — looked around Madison Square Garden on Monday night and remembered the hysteria of the spring of 1979.

headline: Idaho Approves Child Support Bill, Removing Treaty Roadblock
text: An Idaho child support bill that was initially rejected over concerns that it could force the state to follow Islamic law, and which endangered American participation in an international treaty, passed on Monday after the governor called legislators back for a special session.

headline: Weight of a Hat Trick Buckles the Rangers
text: The puck struck the post, then Henrik Lundqvist’s back. He looked behind himself for it, but it had already fluttered into the crease. He tried steering it away with his glove, but the puck skittered free, there for the taking, before winding up on the stick blade of the highest-scoring player in these N.H.L. playoffs.

headline: Militant Group Says It Has Romanian Hostage
text: A jihadist group that is based in the Sahara and was once a part of Al Qaeda’s global network announced that it was holding a Romanian hostage, just five days after it pledged allegiance to the Islamic State.

headline: An Artist Championed by Saint Laurent Brings His Paintings of Trance Dancers to Brooklyn
text: The self-taught artist Arrington de Dionyso, 40, can recite his first art-theory lesson, which came from his mother, a Methodist minister and painter. “When I was four or five years old, my mom told me that Picasso spent his entire life trying to learn how to paint like a child,” he says. “Of course, Picasso had a huge classical background … but she told me, ‘Do your thing, do what you feel, because that’s what a real artist will spend his or her entire life trying to do.’”

headline: Report Highlights Threats to Cartoonists Worldwide
text: The immediacy of visual imagery and the rise of social media have created an environment in which cartoonists are particularly vulnerable to “censorship, punitive lawsuits, physical assault, imprisonment, disappearance and murder,” according to a report to be issued on Tuesday by the Committee to Protect Journalists.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) IN THE BEDROOM (2001) Sissy Spacek, above, and Tom Wilkinson earned Oscar nominations for their portrayals of Ruth and Matt Fowler, a small-town New England couple who deal with the murder of their college-age son, Frank (Nick Stahl), in an unexpected way in this best-picture contender from Todd Field. Marisa Tomei, also nominated, plays the older, married girlfriend who unwittingly leads Frank to his demise. This adaptation of the short story “Killings,” by Andre Dubus, is a “perfectly observed, wrenchingly acted drama” that “cuts to the quick,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “It reminds us that, like it or not, the capacity to commit a crime of passion is part of being human.”

headline: Trade and the Decline of U.S. Manufacturing Employment
text: As Matthew Yglesias notes, many people believe that US manufacturing has disappeared because it has all moved to China and Mexico — but they’re largely wrong. I’m not sure that pointing to measures of industrial production is the bet way to make this point, however. A better approach, or so I’d argue, is to ask how much of the decline in manufacturing employment would have been avoided if we weren’t running big trade deficits.

headline: Q. and A.: Peter Chan on Making Movies in China
text: Peter Ho-sun Chan, 52, was born in Hong Kong, spent his teenage years in Thailand and studied film in Los Angeles. Despite his transnational upbringing, the director of films such as “Comrades, Almost a Love Story” (1996), about mainland Chinese migrants in Hong Kong, and “Perhaps Love” (2005), a musical set in mainland China, still sees himself very much as a Hong Kong filmmaker. “No matter what the subject matter is, the Hong Kong sensibility in me will never change,” Mr. Chan said by telephone from Hong Kong, where he lives. “I can’t pretend that I’m mainland Chinese and make films like a mainland Chinese. I will always be an observer and a storyteller with a Hong Kong perspective.”

headline: Chester Higgins’s Homage to Ethiopia
text: Chester Higgins Jr. has traveled to Africa every year since 1971 as a way to meditate, disconnect and examine his life. Through the experience of photographing new people and places, his art both shapes and reflects his narrative. And nowhere is that truer for him than in Ethiopia, a place that has long enchanted him.

headline: Stupid Austerity Tricks
text: Against willful stupidity, the gods themselves contend in vain. So it’s no surprise that Simon Wren-Lewis is having a hard time of it. Still, it’s amazing just how dependent the pro-austerity camp has become on one dumb trick — misunderstanding, or pretending to misunderstand, the difference between levels and rates of change.

headline: Free Trade Is Not the Enemy
text: CHICAGO — IN 1993, President Bill Clinton tapped me as special counsel to lead the fight to pass the North American Free Trade Agreement. As a new trade debate rages in Washington, I’ve thought a lot about that effort. The mistake we made in the 1990s was overestimating the potential of Nafta’s positive impact. Today, we are making the mistake of underestimating what defeat of the Asia-Pacific deal would mean economically, globally and politically.

headline: Learning From Mistakes
text: If you could go back to 1889 and strangle Adolf Hitler in his crib, would you do it? At one level, the answer is obvious. Of course, you should. If there had been no Hitler, presumably the Nazi Party would have lacked the charismatic leader it needed to rise to power. Presumably, there would have been no World War II, no Holocaust, no millions dead on the Eastern and Western fronts.

headline: How to Prevent an Oil Train Disaster
text: SIX days before last week’s deadly Amtrak derailment, a train carrying crude oil went off the tracks in rural North Dakota and burst into flames. Thankfully, no one was killed. But it should not take a deadly disaster — like the one that took 47 lives in the town of Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, in July 2013 — for us to grasp the risk from oil trains, which pass through many densely populated parts of the United States.

headline: The Fight to Regulate Formaldehyde
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has been trying for several years to reduce the risk of toxic formaldehyde fumes from commonplace items and materials found in American homes. It has been stymied at every turn by industry, antiregulatory Republicans and even some Democrats. These opponents, abetted by the White House, have at least temporarily forced the agency to retreat from a proposal formulated in 2012 that it had hoped would address the issue. Unless the agency and its supporters in Congress fight back, the result could be thousands or even tens of thousands of needless illnesses.

headline: Can Republicans Avoid the Romney Tax Trap?
text: In 2012, Mitt Romney made a promise that would come back to haunt him: that he could cut federal income tax rates by 20 percent across the board; eliminate enough tax deductions and credits to do this without increasing the deficit; and not raise taxes on people making less than $200,000.

headline: Paul Shaffer, ‘Late Show’ Bandleader, on Saying Goodbye to Letterman After 33 Years
text: It’s not only the late-night television career of David Letterman that will come to an end on Wednesday night, when he hosts his final episode of CBS’s “Late Show.” That broadcast will also bring to a close Mr. Letterman’s memorable partnership with Paul Shaffer, the bespectacled, fashion-forward keyboardist who has been the host’s quip-firing bandleader and sidekick throughout his 22-year CBS run, and for 11 years before that on NBC’s “Late Night.”

headline: ‘Man in Profile: Joseph Mitchell of The New Yorker,’ by Thomas Kunkel
text: In his salad days as an uncommonly dapper reporter for The New York Herald Tribune and The World-Telegram, Joseph Mitchell wrote about celebrities, crimes and the quotidian disasters of city life during the Depression: He covered the Lindbergh kidnapping trial (“a mess”), witnessed the electrocution of six men, and watched a woman who had been stabbed in the neck bleed to death while he tried to make her lie still. He might have gone on like that and had a productive if ultimately forgettable career, were it not for a newspaper series he wrote on the anthropologist Franz Boas that became, for Mitchell, “a kind of graduate-level seminar”: “Don’t take anything for granted,” Boas told him, among other things. The advice helped transform Mitchell from a competent beat reporter with a graceful prose style into, arguably, our greatest literary journalist — a man who wrote about freaks, barkeeps, street preachers, grandiose hobos and other singular specimens of humanity with compassion and deep, hard-earned understanding, and above all with a novelist’s eyes and ears. “When the New Journalists came ashore,” John McPhee observed, “Joe Mitchell was there on the beach to greet them.”

headline: ‘God Is Not Here,’ by Bill Russell Edmonds
text: This is a soldier’s sad and troubling account of his yearlong tour in Iraq (2005-6) and his subsequent struggle to regain his balance and find meaning in the experience. In May of 2005, Lt. Col. Bill Russell Edmonds, then a Special Forces captain, volunteered for duty in an ad hoc organization, the Iraqi Assistance Group, which the United States military created to supply advisers to the nascent Iraqi military. He was sent to Iraq, given a brief training course in Baghdad and then loaded into a convoy to Mosul, where he would spend the next year on a small compound Sad­dam Hussein had called the Guest House.

headline: Proving My Blackness
text: I grew up a black boy who looked like a white one. My parents divorced when I was 4, and I was raised mostly by my black mom, in a black neighborhood of Philadelphia, during the Black Power movement. I put my dashiki on one arm at a time like every other black boy, but I was haunted by the moments I’d be out with my mother and other black people would look at me as if I were a cuckoo egg accidentally dropped in their nest. The contrast between “blackness” and how I looked was so stark that I often found myself sifting through archaic, pre-20th-century African-American racial definitions to find a word that fit me. Mulatto, 50 percent African. Quadroon, 25 percent African. Octoroon, 12.5 percent African. The next stop down, at 6.25 percent African, was mustefino. I’d never heard anyone call himself mustefino, and I didn’t want to personally relaunch that brand.

headline: How the Civil War Changed the World
text: Even while the Civil War raged, slaves in Cuba could be heard singing, “Avanza, Lincoln, avanza! Tu eres nuestra esperanza!” (Onward, Lincoln, Onward! You are our hope!) – as if they knew, even before the soldiers fighting the war far to the North and long before most politicians understood, that the war in America would change their lives, and the world.

headline: When It Comes to Wage Abuses, It’s Not Just the Nail Salons
text: The cash registers of many gas stations never sleep. “I was there seven days a week, 12 hours a day, 84 hours minimum. Minimum,” said Chitra KC, 35, who worked in a station on Sunrise Highway in Holbrook, N.Y. He is one of about 27 immigrant workers from Nepal, Bangladesh, Pakistan or India with wage claims against stations on Long Island owned by Steve Keshtgar, who filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 on Dec. 24.

headline: 1965: U.S. Planes Hit North Vietnam
text: SAIGON — Forty U.S. planes today [May 19] pounded targets in North Vietnam for the second straight day after the failure of an American bid to force peace talks. A U.S. military spokesman said planes from the carrier Coral Sea inflicted ‘‘severe damage’’ on two targets — the Hoan Lao barracks and the nearby Chanh Hoa military radio station — about 40 miles north of the border. The planes raked the targets with 50 tons of bombs and rockets and radio-guided missiles. A five-day pause in the attacks on the North ended yesterday after Canada failed in efforts to get North Vietnam to agree to talks. Speculation was growing here that the United States would seek more important targets in the North, possibly in the industrialized Hanoi-Haiphong region, to increase the pressure for talks. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 20, 1965

headline: Restaurant Review: Javelina in Gramercy Park
text: I like Texans. I love their food and their music and their boots. I admire their ability to tame landscapes that are hostile to human life. I respect how quick they are to stick up for their state and its culture. In fact, I may be slightly afraid of Texans. I have no desire to mess with them. I can read the bumper stickers.

headline: Why Remington’s Investors Should Not Sell

headline: In Normandy, a Summer-Ready Seaside Getaway
text: In Trouville, a gorgeous Belle Epoque bathing beauty — the Cures Marines Trouville Hotel — has just had a glamorous makeover. Part of a casino complex that opened at the southernmost edge of the Calvados commune’s famous white sand beach and boardwalk in 1912, the 103 rooms now echo the Norman coastline. Shades of sand, seafoam blue and slate fill the property thanks to the Paris-based architect Jean-Philippe Nuel, who also recently redesigned the legendary art-deco Piscine Molitor municipal-swimming-pool complex in the French capital’s 16th arrondissement into a 124-room hotel. At the Cures Marines, Nuel highlighted Trouville’s proud literary pedigree with oversized, stenciled quotes about the port town on the walls from writers who lived, worked or played there, including Stendhal, Flaubert, Proust and Marguerite Duras, the author of “The Lover,” who lived in Trouville for many years.

headline: N.F.L. Explores Making the 2-Point Conversion More Tempting

headline: 4 Killed and Dozens Wounded in Suicide Bombing in Kabul

headline: Driven | 2016 Honda HR-V
text: The Honda CR-V has been America’s best-selling crossover in seven of the last 10 years. So its new and smaller sibling, the HR-V, is a big deal.

headline: Torture Still Widely Used in Morocco, Amnesty International Says
text: RABAT, Morocco — Violent interrogation methods are still widely used by the Moroccan authorities to crush dissent and forcefully extract confessions from detainees, even though the government has pledged for years to eradicate torture, a new report by the human rights group Amnesty International says.

headline: The Ann Coulter Critique of American Christianity
text: My Sunday column discussed recent remarks from President Obama and the sociologist Robert Putnam on American churches and the fight against poverty, in which both men suggested that culture-war fixations have sidelined American Christianity’s mission to the poor. Given the sums raised and man-hours invested by religious groups in charitable work, this is not a particular compelling argument; in fact, it’s pretty dumb, as a number of writers had already pointed out by the time I got around to the subject. So I added my voice to their chorus, but I also tried to raise one possible way in which you could argue that the churches are failing poorer Americans: Not in their charitable works, but in the actual business of soul-winning itself, as evidenced by the fact that downscale Americans are both less likely than the affluent to attend church and less likely to attend, period, than in the recent past. And I noted that you don’t even have to believe in the soul to see this as a failure: Since the social benefits of religion seem to flow through participation and belonging, even from a purely secular perspective (well, if such a thing exists) America’s churches would probably be doing more for the poor than charity alone can offer if they were keeping more people in the pews.

headline: A National Day of Action, for a Better America
text: Today, May 19, should have been the day that the United States took a step forward on immigration reform. Not an enormous step in the global scheme of things, but a huge one for the people it would have helped.

headline: Rejecting the Cubicle for an Expanse of Space
text: In the era of the coffee-shop office, where a bit of countertop can be enough room from which to run a business, some tenants in New York are clamoring for a very different kind of workplace: one that spans a cavernous 100,000 square feet or more.

headline: Airbag Recall Widens to 34 Million Cars as Takata Admits Defects
text: For more than a decade, the Japanese company Takata, one of the largest suppliers of airbags, denied that its products were defective even as motorists were killed by exploding airbags and automakers around the world recalled millions of cars equipped with its products.

headline: New Rules for Guardrails Close a Testing Loophole
text: The Federal Highway Administration has tightened its standards for highway guardrails, closing a loophole that allowed guardrail makers to revise older devices without additional crash tests.

headline: Hillary Clinton Answers Questions on Iraq, Emails, the Foundation and Wealth

headline: Video Review: The Honda CR-V Gets a Little Brother, the HR-V
text: Consider that Honda’s CR-V has been America’s best-selling crossover seven of the last 10 years. Ponder the Swiss Army knife interior of the Fit. Now, put the two into Seth Brundle’s teleportation chamber (without the fly, thanks) and you get HR-V. It joins Chevy Trax, Fiat 500X, Jeep Renegade and Mazda CX-3 in the current automotive “it” segment, the compact crossover.

headline: Los Angeles Lifts Its Minimum Wage to $15 Per Hour
text: LOS ANGELES — The nation’s second-largest city voted Tuesday to increase its minimum wage from $9 an hour to $15 an hour by 2020, in what is perhaps the most significant victory so far for labor groups and their allies who are engaged in a national push to raise the minimum wage.

headline: Patriots Won’t Appeal N.F.L. Punishment, Owner Says
text: Robert K. Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, who has been confrontational as his team warred with the N.F.L. over whether the Patriots inappropriately deflated footballs in a conference championship game four months ago, did an about-face on Tuesday, saying he would accept the league’s punishment and quit debating culpability.

headline: Many Probiotics Taken for Celiac Disease Contain Gluten
text: Last year, doctors at Columbia University found that people with celiac disease frequently use probiotic supplements, but that those who take these products tend to experience more symptoms of the disease than those who do not.

headline: Iraq’s Sunni Strategy Collapses in Ramadi Rout

headline: A Smoky Bourbon Cocktail from a Legendary Toronto Experimentalist
text: Impactful aromatics have always played an essential role in the creations of the Canadian mixologist Frankie Solarik. Inside BarChef, his Modernist cocktail laboratory on Toronto’s Queen Street West, multisensory presentations evoke the flavors of the season — not just in the glass, but surrounding it, too. Solarik’s Spring Thaw is served in a cool, perfumed fog of cedar, lilac and grapefruit, billowing from a bed of wet moss that nestles a glass of vanilla Campari granita swimming in chamomile gin and sparkling wine. That drink’s a showstopper, wafting in all directions across the bar; a perennial Vanilla and Hickory Smoked Manhattan (the preference of the rappers Jay-Z and Drake) is more self-contained, infused tableside under one of two antique glass domes. If those drinks appear daunting to replicate, Solarik’s Canadian bestseller bar manual “The Bar Chef: A Modern Approach to Cocktails” ($30, Harper) is released today in the United States. And if the drinks recall the culinary artistry of Grant Achatz’s Alinea, it will come as no surprise that the Chicago chef penned the book’s foreword. “Grant came into BarChef in 2009 when we first opened, and his incorporation of aromatics and theater changed my life,” Solarik recalls of the research trip Achatz took prior to opening The Aviary.

headline: Review: American Ballet Theater’s Frenetic Anniversary Gala
text: For its big birthday year at the Metropolitan Opera House, American Ballet Theater, at 75, changed its approach: Instead of the traditional opening-night gala, the company got its feet wet last week with a wince-free run of classic repertory, or heritage works, by some of its early choreographers: George Balanchine, Agnes de Mille, Jerome Robbins, Antony Tudor. A gala was inevitable, though, and on Monday the company presented nearly two dozen excerpts and seven speakers, many of whom tried mightily to explain what makes Ballet Theater so American. By Hour 2, it was like being trapped at an increasingly desperate pitch meeting.

headline: Steve Jobs: A Cottage Industry of Movies and Books

headline: Turn Your Fruit Into Ice

Her mango and lime sorbet is tangy and not very sweet, with just enough sugar and corn syrup to allow the mixture to freeze properly without developing ice crystals.

headline: Mattress Protest at Columbia University Continues Into Graduation Event

headline: Review: New York New Music Ensemble Plays a Tribute Concert for Lee Hyla
text: “A 29-year-old stewardess fell 1,500 feet to her death tonight,” reported The New York Times on Oct. 20, 1962, “when she was swept through an emergency door that suddenly sprang open on an Allegheny Airlines plane.” What might Françoise de Moriere, who was found outside the town of Farmington, Conn., have felt on the way down? What might her fall mean? That’s the subject of James Dickey’s intense 1967 poem “Falling,” now the basis of Mathew Rosenblum’s effective chamber piece, also called “Falling” (2013).

headline: Brooklyn Museum Picks Anne Pasternak as New Director
text: The Brooklyn Museum announced on Tuesday that its next director would be Anne Pasternak, who has spent the last two decades as president and artistic director of Creative Time, a prominent arts organization that stages free projects, exhibitions and events at public sites throughout New York. Ms. Pasternak will succeed Arnold L. Lehman, who is retiring in June as director after nearly 18 years. He reshaped the museum in significant ways, seeking foremost to reach a larger, more diverse audience.

headline: Review: ‘Güeros’ Amid the Mexican Student Protests of 1999
text: Shot in black-and-white, in the boxy, old-fashioned aspect ratio that seems to be the latest thing in art-cinema retro fashion, Alonso Ruizpalacios’s “Güeros” manages to feel both sweetly nostalgic and exuberantly now. It takes place in 1999, during a period of student unrest in Mexico, and many of the young people on screen, militants and slackers alike, live consciously in the shadow of 1968, when campus uprisings shook the country and were murderously suppressed by the military.

text: Not all Netflix series are created equal. “Between,” a Netflix original whose six-episode first season begins appearing weekly on this video-streaming site on Thursday, is a Canadian science-fiction series — Netflix money, north-of-the-border talent and formulas. So we’re talking about something a lot closer to the Syfy channel — home of Canadian shows like “Bitten,” “Lost Girl” and “Continuum” — than to “Daredevil” or “Orange Is the New Black.”

headline: I’m a Moderate Biker Gang Member Compelled to Condemn This Violence
text: On Sunday, a biker gang meeting at the Twin Peaks Restaurant in Waco, Tex., erupted in violence that claimed the lives of nine people and injured 18. This tragedy stemmed from the criminal actions of a fringe minority that does not represent the democracy-loving values of the majority of tolerant biker gangs devoted to freedom, denim, mutual understanding and leather accessories.

headline: Tanlines Share Their Go-To Clothes, Books and Podcasts
text: “I think when we wrote this album, we wanted to incorporate how we play live,” says Tanlines’ Jesse Cohen of the duo’s sophomore record, “Highlights,” out today via True Panther. “The last album sounds like it was written by two guys sitting in front of a computer. This one feels like it was produced in big rooms and on big stages.” Cohen and his bandmate Eric Emm have been making music together since 2008; things really took off after the release of their debut LP, “Mixed Emotions,” back in 2012. “I would say that ‘Mixed Emotions’ thematically felt like an existential-crisis album,” Cohen says. “‘Highlights’ is about relationships and personal stuff. It’s the tone of two people who have answered questions instead of asking questions, though there are some questions still. Nothing is ever figured out if you’re as neurotic as the two of us are.”

headline: Laszlo Krasznahorkai Wins Man Booker International Prize
text: The Hungarian writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai won the sixth Man Booker International Prize at a ceremony on Tuesday night in London. The prize, which comes with £60,000, about $93,000, is awarded every two years for a body of work published either originally in English or available in English translation.

headline: France Answers Hostile Bids With the Two-Vote Share

headline: Hillary Clinton Talks to Small-Business Owners in Iowa, Then Gives Reporters a Turn

Rockefeller of New York, soon after both had been divorced, raised a political storm in a more genteel time and may have cost him the Republican presidential nomination in 1964, died on Tuesday at her home in Tarrytown, N.Y. headline: Data Suggests Legs and Toes in Ancestor of Living Snakes
text: From the robust boa constrictor to the venomous rattlesnake, all of the more than 3,400 snake species that slither today may have descended from the same prehistoric forest prowler, whose sinuous body had two small hind legs with toes and ankles, researchers reported on Tuesday.

headline: Police Say Man Killed in Manhattan Hotel May Have Been a Pimp
text: Two men and two women checked into a room on Sunday at the Hilton Garden Inn on West 35th Street, one of the many chain hotels that now dot the side streets of Midtown Manhattan. They went upstairs to Room 2203. A few hours later, one of the men was dead.

headline: Chinese Plan Investments and Loans for Brazil

headline: I.R.S. Look at Spinoffs May Affect Yahoo Plan

headline: Rev. John Lo Schiavo Dies at 90; University President Barred Basketball
text: The Rev. John Lo Schiavo, who spent 14 years as president of the University of San Francisco, notably making headlines when he took the rare step of suspending the men’s basketball program after repeated violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, died on Friday in Los Gatos, Calif. He was 90.

headline: U.S. Details New Efforts to Support Ailing Bees
text: The White House on Tuesday outlined its strategy to restore the nation’s struggling honeybee and monarch butterfly populations to some semblance of health, mostly by expanding the acreage devoted to the wildflowers and milkweed that are crucial to their survival.

headline: Torture Claims in Tunisia Await Truth Commission
text: TUNIS — One of the most notorious forms of torture was the “roast chicken,” an obscene stress position in which the victim was suspended naked, like a trussed bird on a spit.

headline: Japanese Economy Grows at Fastest Pace in a Year
text: TOKYO — Japan’s climb out of recession accelerated unexpectedly in the first quarter of the year, the government said on Wednesday, as the economy grew at its fastest pace since the beginning of 2014.

headline: Studies Confirm Brain Plaque Can Help Predict Alzheimer’s
text: The largest analysis to date of amyloid plaques in people’s brains confirms that the presence of the substance can help predict who will develop Alzheimer’s and determine who has the disease.

headline: Landmarks Commission Rejects Plan to Change Interior of Four Seasons
text: The interior of the Four Seasons restaurant, a vision of Modernist elegance with its French walnut paneling and white marble pool of bubbling water, should not be changed, New York City’s Landmarks Preservation Commission decided on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Focuses on Top Venezuelan Officials in a Broad Cocaine Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Senior Venezuelan officials are under investigation by the American authorities as part of a wide-ranging inquiry into the distribution of cocaine in the Western Hemisphere, American law enforcement officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Boston Marathon Bomber to Be Formally Sentenced in June, but Process Is Far From Over
text: BOSTON — Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who last week was condemned to death for his role in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, is to be formally sentenced late next month by Judge George A. O’Toole Jr., who presided over the four-month trial.

headline: Gay Marriage on Ballot Shows Shift in Irish Attitudes
text: DUBLIN — If there was any doubt about the pace at which acceptance of gay rights is taking root in societies around the world, consider Ireland.

headline: S.U.V. Driver’s Wife on Attack by Bikers: ‘We Needed to Get Out of There’
text: A woman who was attacked along with her husband by a gang of bikers on the West Side Highway said on Tuesday that the motorcyclists were using knife handles to hammer on a window of their car just before her husband raced away, running over one of the men and breaking his spine.

headline: White House Won’t Upend ISIS Strategy
text: WASHINGTON — The White House on Tuesday defended President Obama’s strategy for countering Islamic State militants in Iraq, arguing that while the group’s capture of the provincial capital of Ramadi had been a setback, it should not be taken as a broader sign that the American approach is failing.

headline: N.B.A. Draft Lottery: Timberwolves Get First Pick, Knicks Fall to Fourth
text: Steve Mills, the general manager of the Knicks, leaned back in his chair and sighed as ESPN went to its final commercial break Tuesday night during the N.B.A.’s annual draft lottery. The order of the top three teams had yet to be revealed, but Mills and the rest of civilization already knew that the Knicks would not be among them.

headline: Insurgents Continue Advance in Syria, Keeping Pressure on Government Forces
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Insurgents continued to advance in the Syrian province of Idlib on Tuesday, fighters and antigovernment activists said, keeping up pressure on government forces despite President Bashar al-Assad’s vow to force them out of territory they have seized in recent weeks.

headline: Lawmakers Back Broader Access to Contraceptives for Women in the Military
text: WASHINGTON — Both houses of Congress are moving to guarantee greater access to contraceptives for women in the military, actions that lawmakers say are prompted in part by concern about unplanned pregnancies in the armed forces.

headline: High Cost of Sovaldi Hepatitis C Drug Prompts a Call to Void Its Patents
text: Activists in several countries are seeking to void patents on the blockbuster hepatitis C drug Sovaldi, saying that the price being sought by the manufacturer, Gilead Sciences, was prohibitive.

headline: House Approves Short-Term Financing for Highways
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Tuesday approved a two-month extension of funding for transportation projects, setting up what could be a defining fight over money for highways and other infrastructure this summer after years of stopgap measures.

headline: Jim Kenney Wins Philadelphia’s Democratic Primary for Mayor
text: Jim Kenney, a former Philadelphia city councilman who has cast himself as a progressive in the mold of Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, handily defeated five other candidates to win the Democratic nomination for mayor Tuesday, which makes him the overwhelming favorite to be mayor when national Democrats gather in the city in 2016 to pick their nominee for president.

headline: David Letterman, Prickly Late-Night Innovator, Counts Down to His Exit
text: In 1988, a rising comic named Jerry Seinfeld went to the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park for a Christmas party for “Late Night With David Letterman.” Mr. Seinfeld had just made a deal to do a sitcom for NBC, and he buttonholed Mr. Letterman in the corner of the restaurant and asked him for advice.

headline: Snowden Sees Some Victories, From a Distance
text: WASHINGTON — For an international fugitive hiding out in Russia from American espionage charges, Edward J. Snowden gets around.

headline: Proposed Rule Seeks Details on Antibiotics in Livestock
text: In a step aimed at tackling the growing problem of antibiotic resistance, the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday proposed a rule that would require makers of drugs for livestock to detail their antibiotic sales by type of animal. The drug makers already have to report total sales of antibiotics, but under the new rule, they would have to specify how much is meant for use in cows, pigs, chickens, turkeys and other animals — information that would help shape policies to most effectively address problems particular to each species. Consumer health advocates applauded the move, but said sales data was only a rough proxy for data on use. A more important step, they said, would be to require farmers to report how much antibiotics they use.

headline: Wind Power Is Poised to Spread to All States
text: All 50 states could become wind energy producers, according to an Energy Department report released Tuesday, once the next generation of larger, taller turbines in development hits the market.

headline: Dr. David Sackett, Who Proved Aspirin Helps Prevent Heart Attacks, Dies at 80
text: Dr. David Sackett, whose clinical trials proved the value of taking aspirin in preventing heart attacks and strokes, and who helped pioneer the use of exacting statistical data in treating patients, died on May 13 in Markdale, Ontario. He was 80.
