text: President Pierre Nkurunziza announced on Wednesday that parliamentary and local elections scheduled for May 26 would be postponed until June 5. But the delay may not affect the protests against Mr. Nkurunziza’s decision to seek a third term. “It is a unilateral decision, and it may be rejected because it was not based on the consensus of all political parties and partners,” said Simeon Barumwete, a professor at the University of Burundi. On Wednesday, a soldier who was part of a group of troops trying to prevent clashes between protesters and the police was shot and killed by a police officer, witnesses said. At least 20 people have been killed in recent weeks, and more than 50,000 people have fled the country.

headline: Tourist From Spain Is Killed by Bus in Manhattan
text: A 68-year-old woman visiting New York City from Spain was killed on Wednesday when a charter bus struck her as she tried to cross a street in Upper Manhattan, the police said.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage and the Irish Catholic Church
text: As Ireland considers legalizing gay marriage, will Irish Catholicism be able to maintain its moral and political authority?

headline: Jeb Bush Opens Up About Mother-in-Law’s Alzheimer’s
text: BEDFORD, N.H. — At an event in Portsmouth, N.H. on Wednesday, Jeb Bush raised his hand, acknowledging that he too had a loved one with Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Yemen: Houthi Leader Is Open to Talks
text: The leader of the Houthi rebel movement said in a televised speech on Wednesday that he was willing to conduct negotiations in a “neutral country” to end Yemen’s nearly two-month-old armed conflict. The comments by the leader, Abdel-Malik al-Houthi, suggested that the Houthis might take part in talks, sponsored by the United Nations, that were announced Wednesday and scheduled to be held in Geneva on May 28. The talks would be the first between Yemen’s warring parties since late March, when a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia began an air offensive to drive the Houthis from territory they had captured. The pace of the fighting has accelerated since Sunday, when a brief cease-fire arranged to deliver relief supplies expired and the Saudi-led coalition resumed airstrikes. More than 1,800 people have been killed since mid-March, and more than half a million Yemenis have been displaced, according to the United Nations.

headline: Puffy, Feathered Sticking Point of a $612 Billion House Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Bruce Westerman, an Arkansas Republican, spoke for many Americans this week when he conceded during a House hearing that he had never laid eyes on a sage grouse. Had he seen one, he surmised, he would have thought “a bobwhite quail got friendly with a Dominecker hen.”

headline: Review: ‘Macbeth,’ Accelerated, at Public Theater
text: There’s very little creeping in the Public Theater’s Mobile Shakespeare Unit production of “Macbeth.” And the pace the director Edward Torres sets isn’t exactly petty. Part of a project dedicated to bringing Shakespeare to underserved audiences, this sped-up and slimmed-down tragedy toured prisons, shelters and community centers before bundling its witches and thanes back to Lafayette Street.

headline: Review: ‘Permission’ and Spankings at the Lucille Lortel Theater
text: The sex farce has all but disappeared from the contemporary stage, and those of you mourning its demise (Hello out there?) may want to check out “Permission,” the new play by Robert Askins, author of the darkly subversive “Hand to God,” now on Broadway. In Mr. Askins’s sex comedy with a twist — or rather a kink — two God-loving young couples discover corporal punishment as a way of spicing up their sex lives, or alleviating the tensions in their marriages, or a little of both.

headline: Metaphor For Fun
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — We get a lot of mail about The New York Times Crossword and central to some of these lighthearted missives is the message, “How dare you?”

headline: Climate Change Is a Threat, Obama Says
text: As part of his commencement address at the Coast Guard Academy on Wednesday, the president described climate change as a “serious threat to global security.”

headline: Mayor de Blasio Is Said to Pick Longtime Friend as Press Secretary
text: Karen Hinton, a veteran communications consultant and a longtime friend of Mayor Bill de Blasio, is expected to become his press secretary as early as next month, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: France Says Troops Killed Qaeda Commander in Mali
text: On Nov. 2, 2013, two French journalists were grabbed in the troubled northern Malian town of Kidal. Hours later, their bodies were found on a dirt track, lying near their kidnapper’s car, which had a broken steering wheel.

headline: Missouri: Michael Brown Memorial Is Removed for Road Work
text: A makeshift memorial to Michael Brown in the middle of a Ferguson street was removed to allow paving, and a permanent tribute will be installed, city officials said Wednesday. The collection of stuffed animals, written messages and other items accumulated on Canfield Drive since Mr. Brown was fatally shot by a Ferguson police officer last August. Wednesday would have been Mr. Brown’s 19th birthday, and his father, Michael Brown Sr., said at a news conference with Ferguson officials that the time had come for the memorial to move. Mayor James Knowles III said the local chapter of the Urban League would temporarily store items from the memorial. Mr. Knowles said crews would begin repaving Canfield this week.

headline: Florida: Judge Faces Suspension Over Threat to Public Defender
text: A judicial review panel recommended a four-month suspension for Judge John C. Murphy of Brevard County, who was caught on video last year berating and threatening to assault a public defender. The six-member Florida Judicial Qualifications Commission, in findings released Wednesday, unanimously found Judge Murphy guilty of violating various judicial canons, including being “dignified and courteous to litigants, jurors, witnesses, lawyers, and others.” The panel also recommended a fine of up to $50,000, a public reprimand and Judge Murphy’s continued participation in a mental health therapy program. He is accused of hitting a former assistant public defender, Andrew Weinstock, outside a courtroom last June after they exchanged words over whether Mr. Weinstock’s client could have a speedy trial. The Florida Supreme Court will decide on the final punishment. It often adopts the panel’s recommendations. In video and audio recorded inside the courtroom, Judge Murphy is heard expressing frustration at Mr. Weinstock after he announced his intention not to waive the speedy trial right of his client. “You know, if I had a rock, I would throw it at you right now,” the judge said at one point. (AP)

headline: Excerpts From Bin Laden’s Papers
text: Here are excerpts from documents seized from the compound in Pakistan where Osama bin Laden was killed.

headline: Owner of American Pharoah Is Fighting Lawsuit Amid Triple Crown Bid
text: While American Pharoah has been winning six of his seven races and making his way to a historic bid next month for thoroughbred racing’s Triple Crown, his owner, Ahmed Zayat, has been contesting a federal lawsuit brought by a felon that alleges Mr. Zayat has failed to pay a $2 million debt he ran up betting via a website in Costa Rica.

headline: Foul Fly Ball Lands With Thud, as Do Yankees
text: WASHINGTON — For 18 seasons, Carlos Beltran has played baseball with a casual grace that sometimes makes a difficult game look effortless. When Beltran was stroking home runs, running the bases or gliding across the outfield to steal away hits, he looked to have a gift that others did not.

headline: Inquiry Finds Misconduct by a Top Surgeon, Paolo Macchiarini
text: An investigation in Sweden into a surgeon who is a pioneer in the field of regenerative medicine has found that he committed scientific misconduct by omitting or falsifying information about the conditions of three patients in medical journals.

headline: Lightning Stun Rangers in Overtime to Take Series Lead
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The sixth and final shot that eluded Henrik Lundqvist on Wednesday night, the shot that nudged his team a little closer toward oblivion, whistled toward him from between the circles. Lundqvist had saved faster shots and heavier shots and closer shots — a breakaway, just a minute earlier — but this puck he just could not track, and he did not even see it as it sailed past him.

headline: No Charges for 15 Students in Sex Case
text: LOS ANGELES — County prosecutors announced Wednesday that they would not bring charges against 15 Venice High School students arrested in March on sex-related accusations involving two underage girls, saying there was insufficient evidence.

headline: Rough Night for Bartolo Colon, and the Rest of the Mets
text: Dan Warthen, the Mets’ pitching coach, stayed in the dugout as the first signs of trouble came for Bartolo Colon. St. Louis’s leadoff batter, Kolten Wong, lined a single into center, and the Cardinals kept making solid contact, but Colon has a history of working out of these situations.

headline: Matthew Weiner on the Coke Ad and the Meaning of ‘Mad Men’
text: Here is audio and video of the Matthew Weiner talk at the New York Public Library.

headline: David Letterman, Ending an Era, Goes for Laughs Instead of Tears
text: There were jokes cracked and tributes paid. There were retrospectives and reminiscences, and a rock band that played at maximum volume. There was, of course, one last Top 10 list, delivered by a parade of celebrity guests.

headline: A Photographer Used to Looking Out Looks Into Her Space
text: Pointing to the large panes that line the street-side wall of her Chelsea home and studio, the photographer Gail Albert Halaban explains the provenance of her celebrated “Out My Window” series. “When my daughter was little, I used to feed her late at night while looking out, and on her first birthday, the shop across the street sent me balloons and flowers, but I’d never met them. They’d seen us the entire year and they noticed that people were over and having cake, so it must be a birthday party. It totally inspired the project.”

headline: Hong Hao Photographs Things (Well, Everything)
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: April Bloomfield’s Secrets for Prepping Vegetables
text: April Bloomfield, who once admitted to T that culinary school was a mere backup plan, believes that seasonal, veggie-centric recipes can and should be as fulfilling as meat-driven dishes. It’s the subject of her newest cookbook, “A Girl and Her Greens” ($35, Ecco), in which she shares recipes and tips for preparing, as the cover promises, “hearty meals from the garden.” In the above video, the chef — and co-owner of the Spotted Pig, Breslin Bar & Dining Room, John Dory Oyster Bar and Salvation Taco in New York; and Tosca Cafe in San Francisco — reveals simple steps to prep portobello mushrooms, Brussels sprouts and artichokes before cooking them. And to show off your new skills, a recipe from her book follows.

headline: Pop-Up Dining Down in New Orleans
text: By serving exceptional food in unexpected locations, the supper club scene steals the culinary spotlight in the Big Easy.

headline: Epix Joining the World of Scripted TV With Two Original Series
text: There were 352 original, scripted television series last year on broadcast, cable and streaming services. None were televised on Epix, the premium television network known for its selection of movies.

headline: Bidding Farewell to a Marquee Name
text: Brian Hawkins and Kathleen Kennedy of Folly Beach, S.C., before the final taping of the “Late Show With David Letterman” in Manhattan on Wednesday.

headline: Word of the Day | nexus
text: nexus • \ˈnek-səs\ • noun

headline: Cavaliers, Behind ‘Great Guy’ J.R. Smith, Grab Lead Over Hawks
text: ATLANTA — After the Cleveland Cavaliers obtained J. R. Smith from the Knicks in a three-team trade in early January, Smith, a gifted but capricious guard, accompanied his new coach, David Blatt, to dinner.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) RED NOSE DAY This British Comic Relief fund-raising campaign — created by the charity worker Jane Tewson and the director Richard Curtis (“Love Actually,” “Notting Hill”), and first broadcast on Christmas Day 1985 from a refugee camp in Sudan — crosses the ocean. In this three-hour event Will Ferrell, Jennifer Hudson, Jack Black, John Krasinski, Emily Blunt, Gwyneth Paltrow, Christina Aguilera, John Legend and Sam Smith, present comedy, music and videos produced by Funny or Die on behalf of 12 nonprofit organizations aiding poor children in the United States and abroad.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Who should we contact in case you become a martyr?”

headline: Editors’ Note: May 21, 2015
text: An article on Dec. 12, 2014, reported on a study published by the journal Science that said gay political canvassers could change conservative voters’ views on gay marriage by having a brief face-to-face discussion about the issue. The editor in chief of the journal said on Wednesday that the senior author of the study had now asked that the report be retracted because of the failure of his fellow author to produce data supporting the findings. An article about the latest developments is on Page A16.

headline: Osama Bin Laden’s Bookshelf Reflects His Fixation on West
text: Among the books, periodicals and letters found in Osama bin Laden’s hide-out in Pakistan was a copy of the former C.I.A. officer Michael Scheuer’s 2004 book, “Imperial Hubris: Why the West Is Losing the War on Terror,” which describes the founder of Al Qaeda as “the most respected, loved, romantic, charismatic and perhaps able figure in the last 150 years of Islamic history.”

headline: Q. and A.: Liu Heung Shing on the New Shanghai Center of Photography
text: The Hong Kong-born photographer Liu Heung Shing has long been known for documenting China and pursuing media ventures from a perch in Beijing. For many years, he lived in a restored courtyard home near the Forbidden City and the leadership enclave of Zhongnanhai.

headline: The Best Latin American Photography
text: Mauricio Lima of Brazil has been named Photographer of the Year in the third Pictures of the Year Latin America contest. Daniele Volpe who is based in Guatemala was awarded second place and Alejandro Cegarra of Venezuela took third in the same category, while Daniel Rodriguez of Portugal was awarded an honorable mention.

headline: Openness on Trade Deal
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Candidate Like David Cameron?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Good Night, David Letterman
text: To the Editor:

headline: Children of the Japanese-American Internment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tubman Versus Jackson
text: Let’s discuss putting a picture of a woman on the $20 bill. But, first: How many of you remember Ivy Baker Priest?

headline: Of Bikers and Thugs
text: On Sunday, there was a deadly biker gang fight and massacre in Waco, Tex. Nine people were killed, and 18 others were injured.

headline: Revisiting the Roots of the Iraq War
New Blood-Donor Policy, Same Gay Stigma
text: LAST week, the Food and Drug Administration released highly anticipated draft recommendations that would allow gay men to donate blood after one year of celibacy. While an improvement from the current, highly criticized lifetime ban, the new policy, which was announced in December, still caters to fear and stigma rather than science. It should be reconsidered.

headline: The High Cost of Dirty Fuels
text: A new report from the International Monetary Fund makes a compelling case for why countries should end subsidies for fossil fuels: It would save millions of lives.

headline: The Power of Hope Is Real
text: An awkward truth for bleeding hearts like myself is that there has never been much rigorous evidence that outside aid can sustainably lift people out of poverty.

headline: What to Make of the Topsy-Turvy Bond Market
text: If you happen to trade bonds for a living, it is entirely understandable if you are feeling a little anxious these days.

headline: Test Yourself | The Solitude of N.H.L. Goalies
text: Below are several paragraphs from the May 20 article “N.H.L. Goalies Need Their Alone Time, er, Stretching Routines.”

headline: Telecom Italia Plans I.P.O. of Wireless Tower Unit
text: LONDON — Telecom Italia said on Thursday that it planned to sell up to 40 percent of its wireless telecommunications tower unit, Infrastrutture Wireless Italiane, in an initial public offering in Milan.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Monkeys Provide Clues to How Tool Use Developed
text: In “Monkeys Provide Clues to How Tool Use Developed,” James Gorman writes about new research on how primates use tools.

headline: Europcar Seeks Regulators’ Approval for I.P.O. in Paris
text: LONDON — The French rental car provider Europcar said on Thursday that it had filed for permission from French regulators for an initial public offering on Euronext in Paris.

headline: Moldova Eyes Russia’s Embrace as Flirtation With Europe Fades
text: CHISINAU, Moldova — Daniela Morari, a Foreign Ministry official who has been traveling her country trying to nudge Moldovans toward the European Union, has heard it all. People are worried that “if you join the E.U., everyone becomes gay” and that Brussels bureaucrats “won’t let you keep animals around your houses,” an alarming prospect in a largely rural country.

headline: U.S. and Cuba Extend Talks on Reopening Embassies
text: Despite a wave of optimism, United States and Cuban negotiators meeting in Washington on Thursday could not reach an accord on re-establishing long-fractured diplomatic ties but agreed to keep talking on Friday.

headline: In ‘Frida Kahlo: Art, Garden, Life,’ Nature Melds With the Artist Herself
text: THE first Frida moment occurs right off the bat in “Frida Kahlo: Art, Garden, Life” at the New York Botanical Garden.

headline: Harlem, Because Convenience Counts
text: Two years ago, objecting to a large pending rent increase for their one-bedroom TriBeCa apartment, Marianne and Erik Jansen moved to Dumbo, Brooklyn. For a one-bedroom in a former factory building, they paid $3,900 a month, slightly less than their TriBeCa rent would have been.

headline: How Good Are You at Saying Goodbye?
text: As David Letterman signs off as host of “Late Show,” his entire team that has been working together behind the scenes for decades will also be saying goodbye. Have you ever had to leave a team, friends or family members?

headline: A Meeting, Seeking a Truce
text: After Armoni Sexton was killed in a drive-by shooting, community members and members of rival gangs within Paterson, N.J., gathered to discuss the longstanding tribal dispute in the city.

headline: Too Late for a Basketball Prodigy, Paterson Seeks a Truce
text: PATERSON, N.J. — The combatants agreed to meet in a law office, in one of those ancient brick mills that cast shadows of Paterson’s flourishing past over its hard streets. This beef between up the hill and down the hill had to end, now that another child had died of gunfire. A basketball prodigy. A boy.

headline: Eurozone Economy Continues to Grow Modestly, Survey Finds
text: PARIS — The eurozone economy continues to expand at a modest pace, a survey of businesses showed on Thursday, though an apparent slowdown in Germany raised concerns about the strength of the recovery.

headline: Making Hay While the Sun Shines
text: Update: I’m reminded that How the Light Gets In is at Hay, but not part of the Hay Festival proper.

headline: Nobody Cares About the Deficit
text: Sitting here in the UK, where everyone continues to believe that budget deficits are the central issue despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary, it’s refreshing to look home once in a while and contemplate the utter collapse of the deficit-scold agenda.

headline: ‘Do No Harm,’ by Henry Marsh
text: My closest friend from medical school is a neurosurgeon, and I recently attended the wedding of his daughter. I was seated at a table with his associates when the conversation turned to our respective careers. I asked why they had chosen neurosurgery. A young member of the group said: “When you enter the brain, you’re seeing the soul. It’s amazing.” A senior neurosurgeon shook his head and disagreed. “It’s psychiatrists who see the soul — not us.” Later I posed the question to my friend. “The brain is the organ of cognition, perception, consciousness. When you operate, the stakes couldn’t be higher.” Not even for cardiac surgery? “The heart is just a muscle,” he replied.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Don’t Get Stuck
text: Good morning on this perfectly fine Thursday.

headline: Can China Take a Joke?
text: ‘Three, two, one, applause!” The audience in the Beijing studio cheered as excitedly as anyone could be expected to cheer for an empty stage. They had gathered on a January evening last year for a taping of “Is It True?” — a show broadcast on the Chinese state-run network CCTV2 and hosted by the comedian Joe Wong. Before Wong came out to tell jokes, the director, an energetic young man in white-framed glasses and a puffy vest, wanted to record the audience members’ reaction. “Don’t be too quiet,” he advised them. “This is a lively program.”

headline: Restaurant Report: Cantina 32
text: There are two rules to follow when dining at Cantina 32, a bistro on Porto’s popular pedestrian street, Rua das Flores: do not refuse the bread, and order the cheesecake.

headline: ‘The Blue Dress’
text: Long after my mother died, I found photographs of her with my father that I’d never seen, taken when she was only 21. Though I recognized her, there was something in her face unfamiliar to me. Looking at the pictures, I felt as I do reading this poem: the melancholy of knowing, as they could not have known then, all that was to come in their lives, each photograph an elegy for their past selves.

headline: Death in the Browser Tab
text: There you are watching another death on video. In the course of ordinary life — at lunch or in bed, in a car or in the park — you are suddenly plunged into someone else’s crisis, someone else’s horror. It arrives, absurdly, in the midst of banal things. That is how, late one afternoon in April, I watched Walter Scott die. The footage of his death, taken by a passer-by, had just been published online on the front page of The New York Times. I watched it, sitting at my desk in Brooklyn, and was stunned by it.

headline: The Presidio in San Francisco Presents a Fresh Face
text: The Army turned over the Presidio in San Francisco, the “guardian of the Golden Gate,” to the National Park Service in 1994. But many visitors today (and even longtime city-dwellers) aren’t familiar with the former military post’s status as a national park, or the fact that it hosts San Francisco’s only overnight campground, set in a high shady grove at the edge of the Pacific, or that it has 24 miles of public trails zigzagging through a fragrant 300-acre forest of eucalyptus, cypress and pine.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Uni-ball Signo UM-151
text: Writers are supposed to have some mystical bond with their pens. With solemn gravity, in places like Paris Review interviews, they are asked what they write with, as if their pen strokes were what readers ultimately consumed. At times, I feel as if I should have some weighty, burnished fountain pen that, as that ad for some luxury product goes, I don’t own but merely “look after for the next generation.” But as a left-­hander with world-­historically abysmal handwriting — in college, college, I once had to read an essay out loud to an indulgent professor from my exam blue book — I have never managed much affection for manual writing instruments.

headline: Hotel Review: The Dean
text: Doubles from $109.

headline: A Closer Look at Hillary Clinton’s Emails on Benghazi
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton last year provided the State Department with 55,000 pages of emails that she said were related to her work as secretary of state, all from the personal account she exclusively used while leading the department.

headline: Frantic Message as Palmyra, Syria, Fell: ‘We’re Finished’
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian Army soldier had long served in Palmyra, but he was on leave when he heard that Islamic State militants had attacked a village northeast of the desert city, killing dozens of his comrades. He sent frantic text messages, trying to reach them. No one answered.

headline: First Batch of Hillary Clinton Emails Captures Concerns Over Libya
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department is expected to release the first batch of emails from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s private email address in the coming days.

headline: Libya-Related Messages From Hillary Clinton’s Personal Email Account
text: The documents, obtained by The New York Times and presented here, represent about a third of the roughly 850 pages of emails from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s personal email account that have been turned over to the special House committee investigating the 2012 attacks in Benghazi.

headline: Today in Politics: Another Senate Cliffhanger as Holiday Approaches
text: Good Thursday morning from Washington. On the campaign trail, Republicans gather in Oklahoma City; Hillary Rodham Clinton has joined the legions of job seekers on LinkedIn; and Jeb Bush shares a tender moment in New Hampshire. But the focus is on the continued drama on Capitol Hill as a legislative knot has yet to untangle itself.

headline: Hillary Clinton Posts Business Bona Fides on LinkedIn
text: Running for president is essentially an exceptionally long job interview. So, on Thursday morning, Hillary Rodham Clinton joined LinkedIn, the social network intended to help people expand their professional network, and, occasionally, get a job.

headline: Morning Agenda: Heavy Fines for Foreign Exchange Collusion
text: HEAVY FINES FOR FOREIGN EXCHANGE COLLUSION | At big banks, foreign exchange trading seemed like the ideal business – relatively low risk for solid revenues. But “what seemed like the perfect business turned out to be the perfect breeding ground for crime,” Michael Corkery and Ben Protess write in DealBook. Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland pleaded guilty to a series of federal crimes over a scheme to manipulate the value of the world’s currencies, the Justice Department said Wednesday. A fifth bank, UBS, was also accused of foreign currency manipulation but was not criminally charged because it had alerted the Justice Department to possible misconduct. However, the accusations cost the bank an earlier nonprosecution agreement related to the manipulation of the London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor.

headline: Review: David Letterman Says Goodbye, With Self-Mockery and a Little Mush
text: “You know what I’m going to devote the rest of my life to?” David Letterman said on his last night as the host of the “Late Show” on CBS. “Social media.”

headline: During Tony Awards Season, Power Is in Their Hands
text: The 844 Tony voters are a varied, and quite busy, lot. Get to know six of them.

headline: Review: ‘Tomorrowland,’ Brad Bird’s Lesson in Optimism
text: My son briefly had a youth baseball coach whose way of inspiring his demoralized players was to stand at the dugout entrance screaming at them to have fun. “Tomorrowland,” Brad Bird’s energetic new film, a shiny live-action spectacle from Disney, reminds me of that guy. There is nothing casual or whimsical about this movie’s celebration of imagination, optimism and joy. On the contrary: It’s a determined and didactic argument in favor of all those things, and an angry indictment of everyone who opposes them.

headline: Secrets, the C.I.A. and The New York Times
text: Since 9/11, the United States’ “war on terror” has become the overarching news story of our time.

headline: Food Companies Fear Bird Flu May Cause Egg Shortages
text: With avian flu devastating a significant portion of the nation’s egg-laying hens, major food companies and restaurant chains are bracing for shortages and scouting the country to find alternative supply sources.

headline: Review: On Taylor Swift’s ‘1989’ Tour, the Underdog Emerges as Cool Kid
text: BOSSIER CITY, La. — Toward the end of Taylor Swift’s concert at the CenturyLink Center here on Wednesday night, she strapped on an electric guitar for the first time of the night and began playing some tart riffs while singing hungry little fillips. She was setting the stage for “We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together,” the 2012 song that became her first No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 and helped turn her inexorably away from country and toward pop megastardom.

headline: CVS Health Agrees to Buy Omnicare in $12.7 Billion Deal
text: As the American population gets older, pharmacies and other health care providers are increasingly positioning themselves to capitalize and serve the needs of this demographic. This group often needs drugs for chronic conditions like diabetes and heart disease, as well as lifesaving medications for sudden conditions like infections or pneumonia.

headline: Oil Again Fouling California Coast Near Site of Historic Spill
text: GOLETA, Calif. — Refugio State Beach is one of the treasures of the California coast, a little-known curve of beach in the hills that on weekends like this one — Memorial Day — would be sprinkled with people who made their way up from Santa Barbara, about 20 miles down the Pacific Coast.

headline: Tariffs Versus Currencies
text: While it’s not remotely in the same league as the execrable Daley op-ed, the CEA report in support of TPP is, as Josh Bivens notes, an odd document. It’s not wrong, or not mostly wrong — I don’t even share all of Bivens’s complaints. It’s just off-topic; at best, it’s a celebration of the results of all the trade liberalization that has taken place since the 1930s, and tells us nothing about policy when trade barriers are already very low, and “trade” agreements are actually about investment and intellectual property.

headline: A Call for a Doctor
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Highlights From David Letterman’s Last ‘Late Show’
text: After a presidential montage proclaiming that “our long national nightmare is over,” David Letterman closed out a 33-year run in late-night television on Wednesday night.

headline: This Time, Senate Votes to Advance Trade Pact
text: WASHINGTON — A flurry of last-minute deal-making on the Senate floor Thursday rescued President Obama’s ambitious trade agenda from defeat, advancing legislation that would empower the president to complete a sweeping, 12-nation Pacific trade accord.

headline: Heads of Deutsche Bank Try to Assuage Shareholders
text: Top executives of Deutsche Bank tried to reassure increasingly restive shareholders on Thursday that they were making progress on cutting costs, delivering more consistent profits and avoiding legal problems that have cost Germany’s largest bank billions of euros in fines and settlements.

headline: Next Wave at BAM: New Season to Include Binoche, Whelan, Soto and Kentridge
text: Juliette Binoche will play the title role in “Antigone” in a production that premiered at the Grand Théâtre de Luxembourg. Wendy Whelan and Jock Soto will dance in the world premiere of a new dance-chamber opera inspired by a Noh drama, “Hagoromo.” And the Debussy String Quartet will play Shostakovich while Australian acrobats perform tricks all around them.

headline: Decoding the Cult Designs of Phoebe English
text: Since the launch of her eponymous label in 2011, Phoebe English has spun a series of darkly compelling womenswear collections in tenderly draped silhouettes and hand-woven textiles. Now, the mind-boggling methods and concepts behind her cult creations are the subject of a dedicated exhibition at London’s NOW Gallery in “Floating, Falling, Drowning, Flying – An Introspective of Process.” “I like to think of it as a sneak peek behind the scenes of creating my pieces,” says English, who’s based in London. “It’s been an exposing, nostalgic and wonderful experience.”

headline: Lumber Liquidators Chief Robert Lynch Resigns
text: Lumber Liquidators, under scrutiny for months as it faces accusations that it sold products with dangerous levels of formaldehyde, said on Thursday that its chief executive had left the company.

headline: Another Spying Scandal in Germany Adds to Political Crisis for Merkel
text: BERLIN — Eleven years ago, as the Iraq war raged, the National Security Agency quietly turned over to its German counterpart a sprawling electronic spying station in Bavaria. The transfer came with a deal: In consultation with the Americans, German spies would continue operating the station to intercept communications in Europe and the Middle East and share what they picked up.

headline: Daily Report: Minecraft Reality Shows, on YouTube
text: Minecraft is one of the most successful video games in the world, with more than 100 million registered users. YouTube is the top video site in the world, with a billion unique visitors a month, writes Nick Wingfield.

headline: Mike Huckabee Opts Out of Iowa Straw Poll Ritual
text: The Iowa Straw Poll is poised to be a slimmed-down affair this year, now that two leading Republicans have opted out of participating in the caucus state ritual.

headline: Hundreds of Volunteers, Armed With Fliers, Tell Nail Salon Workers of Their Rights
text: Hundreds of volunteers fanned out across New York on Thursday morning as part of an outreach campaign for nail salon workers organized by city officials, with the goal of reaching thousands of manicurists by day’s end and educating them about their rights and how to protect their health.

headline: Two Same-Sex Marriage Studies, Two Debunkings
text: Everything you’ve read about same-sex marriage is wrong.

headline: How ISIS Expands
text: The Islamic State aims to build a broad colonial empire across many countries.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Speeches Often Well Received Despite the Price
text: Critics of Hillary Rodham Clinton have been deriding the steep fees that she commands on the corporate speaking circuit, and even though the former secretary of state speaks publicly for free these days, the big companies that paid hundreds of thousands of dollars to hear her talk say she was worth the money.

headline: 1915: Italy’s Troops Massing for War
text: LONDON — The Italian Senate this afternoon [May 21] unanimously ratified the bill which Signor Salandra presented to the Chamber yesterday, which is tantamount to a declaration of war. Everybody inside the building was shouting ‘‘Evviva Italia!’’ except two men in prominent positions, one Principe di Camporeale, and Signor Cefaly, an intimate of the Villa Malta. From the public galleries came shouts of ‘‘Shame!’’ but the prince and his colleague took no notice. The Senators agreed unanimously to grant Signor Salandra’s request that a commission of eighteen members be appointed to examine the bill passed by the Chamber. — The New York Herald, European Edition, May 22, 1915

headline: Throwback Thursday | Thirty-Three Years With David Letterman
text: David Letterman hosted his 6,028th and final late-night show on May 20th, ending as he started, Times television critic Alessandra Stanley notes, “with the irreverence, self-mockery and mischief that made him such an iconoclastic talk-show host.”

headline: Documenting My Patients’ Next of Kin
text: What if a patient dies and nobody is there to mourn? Is it like a tree falling soundlessly in the forest?

headline: Conference Finalists Are Dotted With Knicks’ Castoffs
text: A sharpshooting 3-point specialist, a defensive stopper, a 7-foot starter, a veteran steal artist, a feisty starting forward and a solid backup. It sounds like the elements of a pretty good Knicks playoff team.

headline: Making Computer Science More Inviting: A Look at What Works
text: When Sonja Khan started college, she’d never thought of studying computer science. But when she heard from friends that the intro class was good, she decided to give it a try — and then ended up majoring in it.

headline: How To | Prep Vegetables
text: The chef and cookbook author April Bloomfield invites T into her kitchen.

headline: A Meeting, Seeking a Truce
text: After Armoni Sexton was killed in a drive-by shooting, community members and members of rival gangs within Paterson, N.J., gathered to discuss the longstanding tribal dispute in the city.

headline: New York Council Speaker Raises Profile in Police Dispute With Mayor de Blasio
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s budget proposal made his intention clear: There would be no new money to expand the size of the New York police force.

headline: Jeb Bush Faults Brother for Lack of Budget Discipline
text: CONCORD, N.H. – As Jeb Bush has faced questions over Iraq and the policies of his brother throughout recent days, he found one place where there is a policy difference between the two: curtailing spending.

headline: Mystery Shrouds Movements of Suspect in Tunisia Museum Attack
text: ROME — New information about a Moroccan man arrested in Italy this week in connection with the attack at the National Bardo Museum in Tunis that killed 22 people has raised questions about his movements and the depth of his possible involvement in the March 18 assault.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Sells 51% Stake in China Unit to Tsinghua University
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hewlett-Packard announced on Thursday that it had sold a majority stake in its Chinese networking business to Tsinghua University, in a move to deal with Chinese government restrictions on foreign technology companies.

headline: 1940: ‘Save France’ Call by Reynaud
text: The famous watchword of the French Revolution — the cry that saved France at Valmy — was evoked by Premier Paul Reynaud yesterday [May 21] afternoon, when, addressing the Senate, he declared: ‘‘Messieurs, la patrie est en danger.’’ Making no attempt to minimize the gravity of the situation, the French Premier informed the Senators that the Germans had reached Amiens and Arras yesterday morning. ‘‘If I am told that tomorrow a miracle must be produced to save France, then I believe in the miracle, because France cannot die.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 22, 1940

headline: Summer Travel Gear Inspired by African Methods
text: The designers behind MZ Wallace, Monica Zwirner and Lucy Wallace Eustice, create simple, utilitarian accessories made from durable nylon and leather that, each season, are slightly tweaked by way of unique collaborations and the introduction of new prints (last month they partnered with Charity: Water on a line of pouches and cases to celebrate Earth Day). This month, MZ Wallace is releasing a capsule collection of summer travel gear, including a luggage tag and passport holder, in African batik-inspired patterns. The dizzying prints are also inspired by “More Material,” the exhibition the globally minded designer Duro Olowu curated at Salon 94 Bowery last year, for which he organized textiles, art and fashion all featuring similar motifs. Zwirner and Eustice also took notes from the Austrian artist Franz West, who used tribal wax prints for furniture coverings in the late ’80s. The two patterns used in the collection of items, which also includes a tote bag, sunglasses case and wallet, drew on traditional African block printing and wax dyeing. Form meets function, indeed.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: Looking for something to do right now?

headline: British Police Find Jimmy Savile Case Has Spurred Reports of Child Sexual Abuse
text: LONDON — Jimmy Savile, the disgraced British television personality the authorities say sexually abused dozens of victims over more than two decades, died before he could be prosecuted. But new data released this week by the police suggests that revelations about his catalog of sexual misconduct have helped transform the attitudes of many victims and also led to a greater willingness to report abuse.

headline: U.S. Military Wraps Up Relief Effort for Nepal Earthquake
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — United States military personnel who had been assisting earthquake relief and rescue efforts in Nepal began leaving on Thursday, the Nepalese Army said.

headline: In Reversal, Myanmar Agrees to Attend Meeting on Migrant Crisis
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — After a flurry of diplomatic activity, the government of Myanmar said on Thursday that it would send representatives to a regional meeting in Bangkok next week aimed at resolving the continuing humanitarian crisis of migrants stranded at sea in Southeast Asia and addressing the larger issue of human trafficking.

headline: ‘Tomorrowland’ (With Movie Trailer): Brad Bird Narrates a Scene
text: In “Tomorrowland,” a girl gets a glimpse of a shimmering, optimistic other world. But it’s only a small piece of the complex puzzle this new Disney movie — directed by Brad Bird from a script by Mr. Bird, Damon Lindelof (“Lost”) and Jeff Jensen — lays out in its tale of the future and the ways it is being shaped. In the scene Mr. Bird is discussing, Casey Newton (Britt Robertson) is the daughter of a NASA engineer who has been helping tear down a launch site, meaning he will soon lose his job. Casey, a lover of space, sees the future she wants disappearing as well. After she is arrested for trying to sabotage the demolition, she gets out of jail and discovers an unfamiliar pin among her personal effects, one with special powers. In a recent interview, Mr. Bird discussed some of his ideas behind the sequence. Here are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Tomorrowland’
text: Brad Bird narrates a sequence from “Tomorrowland.”

headline: New Approach Trains Robots to Match Human Dexterity and Speed
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — In an engineering laboratory here, a robot has learned to screw the cap on a bottle, even figuring out the need to apply a subtle backward twist to find the thread before turning it the right way.

headline: Despair, and Grim Acceptance, Over Killings by Brazil’s Police
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Eduardo de Jesus was on his doorstep in Complexo do Alemão, a vast maze here of cinder block homes, when his mother heard the loud blast of gunfire.

headline: Readers Respond: On Errors, Lies and Mistakes in Iraq
text: As debate about the legitimacy of the Iraq War reopened this week, many readers argued that the war was wrong and based on falsified intelligence, even as a few wrote they are pleased that Saddam Hussein was deposed.

headline: A $1,000 Day in Paris for $100
text: Experience a concierge’s idea of the perfect day on the town in Paris, but at a tenth of the price.

headline: Family of Akai Gurley, Man Fatally Shot by Officer in Brooklyn, Sues New York City
text: The family of Akai Gurley, the unarmed man shot and killed in a Brooklyn housing-project stairwell by a police officer last year, has filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against New York City.

headline: At Cannes, Director of Holocaust Film Criticizes Conventional Approach of ‘Schindler’s List’
text: CANNES, France — “Son of Saul,” a first feature by the Hungarian director Laszlo Nemes set at Auschwitz in 1944, has generated some of the strongest reviews of any film shown in competition at this year’s Cannes Film Festival — but also some of the most intense controversy.

headline: Unesco Chief Urges Protection of Palmyra
text: Irina Bokova, the director general of Unesco, on Thursday called for a cease-fire in and around Palmyra, the central Syrian city that fell to ISIS on Wednesday and contains important ancient ruins.

headline: That Was Fast: One Lightning Line Is Ripping Up the Rangers
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Lightning Coach Jon Cooper could not contain the quip. He had just watched his top line of Tyler Johnson, Ondrej Palat and Nikita Kucherov maneuver around and through the Rangers for the second game in a row.

headline: Essays About Work and Class That Caught a College’s Eye
text: Of the 1,200 or so undergraduate admission essays that Chris Lanser reads each year at Wesleyan University, maybe 10 are about work.

headline: Students and Money, in Their Own Words
text: Each year, we put out a call for college application essays about money, work and social class. This year, we picked seven — about pizza, parental sacrifice, prep school students, discrimination and deprivation.

headline: Annabel La Riva | Finding My Voice
text: In her college essay, Annabel La Riva, a LaGuardia High School senior, writes about transcending class differences and finding her own voice through music. Ms. La Riva plans to attend Kenyon College.

headline: Lady Loafers for Summer
text: In a slimmer shape and with feminine details, this old man classic feels like the season’s staple.

headline: Azzedine Alaïa Designs a New Approach to Perfume
text: Azzedine Alaïa, a.k.a. my bet to design Lady Gaga’s wedding dress post-her Grammys appearance, doesn’t do anything on anyone’s schedule but his own. He doesn’t show during the regular ready-to-wear schedule (he doesn’t even show every season), he doesn’t always appear for interviews when promised, and he generally works through the night, while others are asleep.

headline: Arrest Made in Washington Killings
text: WASHINGTON — On a sunny Sunday afternoon in April, Savvas Savopoulos, a wealthy iron company executive well known to this city’s elite, gathered his family and friends in the backyard of his stately brick home to grill lamb on a spit and celebrate Greek Orthodox Easter. It was, one guest said, “an idyllic day.”

headline: Readers, Apparently Fond of a Good Thrashing, Respond to the Javelina Review
text: Why do people get so excited about a pan?

headline: Viewfinder: Hong Hao
text: The photographer keeps track of the items he consumes by assembling them in pictures.

headline: Next Stop for Republican Hopefuls: Oklahoma City
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Every weekend, it seems, there is another Republican presidential cattle call. This one is no different. But instead of bringing their ripest red-meat attacks and catchy one-liners to Iowa or New Hampshire again, the 2016 hopefuls are descending on this state capital.

headline: Some Relics Safe, Syrian Official Says
text: The Syrian antiquities chief, Maamoun Abdulkarim, said Wednesday that while many artifacts from Palmyra had been moved to safety, the question remained how to protect the site from ISIS.

headline: The Dirt on Dirt
text: My mother-in-law often gossips with me about other people’s personal difficulties. She’ll say: “Bob and Sue are childless because Bob is sterile.” It makes me feel uncomfortable, as if I’m invading these people’s privacy. When she starts to do it, I go quiet or look away to signal my discomfort. But she keeps going. Is there a more direct but civil way to let her know I don’t want to hear these stories?

headline: Tara Subkoff’s Cannes Travel Diary
text: The designer recently visited the South of France to premiere her new film, "#Horror.”

headline: Yale Graduate Who Promoted CrossFit Ventures Is Arrested
text: A serial entrepreneur with a Yale undergraduate degree and a penchant for raising money for his ventures from fellow graduates is finding himself answering to authorities.

headline: Danica Patrick Has Plenty of Fans. A New Sponsor? Not Yet.
text: CONCORD, N.C. — Amid the mass of Dale Earnhardt Jr. and Jeff Gordon fans at Charlotte Motor Speedway last Saturday night, with their allegiances loudly emblazoned on T-shirts and hats, this much was apparent: Danica Patrick owned the preteen girl demographic.

headline: Living With Cancer: Patients on Our Own
text: I had to take my husband back to the hospital for a second operation on a torn tendon, but the pills from the cancer trial had not yet arrived. Surely doing without one or two days of the drug would not necessarily lead to a recurrence, I told myself in an effort to still rising waves of anxiety. There were more pressing matters to attend, namely righting wrongful care.

headline: Bangladesh’s Very Public Toilet Crisis
text: PEOPLE trapped in Dhaka’s notoriously gridlocked traffic have developed various coping strategies. Some take naps. Others work or catch up on social media.

headline: Crêpes Canaveral
text: Breton-style crepes on St. Marks Place.

headline: Crêpes Canaveral Spreads Itself Thin
text: On a drizzly evening, two glum young men peered into the shut window of Crêpes Canaveral. Above them hung a lantern, its candle still unlit. “You really want to go through this for a crepe?” one asked. They tromped off around the corner, but within a minute they had slunk back to wait with the rest of us in the rain.

headline: Maggie Black, Teacher to the Stars of Ballet and Modern Dance, Dies at 85
text: Maggie Black, who for decades earned renown for teaching famous ballet and modern dancers how to move in ways, as she put it, that “humans weren’t really made to do,” configuring their bodies to avoid injuries and even to heal them, died on May 11 at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 85.

headline: A Makeover for Brooklyn Marriott
text: Opened in 1998, the New York Marriott at the Brooklyn Bridge predated the wave of hotels that have more recently opened in the booming borough. Now, with a $43 million budget, it aims to update its appeal.

headline: Schools Turn to Propane Buses as Stricter Emissions Standards Loom
text: MACON, Ga. — For many Americans, propane is that stuff from the home improvement store that fuels backyard barbecues and patio dinners. But in a growing number of cities across the country, it is what gets children to school.

headline: Sexually Explicit 3-D  Film Inspires Pans and Walkouts at Cannes
text: CANNES, France — “Love,” a pornographic 3-D film by Gaspar Noé, includes scenes of penetration, mutual masturbation and a penis ejaculating in 3-D toward the audience. Nevertheless, it failed to excite critics, who roundly panned the film, or walked out of a press screening, when it was shown at the Cannes Film Festival out of competition on Thursday.

headline: Members of Congress Ask for Review of Dropped Espionage Case
text: Twenty-two members of Congress have asked Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch to determine whether race played a factor in espionage-related charges brought against a Chinese-American hydrologist and are asking her to investigate whether there is a practice of targeting federal employees based on their race or national origin.

headline: Family Tree of Dogs and Wolves Is Found to Split Earlier Than Thought
text: The ancestors of modern wolves and dogs split into different evolutionary lineages 27,000 to 40,000 years ago, much earlier than some other research has suggested, scientists reported Thursday.

headline: Edna O’Brien: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “The Love Object” says Joyce staked his claim on Dublin, and it was left to Yeats, J. M. Synge and Beckett “to give us the landscape of the country in all its beauty, savagery, ghostliness and loneliness.”

headline: Producer Speaks Out About Editing Ferrara Film
text: CANNES, France — The director Abel Ferrara made headlines in March when he publicly objected to a revised edit of “Welcome to New York,” his fictional take on the sexual assault case involving Dominique Strauss-Kahn and a Manhattan hotel maid.

headline: Rosé Wine From Provence Deserves to Live a Little
text: ÉVENOS, France — On a visit to Château Ste.-Anne, a venerable family producer of naturally made Bandols near this old hilltop village, I was doing what comes so naturally in Provence: drinking a glass of rosé and eating a square of pissaladière, the pizzalike flatbread whose primary toppings — onions, olives and anchovies — are as essential to the Provençal landscape as pastel skies and sun-drenched seas.

headline: Maryland Drops Parallel Parking From Driver’s Test
text: Maryland has announced that demonstrating the ability to parallel park will no longer be a requirement for obtaining a driver’s license in that state.

headline: Boy Scouts’ President Calls for End to Ban on Gay Leaders
text: Robert M. Gates, the president of the Boy Scouts of America and former secretary of defense, called on Thursday to end the Scouts’ ban on gay adult leaders, warning the group’s executives that “we must deal with the world as it is, not as we might wish it to be.”

headline: Reader Idea | Biographical Poetry About Maya Angelou
text: Maya Angelou died a year ago this month, and though we quickly created a page of teaching resources from what was available at the time, we knew that many teachers were also holding their own impromptu classroom memorials.

headline: Obama’s Twitter Debut, @POTUS, Attracts Hate-Filled Posts
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama sent his inaugural Twitter post from the Oval Office on Monday, the White House heralded the event with fanfare, posting a photograph of him perched on his desk tapping out his message on an iPhone.

headline: Catholic Trust Looks to Brazilian Fund for Social Returns
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A Brazilian investment fund is taking to heart the Vatican’s endorsement of leveraging capitalism’s tools to help address inequality.

headline: Officials Discuss California Oil Spill
text: “We are committed to the thorough cleanup of this accident,” a spokesman for the responsible company said.

headline: Bryce Harper Offers Reminder of the Yankees of Old, Not of the Old Ones of Today
text: WASHINGTON — When Bryce Harper, the Washington Nationals outfielder, was ejected from Wednesday’s game against the Yankees after arguing a low strike, there was no celebration in the Yankees’ dugout. No high-fives. No fist pumps.

headline: Going Rogue and Bizarre at the Republican Debates
text: With more Republicans jumping into the presidential race by the week, the party’s top leaders are growing increasingly fearful that their presidential debates, which start this summer, will be more cattle call than Lincoln-Douglas.

headline: Buying Self-Confidence (and Belts) at Taekwondo
text: My 5-year-old son bounced toward me with his new trophy and his bright-white taekwondo belt that he had just received from his master. “Mama, look, I did it,” he said, beaming, as we embraced. “We are so proud of you,” my husband said as he took a turn hugging him.

headline: David Letterman Finale Draws Almost 14 Million Viewers in Ratings
text: David Letterman closed out his 33 years in late-night television on Wednesday with one of the highest-rated shows of his career. “The Late Show” brought in 13.7 million viewers, Mr. Letterman’s biggest audience since February 1994. It also beat every network show in prime time on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Drifting in Daylight’ and ‘Please Touch the Art’
text: A look at works in the free exhibition in Central Park.

headline: Tara Subkoff Does Cannes
text: The designer Tara Subkoff, best known for co-founding Imitation of Christ, is no stranger to the film world — she’s acted in dozens of films, from “As Good as It Gets” to “The Last Days of Disco” — or to ambitious, theatrical, large-scale projects. So it was a natural next step for Subkoff to try her hand at directing. Her new film, “#Horror,” stars Taryn Manning, Natasha Lyonne, Lydia Hearst, Stella Schnabel and Chloë Sevigny (whom Subkoff once enlisted, you may remember, as the creative director for Imitation of Christ); it tells a story of social media gone wrong and cyberbullying taken to nasty extremes. Subkoff just premiered the film at the Cannes Film Festival, where she found plenty to do — from glamorous pool time at the Hotel du Cap to a haunted-house party she hosted at Le Baron, which drew Benicio Del Toro, Michael Fassbender and Larry Gagosian. In the spirit of the film, Subkoff also organized a powerful cyberbullying protest on the Croisette, with over 70 French girls aged 12 to 16 in attendance wearing masks and carrying signs, both of which were created by Subkoff’s husband, the artist Urs Fischer. The protest was shut down by French police (a sure sign, we’d say, that she made an impact). Above, Subkoff shares with T a pictorial record of her Cannes adventures.

headline: Tiny Life, Teeming in the Ocean
text: New findings about microbes collected from the world’s oceans provide insights into creatures directly descended from those of a billion years ago.

headline: Scientists Sample the Ocean and Find Tiny Additions to the Tree of Life
text: Climate change scientists have known for years that rising temperatures affect sea creatures, from the biggest fish to the microscopic plankton at the base of the ocean food chain.

headline: Obama Upgrades Tunisia’s Status as a U.S. Ally
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Thursday that he would designate Tunisia a major American ally as he encourages the North African country in its progress toward a more democratic form of government since the Arab Spring uprisings of 2011.

headline: Rand Paul’s Timely Takedown of the Patriot Act
text: He may have annoyed Senate colleagues by seizing the floor for a marathon monologue on Wednesday, but Senator Rand Paul did Americans a singular service by forcing attention to the fact that their civil liberties remain at stake as Congress drifts toward a renewal of the Patriot Act that is likely to do too little to rein in government surveillance programs.

headline: Where New Rules on Police and Military Gear Fall Short
text: Some police departments around the country have morphed into military combat units since 9/11, thanks to military weapons and equipment that have been freely passed onto them by the federal government. The danger this represents for police-community relations was strikingly evident last year in Ferguson, Mo., where demonstrators protesting the police shooting of Michael Brown encountered what was essentially a war machine clothed in body armor, equipped with combat weapons and perched atop armored vehicles.

headline: Defending ISIS Policy, Obama Acknowledges Flaws in Effort So Far
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama denied that the United States and its allies were losing the fight against Islamic State forces in the Middle East, but he acknowledged in an interview posted online on Thursday that more should be done to help Iraqis recapture lost territory.

headline: 2 Men Captured in Ukraine Admit to Being Russian Soldiers, Monitoring Group Says
text: MOSCOW — The Ukrainian government’s assertion that the Russian military is fighting in eastern Ukraine was given some credence on Thursday by an independent security monitoring group.

headline: Tiny Life, Teeming in the Ocean
text: New findings about microbes collected from the world’s oceans provide insights into creatures directly descended from those of a billion years ago.

headline: Senator’s Deal Helps Advance Trade Bill
text: The fate of a free trade bill — a major economic priority for the White House, Congressional Republicans and some Senate Democrats — remained highly uncertain on Thursday morning as lawmakers huddled in tense negotiations in the well of the Senate.

headline: Man Who Intervened in Manhattan Biker Assault Testifies
text: A Washington Heights man who intervened as a gang of motorcyclists was beating the driver of a sport utility vehicle testified on Thursday that he still did not know why the attackers listened to him.

headline: ‘The Assassin’ Director on Long Takes, Fast Edits and a Warrior in the Shadows
text: CANNES, France — “The Assassin,” the thrillingly beautiful martial arts film from the Taiwanese master Hou Hsiao-Hsien, traces the adventures – as well as the poses, gestures and silences – of a ninth-century Chinese female warrior.

headline: A New Approach for Moving Robotic Arms With the Brain
text: More than a decade ago, Erik Sorto, 34, was paralyzed after a gunshot wound to the neck. Now, using a robotic arm that he controls with his brain, he can pick up a drink and bring it to his lips in one smooth motion.

headline: The Case of the Unhappy Naked Traveler
text: On Wednesday, a US Airways passenger at Charlotte Douglas International Airport, reportedly angry at being bumped from an overbooked flight to Jamaica, stripped naked at the gate in protest.

headline: Review: Wael Shawky, ‘Cabaret Crusades’ at MoMA PS1
text: The most vivid depictions of a war in the Middle East aren’t on television news these days. They’re in an exhibition by the Egyptian artist Wael Shawky at MoMA PS1 in Queens. The show, “Cabaret Crusades,” Mr. Shawky’s local museum solo debut, is made up of three sequential films, each about an hour and set in the distant past, beginning in the 11th century when European armies marched eastward to claim the Holy Land. The story is one of almost unremitting violence, and the scenes of battle, torture and execution are appalling to witness, which is a surprise considering that all the actors are marionettes.

headline: Washington Mayor Names Murder Suspect
text: Mayor Muriel E. Bowser of Washington, and Cathy Lanier, chief of the Metropolitan Police Department, on Thursday identified the suspect in the murder of a household of four last week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza, Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Burundi, Gaza and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: F.E.C. Member Says System Tilts Against Conservative Groups
text: Political tensions intensified on Thursday at the Federal Election Commission, as a Republican commissioner charged that conservative groups were the focus of agency reviews into possible impropriety far more than liberal ones.

headline: Sunlight in a Bottle
text: In Tuscany and Puglia, making olive oil is a lifestyle, one threatened by bad weather and a killer bacteria.

headline: May 21, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Gaza City, Turkey, Burundi and Indonesia.

headline: Review: Megan Hilty Serves Up Some Sweet, Tender Bar Food
text: Behind the brass is a silk-and-lace lining. That was the happy discovery at Tuesday’s opening-night of Megan Hilty’s return engagement at Café Carlyle. Ms. Hilty will long be remembered for her portrayal of Lorelei Lee three years ago in the Encores! concert production of “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,” for which Ben Brantley of The New York Times credited her with “wresting Lorelei from the hands” of Marilyn Monroe and Carol Channing.

headline: Review: Music & More Series Explores Artistic Marriages
text: TriBeCa may have become one of New York’s most desirable neighborhoods to live and shop in, but one thing that’s in short supply there is music. Outside of upscale children’s birthday parties and the annual Tribeca Film Festival carnival, live performances are rare.

headline: Review: ‘Bound’ and ‘Ecsteriority4 (Part 2)’ Explore Confinement and Collision
text: The premise for Travelogues, a series at Abrons Arts Center, is simple and wide open: The curator Laurie Uprichard, formerly the director of Danspace Project and the Dublin Dance Festival, presents work that she has seen and admired, whether it’s from down the block or across the ocean.

headline: Jacob deGrom Throws Gem for Mets: 25 Cardinals Up, 24 Cardinals Down
text: Of all the things that went right for Terry Collins on Thursday, including a masterpiece from Jacob deGrom and two home runs from Lucas Duda, perhaps the best thing was a base hit by the opposing team.

headline: Review: Hope Gangloff at Susan Inglett Gallery
text: Hope Gangloff borrows liberally from her predecessors. Her large-scale portraits owe a huge debt to masters like Vincent van Gogh, Gustav Klimt and Egon Schiele, as well as Suzanne Valadon, Alice Neel and Sylvia Sleigh. Yet Ms. Gangloff is a shrewd assimilator, and her current show includes elements that make it one of the most topical in New York.

headline: CVS’s Deal for Omnicare May Signal a Slowdown in Pharmacy Mergers
text: CVS Health’s $12.7 billion deal for Omnicare portends lower merger activity in the pharmacy sector. The drugstore company’s purchase gives it entrance to nursing homes and expands specialty medicine distribution. But the increasingly concentrated industry is bumping up against antitrust concerns and may have to live with fewer transactions.

headline: Obama Says Tunisia Will Be Non-NATO Ally
text: President Obama hosted the democratically elected president of Tunisia, Beji Caid Essebsi, and announced that the country would become a “major non-NATO ally of the United States.”

headline: Your Contribution to the California Drought
text: The average American consumes more than 300 gallons of California water each week by eating food that was produced there.

headline: Exclusive | 315 Vanderbilt Avenue, Clinton Hill
text: A former union hall that was repurposed as a home/studio/gallery for the artist Jennifer Bartlett is about to enter the market at $8.5 million.

headline: When Every Day Is Memorial Day
text: Irked by how people treat Memorial Day like just another three-day weekend, Andrew Lichtenstein photographed military funerals for soldiers who died in Iraq.

headline: This Year’s Warm Up Parties at MoMA PS1 Offer a Lot of Electronic Music
text: The weekly summer dance parties known as Warm Up, held in the courtyard at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, will run every Saturday from June 27 to September 5, featuring live performances and D.J. sets from experimental musicians including Boys Noize, A.G. Cook of PC Music, Baauer (remember “Harlem Shake”?) and the English grime rapper Skepta.

headline: Cool Books for Hot Summer Days
text: Summer reading rarely involves as much déjà vu as it will this year. We’ll be reading a new Harper Lee book, “Go Set a Watchman,” only 55 years after the publication of “To Kill a Mockingbird.” We’ll still be looking for that next “Gone Girl,” the thriller fan’s equivalent of Ahab’s great white whale. We’ll be hit with “The Devil Wears Prada” knockoffs, including one that’s actually called “The Knockoff” and borrows just as freely from “All About Eve.” The Stephen King-type chiller, in which a famous writer falls prey to an obsessed fan (sound familiar?), will have been written by Stephen King. It’s called “Finders Keepers.”

headline: Video of Man Believed to Be Bike-Riding Thief Is Released
text: For the past few months, he has been making his way through the streets of Manhattan, approaching women and snatching their phones, or in some cases, their pocketbooks out of their hands. Then he leaves quickly, on a bicycle.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Reports Drop in Profit and Sales
text: Hewlett-Packard, the computer and printer giant, reported continued declines in profit and sales on Thursday as it prepared to split into two companies later this year.

headline: How to Improve Rail Safety
text: Americans who grow up with this country’s slow, limited and poorly maintained passenger train systems are typically stunned by the speed, comfort and punctuality of the trains that crisscross Europe and East Asia at speeds often greater than 200 miles per hour. It turns out that state-of-the art train systems abroad are also safer. A lot safer.

headline: Review: Vern Blosum, ‘Late Work’
text: Each of the 11 amusing, poster-size pencil drawings in this exhibition presents a neatly rendered object accompanied by block-lettered captions. The text below the image of a fly swatter reads “No Fly Zone.” “Obsolescence” shows a sidewalk mailbox with its open lower compartment revealing an empty interior, an allusion to the triumph of email. “Ideologues” is illustrated by a pile of decomposing logs. Curiously, a gallery news release says these and the show’s other drawings are the first works produced by Vern Blosum since 1964.

headline: Theater Listings for May 22-28
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Six Baltimore Officers Indicted in Death of Freddie Gray
text: A grand jury in Baltimore has indicted six police officers on homicide and assault charges in the death of Freddie Gray, who was fatally injured last month in police custody, the city’s chief prosecutor said Thursday.

headline: Review: Leidy Churchman, ‘The Meal of the Lion’
text: Leidy Churchman’s art comprises a range of mediums: painting, video, sculpture and installation. But painting and its infinite mutability are his main interest in this expansive solo show, his second at a New York gallery. Here, 19 canvases explore some of the subjects, styles, moods and meanings encompassed by representation, abstraction included. Materials and process receive acute attention. Most images evolved in some way from existing art, advertising or cartography, but personal imagination registers everywhere.

headline: Tattoo History, Antique Typewriters and Letting Go at the Toledo Museum
text: Curators and historians take a serious look at tattoos; the Toledo Museum of Art winnows its holdings; and a typewriter collection celebrates low-tech writing.

headline: Review: ‘Van Gogh: Irises and Roses,’ Sheds Light on a Disappearing Red Hue
text: Art is long, but color can be brief. That’s the message conveyed by “Van Gogh: Irises and Roses,” a small bouquet of paintings by the beloved Dutch artist at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Occupation Fables on DVD: ‘Le Silence de la Mer’ and ‘Vice and Virtue’
text: Compared with the atrocities perpetrated in World War II’s other theaters, the German occupation of France was, in the historian David Bell’s unsentimental characterization, a “sideshow.” Quentin Tarantino would never have set “Inglourious Basterds” in Poland; the Woody Allen character’s obsession with “The Sorrow and the Pity,” in “Annie Hall,” would hardly be so funny if he were fixated on “Schindler’s List.”

headline: Review: ‘Please Touch the Art’ and ‘Drifting in Daylight,’ Outdoor Art at the Parks
text: With the outdoor art season upon us, two inviting and entertaining exhibitions in different New York parks opened last weekend. Organized by the nonprofit Creative Time, “Drifting in Daylight: Art in Central Park,” in the north end of the park, presents mostly ephemeral projects by eight artists. Works by the Danish artist Jeppe Hein are at Brooklyn Bridge Park in a display of interactive sculptures called “Please Touch the Art,” organized by the Public Art Fund, another nonprofit. Neither show is going to rock anyone’s world, but both entail spending time in nice places.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: BAM Has a New Display of Michael Graves Murals
text: Though known primarily as an architect, Michael Graves was also an avid painter who, starting in the early 1970s, included his murals in his architecture projects.

text: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: The Who Celebrates 50 Years Together by Going on Tour
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Watching Pete Townshend’s hands as the Who played Nassau Coliseum here on Wednesday night was a reminder of what made the band great. His hands made bold windmill arcs, scrabbled at trills, picked off single notes and scampered through bluesy squiggles. They were masterly and strategic, defining the sound and structure of each song, yet still reckless. They were exploring, even now, the way his songs are awash in clashing impulses: rebellion, isolation, anger, uncertainty, yearning, fear, lust, frustration, brawling, searching. Three of Mr. Townshend’s many self-questioning manifestos — “I Can’t Explain,” “The Seeker” and “Who Are You” — started a set full of the Who’s surefire material.

headline: Jeb Bush Opens His Campaign Playbook by Opening Himself
text: BEDFORD, N.H. — His S.U.V.’s motor was running and an open door beckoned. But Jeb Bush, quite possibly the most media-friendly hopeful in the Republican presidential field, was not done answering questions.
