text: Shamir, a singer-songwriter from North Las Vegas, has just released his first album, “Ratchet.” He’s a 20-year-old with a high, light voice and a wide frame of reference, channeling a lean kind of post-disco/post-house, and also an emotional, ballad-y kind of country music.

headline: Polish Judge Wants More From U.S. on Polanski Extradition Request
text: WARSAW – A Polish judge said Friday that he had asked American officials for more documents to back up their request to extradite the filmmaker Roman Polanski to the United States.

headline: U.S. and Cuban Negotiators Can’t Quite Seal a Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Despite a wave of optimism, United States and Cuban negotiators this week failed to reach an accord on re-establishing diplomatic ties that had been fractured during the Cold War, United States and Cuban officials said on Friday.

headline: Images That Capture Water’s Pull
text: In her “A Further Shore” series, the photographer Susannah Ray documents the many ways in which New Yorkers connect with the city’s waterways.

headline: Feeling Water’s Pull
text: Memorial Day — a day of remembrance for the dead — begins the high season for New Yorkers’ romance with the water. Like clockwork, people move to the often neglected edges of the land, in search of something they can’t get online. “We shed layers of clothing, and we shed layers of restriction,” the photographer Susannah Ray said. “We move into these waters that were inaccessible in winter, but aren’t inaccessible anymore.”

headline: What I Love | Kate Betts
text: The former fashion-magazine editor is putting her own mark on a long-held family house.

headline: Myanmar’s Navy Seizes 2 Boats Carrying Over 200 Migrants
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar, under international pressure to help resolve the humanitarian migrant crisis in Southeast Asia, announced on Friday that it had seized a boat carrying more than 200 migrants and detained all the passengers.

headline: De Blasio Is Not Insulting Enough to Be Popular
text: In 1981, unless you were living in a cocaine-fueled delusion cultivated at Maxwell’s Plum, there were plenty of reasons to find fault with the governance of New York City, by then under the direction of Mayor Edward Irving Koch for three years.

headline: Bedtime Math’s Founder Uses an Eggbeater for More Than Just Eggs
text: Laura Overdeck knelt in the driveway of her Tudor home, smashing an eggbeater with a hammer.

headline: What Makes a Neighborhood Joint?
text: Almost by definition, a Neighborhood Joint is unique. But after five years and 258 columns, some patterns have emerged, and it seems clear that certain conditions can help turn a hopeful storefront into a local treasure.

headline: Strange, Beloved, Local, Endangered: Five Years of the Neighborhood Joint
text: It’s the funny old store with a display that hasn’t changed in decades and has exactly what you need. It’s the clam shack, the ice cream stand, the well-worn diner, all wonderfully out of step with the current food trend.

headline: Honoring Memorial Day and Looking Ahead
text: A slide show of photographs from 2014.

headline: Daniel Donovan Gets Wary Welcome to Congress After Eric Garner Case
text: WASHINGTON — When a Staten Island grand jury declined last year to issue an indictment against a police officer involved in the death of Eric Garner, New York City’s Democratic members of Congress reacted with outrage and dismay.

headline: Yellen Expects Fed to Start Raising Rates This Year
text: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Friday that she still expected the Fed to start raising its benchmark interest rate later this year.

headline: Review: In ‘Poltergeist,’ They’re Baaack, With GPS and Flat Screens
text: The new “Poltergeist” might well be the scariest movie 13-or-unders have yet seen, just as the original was for their parents back in 1982. Those parents might find it an enjoyable trip down memory lane, even if they do now recognize it as largely a well-served collection of horror-movie tropes.

headline: State Department Releases Hillary Clinton Emails
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department said on Friday it was releasing 296 emails that Hillary Rodham Clinton sent and received when she was secretary of state.

headline: If You Want to Sing Out, He Says He Can Teach You
text: Here on one of the most crowded and noisiest stretches of Main Street in Flushing, Queens, traffic clogs the streets and throngs of Asian immigrants crowd the sidewalks.

headline: A Welcome Call for Change in the Boy Scouts
text: In these days of political polarization and deep mistrust, it’s exciting to see someone like Bob Gates — former national security aide in the White House, former Central Intelligence chief, former Secretary of Defense, current Republican — cross the ideological dead zone on an important issue. In this case, it’s the long process of trying to introduce the Boy Scouts to the 21st Century.

headline: An App for Solo Soccer Players
text: If you are looking forward to the Women’s World Cup this summer, you may find yourself motivated to take to the pitch yourself. If so, you might consider using an app called Jogabo. It’s a service that allows users to schedule soccer games, invite friends or strangers to play, and keep track of goals, assists and other statistics.

headline: Gaza Strip Economy on ‘Verge of Collapse,’ World Bank Says
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Gaza’s war-battered economy is on the “verge of collapse,” dragged down by soaring unemployment rates that followed last summer’s war with Israel, border restrictions and government dysfunction, the World Bank says in a new report.

headline: A Tribute to Oscar Robertson’s High School Team, 60 Years Overdue
text: As a child growing up in Indianapolis, Oscar Robertson never attended the Indianapolis 500.

headline: Art for Food’s Sake at the Whitney Museum’s Untitled
text: Despite some evidence to the contrary — the Modern, say, at the Museum of Modern Art — the words “museum restaurant” have not inspired culinary ecstasy so much as images of footsore diners and tuna salad sandwiches in plastic wrap. While art and eating are both intensely sensual experiences, even in New York they only occasionally coincide. Untitled, the glassy restaurant from Danny Meyer (who not coincidentally also runs the Modern) in the recently opened Whitney Museum of American Art in Manhattan’s meatpacking district, is trying to establish a counter trend with an elegantly simple menu and stylish, sleek décor. Last Wednesday, three weeks after the restaurant opened, the line to get in was not quite as long as the line for the museum, but the dining room was nonetheless packed with a lunchtime crowd that included three members of a family whose interest in a good meal actually preceded their interest in the art.

headline: UEFA Appears Prepared to Allow League in Crimea
text: MOSCOW — Soccer officials in Crimea have said that European soccer’s governing body, UEFA, has approved the creation of a new league on the disputed peninsula, dragging UEFA’s awkward position over the Ukraine crisis into prominence again and aggravating yet another political headache for international soccer authorities.

headline: Shake Shack’s Shares Could Hint at Overvaluation
text: A once-humble New York hot-dog stand may have just turned into the ultimate market indicator. Shake Shack, which went public in January, hit a record high share price on Thursday, implausibly raising the value of the chain, a creation of Danny Meyer, by $250 million, to $3.3 billion.

headline: Dance Class: An ‘Activity’ That Isn’t Very Active
text: How much is your child really dancing in dance class?

headline: A Pioneer Aviator, and a Park Without Its Eponym
text: Q. I recently saw a small display about a woman named Harriet Quimby, a pioneer aviator. Could you tell me more about her?

headline: Hanoi Hits
text: Savoring the specialties in Hanoi and Hoi An restaurants that preserve the informality and limited menus of Vietnam’s beloved street stalls.

headline: Obama Stresses Support for Israel, but Refuses to ‘Paper Over’ Discord
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama sought to reassure American Jews that he is a fierce supporter of Israel as he visited an influential synagogue here on Friday to defend his quest for a nuclear agreement with Iran. The visit was also an attempt to mend a strained relationship with parts of the American Jewish community that dates to the start of Mr. Obama’s presidency and has worsened in recent months.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Shakespeare in Love
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Alan Riding reviews two new books about Shakespeare’s women characters and personal life: Tina Packer’s “Women of Will: Following the Feminine in Shakespeare’s Plays” and Chris Laoutaris’s “Shakespeare and the Countess: The Battle That Gave Birth to the Globe.” Mr. Riding writes:

headline: Painting Recovered From Gurlitt Trove to Be Auctioned in London
text: A Max Liebermann oil painting that vanished for decades in the secret art hoard of Cornelius Gurlitt will get its first public viewing in June in advance of an auction for the work, which once belonged to a Jewish industrialist.

headline: Free Passes to Parks for Fourth Graders
text: Next school year, fourth graders in the United States and their families will be entitled to free admission to America’s national parks, federal lands and waters.

headline: A Juggernaut Lurks Early in Rafael Nadal’s Path at the French Open
text: PARIS — “Not nice Maria,” joked Toni Nadal in a French radio interview here on Friday.

headline: A Full Floor at One57 for $47.78 Million
text: A full-floor aerie on the 77th floor of One57, where the city’s two most expensive single-family residences were purchased recently, sold to a mystery European buyer for $47,782,186.53 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: More Than One Attacker Is Suspected in Killings of 4 in Washington
text: Multiple attackers were involved in taking four people captive in a Washington mansion, making them produce $40,000 in cash and then killing them, an investigator said in court papers filed on Friday, hours after the only person publicly identified as a suspect was arrested.

headline: A Victory for Medical Marijuana
text: It’s the middle of 2015, and the United States is still fighting its old, failed, discredited war on drugs. But sometimes the battlefield fog lifts a little.

headline: How Malia Mills, Swimsuit Designer, Spends Her Sundays
text: The Honolulu-born swimsuit designer Malia Mills grew up customizing crochet bikinis. When she moved to New Hampshire as a teenager, she noted a bit less freedom of expression among her peers. “I went to the town pond, and I was in a crazy racy, hot pink monokini thing and my friends were chilling out in high-neck, low-leg Speedos,” she recalled. “It was a ‘Bridget Jones’s Diary’ moment for me.” Suiting up, she contends, should be a joyous experience, and can be so with the right-fitting piece (or pieces). She is spreading this philosophy through her 14 stores nationwide, including five in New York City and two in the Hamptons, and her website. Ms. Mills, 48, lives with her boyfriend, Christian Busch, 43, in a “loftesque” building in TriBeCa.

headline: Hillary Clinton Takes Questions Again and Addresses Emails
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton took questions for reporters Friday for the second time in a week, commenting on the State Department’s disclosure of emails related to the 2012 attack on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Review: In ‘American Immersion: Clemens Gadenstätter,’ Sonic Mortification
text: “I hope no one has to understand the sensation of having his skin ripped off,” the composer Clemens Gadenstätter said in an onstage interview on Thursday at the Austrian Cultural Forum. He was introducing his 2012 string quartet “häuten (Paramyth 1),” which is designed to evoke that very feeling.

headline: A Mural Tour in Tulum
text: Inspired by the Wynwood Walls of Miami, a street art project that has revitalized a once dreary neighborhood, Susan Bohlken, owner of the beachfront Zamas Hotel in Tulum, Mexico, invited several muralists to the area to literally paint the town last December. The result: 14 new murals on city walls.

headline: Firefighting the Old-School Way
text: This year marks the 150th anniversary of New York City’s professional Fire Department, replacing a patchwork of amateur forces that sometimes battled over turf instead of putting out blazes.

headline: Tobacco Giants Sue Britain Over Rules on Plain Packaging
text: PARIS — Big Tobacco is pushing back against Europe’s effort to remove the marketing allure from smoking.

headline: Voyage of an Iron-Hulled Ship
text: A time-lapse video of Wavertree’s short journey to Staten Island for repairs. Wavertree is a 19th-century vessel and part of South Street Seaport Museum’s collection.

headline: North Carolina Receives Notice of Allegations From N.C.A.A.
text: The University of North Carolina announced Friday that it had received a “notice of allegations” from the N.C.A.A. stemming from a scandal, nearly two decades long, in which the athletic department is accused of directing top athletes to phony classes.

headline: Cuba and U.S. Diplomats Hold More Talks
text: Senior diplomats for the United States and Cuba, Roberta S. Jacobson and Josefina Vidal, announced the end of another round of talks on the restoration of diplomatic relations.

headline: Kate Betts, Onetime Harper’s Bazaar Editor, at Home
text: On a recent Sunday afternoon, Kate Betts, the onetime editor in chief of Harper’s Bazaar, was sitting in her favorite armchair in the parlor of her weekend house in Sag Harbor, N.Y.  “I call this the concierge seat, because you can see everyone coming and going — and spy on them,” said Ms. Betts, alluding to the stereotypical French concierge who is as much the resident busybody of an apartment building as its superintendent.

headline: Josh Duggar Receives Support From Mike Huckabee
text: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee, the Republican from Arkansas who is running for president, has come to the defense of the former director of the conservative Family Research Council’s lobbying group who resigned this week amid allegations that he had molested children.

headline: A Drug Smuggler’s Times Square Visit (for Pleasure, Not Business)
text: Three men strolled in Times Square on a Monday afternoon in February, looking around. Nothing out of the ordinary. Then one of them pointed up, toward the top of a building on 42nd Street.

headline: Jon Pessah’s ‘The Game: Inside the Secret World of Major League Baseball’s Power Brokers’
text: It was the most tumultuous time in baseball history. Between 1992 and 2010, a commissioner was forced out, there was a 234-day strike, home run records were completely obliterated and an entire generation of stars was tainted by steroids.

headline: Review: ‘The Future Was Looking Better in the Past,’ a Long-Ago Crime Reappears
text: In Chicago in 1924, two affluent and intellectually precocious teenagers named Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb coldly murdered a 14-year-old boy named Bobby Franks. The crime and the trial spawned a media circus, novels, plays and films. On Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory in Queens, the performance artist Rebecca Patek added another work to the pile. The Leopold and Loeb case, though, is not the only subject of Ms. Patek’s jumbled, hourlong “The Future Was Looking Better in the Past.” (The subtitle runs on for 28 more words.) The murderers and their victim are played by dancer-actors, who recite segments of actual and imagined courtroom testimony and who appear in video re-enactments and fantasies. But the same performers also portray Ms. Patek and an interviewer discussing the process and motivations behind this show. (Here, and in the program bio, Ms. Patek claims to be related to Loeb.) Threaded in alternation with these two strands is a third, given in audio with subtitles, as if from a wiretap recording. This is a scene presented as another crime, one from last year, in which Ms. Patek engages in sex acts with anonymous men.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Good News for the Nation’s Waterways
text: Joan Mulhern would have loved this day, had she lived to see it. Joan, who died at the age of 51 in December 2012, was a feisty Massachusetts native, passionate Red Sox fan and environmental lawyer who gravitated to the Washington office of Earthjustice, an advocacy group she served as a senior attorney while becoming an absolute terror to anyone who threatened the waters of the United States — legislators and lobbyists, passive regulators, coal companies that insisted on blasting the tops off mountains and dumping coal slag in the valleys and streams below. Her biggest cause, in which she enlisted every environmentalist, journalist and ordinary citizen she could buttonhole, was to restore the full meaning and scope of the 1972 Clean Water Act, whose protections, she believed, had been fatally weakened by the courts and by politicians in thrall to special interests — mainly developers, industrial and municipal polluters, and big farmers. Next week, barring an 11th-hour cave-in by the White House, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers are expected to issue a firm, clear rule restoring federal protections to most (though probably not all) of the waters the Act’s framers, and Joan, had hoped to protect.

headline: Let’s Make the Republican Debates More, Not Less, of a Circus
text: If you go out and interact with Real Everyday Americans in places like Dupont Circle, the lobby of the Des Moines Marriott and my Twitter feed, you’ll know that one of the biggest challenges now facing America involves figuring out how the nine scheduled Republican presidential debates can be held without running afoul of local fire marshals.

headline: U.S. Drug Charges for 2 Former Wesleyan Students Linked to Overdoses
text: Federal prosecutors on Friday said that two Wesleyan University students had sold a popular club drug known as Molly on campus for more than a year before a harrowing night in February when several students were hospitalized with drug overdoses, including one who nearly died.

headline: The Best-Selling Sports Books
text: Trying to decide what to read on the beach this holiday weekend? Here are the best-selling sports books in April 2015, according to The New York Times best-seller list.

headline: TLC Pulls ‘19 Kids and Counting’ From Its Lineup
text: TLC has pulled the popular reality show “19 Kids and Counting” from its lineup, following allegations that one of the show’s stars, Josh Duggar, had previously been investigated on suspicion of molesting several minors.

headline: Obama Reaffirms Commitment to Israel
text: Speaking at the Adas Israel Congregation in Washington on Friday, President Obama sought to allay fears over the Iranian nuclear deal, and reaffirm American commitment to Israel.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Colors of Spring
text: Fashion and nature reflect each other’s beauty.

headline: Why Do We Experience Awe?
text: HERE’S a curious fact about goose bumps. In many nonhuman mammals, goose bumps — that physiological reaction in which the muscles surrounding hair follicles contract — occur when individuals, along with other members of their species, face a threat. We humans, by contrast, can get goose bumps when we experience awe, that often-positive feeling of being in the presence of something vast that transcends our understanding of the world.

headline: Review: Susanna Malkki Makes an Immediate Impression
text: Though the Finnish conductor Susanna Malkki’s long-overdue debut with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night gave me deep pleasure, the occasion also stirred up some annoyance with the Philharmonic’s leadership team. Where has this impressive 46-year-old artist been? How has it taken so long for the Philharmonic to invite her as a guest?

headline: Online, Irish Referendum Looks One-Sided, but Conservatives Hope Vote Reveals a Silent Majority
text: “I live in a rather special world,” the film critic Pauline Kael observed in 1972, one month after President Richard Nixon was re-elected in a landslide. “I only know one person who voted for Nixon.”

headline: Farmers Agree to Water Cuts in California
text: LOS ANGELES — Ever since the Gold Rush, California farmers have staked their claim to water and ferociously protected their rights to use it to irrigate the crops that have made the state the greengrocer for the nation.

headline: Review: Lauren Fox’s Nostalgic Tribute to Groupie Muses
text: “They treated us like goddesses.”

headline: Ireland Votes on Same-Sex Marriage
text: Residents of Ireland reacted Friday as the country held a referendum to decide whether to legalize same-sex marriage.

headline: Maureen Abood’s ‘Rose Water & Orange Blossoms’ Takes You to Lebanon
text: We cooks may have fallen hard for Middle Eastern cuisine, but for the most part, we’ve done it haphazardly, stirring disparate elements of the region into one sun-drenched, sumac-flecked, tahini-laced stew.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Burundi and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Burundi, Thailand, Saudi Arabia and India.

headline: Review: ‘The Mantises Are Flipping W.3,’ a World of Its Own at Danspace Project
text: At first glance, the single false eyelash, conspicuously white, worn by each member of BodyStories: Teresa Fellion Dance is what distinguishes them as a tribe or species in “The Mantises Are Flipping W.3.” Soon, other commonalities become apparent: a contorted physicality, buckling in spasms, and highly animated faces that react to other dancers or to the dancer’s own limbs with astonishment and aggression.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Colors of Spring
text: Fashion and nature reflect each other’s beauty. In early April, the young woman installing the nasturtium vines at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston wore a nasturtium-colored hat. Suddenly there was an explosion of color on clothes. Early in May back in New York, buttercups dominated a farmers’ market. The color showed up in fashion as well, and even on a sports car. One woman’s yellow dress and cellphone cover matched a park telephone. Last week, the flower market was flooded with lilies of the valley. At citywide graduations, students took off caps and gowns to reveal white lace dresses; on the street, they wore white lace dusters. One curious sight: a white dog passing a row of house painters.

headline: May 22, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Burundi, Thailand, Saudi Arabia and India.

headline: Political Unrest Pushes Burundi Closer to Economic Collapse
text: BUJUMBURA, Burundi — In a circular ward of the Prince Regent Charles Hospital, a facility that speaks of better days in this central African country, Armel Manirambona lay on a bed under a white blanket that covered a bullet wound in his abdomen and damage to his colon and liver.

headline: Chris Christie and Jeb Bush Cite Experience in Courting Southern G.O.P.
text: OKLAHOMA CITY – Organizers of this year’s Southern Republican Leadership Conference were able to secure commitments from many of the leading presidential candidates, but the United States Senate‘s schedule has disrupted carefully laid plans. Senators Marco Rubio of Florida and Ted Cruz of Texas – both highly anticipated draws here – had to remain in Washington on Friday to attend to their day jobs. The Senate, as is often the case, is up against a deadline and scrambling to move legislation before a looming recess.

headline: Noteworthy Moments From Cannes
text: As the Cannes Film Festival approaches its final weekend, here are five moments worth revisiting.

headline: The City That Never Stops
text: In mid-May, it seemed as if the parties were endless.

headline: Russia Casts a Shadow Over European Meeting
text: RIGA, Latvia — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain showed up hours late, but the absentee who really mattered — and haunted all discussion during a two-day meeting of leaders from Europe and former Soviet lands — was President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who had not even been invited.

headline: Young Saudis Find Freedom on Their Phones
text: Technology offers opportunity for self-expression in a country with strict social codes.

headline: Gentrification Spreads an Upheaval in San Francisco’s Mission District
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Luxury condominiums, organic ice cream stores, cafes that serve soy lattes and chocolate shops that offer samples from Ecuador and Madagascar are rapidly replacing 99-cent stores, bodegas and rent-controlled apartments in the Mission District, this city’s working-class Latino neighborhood.

headline: Charles Annenberg Weingarten, a Philanthropist With Exotic Pet Causes
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — The billionaire philanthropist Wallis Annenberg answers to the nickname … Moondoggie?

headline: A Marriage of Practical Advice and a Sense of Adventure
text: Judith Sills and Randy Swartz were married April 12 at Le Chéri, a French restaurant in the Philadelphia Art Alliance.v

headline: Letter to Governors about the Prison Rape Elimination Act
text: A letter to governors from the U.S. Department of Justice about the Prison Rape Elimination Act, which was put in place by President George W. Bush.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: On the Red Carpet: Covering Cannes
text: CANNES — I used to cover the Vatican, so I am familiar with hierarchy. That’s useful training for Cannes. The most important film festival in the world is a highly complex ecosystem — French cultural bureaucracy meets the Hollywood caste system. It’s all about access. And status anxiety. Were you invited to the party, the after-party or the after-after party, the one on a yacht?

headline: A Letter From Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas
text: Mr. Abbott told the U.S. Department of Justice that he believed Texas to be in full compliance with the Prison Rape Elimination Act but that he could not certify it.

headline: U.S. Spars With Texas on Ending Prison Rapes
text: In what appeared to be a reversal of his predecessor’s position, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas wrote to Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch last week to assure her that his state intended to abide by national standards to prevent, detect and respond to prison rape “wherever feasible.”

headline: A Family Drama in Three Acts
text: This is a story of redemption. But first, the fall: Last July, Kevin McEnroe, the son of the tennis legend John McEnroe and the actress Tatum O’Neal, was arrested in the East Village on suspicion of buying cocaine, which later turned out to be baking soda. He was also charged with criminal possession of prescription pills.

headline: “The Acropolis”
text: Tod Papageorge’s images of 1980s tourists.

headline: From Mourning Comes Advice, Then Love
text: In April 2014, Randy Swartz went to sit shiva for a friend. At the time, Mr. Swartz was still in mourning for his wife, who had died five months earlier, and as he listened to Judith Sills give a eulogy for their mutual friend, Larry Teacher, a founder of the Running Press publishing house, he realized she might be able to help him in his own mourning process.

headline: Fighting Pollution From Microbeads Used in Soaps and Creams
text: Stiv Wilson is not much of an exfoliator.

headline: Kim K., J-Lo, Beyoncé Undress for Success With the Naked Look
text: To the Billboard Music Awards a week ago, Jennifer Lopez bared most of her stomach and the undersides of her breasts in a creation by … hmm, let me look that up.

headline: South Asian-American Men Balance Tradition and Modernity to Find a Bride
text: The Urdu phrase “bus bohot hogiya hay” sends chills down Umair Khan’s spine.

headline: The R&B Star Akon and an Emirates Foundation Invest in a Solar Energy Work Force for Africa
text: The United Nations hosted the second Sustainable Energy for All Forum this week. The four-day set of events and announcements was aimed at fulfilling Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon’s creditable 2011 vision of achieving universal access to modern energy services by 2030 (along with a doubled global rate of improvement in energy efficiency and doubled share of renewable energy in the global energy mix).

headline: Theater Review: First Lady Runs the Country When President Wilson Can’t
text: She doesn’t read newspapers, because the news dismays her. She’s never voted, because in 1915, American women don’t have that right. She’s a product of finishing schools, not universities. And when she travels to Paris, she spends her time at couture houses, not museums. But the lovely, well-dressed woman we meet at the start of Joe DiPietro’s newest play, the final offering of Long Wharf Theater’s 50th-anniversary season, manages to interest, seduce and marry the president of the United States, and then to run the country after he is incapacitated by a stroke.

headline: Even With Kentucky G.O.P. Race Unsettled, a Candidate Is Confident
text: With no winner declared in Kentucky’s Republican primary for governor and a machine adding up votes again, the state Republican Party is holding off announcing the keynote speaker for this month’s Lincoln Day Dinner, a slot reserved for the eventual winner.

headline: Locally Made Cheeses Are Having a Moment in Connecticut
text: Farmers’ markets are set to reopen for the summer season, and tucked in among tables of just-picked corn and cartons of fresh lettuces and greens is one commodity Connecticut consumers can expect to see a great deal more of: locally made cheese.

headline: A Closer Look at Stylish Gallerists
text: Chilly and label-fixated they’re not.

headline: At Frieze Art Fair, Figures at an Exhibition
text: Laurie Harrison stood swanning at her booth at the Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island the other day, her brash turnout a magnet to the swarms of photographers, street-style bloggers and self-appointed fashion watchers milling inside the bright white tent.

headline: Review: ‘Small World’ Pits Disney and Stravinsky in Duel of Ideas
text: What happened when Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” met Mickey Mouse?

headline: Review: ‘New Country,’ by Mark Roberts, With Dirty Jokes Aplenty
text: “Two and a Half Men” was often among network prime time’s raunchier shows during its long run, but Mark Roberts, one of the brains behind it, apparently was holding a lot back. His raucous “New Country,” having its premiere at the Cherry Lane Theater and featuring one especially blazing performance, is full of the kinds of lines television censors snip out. But Mr. Roberts, a principal writer for the series, also does a pretty good job of slipping in a bit of heart amid the offensiveness.

headline: Review: ‘Texas Rising,’ a Mini-Series on Alamo Aftermath With Dialogue to Forget
text: A lot of the heroes of the Texas Revolution died at the Alamo, including, apparently, most of the interesting ones.

headline: Review: Almost Everything at the Iron Horse Pleasantville has Changed but the Name
text: The name is the same but almost everything else about the former Iron Horse Pleasantville restaurant has changed. Diners looking for the magical fare created by Philip McGrath, the past owner and chef, might be disappointed. There’s a new guy in charge with a different vision. David Barrera took over the restaurant in September 2013, closed it last January for a month’s renovation and reopened it in February.

headline: At Cannes Film Festival, Good Sometimes Isn’t Enough
text: CANNES, France — We came, we saw, we cheered and, as you may have heard, we also jeered. In other words, welcome to the latest edition of the Cannes Film Festival, which ends Sunday. For more than a week, thousands of journalists and industry insiders have swarmed into this Riviera city to sift through titles that will be coming to a theater near you or just your favorite small screen. Inside the festival headquarters, journalists have raced from screening to screening while, at the film market, business types have bought and sold movies and sometimes projects that no critic has seen nor may ever want to, like “I Am Wrath,” a revenge flick set to star a gun-toting John Travolta.

headline: Review: ‘I’m Not the Stranger You Think I Am,’ Where Theater Meets Confessional
text: There’s no hiding in the dark this time, and none of the usual safety in numbers. It’s just you and her — or him — eyeball to eyeball, in a closed, red space the size of a confessional. If you blush or yawn or wipe tears from your eyes, she sees it; that means, of course, that she feels it, too.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Photographs from Washington and elsewhere.

headline: Blending French and African Identities
text: A project looks at how young Afro-French women maneuver a cultural landscape that often marginalizes or excludes them.

headline: At Restaurant Lorena’s in Maplewood, a Menu Built Around Vegetables
text: Like many dishes I ate at Restaurant Lorena’s, now entering its tenth year and among Open Table’s top 100 restaurants in America in 2014, the warm crepe of crab and mushrooms reminded me of my early training as a critic. I was 8. My mother had a passion for fine French restaurants. The pricier the better.

headline: Tod Papageorge’s Summers Amid the Ruins

He would wake up each morning at the Zafolia Hotel and walk up the hill to the Acropolis to spend the day photographing the scene around the ancient citadel, sweating in the sun.

text: The title of “The Goldilocks Zone,” a new play presented by the Passage Theater Company at the Mill Hill Playhouse in Trenton, is derived from an astronomical term that describes planets capable of sustaining life as we know it.

headline: Contra Dancing Grows in Popularity on Long Island

Later in the 20th century, there was a slight dip in enthusiasm when cholesterol levels became the health topic du jour. Still, by the 1990s, steakhouses were again riding high. They still are: The section of Route 25A from Great Neck to East Norwich is known as Steakhouse Row.

headline: Dean Potter’s Final Flight: One Risk Too Many
text: MADISON, N.H. — FOR all his feats of athletic daring, Dean Potter preferred to think of himself as an artist. The extreme sports star’s greatest achievements, like walking a highline rigged across Upper Yosemite Falls or free-soloing a new route on Fitzroy, a 10,000-foot spike of granite in Argentina, required the sort of creative vision and self-belief that comes only from close study of the wilderness landscape, and constant practice.

headline: Eiffel Tower Workers Stage a Strike to Protest Pickpockets

headline: G.M. Inquiry Said to Find Criminal Wrongdoing

headline: Walmart Pushes for Improved Animal Welfare
text: Walmart, the nation’s largest grocery retailer, said on Friday that it would ask its meat, seafood, poultry, deli and egg suppliers to adopt animal welfare standards that include sufficient space and easy access to food and water.

headline: What’s Behind Big Science Frauds?
text: IN December, Science published a paper claiming that people could change their minds about same-sex marriage after talking for just 20 minutes with a gay person. It seemed too good to be true — and it was.

headline: A Costly Tax Break for Nonpublic Schools
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo can talk passionately about improving New York’s “failing public schools,” but when he made that point at churches and a yeshiva last Sunday it was, at best, disingenuous. He was there to sell his bill that would help private and parochial schools, by offering big tax credits to their donors. This energetic effort for an expensive and possibly unconstitutional bill that Mr. Cuomo has named the Parental Choice in Education Act could cost the state more than $150 million a year. That money should be used to help almost 2.7 million public school students in the state, not given to wealthy donors subsidizing mainly private or religious schools.

headline: Drivers and Officials Preparing for a Slower, and Possibly Safer, Indianapolis 500
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The final practice session for the Indianapolis 500 was conducted Friday without incident.

headline: Senate Vote Is a Victory for Obama on Trade, but a Tougher Test Awaits
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama moved closer to expanded trade negotiating power Friday night after the Senate passed hard-fought legislation that would help complete the most ambitious trade accord in a generation. The deal would link 12 nations on either side of the Pacific into a trading bloc that would encompass 40 percent of the global economy.

headline: Honduras: Ex-President’s Son Arrested
text: Fabio Porfirio Lobo, the son of a former Honduran president, appeared in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Friday on a charge of conspiring to import cocaine into the United States, the authorities said. The charge carries a maximum sentence of life in prison, said the office of Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Mr. Lobo had been arrested in Haiti. The defendant’s father, Porfirio Lobo, served as president of Honduras from 2010 to 2014. The Associated Press reported that the father, in an interview with government television, said he hoped that his son could prove his innocence. “Fabio is not a child,” The A.P. quoted him as saying. “He is a man with a family and must answer for his actions.” Manuel J. Retureta, a lawyer for Mr. Lobo, said his client would enter a plea of not guilty.

headline: Pakistan Widens Inquiry Into Fake Diplomas
text: LONDON — Heavy scrutiny by investigators, politicians and the fractious Pakistani media sector has mounted over the past week for Axact, a Karachi-based software company that has made millions selling fake degrees through a sprawling empire of school websites.

headline: Colombia Rebels End Truce After a Government Attack
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Colombia’s largest guerrilla group suspended a unilateral cease-fire on Friday, a day after an attack by government forces killed 26 rebel fighters, dealing the latest setback to peace talks aimed at ending more than 50 years of war.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Take Tougher Tone at Forum
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — There is a Republican presidential candidate forum practically every weekend these days, and the onset of the Memorial Day holiday was no different. But the White House hopefuls who descended on this conservative capital of the energy industry suggested that the nascent Republican nominating contest is shifting to a new, harder-edged phase.

headline: 40 Are Killed in Gun Battle in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — More than 40 people were killed Friday in a confrontation with members of the federal police, who have sought to tamp down an increase in crime in southwest Mexico marked by an accelerating series of violent challenges to authority.

headline: Banks as Felons, or Criminality Lite
text: As of this week, Citicorp, JPMorgan Chase, Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland are felons, having pleaded guilty on Wednesday to criminal charges of conspiring to rig the value of the world’s currencies. According to the Justice Department, the lengthy and lucrative conspiracy enabled the banks to pad their profits without regard to fairness, the law or the public good.

headline: Rising Dissent and Lawsuits Pushed Scouts to Change
text: As Robert M. Gates, the president of the Boy Scouts of America, called Thursday for an end to the organization’s ban on openly gay leaders, the group was already facing state civil rights investigations in New York and Colorado and the looming threat of lawsuits that the Scouts seemed almost certain to lose.

headline: Drop That Gas Nozzle: New Jersey Is Full-Service Island, and Likes It

headline: Increasingly, Polish Voters Call for Change in Politics
text: WARSAW — Poland, always eager to close the gap with its Western neighbors, has developed yet another symptom of contemporary Europeanness: a growing chunk of voters alienated from the traditional political parties and deeply disenchanted with the country’s entire political class.

headline: Two Sides Claim Victory as Syrian Troops Flee Hospital

text: With two weeks to go before a crucial parliamentary election in Turkey, tensions are rising and some critics of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan fear a new crackdown is starting to ensure that his Justice and Development Party wins. That kind of brute manipulation of the political process would be a serious mistake, further weakening the country’s battered democracy and tainting whatever victory might emerge.

He was 89.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) DAWN OF THE PLANET OF THE APES (2014) A decade has passed on screen since “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” and millions of people have fallen prey to a lethal virus, leaving survivors to cobble together a society in the ruins of San Francisco, where Dreyfus (Gary Oldman), the former police chief, is in charge. But across the Golden Gate Bridge in Marin County, the upright-walking chimpanzee Caesar (Andy Serkis) and his team have built their own civilization, complete with distinctive wooden architecture, domesticated horses, a sophisticated sign language and an education system overseen by the orangutan Maurice (Karin Konoval). But when the humans ask to encroach on their territory to build a hydroelectric station, the alarms are sounded — and schisms formed. “It’s a satisfying movie and an example — a dispiritingly rare one these days — of what mainstream Hollywood filmmaking can still achieve,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Matt Reeves’s Oscar nominee for best achievement in visual effects. “That we have progressed from ‘Rise’ only as far as ‘Dawn’ suggests many future sequels, which may, in this case, be a source of hope as well as dread, provided that civilization doesn’t collapse in the meantime.”

headline: Regimes and Regressions (Wonkish)

I actually did explain my reasoning right there in the post (although I should know by now that careful reading is, let’s say, not a universal skill), but let’s revisit that anyway — and while we’re at it, let me talk about the broader principle involved.

headline: Hey, Driver: Hang Up the Phone, Turn Off the TV and Step on It
text: When the Haggler jumps in a taxi in New York City these days, the driver is often nattering away on a cellphone. For cabbies, this is against the law, even if they use a hands-free connection, so the nattering is usually furtive. But on two recent occasions drivers had hooked their phones, through a Bluetooth connection, to the vehicle’s speakers. Instead of music, the Haggler listened to a personal conversation, loud and clear.

headline: The Ancient Ruins Terror Can’t Destroy
text: THE guard from the antiquities authority was asleep when I arrived at the Temple of Bel, deep in the Syrian desert. Not unreasonable, given that it was before visiting hours, maybe 5:30 a.m., and almost totally dark. A ribbon of purple on the horizon hinted at sunrise, and the war raging over there, in Iraq. But this was Syria, in 2005, and another day of the Assad family dictatorship was dawning in perfect order. European tourists were about to crawl over the ruins of Palmyra, and the biggest structure of all, a 2,000-year-old monument to an official god, was barely visible in front of me. “O.K.,” the guard said, waving me inside. “Go ahead. You can look.”

headline: N.S.A. and Other Matters Leave McConnell’s Senate in Disarray
text: WASHINGTON — The sleepy United States senators thought they were done voting. But then, around 1 a.m. on the Saturday before Memorial Day, Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky and presidential candidate, marched spryly to the Senate floor to let it be known that, no, he would not agree to extend the federal government’s bulk collection of phone records program. Not even for one day.

headline: Pope’s Focus on Poor Revives Scorned Theology
text: VATICAN CITY — Six months after becoming the first Latin American pontiff, Pope Francis invited an octogenarian priest from Peru for a private chat at his Vatican residence. Not listed on the pope’s schedule, the September 2013 meeting with the priest, Gustavo Gutiérrez, soon became public — and was just as quickly interpreted as a defining shift in the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: For Hitters in Baseball, Facing a Shift Can Mean an Adjustment, or Not
text: The first time a left-handed hitter steps into the batter’s box and sees the infield defense shifted radically toward the right side, it can be jarring. No longer is it just batter against pitcher, as it has been from nearly the first time he picked up a bat.

headline: Poetry Kept My Patient Alive

Brilliant, yet sadly bedeviled by schizoaffective disorder — a condition somewhere between schizophrenia and bipolar — he feared he would die before his gift was discovered. “I think I’m dying,” he said every week. His poetry reflected this preoccupation. For example:

headline: Stupid Pentagon Budget Tricks
text: Presidents do not often veto defense budget bills, which annually set spending levels for the huge military structure intended to keep the country safe. But President Obama has threatened to do just that this year, and he should follow through if Congress doesn’t make significant changes in the legislation now under consideration.

headline: What College Applications Shouldn’t Ask
text: Over the last several years, the federal government has been pushing school districts across the country to dial back disciplinary policies under which children are suspended for minor misbehavior that once would have been dealt with in a meeting with parents or though minor sanctions like detention. These “zero tolerance” policies make it more likely that children will drop out, and they are especially damaging to minority students, who are disproportionately subjected to suspension, expulsion or even arrest for nonviolent offenses. Now, colleges that penalize applicants for high school disciplinary records should change their policies as well.

headline: Driving Uber Mad

headline: Can the Islamic State Survive?
text: THE fall of an autocrat leads to foreign occupation and civil war. A revolutionary movement with a messianic vision capitalizes on the chaos to gain power. The revolutionaries rule through terror and the promise of utopia, and inspire copycats around the world. But other nations impose a quarantine, internal rivals regain ground, and despite initial successes the new regime seems unlikely to survive — especially once outside powers, including the United States, join the fight against it.

headline: Moguls Busily Buying Campaign Clout
text: Alongside the affluent angels who back Broadway shows and the horse fanciers who invest fortunes to own a stakes winner lies a new class of American mogul — ultra-rich political donors buying a sense of power by giving unlimited money to the single-candidate super PACs that are already dominating and undermining the 2016 presidential campaign. Single-candidate super PACs are proving irresistible because they can legally accept open-ended donations while inventing elaborate fictions to pretend they are independent of a candidate, even as they plainly are not.

headline: Our Pampered Wilderness

headline: 30 Seconds With Edwin Moses: Understanding Racing Mechanics
text: Edwin Moses, 59, won gold medals in the 400-meter hurdles at the 1976 and 1984 Olympics. From 1977 to 1987, he won 122 consecutive races and set the world record four times. In 2000, he was elected the first chairman of the Laureus World Sports Academy, an international service organization designed to increase participation in sports and to promote sports as a tool for social change. Moses graduated from Morehouse College in Atlanta with a degree in physics and industrial engineering. He worked as an engineer at General Dynamics in the cruise missile program before devoting himself to sports full time. He has long been a fan of Formula One racing. Since 2000, Mercedes has been a sponsor of Laureus, giving Moses a door to the Formula One paddock. The questions and answers below have been edited and condensed.

headline: Spain’s Many Indicted Politicians Undercut ‘Red Line’ Against Graft
text: MADRID — In the campaign before regional and local elections across Spain on Sunday, Alberto Fabra, the leader of Valencia, decided he was drawing a “red line” under years of corruption. He would not, he pledged, allow any indicted official from his Popular Party to run again for office.

text: After the fifth run crossed the plate in the third inning, C. C. Sabathia was pulled from the game and headed to the dugout, receiving an assortment of jeers from an exasperated crowd that felt it had seen this show before.

headline: Pressure Shifts to Ben Bishop After the Rangers’ Onslaught
text: TAMPA, Fla. — By most accounts, he never panics, always keeping a calm, communicative demeanor on the ice and in the Tampa Bay Lightning’s dressing room. Ben Bishop had at least five reasons to break character after a 5-1 loss to the Rangers on Friday night, but as he leaned against a wall and spoke of his Game 4 debacle, he betrayed little emotion.

headline: Decade After Katrina, Pointing Finger More Firmly at Army Corps
text: NEW ORLEANS — Nearly 10 years on, one might assume that the case of Hurricane Katrina is closed.

headline: As N.B.A. Playoff Injuries Pile Up, Teams Are in Survival Mode
text: HOUSTON — Dwight Howard, having nursed his sprained left knee with ice and electrical stimulation for much of the previous 36 hours, declared himself ready to go at the Rockets’ morning shootaround before their game Saturday night here against the Golden State Warriors in the Western Conference finals.

headline: Actions Speak Louder for a Pirates Rookie
text: PITTSBURGH — Jung Ho Kang grinned late Friday night as he balanced on a motorized scooter and zipped through pockets of pedestrian traffic in the hallway outside the Pittsburgh Pirates’ clubhouse.

headline: Gay Activists Hail Vote, 3 Decades After a Fatal ‘Queer Bashing’ Hate Crime
text: DUBLIN — Many of the young voters so pivotal to the successful campaign to legalize same-sex marriage in Ireland were not even born when the country’s version of New York’s Stonewall Riots occurred. In 1982, Declan Flynn, a 31-year-old gay man, was kicked and beaten to death with sticks by a gang of four youths in Fairview Park in Dublin’s north inner city.

headline: Tree Project Aims to Put the Oak Back in Oakland
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the beginning, before stylized images of oak trees started appearing on T-shirts, bumper stickers and even Mayor Libby Schaaf’s election-night earrings in November, there were actually oak woodlands in Oakland.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Free Shirts, Big Environmental Costs

headline: The Victory for Same-Sex Marriage in Ireland
text: Months ago, it seemed to some like a long shot that love, common sense and justice would prevail as voters in Ireland began contemplating whether same-sex couples should be allowed to marry under their Constitution. On Friday, love didn’t just prevail across Irish cities and villages. It triumphed.

headline: A Tale of Many Cities
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Kevin G. Der has published 32 puzzles in The New York Times, and I believe that I have liked all of them. They are generally clever, clean and tight when they contain a theme.

headline: Body Found in Hudson River Near Where Kayaker Disappeared
text: New York State Police troopers discovered a body in the Hudson River on Saturday, near the United States Military Academy at West Point, not far from where a kayaker who authorities say was murdered by his fiancée disappeared.

headline: Republican Rivals Skirt Specifics on Plans to Fight ISIS
text: Lindsey Graham and Rick Santorum want to deploy 10,000 American troops in Iraq as part of a coalition with Arab nations against Islamic State militants, and will settle for nothing less than “destroying the caliphate,” in Mr. Graham’s words.

headline: Salvadorans Celebrate a Beloved Archbishop
text: Tens of thousands of people filled the streets of of El Salvador’s capital to celebrate the beatification of Óscar Romero.

headline: Shrine to a Honky-Tonk Hero
text: Like George Jones’s music, his museum in Nashville is a trove of raw feeling, tragedy, humor, hokiness and eccentricity.

headline: Mower Meets Moonshine at a Museum for Country Star George Jones
text: NASHVILLE — The pilgrims wandered among the relics of the honky-tonk hero George Jones, scrutinizing his bowling ball and his bowling shoes, his address book with its hand-scrawled numbers for Ray Charles and Johnny Cash, and his first guitar, a well-worn Gene Autry Melody Ranch acoustic.

headline: Matt Harvey Stumbles and the Mets Fall to the Pirates
text: PITTSBURGH — Before the first pitch here on Saturday afternoon, the pressing question was whether the Mets would provide Matt Harvey the runs to support his recent dominant form. The answer quickly became inconsequential as Harvey slogged through one of the worst starts of his short career, giving up more runs than he had in his previous five starts combined.

headline: T.K. Jones, 82, Dies; Arms Official Saw Nuclear War as Survivable
text: Thomas K. Jones, an American defense official and arms negotiator who turned Nikita Khrushchev’s defiant “We will bury you” threat on its head when he declared in 1982 that Americans could survive a Soviet nuclear attack by digging shelters — “If there are enough shovels to go around,” he said, “everybody’s going to make it” — died on May 15 in Bellevue, Wash. He was 82.

headline: Denver Brings the West to the Title Game
text: PHILADELPHIA — None of the traditional motivational ploys — the guest speakers and the playoff beards — had worked in the past, so Coach Bill Tierney cut it out, all of it.

headline: With Victories, ISIS Dispels Hope of a Swift Decline
text: BAGHDAD — Just last month, when Western and Iraqi officials talked about the Islamic State, it was mostly to list a series of setbacks to the terrorist group: defeated in the Syrian town of Kobani, battered by a heavy airstrike campaign, forced out of a growing list of towns and cities in Iraq.

headline: Hanoi Hits
text: Savoring the specialties in Hanoi and Hoi An restaurants that preserve the informality and limited menus of Vietnam’s beloved street stalls.

headline:
Ethiopia’s Ruling
Party Is Expected to
Keep Grip on Power
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Like the other people in his village, Berhanu Wodajo, a 40-year-old farmer, is planning to vote for “the bee.”

headline: Saudis Say ISIS Ordered Suicide Bombing of Mosque
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The Saudi Interior Ministry on Saturday said that a Saudi man taking direction from the Islamic State had carried out a deadly suicide bombing a day earlier, bolstering the group’s claim of responsibility.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Everything to do with technology is a window to the outside world, and there is nothing out there that our young people don’t know about.”

Eretha Williams and Mr. Williams Sr. of Alexandria, Va. Pratt N. Wiley, the brother of the bride, who received permission from Massachusetts to officiate, led the ceremony at their parents’ summer home in West Tisbury, Mass.

text: Emily Constance Cole, a daughter of Constance and Thomas Cole of Kenilworth, Ill., is to be married Sunday to Alexander Lee Groden, the son of Randie R. Groden and Dr. Joseph M. Groden of Belmont, Mass.

text: Laura Griffith Carey, the daughter of Gretchen Frank Carey of Philadelphia and Francis J. Zabriskie, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride’s father.

They were joined under Pennsylvania’s self-uniting marriage statute. Michael P. Shea, a cousin of the bride and a United States district judge for the District of Connecticut, took part in the ceremony.

text: Cheryl Yvette Dawson and Madifing Kaba are to be married Sunday evening at the Alger House, an event space in Manhattan. The Rev. Jill Flowers, who was ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary, is to officiate.

Sata and Devendra C. Sata of Glen Oaks, N.Y. Pandit Nayan Pathak, a Hindu priest, is to lead the ceremony at Chutney Manor, a banquet hall in Monmouth Junction, N.J.

text: Dr. Antonia Jocelyn Henry and Martin Diaz III were married Saturday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Leslie K. Sterling officiated at St. Bartholomew’s Episcopal Church, where she is the rector.

text: Marlee Kind Berman and Thomas Edward Dillon were married Saturday evening at HollyHedge Estate, an inn in New Hope, Pa. Brian Dillon, a cousin of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Laura Lane, Nicholas Radkowsky
text: Laura Rose Lane and Nicholas Edward Radkowsky were married Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Museum. The officiant was Stephen Soroka, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

headline: Stephen Curry, With a Little Help, Tramples the Rockets
text: HOUSTON — The Golden State Warriors were planning to practice once they arrived here Friday afternoon, but their scheduled flight out of California was delayed because the airplane needed a new part. The delay stretched from minor (two hours) to major (six hours) after the people in charge concluded that the team needed a different plane entirely.

headline: Hundreds Along River in Nepal Are Forced to Evacuate After Landslide
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Hundreds of residents living along a mountain river in the Myagdi District in western Nepal have been forced to seek higher ground after a massive landslide near the village of Kafaldanda blocked the Kali Gandaki River and created a huge natural dam that could burst.

headline: Corrections: May 24, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Peace Activists Cross Demilitarized Zone Separating Koreas
text: PAJU, South Korea — A group of 30 female peace activists, including the feminist leader Gloria Steinem and two Nobel Peace Prize laureates, crossed the demilitarized zone from North Korea to South Korea on Sunday, calling for an end to the Korean War, whose unresolved hostility has been symbolized by the heavily armed border for six decades.

headline: Three American Ballet Theater Dancers Plan Their Last Steps
text: This season, three principal dancers will bid American Ballet Theater farewell: Paloma Herrera and Xiomara Reyes dance their final performances, both in “Giselle” on Wednesday (Ms. Herrera in the afternoon and Ms. Reyes in the evening), while Julie Kent follows suit in “Romeo and Juliet” on June 20. Each recognizes that it’s time. But that doesn’t make it easy. As Ms. Reyes pointed out, “It’s a heartbreak, don’t get me wrong.”

headline: 1915: Germany at War With Italy
text: LONDON — Following on Italy’s declaration of war on Austria-Hungary, says an Amsterdam despatch, Germany declared war this morning [May 24] on Italy. A Berlin official telegram says: ‘‘The Italian Government yesterday caused to be declared through Duca d’Avarna, Italian Ambassador to the Austro-Hungarian Government, that Italy considered herself from midnight in a state of war with Austria-Hungary. The Italian Government by this provocative attack on the Dual Monarchy has also broken without right or reason the alliance with Germany. The loyal relation existing according to treaty between Austria-Hungary and the German Empire which has been still more firmly welded by comradeship in arms has remained uninjured by the defection of the third ally and her desertion to the enemies’ camp. The German Ambassador, Prince Bülow, has therefore received instructions to leave Rome conjointly with the Austro-Hungarian Ambassador, Baron Macchio.’’ Prince Bülow left Rome this evening at 9.45. The Prussian Minister to the Vatican and the Bavarian Ministers to the Quirinal and the Vatican left by the same train. — The New York Herald, European Edition, May 25, 1915

headline: Thanks to a 4-Year-Old, a Laugh Stronger Than Death
text: My 4-year-old son came careening down the nursing home hallway in my grandma’s wheeled walker, and I surrendered all semblance of control.

headline: Shrine to a Honky-Tonk Hero
text: Like George Jones’s music, his museum in Nashville is a trove of raw feeling, tragedy, humor, hokiness and eccentricity.

headline: 1965: Forces of OAS Take Over Job In S. Domingo
text: SANTO DOMINGO – An inter-American peace-keeping force, comprised primarily of U.S. troops, today [May 24] took over the job of ending the Dominican crisis. A Brazilian general, Hugo Panasco Alvim, was named to command the Organization of American States forces, the first such in hemispheric history. The U.S. ground commander, Lt. Gen. Bruce Palmer jr., was named deputy commander. Jose A. Mora, secretary-general of the OAS, last night signed documents officially putting the unit into operation as junta and rebel troops continued to observe an informal cease-fire.

headline: ‘A Lot of Heroes Around Here’
text: Darrell Stafford, a 32-year veteran of Arlington National Cemetery, reflects on his job as interment supervisor, in which he oversees proper burials of both coffins and cremated remains.

headline: Before a Soldier’s Rest, a Panoply of Details
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Darrell Stafford inspected a freshly dug grave at Arlington National Cemetery recently and nodded. The burial plot, 5 feet by 10 feet, was ready for the coming ceremony. It was just one of 28 funerals that he would help oversee that day.

headline: John F. Nash Jr., Math Genius Defined by a ‘Beautiful Mind,’ Dies at 86
text: John F. Nash Jr., a mathematician who shared a Nobel in 1994 for work that greatly extended the reach and power of modern economic theory and whose long descent into severe mental illness and eventual recovery were the subject of a book and a film, both titled “A Beautiful Mind,” was killed, along with his wife, in a car crash on Saturday in New Jersey. He was 86.

headline: Long Hours at Work Leave Her Little Time for Brother in Need
text: Every workday morning, DeBorah Palmer pulls on her navy blazer and starts her rounds. She is a security guard who patrols the galleries of a Manhattan museum and assists the visitors streaming through its doors.

headline: A Flattering Biographical Video as the Last Exhibit for the Defense
text: GILROY, Calif. — About 3,000 miles from New York, members of a camera crew gathered around Anthony Quijada, trying to do for their not-famous, not-rich client what some high-priced lawyers are doing for theirs in New York courts: Make a video that can keep him out of prison.

headline: U.S. Defense Secretary Blames Iraqi Forces for ISIS Victory in Ramadi
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said Sunday that Iraqi forces had demonstrated “no will to fight” against the Islamic State, blaming them for a retreat that led to the terrorist group’s victory in capturing the Iraqi city of Ramadi.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (13, 49); 9:30 P.M. (21) NATIONAL MEMORIAL DAY CONCERT For the 10th year, Gary Sinise and Joe Mantegna will host this annual broadcast from the West Lawn of the Capitol; this year’s event will honor disabled veterans and Gold Star Children, an organization for those who have lost a parent to war, and observe the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II. The “American Idol” winner Nick Fradiani will sing the national anthem. Gloria Estefan (above), Laura Benanti, Tessanne Chin, Katherine Jenkins, Jason Dolley and Russell Watson will perform with the National Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jack Everly.

headline: John Nash’s Nobel Prize Ceremony
text: John F. Nash Jr. shared the 1994 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for his work on noncooperative games theory.

headline: After a Fire, a Pastor Keeps a Harlem School Going From His Brownstone
text: The sounds of children once again fill the ground floor of the Eatmans’ brownstone on West 119th Street. This was not exactly the plan the Harlem couple had envisioned after raising four of their own children. But as the Rev. Charles Eatman Sr. knows, few things — other than the Ten Commandments — are written in stone.

headline: Cleveland Streets Are Calm, but Anger Lingers Day After Officer’s Acquittal
text: CLEVELAND — The 10 a.m. service at Elizabeth Baptist Church should have been a joyous occasion. It was Pentecost Sunday. The weather was beautiful. Worshipers applauded schoolchildren who received A’s and B’s on their report cards.

headline: ‘Tomorrowland’ Is a Box-Office Disappointment
text: LOS ANGELES — Disney’s big-budget “Tomorrowland” was a relative bust at the domestic box office over the holiday weekend, a result that will likely make Hollywood even more reluctant to invest in original stories.

headline: Nico Rosberg Wins at Monaco After a Crash and Blunder
text: MONACO — A late-race accident by a 17-year-old driver with no driver’s license, along with a little too much television watching by the race leader and an over-optimistic calculation by his team caused a sudden reversal of fortune that cost Lewis Hamilton certain victory at the Monaco Grand Prix on Sunday.

headline: The Taste That Doesn’t Really Satisfy
text: Imagine a meal made of the milk left in the bottom of a bowl of cut-rate cereal, the liquid thickened with sweepings from the floor of a health food store, and you have some sense of what it is like to consume the protein-packed shakes that have replaced Flamin’ Hot Cheetos and Red Bull in the diets of some tech workers in Silicon Valley.

headline: In Busy Silicon Valley, Protein Powder Is in Demand
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Every night, Aaron Melocik, a software developer, follows a precise food routine. He blends together half a gallon of water, three and a half tablespoons of macadamia nut oil and a 16-ounce bag of powder called Schmoylent. Then he pours the beige beverage into jars and chills them before bringing the containers to work the next day at Metrodigi, an education technology start-up.

headline: Roger Federer Is Not Amused With Fan’s Selfie
text: PARIS — A traditionalist, Roger Federer has long struggled to adapt to the new, cheek-to-cheek world of the selfie.

headline: Uncertainty and Helplessness Become a Way of Life in Nepal
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — I am not the old me.

headline: Afghans Form Militias and Call on Warlords to Battle Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Facing a fierce Taliban offensive across a corridor of northern Afghanistan, the government in Kabul is turning to a strategy fraught with risk: forming local militias and beseeching old warlords for military assistance, according to Afghan and Western officials.

headline: Juan Pablo Montoya Wins the Indy 500
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Sometimes people ask Juan Pablo Montoya, whose intensity can be mistaken for anger, if he still enjoys racing.

headline: At Cannes Film Festival, ‘Dheepan’ Wins Palme d’Or
text: CANNES, France — The 68th Cannes Film Festival came to a surprising close on Sunday night when the Palme d’Or was awarded to “Dheepan,” Jacques Audiard’s tense drama about three Sri Lankan refugees struggling to assimilate in a violent French ghetto only to end up in a pastoral British backyard. The movie was well received by critics if far from a passionate favorite.

headline: The New Dictators Rule by Velvet Fist
text: THE standard image of dictatorship is of a government sustained by violence. In 20th-century totalitarian systems, tyrants like Stalin, Hitler and Mao murdered millions in the name of outlandish ideologies. Strongmen like Mobutu Sese Seko in Zaire left trails of blood.

headline: A Stand for Peace
text: A group of female peace activists calling for a formal end to the Korean War crossed the demilitarized zone from North Korea to South Korea on Sunday.

headline: The Rohingya Migrants’ Plight
text: Migrants at sea find very little welcome in Southeast Asia.

headline: Anne Meara, Comedian and Actress, Dies at 85
text: Anne Meara, who was half of one of the most successful male-female comedy teams of all time and who went on to enjoy a long and diverse career as an actress and, late in life, a playwright, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: 911 Call About Motorcyclists
text: Rosalyn Ng describing the scene of motorcyclists surrounding the vehicle that she was riding in on Sept. 29, 2013.

headline: Review: American Ballet Theater’s ‘Giselle’ Bounds as Past Giselles Watch
text: Every year, American Ballet Theater announces, more than half a year in advance, not only some eight or nine programs for its eight-week May-July season at the Metropolitan Opera House but, for some of them, as many as eight casts. This establishes a climate of balletomania, where dancers matter as much as repertory; and usually the Met balletomanes reach peak frenzy in late June, with Ballet Theater’s productions of “Romeo and Juliet” (love, death and acting) and “Swan Lake” (love, death and fouetté turns).

headline: Review: DanceAfrica Festival Bids a Percussive Farewell to Chuck Davis
text: In 1977, when Chuck Davis planted the first seed for his DanceAfrica festival, he presented his company in the Lepercq Space at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where he built an African village. Now in its 38th year, the event continues at the academy’s opera house as a beloved tradition that rings in Memorial Day weekend with a cacophonous bang.

headline: Fusion Media Aims at Millennials, but Struggles to Find Its Identity
text: In 2011, when Isaac Lee, president of news for Univision, set out to persuade his company and Disney to back Fusion, a digital news service and cable channel he wanted to start, he promised nothing less than the holy grail: young viewers for the older media conglomerates.

headline: Review: ‘David Rosenboom: Propositional Music,’ an Avatar of Experimentalism
text: What’s a major art museum without a performance space for music? The inviting new Whitney Museum downtown in the old meatpacking district has a nice one, the Susan and John Hess Family Theater. It may not be big but it’s going to be popular.

headline: Review: ‘The Last Alaskans,’ a New Animal Planet Series
text: The word “Alaska” or a variant of it in a reality-show title sets you up for low expectations. “The Last Alaskans,” an affecting series that begins Monday on Animal Planet, defies quite a few of them.

headline: Todd Haynes’s Film ‘Carol’ Draws Attention at Cannes
text: CANNES, France — In 1952, the year the American Psychiatric Association declared homosexuality a “sociopathic personality disturbance,” readers began discovering Patricia Highsmith’s lesbian romance “The Price of Salt.” Initially published under the name Claire Morgan — the cover promised “a modern novel of two women” — it involves a naïve 19-year-old, Therese Belivet, whose world spins deliriously off its axis when she meets the older Carol Aird, a lovely blonde whose voice, Highsmith wrote, “was rich and supple, and somehow full of secrets.”

headline: Bronislaw Komorowski, Poland’s President, Concedes Defeat to Right-Wing Challenger Andrzej Duda
text: WARSAW — Andrzej Duda, the photogenic, 43-year-old candidate of Poland’s leading right-wing party, stunned the nation’s political establishment on Sunday by wresting the presidency from the incumbent, Bronislaw Komorowski, who is allied with the party that has governed during eight years of stability and prosperity.

headline: Review: ‘The Last Two People on Earth’ Offers Soft-Shoe Après Déluge
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The singular talents of Mandy Patinkin and Taylor Mac — yes, you read that correctly — combine to delightful effect in “The Last Two People on Earth: An Apocalyptic Vaudeville,” the weird and weirdly transfixing entertainment having its premiere here at American Repertory Theater.

headline: Review: ‘Grace of Monaco,’ a Fractured Fairy Tale on Lifetime
text: “Grace of Monaco” is a Lifetime movie, showing on Monday, that stars Nicole Kidman as Grace Kelly in a not-so-happily-ever-after stage. It’s not good, of course, but it is kind of great, almost irresistible. This is a star-studded, lavishly made drama that falls into that special niche: If it were any better, it would be worse.

headline: Behind the Downfall at BlackBerry
text: Ever since Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis stepped down as co-chairmen and co-chief executives of BlackBerry, neither has spoken much in public about the once-dominant smartphone maker’s fall into near market obscurity. The two and many others have opened up, however, to two reporters from The Globe and Mail in Toronto: Jacquie McNish, a senior business writer and author of several books and Sean Silcoff, who reports about the company. The resulting book, “Losing the Signal: The Untold Story Behind the Extraordinary Rise and Spectacular Fall of BlackBerry,” which will be published in the United States on Tuesday, fills in some details of the early history of BlackBerry. And its later chapters offer gripping details about the emotional and business turmoil surrounding its near collapse.

headline: Appropriate Exclamation
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — A very happy Memorial Day to you all, and a big thank you to those who have served and who continue to serve our country.

headline: Amazon to Stop Funneling European Sales Through Low-Tax Haven
text: In the continuing battle between Europe and American tech companies, score one for Europe.

headline: Lincoln Center President Received Increase in Bonus in Final Year
text: Lincoln Center showed its appreciation to Reynold Levy, its president who stepped down last January, by raising his bonus to $600,000 in 2013, his last year with the organization, according to recent tax filings.

headline: Olsen Twins Won’t Appear in ‘Full House’ Reboot
text: You’re in big trouble, mister! The coming Netflix reboot of “Full House” will move forward without Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, the twins who took turns playing the cheeky Michelle Tanner on the ’90s sitcom. “Although Ashley and Mary-Kate will not be a part of ‘Fuller House,’ I know how much ‘Full House’ meant to them and they are still very much considered family,” said Robert L. Boyett, the show’s executive producer, in a statement given to The Hollywood Reporter. The Olsen twins started filming in the role of Michelle at 9 months old, and remained on the show for its full eight seasons. They now run Dualstar, a lifestyle and fashion company. The new season will center on other members of the original Tanner clan, including D. J. (Candace Cameron Bure) and Stephanie (Jodie Sweetin). The Olsens’ former co-star John Stamos, who announced the show’s return on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” last month, tweeted that he was “heartbroken” the twins would not be returning. Still, there’s always a chance they’ll change their minds: David Lynch recently returned to the revival of “Twin Peaks” after renouncing his ties to the project.

headline: Lincoln Center President Saw Increase in Bonus
text: Lincoln Center showed its appreciation to Reynold Levy, its president who stepped down last January, by raising his bonus to $600,000 in 2013, his last year with the organization, according to recent tax filings. The bonus was on top of his $1.29 million salary and pushed Mr. Levy’s total compensation package to $2.4 million, including retirement payments and other benefits, up from $2.2 million the previous year. “The bonus was based on annual reviews of his performance and his project performance,” said Eileen McMahon, a representative for Lincoln Center. She also noted that the bonus, first reported by The New York Post, was based on 18 months of work, not 12. Mr. Levy spent 11 years as president of the performing arts center, where he was renowned for his fund-raising abilities and applauded for completing an ambitious $1.2 billion renovation project. His recently released memoir, “They Told Me Not to Take That Job: Tumult, Betrayal, Heroics, and the Transformation of Lincoln Center,” depicts the interior struggles over the renovation and included criticism of other New York cultural executives.

headline: Review: ‘Afterword, the AACM (as) Opera’ Lends a Voice to Stories of Black History
text: African-American stories are rarely reflected in opera. But within the span of three weeks, three composers have brought new works to the stage that draw their subject matter from black history.

headline: Review: ‘Another Person’s Poison,’ Matthew Smith’s Book on Food Allergies
text: If you grew up food-allergic in the late 20th century, you probably grew up haunted by the ghost of Katherine Brodsky, the Brown University student with a peanut allergy who died in 1986 after eating chili at a restaurant in Providence, R.I. The chili had been thickened with peanut butter. It took two spoonfuls to kill Ms. Brodsky.

text: On Monday at noon, the Columbia baseball team will gather for what has become a happy, if unlikely, ritual. After practice, team members will go to an athletic complex lounge on 218th Street in Upper Manhattan and watch on television as their program is selected to the 64-team field of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Opposing Views of Menace at Trial in Motorcycle Assault

headline: In Some Cases, Pants (Not Shorts) Make the Goaltender
text: PHILADELPHIA — Conditions were relatively cool Saturday in Philadelphia, which wound up be being a good thing for Denver goalkeeper Ryan LaPlante. Besides the bulky gear he wore on his head and torso, LaPlante jogged onto the field with something a little more unusual: a pair of baggy gray sweatpants, cinched at the waist and rolled up at the knees.

headline: Ruling Party Loses Hold as Leftists Surge in Spain

text: FORT BENTON, Mont. — A red bus tottered down a rural road here Sunday, and inside, passengers pressed noses against glass as a guide urged them to envision this place 153 years ago, when the path was a muddy new wagon road cutting through wilderness.

headline: Hold the Mimosa. I’ll Have a Biscuit.
text: Not counting New York’s several million rats, which it is better not to think about, there is no more ubiquitous mammal in this city of concrete and steel than our pet dogs. They fertilize the sidewalks. They ride the subways in Louis Vuitton totes. They fill the air with their barks.
