headline: Martin Sheets, Who Shone at the Special Olympics, Dies at 62
text: Martin Sheets, who became a face of the Special Olympics, winning more than 250 medals competing for more than 40 years in its events for people with intellectual disabilities, died on Thursday in Greensboro, N.C. He was 62.

headline: Bernie Williams, an Improbable Star in Center Field, Is Immortalized Just Beyond It
text: On July 5, 1991, Cal Ripken Jr. drove a pitch from the Yankees’ Tim Leary to the center-field wall at the old Yankee Stadium. Roberto Kelly chased after it, crashed into the fence and sprained his right wrist. Two days later, Bernie Williams was roaming center field in the Bronx.

headline: Explaining a Cornerstone of Game Theory: John Nash’s Equilibrium
text: John F. Nash Jr. was best known for advances in game theory, which is essentially the study of how to come up with a winning strategy in the game of life — especially when you do not know what your competitors are doing and the choices do not always look promising.

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Recap: Ethics Are for Losers
text: Season 2, Episode 7: “Adult Content”Business isn’t easy, and it doesn’t pay to be nice. You’ve got to do whatever you can to win, sometimes even play dirty. If that means hacking into a competitor’s server to undercut his deal with one of the world’s largest online pornography companies, well, then — to quote a memorable line from this week’s “Silicon Valley” — “Welcome to the left-hand path, my friend.”

text: Anton Stralman lingered in his zone for a moment as the Rangers retreated and the Lightning turned and headed up ice. Until this point, about halfway through the game, the Rangers had looked like the better team, skating harder and faster, creating the better chances. But all the Lightning needed to score were the puck and an opening.

headline: Body Recovered in Hudson Is Identified as Missing Kayaker’s

headline: LeBron James Lifts Cleveland to Win With Triple-Double

As the ball bounced away, the final buzzer sounded and the Cleveland Cavaliers secured a 114-111 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 3 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) THE HURT LOCKER (2009) In this Oscar winner for best picture, the director, Kathryn Bigelow, focuses on the men of an Army unit whose job is to detect and defuse — or if that doesn’t work, detonate — improvised explosive devices in Iraq. The unit’s wild card is Staff Sgt. William James (Jeremy Renner, above left, with Anthony Mackie), who “looks like a man having the time of his life,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, as “he approaches each new bomb or skirmish not with dread but with a kind of inspired, improvisational zeal.” He added, “Ms. Bigelow, practicing a kind of hyperbolic realism, distills the psychological essence and moral complications of modern warfare into a series of brilliant, agonizing set pieces.”

headline: China Hopes ‘Blacklist’ Will Curb Its Travelers’ Misbehavior Abroad
text: Tourists from China intent on celebrating their new wealth — much of it gained since 2008, when the government introduced major stimulus programs amid a sagging global economy — are a fast-growing presence around the world. Their range extends from American cities to European villages, from African safari parks to Southeast Asian beaches. Recently a group of more than 6,000 Chinese tourists attracted attention by taking a company-sponsored vacation in France.

headline: The Big Meh
text: Remember Douglas Adams’s 1979 novel “The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy”? It began with some technology snark, dismissing Earth as a planet whose life-forms “are so amazingly primitive that they still think digital watches are a pretty neat idea.” But that was then, in the early stages of the information technology revolution.

headline: More Black Doctors
Scientific Collaboration, Then and Now
Stronger Regulation of Toxic Chemicals
text: Both houses of Congress are moving to reform the notoriously weak Toxic Substances Control Act, which is supposed to ensure the safety of chemicals used in a wide range of consumer and industrial products. The measures under consideration have strong bipartisan support and are thus likely to provide the first significant reforms to the law since it was enacted nearly four decades ago.

headline: Restoring Memoriam to Memorial Day
text: This Memorial Day, as we head to the lake and the beach, grill and drink, shop and save, lay out in the sun or seek shady places, we must remain cognizant that the holiday didn’t begin as a day of celebration or commerce but one of solemnity and, indeed, memoriam.

headline: Decision Time on the Hudson
text: This month the dredges and barges went to work again on the upper Hudson River to begin the sixth and last year of one of the largest and most expensive environmental cleanups in American history. The polluter, General Electric, has been digging up toxic PCB’s, polychlorinated biphenyls, that it dumped into the river, by the millions of pounds, decades ago. It plans to keep dredging through the fall, then pack up its machinery and walk away from the job.

headline: To Baku and Back With Freebies
text: When does a congressional fact-finding trip become an embarrassing junket? Ten House members and 32 of their staff members should be pondering that question now that their all-expenses-paid trip to Baku two years ago has been found by ethics investigators to have been secretly financed by Azerbaijan’s state-owned oil company. That would be a violation of House ethics rules and federal law against foreign governments’ intruding into United States policy.

headline: Malaysian Police Suspect That Mass Graves Are Those of Migrants
text: HONG KONG — The police in Malaysia said on Monday that they had found mass graves on the country’s border with Thailand that may hold the remains of migrants who died in camps run by smugglers.

headline: Still Secret and Secure, Safe Rooms Now Hide in Plain Sight
text: While serving as president of the New School, Bob Kerrey, the former United States senator, needed a residence befitting his station. The university moved him into a red brick Neo-Grec townhouse on West Fourth Street in Manhattan, which was previously owned by the actress Gwyneth Paltrow.

headline: Judy Blume’s ‘In the Unlikely Event’
text: Judy Blume isn’t just revered, she’s revolutionary. She has dared to write about so-called taboo topics for children and young adults — racism (“Iggie’s House”), bullying (“Blubber”), sex (“Forever . . . ”) — and has done it so honestly that her work is both beloved and banned. Now, in her first novel for adults in 17 years, she uses her own young life as source material, revisiting a time when three planes crashed over eight weeks in her hometown, during an indelible period of history — the ­beginning of the 1950s, just as the glossy suburban dream of picket fences and safe conformity jutted up against unrelenting Cold War paranoia.

headline: 1871 | To Skewer Boss Tweed, The Times Spoke German
text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Malaysia Police Chief Comments on Graves
text: Malaysia’s police chief says 139 graves believed to contain the remains of migrants have been found near the country’s border with Thailand.

headline: Ehud Olmert, Israeli Ex-Premier, Is Sentenced to 8 Months in Jail
text: JERUSALEM — Ehud Olmert, the former Israeli prime minister who was forced out of office amid allegations of corruption, was sentenced on Monday to eight months in jail for fraud and breach of trust in a case involving an American businessman.

headline: Britain to Curb Who Can Vote in E.U. Membership Referendum
text: LONDON — With the Labour Party accepting that a referendum on British membership in the European Union is inevitable, the Conservative government announced on Monday that the list of eligible voters would be similar to that of the recent general election, meaning that most European Union citizens living in Britain will not be able to cast a ballot.

headline: Getting It Right
text: What is it to truly know something? In our daily lives, we might not give this much thought — most of us rely on what we consider to be fair judgment and common sense in establishing knowledge. But the task of clearly defining true knowledge is trickier than it may first seem, and it is a problem philosophers have been wrestling with since Socrates.

headline: A Dog of One’s Own
text: I’d come to this party to make out with the host, but his attentions were someplace blonder. So when I turned and saw the guy in the old leather jacket — his earnest dance moves, his hopeful smile — I smiled back and danced away. He followed.

headline: Obamacare’s Big Gamble on Hospital Productivity
text: Can hospitals provide better care for less money? The assumption that they can is baked into the Affordable Care Act.

headline: How the Civil War Became the Indian Wars
text: On Dec. 21, 1866, a year and a half after Gen. Robert E. Lee and Gen. Ulysses S. Grant ostensibly closed the book on the Civil War’s final chapter at Appomattox Court House, another soldier, Capt. William Fetterman, led cavalrymen from Fort Phil Kearny, a federal outpost in Wyoming, toward the base of the Big Horn range. The men planned to attack Indians who had reportedly been menacing local settlers. Instead, a group of Arapahos, Cheyennes and Lakotas, including a warrior named Crazy Horse, killed Fetterman and 80 of his men. It was the Army’s worst defeat on the Plains to date. The Civil War was over, but the Indian wars were just beginning.

headline: Soldier in Tunis Fires on Colleagues in Deadly Attack
text: TUNIS — A Tunisian soldier opened fire on fellow troops inside the central army barracks in the capital on Monday morning, killing seven soldiers and wounding 10 others, the Tunisian Defense Ministry said. The soldier was killed in an exchange of fire.

headline: More Than 70 Wounded in Bombing of Afghan Government Compound
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A powerful truck bomb rammed into a government compound in southern Afghanistan on Monday morning, wounding more than 70 people, the authorities said.

headline: How Theresa Jones, Military Widow and New Real Estate Assistant, Does It
text: Theresa Jones, mother of an 18-month-old and a 7-year-old, knows better than most the grim statistic that more than a quarter of the children left behind when an active-duty service member is killed are under 5. Just over a year ago, she was nursing her youngest child, then 2 months old, when uniformed men arrived at her home to inform her of her husband’s death.

headline: A Memorial Day Luxury
text: Happy Memorial Day! If you need us, we’ll be at the pool/beach/lake/public water sprinkler for children near the Met in Central Park today. If I had it my way, we’d all be together, too — with our toes in the sand, sitting on piles of snuggly soft, body-engulfing velour and terry beach towels like the ones from Ruby Mint. A Laguna Beach native, Erin O’Neil launched the line last year primarily so that she could work from home, to spend more time with her daughter, Ryan Ruby. And if the 40″-by-72″ squares of cotton were just a touch less costly ($78 each), I’d stock up on them and do basically the same thing: not go to work (until tomorrow, when it’s back to business as usual).

headline: Uber Closes In on Its Last Frontier: Airports
text: ATLANTA — In a productive week, Ingemar Smith, driver for hire, picks up about 50 passengers from Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport. Instead of pulling up to the curb outside the baggage claim area, the typical zone for fetching fliers, Mr. Smith and his silver Toyota Prius often lurk in the short-term parking deck, another minute’s walk.

headline: The Corporate Archipelago
text: At HowTheLightGetsIn, the other Hay festival, where I just participated in a panel on the future of capitalism. I know, why such a small topic? But what I found myself thinking and talking about is actually the present of capitalism — and in particular about the peculiar delusion that we live in a world of individual competition in freewheeling markets.

headline: Your (Long) Weekend Briefing
text: Catch up on the week’s top stories as the U.S. honors Memorial Day.

headline: Grexit and the Morning After
text: We just had another electoral earthquake in the euro area: Podemos-backed candidates have won local elections in Madrid and Barcelona. And I hope that the IFKAT — the institutions formerly known as the troika — are paying attention.

headline: In Kansas City, All Things Craft

headline: 1915: Italian Troops Advance
text: ROME — The Italian Headquarters Staff to- day [May 25] issued the following communiqué describing the operations which took place yesterday in Carniola and in Friuli: On the frontier of Carniola, at seven o’clock on the evening of May 23, the Austrian artillery opened fire on our positions without achieving any result. During May 24 our artillery shelled the positions occupied by the enemy’s artillery. On the frontier of Friuli our troops have everywhere advanced into enemy territory and have encountered only a feeble resistance. We have occupied Caporetto, the heights between the Judrio and Isonzo, Cormons, Cervignano and Terzo. — The New York Herald, European Edition, May 26, 1915

headline: Living at High Altitude Is Linked to Higher SIDS Risk
text: Living at high altitude is associated with increased risk of sudden infant death syndrome, a new report has found.

headline: Doctoring, Without the Doctor
text: WOOD LAKE, Neb. — There are just a handful of psychiatrists in all of western Nebraska, a vast expanse of farmland and cattle ranches. So when Murlene Osburn, a cattle rancher turned psychiatric nurse, finished her graduate degree, she thought starting a practice in this tiny village of tumbleweeds and farm equipment dealerships would be easy.

headline: Ants That Show Some Spring in Their Jaws to Escape
text: Trap-jaw ants are named for their fearsome pair of spring-loaded mandibles that snap shut on prey with speed and finality. The ants also have a stinger they can use for good measure if they feel the need to add venom to injury.

headline: ScienceTake | The Great Ant Escape
text: Trap-jaw ants have a startling way to jump out of the slippery-sloped pits of predators.

headline: Venerable Korean American Group in New York Descends Into Chaos
text: Should you happen to meet the president of the Korean American Association of Greater New York this spring, you might find yourself speaking with a 60-year-old Korean man named Sung Ki Min. Then again, you might instead find yourself talking with a 54-year-old woman named Minsun Kim.

headline: Vacationers Stay Fit (and Out of the Gym)
text: Travel often means a break in fitness routines. After all, not all hotel gyms are inviting (limited equipment can be a problem). But a number of properties around the world are now offering more compelling workout programs.

text: Photo Tour “Summer Highlights of West Greenland” is the inaugural tour offered by Big Chill Adventures, established last year by Sarah Aciego, a glaciochemist, and her mother, Mindy Cambiar, a photographer.

headline: Jon Stewart, Iraq War Critic, Runs a Program That Helps Veterans Enter TV
text: During the surge in Iraq in 2008, Nathan Witmer led an Army scout platoon in a thicket of villages rife with insurgents and roadside bombs. What he really wants to do is direct.

headline: 1965: Plot to Kill De Gaulle Is Foiled
text: PARIS — The arrest of six would-be assassins foiled a plot to kill President Charles de Gaulle during his provincial tour last week, Interior Ministry officials disclosed today. A bomb was to be planted at the foot of a statue of Premier Georges Clemenceau, World War I leader, at Sainte-Hermine, in the Vendée region. The plotters would have exploded it by remote control as Gen. de Gaulle laid a wreath. Officials said the plot was directed from abroad by Jean-Jacques Susini, a leader of the terrorist Secret Army Organization. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 26, 1965

headline: Migrants Flooding Into Malaysia and Indonesia Trade One Nightmare for Another
text: GELUGOR, Malaysia — The more than 3,000 migrants from Bangladesh and Myanmar who recently landed in Indonesia and Malaysia ended weeks of a nightmare at sea only to fall into an administrative limbo that could last years, even decades.

headline: Poles React to Presidential Vote Result
text: Polish voters, clearly eager for a change, elected the conservative Andrzej Duda as president. The morning after the election, Mr. Duda handed coffee out to voters in Warsaw.

headline: Two Young Americans Smiling: One Upset Venus Williams. The Other Lost.
text: PARIS — In the fading light of Monday evening, a rare flash of positivity from Sloane Stephens shone across Suzanne Lenglen Court. In their long-awaited first meeting, the 40th-ranked Stephens beat 15th-seeded Venus Williams, 7-6 (5), 6-1, in the first round of the French Open.

headline: Taliban and Afghan Peace Officials Have Secret Talks in China

headline: Etan Patz Jurors, on Anniversary, Meet at Scene of Boy’s Disappearance

headline: One Man’s Millions Turn a Community in Florida Around
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Two decades ago, Harris Rosen, who grew up poor on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and became wealthy in the Florida hotel business, decided to shepherd part of his fortune into a troubled community with the melodious sounding name of Tangelo Park.

headline: Destroying California On Screen
text: From the 1936 film “San Francisco” to the soon-to-be-released “San Andreas,” California has been repeatedly destroyed on the silver screen.

headline: Profit Soars at the Vatican Bank After a Governance Overhaul
text: ROME — The Vatican bank said on Monday that its 2014 net profit had soared, recovering from the expense of last year’s extraordinary overhaul of the organization’s governance.

headline: California Dream Under Attack in All Manner of Cinematic Imaginings
text: LOS ANGELES — Here it comes again: The California Apocalypse.

headline: Wide Use of Antibiotics Allows C. Diff to Flourish
text: You might say Jacob Epstein, a lean, healthy, 88-year-old Floridian, died in early May from a broken arm. Following surgery to reset the bone, he was given an antibiotic to prevent postoperative infection, a common hospital practice.

headline: Netanyahu Appoints Hawkish Ally to Run Foreign Ministry
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday named a longtime confidant who is hawkish on Iran and the Palestinian issue to run the Foreign Ministry, the latest in a series of moves that consolidate Mr. Netanyahu’s conservative grip on his new government.

headline: Charter Deal for Time Warner Cable Signals Shift in TV Industry
text: Trying to succeed where Comcast failed, Charter Communications has struck a deal to buy Time Warner Cable, an acquisition that would create a powerhouse in the consolidating American cable and broadband industry.

headline: Pensions and Politics Fuel Crisis in Illinois
text: CHICAGO — Illinois is facing one of the worst fiscal crises of any state in recent decades, largely because it has mismanaged its pension system.

headline: One-Two Punch of Earthquakes and Landslides Exposes Hydropower Vulnerability in Nepal
text: Here’s a “Your Dot” contribution exploring the vulnerability of Nepal’s “hydrocentric” energy system to damage from earthquakes and landslides. It’s written by Gagan Thapa, a member of Parliament and chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on Agriculture, Energy, and Natural Resources, and Kashish Das Shrestha, a photographer and writer who has worked with Thapa for more than 10 years on sustainable development policy. (You can find them on Twitter at @ThapaGK and @KashishDS.)

headline: University of Tokyo Ends a 94-Game Victory Drought
text: Sooner or later, one way or another, the University of Tokyo’s baseball team was bound to win a game. Any game. Just one.

headline: At Least 5 Are Killed and 12 Are Missing as Storms Ravage Texas and Oklahoma
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Louie Bond called it a tsunami, a surge of water that began late Saturday night with torrential rains in Texas’ Hill Country and raced down the bluff-lined valley carved out by the Blanco River.

headline: Scientists Make Novel Attempt to Save Giant Turtle Species
text: Earlier this month, an international team of scientists, veterinarians and zookeepers gathered at the Suzhou Zoo near Shanghai. Their desperate mission: to attempt the first artificial insemination ever of a softshell turtle, saving the species from oblivion.

headline: Decomposed Remains Found in Malaysia
text: Forensic experts collected bags of human remains on Monday that were found at the site of mass graves in northern Malaysia.

headline: Facing Elimination, the Rangers Expect to Go Home, for Game 7
text: The Rangers are all too familiar with their predicament against the Tampa Bay Lightning in the Eastern Conference finals. They are facing elimination again, trailing a series by three games to two for the sixth time over the last four postseasons.

headline: Cleveland Reaches Settlement With Justice Department Over Police Conduct
text: CLEVELAND — Cleveland has reached a settlement with the Justice Department over what federal authorities said was a pattern of unconstitutional policing and excessive use of force, people briefed on the case said Monday.

headline: Shop Owners in a Changing Brooklyn Decide to Call It Quits
text: To hear some mourners of New York’s late, great nostalgia-filled haunts tell it, the soul of the city is crumbling. With every upward tick in property values, the eternal lament goes, another rapacious landlord muscles out a neighborhood dive bar for a new bank, drugstore or gym.

headline: Allegations Against French Peacekeepers Highlight Obstacles in Addressing Abuse
text: UNITED NATIONS — “Petit, viens,” — little boy, come here — a French soldier called out at a checkpoint in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic.

headline: Poland’s Governing Party Reels After Challenger’s Presidential Victory
text: WARSAW — Poland’s political establishment was reeling on Monday from the defeat of the incumbent president by a little-known 43-year-old candidate from the right-wing opposition, a result that appeared to be a repudiation of the center-right party that has governed the country during eight years of prosperity and stability.

headline: Even Einstein’s Research Can Take Time to Matter
text: In science, a “sleeping beauty” refers to a research paper whose importance is not recognized until many years after it is published. A new analysis of 22 million studies, published over more than a century, finds that sleeping beauties are common.

headline: Senator Thad Cochran Marries Longtime Aide
text: Congratulations are in order for Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, who married Kay Webber, a longtime aide, in Gulfport, Miss., on Saturday. The wedding comes about a year after the 77-year-old Republican won his party’s nomination in one of the most personal and intense primary battles in the country.

headline: Relax, the Terminator Is Far Away
text: In glossy sci-fi movies like “Ex Machina” and “Chappie,” robots move with impressive — and frequently malevolent — dexterity. They appear to confirm the worst fears of prominent technologists and scientists like Elon Musk, Stephen Hawking and Bill Gates, who have all recently voiced alarm over the possible emergence of self-aware machines out to do harm to the human race.

headline: Oral Steroids May Be Ineffective Against Sciatica Back Pain
text: Prednisone, a drug commonly prescribed to treat acute sciatica — the back and leg pain caused by a herniated disk — is almost completely ineffective against the condition, a randomized trial has found.

headline: Review: Joshua Redman Joins the Bad Plus in a Chemistry Experiment
text: THE BAD PLUS JOSHUA REDMAN

headline: W.H.O. Plan Aims to Combat Resistance to Antibiotic Drugs
text: GENEVA — United Nations member states agreed Monday to a plan to tackle resistance to antibiotic drugs, spurred by warnings of a catastrophe for public health and heavy economic losses if they did not act.

headline: Review: Shana Cleveland & the Sandcastles Demonstrate a Low-Flame Curiosity
text: SHANA CLEVELAND & THE SANDCASTLES

headline: Review: Allen Stone Keeps His Distance From Modern Music in ‘Radius’
text: ALLEN STONE

headline: Review: ‘Guidelines’ Is Jean-François Caissy’s Look at High School
text: “Guidelines” was filmed in a high school in rural Quebec, but its insights resonate worldwide. More preoccupied with time than place, this deceptively simple documentary by Jean-François Caissy regards the turbulence of adolescence as a negotiation between risk and restraint.

headline: Spain’s Local Election Results Reshape Political Landscape
text: MADRID — Ada Colau, 41, was not even born when Manuela Carmena, 71, joined Spain’s underground Communist party and started her legal career by attacking labor restrictions imposed by Francisco Franco, the Spanish dictator.

headline: Students Measure Space Dust as New Horizons Heads for Pluto
text: In the nine years that NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft has spent zooming toward Pluto, most of the seven instruments aboard the piano-size probe have been in hibernation, waiting for their chance to plumb the mysteries of our solar system. One, however, has been collecting and pinging back data all this time, a tireless worker with a taste for dust.

headline: Review: ‘The Digital Doctor’ by Robert Wachter Weighs Medicine’s Technological Transformation
text: Janus was the Roman god of doorways and beginnings, the one depicted in sculpture with two faces on a single head. An elderly face gazes backward. (Fondly? Bitterly? Regretfully? Who knows.) A youthful face looks forward, presumably with resolution and hope.

headline: Review: On ‘II,’ Metz Plays With Punk Attitude
text: METZ

headline: A Coach Reaffirms His Standing as Denver Claims Lacrosse Title
text: PHILADELPHIA — As Denver Coach Bill Tierney slowly made his way toward his jubilant players, somebody handed him a pair of scissors, then a snipped piece of net and then the national championship trophy, which he held in his arms, reluctantly, for about five seconds.

headline: Nature’s Waste Management Crews
text: One of the biggest mistakes my husband made as a new father was to tell me he thought his diaper-changing technique was better than mine. From then on, guess who assumed the lion’s share of diaper patrol in our household?

headline: Review: In Philipp Blom’s ‘Fracture,’ Careening Atoms in the Era Between the Wars
text: In “The Vertigo Years: Change and Culture in the West, 1900-1914,” the German historian Philipp Blom pulled off a neat trick. He invited readers to indulge in a thought experiment, to imagine the early 20th century without the imminent prospect of a world war; to experience it, in other words, as its contemporaries did.

headline: Review: Gwen Welliver Goes Equine at La MaMa Moves!
text: For its 10th edition, La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival is presenting about a dozen choreographers over four weeks. A few of those — Gwen Welliver, Brandon Collwes and Eric Geiger and Anya Cloud — shared a bill over the weekend in the close quarters of La MaMa’s First Floor Theater.

headline: With Money Drying Up, Greece Is All but Bankrupt
text: ATHENS — Bulldozers lie abandoned on city streets. Exhausted surgeons operate through the night. And the wealthy bail out broke police departments.

headline: Review: Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg Goes ‘Up and Down’
text: Where to begin with “Up and Down,” the latest production from Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg? Maybe at the end, when the choreographer Boris Eifman takes a bow. On Friday at City Center, where the work had its New York premiere as part of a nine-week North American tour, wild applause greeted Mr. Eifman through multiple curtain calls. It’s this loyal following that brings his troupe trundling through City Center every few years.

headline: Mets Get a Lift From a Heavy Hitter (and Pitcher) of Their Own
text: What’s not to like about watching hefty Bartolo Colon step into the batter’s box? Sometimes he even keeps his helmet on his head as he swings away, and on occasion he even makes contact with the ball.

headline: Iran Judge Closes Reporter’s Trial, Ignoring Pleas for Transparency
text: Ignoring foreign requests for court access, the Iranian judge presiding over the espionage case against Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter imprisoned for 10 months, has barred everyone except the defendant and his lawyer, Mr. Rezaian’s brother said Monday on the eve of the trial.

headline: For Kristin Chenoweth and Kelli O’Hara, a Fearsome Fairy Godmother
text: When it was her turn to sing at Florence Birdwell’s master class for former students in Midtown Manhattan the other day, Heather Botts, a delicate blonde with a beautiful voice, announced that she would be performing “Another Life,” from the musical “The Bridges of Madison County.”

headline: One-Time Bonuses and Perks Muscle Out Pay Raises for Workers
text: Yacht-size bonuses for Wall Street big shots and employee-of-the-month plaques for supermarket standouts are nothing new, but companies’ continued efforts to keep costs down have pushed employers to increasingly turn to one-off bonuses and nonmonetary rewards at the expense of annual pay raises.

headline: Review: ‘Welcome to This House,’ the Private Life of a Poet
text: “Welcome to This House,” Barbara Hammer’s impressionistic yet informative portrait of the poet Elizabeth Bishop, certainly pays tribute to the towering literary achievements of Bishop (1911-79). But Ms. Hammer, an experimental filmmaker whose movies have often chronicled lesbian experience, largely examines Bishop’s private life, an often peripatetic existence strewn with lovers in a deeply closeted era.

headline: What Slump? Yankees Hit Five Homers in Rout of Royals
text: Brett Gardner accounted for four of the Yankees’ eight first-inning runs on Monday, scoring twice and driving in Didi Gregorius and Slade Heathcott with a home run.

headline: Review: Junk Ensemble Explores Darkness and Danger in ‘Dusk Ahead’
text: Three blindfolded dancers grope in near darkness as two others lead them in different directions to the sound of hand bells. Moments later, four performers execute a squiggly gestural sequence knitted together with shoulder shrugs, flowing arms and slow pliés punctuated by quick swipes of the ankle. At the back of the stage, another dancer, wearing a wolf’s head, saunters by.

headline: City Ballet’s Spring Season Includes ‘N.Y. Export: Opus Jazz’
text: As the current New York City Ballet season advances, every performance brings a sharp change in the company barometer. Not all the news is good news. Some valued dancers have been absent with injuries; some tedious ballets have returned to repertory; some casting has made good choreography look no more substantial than cotton candy; and some debuts of important dancers in important roles haven’t worked out.

headline: Officials Describe the Origins of Four Crucial Words: ‘Established by the State’
text: At stake in King v. Burwell is whether the phrase prevents millions of people in federal health care exchanges from receiving tax subsidies through the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Bears Release Ex-49er Ray McDonald After Arrest in California
text: The Chicago Bears released defensive lineman Ray McDonald after he was arrested Monday in California on a domestic violence charge, the latest in a string of run-ins that have tested the boundaries of the N.F.L.’s tougher personal conduct policy.

headline: At Least 3 Die in New York City Crashes on Holiday Weekend
text: A series of fatal car crashes occurred around New York City over the holiday weekend, leaving at least three people dead and a 7-year-old girl with serious injuries. At least one of the accidents involved an intoxicated driver.

headline: After a Political Reversal in Alberta, ‘Anything Seems Possible’
text: EDMONTON, Alberta — This is the Canadian province known for oil, cowboys and rodeos, and as the adopted home of Prime Minister Stephen Harper, whose Conservative Party has long dominated politics.

headline: As Facebook Sweeps Across Europe, Regulators Gird for Battle
text: LONDON — One arm of the European Union is looking into whether Facebook and other tech companies unfairly favor their own services over those of rivals. At least five data protection watchdogs across the region are questioning Facebook’s privacy settings.

headline: Congress Pursues Deal on Phone Data Collection in Rare Talks During Recess
text: WASHINGTON — Senior lawmakers are scrambling this week in rare recess negotiations to agree on a face-saving change to legislation that would rein in the National Security Agency’s dragnet of phone records, with time running out on some of the government’s domestic surveillance authority.

headline: McNeil Robinson II, 72, Organist and Composer, Is Dead
text: McNeil Robinson II, an acclaimed organist, composer and teacher, died on May 9 in Manhattan. He was 72.

headline: The Synagogue Beyond the Outfield Wall
text: The oldest synagogue in South Bend, Ind., was saved from demolition and then repurposed by the city’s minor league baseball team.

headline: Who’s the Watchdog? In Europe, the Answer Is Complicated
text: LONDON — Who has the right to regulate Facebook?

headline: Deaths of Math Genius John F. Nash Jr. and Wife Show Need to Use Seatbelts in Back, Experts Say
text: The crash that killed the mathematician John F. Nash Jr. and his wife, Alicia, on Saturday on the New Jersey Turnpike remains under investigation, but preliminary findings by the police seem to make one thing clear: The Nashes, who were thrown from the back seat of their taxi, were not wearing seatbelts.

headline: After a Year of Outsize Expectations, Narendra Modi Adjusts His Plan for India
text: NEW DELHI — Standing before India on the first anniversary of his swearing-in, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday gave a speech that was notable for the subjects it avoided: Large-scale job creation. Manufacturing. Urbanization.

text: The High Line.

headline: Years Later for Guillermo Vilas, He’s Still Not the One
text: PARIS — It was 1975, and Guillermo Vilas — a charismatic Argentine with long hair, heavy topspin and a poetic streak — reached his first French Open final, losing to Bjorn Borg.

headline: Four Words That Imperil Health Care Law Were All a Mistake, Writers Now Say
text: WASHINGTON — They are only four words in a 900-page law: “established by the state.”

headline: In Time Warner Cable Deal, Charter Seeks National Heft
text: It was only 15 months ago that Charter Communications looked like a big loser in the race to add heft in the cable and broadband industry. Comcast, a rival, had swooped in with an audacious $45 billion bid for Time Warner Cable, appearing to end the prolonged takeover battle that Charter had been waging for the cable operator.

headline: How a Fax Helped Rewrite Women’s Soccer in the U.S.
text: BRICK, N.J. — To get an idea of how long Christie Rampone has played on the United States women’s national team, let her tell you how U.S. Soccer first invited her to try out for the squad.

headline: Doubts About Study of Gay Canvassers Rattle the Field
text: He was a graduate student who seemingly had it all: drive, a big idea and the financial backing to pay for a sprawling study to test it.

headline: Dellavedova Is a Firebrand and a Spark Plug for the Cavaliers
text: CLEVELAND — Randy Bennett sighed and laughed Monday as he considered the rhetorical storm that had been circling his former player Matthew Dellavedova.

headline: Eating Kumquats With Grover
text: Grover visits The New York Times’ Melissa Clark and some young friends to talk about a new cookbook, “Sesame Street Let’s Cook!” What is Grover’s favorite food?

headline: Like the Best Bonds
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — This one by Gareth Bain made me smile. Not just because of the sentiment behind the Beatles’ song that happens to be the revealer, but also because this puzzle was a really smooth solve. Easier, perhaps, than the Monday puzzle, but that’s the thing about wheelhouses: We all decorate them differently.

headline: Similac Advance Infant Formula to Be Offered G.M.O.-Free
text: The maker of Similac Advance, the top commercial baby formula brand in the United States, says it will begin selling the first mainstream baby formula made without genetically altered ingredients by the end of the month at Target.

headline: Jets Are Scrambled Over New York as Airports See a Flurry of Threats
text: Two F-15 jets were sent to escort an Air France flight into New York, the first of at least six intercontinental flights arriving in the region on Monday that were the subject of phone threats about chemical weapons or bombs.

headline: Young Treasure Hunters Dig Up History Lessons in a Classroom’s Closet
text: Bobby Scotto, a fourth grader at the Children’s Workshop School on 12th Street in the East Village, wants to be an archaeologist when he grows up, and he is already off to a good start. In the past few months he has excavated dozens of old coins, a toy watch and other artifacts, all from an unlikely dig site: his classroom’s closet.

headline: Fire Kills 38 at Seniors Home in China
text: HONG KONG — A fire possibly caused by an electrical problem killed at least 38 people in a retiree home in central China, according to state news media reports on Tuesday.

headline: Hillary and Bill Clinton March In Memorial Day Parade in Chappaqua
text: In their first joint public appearance since she declared her candidacy, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Bill Clinton marched with veterans on Monday in the Memorial Day parade in Chappaqua, N.Y.

headline: Columbia Is the No. 3 Seed in Florida
text: Columbia drew the No. 3 seed in the Coral Gables, Fla., region of the N.C.A.A. Division I baseball tournament. The Lions will play the No. 2 seed, East Carolina, when the 64-team tournament begins on Friday. Miami is the top seed in the region, and Florida International is No. 4.

headline: Massimo Bottura’s Pope Francis-Approved Refectory, and Recipe to Turn Stale Bread Into Gold
text: Italy’s most progressive exhibition of sustainable cooking commences this Thursday, when the Michelin-starred chef Massimo Bottura throws open the doors of Refettorio Ambrosiano, the once-derelict theater repurposed to educate and feed the refugees and working poor who reside far across town from the multinational pavilions welcoming culinary tourists to this summer’s Expo Milano 2015. The contemporary refectory in the heart of the city’s under-resourced Greco neighborhood will host a coterie of Bottura’s most charitable colleagues, beginning with Eleven Madison Park’s Daniel Humm and former Chez Panise chef Seen Lippert, eager to make a feast of the exposition’s transported food waste for those most in need by performing culinary alchemy twice daily in a glass-enclosed stage. “At lunchtime, there are going to be students there; and the very best chefs in the world, the rock ‘n’ roll stars, will be cooking scraps for them,” says Bottura of the facility’s secondary mission. “It’s like the Pope washing the feet of the people in the street.” While Bottura’s inspiration for the project draws on local influences including the Italian cinematic fantasia “Miracle in Milan” and Leonardo da Vinci’s “Last Supper,” his greatest motivator has been Pope Francis, whose spontaneous utterance of “Buon pranzo!” (“Good lunch!”) five days into his papacy inspired a renewed sense of faith within the chef. “Introducing himself with those words reminds everyone to start each day with humility, and humility is the most important thing,” Bottura says, “because from there others are going to follow you.”

headline: Man in New Jersey Dies of Rare Viral Disease After Returning From Liberia
text: WASHINGTON — A man died of Lassa fever at a hospital in New Jersey on Monday after returning from Liberia this month, health authorities announced.

headline: Houston Remains Alive, and Curry Survives a Scare
text: HOUSTON — Stephen Curry felt as if he was in the air forever. He was simply trying to make a play on the ball when Trevor Ariza pump-faked underneath the Houston Rockets’ basket. But Curry, the star of the Golden State Warriors, went up and over, sliding off the back of Ariza like an egg on a skillet before tumbling to the court at Toyota Center.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
text: MIDNIGHT (TCM) PAPILLON (1973) Steve McQueen (left, with Dustin Hoffman) stars as Henri Charrière, a.k.a. Papillon, an honorable safecracker framed for the murder of a pimp and sentenced to life in a penal colony on Devil’s Island, off the coast of French Guiana. Mr. Hoffman plays his best friend, Louis Dega, a convicted counterfeiter with bad eyesight and enough money to buy Papillon as his bodyguard. After a hairbreadth escape, Papillon is befriended by Indians who “inhabit what looks to be the West Indies’ newest and most chic island resort and cabana colony and, to be hospitable, present him with his very own Dorothy Lamour, a maiden named Zoraima who is played by Ratna Assan,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “Though its native girls go topless, and the production budget was huge, ‘Papillon’ is the escapist movie we used to go see on Saturday night without even bothering to read the marquee.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It’s half the battle — to visualize they can go to college.”

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: John Murphy, Congressman Convicted in Abscam Sting, Dies at 88
text: John M. Murphy, a former New York City congressman who served 18 years in the House before being caught taking a $50,000 cash payment in the Abscam sting operation in the late 1970s, died on Monday on Staten Island. He was 88.

headline: The University of Minnesota’s Medical Research Mess
text: MINNEAPOLIS — IF you want to see just how long an academic institution can tolerate a string of slow, festering research scandals, let me invite you to the University of Minnesota, where I teach medical ethics.

headline: Immigrant Families, in a Broken Detention System

headline: Talent Loves English
text: Eight hundred years ago next month, English noblemen forced King John to sign the Magna Carta. It’s still having amazing effects on the world today. The Magna Carta helped usher in government with a separation of powers. It helped create conditions in which centralized authority could not totally control fiscal, political, religious or intellectual life. It helped usher in the modern Anglo-Saxon state model, with its relative emphasis on the open movement of people, ideas and things.

headline: Juvenile Justice Reform in Louisiana
text: To the Editor:

headline: Latin America Rethinks Drug Policies
text: During the 1980s and 1990s, as the United States battled the scourge of cocaine throughout the hemisphere, Washington did most of the talking. Latin American governments were forced to listen and fall in line. The American government had the most money to throw at the problem, the toughest justice system and the biggest bully pulpit.

headline: The Importance of Play as a Learning Tool
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Foolish Attempt to Weaken Truck Safety
text: The trucking industry is again pushing Congress to allow bigger and heavier trucks with overworked drivers behind the wheel onto the country’s roads.

headline: Long Odds in the Game of Life
text: LAS VEGAS — THE first essay assignment I give to my freshman composition students is to answer the question, “Why are you pursuing a university education?”

headline: To Save New York’s Public Housing
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled a plan last week to turn the New York City Housing Authority around. It lays out a broad-based assault on a huge problem: the rotten condition of the 328 public-housing developments that more than 400,000 New Yorkers call home.

headline: Jason Rezaian of Washington Post Goes on Trial in Iran
text: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent accused by Iran of espionage who has been imprisoned for more than 10 months, went on trial in a Tehran courtroom on Tuesday morning, state news media reported.

headline: When Family-Friendly Policies Backfire
text: In Chile, a law requires employers to provide working mothers with child care. One result? Women are paid less.

text: Below are several paragraphs from the May 20 article “Minecraft Stars on YouTube Share Secrets to Their Celebrity.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Ireland, by Popular Vote, Allows Same-Sex Marriage
text: In “Catholic Church Ponders Future After Same-Sex Marriage Vote in Ireland,” Danny Hakim writes about the landmark vote and what it could mean for the Roman Catholic Church in that nation.

headline: U.S. Caution in Strikes Gives ISIS an Edge, Many Iraqis Say
text: WASHINGTON — American intelligence analysts have identified seven buildings in downtown Raqqa in eastern Syria as the main headquarters of the Islamic State. But the buildings have gone untouched during the 10-month allied air campaign.

headline: If You Had a Fortune to Donate, What Causes or Organizations Would You Support?
text: Imagine that at some point in the future, you have made a sizable fortune. What would you spend it on? How likely do you think you would be to invest in programs designed to help people? Why?

headline: Chinese Distiller Sued in Test of State v. Private Ownership
text: Many of China’s high-end liquor producers have experienced difficulties since President Xi Jinping assumed power more than two years ago and opened a campaign against official corruption and ostentatious living. But the state-owned Wuliangye, one of the country’s leading manufacturers of alcoholic beverages, now faces a problem with far deeper roots.

headline: ‘Palace of Treason,’ by Jason Matthews
text: “Red Sparrow,” Jason Matthews’s debut thriller, is a challenging act to follow. Lavished with deserved praise, it introduced Dominika Egorova, of the Russian Intelligence Service, one of the most complex and compelling heroines to grace the espionage genre. Brave, beautiful and deadly, Egorova is a synesthete, who sees a halo of color above the heads of those around her, and a graduate of the Sparrow School, where female agents are taught advanced sexual techniques as an aid to seduction and recruitment.

headline: Hollywood
text: Who qualifies as an icon? What deserves to be called iconic? In matters of Hollywood, a designation that originally pertained to religious imagery is now regularly applied to subjects as secular as “Animal House,” Sandra Bullock, “Vertigo,” W. C. Fields and that scene in the original “Friday the 13th” where Kevin Bacon is stabbed through the neck with an arrow. One army of admirers may think the title ought to go to “This Is Spinal Tap”; for a different platoon, Judy Garland deserves the title for life.

headline: Humor
text: A complaint: The “humor section” is a meaningless bookseller’s term. Think about it for a second. If you go to the bookstore and find yourself browsing the biography section, you know what you’re going to get: biographies. Mystery section: mysteries. Sports: books about sports. But humor is something else entirely, conveying an intention rather than a subject. Rare is the humorous book about humor, although Joe Randazzo has just written quite a good one about breaking into the humor industry. Books filed under “humor” aren’t about anything specific. Their subjects run the gamut from “Calvin and Hobbes” anthologies to comedic memoirs to pop culture parodies to the sorts of gift books that are best read from the cozy confines of the commode. Their only commonality is their desire to amuse.

headline: A House of Worship, Converted
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Not long ago, the oldest synagogue in this college town underwent a $1 million restoration. The building, to the relief of many, was salvaged from disrepair and possible demolition. But in the process, its character was markedly changed.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Broadband at the Center of Charter-Time Warner Cable Deal
text: When Charter Communications announced a pair of deals on Tuesday to acquire Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks for a total of $67.1 billion, it put the focus squarely on the cable industry’s future: broadband.

headline: Corrupting the Chinese Language
text: HONG KONG — On a recent walk along a street in the southern Chinese city of Sanya, I heard a shop pumping out a rock version of the famous Communist Party anthem “Socialism Is Good.” Although I loathe this song, as the music became louder, I still found myself singing along under my breath. “The reactionaries toppled / Imperialists flee with their tails between their legs. ... The Communist Party is good / The Communist Party is good / The Communist Party is a good leader of the people.”

headline: New York Today: New Views of the Past
text: Good morning on this tropical Tuesday.

headline: Irish Government Votes to Shed Stake in Aer Lingus
text: PARIS — The Irish government agreed late on Tuesday to accept a takeover proposal for its 25 percent stake in the country’s flag carrier, Aer Lingus, from the parent company of British Airways, removing one of the last hurdles to the airline’s full privatization after three-quarters of a century of state ownership.

headline: Malaysia Denies Entry to Joshua Wong, Hong Kong Democracy Activist
text: HONG KONG — Joshua Wong, a prominent democracy activist from Hong Kong, was denied entry into Malaysia on Tuesday in what critics called an act of political censorship by the Malaysian government.

headline: Today’s Travel News and Tips
text: In Transit is trying out a new schedule. We will be posting a digest each weekday morning that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know. We’d love your feedback as we refine the format and focus, so please email travmail@nytimes.com or comment below to share your thoughts.

headline: Today in Politics: Martin O’Malley Readies His Hat Outside the Ring
text: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where yet more names are set to be added to the list of presidential candidates. While much has been made of the large Republican field, Democrats are ready for their own, if more modest, expansion.

headline: Reducing My Dose, Unblocking My Muse
text: I’m spending a month at an artist residency in central Mexico, where I’ve befriended a local healer named Katuza who believes in the spirit world. He believes in the power of plants, especially peyote. He believes in the temescal (sweat lodge) as a cure for most ailments, including depression, anxiety, and insomnia. He has long gray hair, a long gray beard, the wide eyes of the ecstatic. He says that I need to release the things I hold in my chest. “We will teach you how to scream,” he says. He often uses the first-person plural — maybe because English is his second language, maybe in homage to interconnectedness.

headline: How Should Americans Remember the Post-Civil War Period?
text: Finding ways to create a public memory of Reconstruction.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | May 19-25, 2015
text: Have you been following the news?

headline: The IMF’s New Cloves
text: A brief further note on the European situation: to me, at least, there are some echoes of 1998. Back then the IMF, in its attempt to deal with the Asian financial crisis, focused — as it does now in Europe — on the supposed need to couple financial deals with structural reform. In the case of Asian debtors, this meant taking on crony capitalism — and God knows crony capitalism was very real.

headline: Morning Agenda: Charter to Buy Time Warner Cable for $56.7 Billion
text: CHARTER TO BUY TIME WARNER CABLE FOR $56.7 BILLION | Charter Communications said Tuesday that it would buy Time Warner Cable for $56.7 billion in a deal that would reshape the American cable and broadband industry,  Mark Scott writes in DealBook. Under the terms of the proposed deal, Charter offered investors in Time Warner Cable $195.71 for each share in the company — a 14 percent premium over the share’s closing price on Friday — in a cash-and-stock deal that values Time Warner Cable at $78.7 billion. Buying Time Warner Cable would transform Charter, a small operator based in St. Louis, into the second-largest cable television operator, behind Comcast.

text: With the help of a reporter across the pond, my colleague Patrick LaForge unearths more examples of journalese:

headline: Ex-Trader Is Painted as ‘Ringmaster’ at Libor-Rigging Trial
text: LONDON — Tom Hayes, a 35-year-old former trader for Citigroup and UBS, was the “ringmaster” in a concerted effort to manipulate global benchmark interest rates to make as much money as he could, prosecutors said on Tuesday in a London court.

headline: Bernie Sanders: A Revolution With an Eye on the Hungry Children
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont won’t condemn Hillary Rodham Clinton for raking in millions in speech fees and campaign donations. But he warns it could curb her effectiveness in challenging corporate interests on behalf of working Americans.

text: Can you parlay a hotel room reservation into thousands of frequent-flier miles?

headline: Migrant Crisis in Southeast Asia Shows Signs of Ebbing
text: HONG KONG — No boats of Southeast Asian migrants have landed since the last one washed ashore in Indonesia a week ago. Search and rescue vessels from Malaysia and Indonesia have found no more migrants at sea. Some refugees appear to be returning to Myanmar.

headline: Rain Spreads Destruction in Houston, Killing Four
text: HOUSTON — Families in one of the neighborhoods hardest hit by flooding here survived by going onto their roofs, into their attics and on top of dressers. The Toyota Center, the downtown basketball arena where the Houston Rockets played the Golden State Warriors on Monday night, became a kind of emergency shelter, as nearly 1,000 fans were allowed to stay there after the game while the storm passed and some slept in the seats.

headline: You Can’t Get Hurt in This Precinct
text: Dear Diary:

headline: When Two Mothers — Foster and Birth — Meet

headline: Frenetic Trading of 3 Stocks Confounds Hong Kong Market
text: HONG KONG — It is a stock market mystery.

headline: Elastic City Announces Second Annual Festival of Walking and Talking
text: The performance artist Karen Finley, the writer Wayne Koestenbaum and the free-form-radio d.j. Vin Scelsa are among those who will lead “participatory walks” and other events around various corners of New York as part of the arts group Elastic City’s second annual festival.

headline: A Place to Sip Piña Coladas in Your Own Private Pool
text: To escape the tyranny of the all-inclusive big-box resorts that dominate much of the Riviera Maya, the pristine stretch of coastline that stretches from Cancun to Tulum (and beyond), there’s Mahekal — a 122-room boutique hotel nestled on the glistening Caribbean Sea and right off bustling Fifth Avenue in Playa del Carmen. Opened in December, the luxury village is comprised of many thatched-roof, airy casitas that are both plush and vibrant. Splurge for one a stone’s throw from the beach with your own private plunge pool. When you get tired of sipping banana piña coladas at the infinity pool or in the hammock on your porch, hire a private boat that leaves right from the property’s water edge to take you 30 minutes down the coast to Ihna Bay, where you’ll find shallow reefs and dazzlingly clear water ideal for snorkeling. Unplugging from the world is practically mandated — there are no televisions, and Wi-Fi, while it is available in the rooms, is spotty. Access to shopping and ruins is easy — but not worth sacrificing a day in paradise.

headline: Shopping Online for Hillary Clinton Keepsakes
text: For Hillary Rodham Clinton supporters, the campaign kitsch has arrived.

headline: Daily Report: As Facebook Sweeps Across Europe, Regulators Gird for Battle
text: One arm of the European Union is looking into whether Facebook and other tech companies unfairly favor their own services over those of rivals. At least five data protection watchdogs across the region are questioning Facebook’s privacy settings, Mark Scott writes.

headline: New Jersey Lassa Fever Death Prompts C.D.C. Action
text: WASHINGTON — The story had the grim ring of familiarity. A man who had come from Liberia showed up at a hospital, complaining of fever and tiredness. He was examined and sent home. Several days later he was hospitalized again, in worse condition. In another few days he was dead.

headline: The Cannes Catwalk: Brand Ambassadors Run a Little Loose
text: Even beyond the shoes kerfuffle — you know: the one where flats were “banned” from the red carpet, causing a long, dark night of the soul among those who fear female fashion stereotyping everywhere — the 12 days of celebrity preening and pitching that recently came to an end at the Cannes Film Festival looked pretty noteworthy, at least from a style perspective.

headline: Why I Invite Kids to Send Essays About Money
text: For the last several years I have invited readers to submit outstanding college application essays about money, work and social class. Let me start by admitting the selfish motive for this: Reading these essays in their raw and occasionally not-quite-edited glory is an absolute blast.

headline: 1915: German Aeroplane Destroyed
text: Describing the failure of a German aerial raid on Paris yesterday [May 26], the French Ministry of War yesterday issued the following communiqué: — ‘‘A German aeroplane which was heading for Paris this morning encountered the aeroplane squadrons of the entrenched camp and dropped some of his bombs without any results at Villenoy, near Meaux. Warned of the enemy’s raid, the French aeroplane squadrons at the front awaited his return, and the machine, an Aviatik, which was still carrying four bombs, was brought down by one of our aviators near Braine, in the Soissons region.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, May 27, 1915

headline: Visa Signature: Experience New York
text: A couple’s getaway to New York reveals hidden gems, thanks to tips from the Park Hyatt New York’s concierge service: the city’s best pizza, its finest fashions and its most stunning views.

headline: Readers’ Turn: The Dad Bod
text: Each Tuesday, The Upshot’s newsletter will feature a selection of comments from an article that resonated with our readers in the past week.

headline: Jury Is Still Out on European Central Bank’s Stimulus Program
text: SINTRA, Portugal — By some measures, the European Central Bank is confounding the naysayers.

headline: Houston Flooding Is Latest Example of Weather’s Sway on Sports
text: After the Rockets beat the Warriors in Game 4 on Monday night in Houston, the team urged fans to stay in their seats to wait out the torrential rainstorms and flooding going on outside. Although many fans left, others played it safe and hung around, as did the Rockets star Dwight Howard.

headline: Clintons March in Memorial Day Parade
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton and former President Bill Clinton marched with veterans on Monday in the Memorial Day parade in Chappaqua, N.Y.

headline: Bernie Sanders Comes Clean
text: Voters should be grateful for the government transparency laws that required Senator Bernie Sanders, a rival to Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination, to reveal how much he made last year in speaking engagement fees. The total is $1,867.42 for three appearances, a grand sum that is chump change in presidential politicking but enough for the senator to respectably donate the money to charity.

headline: Two Apple Designers Step Up as Jony Ive Becomes Chief Design Officer
text: Over the last several months, Apple has been cranking up the volume on two lesser-known Apple employees: Richard Howarth and Alan Dye. And it’s no wonder as the two will soon take over day-to-day design responsibilities from Jony Ive, Apple’s all-important design guru.

headline: Verbatim: Scott Walker Reflects on Israel Trip
text: — Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a Republican and likely presidential candidate, on what he learned during his recent trip to Israel.

headline: Jeb Bush as John Kerry
text: Almost two months ago, I wrote a column sketching out how Jeb Bush might lose the Republican nomination. Since then, it’s become more interesting, because it’s more challenging, to try to figure out exactly how he might win. Yes, he has the money; yes, he has the connections; yes, he still leads, technically, in the current poll of polls. But he isn’t going to take the Republican nomination with 15 percent of the primary vote; he needs a whole lot of voters who currently lean toward Marco Rubio or Scott Walker or Paul or Huckabee or Carson or Cruz or PerryFiorinaJindalSantorumKasich to decide, actually, I guess Jeb Bush is the candidate for me. If neither Rubio nor Walker were in the race, it would be relative easy to see how that consolidation would eventually happen (as it did for Mitt Romney in the end). But with them — and their own money, their own respectable center-right supporters, and so on? Let’s just say that when you’re polling at just 25 percent in a head-to-head against Rubio (and the Rubio-Walker head-to-head is a lot closer), you have a problem that a better answer to questions about the Iraq invasion isn’t going to be enough to solve.

headline: Does an Award Like the Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction Help or Hurt the Cause of Women Writers?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Zoë Heller and Dana Stevens debate the merit of literary prizes for which only women compete.

headline: Rolling Stones Start Themselves Up in San Diego
text: The Rolling Stones kicked off their 15-city “ZIP Code” North American tour in San Diego on Sunday night, delivering an energetic 20-song show before a sold-out stadium crowd.

headline: A Dutch Festival Returns
text: Le Guess Who?, the nine-yearold free-form Dutch music festival in Utrecht, will take place Nov. 19 to 22, its organizers will announce on Tuesday.

headline: Aftermath of Flooding in Texas
text: Aerial views of the Houston area show the aftermath of flooding, after heavy storms and flash floods hit parts of the state.

headline: Deutsche Bank to Pay $55 Million to Settle Derivatives Inquiry
text: Deutsche Bank “overstated” the value of a multibillion-dollar portfolio of sophisticated derivatives during the height of the financial crisis, leading it to file inaccurate financial statements for at least a six-month stretch, securities regulators in the United States said on Tuesday.

headline: Things I Wish I’d Been Wrong About
text: Brad DeLong remembers a blog post of mine from 2009 about the non-threat of an interest rate spike; I have to say that it looks pretty darn good analytically after all these years. Unfortunately, it was also right about this:

headline: Here Comes Hillary: Even Comic Books Aren’t Immune From Campaign Fever
text: Bluewater Productions, which publishes comic book biographies, has come down with 2016 presidential campaign fever. On Wednesday the company will release “Hillary Clinton: The Road to the White House,” written by Michael L. Frizell and illustrated by Joe Paradise. It follows the release of a comic devoted to Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, and there are plans for comics focusing on Jeb Bush, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida.

headline: French Muslims Say Veil Bans Give Cover to Bias
text: WISSOUS, France — Malek Layouni was not thinking about her Muslim faith, or her head scarf, as she took her excited 9-year-old son to an amusement site near Paris. But, as it turned out, it was all that mattered.

headline: ‘Ty Cobb: A Terrible Beauty,’ by Charles Leerhsen
text: Only institutions that possess actual powers of war inspire more self-righteous reflection about the uses of their authority than the Baseball Hall of Fame. When more lenient fans discuss what level of villainy should be allowable in members of the hall, a common refrain goes: “Well, if they let Ty Cobb in. . . . ”

headline: Margaret Atwood Delivers Work to Be Published in 2114
text: LONDON — The author Margaret Atwood — perhaps best known for her dystopian-future-set novel “The Handmaid’s Tale” — made a further contribution to the fictional future today, handing over a secret manuscript to Oslo’s public library to be published in 2114.

headline: Youth, Pre-Revolt
text: Daniel King’s photographs capture Ukrainian teens months before the recent civil unrest there.

headline: Asparagus: Stylish, Slender and Easily Accessorized
text: Hooray and hallelujah. Fat spears of local asparagus have made their triumphant seasonal return to Northeastern farmers’ markets. Juicier, sweeter and, obviously, far fresher than long-haul asparagus from Peru or Chile, local asparagus is a cheap thrill; get it while you can.

headline: SFX Reaches $774 Million Deal for Founder to Take Company Private
text: SFX Entertainment, a company started to capitalize on the popularity of dance music festivals, has reached a $774 million deal for its founder, Robert F.X. Sillerman, to take the company private, less than two years after its initial public offering.

headline: Treating Corporations as People
text: As a Republican presidential candidate, Mitt Romney once responded to a heckler by saying, “Corporations are people, my friend.”

headline: Ugly Fruits Get Their Day
text: A European advertising campaign asks why fruit that simply isn’t pretty needs to get thrown away.

headline: 1965: Voting Rights Bill Adopted
text: WASHINGTON — After five weeks of debate, the Senate today [May 26] approved President Johnson’s Negro voting rights bill by a 77-to-19 roll call. Senate passage of the historic measure came after the isolated Southern camp concluded a bitter verbal assault on the bill, which would suspend literacy tests and install federal registrars throughout much of the old Confederacy. The bill now goes to the House. Should the House, however, insist on making some relatively minor changes in the voting bill, a conference could still be avoided by sending the revised draft back to the Senate for approval. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 27, 1965

headline: Lassa Fever Carries Little Risk to Public, Experts Say
text: The report that a man who traveled from Liberia to New Jersey had died on Monday from the viral illness Lassa fever is another reminder that infectious diseases can hop continents and elude detection by health care workers who do not know a patient’s travel history.

headline: Iraqi Army and Shiite Militias Begin Push to Take Ramadi From ISIS
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi officials said Tuesday that a combined force of Iraqi soldiers and allied Shiite militias had started moving to retake the city of Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province, from Islamic State fighters.

headline: Time Warner Cable Finds That Money Covers Charter’s Flaws
text: Time Warner Cable has concluded that one out of four ain’t bad.

headline: Toogood’s Indigo Installation in Amagansett
text: “We hereby reject and reprehend the cruel diktats of the discredited fashionista treadmill,” reads the brand manifesto for Toogood, the clothing line created by the British designer Faye Toogood and her younger sister, the Savile Row-trained pattern cutter and fashion designer Erica Toogood. Like the elder Toogood’s celebrated furniture and interiors, the project — which introduces its second collection this spring, though the sisters disavow the concept of fashion seasons — is a humanistic exploration of the possibilities of handicraft. Each unisex, oversize piece is named for a profession (the plumber jumpsuit, the beekeeper jacket) and finished with droll details (handpainted mask appliqués, “Abolish the High Street” spelled out in frayed rope) that must be seen in person to be fully appreciated. Now, Statesiders will have the chance to do just that thanks to a new installation created by the sisters at Tiina, the Amagansett boutique owned by the influential Finnish-born stylist Tiina Laakkonen.

headline: Kayak Suspect Moved Paddle Away as Fiancé Died, Prosecutors Say
text: GOSHEN, N.Y. — Her fiancé, separated from his kayak, struggled in the frigid and choppy waters of the Hudson River, reaching for his paddle to save his life. But prosecutors here in Orange County said on Tuesday that Angelika Graswald moved it away, and was slow to call for help.

headline: Suspect Killed by Police After Woman Is Fatally Shot Outside Queens Casino
text: Gunshots were fired early on Tuesday in the parking lot of the Resorts World Casino in Queens. The police were called, and officers discovered a 55-year-old woman slumped in her car, fatally wounded.

headline: Jeb Bush Signals More Funding and Faster Drug Approval for Alzheimer’s
text: Former Gov. Jeb Bush opened up last week about his mother-in-law’s affliction with Alzheimer’s disease and, on Tuesday, shed some light on what he thinks should be done to fight the illness.

headline: More Strikes at National Gallery in London
text: National Gallery employees in London began a new wave of strikes on Tuesday at one of London’s most-visited museums to protest ongoing measures to privatize some staff positions.

headline: Urban Gardening Tips

text: Kerry Trueman and Matt Rosenberg began by growing tomatoes on the roof of their third-floor walk-up in the West Village more than 20 years ago.

headline: Charter’s Advisers Stage a Comeback
text: When Comcast swooped in with an offer to buy Time Warner Cable for $45 billion last year, a small platoon of advisers for Charter Communications found themselves out of a huge payday.

text: Gabriel Byrne and Jessica Lange will play James and Mary Tyrone on Broadway in Eugene O’Neill’s “Long Day’s Journey into Night,” the Roundabout Theater Company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Ann Kirkpatrick to Challenge John McCain for Arizona Senate
text: Representative Ann Kirkpatrick announced on Tuesday that she will run for United States Senate in Arizona, setting up a likely challenge to Senator John McCain.

headline: With Short-Term Goals, Go for a Bird in the Hand
text: A friend of mine recently sold his house. It will be a few years before he’ll buy another one. Because the house was worth a lot more than what he and his wife owed the bank on their mortgage, they are now sitting on a pile of money and wondering what to do with it.

headline: Tech Rivalries Impede Digital Medical Record Sharing
text: WASHINGTON — Since President Obama took office, the federal government has poured more than $29 billion into health information technology and told doctors and hospitals to use electronic medical records or face financial penalties.

headline: Police in Cleveland Accept Tough Standards on Force
text: CLEVELAND — The Cleveland police department, which has become synonymous with the racially charged debate over police tactics, has agreed to follow some of the most exacting standards in the nation over how and when its officers can use force, and it will accept close oversight to make sure those rules are not ignored, city and federal officials said Tuesday.

headline: The ‘King of Cable’ Behind a Charter-Time Warner Cable Deal
text: When the billionaire media executive John C. Malone bought a million acres of Maine forestland in 2011, assuming the mantle of America’s top landowner from his friend and fellow mogul Ted Turner, he made no triumphant announcement. Instead, he shielded his identity through a shell company.

headline: A Drive for Swing State Votes Has Colorado’s Latinos Listening
text: AURORA, Colo. — Under the red roof of Lupita’s Mexican Restaurant, Elizabeth Oxley and her 23-year-old daughter, Leticia, work seven days a week, from breakfast to last call, to keep pace with the price of their family’s American dream. There is a $250,000 renovation on their restaurant to pay off. Mortgage bills. College loans.

headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Settle Meaning of ‘One Person One Vote’
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Tuesday to hear a case that will answer a long-contested question about a bedrock principle of the American political system: the meaning of “one person one vote.”

headline: Reporter’s Brother on Iran Spying Trial
text: Ali Rezaian — the brother of Jason Rezaian, a reporter for The Washington Post — spoke on Tuesday as his brother’s trial on espionage charges began in Iran.

headline: Obama Warns Senators on Lapse in Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — With time running out, President Obama on Tuesday urged the Senate to pass legislation to renew surveillance programs that are scheduled to expire next weekend or risk endangering the American people.

headline: Aquavit
text: Scandinavian cuisine that stands the test of time in Midtown.

headline: Restaurant Review: Aquavit in Midtown
text: Time to cheer for Aquavit and its power to defy the forces of gravity.

headline: Key to a Quick Goal? It May Be Resting in the Penalty Box
text: The moment when a hockey penalty is successfully killed has its own rhythm. The goalie whose team no longer has the man advantage pounds his stick against the ice, alerting his teammates the way a guard might signal a prison break. And the punished player bursts from the penalty box, often to join the action, skating harder than ever.

headline: Scott Walker May Let Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio Fight Over Florida
text: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has not formally announced that he is seeking the Republican presidential nomination, but he has clearly given some thought to what his campaign strategy might be if he does run.

headline: Will the Charter-Time Warner Deal Benefit Customers?
text: Charter’s proposed $56.7 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable poses fewer antitrust problems than Comcast’s ill-fated plan to buy Time Warner Cable. But the Federal Communications Commission should still study the proposal carefully to make sure it will benefit the companies’ customers.

headline: Portraits of the Youth of a Nation on the Verge of Revolution
text: Everyone knows that adolescence can be a particularly turbulent time. But in the case of the teenagers photographed by Daniel King for “Ukraine Youth: Between Days” (Damiani, $40), the nation’s then-impending revolution lends an added dimension of angst to that equation — “The Breakfast Club,” this is not. Shot in the final months of 2013 leading up to Ukraine’s descent into civil war, King’s photographs document the innocent revelry and flirtations of kids whose country’s fate is increasingly uncertain. King’s candid work falls somewhere between Larry Clark and Nan Goldin, and his interest in Ukrainian teens is part of a larger project he is working on, photographing “youth culture around the world.”

headline: Federal Panel Lets Injunction Against Obama’s Immigration Actions Stand
text: A federal appeals court on Tuesday denied the Obama administration’s request to lift a hold on the president’s executive actions on immigration, which would have granted protection from deportation as well as work permits to millions of immigrants in the country illegally.

headline: Security Researchers Start Effort to Protect ‘Smart’ Cities
text: It’s a brave new world when hackers step in to protect citizens because regulators are not getting the job done.

headline: Fledgling Fashion Designers
text: Some of the best looks from the 2015 graduating classes’ best talent.

headline: ASAP Rocky’s Album Released Early, Thanks to a Leak
text: Album release dates might add an asterisk: *if there is no leak.

headline: Supreme Court Rules on Whistle-Blower Case and Bankruptcy Judges
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled in favor of military contractors facing a whistle-blower lawsuit and expanded the power of bankruptcy judges to decide claims ordinarily litigated in other federal courts.

headline: Garlic Shrimp Lightened by Its Own Broth
text: Garlic shrimp is a favorite tapa in Spain and a popular seafood dish on both coasts of Mexico. I love everything about it except for the excessive amount of olive oil, so I lightened the traditional dish by swapping out some of the oil for a tasty broth made with shrimp shells.

headline: ‘Hand to God’ Melds Gore and Giggles, Each Often Elicited by a Puppet
text: In “Hand to God,” a hand puppet named Tyrone violently bites the ear of an unsuspecting young man, and the audience, both times I saw the show, seemed unsure how to react.

headline: Jungle Camp in Malaysia Yields Graves and Signs of Migrant Abuse
text: BUKIT WANG BURMA, Malaysia — Among the debris of wood, bamboo and plastic tarpaulin at an abandoned camp in the dense jungle here lies a coffin-size cage made from sticks tied together with rusted barbed wire. Next to it, an enclosure that could have held scores of people also bristles with barbed wire. And over a ridge, the police have started unearthing bodies from shallow graves.

headline: Ducks’ Patrick Maroon, a Fallen Top Prospect, Climbs All the Way Back
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The 2010-11 season was supposed to be a pivotal one for the Philadelphia Flyers prospect Patrick Maroon. A sixth-round draft pick by the Flyers in 2007, he was expected to make the jump to the National Hockey League.

headline: Obama Urges Senate to Work During Recess
text: The president urged the Senate on Tuesday to pass legislation that would renew telephone surveillance programs before authorities from the Patriot Act expire on Sunday night.

headline: Rucksacks
text: The classic design gets a grown-up feel thanks to dark colors and luxe materials.

headline: 2 Rising Players, Bouchard and Dimitrov, Fail to Get Out of First Round
text: PARIS — While most favorites at the French Open advanced past the first round without issue, two of the brightest young lights of last summer could not on Tuesday.

headline: Fried Guacamole, an Appetizer Mashup at Abajo
