headline: Tibetan Food Finds a New Home at Punda
text: Tenzing Tsering grew up as a Tibetan refugee in the northeast Indian state of Meghalaya, whose Sanskrit name means “abode of clouds,” perhaps because more rain falls there — more than 400 inches a year — than anywhere else on earth. His résumé could be a case study in culinary diaspora: He cooked in Moscow and Siberia, at Kathmandu’s only vegetarian hotel and at the high-end Indian restaurant Tulsi in Manhattan, and was the personal chef to the president of the Russian (and predominantly Tibetan Buddhist) republic of Kalmykia.

headline: Smuggling a Beer for My Hospital Patient
text: My pager went off late one afternoon with a message from the oncology service at my hospital, asking me to see a 70-year-old man with metastatic cancer and trouble breathing. I wasn’t hopeful. I had chosen to train in pulmonary and critical care medicine because I wanted to be someone who saved lives. But, it turned out, there was so much sickness I couldn’t fix.

headline: Republican Field Stays Muddled as More Candidates Arrive
text: The announcements are arriving seemingly by the day from places like Pennsylvania, New Hampshire, Arkansas and sometimes just online.

headline: Tracy Morgan to Appear on ‘Today’ Show
text: Tracy Morgan is set to make his first television appearance since being severely injured in a car crash last June. The actor and comedian will be interviewed on Monday by Matt Lauer on the “Today” show on NBC, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: In ‘Fun Home,’ a Wife’s Late, Desperate Outcry
text: You can’t set your watch by it anymore, but the Broadway musical’s climactic “11 o’clock number” is still very much a thing, even in musicals that defy convention. A holdover from the days when shows began at 8:30 p.m. and ran closer to three hours, the 11 o’clock number has typically referred, in musical comedies, to a song late in the second act that’s designed to wow the audience before the finale, or in musical dramas to a song that feels like an inevitable emotional destination — an end point, if not the show’s ending.

headline: Review: Kamel Daoud Interrogates Camus in ‘The Meursault Investigation’
text: Harun, the narrator of Kamel Daoud’s stunning debut novel, “The Meursault Investigation,” is the brother of the nameless Arab murdered by Meursault, the narrator of Camus’s existential classic, “The Stranger.” No one even remembers his dead brother, Harun says, because the author of that book depicted him as “a poor illiterate” whose sole purpose, apparently, was “taking a bullet and returning to dust — an anonymous person” with “no name, no face, no words.”

headline: Luis Gispert’s Art of Gold
text: Luis Gispert had been in his Brooklyn studio, putting the finishing touches on his latest series, for weeks; then he was interrupted. His wife, Teresa Lopez-Castro, went into labor for more than 30 hours, before his daughter, Lucia Mar, was born on May 20. “My wife is so tough,” he says. Somehow, it didn’t stop Gispert — whose bling-inflected exhibition “Aqua Regia,” named for the only chemical that can dissolve gold, opens on May 29 at OHWOW Gallery in Los Angeles — from completing his series and shipping it out on time.

headline: Mary-Louise Parker Stars in ‘Heisenberg,’ a Play About the Implications of a Kiss
text: When Mary-Louise Parker puckers up, you’d better brace yourself for something wild. New York theatergoers first fell love with her 25 (can it be?) years ago when she appeared in Craig Lucas’s “Prelude to a Kiss,” in which she set off a fairy-tale transformation by locking lips with an old man. Now she is again demonstrating the miraculous powers of osculation in “Heisenberg,” a play by Simon Stephens, opening on Wednesday. In this latest offering from Mr. Stephens, the intellectually adventurous author of “Punk Rock” and “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,” Ms. Parker plays a woman who alters destiny when she kisses a stranger (Denis Arndt) on the neck in a London train station. This Manhattan Theater Club production is staged by Mark Brokaw, who memorably directed Ms. Parker in Paula Vogel’s “How I Learned to Drive.” (Wednesday through June 28, the Studio at Stage II, City Center, 131 West 55th Street; 212-582-1212, nycitycenter.org.)

headline: Chemical Weapon Stockpiles Greatly Reduced, Treaty Group Reports
text: In the nearly two decades since the global treaty prohibiting chemical weapons took effect, 90 percent of stockpiles declared by its members have been eradicated, the organization responsible for monitoring compliance said Thursday.

headline: ‘The Daily Show’ Sets Sept. 28 as Debut for New Host Trevor Noah
text: Trevor Noah has had a nice long honeymoon period – well, it wasn’t always nice, though it certainly felt long – but his time as Jon Stewart’s heir apparent now has an end date. On Sept. 28, Mr. Noah will take over as host of “The Daily Show,” the Comedy Central news satire show, the network announced on Thursday. Mr. Stewart, who has anchored the program since 1999, previously said that his final show will be Aug. 6, after which it will take a production hiatus.

headline: Serena Williams Struggles, but Clears a Mental Hurdle at the French Open
text: PARIS — Serena Williams joked after her first-round victory at the French Open on Tuesday that she was simply relieved to have defended the ranking points she had earned at the tournament last year, when she crashed out in the second round.

headline: Sepp Blatter Addresses FIFA Congress
text: FIFA President Sepp Blatter discussed the arrests of top officials on Thursday at the opening ceremony of the 65th FIFA Congress.

headline: James Bond to Find an Old Acquaintance in New Novel: Pussy Galore
text: LONDON — “Will you visit me in Sing Sing?” the violet-eyed Pussy Galore asked James Bond at the end of Ian Fleming’s “Goldfinger.” Did he? Perhaps we’ll find out soon: Pussy Galore is set to return in Anthony Horowitz’s new James Bond novel, the author announced Thursday. Mr. Horowitz also divulged the title of the novel, which will be published in September. Those averse to puns, look away: it’s “Trigger Mortis.”

headline: 1965: Hussein: Jordan Will Retaliate
text: AMMAN — King Hussein of Jordan declared today [May 28] that Israeli border attacks endanger ‘‘regional security and world peace.’’ He warned that Jordan ‘‘will retaliate the next time Israel violates truce provision.’’ The king summoned the ambassadors of Britain, France and the United States and cited the ‘‘provocative’’ attacks by Israeli forces on three border villages last night. A government spokesman charged that Israel prepared for the action by distributing a memorandum at the UN Security Council accusing Jordan of blowing up two houses at Affula in Israel. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, May 29, 1965

headline: Bulls Dismiss Coach Tom Thibodeau and End a Rocky Tenure
text: In five seasons as coach of the Chicago Bulls, Tom Thibodeau compiled a 255-139 record and guided the team to five straight playoff appearances while dealing with serious injuries to stars like Derrick Rose.

headline: Latvia: The Thrill Is Gone
text: Back in 2013, when Olivier Blanchard presented a paper on Latvia at the Brookings Panel, many of the participants were bemused: why was the august panel devoting so much time to a country with the population of Brooklyn? But Latvia was, for a time, the great poster child for austerity.

headline: U.S. to Limit Petroleum Drilling on Habitat of Greater Sage Grouse
text: The Obama administration, aiming to keep a finicky, chickenlike bird called the greater sage grouse off the endangered species list, moved on Thursday to limit petroleum drilling and other activities on some of its wide-ranging habitat in the American West.

headline: Art and Hypocrisy in the Gulf
text: LONDON — On May 11, the Lebanese artist Walid Raad was turned away at the airport when he tried to enter the United Arab Emirates, where the government is making a big investment in art with the Saadiyat Island project. The project, in the capital, Abu Dhabi, will include branches of the Louvre and the Guggenheim as well as a campus of New York University.

headline: An Artist Recreates Her Mother’s All-White-Everything Closet
text: “Sara was beautiful inside and out; her hair was white, and she wore only white clothes,” explains the artist Maira Kalman in the audio guide to her new exhibition, “Sara Berman’s Closet,” a painstaking recreation of her mother’s closet. “Mostly, she was adored.” Berman, who was born in Belarus in 1920, lived in Palestine and the Bronx before relocating in 1982 to Greenwich Village, where she maintained an impeccably organized closet filled with all-white clothing and accessories. The closet was both ordinary and extraordinary, and Kalman wanted to share with others its clarity of vision. “I thought it would be amazing to have people come see the closet and pay 50 cents to a dollar,” Kalman says with a laugh. “It was a crazy idea that made a lot of sense to me.”

headline: Dalai Lama Urges Aung San Suu Kyi to Help Myanmar’s Rohingya
text: BANGKOK — When they embraced democracy and vowed to leave behind their repressive and dictatorial past, the leaders of Myanmar enjoyed a honeymoon of praise and admiration from luminaries across the globe.

headline: Texas Storm Victims Start Cleaning Up, Even as Rain Still Falls
text: WIMBERLEY, Tex. — The Blanco River runs past the house Sue Sweat has rented for 13 years, and “it’s usually ankle deep,” she said, low enough to walk across.

headline: Kennedy Center Sets Lineup for New American Orchestras Festival
text: When the Kennedy Center in Washington announced this year that it would start a new festival of American orchestras to fill the void that was left after the adventurous Spring for Music Festival at Carnegie Hall folded after four years, the orchestral world took notice.

headline: Rhubarb, From Plant to Salad
text: Chef Michael Reardon prepares a salad with the “pie plant” and other springtime ingredients.

headline: What Is Your Experience With the Legal System?

headline: How to Get the Most Out of the National Parks This Summer
text: Last year saw a record number of visitors to the National Park Service’s more than 400 parks, monuments, battlefields, seashores and other sites. Those numbers are expected to increase as the agency approaches its centennial on Aug. 25, 2016.

headline: Spotted Pig Team Plans a High-Rise Project Downtown
text: Here’s fresh evidence that downtown, far downtown, has become a major dining draw: The chef April Bloomfield and the restaurateur Ken Friedman of the Spotted Pig are planning a high-altitude project spanning four of the top floors of 70 Pine Street, a 1931 Art Deco building that was the New York headquarters of the insurance giant AIG.

headline: Celebrating ‘The Goonies’ in Oregon
text: Goonies never say die. But they do enter their 30s.

headline: S.E.C.’s Kara Stein Takes Aim at Deutsche Bank
text: The recent spate of settlements by big Wall Street banks has underscored their astonishing ability to persuade powerful government officials to let them escape without any real penalty for wrongdoing.

headline: Ever Elusive Sonoma Chardonnay
text: Good wine has a seemingly endless capacity to surprise. It scorns expectations, dismissing them almost at first sniff and swallow, and turning them inside out by the time the bottle is done. This is one of the most beautiful things about wine, yet one of the most difficult obstacles to overcome.

headline: Jewelry
text: A bouquet of colorful floral jewels.

headline: Review: In ‘Inequality,’ a Respected Scholar Wades Into a Contentious Political Issue
text: The crisis of “income inequality” has become a cause célèbre. Until recently, the gap between the rich and poor was a topic rarely championed aggressively even by the more liberal wing of the Democratic Party out of fear of being branded a tax-and-spender or class warmonger.

headline: ‘Charlie Parker’s Yardbird’ Ties Jazz and Opera Together in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — On a recent morning in a rehearsal room behind the Academy of Music here, the tenor Lawrence Brownlee practiced a tricky passage at the piano. The melodic profile of his vocal line zigzagged and spiked like an erratic electrocardiogram, but what gave Mr. Brownlee the most trouble was the text.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Cava
text: Cava, like California chardonnay, has suffered from a bad reputation. Not without reason. Millions of bottles of cava, the Catalonian sparkling wine, are sold every year, and much of it is inexpensive and not particularly good. Yet a handful of cava producers, working conscientiously in the vineyards and diligently in the cellar, have demonstrated that it can be among the most distinctive of all sparkling wines.

headline: Google Intensifies Focus on Its Cardboard Virtual Reality Device
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has seen the future, and it is littered with cardboard boxes.

headline: A Jewelry Designer Who Sculpts First
text: The French jewelry designer Charlotte Chesnais delineates her preliminary ideas in clay, rather than in the form of flat sketches. “I like volumes,” Chesnais says. “The infinity of possibilities, the technical constraints…” One need only look at the lean sculptural wristlets and entwined rings in Chesnais’s first collection for corroboration. She’s quick to cite sculptors as a main source of inspiration — particularly Constantin Brancusi, Anthony Caro, François-Xavier and Claude Lalanne and Lygia Clark. Moreover, she never tires of her home base, Paris, as a storehouse of creativity. “My answer will seem pretty clichéd,” she says, “but a simple ride on my bike fills me with images and interesting silhouettes.”

headline: George Pataki Takes Aim at Hillary Clinton
text: EXETER, N.H. – George E. Pataki may be the most centrist candidate running for the Republican presidential nomination, but there was nothing moderate about his criticism of Hillary Rodham Clinton during his announcement speech Thursday.

headline: When an Off-the-Rack Rolls-Royce Just Won’t Do
text: IN the rarefied world of ultraluxury cars, buyers can already own some of the most lavish vehicles on the planet.

headline: Finance Officials Focus on Economic Growth at Group of 7 Meeting
text: DRESDEN, Germany — Central bankers and chief finance officials of the world’s wealthiest democracies received a master class in economics Thursday, as they struggled to find ways to make their torpid economies grow faster.

headline: Robert S. Wistrich, Scholar of Anti-Semitism, Dies at 70
text: Robert S. Wistrich, who devoted his four-decade scholarly career to dissecting anti-Semitism, from the biblical Haman, who warned King Ahasuerus of Persia against strangers whose “laws are diverse from all people,” to modern Islamist extremists who deny Israel’s right to exist, died on May 19 in Rome. He was 70.

headline: George Pataki Flubs New Hampshire Locale in Kickoff Speech

headline: Viewfinder: Alison Rossiter

headline: 10 Public Figures Who Aren’t Running for President
text: With the entrance of Rick Santorum on Wednesday and George Pataki on Thursday morning, the Republican field has grown to eight candidates — and that’s not including those, like Jeb Bush, who are all but sure to enter the race but just haven’t formally announced yet. As the field grows, it is perhaps easier to keep track of those who aren’t running than those who are. To that end, the following is a partial list of prominent public figures who have not yet declared their candidacy:

headline: Year-End Roundup, 2014-15 | Language Arts, Journalism and the Arts
text: As we do after Memorial Day each year, this week we are looking back and collecting the year’s teaching materials for each subject area, so teachers can find them all in one place.

headline: Study on Attitudes Toward Same-Sex Marriage Is Retracted by a Scientific Journal
text: A leading scientific journal on Thursday retracted a highly publicized study reporting that attitudes toward same-sex marriage could be altered by brief face-to-face conversations with people who have a stake in the issue.

headline: Putin Declares Soldiers’ Deaths and Wounds Secret, in War and Peace
text: MOSCOW — The deaths or wounds of Russian soldiers in “special operations” can be classified as military secrets, even in peacetime, President Vladimir V. Putin decreed Thursday. The decree comes as Russia faces accusations that it is sending its soldiers clandestinely to fight in Ukraine, an allegation the Kremlin denies.

headline: Modern Love | Losing My Religion
text: Once a devout Christian, Arla Knudsen wore a silver purity ring symbolizing no sex before marriage until, at 16, she stopped believing and it became her mission to lose her virginity.

headline: Studio Museum in Harlem Plans a Stanley Whitney Solo Show
text: The Studio Museum in Harlem announced that it would open the first solo New York museum exhibition devoted to the work of Stanley Whitney, whose heavily brushed, brightly colored canvases have made him a kind of painter’s painter over the last few decades.

headline: After a First Time, Many Second Thoughts
text: I was 13 years old, standing on stage with a group of fellow teenagers, when our pastor announced in front of the entire congregation, “These young people have all made the righteous decision to save themselves for marriage.”

headline: Race and Gender Biases Can be Reduced With Sleep Therapy, Study Finds
text: It may be possible to reduce biases regarding race and gender while a person sleeps, according to a new study published in the journal Science.

headline: A. R. Gurney’s ‘Sylvia’ Coming to Broadway With Annaleigh Ashford

headline: Cameron Presses E.U. for ‘Better Deal for Britain’
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron, with a majority mandate from the British people, is off on a whirlwind tour of European Union capitals to seek “a better deal for Britain,” warning that otherwise, Britain will leave the bloc. Not so very long ago, Alexis Tsipras, with a fresh mandate from the Greek people, tried the same with the threat of an exit.

text: Photos from Niger, Burundi, Greece and India.

headline: Chris Ofili’s ‘The Holy Virgin Mary’ to Be Sold
text: The Australian collector David Walsh is selling Chris Ofili’s 1996 painting “The Holy Virgin Mary,” which caused a furor when it was shown at the Brooklyn Museum in October 1999 as part of Charles Saatchi’s touring “Sensation” exhibition of works by Young British Artists (YBAs).

headline: Signs of Slower Growth in Top-End Art Sales
text: The huge numbers generated by Christie’s, Sotheby’s and Phillips at auction binges in New York from May 11 to 15 created a sense that prices for the most desirable Modern and contemporary artworks are rising unstoppably. But new research by the London art market analysts ArtTactic suggests the pace of growth for high-value contemporary works is slowing.

headline: National Gallery Buys George Caleb Bingham’s ‘The Jolly Flatboatmen’
text: In its pre-Instagram, pretelevision, all-but-pre-photography day, George Caleb Bingham’s “The Jolly Flatboatmen” (1846) was a viral image, a joyous genre painting of America’s westward expansion that became wildly popular through mezzotints and lithographs. The work itself, considered one of the most important American paintings of its kind, has hung in the National Gallery of Art in Washington for so many decades — regularly since 1956 — that it long ago came to seem like a part of the museum’s fabric. But the painting was privately owned, for many years by the Pell family and then by the Detroit collector Richard Manoogian, who bought it in 1986 for $6 million, at the time the most ever paid privately or at auction for an American painting. Now, the National Gallery has brought the boatmen fully into the fold, acquiring the painting from the Richard and Jane Manoogian Foundation for an undisclosed price.

headline: Avago Deal Offers Blueprint for Chip Maker Consolidation
text: Avago Technologies is offering what might become a textbook merger case. In its $37 billion acquisition of rival chip maker Broadcom, Avago’s record, industry logic, cash-and-stock mix, premium of just less than 30 percent and synergies all add up. Only an interloper could spoil the party.

headline: A Primer on Android Pay and Google Wallet
text: Google on Thursday confirmed the arrival of Android Pay and a revamped Google Wallet, an overhaul of the company’s mobile payments products, which was previously reported by The New York Times.

text: Roughly three weeks after their arrest in a federal corruption case, Dean G. Skelos, the former majority leader of the New York Senate, and his son were indicted by a grand jury on Thursday on charges of extortion, wire fraud, conspiracy and bribe solicitation.

text: The Nigerian-born, British-educated lawyer-turned-fashion-designer merges riotous prints with daring shapes for collections that transcend trends — and global boundaries.

headline: Review: International Contemporary Ensemble Weaves Among Tonalities
text: Pianists are usually the only musicians who require a helper onstage — the page turner. But during Wednesday’s concert by the International Contemporary Ensemble at the Abrons Arts Center, the guitarist Dan Lippel was aided by an assistant of a different kind: a peg turner. At certain moments during the performance of Larry Polansky’s “Preamble” for two harps and guitar, the multitasking percussionist Nathan Davis reached over to adjust the tuning of Mr. Lippel’s instrument in midplay.

text: A 10-room penthouse was bought by Paul McCartney and his wife, Nancy Shevell.

headline: Appeal of Savings Bonds Wanes in Ultralow Interest Environment
text: Government savings bonds aren’t meant to be blockbuster investments; they are intended to be safe havens for your cash. But lately, rates on savings bonds are downright anemic.

text: Donning a parka atop a mountain, relaxing at the pool or watching lava flow, visitors to this part of Hawaii encounter vastly different landscapes.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Book List: Not Light Summer Reading
text: LANSING, Mich. – As summer draws closer, book recommendations are in high demand. So at a question-and-answer session here, Jeb Bush was asked for his, which weren’t quite the beach-read variety.

headline: Review: ‘L’Épreuve Villageoise,’ a Rare Gem, at Gould Hall
text: Believe it or not, we have Parisian music critics from the mid-1780s to thank for the existence of “L’Épreuve Villageoise” (“The Village Trial”), an utterly charming French comic opera by André Grétry. And a delighted audience at Gould Hall on Wednesday night had Opera Lafayette to thank for presenting a rarity in such a beguilingly simple production, directed by Nick Olcott, with a winning cast.

headline: Review: ‘Russian Modernism’ at Neue Galerie, Figurative Focus With Amorphous Results
text: “Russian Modernism: Cross-Currents of German and Russian Art, 1907-1917” at the Neue Galerie is a lively, scattershot exhibition, with numerous paintings of great interest, others of not so much and many by Russian artists most of us have barely heard of.

headline: Review: Simon Denny Sees the Dark Side of Technology at MoMA PS1
text: In a recent column for The New York Times, the economist Paul Krugman argued that the benefits of the digital technology revolution of the past four decades have been greatly overestimated. The new technologies, he suggested, might be “more fun than fundamental.” Worse, euphoric media chatter about how they’re changing the world for the better “acts as a distraction from more mundane issues,” like putting people to work in usefully productive jobs.

headline: Arrests Overshadow Palestinians’ Bid to Oust Israel From FIFA
text: ZURICH — The protesters outside the arena where FIFA staged the opening ceremony for its annual congress Thursday held Palestinian flags and blunt banners.

headline: Review: Lilja Birgisdottir, ‘If Your Colors Were Like My Dream’
text: When artists refer to color theory, they usually mention thinkers like Isaac Newton, Goethe and Josef Albers. The Icelandic artist Lilja Birgisdottir takes a different approach, employing New Age aura reading and wardrobe color analysis. The results in this small, minimal show — her first solo exhibition in New York — are poetic and provocative.

headline: An Unsettling Report on Iran and North Korea
text: As the clock ticks down to a June 30 deadline for a nuclear deal with Iran, the news has emerged that North Korean nuclear and missile experts may (I emphasize may because I have seen no confirmation) have visited a military site near Tehran last month.

headline: Review: Tabor Robak, ‘Fake Shrimp’
text: If memory serves, the artist John Baldessari once argued in effect that a new medium loses it newness when artists start using it as naturally as they would a pencil. The brilliant digital artist Tabor Robak is way past that point, as demonstrated by his second solo show in New York, and at this gallery.

headline: On Twitter, Obama Talks Climate, Trade, Bulls and LeBron
text: President Obama got some use out of his new Twitter account on Thursday, logging on for a live chat about climate change.

headline: John Wesley: ‘Important Works From 1961 to 1966’
text: The cartoon-based paintings and sculptures that John Wesley produced at the start of his career in the 1960s were widely seen as examples of Pop Art. But the works had a poetic psychology unlike those of most other Pop stylists. An apposite piece in this wonderful show is a table from 1965 with the profiles of Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant painted on its round top and pictures of a standing, sexy woman on each side of its square base. The two parts appear unrelated, but considering that Mr. Wesley was then in the middle years of a marriage to the painter Jo Baer that he once called “a disaster,” a play between civil war and union of the sexes comes to mind.

headline: How Netflix Keeps Finding Itself on the Same Side as Regulators
text: Whatever the outcome of the latest proposed mergers and acquisitions in the media industry, a clear winner has already emerged, and it’s not even a party to any of the deals: Netflix, the streaming television pioneer.

headline: Madoff Accountant Avoids Prison Term
text: By his own admission, David G. Friehling was not much of an auditor for Bernard L. Madoff — pretty much rubber-stamping financial statements for the man who masterminded an enormous Ponzi scheme.

headline: Review: Ramin and Rokni Haerizadeh and Hesam Rahmanian
text: Satire, gender-bending and exuberantly mixed mediums are among the feats of this art extravaganza, an exhibition that never stops giving. It features the collective and individual efforts of two Iranian brothers — Ramin and Rokni Haerizadeh — and their Iranian-American friend Hesam Rahmanian. To unite the array, the artists have painted the gallery’s floor and walls to suggest a Middle Eastern courtyard; they have also festooned white plastic lawn chairs with blue tape and collaborated on videos, assemblages, bulky but often arresting paintings and a functioning fountain that once graced the foyer of their home in Dubai. Adding to the show’s expansive embrace are impressive works from their art collection by six women: Martha Wilson, Etel Adnan, Rose Wylie, Angela Dufresne, A. K. Burns and Hannah Barrett.

headline: Anxiety on Campus: Reporter’s Notebook
text: I’ve been working for more than a month on the  article about increased anxiety among college students. But I’ve been reporting stories about teenagers and young adults since long before my girls were born — and now they’re teenagers.

headline: Risks to Hands-Free Driving
text: A growing number of new cars have sophisticated technologies designed to prevent accidents and make driving less stressful and monotonous. Some of these advances also pose a potential problem: they could increase distracted driving.

headline: Colorado Killer James Holmes’s Notes: Detailed Plans vs. ‘a Whole Lot of Crazy’
text: DENVER — The spiral notebook is a road map to murder, filled with plans, diagrams and to-do lists that James E. Holmes laid out in scrupulous detail before carrying out a shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater. In his own handwriting, he plans a “mass murder spree” and considers theaters and times to attack for “maximum casualties.” He also plots his own psyche with pages of self-diagnosis of what he calls his “broken mind.”

headline: Review: Highway Restaurant & Bar in East Hampton
text: When it comes to restaurants, is there such a thing as a doomed location? An address where nothing can survive, no matter the quality of the venture? If so, then 290 Montauk Highway in East Hampton might be such a spot. It’s the restaurant version of a black hole, swallowing no fewer than five establishments in a little over 10 years. Many of these lasted but a single season; others just a few months.

text: The affection in which the ballerinas Paloma Herrera and Xiomara Reyes have been held was matched on Wednesday by the warmth with which they greeted their colleagues and audiences at their farewell performances. Ms. Herrera danced the matinee of “Giselle” at the Metropolitan Opera House, Ms. Reyes the evening.

The latest, which opened in November 2013, is Locali Pizza Bar & Kitchen, whose name is Italian slang for “the spot,” and whose food and fair prices suggest it may have found a permanent home.

headline: Review: George Cables Trio at the Village Vanguard

At 70, he’s led a band at the Village Vanguard only once before, and only last August. This week he’s there for the second time, and played to a full and engaged room on a Wednesday night.

This passion for plein air painting is a phenomenon of recent years that has come to include competitions, workshops and shows in towns, villages and scenic spots like the Eastern Shore of Maryland, which hosts more than 200 artists each July at Plein Air Easton.

headline: A New Jersey Sausage-Eater’s Tour of Europe
text: When Herminio Lopes, the owner of Lopes Sausage Company in Newark, got a call from the White House in 1996 with a request for 100 pounds of linguiça and chorizo to be packed for President Bill Clinton, he didn’t believe it — until Secret Service agents showed up two hours later to check the shipment.

headline: Undefeated Boxer Keeps Up the Fight for His Mother’s Oxtail Stew

headline: U.S. Accuses Ex-House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Paying to Hide ‘Misconduct’
text: CHICAGO — J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, has been charged with lying to the F.B.I. and making cash withdrawals from banks in a way that was designed to hide that he was paying $3.5 million to someone for his “misconduct” from years ago, a federal indictment released on Thursday said.

headline: Review: ‘From Bauhaus to Buenos Aires: Grete Stern and Horacio Coppola,’ a Bicontinental Couple
text: Divided into alternating his-and-hers rooms and zigzagging across the Western Hemisphere, it’s hard to tell at first if “From Bauhaus to Buenos Aires: Grete Stern and Horacio Coppola” at the Museum of Modern Art is about an artistic couple, 20th-century migration or European modernism and its diaspora. In many ways, it’s about all of these. But despite more than 300 somber, high-contrast vintage black-and-white photographs, films and display cases of ephemera organized in neat rows, the exhibition is a bit of a hot mess.

headline: U.S. Soccer Will Support Blatter Rival in FIFA Election
text: ZURICH — At dawn on Wednesday, Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, woke with a start, his phone buzzing on the desk of his room at a luxury hotel here. A police raid was quietly going on in the halls around him, and some of Mr. Gulati’s closest professional colleagues — a few of them his friends — were being arrested on various charges related to corruption. The calls and texts did not stop for hours.

headline: Mmuseumm 2 to Open in TriBeCa, All 20 Square Feet of It
text: LOTS of New Yorkers faced with space-starved apartments and carefully assembled obsessions have joked about opening a museum of their stuff. Not many would actually go through with it. Not many are the Kalman family.

headline: Review: ‘Aloha,’ a Hangout Movie With Bradley Cooper and Emma Stone in Hawaii
text: Let me say right up front that I will always root for Cameron Crowe. That’s the kind of blunt, sincere, slightly inappropriate statement one of his characters might blurt out at an odd moment, and so much the better. He had me at the “Fast Times at Ridgemont High” script, and I’m probably not the only self-conscious, music-crazed guy of my generation who found possible alternate selves in Mr. Crowe’s alter egos: Lloyd Dobler in “Say Anything,” William Miller in “Almost Famous” and even Jerry Maguire himself.

text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Be Here Now
text: With the rise of texting and mobile communication, I have noticed that people are generally less punctual. I often make plans with friends and receive a text five minutes before the appointed time saying: “Running late. Be there in 15.” When the offending parties finally arrive, they say, “Sorry, I’m late.” I reply, “That’s O.K.” And we move on. But it isn’t O.K. It’s annoying and disrespectful of my time. What can I say without seeming like a jerk?

headline: Breaking Silence, Richard Fuld Speaks on Love, Putin and ‘Rocky’
text: After nearly seven years of public silence, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, had a lot to say.

headline: Andrew Bujalski Narrates a Scene From ‘Results’
text: A comedy about personal trainers and the clients who fall for them, the latest film from the Austin independent filmmaker Andrew Bujalski has something his work has previously lacked: well-known actors. This one stars Guy Pearce, Cobie Smulders and Kevin Corrigan. In a recent interview, Mr. Bujalski, whose last film was the more experimental “Computer Chess,” talked about working with his cast and in this video, discussed this early scene, introducing the intense Kat (Ms. Smulders) as she spots one of her clients eating a cupcake and decides to chase her down.

headline: A Havana Home
text: Pamela Ruiz and Damian Aquiles’s house is finally as they imagined it — a place for Americans to experience the country’s newly opened cultural scene.

headline: Review: ‘Results’ Tracks Exertions in Matters of the Cardio
text: “Results” is something of a paradox: a straightforward movie that reveals itself by stealth and indirection. Tracing the awkward interactions of three Austin, Tex., residents — a personal trainer, her boss and an out-of-shape client — the film seems to wander amiably, almost aimlessly through daily routines and low-key surprises. Only toward the end do you realize that the characters have been arranged into a pleasing and familiar romantic-comedy triangle and that you’ve been watching a beautifully played game of underhand slow-pitch screwball.

headline: Hillary Clinton Plans Livelier Campaign Schedule for June

headline: Bicyclist Is Killed by Car Fleeing Court Police
text: The pursuit began around 11:30 p.m. Wednesday, with an attempted traffic stop in the Bronx, executed by an unlikely set of enforcers: New York State Court officers, who are more practiced in shepherding defendants to their hearings than in patrolling the nighttime streets.

headline: A New York Dive Bar’s Last Call
text: When Timothy Fadek learned that the Subway Inn, a New York dive bar that was one of his haunts as a student, was about to close, he set out to document its end (and relocation).

headline: Chris Christie Ready to Desert Common Core Standards
text: Gov. Chris Christie said on Thursday that New Jersey could abandon Common Core education standards, changing his position as he tries to reconcile policies that he embraced as the moderate governor of a blue state with his bid to win over conservative voters in the presidential contests.

text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dance Listings for May 29-June 4
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Indictment of John Dennis Hastert
text: Federal authorities accused the former House speaker of structuring withdrawals from various accounts in order to avoid bank reporting requirements.

headline: Review: ‘Gemma Bovery,’ a Modern Sex Comedy With a Nod to Flaubert
text: Don’t expect “Gemma Bovery,” Anne Fontaine’s contemporary riff on Flaubert, to shed any new light on that author’s most famous character. This version of the 19th-century masterwork “Madame Bovary,” adapted from a graphic novel by Posy Simmonds, is only a platform for a frothy modern sex comedy, much of which takes place in the prurient imagination of its narrator and central character, Martin Joubert (Fabrice Luchini).

headline: Rare Early Proof of ‘The Bell Jar’ to Be Auctioned
text: LONDON — In 1985, a college student bought a second-hand copy of a novel by Victoria Lucas in a Winchester bookshop. It was called “The Bell Jar,” and for 30 years, it has sat on a shelf. Recently its owner, known only by her blogging name, Lucy WithaY, searched online for the name and the title. The book turned out to be a rare 1962 proof of Sylvia Plath’s famous — and only — novel, published under a pseudonym in 1963, shortly before the writer committed suicide at the age of 30.

headline: Movie Review: ‘San Andreas’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “San Andreas.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Aloha’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Aloha.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Results’
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Results.”

headline: Masthead Executives in Name, but No Longer in Place
text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Massachusetts: Sentencing Date Is Set for Boston Bomber
text: The judge in the Boston Marathon bombing case on Thursday set June 24 as the date he will formally sentence Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the convicted bomber, to death. A jury on May 15 recommended he be put to death; the official sentencing next month, by Judge George A. O’Toole Jr. of Federal District Court, will complete that phase of the process. But defense appeals are likely to extend the case for years, and there is no telling when or even whether an execution might take place. Twenty survivors and relatives of victims of the bombing are expected to speak at the sentencing hearing. Mr. Tsarnaev, 21, may also speak if he wishes; he did not testify during his trial.

headline: Kentucky: Outcome Unchanged in Governor Race
text: A statewide recanvass on Thursday did not change the outcome of the closely fought election for the Republican nomination for governor, regulators said. The state agriculture commissioner, James R. Comer, requested the recanvass after preliminary results from the May 19 primary election showed him trailing Matt Bevin, a businessman from Louisville, by 83 votes. But after the procedure, which differs from a recount, Secretary of State Alison Lundergan Grimes announced that the margin between the two men had not changed. Mr. Comer must decide by Friday whether to seek a recount through the courts. His campaign said he would announce on Friday afternoon “the next steps he will take in this race.”

headline: Nebraska: Challenge to Repeal of the Death Penalty
text: Doug Peterson, the attorney general of Nebraska, said he would challenge the constitutionality of the state’s new law repealing the death penalty. The bill, which was passed on Wednesday after lawmakers overrode a veto from Gov. Pete Ricketts, replaces the death penalty with life imprisonment in Nebraska. But Mr. Peterson, who has been a vocal opponent of the bill, said on Thursday that he believed the law was unconstitutional because it effectively changed the sentences of the 10 inmates on death row. One senator who opposed repeal of the death penalty has begun another effort to fight the new law and is trying to collect at least 115,000 signatures from registered voters, which would force a voter referendum in 2016.

headline: Anthony C. Yu, Translator of the Saga of a Chinese Pilgrimage, Dies at 76
text: The epic saga of a heroic Chinese monk’s pilgrimage to India with a Monkey King, a pig spirit and other disciples in a search for sacred Buddhist scriptures was first published in 1592. The novelistic quest lasted 16 years.

headline: Sepp Blatter’s Embattled FIFA Presidency
text: As Mr. Blatter emerges from a week of scandal with a fifth term as the head of soccer’s world governing body, a look back at his troubled tenure.

headline: James Patterson Is Starting Imprint for Children’s Books
text: The novelist James Patterson is so prolific that his annual output rivals that of many small publishing houses. Last year, with help from his stable of co-authors, he published 16 new novels, and sold around 20 million copies of his books.

headline: This Week’s Movies | May 29, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “San Andreas,” “Aloha” and “Results.”

headline: Greenleaf Music Label Turns 10 With a Show at SubCulture
text: Just after he was introduced on Wednesday night as “the C.E.O. of Greenleaf Music,” Dave Douglas hopped onstage at SubCulture in Manhattan and, with a chuckle, tried to dial back any hint of grandiosity. But Mr. Douglas — the irrepressible trumpeter-composer-bandleader, and an organizer of people and ideas — wasn’t undercutting the point of the evening, a 10th-anniversary celebration for his record label. If anything, he seemed proud, and a bit protective, of the label’s tenacious modesty of scale.

headline: Retracted Scientific Studies: A Growing List
text: The retraction by Science of a study of changing attitudes on gay marriage is the latest in a growing number of prominent withdrawals of the results of studies from scientific literature.

headline: Many Companies Cut Ads From TLC’s ‘19 Kids and Counting’
text: At least 20 companies have distanced themselves from TLC’s popular reality show “19 Kids and Counting” since the cable network announced last week that it was withdrawing the program from its lineup. The network’s decision — and the subsequent move by brands to remove ads — came after a report that one of the show’s stars, Josh Duggar, had been investigated on suspicion of molesting several underage girls.

headline: World Cup Sponsors’ Situation Is Complex
text: World Cup sponsors demonstrated various levels of caution in their responses this week to the United States Justice Department’s indictment of nine FIFA officials on corruption charges.

headline: Review: ‘Heaven Knows What’ Dramatizes a Young Junkie’s Life
text: The characters of the junkie chronicle “Heaven Knows What” lead their lives in the open, which is to say on the streets of New York. Whenever a couple of them are arguing — which is frequently — you glimpse passers-by steering their way around the commotion with the practiced resolve of New Yorkers trying to mind their own business. At the very least, the directors, Josh and Benny Safdie, have created a small, beautiful classic of street theater by rendering these public disputes within a vibrant Manhattan setting through ingenious photography.

headline: Reality Checks in Debate Over Surveillance Laws
text: WASHINGTON — As the Senate moves closer to a Sunday night showdown over whether it will let Patriot Act surveillance powers expire on Monday, supporters and critics of how the government has used those authorities have been using increasingly alarming language.

headline: Gigi Jordan Receives 18-Year Sentence for Killing Her Son
text: A wealthy businesswoman who poisoned her son in a Manhattan hotel room was sentenced to 18 years in state prison for manslaughter on Thursday, ending a bizarre case that turned on her claim that she murdered her child to prevent him from being sexually tortured.

headline: Morris Wilkins, Who Lured Honeymooners to Poconos, Dies at 90
text: During the post-World War II marriage boom, when gas shortages persuaded honeymooners from New York and Philadelphia to stay closer to home, hoteliers began luring newlyweds to the Poconos instead of to Niagara Falls.

headline: Michael King, Builder of a TV Empire, Dies at 67
text: Michael King, who with his brother transformed King World Productions, a modest company they inherited from their father, into a syndicator of television megahits like “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” “Jeopardy!” and “Wheel of Fortune,” died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 67.

headline: Review: In ‘I Believe in Unicorns,’ a Princess Meets Her Punk Prince Charming
text: Like its heroine, “I Believe in Unicorns” is faltering and undeveloped, but with a wiry core that belies its apparent uncertainty. Stretched to 80 minutes, the story (by the director Leah Meyerhoff) almost breaks; that it holds together without compromising its simplicity or emotional authenticity only proves that, contrary to the  maxim, you don’t need a gun if you’ve got the right girl.

headline: Obama, in Miami, Comments on Extreme Weather, Terrorism, Cuban-Americans and Basketball
text: MIAMI — The visit lasted less than 24 hours, but President Obama managed to use a stop in South Florida to maximum advantage as he touched on some of the highest priorities of an administration heading into its final stages.

headline: Review: In ‘Tu Dors Nicole,’ the Daughter Loafs While the Parents Are Away
text: “Tu Dors Nicole,” the third feature by the Québécois director Stéphane Lafleur, is a movie about wasting time. Is there really such a thing? Or is all of life what might be called “a learning experience” with interludes in which nothing seems to be happening, while a storm brews.

headline: Chimpanzees in Liberia, Used in New York Blood Center Research, Face Uncertain Future
text: After about 30 years of using a colony of chimpanzees in Liberia for biomedical research, which ended 10 years ago, the New York Blood Center has now withdrawn all funding for them, prompting animal welfare groups to urge the center to reconsider its decision.

headline: ISIS Alternates Stick and Carrot to Control Palmyra
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hours after they swept into the Syrian city of Palmyra last week, Islamic State militants carried out scores of summary executions, leaving the bodies of victims — including dozens of government soldiers — in the streets.

headline: U.N. Resolves to Combat Plundering of Antiquities by ISIS
text: Increasingly frustrated by the Islamic State’s brazen pillaging and trafficking of artifacts in the Middle East, all members of the United Nations agreed on Thursday to take new steps intended to thwart and prosecute antiquities smugglers, ensure the return of plundered ancient treasures and counter what diplomats described as “cultural cleansing,” a new tactic of war to spread hatred and erase the heritage of civilizations.

headline: Review: ‘The True Cost’ Investigates High Price of Fashion Bargains
text: A distressing overview of the consequences of our addiction to fast fashion, “The True Cost” might suggest another exposé of corporate greed versus environmental well-being. That is certainly in evidence, but under the gentle, humane investigations of its director, Andrew Morgan, what emerges most strongly is a portrait of exploitation that ought to make us more nauseated than elated over those $20 jeans.

headline: Pataki Kept His Own Counsel on Matters of Family and Citizenship
text: “I don’t want to get into that,” George E. Pataki said one evening in 1996, when asked why he was hanging around in the audience at the San Diego Convention Center instead of backstage with the other speakers.

headline: Forget the Calls. Players Challenge the People Who Make Them.
text: PARIS — The cooling-off period continued Thursday at the French Open.

headline: China’s Publishers Court America as Its Authors Scorn Censorship
text: A few years ago, the Chinese writer Murong Xuecun had the kind of career most novelists dream about. His eight books had sold two million copies in China, and he had amassed more than eight million social media followers.

headline: Complaints Rise Against Nation’s Railroad Police
text: WASHINGTON — Since the days when Jesse James robbed trains in the Old West, obscure police forces run by the nation’s railroads have operated with the power to make arrests, issue warrants and perform undercover work.

headline: Let Patriot Act Provisions Expire
text: Barring a last-minute compromise, congressional authorization for the program the government uses to sweep up Americans’ phone records in bulk will lapse on Sunday. That would be perfectly fine.

headline: Political Fights Throw Sand in Gears of S.E.C.
text: More than once this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission was close to securing a landmark accounting fraud case. Then it came undone, the result of divisions within the S.E.C. And now the case might be back on track — that is, unless it’s not.

headline: 15 Chinese Accused of Using Test-Taking Impostors for College Entrance Exams
text: BOSTON — Fifteen Chinese nationals have been accused of cheating the college entrance examination system with a scheme that involved fake passports and test-taking impostors, according to a federal indictment unsealed on Thursday.

headline: Yemen: Amnesty Says Antiaircraft Fire by Houthis Has Killed Many Civilians
text: Antiaircraft munitions fired by Yemen’s Houthi rebels have killed or maimed scores of civilians in Sana, the capital, Amnesty International said in a report issued on Thursday. Doctors and residents told the group that the munitions were the leading cause of casualties in the city, adding to the many dangers that have confronted civilians during the conflict between the Houthis and their allies and a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia. Airstrikes by the Saudi coalition that struck weapons depots in residential areas in the capital have also killed and wounded residents, the group found. In two recent airstrikes, residents told Amnesty that the coalition had provided no warning beforehand.

headline: Rangers Rule New York, a City of Shrinking Success
text: New York City has never been a “good try” kind of town. That applies, quite naturally, to its sporting interests.

headline: Syria: Insurgent Coalition Pushes Assad’s Forces From a Stronghold
text: Insurgents seized one of the last Syrian government positions in the northern province of Idlib on Thursday night, in the latest in a series of recent gains by a newly effective opposition coalition that includes the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda as well as other Islamist factions and a few nationalist groups backed by the United States. The government forces’ quick retreat from the small city of Ariha left insurgents celebrating in the streets and made it appear increasingly unlikely that forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad would retake the provincial capital, also called Idlib, as officials vowed to do when it fell to insurgents two months ago. The government is also facing advances by the Islamic State, which seized the central desert city of Palmyra last week. Taking Ariha puts the insurgents a step closer to the government’s coastal strongholds and the plains around the city of Hama.

headline: North Carolina Governor Vows to Veto a Bill Seen as Targeting Gay Marriage
text: ATLANTA — In a sharp rebuff to lawmakers in his party, North Carolina’s Republican governor said on Thursday that he would veto a measure to allow certain public officials to refuse to perform marriage ceremonies on the basis of their religious beliefs.

headline: New Round in a Rivalry for de Blasio and Cuomo
text: ALBANY — Mayor Bill de Blasio, his political agenda imperiled in the final days of the state legislative session, let off some steam this week when he urged Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to show “leadership” with lawmakers.

headline: Review: ‘Cagney,’ a Tribute to the Tough Guy Who Tapped
text: Normally, if you’re doing a musical about James Cagney, casting is a challenge. Not so for the York Theater Company’s “Cagney.” Robert Creighton, who wrote the music and lyrics (with Christopher McGovern), just cast himself.

headline: Review: ‘An Act of God,’ With Jim Parsons as an Almighty Comedian
text: If God were really as adorable and funny as Jim Parsons in the new Broadway show “An Act of God,” perhaps many more of us would be minding our morals, rapaciously atoning for our sins and generally doing unto others as we would like to be done unto, all in the hopes of a breezy welcome at the pearly gates.

headline: Mandela Documentary Wins Top Prize for Audio Books
text: The Audiobook of the Year is not a book.

headline: Doing Particularly Well
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Now, this is an excellent Friday puzzle. Really crunchy entries, ramped-up cluing that keeps those entries just out of mental reach and a few lessons (for me) to learn. This was a fun 68-worder by Patrick Berry.

headline: Puerto Rican Mayor Faces Taxi Troubles on a Trip to Bronx
text: It was a trip that drivers balked at not once, but twice.

headline: Port Authority Picks Group to Remake La Guardia Airport
text: The first step toward turning La Guardia Airport into a travel hub fit for the 21st century was belatedly set in motion on Thursday afternoon. But the entire makeover probably will not be completed until the century enters its third decade.

headline: Taxi Commission Reassures Uber That Proposed Rules Are Not a Threat to Innovation
text: Opponents have attacked proposed rules aimed at strengthening New York City’s regulation of car-hailing apps, like Uber, calling the measures a threat to innovation.

headline: The 24/7 Work Culture’s Toll on Families and Gender Equality
text: The biggest obstacle to women in joining the highest ranks of the business world is a lack of family-friendly policies. That, at least, has been the conventional wisdom in recent years, and it has been embraced by progressive companies that offer flexible schedules or allow people to work from home.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka May Soon Return to Majors
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — If Masahiro Tanaka, with his fragile right elbow ligament, seems to be a pitch-by-pitch proposition for the Yankees, then it is not surprising that his return is a halting, step-by-step process as well.

headline: Campsites in the Heart of New York City
text: New Yorkers don’t go camping.

headline: Coach’s Process Fuels Rangers’ Procession
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The day before another defining Game 7, Coach Alain Vigneault stood near center ice at the Rangers’ practice complex, leaning on his stick, hand on hip, as practice whirled around him. Assistants ran drills and issued instructions, players raced about, and Vigneault watched quietly.

headline: Review: ‘Unfreedom,’ a Raj Amit Kumar Tale of Sex, Religion and Tradition
text: Balanced precariously on the twin pillars of female sexuality and male sadism, Raj Amit Kumar’s “Unfreedom” conjures a pandemonium of religious violence and rampant homophobia.

headline: Review: ‘Sunset Edge,’ Where Mysteries Lurk at an Abandoned Trailer Park
text: “Sunset Edge,” a first feature by Daniel Peddle, is full of striking images but badly overestimates the entertainment value of abandoned trailer parks for the average moviegoer.

headline: Word of the Day | integral
text: integral • \ˈin-ti-grəl (usually in mathematics); in-ˈte-grəl also -ˈte- also ˈin-trə-gəl\ • noun and adjective

headline: Review: In ‘Survivor,’ a Thriller About Terrorism, Milla Jovovich Is on the Run
text: Milla Jovovich spends most of “Survivor,” a thriller about a terrorist plot, running from various people. She runs from London to New York and, ultimately, into the land of the preposterous.

headline: S. Parker Gilbert, 81, Dies; Led and Later Shook Up Morgan Stanley
text: S. Parker Gilbert, a former chairman of Morgan Stanley who led its public stock offering in 1986 and organized a management revolt at that storied investment house 20 years later, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 9 P.M. (13) BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA: ANDRIS NELSONS’ INAUGURAL CONCERT Mr. Nelsons (above), the Latvian conductor, makes his debut as the ensemble’s music director in this program of Wagnerian and Italian verismo repertory, featuring his wife, the soprano Kristine Opolais, and the German tenor Jonas Kaufmann. Among the works in this “Great Performances” presentation, taped in September, are Wagner’s “Tannhäuser” overture, which Mr. Nelsons has credited with inspiring him at the age of 5 to pursue a life in music. “As he walked to the podium on Saturday he was greeted with a long, rousing ovation; many people were on their feet,” Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times in his review of that concert. “But the best indication that Mr. Nelsons was a strong choice for the job was the superb playing of the musicians of this great orchestra, especially in, of all things, Respighi’s familiar 1924 symphonic poem, ‘Pines of Rome.’ If you are going to conclude an important inaugural concert with a shameless showpiece, well, picking this skillfully written, dazzlingly orchestrated and colorful score was the way to go. Mr. Nelsons drew a glittering, textured and cinematic account of that 20-minute work from his players.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Prison is not four walls. Outside, people did not have any mercy. People would call you names, especially for a woman there was a lot of shame.”

headline: Corrections: May 29, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Alex Rodriguez’s Savvy Stumble Can’t Keep Yankees Upright
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — A younger man might have been able to nimbly slide around Oakland catcher Josh Phegley. Then again, such a maneuver would not have been necessary for a younger man — he would have arrived home far before the throw from center fielder Billy Burns.

headline: A New York Dive Bar’s Last Call
text: There is nothing artisanal, twee or ironic about real-deal New York City dive bars like the Subway Inn. Its walls and tables absorbed decades of smoke, beer and heaven knows what else as it offered an after-work haven to construction workers, sales clerks and executives. And like all things that gave this city character, it fell victim to a hot real estate market.

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Insecure American
text: America remains, despite the damage inflicted by the Great Recession and its aftermath, a very rich country. But many Americans are economically insecure, with little protection from life’s risks. They frequently experience financial hardship; many don’t expect to be able to retire, and if they do retire have little to live on besides Social Security.

headline: The Small, Happy Life
text: A few weeks ago, I asked readers to send in essays describing their purpose in life and how they found it. A few thousand submitted contributions, and many essays are online. I’ll write more about the lessons they shared in the weeks ahead, but one common theme surprised me.

headline: Selling Off Apache Holy Land
text: Tucson

headline: Horrors of Human Trafficking in South Asia
text: Thousands of migrants fleeing ethnic persecution in Myanmar and poverty in Bangladesh have taken to the Andaman Sea, west of Thailand and Malaysia, in a desperate search for someone to take them in. Some 8,000 have been abandoned in the last month alone by smugglers who offered passage and a better future. Their plight, coupled with grim tales of abuse emerging from makeshift camps in the jungles of Thailand and Malaysia, paint a horrific picture of a regionwide network of human trafficking.

headline: When Fraud Rocks a Science Journal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Test Yourself | Digging Up History Under the Classroom Floor
text: Below are several paragraphs from the May 25 article “Young Treasure Hunters Dig Up History Lessons in a Classroom’s Closet.”

headline: Bidding Farewell, at Last
text: After several false starts, Bob Schieffer, a 46-year veteran of CBS, is finally retiring.

headline: Equinix to Buy Data Center Rival Telecity for $3.6 Billion
text: LONDON — The American data center provider Equinix said on Friday that it had struck a deal to acquire its smaller British rival Telecity Group for about $3.6 billion in cash and stock.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | You Draw It: How Family Income Affects Children’s College Chances
text: In “You Draw It: How Family IncomeAffects Children’s College Chances,” Gregor Aisch, Amanda Cox and Kevin Quealy write about the relationship between wealth and college access. Before you answer the questions below, draw your guess for how family income relates to college enrollment.

headline: Model Invites Bill Clinton to Her Gala
text: In this August 2013 letter, the model Petra Nemcova rewrote an earlier invitation asking Bill Clinton to accept a lifetime achievement award from Ms. Nemcova’s Happy Hearts Fund charity.

headline: Clinton Foundation Bills Small Charity for Big Donation
text: Six months after Bill Clinton accepted a lifetime achievement award at the Happy Hearts Fund gala in June 2014, the Clinton Foundation sent this invoice to the charity, run by the model Petra Nemcova. It sought to collect a $500,000 donation.

headline: Five Things to Remember Before You Renovate
text: Before you start knocking down walls, it pays to do some research — especially if you live in New York City, where renovation can be a confusing and complicated process.

headline: Sepp Blatter Withstands Scandal and Criticism to Secure a Fifth Term
text: ZURICH — The week began with Sepp Blatter, FIFA’s longtime president, acting anxious. Normally gregarious and chirping, Mr. Blatter greeted arriving members of the executive committee of FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, on Monday with an uncharacteristic reserve. He was, according to several officials who met with him, strangely quiet and introspective. He even talked about the possibility of losing the presidential election.

headline: Bob Schieffer of ‘Face the Nation’ Prepares to Sign Off
text: Bob Schieffer tried to retire a decade ago. CBS asked him to stay. Mr. Schieffer tried again a few years later. CBS asked him to stay. Mr. Schieffer tried once more last year. CBS asked him ... well, you get the idea.

headline: An Award for Bill Clinton Came With $500,000 for His Foundation
text: To commemorate the 10th anniversary of the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami, Petra Nemcova, a Czech model who survived the disaster by clinging to a palm tree, decided to pull out all the stops for the annual fund-raiser of her school-building charity, the Happy Hearts Fund.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Neighborhood Joint?
text: The pizza shop across from school, where they know your order the moment you walk in? The ice cream spot where everyone hangs out in the parking lot on summer evenings? The cafe that always offers generous free samples of cookies and brownies at the counter?

headline: Working Through Unemployment Worries
text: Fake companies are used in Europe for job training to combat long-term unemployment, one of the most pressing problems from the economic crisis.

headline: In Europe, Fake Jobs Can Have Real Benefits
text: At 9:30 a.m. on a sunny weekday, the phones at Candelia, a purveyor of sleek office furniture in Lille, France, rang steadily with orders from customers across the country and from Switzerland and Germany. A photocopier clacked rhythmically while more than a dozen workers processed sales, dealt with suppliers and arranged for desks and chairs to be shipped.

headline: U.S. Signals Willingness to Expand Military Cooperation With Nigeria
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — As Nigeria swore in Muhammadu Buhari as the new president on Friday, the Obama administration signaled that it was prepared to expand military cooperation in the fight against Boko Haram.

headline: Review: In ‘Barely Lethal,’ a Secret Agent Finds High School Highly Perilous
text: “Barely Lethal” is an amusing comedy for a certain demographic, but because of its plot and cast it might instead draw a crowd that will greet it with contempt.

headline: Steris to Fight F.T.C. Move to Block Merger With Synergy Health
text: LONDON — The Steris Corporation, a maker of medical equipment, said on Friday that it would fight a decision by the Federal Trade Commission to block its proposed takeover of Synergy Health, a British company that provides equipment sterilization services to businesses.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Review: ‘Uncertain Terms’ Enters a Home for Pregnant Young Women
text: Nathan Silver’s “Uncertain Terms” drops a handyman, Robbie (David Dahlbom), into the emotional maelstrom of a secluded home for pregnant young women. His well-intentioned aunt, Carla (Cindy Silver), who runs the home, can’t get her own son to help out. Robbie, an unhappily married 30-year-old, predictably finds himself entangled with a couple of the residents, thanks to their restless idleness and his discontent.

headline: Meet the First-Time CFDA Nominees
text: Brief interviews with rookie nominees for the CFDA awards.

headline: Asian States Say They’ll Focus on Causes of Migrant Crisis
text: BANGKOK — A meeting held here on Friday to address the continuing exodus of migrants and refugees from Myanmar and Bangladesh ended with a commitment by the participants to target the root causes of the crisis and an ambitious plan of assistance for the impoverished and strife-torn native areas of would-be migrants.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: May 29
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of the Second Avenue subway line, outdoor lunches and a peacock in the Bronx.

headline: The Voices of Students: And the Winners Are …
text: On May 15, we announced An Invitation to High School Students, introducing a letter-writing competition. Now, after more than 1,300 impressive entries in just seven days — and some difficult decisions on our part — we’re ready to announce the 16 winners.

headline: New York Today: Notes From Underground
text: Good morning on this balmy Friday.

headline: Police Commander From Tajikistan Appears in ISIS Video
text: MOSCOW — A senior police commander from Tajikistan who vanished last month has reappeared in an online video, saying he had defected to join the Islamic State group in Syria.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Guiding Families to a Fair Day in Court
text: If a member of your family was arrested, would you know how to help? Would you know what to look for in a police report? Or guide your relative about what to expect from the defense attorney?

headline: Today in Politics: Senate Faces Uncertain Sunday as N.S.A. Deadline Nears
text: Senate Faces Uncertain Sunday as N.S.A. Deadline Nears

headline: Re: When Kids Fly
text: After an article about children who take part in extreme sports was published in the May 17 issue of the magazine, the topic was taken up on the “Today” show. The hosts eventually turned the question on one another: Would you let your children participate in extreme sports?

headline: ‘On the Way Back Home’
text: I first encountered Christopher Gilbert’s poems in his debut volume, published more than 30 years ago. I’ve been waiting for another installment of his particular vision ever since. This poem reads like a love letter to the world — always new to the keen observer. The pacing of the lines enacts the experience of witnessing what seems an ordinary event made extraordinary by the speaker’s attention.

headline: Brushed Off
text: When I was young, my mother and father would say, “He will become a doctor, he’ll be something.” But my passion was art. In school, in my village near the Afghan border, I studied through matric, finishing 10th grade, and I made quite a name for myself in class with my drawing skills. But I would often skip school, and when I left school for good, this passion for painting grew. I worked as an apprentice to a painter in Quetta for almost three years. I used to do just calligraphy, but then I developed an interest in painting trucks.

headline: Bomani Jones Takes the Dismal Science to ESPN
text: You have three degrees in economics, which I assume is not common among your colleagues at ESPN. Do you still consider yourself an economist? Yes. Being an economist is much more about a thought process than it is anything specific about your job. It’s thinking about how to maximize utility and the allocation of scarce resources — that’s what I’m doing every day now.

headline: How to Ride a Bull
text: “Superstition is not going to help you,” Adriano Moraes says. When he started riding bulls professionally in the United States in 1993, he found American cowboys to be oddly obsessed with bad luck — they didn’t put their hats on beds, accept $50 bills or eat chicken before getting on a bull. Instead, Moraes says, develop your core strength. He did 2,000 crunches a day during the 15 years he competed with the Professional Bull Riders, the international organization known as the P.B.R., eventually becoming its first three-time world champion. Bulls can weigh up to 2,200 pounds and are bred for their explosive leaps and midair spins. “Dance with the bull,” advises Moraes, 45, who retired in 2008 and now scouts talent (bovine and human) and runs events for the P.B.R. in his native Brazil. “Never try to fight; if you fight, you always lose.” Stay up near the animal’s shoulders, away from its high-kicking hindquarters.

headline: The Arrogance of Jeb Bush
text: You thought he was the smart Bush. You thought he was the reasonable one. You thought he was the Republican with one foot in the 21st century, the man who wasn’t going to say crazy things to win the primary voter who believes in crazy things. But you haven’t been paying attention to Jeb Bush.

headline: Today’s Travel News and Tips
text: In Transit is trying out a new schedule. We will be posting a digest each weekday morning that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know. We’d love your feedback as we refine the format and focus, so please email travmail@nytimes.com or comment below to share your thoughts.

headline: In Varazdin, a Thriving Arts Scene Emerges
text: The Julijan apartment in the heart of Varazdin, Croatia, is as much a representation of the city’s character as it is a short-term rental for travelers. Situated on the top floor of a two-story 18th-century building that’s surrounded by cobblestone streets, the flat overlooks a small garden where more than 50 open umbrellas in bright shades rest on thin metal crisscrossing wires, forming a canopy, and the mishmash of seating includes a white bathtub that the owner, Martin Kaminic, cut in half and fashioned into a bench.

headline: In Hawaii, Surf, Sun and Snow
text: Frostbite and altitude sickness were not exactly the sensations I had in mind when I started planning my Hawaiian vacation.

headline: Director Wang Xiaoshuai Sees Worst Time for Independent Films in China
text: By most measures, the explosion of the film market in China over the past two decades has been a positive development.

headline: Malaysia Bars Entry to 2nd Hong Kong Activist
text: HONG KONG — Malaysia denied entry to a second political activist from Hong Kong on Friday, three days after the country’s police chief said that he put the student protest leader Joshua Wong on a blacklist for fear of harming the country and hurting its ties with China.

headline: New York Film Festivals Offer Variety in Topic and Location
text: A look at nine festivals and film series on rooftops and in theaters, museums and even beer gardens.

headline: Gay Hotelier Who Hosted Ted Cruz Made a Campaign Donation, Too
text: When the gay hoteliers Ian Reisner and Mati Weiderpass found themselves under siege for hosting a dinner for Ted Cruz, the Texas senator who is running for president and has been vociferously opposed to same-sex marriage, they repeatedly stressed that the event was not a fund-raiser.

headline: Year-End Roundup, 2014-15 | Math, Science, Health and Technology
text: One of many short videos in The Times’s ScienceTake series.

headline: Morning Agenda: Fuld Breaks His Silence
text: FULD BREAKS HIS SILENCE | In his first public appearance since the financial crisis, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, used his speech at the Marcum MicroCap Conference in New York to touch on a wide range of topics like the Islamic State and the American economy, quoted from the movie “Rocky” and ruminated on the meaning of life. “But while Mr. Fuld, known as ‘the Gorilla’ of Wall Street for his brusque style, was eager to share his views about the world, he assiduously avoided talking about his role in the largest bankruptcy in United States history,”  David Gelles writes in DealBook. Instead, Mr. Fuld offered his views on personal topics and made frequent references to his resilience. One example: “What did Rocky say? ‘It’s not how hard you hit but whether you get up after you’ve been knocked down.’ I love Rocky.”

headline: Police Detain Wu Gan, Chinese Activist Known as ‘Super Vulgar Butcher’
text: The Chinese police have detained Wu Gan, a burly rights activist with a signature bald head and black beard, who supporters say skillfully merges cyberspace and real-life protests but whom authorities have painted in a barrage of articles and reports on state-run television as a morally degenerate troublemaker from a bad family.

headline: This Book Is Too Old for You
text: I’ve done everything I could think of to turn my 8-year-old daughter, Hannah, into a reader. “The Magic Tree House” books, E. Nesbit, anything that caught her fancy at the bookstore. (Anybody need a six-volume boxed set of “The Cupcake Diaries”?)

headline: Video Reviews of ‘San Andreas,’ ‘Aloha’ and ‘Results’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “San Andreas,” “Aloha” and “Results.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Working Through Unemployment Worries
text: Fake companies are used in Europe for job training to combat long-term unemployment, one of the most pressing problems from the economic crisis.

headline: For Rand Paul, the Senate and Surveillance, It’s a Battle Royale
text: No, it’s not an ad for a monster truck rally or an Ultimate Fighting Championship brawl.

headline: Explosion Near Shiite Mosque Kills 4 in Eastern Saudi Arabia
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A suicide bomber dressed in women’s clothing detonated his explosive belt near the entrance to a Shiite mosque in eastern Saudi Arabia on Friday, killing three other people, according to Saudi state media. The Islamic State jihadist group claimed responsibility, as it did just a week ago for a similar attack in the same region.

headline: Holding Your Breath in India
text: NEW DELHI — FOR weeks the breathing of my 8-year-old son, Bram, had become more labored, his medicinal inhaler increasingly vital. And then, one terrifying night nine months after we moved to this megacity, Bram’s inhaler stopped working and his gasping became panicked.

headline: What’s on This Week Around the World
text: Shanghai

headline: U.S. Economy Contracted 0.7% in First Quarter
text: The United States economy got off to an even weaker start this year than first thought, the government reported Friday, as economic activity contracted because of a more dismal trade performance and continued caution by businesses and consumers alike.

headline: Life’s Unfairness, Pothole Division
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Jeb Bush Plans Appeal to Groups Not in the Republican Fold
text: BATH TOWNSHIP, Mich. — Since he first hit the trail for his presidential campaign-in-waiting, Jeb Bush has repeated this line at event after event: “There are a whole lot of conservatives, they just don’t know it yet.”

headline: Beijing Destroys Confiscated Ivory and Vows to End Trade
text: The Chinese forestry authority said on Friday that it would phase out entirely the country’s domestic ivory trade, making the announcement at an event in Beijing in which nearly 1,500 pounds of confiscated elephant tusks and ivory carvings were crushed.

headline: On the Midtown Skyline, a Race to the Clouds
text: The race to the sky has kicked into high gear in Midtown Manhattan, where a new round of luxury skyscrapers aimed at multimillionaires is on the rise in and around West 57th Street. If all goes according to the developers’ plans — and the market cooperates — the towers will climb to new heights in just a few years, setting price records, casting long shadows over Central Park and significantly altering the city’s skyline.

headline: The Savory Side of Rhubarb
text: The fashion photographer and farmer Greg Kessler teams up with New York chefs to trace the trajectory of seasonal food, from its original source to a place on your table. This edition: chef Michael Reardon (Margaux at the Marlton Hotel).

headline: Daily Report: Google Intensifies Push Into Virtual Reality
text: Google has seen the future, and it is littered with cardboard boxes, Conor Dougherty reports.

headline: Nike Is the Most Valuable Apparel Brand in the World
text: The 10th annual BrandZ Most Valuable Global Brands ranking is out from the advertising company Millward Brown, and though everyone got superexcited about the news that Apple retook the top spot from Google in 2015, there’s something else that really is worth noting: Nike is the No. 1 most valuable apparel brand.

headline: Photographer Gets Prison Sentence for Swindling L’Oréal Heiress
text: PARIS — A French court has sentenced a celebrity photographer to three years in prison for swindling the L’Oréal heiress Liliane Bettencourt out of millions of euros, but it acquitted a former minister who served under the former President Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: 1940: Female Spy Is Given Death
text: The death sentence for espionage was pronounced in absentia on blonde Baroness Von Einem, daughter of a German World War general, by a Paris military tribunal last night [May 29]. The death penalty was the second to be meted out to women spies in France since the war began. Carmen Mory, a Swiss woman, three days ago exhausted her last appeal in an effort to escape a death sentence passed on her April 28 in Paris.

headline: The Gang’s All Here for ‘Entourage,’ One of a New Breed of Reboot
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — On a gorgeous day here last spring, sitting at a tony bistro, the guys from “Entourage” were back doing what they do best. Crudely insulting one another. Marveling at Vince’s latest female conquest. And running into yet another celebrity.

headline: Downloading Mac App Updated Automatically
text: Q. Does the Mac automatically install updates to programs from the Mac Store, or just OS X Yosemite system patches?

headline: Alicia Vikander, Who Portrayed Denmark’s Queen, Is Screen Royalty
