text: “I could stop traffic,” Alicia Vikander said, sliding out of a banquette at Koi in the Trump SoHo New York as a roomful of diners collectively paused, forks aloft, and gaped.

headline: Martin O’Malley Tunes Up for Announcement With ‘Hail to the Chief’
text: Martin O’Malley, a Hillary Clinton Loyalist, Is Now a Potential 2016 Alternative

headline: Stuff We Liked
text: Here are some items that caught our attention this week:

headline: Strengthening Troubled Sibling Bonds to Deal With an Aging Parent
text: ROSIE, Therese and Linda McMahan were always close, but after their father died unexpectedly in 2011, they found their relationship strained.

headline: Biracial Beauty Queen Challenges Japan’s Self-Image
text: TOKYO — WHEN Ariana Miyamoto was crowned Miss Universe Japan 2015, participants said she stole the show with a saucy strut, an infectious smile and a calm self-confidence that belied her 21 years. But it was not just her beauty and poise that catapulted her to national attention.

headline: ‘A Road Three Hundred Years Long’: A Cinema Stirring Amid an Exodus
text: The history of American cinema is hardly synonymous with Hollywood’s.

headline: Renovating in New York: Let ’Er Rip? Not So Fast
text: Robert and Debra Liano thought their renovation plans were straightforward, but it didn’t take them long to discover that very little about New York City construction is simple, easy or inexpensive.

headline: Penguins With Parent Problems No. 5: That Queasy Feeling
text: What’s this? A Random Penguin! Let it brighten your day. And you can read more about the Penguins here.

headline: In ‘Love & Mercy,’ Brian Wilson Is Portrayed by John Cusack and Paul Dano
text: In 1973, following a creative breakdown, a long descent into drug use and the death of his father, Brian Wilson — the primary force in the Beach Boys, among the most significant American rock ’n’ roll bands of all time — became a recluse. For the next two years, he spent most of his days in bed, occasionally showing up in public without changing out of his bathrobe.

headline: ‘42nd Street’ and Looney Tunes Classics: Showstoppers Live and Animated
text: “Casablanca” became a cult movie, the author and semiotician Umberto Eco theorized, “because it is not one movie. It is ‘movies.’ ” The same could be said of “42nd Street,” an earlier Warner Bros. production, re-reissued in a sparkling new Blu-ray from Warner Archives.

headline: At This Mexican Retreat, Artists Work With the Community
text: HIDALGO, MEXICO — In a dusty patio shaded by a corrugated iron roof, Galia Eibenschutz, an auburn-haired Mexican artist, stood in a circle of giggling 8- and 9-year-olds who swayed on their heels with their eyes closed. “Imagine roots growing from the soles of your feet,” she said. “Now, a branch shoots from your head.”

headline: Selling Private Collection of Artifacts Requires Special Care
text: THE first coin that captured D. Brent Pogue’s attention was a 1915 wheat penny. He was 10 years old, and at the time, he thought it was worth $250 million.

headline: China Deployed Artillery on Disputed Island, U.S. Says
text: SINGAPORE — The United States has spotted a pair of mobile artillery vehicles on an artificial island that China is building in the South China Sea, a resource-rich stretch of ocean crossed by vital shipping lanes, American officials said.

headline: Jamie xx Looks Inward and Back on ‘In Colour’
text: Though he’s best known for playing guitar and percussion with the minimalist rock trio the xx, Jamie xx — born Jamie Smith in London — grew up steeped in dance music and was a D.J. in bars and clubs at the same time the band was taking off. Now, with “In Colour,” his first solo album, Mr. Smith, 26, is tapping a broader tonal range than the xx’s severe palette allows. “On my own, I become very self-indulgent and go off on tangents,” he said.

headline: Anne Washburn Brings Backstage Drama to Center Stage in ‘10 Out of 12’
text: On a recent afternoon, the stage manager Amanda Spooner sat at a table cluttered with a giant monitor, several coffee cups, a bottle of water, a bowl of M&M’s, a bag of sriracha popcorn, vegan cookies, Post-it notes in assorted colors and cables that slithered away into the darkness of the Soho Rep theater. It was the second day of technical rehearsals for Anne Washburn’s new play, “10 Out of 12,” which began previews on Tuesday.

headline: Blatter Vows to Tackle FIFA’s Problems
text: Sepp Blatter, the president of soccer’s world governing body, pledged to promptly address what he called the “storm” unleashed by the accusations of corruption made against senior soccer officials.

headline: Letter From the Editor: How to Tell a Simple Story
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Near Donetsk, a Rift Frozen in Time
text: For months, a billionaire-funded Ukrainian militia and whip-wielding Cossacks have been locked in a war of waiting near the long-contested Donetsk airport.

headline: Paul McCartney’s $15.5 Million Central Park View
text: A duplex penthouse at 1045 Fifth Avenue, a bronze-glass apartment building in a neighborhood where limestone and brick prewar co-ops are more the norm, sold to Paul McCartney and his wife, Nancy Shevell, for $15,500,000, and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Andrew Lloyd Webber to Share Early Version of ‘School of Rock’
text: It’s been a long time since he rock ’n’ rolled, but Andrew Lloyd Webber has a new rock musical he is about to try out at a well-known Manhattan club, and you’ll have to be on the right list if you want to get past the bouncers to see it.

headline: New Albums Feature Mbongwana Star, Karen Dalton Covers and Zella Day
text: Mbongwana Star

headline: Moment of Japanese Volcanic Eruption
text: Video from the Japan Meteorological Agency’s live camera shows the volcanic eruption of Mount Shindake on the remote island of Kuchinoerabu on Friday.

headline: Windshield Devices Bring Distracted Driving Debate to Eye Level
text: In a widely watched YouTube video, a man is driving around Los Angeles when his phone rings. On a small screen mounted on the dashboard, an image of the caller, the man’s mother, appears.

headline: Trial of Chinese Lawmaker Features Accusations of Prostitution
text: Liang Yaohui was, by all appearances, an upstanding member of the community in the southern factory city of Dongguan. Born and raised in the city, he rose from owning a barber shop to investing in oil fields, owning a five-star hotel popular with foreigners and being interviewed by one of the Communist Party’s flagship newspapers.

headline: Carly Fiorina’s Gender Game
text: Carly Fiorina — the only woman (so far) in an increasingly giant Republican presidential field — underwhelmed reporters on Wednesday when she showed up at a South Carolina hotel where Hillary Clinton was giving a speech. Asked if she was at the hotel because of Mrs. Clinton’s appearance, she said, somewhat unconvincingly, “I planned to be here weeks and weeks ago!”

headline: Dany Laferrière, a Guardian of French, Joins the Académie Française
text: PARIS — He was raised in a small village in Haiti and came of age as a novelist in Montreal, working nights as a janitor after fleeing the Haitian dictatorship of Jean-Claude Duvalier, a.k.a. Baby Doc, in 1976. Now, Dany Laferrière has become one of the few non-French citizens inducted into the Académie Française, the inner sanctum of French letters and august protector of the language.

headline: Aftermath of Saudi Arabia Mosque Attack
text: Security officers inspected the scene of a bombing outside a mosque in Dammam, Saudi Arabia, which killed at least four people.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: College Stress, Flossing and Back Pain Relief
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Between Books
text: Novelists do all kinds of things as they wait for their books to be published, from imagining unforeseen commercial success to imagining unforeseen commercial success. Just kidding — we also update our websites. But eventually we have to face the fact that we are finished with that book — finished, and it’s not even in bookstores yet — and it is time to start something new.

headline: Matt Bevin Prevails as James Comer Concedes Kentucky Governor Primary
text: After a recanvass of vote totals left him still narrowly trailing, James R. Comer, the Kentucky agriculture commissioner, on Friday conceded the Republican primary race for governor to Matt Bevin, a wealthy Louisville businessman and Tea Party favorite.

headline: Jacob Lew Warns Time Is Running Out to Reach Greek Debt Deal
text: DRESDEN, Germany — The United States Treasury secretary on Friday once again warned eurozone countries that they should not delay reaching a deal on further aid for Greece, highlighting a growing sense that negotiations are moving too slowly to avoid the country’s disorderly exit from the eurozone, with repercussions for the global economy.

headline: U.S. Soccer’s Next Generation Set to Kick Off in Under-20 World Cup
text: Even as FIFA reels from the indictments of some of its top officials, its tournaments continue around the world. Next up in New Zealand is the under-20 World Cup, a proving ground for future stars. And the United States could be a contender.

headline: Aided by the Sea, Israel Overcomes an Old Foe: Drought
text: JERUSALEM — At the peak of the drought, Shabi Zvieli, an Israeli gardener, feared for his livelihood.

headline: Request for Delay of Mortgage-Disclosure Rule
text: New rules intended to make mortgage terms more transparent and easier for consumers to understand are scheduled to take effect on Aug. 1. But although the changes have been in the works for almost two years, the lending industry says it is not prepared for the shift.

headline: Shrinking Economy? No, but It’s Not Surging Either
text: The government reckons that the American economy shrank over the winter, but no one really believes it.

headline: Nigerian Leader on Fighting Boko Haram
text: During his inaugural speech on Friday, President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria said the country’s military would intensify its offensive against Boko Haram.

headline: What I Love | Judy Kuhn
text: The actress Judy Kuhn lives with her husband, David Schwab, and their daughter in a TriBeCa loft.

headline: Palestinian Soccer Association Drops Effort to Suspend Israel From FIFA
text: JERUSALEM — The Palestinians dropped their bid to suspend Israel from international soccer competition at the last minute Friday, and agreed to instead form a committee of the sport’s governing body, FIFA, to handle their complaints of racism and discrimination.

headline: ‘They Told Me Not to Take That Job,’ by Reynold Levy
text: When Reynold Levy was approached in the early 2000s about becoming the president of Lincoln Center, friends and colleagues gave him the advice embodied in the blunt title of this chatty memoir. The performing arts center on the Upper West Side, one of the largest in the world, had become a rat’s nest of competing fiefs and bureaucratic infighting. Who would want to lead it?

headline: ‘My Paris Dream,’ by Kate Betts
text: We’ll always have Paris. And as long as there are Americans who long to reinvent themselves, we’ll always have books about Paris — books that still mention Hemingway and ­pigeon-gray rooftops, lovers in cafes and swirling Gauloise smoke. If there’s anything new to be said about the city, or a surprising new way in which to describe it, it’s as rare as a helpful French bureaucrat — at least in the latest batch of books in which Paris is a main character. Kate Betts, at least, got what she went there for. And now, almost 30 years later, she shares her coming-of-age in a self-assured book that should be given to every college senior with a Doisneau poster (or Chanel ad) on her wall.

headline: Buzzing in Midtown
text: This weekend, publishing-industry insiders and readers of all stripes will be in New York for BookExpo America, the annual trade convention. Jonathan Franzen was scheduled to kick off this year’s event, discussing his forthcoming novel, “Purity,” with the literary critic Laura Miller. Franzen represents an old-fashioned bookish draw, but much of the conference could be mistaken for a TV upfront, with new books peddled by big names like Mindy Kaling, B. J. Novak, Aziz Ansari, Nick Offerman and David Duchovny.

headline: Letters: ‘One Nation Under God’
text: ‘One Nation Under God’

headline: Gardening
text: Gardeners have active fantasy lives to keep us going despite constant setbacks. Fifty shades of green don’t begin to capture what’s looping through our brains. Lucky is the gardener who can bring those fantasies to life — to the delight or comfort of family and strangers alike. In Charleston, S.C., David Rawle has created a beautifully tranquil public garden dedicated to the memory of his mother, Theodora, an avid gardener. Theodora Park features palmetto trees and camellias; a ceramic artist has created colorful tiles for a fountain. On the other coast, Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, is sinking five billion shades of green into an Eden for his company’s new California campus. Perhaps no one will ever be tempted to leave.

headline: U.S. Removes Cuba From State-Sponsored Terrorism List
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday removed Cuba from a list of state sponsors of terrorism, a crucial step in President Obama’s push to normalize ties between Washington and Havana.

headline: ‘Emma: A Modern Retelling,’ by Alexander McCall Smith
text: As bicentenaries come and go, so do adaptations of Jane Austen. “Pride and Prejudice” (1813) begat “Pride and Prejudice and Kitties” (2013), not to be confused with “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies” (2009). In 2011, two centuries after Austen broke into print, the Austen Project commissioned modern retellings of her six novels.

headline: ‘Re Jane,’ by Patricia Park
text: “You act like an orphan!” The ­Korean-American writer Patricia Park was always struck by the strange rebuke her mother hurled at her in limited English whenever she was bad. In an interview with her publisher, Park said that when she read Charlotte Brontë’s classic 19th-century orphan tale, “Jane Eyre,” it came together: Whether 170 years ago in England or 60 years ago during the Korean War when her mother was growing up, parentless children who hadn’t gotten “a good family education,” as her own family put it, were scorned, the lowest kind of misfit.

headline: ‘American Epics: Thomas Hart Benton and Hollywood’
text: Thomas Hart Benton was already 14 in 1903, when “The Great Train Robbery” flickered onto screens, but he was still impressionable enough to become part of the first generation of American artists to let the influence of movies run through their work. In Benton’s case, “run” is almost literal; everything in the fluid, vivid murals that made him famous seems to be pulsing or coursing. His pictures were, in a sense, motion pictures, which may be why, in 1937, Life magazine commissioned him to go to Hollywood to create a “movie mural” that would bring its readers closer to the heart of the still-newish mystery of how films were created.

headline: ‘Burning Down George Orwell’s House,’ by Andrew Ervin
text: In this debut novel, Andrew Ervin works familiar ground: the burnt-out protagonist who gives up a comfortable but spiritually toxic life in order to refresh his soul and seek redemption in a far-off — or, in current parlance, “off the grid” — place, which according to the formula will inevitably be populated by locals for whom the appropriate collective noun is “menagerie.” One approaches the scenario braced for cliché. But Ervin pulls it off, and then some. “Burning Down George Orwell’s House” is a sweet book full of delights. Since many of its best passages are rhapsodies on single malt whiskies, one is tempted to call it a wee bonny dram of a tale.

headline: California’s ‘Hellhole’ for Traffic Violators
text: The harsh lessons of the confrontation between the citizens and police of Ferguson, Missouri, last year are registering nationwide — notably in California where Gov. Jerry Brown is proposing amnesty for poor people buried under the escalating costs of unpaid traffic fines. “It’s a hellhole of desperation,” Mr. Brown said, underlining charges that the state has been exploiting low-income and minority residents caught in a spiraling accumulation of court costs that they can’t pay.

headline: ‘The Brethren,’ by Robert Merle
text: Historical fiction plays a delicate trick, honoring the factual record even as it embroiders it. Where to adjust the register without straying beyond the fixed range? One of the many delights vouchsafed by Robert ­Merle’s “The Brethren” is the sense that the author is astonished that what he’s writing about actually happened — that 450 years ago France consisted of a batch of tenuously ­allied provinces, with Catholics and Protestants locked in holy and civil war; that 14-year-old ­nobles were joined in ­marriage; that kings died in jousting ­matches; that Gypsies haunted untamed forests; that castles were ­defended with blunderbusses and cutlasses. Where Merle teases this history is through his invented Huguenot family, headed by two Jeans, the exemplary Baron Jean de Siorac and his austere best friend, Jean de Sauveterre — the “brethren” of the novel’s title, united by war and joint masters of Mespech, a castle in ­southern Périgord.

headline: Mutual Fund Giants Vote to Keep the Insiders In
text: Are Fidelity Investments and the Vanguard Group, two of the nation’s largest mutual fund companies, the skunks at the proxy access party?

headline: Y.A. Crossover
text: KISSING IN AMERICA

headline: ‘Daughters of the Samurai,’ by Janice P. Nimura
text: For college students today, junior year is considered the optimal occasion for study abroad, a time when they have “transitioned” from the comforts of home, declared a major and acquired a smattering of a foreign language. For three Japanese girls in 1871 — Sutematsu Yamakawa, age 11; Shige Nagai, 10; and Ume Tsuda, 6 — study abroad began much earlier and lasted for 10 long years. They were transformed in the process, as was the country they left behind. “Though they were, each of them, purebred daughters of the samurai,” Janice P. Nimura remarks in this beautifully written book, “they became hybrid by nurture,” at home neither in their adopted country nor in their homeland.

headline: ‘Oh! You Pretty Things,’ by Shanna Mahin
text: Recent transplants to Los Angeles are often mocked for their jejune view of the city. “Why, nobody walks here . . . or eats bread . . . and yikes, Harry, there’s another set of breast implants!”

headline: ‘Beale Street Dynasty’ and ‘Dreams to Remember’
text: In 1917, the composer W. C. Handy titillated the nation with “Beale Street Blues,” his song about a true-life Sodom and Gomorrah in downtown Memphis. “If Beale Street could talk, if Beale Street could talk,” he wrote, “married men would have to take their beds and walk.” Fats Waller, Lena Horne and the former Beale resident Alberta Hunter all went on to sing it, but probably few people today know about that post-Civil War nirvana for liberated slaves. On Beale Street, freedom ran raucously, dangerously amok. Races cohabited and brothels thrived; heated games of dice-rolling often ended with the flash of switchblades. Cocaine was sold over the counter. The anarchy was set to a soundtrack of early jazz, much of it provided by Handy, the bandleader and composer of “St. Louis Blues.”

headline: ‘Gironimo!’ and ‘Lanterne Rouge’
text: There are many sensible reasons the British travel writer and humorist Tim Moore cycled the 1914 route of the Giro d’Italia (the Tour of Italy) wearing antique woolen biking shorts held up by a safety pin, on a bike with wine corks for brakes, wooden rims, no gears and 100-year-old parts.

headline: ‘The Sculptor,’ by Scott McCloud
text: If you want to read ambitious comics and graphic novels, you have many choices, but if you want to learn how to read them, you probably have to start with Scott McCloud. The writer and artist first got noticed for a teenage superhero series, “Zot!” (1984-91), then broke through with “Understanding Comics” (1993), an exegesis, in comics form, of comics form. McCloud drew himself as a friendly, bespectacled guide, demonstrating why “cartoony,” stylized faces (as in “Peanuts”) help us identify with characters; and how comics can tell many sorts of stories, whether or not there are superpowers or family traumas involved. “Reinventing Comics” (2000) predicted broad uses for digital platforms; “Making Comics” (2006) showed potential creators how to use the pen-and-ink and electronic tools we have.

headline: Physical Evidence Scant, Focus Is on Statements in Kayak Case
text: Until last weekend, the biggest challenge facing prosecutors in the murder case involving two kayakers was the missing body. That was resolved Saturday, however, when the police found the body of Vincent Viafore, 46, in the middle of the Hudson River, just north of the United States Military Academy at West Point.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Judy Blume’s ‘In the Unlikely Event’
text: This week, Judy Blume talks about her new novel; Liesl Schillinger rounds up new travel books; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Vanessa Grigoriadis discusses Wednesday Martin’s memoir, “Primates of Park Avenue”; feedback from readers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Judy Blume’s ‘In the Unlikely Event’
text: This week, Judy Blume, Liesl Schillinger and Vanessa Grigoriadis.

headline: ‘Church of Marvels,’ by Leslie Parry
text: Leslie Parry’s debut novel opens with a strange discovery: Sylvan, an isolated young man living on the Lower East Side of 1890s Manhattan, finds an infant abandoned in a privy. Sylvan is a night-soiler — if you’re unfamiliar with the profession, imagine the worst possible sanitation job that a person could hold before the age of indoor plumbing — and until he finds the baby, he’s had very little in the way of direction or hope. The family who raised him have all died of TB.

headline: ‘Bitter Bronx’ and ‘Just Kids From the Bronx’
text: Brooklyn, Brooklyn, Brooklyn. It’s all anyone talks about. From a punch line to a symbol of cool urban affluence with a literary bent, it’s had a niche in the national psyche for decades. The other boroughs look on, some more annoyed than others.

headline: ‘The Last Bookaneer,’ by Matthew Pearl
text: You will not find ‘bookaneer’ in any dictionary,” says the narrator of Matthew Pearl’s fifth novel, “The Last Bookaneer,” and he’s right. In his afterword, Pearl does claim to have encountered this unfortunate pun in an 1837 text by the poet Thomas Hood, but if so it never managed to appear in the Oxford English Dictionary. Either the editors of the O.E.D. are slipping or Matthew Pearl is having us on.

headline: Gary Clement’s ‘Swimming, Swimming,’ and More
text: Swimming pools loom giant in the imaginations of children. They’re symbols of summer, and of vacations. The big ones can be vast and terrifying. The kiddie ones can be conquered. If we learn to swim, most of us in America first learn how in pools.

headline: Inside the List
text: Feeling Lucky: To anybody who’s known a toddler, it might seem counterintuitive that the children’s picture book list at the moment is so stable and calm — seven of this week’s 10 entries have been on the list for six months or longer. (In some cases much longer: Hervé Tullet’s “Press Here” is coming up on four years.) That means that Dan Santat’s sweet story “The Adventures of Beekle,” about an imaginary friend in search of his human, is a relative newcomer: It’s No. 7 after 13 weeks. Santat’s book got a bump when it won the Caldecott Medal in February, setting it apart as last year’s “most distinguished American picture book.” The award caught Santat off guard, he told Publishers Weekly at the time. “I never really thought that I had a chance,” he said. “When I got the call, I hate to admit it, but I started crying. I crumpled to the floor and started crying.” Santat has illustrated other people’s books for a long time (he previously hit the list as the illustrator for Ahmet Zappa’s “Because I’m Your Dad,” in 2013), but “The Adventures of Beekle” is just the second story he’s written on his own. He almost chose not to, he told Publishers Weekly: Five years ago he had a chance to join Google, drawing doodles for the home page. “Should I take this job and make money to support my family,” he asked himself, “or should I chase my dream?” Turning Google down, he continued, “motivated me to use the other side of my creative brain, to write more.” It paid off. Among the highlights of Santat’s February, according to his Tumblr account, was outselling “50 Shades of Grey” (“for a brief moment”) and receiving the following Valentine’s “newsletter” from his 9-year-old son, Alek: “Dan Santat has just won his amazing Caldecott award. Many people think that Dan is known around the world.”

headline: For Cruise Visitors, an On-Shore Taste of Alaska’s Bounty
text: Nearly one million cruise passengers annually visit Juneau, Alaska’s rugged state capital, from May through September, often swarming the town of nearly 33,000 residents on day trips and shore excursions. Its main attractions include the nearby Mendenhall Glacier, where the visitors’ center offers boardwalk trails that overlook bear-viewing areas, and small boat trips to watch orca and humpback whales.

headline: Blatter Speaks Before FIFA Election
text: Sepp Blatter addressed the FIFA congress in Zurich on Friday, speaking through a translator before the presidential election. Mr. Blatter is running for a fifth term as president of FIFA.

headline: Drink and Draw
text: An all-female art show in East Williamsburg, cleverly named “Girls of Summer.”

headline: Meet ‘Harry,’ a Detective Wrestling With Grief and Drug Trafficking
text: “Someone once said the darkness that surrounds us cannot hurt us,” Harry Anglesea, a police detective in New Zealand, says a month after the unexpected death of his wife. “It is the darkness in our hearts that we should fear.” Unable to cope with his searing grief in solitude, he returns early from bereavement leave to solve a vicious murder involving a young Samoan high on the drug P. But when the trail leads to a major meth shipment headed to Auckland from offshore, the world of the psychologically scarred Harry, which includes a daughter, starts to disintegrate.

headline: Classical Music Ensembles Offer Free Concerts
text: The barriers to entry are nil in three free concerts by leading new-music groups. On Sunday, in honor of Henry Street Settlement’s 100th anniversary, the International Contemporary Ensemble and the guest conductor Steven Schick perform George Lewis’s raucous, sly “The Will to Adorn,” Varèse’s “Intègrales” and the original 1944 ballet-score version of Copland’s “Appalachian Spring.” (7 p.m., Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, at Pitt Street, Lower East Side, iceorg.org.) In the first of two back-to-back Pop-Up Concerts at the Miller Theater, the American Contemporary Music Ensemble plays works on Tuesday by the composer and pianist Timo Andres, including his 2012 Piano Quintet and the New York premiere of “Clear and Cold” for solo piano. The event on Wednesday features an enviable ensemble — the pianist Vicky Chow, the violinist Jennifer Choi and the cellist Michael Nicolas — in three trios by John Zorn. (6 p.m., Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, 212-854-7799, millertheatre.com.)

headline: Maria Schneider, With New Album, to Perform at Birdland
text: The composer-arranger Maria Schneider has been the farthest thing from idle in recent seasons: Last year, her music turned up on a film-noirish new song by David Bowie, months after her ambitious album “Winter Morning Walks” won three Grammys in the classical field. But it has been eight years since Ms. Schneider released an album with the Maria Schneider Orchestra, her flagship band.

headline: David Gulpilil Stars in ‘Charlie’s Country’
text: When moviegoers first met David Gulpilil in the 1971 film “Walkabout,” he was an unknown teenager. Now he’s one of Australia’s best-known Aboriginal actors. And he’s still playing characters who are exploring the intersection of traditional and modern cultures in that country — most recently in “Charlie’s Country,” a film by Rolf de Heer that opens on Friday at Lincoln Plaza Cinema.

headline: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet Will Take Final Bow at BAM
text: Richard Branson has his Virgin Galactic, Elon Musk has his SpaceX, and Nancy Laurie, a Walmart heiress, had her Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet: all visionary pet projects shooting for the stars. For 12 highly visible years, Cedar Lake traced a burning arc through the dance world and, like a meteor, is about to expire. The company abruptly announced its closure in March to the surprise of many and takes a final bow this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Robert Irwin Instillation of Color and Light Returns
text: Robert Irwin — an artist whose work migrated from galleries “out into the world,” as he put it, in the form of architectural interventions, gardens and barely there tweaks to the perception of the everyday — has had a rich history with the Dia Art Foundation. He collaborated with the foundation on the master plan for its sprawling outpost in Beacon, N.Y., shaping even the parking lot. Now Mr. Irwin, 86, is returning to Beacon with an installation that brings him back into the galleries as a sculptor of space and light. “Excursus: Homage to the Square³ (1998-99),” which goes on view Monday and remains through May 2017, is a maze of translucent chambers, formed with scrim and fluorescent lights, that Mr. Irwin describes as being mostly about color, “with very little matter involved,” and a nod to the color theories of the painter Josef Albers. The installation represents the return of “Excursus” to public view almost 17 years after its premiere at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea, where it became a kind of touchstone of Mr. Irwin’s working methods. (3 Beekman Street, Beacon, N.Y.; 845-440-0100, diaart.org.)

headline: Paperback Row
text: IN THE KINGDOM OF ICE: The Grand and Terrible Polar Voyage of the USS Jeannette, by Hampton Sides. (Anchor, $16.95.) In June 1881, two years into its Arctic expedition, the U.S.S. Jeannette’s hull was crushed by ice, forcing the commander, George Washington De Long (1844-81), and his 32-man crew to abandon ship 1,000 miles north of Siberia. Sides’s first-rate narrative recounts the horrors (crude amputations, madness, starvation) in the crew’s desperate struggle to survive.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties are in the West Village, on the Upper West Side and in Manhattan Beach.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE DAEMON KNOWS: Literary Greatness and the American Sublime, by Harold Bloom. (Spiegel & Grau, $35.) Inspiration’s origin, sought through close readings of daemon-possessed writers interrogated in pairs (e.g., Twain with Frost).

headline: Cooking
text: Ask anyone what makes a cookbook a success and you’re bound to get a range of answers. Some of us require the full escapist experience we’d expect of a novel, a ­cover-to-cover immersion in another food lover’s world. Some call it a win if the book offers a single recipe to add to the Forever Repertoire. Others ask: Will it offer techniques and inspiration to apply elsewhere? Will it romanticize the food we grew up with? Or have us sprinting to the nearest farmers’ market to exorcise the food demons of our past? By any of these measures, this spring’s new cookbooks deliver.

headline: ‘Primates of Park Avenue: A Memoir,’ by Wednesday Martin
text: A few pages into “Primates of Park Avenue,” I raised an eyebrow as high as a McDonald’s arch. Was Wednesday Martin, a ­Midwestern-born Ph.D., trying to explain the rites of the Upper East Side to me, an autochthonous Manhattanite schooled at one of the neighborhood’s top “learning huts”? She was a late transfer to the New York troop — a particularly vicious troop, at that — and it’s a weak position to be in throughout the primate kingdom, whether human or monkey.

headline: Debate Over the Rabbi and the Sauna
text: For years, Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt, the leader of an affluent Modern Orthodox synagogue in the Bronx, did something unusual with the boys in his congregation.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
text: This week’s properties include a farmhouse in Stamford, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Glen Cove, Long Island.

headline: 1915: Mental Strain on German Sailors
text: LONDON — Twelve sailors employed aboard interned German liners in New York have lately gone mad. Three became so violent, says the ‘‘Daily Telegraph’s’’ correspondent, that they have been placed in a padded room in the county jail. Dr. King, the official medical officer, describes their malady as ‘‘acute melancholia,’’ produced largely by homesickness and absence from their native land in a time of stress.

headline: A Hobby Anthropologist Dissects the Tribes of the Upper East Side
text: A few weeks ago, a woman named Wednesday Martin, a hobby anthropologist whose graduate degree is in comparative literature, published an op-ed article in The New York Times outlining some of the observations she makes in her forthcoming book, “Primates of Park Avenue.” News of the book, a memoir that presents itself as a pop ethnography of Upper East Side motherhood, immediately prompted intense reaction in part because of some of the claims made in it — that wealthy nonworking mothers receive a “wife bonus” for outstanding domestic performance, to cite an example — and in part because Ms. Martin, observed last week table-hopping at Michael’s in jeans and heels, had seemed to so thoroughly embrace the manners of the women she had written about with such an imperious strain of sympathy.

headline: At the Races With a Top Horse Trainer and an Owner
text: When Sheila Rosenblum, a New York socialite, met Linda Rice, a trainer and owner, three years ago, Ms. Rosenblum owned a small number of horses that had never won a race. The pair joined with another woman, Iris Smith, to create Triumphant Trio, a rare all-female partnership, which has been attracting attention.

headline: Cher for Marc Jacobs, Hillary Clinton Merch and Cannes Flatgate
text: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Women Who Bought American Pharoah’s Half Brother
text: For an industry in which the ultimate compliment is being “a real horseman,” Linda Rice is an anomaly. Barely topping 5 feet, Ms. Rice has shoulder-length blond hair and sharp features that could make her a Ralph Lauren model. The first female horse trainer to top the standings at a major racetrack, she’s tough and she speaks at a no-nonsense clip.

headline: One-Tap Giving? Extra Steps Mire Mobile Donations
text: On Monday, perhaps it was a Memorial Day parade that moved you. The sight of veterans marching might have touched off a desire to make a donation right then and there to the American Legion.

headline: Soft-Shell Crab Arrives With the Heat
text: An Alaskan King crab is enormous, with incredibly long legs. By comparison, the hefty, meaty West Coast Dungeness crab seems small.

headline: Australian Start-Ups Lure Silicon Valley Money
text: SYDNEY, Australia — In November 2013, John Locke and Nate Niparko, two members of the investment team at the American venture capital firm Accel Partners, got off a plane here and jumped in a taxi.

headline: Candida Höfer’s Wide Open Spaces
text: The German photographer Candida Höfer is often described as a photographer of empty space. Since 1980, she has focused her lens almost exclusively on the uninhabited interiors of public buildings around Europe and the United States: libraries, universities, museums, palaces, theaters, opera houses.

headline: 20 More Cookbooks
text: BENU. By Corey Lee. (Phaidon, $59.95.) A lavishly illustrated celebration of the three-Michelin-starred San Francisco restaurant and its Korean-American chef.

headline: Green Garlic Toast
text: Melissa Clark makes compound butter with green garlic to spread on toast, among things.

headline: Green Garlic Toast Offers a Hint of Springtime
text: Green garlic season is fleeting.

headline: A Guiding Hand for Those in the Backstretch
text: ELMONT, N.Y. — In his years as a chaplain to grooms and hot walkers and exercise riders and the rest of the workers at three racetracks in New York State, the Rev. Humberto Chavez had made countless hospital visits and seen more than enough fractured skulls and shattered legs. Nothing, however, prepared him for the sight of a jockey named Andrew Lakeman in a Long Island medical center one night in May 2007.

headline: Talking Baseball With Bill de Blasio
text: The mayor was trying not to crack up.

headline: Judy Kuhn, ‘Fun Home’ Star, on Her TriBeCa Loft
text: In 1989, when Judy Kuhn moved from Chelsea to TriBeCa with David Schwab, prospective visitors seemed to think a Sherpa would be required for the journey.

headline: Vacant Majesty
text: Candida Höfer’s photographs of empty theaters and opera houses.

headline: E.P.A. Proposes Changes to Fuel Standards
text: The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday released a much-delayed proposal for the amount of biofuel that must be blended into conventional vehicle fuel, seeking to reduce the levels now specified but still require modest increases over the next few years.

headline: ASAP Rocky Returns to a Haze
text: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss ASAP Rocky’s new album.

headline: New York Nail Salons Now Required to Post Workers’ Bill of Rights
text: Effective immediately, every nail salon in New York will be required to post a manicurists’ bill of rights in clear sight of customers and employees, the latest effort by city and state leaders to curb the widespread exploitation of workers in the sprawling nail salon industry.

headline: Northern Discomfort
text: The FT has an interesting although garbled story about Finland’s economic woes. Ignore the numbers, which as best I can tell are all wrong (is this becoming an FT trademark?); more crucially, someone seems confused about the difference between wages and unit labor costs. If you go to the Conference Board numbers, you find that Finland has indeed seen a rapid rise in ULC, but not because of a wage explosion; it’s all about collapsing manufacturing productivity.

headline: After Divorce, Losing Veterans’ Support Along With a Spouse
text: My wedding day was the first best day of my life. I could not have ordered a more perfect day if I had had a menu of choices in front of me. The marriage to my best friend was what I was really looking forward to. I wanted to settle down and start a family and that’s what we did. Our ideal world was lost on Sept. 6th, 2003. My husband, a member of the National Guard, was activated two days before our second son was born. Two weeks later he went to Iraq on what ended up being almost a year-and-a-half journey where he fought for his country and I fought to maintain our home.

headline: Popcast: ASAP Rocky Returns to a Haze
text: ASAP Rocky’s music has been blurry before, but on his new album, “At.Long.Last.ASAP,” it’s blurry in a new way. On his first mixtape, in 2011, he was adapting Houston slowness as one of many ways to expand the possibilities of New York hip-hop. Now he’s gone farther and made something closer to an hour-plus of psychedelia, a major hip-hop record with many different producers and guest rappers from many different precincts — Kanye West, Lil Wayne, Future, M.I.A., Rod Stewart — that doesn’t act on the listener the way such records normally do. It remains coherent and unified no matter how much it drifts and disorients. Jon Caramanica, whowrote about the album this week, explains how the album represents the aesthetics of Rocky and his associate ASAP Yams, who died in January.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Most Ugly Child
text: I had a really good time over the weekend at How The Light Gets In; to be honest, more the music than the deep thought, but maybe that’s me. Here’s one example, your basic terrific country/Americana band from Nottingham (hey, they have sheriffs too, right)?

headline: Study Using Gay Canvassers Erred in Methods, Not Results, Author Says
text: The graduate student at the center of a scandal over a newly retracted study that has shaken trust in the conduct of social science apologized for lying about aspects of the study, including who paid for it and its methodology, but he said Friday in his first interview since the scandal broke that he stands by its finding that gay canvassers can influence voters’ attitudes on same-sex marriage.

headline: ‘Devious Defecator’ Case Tests Genetics Law
text: Seven years ago, Congress prohibited employers and insurers from discriminating against people with genes that increase their risks for costly diseases, but the case that experts believe is the first to go to trial under the law involves something completely different: an effort by an employer to detect employee wrongdoing with genetic sleuthing.

headline: The Unreleased Nikes President Obama Got First
text: What do you give to the man who has everything — no, really, everything, including a bowling alley in his house? Nike has an answer that’s hard to top: When President Obama visited the company’s world headquarters in Beaverton, Ore., earlier this month, he was the first person on Earth to receive the soon-to-be-released MTM, a new two-pair pack Nike is releasing in June in celebration of 30 years of Air Jordan. MTM is named for the three men who designed the two pairs in collaboration: Nike C.E.O. Mark Parker and designer Tinker Hatfield and, of course, Michael Jordan himself. “The MTM is a great way to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Air Jordan franchise,” Jordan says of the collaboration. “It was a lot of fun to work with Tinker Hatfield and Mark Parker on reimagining two of the best shoes we have ever created.”

headline: Why Homeowner Insurance Deductibles Vary by State
text: AS with most types of insurance, you can lower the monthly premium on your homeowner’s policy by raising your deductible. But whether it makes sense to do so can vary by state, a new report finds.

headline: The “Girls of Summer,” Anatomically Speaking
text: On Thursday evening, bare breasts abounded in Vandervoort Studio in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Not in the flesh. But rather, on paper (and on a few pots) along the studio’s white walls and on a table beneath the windows. The art showcased the “Girls of Summer” — a clever anatomic euphemism that lent the pop-up show its name. “I originally wanted to call it ‘free the nipple,'” says Nikki Cohen, the curator of the one-night-only exhibition and founder of the conceptual art project This Place. The concept originated at a “Drink and Draw” — a gathering that This Place regularly hosts around New York City, at which guests sip boozy drinks and sketch a nude female model.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: New Class of Drugs Shows More Promise in Treating Cancer
text: A new drug that unleashes the body’s immune system to attack tumors can prolong the lives of people with the most common form of lung cancer, doctors reported on Friday, the latest example of the significant results being achieved by this new class of medicines.

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘Let’s Do Some Railing’
text: Many readers brought an international perspective to conversation about a fatal train derailment in Philadelphia earlier this month, saying the crash and a national reluctance to invest in passenger rail were signs of U.S. decline.

headline: Review: Betty Buckley’s ‘Dark Blue-Eyed Blues’ Has Hardly Any Blues at All
text: Forget that Betty Buckley’s brilliant new show at Joe’s Pub, “Dark Blue-Eyed Blues,” has only a distant resemblance to a blues concert. Yes, Thursday’s opening night included the Harold Arlen-Johnny Mercer standard “Blues in the Night,” but that’s just one of many elements.

headline: Blatter Expresses Thanks to FIFA
text: FIFA’s president, Sepp Blatter, spoke after being elected to a fifth term on Friday. His only rival, Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan, withdrew his candidacy after the first round of voting.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Judy Blume’s ‘In the Unlikely Event’
text: In the annual Summer Reading issue of The New York Times Book Review, Caroline Leavitt reviews “In the Unlikely Event,” Judy Blume’s first novel for adults in 17 years. The novel was inspired by a historical incident, when three planes crashed over eight weeks in Ms. Blume’s hometown, Elizabeth, N.J., in the 1950s. Ms. Leavitt writes:

headline: Russian Military Insignia Are Reported in Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — International monitors tracking cease-fire violations in eastern Ukraine reported Friday that they had encountered four people wearing military uniforms with Russian insignia in a town about 25 miles southeast of the regional capital of Donetsk, which is controlled by pro-Russian separatists.

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: Hastert Case Is Said to Be Linked to Decades-Old Sexual Abuse
text: WASHINGTON — J. Dennis Hastert, who served for eight years as speaker of the House of Representatives, was paying a former student hundreds of thousands of dollars to not say publicly that Mr. Hastert had sexually abused him decades ago, according to two people briefed on the evidence uncovered in an F.B.I. investigation.

headline: In Israel, Desalination at the Heart of a Water Revolution
text: A major national effort to desalinate Mediterranean seawater and to recycle wastewater has provided the country with enough water for all its needs.

headline: Jeb Bush Assails  Obama on Removing Cuba From Terror List
text: Former Gov. Jeb Bush continued to take a hard line against normalizing relations with Cuba on Friday, accusing the Obama administration of capitulating to an oppressive regime by removing it from a state-sponsored terrorism list.

headline: ISIS Claims Deadly Car Bombings at Baghdad Hotels
text: BAGHDAD — The Islamic State claimed responsibility on Friday for car bombings that struck two luxury hotels in Baghdad, which a security official said had killed 14 people and wounded 25.

headline: Chirlane McCray, in Italy, Speaks at a Conference on Black Images in Art
text: FLORENCE, Italy — The travel logs of New York City’s first family this week appear to be a bit lopsided.

headline: Palestinians End FIFA Bid Against Israel
text: Jibril Rajoub, president of the Palestine Football Association, told delegates at FIFA’s annual congress on Friday that the group was ending its efforts to have Israel excluded from FIFA.

headline: Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island to Announce Presidential Bid
text: Democrats are finally starting to line up to take on Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: The Lower East Side Goes From Gritty to Glossy
text: There was a time when immigrants fought to get out of the gritty Lower East Side, but some of their descendants are fighting to get back in as the area has been revitalized. That battle is becoming a bit harder as condominium prices start hitting highs comparable to those in pricier Lower Manhattan neighborhoods like SoHo, NoLIta and NoHo.

headline: Home Is Where the Boards Are
text: Eugene Kang’s shop in Upper Manhattan grew from a sometime venture in the corner of his living room into a store for those in the know.

headline: Ring 5A for the Secret Skateshop of Washington Heights
text: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Eugene Kang sat in the middle of Terminal Skateshop, telling a story about a problem customer, a neighborhood barber who came in looking to buy a board. Mr. Kang helped him pick one out, along with trucks, wheels, bearings — the works — and, making small talk, asked him where he normally skates. The barber explained that he didn’t; he just wanted to hang the board up at work, for show.

headline: Edward P. Gilligan, American Express Executive, Dies at 55
text: Edward Gilligan, the president of American Express and heir apparent to the company’s chief executive, Kenneth Chenault, died on Friday after falling ill during a flight to New York. He was 55.

headline: Practicing the Dying Art of TV Repair
text: “Marty Jennings, Tough Guy,” reads the plaque on the counter at Jennings TV, a tiny repair shop on First Avenue near 55th Street.

headline: Humana Is Said to Consider Sale of Company
text: The wave of deal-making that has swept across the health care industry now appears poised to pull in health insurers, a development driven by the Obama administration’s insurance overhaul.

headline: Irish Media, Fearing Lawsuits, Steers Clear of a Billionaire
text: LONDON — When the financial crash hit in 2008, it plunged Ireland into a crippling recession from which it has only recently stirred. But the toxic legacy of those years has not gone away, and now it has provoked another crisis, this time over media freedom.

headline: Review: ‘Treetop Cat Rescue’ on Animal Planet
text: Whether you’ll enjoy Animal Planet’s latest show comes down to how much you trust cats. If you think they’re merely adorable, innocent balls of fur, sure, help yourself to a mindless half-hour. If, on the other hand, you view them as manipulative little buggers intent on world domination, then prepare to be alarmed.

headline: Ross Ulbricht, Creator of Silk Road Website, Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
text: Ross W. Ulbricht, the founder of Silk Road, a notorious online marketplace for the sale of heroin, cocaine, LSD and other illegal drugs, was sentenced to life in prison on Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Great Barrier Reef Is Not ‘in Danger’ but Needs Care, U.N. Experts Say
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Despite threats to the Great Barrier Reef from climate change and human activity, United Nations conservation experts stopped short of recommending on Friday that the reef, a World Heritage site, be classified as “in danger.”

headline: Warriors’ Klay Thompson Has a Concussion and Is Indefinitely Sidelined
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Klay Thompson of the Golden State Warriors sustained a concussion, the team said Friday, casting doubt on his availability for the start of the N.B.A. finals next Thursday.

headline: No, You Can’t Blame Your Belly on Traffic
text: Honking horns and screaming sirens could give a city dweller a migraine. But can an urban area’s unruly rhythm also give a person love handles? That’s the claim that some recent headlines made based on a study that looked at traffic noise and obesity.

headline: Elizabeth Wurtzel Finds Someone to Love Her
text: The author Elizabeth Wurtzel was never on the short list for bride. She has stated as much in her inflammatory writings for decades, and has even written that single people are more interesting by necessity.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Photographs of the presidential hopefuls Hillary Rodham Clinton, Senator Bernie Sanders, Gov. Chris Christie and Rick Santorum, and more.

headline: How Tanya Menendez and Matthew Burnett, Founders of Maker’s Row, Spend Their Sundays
text: Tanya Menendez and Matthew Burnett are the founders of Maker’s Row, a Brooklyn start-up that connects entrepreneurs with American manufacturers. Forbes magazine recently included Ms. Menendez, 27, in its 30 under 30 issue. Mr. Burnett, 30, is a former watch designer who worked for Marc Jacobs and DKNY. Maker’s Row is their second company: In 2011, Ms. Menendez left a job at Goldman Sachs to join Mr. Burnett at a leather goods line he had started called the Brooklyn Bakery. A year before that, she joined him romantically. The two met through friends at a Roots concert in Prospect Park. They live in a one-bedroom apartment near Borough Hall in Downtown Brooklyn with their dog, Mr. Pickles.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: Political pictures from the last week selected by the editors of The New York Times.

headline: Review: Young Dancers of Graham 2 Show Palpable Passion for the Legend
text: It takes more than just good dancers or a committed artistic director, or even a stellar board of directors, to preserve a choreographer’s legacy. Good teachers are also essential, to train all those future heirs.

headline: A Fresh Lens on the Notorious Episode of Ota Benga
text: Last week, a New York State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan heard arguments on an engaging issue: whether two caged chimpanzees at Stony Brook University can be defined as legal persons, and are therefore being unlawfully held against their will.

headline: Review: Manfred Honeck Coaxes a Burnished Sound From the New York Philharmonic
text: The New York Philharmonic played Mozart, Brahms and Johann Strauss on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall. A program so crustily traditional almost feels like news, given the orchestra’s innovative track of the last few months, with intriguingly balanced programs and new(ish) works by Thomas Adès and John Adams, Thierry Escaich and Peter Eotvos. Under Alan Gilbert, evenings of Old World heft are no longer the norm.

headline: Why the S.E.C. Could Use Commissioners With Wall Street Experience
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission will soon have two top vacancies, and a Wall Street pedigree would be a plus for new watchdogs. Nominees with financial industry ties might prompt gripes about the revolving door, but it pays to know how the market works.

headline: Have We Learned Anything From the Columbia Rape Case?
text: Last week, one of the messiest campus sexual-assault cases in recent memory came to an equally messy conclusion when Emma Sulkowicz, aided by four friends, carried a 50-pound mattress onto the stage at a Columbia University graduation ceremony. In a much-publicized art-performance-slash-protest, Sulkowicz had carried the mattress everywhere she went on campus since the beginning of her senior year last fall, vowing to continue to do so until she graduated — or until Columbia expelled a classmate she accused of rape in April 2013. More than seven months earlier, she says, Paul Nungesser, a friend at the time, raped her during what had until that point been a consensual encounter at the start of their sophomore year.

headline: Previous Mass Die-Offs of the Endangered Saiga Antelope Hint at a Warm, Wet, Weedy Culprit in Kazakhstan
text: Update, Nov. 4 | Carl Zimmer has filed a fresh update from the scientists investigating the mass die-off of saiga populations. They see signs of weather conditions triggering a toxic change in normally harmless bacteria.

headline: Suge Knight Gets New Lawyer, and Murder Trial Is Delayed
text: LOS ANGELES — In an unusual set of hearings on Friday, Marion Knight, the former chief executive of Death Row Records, who is known as Suge among associates in the music world, was granted a delay in his scheduled murder trial as he enlisted a new lawyer, Thomas A. Mesereau Jr., in both that case and a separate robbery case.

headline: Living Large
text: A photographer’s work tries to show the daily lives of people whose dreams and accomplishments exceed their stature.

headline: Pictures of the Day: United States and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the United States, Indonesia, Germany and Switzerland.

headline: Inside the Mind of a Criminal
text: FOR decades, researchers have interviewed criminals to find out how and why they break the law. But the accounts are not always accurate: Narrators manipulate, suffer from faulty memory or justify actions rather than recount facts.

headline: Finding a Toad With a New York Accent
text: Walking along a little-used trail in Bergen Beach three or four years ago, I came across a pudgy toad scampering across the sandy path. Unlike frogs, which leap gracefully, toads scramble through the underbrush on shorter legs. This one, traveling at top toad speed, may have been motivated by a garter snake following closely, probably with dinner in mind. I sensed a photo opportunity, but the snake preferred to dine alone, and veered off quickly. Undeterred, I photographed the toad and filed the photos. This was fortunate — though I have heard the bleats of a few Fowler’s toads since, this was the last one I have seen in the five boroughs.

headline: For Robert Fairchild and Tiler Peck, a Partnership That Stays in Step
text: Ah, the first year of married life, when yesterday’s wanderlust ends and a couple settles into snug domestic routines without tomorrow’s distractions of children and accumulating responsibilities.

headline: May 29, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from the United States, the West Bank, Indonesia and Germany.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Share Your Manhattanhenge Instagram Photos
text: The New York Times invites readers to share their photos of Manhattanhenge, when the sun aligns with Manhattan’s cross streets.

headline: Activist Hedge Fund Elliott Hires Chief Operating Officer
text: Elliott Management, the activist hedge fund run by Paul E.. Singer, has poached a top Citigroup executive to serve as its new chief operating officer, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Friday.

headline: Death on the Steppes: Mystery Disease Kills Saigas
text: Before the end of the last Ice Age, saigas roamed by the millions in a range stretching from England to Siberia, even into Alaska. Eventually they moved to the steppes of Central Asia, where they continued to thrive — until the 20th century, when these strange-looking antelopes began flirting with extinction.

headline: Brooklyn Hamlet of Free African-Americans Was Ahead of Its Time
text: The houses on Hunterfly Road, an abandoned Colonial trail, are the last vestiges of a lost settlement in Brooklyn. Clustered behind a dense meadow rippling with bluestem grass and dandelions, the three wooden houses were once part of Weeksville, a hamlet where more than 500 free African-Americans lived the white-picket-fence dream years before President Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation in 1863.

headline: Washington Bans Political Ads From Public Transit
text: WASHINGTON — Officials in Washington said on Friday that they had suspended all issue-oriented advertising in the public transit system because of fears that granting a request to display a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad would make the region’s buses and trains “a target.”

headline: World’s 50 Best Restaurants Defends Its List
text: A slow-burning squabble in the culinary world heated up on Friday, when the website for Occupy 50 Best, a movement started this month to protest favoritism, opacity and sexism in an influential annual list of the World’s 50 Best Restaurants, was briefly shut down at the request of the 50 Best organization.

headline: FIFA Charges Instantly Earn Loretta Lynch Global Recognition
text: WASHINGTON — Thabiso Sithole, a sports reporter with the South African Broadcasting Corporation, had just finished his Wednesday evening segment on the American indictments that had rocked international soccer when his cousin called.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Man Code
text: Established dress codes are under assault, but aren’t they always?

headline: Bill Cunningham | Man Code
text: Established dress codes are under assault, but aren’t they always? Younger men want to express themselves at work. They attempted to eliminate the necktie decades ago. It never happened. Today, for serious young men, it’s all about the disappearance of socks. City men have new transportation options: bicycles, scooters and skateboards for young creatives working where dress codes don’t exist.

headline: The Economy Will Rebound, but Prosperity Won’t
text: Rearview mirrors exist for a reason: to help us see what’s sneaking up on us from behind. The quarterly economic report is a rearview mirror. The latest one, released on Friday, shows that the economy contracted at an annual pace of 0.7 percent in the first quarter of 2015. Activity has picked up since then, so the tendency is strong to dismiss what is in the mirror, along these lines:

headline: Flowers, Gardens and Picasso
text: With the warmer weather, parties spread outdoors.

headline: Bank of America Fined for Violations of Military Relief Law
text: Bank of America must pay a $30 million fine after a financial regulator found numerous violations related to the accounts of 73,000 military service members.

headline: Inside the 2015 Havana Biennial
text: The 12th edition of this exhibition runs through June 22.

headline: Surfing Headlong Into a New Life
text: What started as a diversion, a leisure activity to help fill empty hours, became a kind of organizing principle.

headline: ‘Moone Boy: The Blunder Years’ and ‘The Imaginary’
text: Imaginary friendhood is suitable only for children. Unlike riding scooters and having tantrums — done by the fully grown as often as the young — chatting with invisible pals beyond a certain age can result in hospital stays for exhaustion. But do today’s overscheduled kids even have time for an imagined ­companion’s limitless adventure and unconditional love? Two new novels made me hope they do.

headline: Google Wants to Turn Your Clothes Into a Computer
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If you thought it was only a matter of time before Google tried to turn your pants into a computer, well, guess what, you were right.

headline: Painting Parties Mix Creativity and Cocktails
text: “Let’s start by taking two scoops of yellow paint and one-half scoop of red, then mixing them together with your Bart Simpson brush,” said an affable illustrator from the Bronx named Tony Tan. Mr. Tan, donning a wireless headset mike, was in the dimly lit lower level of Sofrito in White Plains calling out instructions to 40 students on how to paint a tropical landscape called “Lazy Sunset” in several simple steps.

headline: The Havana Biennial Is Running at Full Throttle
text: HAVANA — With the recent political thaw between Cuba and the United States, changes are already lapping the shores of this island nation and may soon be pounding the great sea wall, the Malecón, that stands between Havana, the open water, and a big-spending, big-building, culturally big-footing neighbor to the north.

headline: In Sequins or Mufti, Chita Rivera Makes a Big Entrance
text: When the speakers on the rooftop of the Strand Hotel in Midtown began to blare a disco version of “America” from “West Side Story,” Chita Rivera, the original Anita in the 1957 Broadway production, cut loose, splaying her crimson-tipped fingers and breaking into a giddy trot.

headline: Standoff Over Rescued Dogs in Northeast China
text: Dog traders, animal rights activists and the authorities have been negotiating for more than a week over control of nearly 500 dogs rescued from a truck stopped on a highway in northeast China.

headline: Let’s Celebrate the Art of Clutter
text: We are in a collective, and most unfortunate, paroxysm of guilt and anxiety about stuff.

headline: At Donohue’s, a Nightly Steak, a Life Gone By
text: His was the corner table to the left of the bar. Four days a week, twice daily, at seven meals out of eight for decades, Robert Hatfield Ellsworth could be found seated in a booth of channel-quilted vinyl at Donohue’s Steak House.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: As Insults Fly in the Greek and German Media, Some Wish for Less News
text: ATHENS — As a nightly news anchor for Skai TV in Greece, Sia Kossioni closely monitors Germany, checking the latest remarks from German politicians, studying public opinion polls and reading the German news media to learn what they are saying about the Greek bailout negotiations. She even speaks German.

headline: How to Find Your Place in the World After Graduation
text: PARIS

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Details Uncovered in Boston’s 2024 Olympic Bid May Put It in Jeopardy
text: BOSTON — The so-called bid book that Boston business leaders presented last year to the United States Olympic Committee helped the city win the competition over Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington as America’s candidate to host the 2024 Summer Games.

headline: Old School
text: “Out of Line: The Art of Jules Feiffer,” “100 Great Children’s Picturebooks” and more.

headline: Indian University Suspends Student Group Accused of Spreading Hatred Toward Modi
text: NEW DELHI — A branch of India’s most prestigious engineering university in the southern city of Chennai has suspended a left-wing student group that was accused of spreading hatred toward Prime Minister Narendra Modi, a university official said on Friday.

headline: After a Protest, a Toronto Festival Removes Action Bronson From Main Stage
text: A Toronto music festival is trying a compromise with Action Bronson, the colorfully foul-mouthed New York rapper, after an online petition that accused him of “violent misogyny” in his lyrics led to a decision ask him to perform at a different venue at the festival rather than as a headliner in a public square on June 21.

headline: Hundreds of Watches Are Stolen but a Victim Remains Undaunted
text: Thirty-five years ago, a Mexican sculptor named Elias Lifshitz, who had recently moved to New York City to accept the challenge he more or less knew from a song — “If you can make it here,” he said this week, “you can make it anyplace” — opened a little shop on East 77th Street. He called it Lifshitz Gallery, and there he learned an early, hard lesson: Not as many people were interested in buying art — his or anyone else’s — as he had hoped.

headline: Comics
text: Nick Sousanis’s “Unflattening,” Drawn and Quarterly’s celebration of 25 years and more.

headline: Intel Takeover of Altera Is Expected
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel is close to clinching a takeover of fellow chip maker Altera for more than $15 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday, the latest sign of consolidation in the semiconductor industry.

headline: Review: An Abundance of Giselles, With Debuts and Farewells
text: It’s not unusual for American Ballet Theater to present eight performances of “Giselle” in eight days at the Metropolitan Opera House; this occurs most years. This year’s casting, however, prompted many in the audience to undertake unusually large Giselleathons, thanks to important debuts, farewells and returns.

headline: What the U.S. Can and Can’t Do in a Violent Mideast
text: To the Editor:

headline: Are Democrats More Liberal Now?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preventing Sexual Abuse by U.N. Peacekeepers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Initially Delayed, Iggy Azalea’s Tour Is Now Canceled
text: Iggy Azalea’s “Great Escape” tour, which had already been pushed back from spring to the fall “due to tour production delays,” according to a statement in March, has now been canceled.

headline: A U.S. Tax Investigation Snowballed to Stun the Soccer World
text: WASHINGTON — Chuck Blazer was a powerful figure in international soccer, and he enjoyed the trappings that came with the role: two apartments at Trump Tower in Manhattan, expensive cars, luxury properties in Miami and the Bahamas.

headline: Firing of Seton Hall Priest Highlights a Catholic Debate on Gay Believers
text: When the Rev. Warren Hall called a reporter for the gay sports website Outsports.com last week to discuss his firing as director of Seton Hall University’s campus ministry, there was a certain logic to his move.

headline: Review: ‘Deep Web’ on Epix Explores Dark Corners of the Internet
text: The Silk Road case, about the online drug-selling enterprise broken up by law-enforcement officials in 2013, has already received some television attention and understandably so. It’s a real-life version of the kinds of tech-heavy crime dramas that TV has been serving up for several years now.

headline: Review: ‘For the Last Time’ Sets a Hawthorne Novel in New Orleans, in 1950
text: There must be less likely sources for a jazz musical, but Nathaniel Hawthorne’s novel “The Marble Faun,” from 1860, seems pretty improbable. Steeped in Puritan piety, it’s a misty melodrama set in Rome among four artist friends, one of whom is hiding a sinister secret.

headline: Bernie Sanders Recants 1972 Article on Women’s Fantasies of Rape
text: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Senator Bernie Sanders said a 1972 article he wrote describing women’s fantasies of rape had been misinterpreted, and its resurfacing showed how campaigns had become “soap operas.’’

headline: Review: A. R. Rahman, Full of Bollywood Hits at the Beacon
text: Idealism and omnivorousness converge in the music of A. R. Rahman, the hugely prolific Oscar-winning Indian film composer whose Intimate Concert Tour sold out the Beacon Theater on Thursday night.

headline: Reynaldo Rey, 75, Actor and Comedian, Is Dead
text: Reynaldo Rey, an actor and comedian known for his work in the 1995 Ice Cube hit film “Friday” and some 50 other movies, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 75.

headline: B.B. King Returns to a Mississippi Home, and Its Warm Embrace
text: INDIANOLA, Miss. — B.B. King, the man some called the ambassador of the blues, came home this week for the last time.

headline: Review: In ‘The Upper Room,’ Homesteaders Living an Eco-Nightmare
text: Doom is more than lapping at the shores of their wooded sanctuary off the coast of Maine. The rising surf is claiming the island, and not so slowly either.

headline: Review: Jane Comfort Signals a Departure With a Moody New Work
text: Jane Comfort is a choreographer with a penchant for fusing text and movement — until now. “Altiplano,” which received its premiere on Thursday as part of the La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, signals a departure for this longtime modern choreographer, who in past dance-theater works has explored the myth of Persephone and notions of beauty with Barbie.

headline: Paying Tribute to a Blues Giant
text: People lined up in Mississippi to view the body of B.B. King, whose bronze coffin was flanked by Gibson guitars.

headline: Nikki Finke, Feared Hollywood Reporter, Turns to Fiction
text: LOS ANGELES — If Nikki Finke had not been a journalist, she says she could have been a detective. The police in New York, where she reported decades ago, used to show her “these gruesome homicide photos,” she said, to try to freak her out. Instead she found them fascinating.

headline: Jerry Dior, Designer of Major League Baseball’s Logo, Dies at 82
text: Jerry Dior, a graphic designer who created one of the most instantly recognizable logos in the history of American marketing — the silhouetted batter that has long symbolized Major League Baseball — but who received official credit for it only 40 years after the fact, died on May 10 at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 82.

headline: Once-Calming Leader and a Stunning Turn
text: WASHINGTON — J. Dennis Hastert was propelled to power in Congress by one sex scandal only to see his House majority dragged down by another. Now the former speaker is himself caught in a murky criminal episode with dark overtones and sexual allegations.

headline: Iraq: 14 Are Killed in Hotel Bombings
text: The Islamic State took responsibility on Friday for car bombings that struck two luxury hotels in Baghdad, which a security official said had killed 14 people and wounded 25. The bombings took place in the parking lots of the hotels around midnight Thursday, highlighting the ability of militants to maneuver around strict security measures. Foreigners frequently stay at the hotels. In one attack, a bomb in a parked car hit the Cristal, which used to be called the Sheraton, in the city center, starting a fire in the middle of one of the city’s busiest areas. The hotel is a frequent spot for weddings and is next to an upscale private club. The other attack, a suicide car bombing, hit the Babylon, a recently renovated hotel that sits on the banks of the Tigris opposite the American Embassy.

headline: Iran: Prisoners’ Relatives to Testify
text: Relatives of three Americans imprisoned in Iran and of a fourth who has been missing there for eight years will be the featured witnesses on Tuesday at a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing, its chairman, Representative Ed Royce, Republican of California, announced Friday. Mr. Royce said in a statement that their testimony would provide an opportunity “to hear from the families of these four Americans and explore ways to secure their release.” The four are Nagameh Abedini, wife of Saeed Abedini, an Idaho pastor sentenced to eight years; Sarah Hekmati, a sister of Amir Hekmati, a Marine veteran from Michigan sentenced to 10 years; Ali Rezaian, brother of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been held since July and could face up to 20 years on charges including espionage; and Daniel Levinson, son of Robert A. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent who disappeared in 2007. The hearing is taking place a week after the start of Mr. Rezaian’s trial in Tehran, which has been described as a sham by the United States government, outside rights groups and his family.

headline: Los Angeles Labor Group Backs Minimum Wage Increase, Then Seeks Exemption
text: LOS ANGELES — Labor unions across the country have been among the most vocal and important backers of the nationwide fight to increase the minimum wage to $15. At the same time, some labor leaders — including one here who helped lead the successful effort to raise the minimum wage in Los Angeles — have encouraged cities to adopt provisions that would allow employers with unions to pay below that level.

headline: One World Observatory Opens Atop Trade Center
text: Visitors on Friday took in the view from the One World Observatory, on floors 100, 101 and 102 of One World Trade Center.

headline: Chinese Security Laws Elevate the Party and Stifle Dissent. Mao Would Approve.
text: BEIJING — China’s new national security law, released in draft form this month, has little to say about such traditional security matters as military power, counterespionage or defending the nation’s borders.

headline: Where’s Edward Snowden Now?
text: Edward Snowden went from unknown intelligence contractor to international celebrity-in-exile in June 2013. Today he is on a worldwide speaking tour, making his virtual rounds from Texas to Stockholm.

headline: Obama Warns the Senate to Pass Surveillance Law
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama suggested ominously on Friday that allowing domestic surveillance programs to expire at a Sunday deadline could lead to a terrorist attack on the United States.

headline: Jack Sock Carries a Torch and a Fiery Forehand
text: PARIS — The young American Jack Sock has played well — even brilliantly at times — to get himself back into the third round of the French Open. And guess who is waiting for him? The even younger Borna Coric, a Croatian and a Roland Garros rookie with a buzz cut, a deep tan and star mentors galore who is just 18 and already resolute beyond his years.

headline: U.N. Role Is Questioned in Sexual Abuse Inquiry
text: GENEVA — Questions over the handling of a confidential United Nations inquiry into allegations of sexual abuse by French soldiers in the Central African Republic deepened on Friday when an advocacy group published leaked documents that it said detailed the reactions of senior human rights officials.

headline: Vladimir Katriuk, Beekeeper Accused of Nazi War Crimes, Is Dead at 93
text: Vladimir Katriuk, a Ukrainian-born beekeeper and former butcher who was No. 2 on the Simon Wiesenthal Center’s list of most wanted Nazi war criminals, died this month in a hospital in Salaberry-de-Valleyfield, Quebec, near where he lived. He was 93.

headline: Governor Cuomo, ‘City Boy’
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo recently mocked Mayor Bill de Blasio’s latest frustrations with Albany, suggesting that such complaints from City Hall were part of a long New York tradition of squabbling between governors and New York City mayors. While true, that history does not mean the governor can play the political bully with the mayor and shortchange more than eight million city residents. The mayor is pushing for real solutions — for schools, housing and mass transit. These issues deserve Mr. Cuomo’s leadership, not political one-upmanship.

headline: Federal Judge to Quit Post; He Faced Abuse Charge
text: A federal judge who was arrested last summer in Atlanta on accusations of domestic abuse resigned on Friday.

headline: Saving Canada’s Boreal Forest
text: STRETCHING from interior Alaska across Canada to Newfoundland, and sandwiched between the prairies and the Arctic, North America’s boreal forest is a mind-boggling 1.5 billion acres in size — bigger even than the vast rain forests of the Brazilian Amazon or the Congo. And despite the relentless pace of development and industrialization worldwide, 80 percent of it remains wild and intact.

headline: Duncan Keith Remains Cornerstone of Blackhawks’ Dynasty and Defense
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The Chicago Blackhawks have endured the rigors of five trips to the Western Conference finals in the past seven seasons thanks, in no small part, to their longest-tenured and most heavily used player, defenseman Duncan Keith.

headline: Police Unions Must Not Block Reform
text: WASHINGTON — THE decline of public trust in the police we’ve seen after a string of incidents in Ferguson, Mo., Cleveland, New York and Baltimore has many causes. Policies like hot-spot policing and stop-and-frisk searches — outgrowths of the “broken windows” law enforcement strategy — have put enormous pressures on minority and low-income communities. But the role played by police unions in shielding their members from accountability for excessive force has also contributed to the erosion of trust.

headline: Pushback in the South China Sea
text: The United States has good reason to push back more forcefully against China’s grab for power in the South China Sea, as Defense Secretary Ashton Carter did on a trip to Asia this week. Beijing has repeatedly ignored earlier warnings to moderate the aggressive behavior that is unsettling its regional neighbors and further undermining its relations with the United States.

headline: To Fill Budget Hole, Kansas G.O.P. Considers the Unthinkable: Raising Taxes
text: TOPEKA, Kan. — With the state facing a $400 million budget hole for the coming fiscal year, the conservatives who dominate the Legislature here say they are agonizing over the likelihood of doing something that did not seem to be in their DNA: raising taxes.

headline: Jury in the Bronx Awards $45 Million for a Death After Surgery
