text: A Bronx jury has awarded $45.6 million to the parents of a man who was paralyzed at 14 and later died as a result of a spinal operation at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center, according to court papers released Friday.

headline: Families Press for Changes in Policy on Hostages
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama met recently with the mother of James Foley, the American hostage beheaded last August by the Islamic State, she said, he told her that freeing her son and the other American hostages held with him had been his top priority.

headline: The Man Who Built the N.C.A.A.
text: In the course of working on a book about the N.C.A.A. these past few years, I’ve found myself grappling with the legacy of Walter Byers.

headline: Noted Employee of Slate
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes you get the puzzle, and sometimes the puzzle gets you. This was a tough one for me, and it’s all because 1) I got excited that I finally recognized a rebus in a puzzle that didn’t actually contain one and 2) I momentarily conflated two characters in a famous television series that was nearly before my time.

headline: What’s Obama’s Plan C for Immigration?
text: What a bad week it was for President Obama’s immigration policies, and for millions living in limbo in the United States.

headline: Paying Tribute to a Blues Giant
text: People lined up in Mississippi to view the body of B.B. King, whose bronze coffin was flanked by Gibson guitars.

headline: Gov. Walker and the Cool Thing
text: We’ve been wondering when a presidential candidate would say something incredibly insensitive about women and reproduction.

headline: Some Things Change and Others Don’t, Says ’41 Police Recruit
text: In 1941, a police recruit named John T. Downer began walking a beat in Brooklyn’s 84th Precinct, and was taken out to lunch by a patrolman.

headline: City Panel Moves to Designate Stonewall Inn as a Landmark
text: With its burned-out neon sign and darkened windows, there was little to distinguish the Stonewall Inn from any other West Village bar when it was raided the night of June 28, 1969.

headline: Rangers Are Shut Out in Game 7 as Lightning Reach Finals
text: When Alex Killorn spun away from the boards and darted toward the slot, Henrik Lundqvist looked ready, crouching in the net, his glove up, his stick out.

headline: Harvey’s Strong Start Slips Away in Mets’ Loss
text: In 10 pitches, Matt Harvey electrified the Friday night crowd at Citi Field as if it were 2013, zipping 98-mile-an-hour fastballs past overmatched hitters and reloading as quickly as the catcher could toss the ball back his way. He pitched the first inning like he had a late-night movie to catch. He pitched like he was laughing at those who feared he might have a so-called dead arm.

headline: C.C. Sabathia Has a Big Heart for Home
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Margie Sabathia-Lanier, asleep in bed after working the graveyard shift as a phone operator at Travis Air Force Base, was awakened by a knock on the bedroom door.

headline: Magic Slips Away From Henrik Lundqvist at the Place It Had Helped Him Most
text: At least on paper, the Rangers were the favorites heading into the finale of the Eastern Conference finals against the Tampa Bay Lightning. They were playing on home ice, they had demolished the Lightning on the road in Game 6 and they had their ultimate trump card, Henrik Lundqvist, in goal.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) 2015 ROCK AND ROLL HALL OF FAME INDUCTION CEREMONY Joan Jett & the Blackhearts, the Paul Butterfield Blues Band, Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble, Green Day, the “5” Royales, Lou Reed, Bill Withers and Ringo Starr were honored at this 30th annual induction ceremony, taped on April 18 at the Public Auditorium in Cleveland. Revelers including Patti Smith, Paul McCartney, Stevie Wonder, Miley Cyrus (above left with Ms. Jett), Beck, Jimmie Vaughan, Dave Grohl, John Mayer, Karen O and Joe Walsh help serve up hits like “Crimson and Clover,” “Ain’t No Sunshine,” “American Idiot,” “Pride and Joy,” “Satellite of Love” and “With a Little Help From My Friends.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “All Ross Ulbricht cared about was his growing pile of bitcoins.”

headline: Corrections: May 30, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Real America
text: Younger and/or foreign readers may not recall how big a role the alleged moral superiority of small-town America used to play in conservative politics (and still does, to some extent). Republicans portrayed themselves as the party of the “real America”, of family values, as opposed to the decadent left in its enclaves on the coasts. Defense of traditional values played a big role in the 2004 campaign.

headline: Last Exit Before Chaos
text: There’s an odd summer-of-1914 feel to the current state of the Greek crisis. While some of the main players are, rightly, desperate to find a way to head off Grexit and all it entails, others – on the creditor as well as the debtor side — seem not just resigned to collapse but almost as if they’re welcoming the prospect, the way, a century ago, far too many Europeans actually seemed to welcome the end of messy, frustrating diplomacy and the coming of open war.

headline: World Science Festival Finds Success in Physics, and More, as Spectacle
text: Brian Greene grasps a beam of light. He freezes in an electrified rock-star pose, and as a live orchestra begins to hum, the beam of light slips through his fingertips and flashes across the stage.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to new exhibits at the Bronx Zoo.

headline: In Travel Accessories, Style Meets Convenience
text: There is no shortage of tech gadgets designed to make travel easier, but equally innovative accessories have been few and far between. That is finally changing with an array of stylish options.

headline: In Morocco, Exploring Remnants of Jewish History
text: Boy 1: “What are those two guys doing walking around here?”

headline: Profiting From the Desperate
text: Daniel Puff, a recovering drug addict, is caught in an unregulated housing system, known as “three-quarter” housing, that preys on the vulnerable homeless.

headline: Response From Yury Baumblit’s Lawyer
text: A lawyer for Mr. Baumblit responded to questions from The Times’s Kim Barker about his client and Back on Track, a company that runs three-quarter homes. The transitional homes provide housing for the mentally ill, homeless and addicts.

headline: A Choice for Recovering Addicts: Relapse or Homelessness
text: After a lifetime of abusing drugs, Horace Bush decided at age 62 that getting clean had become a matter of life or death. So Mr. Bush, a homeless man who still tucked in his T-shirts and ironed his jeans, moved to a flophouse in Brooklyn that was supposed to help people like him, cramming into a bedroom the size of a parking space with three other men.

headline: Easy Peasy
text: An abundance of fresh English peas can turn any dish into a bright springtime meal, writes Martha Rose Shulman, who offers a light summer shrimp and pea dish made with green garlic. We’ve added some of our favorite recipes from Martha that include peas.

headline: Mohamed Soltan, U.S. Citizen Imprisoned in Egypt, Is Released
text: CAIRO — Mohamed Soltan, an American citizen who spent nearly two years in an Egyptian prison on charges that he supported an Islamist protest, has been released by the Egyptian authorities and flew back to the United States on Saturday, his family said in a statement.

headline: Martin O’Malley Announces Presidential Campaign, Pushing Image of Vitality
text: BALTIMORE — In another campaign year, Martin O’Malley’s résumé and good looks might be irresistible to Democratic primary voters. He is a former big-city mayor whose story of renewal in Baltimore seemed well tailored to an increasingly urban and minority party. He is a former two-term governor of Maryland — and the lead singer and guitarist in a rock ’n’ roll band.

headline: What Martin O'Malley Would Need to Do to Win
text: Mr. O’Malley, a former governor of Maryland, is running for the Democratic presidential nomination. Here is a look at his prospects.

headline: Martin O’Malley on the Issues
text: Martin O’Malley, a former governor of Maryland, announced his candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination on Saturday. Positioning himself to the left of Hillary Rodham Clinton, he says he has a more consistent record than she does on matters like supporting same-sex-marriage, opposing the Iraq war and advocating on behalf of immigrants. Here are his stands on key issues.

headline: ‘White-Glove’ Co-op Rules That Rankle
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Reply From Yury Baumblit’s Lawyer
text: A lawyer for Mr. Baumblit responded to questions from The Times’s Kim Barker about his client and Back on Track, a company that runs three-quarter homes. The transitional homes provide housing for the mentally ill, homeless and addicts.

headline: Battle Lines in G.O.P. Set Stage for Surveillance Vote
text: WASHINGTON — Since 2011, when Republicans took control of the House, Congress has lurched from one deadline to the next, as Republicans and Democrats have sparred bitterly over funding for the government, the ability to lift the debt ceiling and other policy matters.

headline: Martin O’Malley Reached Out to Hillary Clinton Ahead of Campaign Announcement
text: When Martin O’Malley began actively exploring a presidential run in 2013, he reached out to Hillary Rodham Clinton, the front-runner for the Democratic nomination, to let her know. She told him he should dowhat he needed to do.

headline: For the Golden State Warriors, Practice Makes Perfect Silliness
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Golden State Warriors are a joy to watch. Their offense is based on movement and spacing, all five players working together to create open shots. If Coach Steve Kerr is the conductor, Stephen Curry is his soloist, a 6-foot-3, 190-pound virtuoso in high-tops.

headline: Tokyo Police Respond to the Call of Football
text: KAWASAKI, Japan — The members of the Tokyo Police Department’s Ninth Riot Squad are professionals at containing demonstrations, foiling terrorists and preventing mayhem. On any given Sunday, they also make mayhem on the football field as the Keishicho Eagles.

headline: A Little Praise for Sepp Blatter. Very Little.
text: Now that Sepp Blatter has won his fifth term as president of FIFA, defying all common sense that the leader of a corrupt sport should be ousted instead of rewarded, he can move on to the next big event on his calendar: the Women’s World Cup.

headline: Marlins’ Gordon Tries to Match Notable Names: Cobb. Sisler. Snuffy Stirnweiss.
text: Howie Kendrick has delivered the type of production the Los Angeles Dodgers were hoping for when they traded for him in December. After going 1 for 4 on Friday night, Kendrick had a .291 batting average, which was in line with his .292 career average entering the season.

headline: The Vision of Walter Byers, a Flawed Leader, Still Shapes the N.C.A.A.
text: Walter Byers died last week at the age of 93, but his legacy as the first executive director of the N.C.A.A. resonates in virtually every aspect of the multibillion-dollar enterprise of intercollegiate athletics.

headline: Variety: A Trained Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Unlike the New York City subway system, this acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon showed up on time, was incredibly clean and did not emit a strange odor, and was easy to solve. [You don’t “solve” the New York City subway system. — Ed.] [You do if you miss your connection on the 1, 2 or 3 Line. — D.A.]

headline: For Horse Trainer Dallas Stewart, Diamonds in the Rough Are a Specialty
text: The trainer Dallas Stewart admits that his willingness to enter horses who seemingly lack the background to be competitive in major races comes off as “a little bit sketchy.” His wife, Yvette, is more blunt in discussing her husband’s makeup.

headline: Nick Imison Is Tennis’s Workaholic Diplomat
text: PARIS — The yellow brick road of interviews leads to Nick Imison.

headline: At the French Open, Nick Kyrgios and Other Young Standouts Hit a Wall
text: PARIS — The three youngest men remaining in the French Open took the court for their third-round matches Saturday, and all three lost without taking a set.

headline: New Jersey State Trooper Killed After Patrol Car Hits Deer
text: A New Jersey State Police trooper was killed early Saturday after his patrol car struck a deer and veered off a highway in Monmouth County, the authorities said.

headline: Keeping Shoppers Happy
text: Juan Carlos Linares, 34, is general manager of Tanger Outlets in National Harbor, Md.

headline: How the Cayman Islands Became a FIFA Power
text: GEORGE TOWN, Cayman Islands — Chickens scurried about on Friday morning as a bulldozer spread crushed rock for a new soccer field with artificial turf at the Cayman Islands Football Association.

headline: Talks Begin to Conclude Nuclear Deal With Iran
text: GENEVA — With only a month to go before a deadline for a nuclear accord with Iran, Secretary of State John Kerry began a major push Saturday to conclude the agreement.

headline: A Beehive That Takes the Sting Out of the Harvest
text: Cedar Anderson sometimes drizzles an entire jar’s worth of honey on his food. “Some people call me Pooh Bear,” he says.

headline: Hundreds Protest After Gunmen Target Ethnic Pashtuns in Southern Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Tensions were running high on Saturday in southwestern Pakistan after dozens of heavily armed gunmen, wearing the uniforms of security forces, stopped two buses, singled out ethnic Pashtuns and fatally shot at least 22 of them on Friday night.

headline: Martin O’Malley Running for President
text: Former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland announced his campaign on Saturday.

headline: Obama Seeks Support on Surveillance
text: President Obama addresses gridlock in the Senate over the renewal of a federal surveillance program.

headline: At Odds Over a Sloppy Résumé
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Manhattanhenge: Scenes From the Streets
text: A collection of Instagram photographs taken by readers of the sun setting on Friday in alignment with Manhattan’s east-west street grid.

headline: Creative Spending Benefits the Astros
text: Lance McCullers Jr. was new to the Fresno Grizzlies in mid-May, promoted to the Houston Astros’ highest minor league affiliate after 29 overpowering innings in Class AA. His plan all along was to pitch for Houston this season, but he figured he would have to prove himself at a new level before getting there.

headline: For Mets, David Wright’s Injury Could Bring Back Revolving Door at Third
text: For most of the last half-century, at least until David Wright arrived, one of the least exclusive clubs in baseball was third baseman for the Mets. The position seemed available to one and all — from Don Zimmer on Day 1 of the franchise, to Manny Alexander and almost every alphabetical permutation in between.

headline: Sepp Blatter Blames U.S. and England for FIFA Arrests
text: The embattled Sepp Blatter struck a familiarly defiant tone as he began his fifth term as president of FIFA, blaming others for the widespread corruption scandal that has engulfed international soccer.

headline: Wanted: A Theology of Atheism
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — ONE Sunday last month, I walked into an auditorium past greeters and a table loaded with coffee, fruit and cookies. Onstage two young men tuned their guitars. A blank screen hung down, a silent signal that not knowing the words would be no excuse for not singing along. But this was no typical church service.

headline: Who Will Watch the Charities?
text: LAST week federal authorities disclosed that four cancer charities had bilked tens of millions of dollars from donors. Questions continue to surface about the lack of transparency at the Clinton Foundation. Philanthropy, we’re learning, is a world with too much secrecy and too little oversight. Despite its increasing role in American society, from education to the arts to the media, perhaps no sector is less accountable to outsiders.

headline: What YouTube Taught Me
text: I’VE been watching a lot of how-to videos on YouTube about baseball gloves, and here’s what I’ve learned. The will to teach — a close cousin of the desire to perform — far exceeds the educational value of most online tutorials. Of course, if you’ve ever sought advice about how to break in a new glove, you already know that.

headline: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie: My Father’s Kidnapping
text: MY father was kidnapped in Nigeria on a Saturday morning in early May. My brother called to tell me, and suddenly there was not enough breathable air in the world. My father is 83 years old. A small, calm, contented man, with a quietly mischievous humor and a luminous faith in God, his beautiful dark skin unlined, his hair in sparse silvery tufts, his life shaped by that stoic, dignified responsibility of being an Igbo first son.

headline: Guess Who Doesn’t Fit In at Work
text: ACROSS cultures and industries, managers strongly prize “cultural fit” — the idea that the best employees are like-minded. One recent survey found that more than 80 percent of employers worldwide named cultural fit as a top hiring priority.

headline: The Education Assassins
text: A CONTEST for the least popular arm of the federal government would have many strong contenders.

headline: Hooray for Hillarywood?
text: IS Hollywood really ready to give a 67-year-old woman a leading role in a big-budget production?

headline: Overcoming a Lifetime of Stage Fright
text: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. — IT had been 40 years since my last recital, but the first time I played the piano at Mineta San Jose International Airport, my body responded right on cue. My hands turned wet with sweat, my heart pounded, my feet gave a soft little drum roll on the floor.

headline: The Pressure to Look Good
text: “I LOVED that letter you wrote!” the woman in the elevator of the Medical Arts Building on Walnut Street in Philadelphia said.

headline: Cynthia Moss
text: Cynthia Moss is a wildlife researcher and conservationist who has spent more than 40 years living with and observing elephants in Kenya, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Tanzania and Botswana.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Dave Sweet, a Quiet Pioneer of Surfboarding, Dies at 86
text: Dave Sweet, whose obsessive tinkering 60 years ago in search of a better way to ride a wave resulted in a surfboard revolution — the first board with a core of polyurethane foam, still the leading choice of surfers from Oahu to the Maldives — died on May 18 in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: How a School Network Helps Immigrant Kids Learn
text: IN 1982, the Supreme Court ruled that the children of illegal immigrants cannot be denied a free public education. It’s not their fault, after all, that their parents brought them into this country.

headline: Directing the Final Scene
text: When they pulled out the pump that was keeping my father’s heart going, his hands shot up in the air, and he shouted “Wonderful!” My brother, Jeff, and I knew why. He had been waiting to die for a year, having tried to take his life with far too few pills to do the job. It left him, at 81, doomed to a life sentence with a failing heart that wouldn’t let him be the fun-loving, bridge-playing, romantic crooner we had known. He was happy to be leaving us and we, in turn, were happy to see him go. We’d been mourning him for a year as he faltered and despaired.

headline: Afghan Police Chief, Long a Taliban Target, Faces a New Emotion: Fear
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — He says he has lost count of the number of times the Taliban have tried to kill him.

headline: Cashing In on a Charter-Time Warner Cable Merger
text: Whatever cable customers and regulators may think of Charter Communications’ plans to acquire Time Warner Cable for $56 billion, one small group of men has reason to celebrate.

headline: Treating H.I.V. Patients Before They Get Sick
text: A major international clinical trial has provided the strongest evidence yet that people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, should get treated as soon as possible, even if they are feeling well, to ward off serious illness and fatal complications in future years. The finding raises the powerful moral question of whether global and national organizations can find the will — and the resources — to protect millions of people from deaths and diseases that could be prevented.

headline: Racial Penalties in Baltimore Mortgages
text: The mortgage crisis that brought the economy to its knees seven years ago was especially devastating for black communities, where homeowners who qualified for safe, traditional mortgages were often steered into ruinously priced loans that paid off handsomely for brokers and lenders while leaving borrowers vulnerable to foreclosure. The crisis left many middle-class minority communities strewn with abandoned houses, further widening the already huge wealth gap between African-Americans and whites.

headline: The ‘Non-Candidate’ Money Spigot
text: Campaign watchdog groups are wisely urging the Department of Justice to investigate the ever cozier relationships between candidates and their supposedly independent “super PACs,” which are reducing the presidential campaign to a free-for-all shopping mart for megadonors seeking influence.

headline: Presidential Races Under Microscope, and The Times, Too
text: SEVENTEEN months before the presidential election, The Times is already in a full-court press on campaign coverage: eleven reporters, hundreds of stories, one major scoop, and an intensive focus on presenting the news attractively for mobile devices.

headline: 2015 Fantasy Football Preseason Player Rankings
text: These player rankings are for standard and PPR scoring formats and will be updated throughout the preseason.

headline: In France, a Party’s Name Change Tracks a Drift to the Right in Europe
text: PARIS — In one sense, it was just an effort at rebranding a party that has suffered electoral defeat, scandal and internal divisions in the past few years. This weekend, France’s main conservative party, under the leadership of former President Nicolas Sarkozy, voted to rename itself the Republicans, dropping its rather unwieldy identity as the Union for a Popular Movement.

headline: Our Water-Guzzling Food Factory
text: LET’S start with a quiz.

headline: The Prospects for Polygamy
text: ON every issue save abortion, social liberalism is suddenly ascendant in America. The shift on same-sex marriage has captured the headlines, but the change is much more comprehensive: In just 15 years, we have gone from being a society divided roughly evenly between progressive and traditionalist visions to a country where social conservatism is countercultural and clearly in retreat.

headline: FIFA’s Outsize Generosity
text: Under FIFA’s system, the smallest country has the same voting power as the biggest, and payments from FIFA for projects help to ensure allegiance to Sepp Blatter.

headline: Yorkville, Where Hastert Taught, Is Shaken by Charges for ‘Denny’
text: YORKVILLE, Ill. — For years, J. Dennis Hastert has been the pride of this small city. There may not be a bronze statue in his honor, but that would be counter to what people here have most admired about Mr. Hastert: that someone who once wielded so much power could also be so ordinary, so much like them, so Yorkville.

headline: After Speakership, Hastert Amassed His Millions Lobbying Former Colleagues
text: WASHINGTON — J. Dennis Hastert, the longest-serving Republican House speaker in history, was swept from leadership in 2006 on a wave of Republican revulsion over what critics saw as a legislative favor factory he presided over in Congress. That wave deposited him on K Street, a prime address for the capital’s lobbyists, where his influence and good name kept the favors flowing — including into his bank accounts.

headline: Martin O’Malley’s Star-Spangled, Snafu-Speckled Debut
text: BALTIMORE — Martin O’Malley couldn’t have asked for a more picturesque backdrop for his presidential campaign announcement on Saturday: A blue sky met the clear water of Baltimore’s Inner Harbor off Federal Hill Park.

headline: Rangers Left to Digest Another Empty Result
text: For these Rangers, simply skating in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals — scoreless with the Tampa Bay Lightning heading into third period — was something of a postseason miracle.

headline: With Veteran Help, Lightning Gain Finals
text: Last season, the Tampa Bay Lightning watched the Rangers win the Prince of Wales Trophy as the Eastern Conference champions, after being swept out of the playoffs by the Montreal Canadiens in the first round.

headline: Gregorius Inherited Jeter’s Position, but So Far, Not His Defensive Instincts
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The signature play in Derek Jeter’s long Yankees career occurred here. During the 2001 playoffs, the Yankees, clinging to their postseason life against the A’s, were rescued when Jeter raced across the diamond to cut off a throw home and flipped it backhanded to catcher Jorge Posada, who tagged out Jeremy Giambi just before he touched home plate for what would have been a crucial run.

headline: Leadership on View in ‘Art Walk’ Near West Point
text: Under a tree in Ladycliff Park in Highland Falls, three life-size concrete women sit together, their knees jutting up toward their chests. Featureless, armless, their rough-hewed bodies face one another as if engrossed in conversation.

headline: Yogi Berra’s Values Shape Museum’s Mission
text: May 12 marked Yogi Berra Day in New York and New Jersey, and except for the Drums of Thunder, a drum corps of fourth and fifth graders from Hillside Elementary School in Montclair, it was a quiet, tender affair — part photo opportunity, part nostalgia.

headline: Nashville Debates How to Prevent Another Devastating Flood
text: NASHVILLE — As Texas reels from catastrophic flooding, this booming city on the Cumberland River is contemplating what to do to protect itself in the wake of its own disaster from five years ago, the May 2010 flood that killed 10 people and damaged or destroyed 11,000 properties.

headline: Review of ‘Rock of Ages’ at Gateway Playhouse in Bellport
text: “Rock of Ages,” now at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport, is an entertaining, high-energy party. It is also exceedingly silly, but that’s a good thing. If this musical, featuring broad humor and 1980s pop songs, many of them from hair-metal bands like Poison and Twisted Sister, took itself seriously, it could easily become insufferable.

headline: Camping in Church? Make Way for Champers
text: Glampers, make way for “champers.” Travelers can now spend a night surrounded by history in three of England’s treasured country churches as part of the “champing” program — camping in churches — run by the Churches Conservation Trust. The trust, which cares for more than 340 churches no longer used for regular worship, is offering overnight stays as a way to help preserve the buildings, raise money and promote “slow tourism.”

headline: Japanese Towns Thank Their Moneyed Donors
text: The patrons who help finance Japan’s poorer areas not only get tax benefits, they also receive fresh local foods from the towns they support.

headline: In Japan, You Get a Tax Break and a Side of Lobster and Beef
text: HIRADO, Japan — Tax breaks come in many forms. Charitable gifts. Health care expenses. Mortgage interest payments.

headline: Review: A Rambunctious Production of ‘Kiss Me Kate’ in Hartford
text: The most notorious spanking in theater history is being delivered with good-humored gusto at Hartford Stage, where the musical “Kiss Me, Kate” is happily conflating Shakespeare and Cole Porter in a rambunctious production masterminded by the director Darko Tresnjak and the choreographer Peggy Hickey.

headline: E.P.A. Proposal Will Put Bigger Trucks on a Fuel Diet
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Inside the National Vehicle and Fuel Emissions Laboratory here, a mammoth contraption, with steel rollers, advanced electronics and exhaust tubes, is nearing completion.

headline: Japanese Towns Thank Their Moneyed Donors
text: The patrons who help finance Japan’s poorer areas not only get tax benefits, they also receive fresh local foods from the towns they support.

headline: Making Projections
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE  — When The Girl was of pre-school age, she liked to dress herself and, as the mature, authority figure in her life, I (metaphorically, Officer) threw her under the bus to her teacher. Those of you who are parents or guardians of small children can probably already see where this is going, but I feel like I need to get this off my chest.

headline: A Florida Police Killing Like Many, Disputed and Little Noticed
text: OAKLAND PARK, Fla. — The witnesses who saw a Broward County deputy sheriff kill a man who had strolled through his apartment complex with an unloaded air rifle propped on his shoulders agreed: Just before he was gunned down, Jermaine McBean had ignored the officers who stood behind him shouting for him to drop his weapon.

headline: Iowa Republicans Move to Draw Candidates to Straw Poll
text: With multiple presidential hopefuls indicating that they will not spend money on the Iowa Republican straw poll this summer, the importance of a decadeslong tradition increasingly seems diminished. Concerned about this prospect, a group of Republican activists in Iowa is moving to press candidates into actively participating in the Aug. 8 gathering.

headline: Democrats Seek a Richer Roster to Match G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — Over the last few months, Harold M. Ickes, a longtime ally of Hillary Rodham Clinton, has helped organize private meetings around the country with union leaders, Clinton backers and Democratic strategists. The pressing topic: Who will step up to be the Democrats’ megadonors in the 2016 presidential race?

headline: Ukrainian Migrants Fleeing Conflict Get a Cool Reception in Europe
text: WARSAW — Volodymyr Zelenyuk knew it was time to bolt when the pro-Russian separatists came to the carwash he owned in the eastern Ukrainian coal town of Antratsyt and demanded his help making and repairing weapons.

headline: Jon Niese’s Troubles Continue as Marlins Thrash Mets
text: Through Jon Niese’s first six starts of the season for the Mets, his successes were largely overshadowed.

headline: Building of Islands Is Debated, but China and U.S. Skirt Conflict at Talks
text: SINGAPORE — It was an unexpectedly direct exchange: With nearly every significant Asian defense official gathered in a single room, a senior Chinese military officer on Saturday defended his country’s island-building spree in the South China Sea and rebuked Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter for saying it threatened the region’s stability.

headline: Rare Stumble for U.S. Women Against South Korea
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The United States will enter the Women’s World Cup on a nine-match unbeaten streak, but a scoreless tie with South Korea on Saturday raised more questions than it answered about the team’s ability to win its first world title since 1999.

headline: Malaysians Seek Escape in Pulp Fiction as Government’s Grip Tightens
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — When Anis Suhaila wants a cheap thrill, she turns to Instagram and Twitter to learn about the latest Malaysian paperback releases. But she does not buy them in ordinary bookstores here, some of which do not carry the titles she is most interested in.

headline: Lionel Messi Powers Barcelona to Victory in Copa del Rey
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Barcelona completed the second leg of a possible treble by winning the Copa del Rey on Saturday, led by an unstoppable Lionel Messi, who opened and closed Barcelona’s scoring in a 3-1 win over Athletic Bilbao.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: FIFA Charges Merited, but Timing Seems Questionable

headline: Sparks and Words Fly as Serena Williams Upends a Rival
text: PARIS — Her latest match with Serena Williams had been over for more than an hour, and Victoria Azarenka was still shaking her head in disbelief as she sat at a table in the French Open players lounge on Saturday night.

headline: Ex-President of Georgia to Lead Ukraine Region
text: MOSCOW — President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine on Saturday appointed the former president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, as governor of the Odessa region, turning to a longtime nemesis of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for help governing an area coveted by pro-Russian separatists.

headline: Russia’s Barring of Officials Seen as Reprisal
text: BERLIN — Russia has barred dozens of European officials from entering its territory in what appears to be retaliation for the European Union’s barring of Russian politicians, officials and businessmen who Europe says have supported the annexation of Crimea or the pro-Russian forces fighting in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Beau Biden, Vice President Joe Biden’s Son, Dies at 46
text: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden III, the former attorney general of Delaware and the elder son of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., died on Saturday in Bethesda, Md. He was 46.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 1 Finale Recap: Jamie Is Broken
text: Season 1, Episode 16: “To Ransom a Man’s Soul”

headline: The ‘Outlander’ Show Runner, Ron Moore, on That Harrowing Season Finale
text: It was the episode that “Outlander” fans had long been awaiting — and dreading. In this Starz drama’s first-season finale, the 18th-century Scottish warrior Jamie Fraser (Sam Heughan) submitted to the brutal sexual advances of the evil redcoat Black Jack Randall (Tobias Menzies) in an attempt to free our heroine, Claire Randall (Caitriona Balfe).

headline: U.S. Paid Residents Linked to Nazi Crimes $20 Million in Benefits, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The American government paid $20.2 million in Social Security benefits to more than 130 United States residents linked to Nazi atrocities over the course of more than a half-century, with some of the payments made as recently as this year, according to a federal investigation.

headline: Chicago Blackhawks Win the West and a Spot in the Finals
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The Chicago Blackhawks earned a spot in the Stanley Cup finals for the third time in six seasons by defeating the Anaheim Ducks, 5-3, on Saturday night in Game 7 of the Western Conference finals at Honda Center.

headline: Rivka Liss-Levinson, Benjamin Aronin
text: Rivka Chana Liss-Levinson and Benjamin Shepard Aronin are to be married Sunday at Temple Israel of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Lester Bronstein is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Out of Sight, Not Out of Mind
text: Natalia Nemchinov, a daughter of Elena Nemchinov and Sergei Nemchinov of Rye, N.Y., was married Friday to Jovan Kandic, the son of Ljiljana Kandic and Zarko Kandic of Belgrade, Serbia. Edwina Townes, a staff member in the New York City clerk’s office, officiated at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau.

headline: Olivia Richardson,  Christopher Khouri
text: Olivia Rose Richardson, a daughter of Melissa Meell Richardson and Dr. Stephen B. Richardson of Rye, N.Y., was married Saturday to Christopher Joshua Khouri, the son of Barbara Tanca Khouri of New York and George A. Khouri of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Peter A. Sulyok performed the ceremony at the Bridgehampton Presbyterian Church in Bridgehampton, N.Y. On May 28, the Rev. Constantine Lazarakis led another ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Hamptons in Southampton, N.Y.

headline: Jonathan Gregg,  Derek Mize
text: Jonathan Daniel Gregg and James Derek Mize were married Saturday by Jack Harrison, a Universal Life minister, at Bryant Park Grill in New York.

headline: Molly Cyphers, Nicholas Berry
text: Molly Lisbeth Cyphers and Nicholas McGraw Berry were married Saturday. The Rev. Dr. Hillary D. Raining performed the ceremony at St. Christopher’s Episcopal Church in Gladwyne, Pa., with the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, another Episcopal priest, taking part.

headline: Serena Roberts,  Anthony Houlihan
text: Serena van Slyke Roberts and Anthony Joseph Houlihan were married Saturday in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan. The Rev. Cynthia A. Stravers, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Elizabeth Murphy, Mason Scherer
text: Elizabeth Wells Murphy, the daughter of Elizabeth K. Breckinridge and Peter L. Murphy, both of Columbia, S.C., was married Saturday to Mason Douglas Scherer, a son of Cynthia A. Scherer and Douglas K. Scherer of Pottstown, Pa. The Rev. Kevin M. Roberts, a Baptist minister, officiated at a nondenominational ceremony at the Lace House, a historic home on the grounds of the South Carolina Governor's Mansion in Columbia.

headline: Davlyn Grant and Kyle Mosley
text: Davlyn Cecile Grant, the daughter of Dr. Lynn J. McKinley-Grant and Dr. David C. Grant Jr. of Washington, was married Saturday to Kyle Aaron Mosley, the son of Camille Riggs Mosley of Washington and the late Dwight A. Mosley. The Rev. John Matthew Borders III, a Baptist minister, officiated at the Agricultural Hall in West Tisbury, Mass.

headline: Kimberlea Tracey, Stephen Jeffries
text: Kimberlea Anne Tracey and Stephen Benjamin Jeffries were married Saturday evening at Trinity Church in Boston. The Rev. Samuel T. Lloyd III, the church rector, performed the ceremony, with the Right Rev. Dean E. Wolfe, the Episcopal bishop of Kansas, taking part.

headline: Amanda Calkins, Andrew Baker
text: Amanda Waters Calkins and Andrew Stevens Baker were married Saturday. Benjamin B. Baker, the father of the groom, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the Shining Tides, a Y.M.C.A. camp in Mattapoisett, Mass.

headline: A Night in Cuba, a Run in the Park
text: Elena Cecilia Castañeda, a daughter of Elena Couriel and Javier E. Castañeda of Miami, was married Saturday evening to David Alexander Gottesman, a son of Andrea Carson Gottesman of Roslyn Heights, N.Y., and Dr. Malcolm H. Gottesman of Glen Head, N.Y. Rabbi Lawrence M. Schuval officiated at the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach.

headline: Alexandra Lippman,  Daniel Landy
text: Alexandra Nicole Lippman, the daughter of Linda F. Lippman and James M. Lippman of Los Angeles, was married at her parents’ house Saturday evening to Daniel Max Landy, a son of Alice J. Radin and Alex P. Landy of North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Morley Feinstein officiated.

headline: Kirby Taylor, Hardwick Caldwell
text: Jessica Kirby Taylor and Joseph Hardwick Caldwell were married Saturday at the Tennessee River Gardens, a wildflower garden and wildlife preserve in Chattanooga that is owned by the groom’s family. The Rev. John Talbird, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Ted Sperling and Noah Waxman
text: Ted Sperling and Noah Waxman were married Monday at the boat house at the Sedgewood Club in Carmel, N.Y. Rabbi Benjamin H. Spratt officiated.

headline: Marissa Schaffer, Daniel Sartori
text: Marissa Lauren Schaffer, the daughter of Toby R. Schaffer and Dr. Jonathan L. Schaffer of Moreland Hills, Ohio, is to be married Sunday to Dr. Daniel John Sartori, the son of Clara C. Sartori and Dominic J. Sartori of Darien, Conn. Rabbi David H. Aaron is to officiate at the Cleveland Botanical Garden.

headline: Stephanie Santoro, Spencer Acker
text: Stephanie Dawn Santoro, the daughter of Susan S. Santoro and Michael J. Santoro of Guilford, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Spencer Bryan Acker, a son of Andrea P. Acker and David Acker of Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Herbert N. Brockman officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

headline: Claire Natale and Elijah Visbal
text: Claire Maureen Natale and Elijah Francis Visbal were married Saturday at St. Andrew Church in Erie, Pa. James P. Power, a Roman Catholic deacon and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kaylan Christianer,  Andrew Teich
text: Dr. Kaylan Christianer and Andrew Franklin Teich are to be married on Sunday by the Rev. Dr. Robert Moore, a Lutheran minister, at Healdsburg Country Gardens in Healdsburg, Calif.

headline: Emily Simon and Matthew Crystal
text: Emily Campbell Simon, the daughter of Janet M. Simon and J. Peter Simon of Green Village, N.J., was married Saturday to Dr. Matthew Alan Crystal, a son of Elizabeth Crystal and Norman Crystal of Green Brook, N.J. The Rev. Patrick G. O’Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

headline: Melanie Gudesblatt,  James Apgar
text: Melanie Gail Gudesblatt and James Campbell Nelson Apgar are to be married Sunday by Daniel Lamb, an uncle of the bride and a justice for the Town of Saugerties, N.Y., at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

headline: Sarah Paiji, Kenneth Yoo
text: Sarah Lee Paiji and Kenneth Yoo were married Saturday. Eugene Lee, an uncle of the bride who is a minister of the World Evangelical Mission Alliance, officiated at Oheka Castle, the Otto Kahn estate in Huntington, N.Y.

headline: Amy Shyer, Alan Rodrigues
text: Amy Elizabeth Shyer, the daughter of Nancy Gibbons Shyer and Bruce N. Shyer of Oakland, Calif., was married Saturday to Alan Rohit Rodrigues, a son of Sheeba R. Rodrigues and Dr. Joseph V. Rodrigues of Dresher, Pa. The Rev. Richard P. Meyer, a Conservative Baptist minister, officiated at Monson Vineyards in Geyserville, Calif.

headline: Amelia Huck, Francis Manley V
text: Amelia Emerson Huck and Francis James Manley V were married Saturday by the Rev. David R. Anderson, an Episcopal priest, at St. Luke’s Parish in Darien, Conn.

headline: Emily Sussman and Kevin Craw
text: Emily Tisch Sussman, a daughter of Laurie M. Tisch of New York and S. Donald Sussman of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Kevin James Craw, a son of Joanne T. Craw and James M. Craw of Oakland, N.J. Senator Cory Booker became a minister of the American Fellowship Church for the event. He officiated in an outdoor ceremony at Four Freedoms Park at Roosevelt Island, N.Y.

headline: Deborah Ho and David Zhou
text: Dr. Deborah Yuan-Yu Ho and David Zhou were married Friday in Manhattan in the chambers of Judge Pierre N. Leval of the Federal Court of Appeals, for whom the groom was a law clerk in 2011 and 2012.

headline: Allison Urbanik, Daniel Kimmel
text: Allison Elizabeth Hong Urbanik, the daughter of Frances Hong Urbanik and David Urbanik of Farmington, Conn., was married Monday to Daniel Mifflin Kimmel, a son of Lawrie A. Mifflin and Arthur G. Kimmel, both of Brooklyn. Mary A. Coburn, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at St. Clement’s Castle in Portland, Conn.

headline: Amanda Tomney, Luke Rooney
text: Amanda Grace Tomney and Luke Austin Rooney were married Saturday by the Rev. Peter Fink, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York.

headline: Elizabeth Fisch, Michael Dishi
text: Elizabeth Fisch, a daughter of Rachel N. Davidson and Mark Fisch of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday to Michael Dishi, a son of Rachel Dishi and Avi Dishi, also of Manhattan. Rabbi Jacob Nasirov is to officiate at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Lynn Starace, Benjamin Ritter
text: Lynn Patricia Starace, the daughter of James O. Starace and Maureen E. Starace of Matawan, N.J., was married Saturday to Benjamin Peter Ritter, the son of Valerie J. Ritter and Peter H. Ritter of East Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. John Scully, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Clement Church in Matawan, N.J.

headline: Marisa Sargent, Joshua Bernhardt
text: Marisa Joleen Sargent and Joshua Aaron Bernhardt were married Saturday in New York. Rabbi Renee Feller officiated at the New York Palace Hotel with the Rev. Neil O’Connell, a Roman Catholic priest, assisting.

headline: Sochie Nnaemeka, Edward Fertik
text: Sochie Ursula Nnaemeka, a daughter of Geraldine M. Nnaemeka and Dr. Peter E. Nnaemeka of New Rochelle, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Edward Stolper Fertik, the son of Antonia E. Stolper and Robert A. Fertik of New York. The Rev. Dr. F. Paul De Hoff, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y.

headline: Anna Gurvich, Jeffrey Hadzima
text: Anna M. Gurvich, a daughter of Michael B. Gurvich and Maria A. Shtaveman of Mount Pleasant, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Jeffrey Joseph Hadzima, the son of Margaret D. Hadzima and Joseph G. Hadzima Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass. The Rev. Kirkland F. Russell Jr., an Anglican priest, officiated on Pink Sands Beach at the Ocean View Club on Harbour Island, the Bahamas.

headline: Alexandra Costanza,  Morgan Whitworth
text: Alexandra Katherine Costanza, the daughter of Philip J. Costanza and Katherine R. Costanza of San Jose, Calif., was married Saturday to Morgan Edwin Whitworth, a son of Elizabeth N. Whitworth and Dr. Hall B. Whitworth of Winter Park, Fla. Chief Judge Anne C. Conway of the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, for whom the groom is a law clerk, officiated at Tehama Golf Club in Carmel, Calif.

headline: Two Sidekicks Take On All Forces
text: Rebecca Rose Lewis and Timothy Allan Hade were married Saturday at Twin Willows, an estate owned by a family friend in Lyme, N.H. The bride’s brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: In Sickness and in Laughs
text: Elyse Christine Jasmund, the daughter of Elizabeth Donlin Jasmund and David J. Jasmund of Winter Park, Fla., was married Saturday to Andrew Mifflin Starling, a son of Susanne Hollyday Starling and Alan C. Starling of Orlando, Fla. The Very Rev. Richard M. Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Knowles Memorial Chapel on the campus of Rollins College in Winter Park.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Our side isn’t used to being asked for that kind of money. If you asked them to put up $100 million for a hospital wing, they’d be the first in line.”

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Catch up on the week’s top stories.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
text: 10:30 A.M. (CBS) FACE THE NATION After 24 years as this show’s host and 46 with CBS, Bob Schieffer, above, signs off by interviewing Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate and former Florida governor.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Catch up on the week’s top stories.

headline: Corrections: May 31, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Outfielder Makes His Debut With the Yankees in a Win Over the Athletics
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Here was outfielder Ramon Flores on Saturday afternoon, sitting in a major league clubhouse, wearing a major league uniform. He was at the airport in Philadelphia at 5 a.m., connected in Minneapolis and arrived in the Bay Area in time for lunch. He had seen his name in the starting lineup posted on the wall, had just been congratulated by several teammates and was talking to about a dozen reporters.

headline: The World’s Coming Broadband Divide
text: Several events last week pointed out how much business success, economic development and even international competition is starting to depend on once unimaginably fast Internet speeds.

headline: For Some in Chicago, Spike Lee’s ‘Chiraq’ Has a Title That Rankles
text: CHICAGO — In his 1914 poem, an admiring Carl Sandburg called Chicago the “City of the Big Shoulders,” a proud label for the working people who called it home. During the winter of the polar vortex 100 years later, as temperatures dipped below zero and bitter winds whipped off Lake Michigan, miserable Chicagoans quipped that they were living in Chiberia.

headline: John Kerry Cuts Europe Trip Short After Breaking Leg in Bicycle Accident
text: GENEVA — Secretary of State John Kerry plans to cut short his trip to Europe after breaking a leg while bicycling on Sunday and will return to Boston for medical treatment.

headline: Doctors Seek Test for Deploying New Life-Extending Cancer Drugs
text: CHICAGO — New drugs that boost the immune system’s ability to fight tumors may be one of the greatest medical advances in years, cancer doctors say, pulling some patients from death’s door and keeping them in remission for years.

headline: China Says It Could Set Up Air Defense Zone in South China Sea
text: BEIJING — A Chinese admiral said Sunday that Beijing could set up an air defense zone above disputed areas of the South China Sea if it thought it was facing a large enough threat, according to Chinese news media.

headline: A Special-Needs Parent Against My Will, Learning My Own Adaptive Lesson
text: I recently attended my 3-year-old daughter’s first ballet recital. It was one of the hardest things I’ve ever done.

headline: Western Officials Alarmed as ISIS Expands Territory in Libya
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The branch of the Islamic State that controls Surt has expanded its territory and pushed back the militia from the neighboring city of Misurata, militia leaders acknowledged Sunday.

headline: Grim History Surfaces With Wreckage of Slave Vessel
text: The Portuguese slave ship São José Paquete Africa left Mozambique in 1794 bound for Brazil, but never made it past the Cape of Good Hope.

headline: Grim History Traced in Sunken Slave Ship Found Off South Africa
text: WASHINGTON — On Dec. 3, 1794, a Portuguese slave ship left Mozambique, on the east coast of Africa, for what was to be a 7,000-mile voyage to Maranhão, Brazil, and the sugar plantations that awaited its cargo of black men and women.

headline: 1890: A Railway Horror
text: NEW YORK — Later telegrams from San Francisco give the following additional details of the accident to the Oakland train, an account of which was cabled yesterday [May 30].

headline: ‘Skylight’ Revival on Broadway Makes Back Investment
text: The Broadway revival of “Skylight,” starring Carey Mulligan and Bill Nighy, has recouped its capitalization despite a relatively limited run, the producers said Sunday.

headline: Grim History Surfaces With Wreckage of Slave Vessel
text: The Portuguese slave ship São José Paquete Africa left Mozambique in 1794 bound for Brazil, but never made it past the Cape of Good Hope.

headline: This Age of Derp, Kansas Edition
text: Menzie Chinn notes the continuing failure of the Kansas experiment with supply-side tax cuts. And yes, it is an experiment — Gov. Brownback said it was, and by cutting taxes radically on the basis of ideology rather than any compelling event, Kansas in effect provided us with a natural experiment on exactly what such cuts accomplish. Menzie uses business indicators; I just look at employment growth since Brownback took office, compared with the nation as a whole (red line). No hint whatsoever of a supply-side boost, and of course a terrible fiscal crisis.

headline: Crane Accident in Midtown Manhattan Injures 7 and Damages Buildings
text: A heating and air-conditioning unit weighing several tons came untethered from a crane and fell 30 stories to the ground in Midtown Manhattan on Sunday, leaving seven people scraped, bruised and shaken up, officials said.

headline: Beau Biden Introduces His Father in 2012
text: Joseph R. Biden III, who was known as Beau, introduced his father, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., during the 2012 Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: A Peep Inside the Former Home of Walter Winchell, America’s Top Transom Peeper
text: The temptation is to begin with a Winchellism like this: “Good evening, Mr. and Mrs. America from border to border and coast to coast and all the ships at sea. Let’s go to press.” So much time has passed since that was a national catchphrase that an explanation would be necessary — an explanation of what Winchellisms were and who coined them.

headline: Seismic Swarms of ‘San Andreas’ Top Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES – Dwayne Johnson became a bona fide movie star over the weekend, powering his “San Andreas” disaster thriller to a better-than-expected $53.2 million in North American ticket sales.

headline: An Artist With Too Many Ideas to Consider Retiring
text: The thought sometimes flashes through her mind in the sleepless hours after midnight, when she is energized and annoyed by the deluge of ideas flooding her brain.

headline: Netanyahu Lashes Out at Criticism of Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Sunday that his country faced “an international campaign to blacken its name” based not on his policies toward the Palestinians but “connected to our very existence,” likening the mounting boycott movement to anti-Semitic “libels” of previous eras.

headline: Lennie Merullo, the Last Cub to Play in a World Series, Dies at 98
text: Lennie Merullo was honored by the Chicago Cubs at a June 2014 game, throwing out the ceremonial first pitch and leading the crowd in “Take Me Out to the Ballgame” during the seventh-inning stretch, part of the many events marking Wrigley Field’s 100th anniversary.

headline: 1940: Flanders Evacuation Continues Orderly as Bad Weather Hampers Nazi Bombers
text: LONDON — A series of dramatic eyewitness descriptions of Allied soldiers arriving in English ports after being evacuated from Flanders was given today [May 31] by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

headline: Beau Biden’s Death Triggers an Outpouring of Grief
text: WASHINGTON — In a town where few events ever truly break through the thick layer of partisanship, the death of Joseph R. Biden III on Saturday night unleashed an outpouring of sorrow.

headline: ‘Big Bang Theory’ Creates Science Scholarship
text: The stars of the “The Big Bang Theory” will be putting their very big paychecks to good use. Actors on the sitcom, as well as members of the crew and the CBS show’s co-creator Chuck Lorre, have created a scholarship at the Univerity of California, Los Angeles, for science students seeking financial aid.

headline: Review: Matthew Aucoin’s ‘Crossing’ Is a Taut, Inspired Opera
text: BOSTON — At 25, the American composer, conductor, pianist, poet and sometime critic Matthew Aucoin has already been an assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera, made his conducting debut with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and written pieces for Yo-Yo Ma, among other renowned artists, not to mention lecturing on music and poetry at the Shakespeare Society in New York.

headline: Doris Hart, a Tennis Star Who Deftly Overcame Leg Ailments, Dies at 89
text: Doris Hart, who overcame a life-threatening leg infection as a child and became one of the world’s best tennis players in the decade after World War II, died on Friday at her home in Coral Gables, Fla. She was 89.

headline: As Rafael Nadal Awaits, Jack Sock Hopes to Win a Battle of Forehands
text: PARIS — Jack Sock has already experienced a Jack Sock Day, which took place last September in Lincoln, Neb. He has also been honored at a University of Nebraska football game and is still hoping to take batting practice with the Kansas City Royals in his other touchstone city.

headline: Jeb Bush Says He Is Still Just Considering a Presidential Run
text: Jeb Bush continued to maintain he was merely thinking about a presidential bid when asked on Sunday if he was delaying an announcement to continue courting wealthy donors.

headline: Review: ‘A Human Being Died That Night,’ a Look at an Apartheid Assassin, at BAM
text: The words are sober, almost clinical: “A Human Being Died That Night.” The play that bears this title, on the other hand, reveals in searing, sometimes heart-rending detail the atrocities committed by the South African police forces during the terrible years of apartheid.

headline: Obama’s Trade Deal Faces Bipartisan Peril in the House
text: WASHINGTON — The bruising battle over President Obama’s push for the power to negotiate two potentially far-reaching trade pacts will shift this week to the House, where the White House faces entrenched opposition from Democrats and the stirring of rebellion from the Republicans’ right flank.

headline: Ex-FIFA Official Cites Satirical Article From The Onion in His Self-Defense
text: Jack Warner, a former vice president of world soccer’s governing body, FIFA, defended himself against corruption charges on Sunday by citing an article from The Onion, apparently unaware that it was satire.

headline: Review: Donald Berman Balances Fire and Rhapsody at Bargemusic
text: In the middle of an aphoristic gallery of portrait pieces by Scott Wheeler on Friday night, the pianist Donald Berman paused, seemingly to look out the window.

headline: Review: Jane Comfort Signals a Departure With a Moody New Work
text: Jane Comfort is a choreographer with a penchant for fusing text and movement — until now. “Altiplano,” which received its premiere on Thursday as part of the La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, signals a departure for this longtime modern choreographer, who in past dance-theater works has explored the myth of Persephone and notions of beauty with Barbie.

headline: Review: ‘To Life!,’ a Show of Songs Cut From ‘Fiddler on the Roof’
text: Unless you’re a finicky musical-theater historian or a fanatical devotee of the show being examined, a program of songs discarded from “Fiddler on the Roof” should be a tough sell.

headline: Review: School of American Ballet Workshop Includes ‘Harlequinade’
text: At the annual workshop performances of the School of American Ballet you can see the past becoming the future: the stars of tomorrow, often coached by the stars of yesterday, frequently in ballets and roles that the teachers danced back when they were promising students. The historical continuity is strong, as is the connection to New York City Ballet. That’s where the teachers had their dancing careers and where many of the best pupils end up. Many of the students have already performed with City Ballet, as children in “The Nutcracker” or “Harlequinade.”

headline: Bartolo Colon Adds a Double to His Legend in a Win Over the Marlins
text: The Mets’ pitching staff already has a Thor in Noah Syndergaard and a Dark Knight in Matt Harvey. But Bartolo Colon may be the true superhero.

headline: Review: Stephen King Leaps Through Time in ‘Finders Keepers’
text: Stephen King has won many specialized awards — the Black Quill, the Balrog, the Bram Stoker, just to name a few of the B’s — during his long, incredibly prolific career. But until April he had never won an Edgar for best novel. This is the greatest genre-specific accolade available for crime books and thrillers, and Mr. King finally won it for “Mr. Mercedes,” an atypical King novel published last June. It features a vicious, teasing killer determined to inflict mass violence on crowds of Americans. And it describes him in what is, for Mr. King, a pretty no-frills fashion.

headline: Key Parts of Patriot Act Expire Temporarily as Senate Moves Toward Limits on Spying
text: WASHINGTON — The government’s authority to sweep up vast quantities of phone records in the hunt for terrorists expired at 12:01 a.m. Monday after Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, blocked an extension of the program during an extraordinary and at times caustic Sunday session of the Senate.

headline: Review: ‘Red Hot + Arthur Russell’ Pays Funky, Introspective Tribute to a Composer and Musician
text: Red Hot + Arthur Russell, which started its two nights at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday, was a tribute to the kind of genre-busting artist who defined downtown New York City in the 1970s and ’80s.

headline: Lifetime’s ‘UnREAL’ Traces the Cracks in Reality TV’s Fourth Wall
text: Imagine everything on “The Bachelorette” is nonfiction. The kisses and the heavy petting. The warp-speed growth of love-like feeling. The letdowns and the meltdowns. The belief in a happy ending. The current season of the show — the 11th, or 30th if you include its partner show, “The Bachelor” — is only two weeks in, and already, all of those things have erupted.

headline: Review: ‘The Whispers,’ on ABC, an Imaginary Friend With Dangerous Intentions
text: The brightly creepy opening scene of “The Whispers” gives you what you want in the television equivalent of a beach read. While children cavort on an idyllic suburban lawn, one little girl stands off to the side talking to her imaginary friend. Having received her instructions, she goes in the house and gathers the tools — a hammer, a saw — that she’ll need to build a booby trap designed to kill her mother.

headline: Review: ‘American Genius’ Focuses on Rivalries on the Road to Innovations
text: Serious historians would surely find an abundance of oversimplification in “American Genius,” an eight-part series that begins with two episodes Monday night on the National Geographic Channel. But the treatments still have a lot to recommend them, whether it’s raising the profile of some less-heralded historical figures or simply reminding us of the speed of change.

headline: Review: ‘The Sleeping Beauty,’ Reawakened by American Ballet Theater
text: The ballet of “The Sleeping Beauty” — new in St. Petersburg in 1890 — addresses tradition, renewal and diverse aspects of dance theater. To Serge Diaghilev, the idea of staging it in the West first arose from Tchaikovsky’s music, which, in 1920, he and Stravinsky (Russians unable to return to Russia) found themselves continually playing. But when Diaghilev’s production was realized, in London in 1921 with designs by Léon Bakst, Stravinsky found that its greatest revelation was not Tchaikovsky’s score — for many of us the best and most abundant of all his compositions — but Marius Petipa’s choreography. Its classicism showed, as Stravinsky wrote in his “An Autobiography,” “the triumph of rule over the arbitrary” and “the perfect expression of the Apollonian principle.”

headline: Review: American Symphony Orchestra’s George Perle Centennial Tribute
text: It is a rare encounter with the great musical revivalists Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra that does not involve a lot of scholarly baggage or special pleading for a forgotten composer. But “American Variations: Perle at 100,” an attractive program well played at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening, pretty much spoke for itself.

headline: Challenging Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders Gains Momentum in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — A mere 240 people live in the rural northeast Iowa town of Kensett, so when more than 300 crowded into the community center on Saturday night to hear Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, many driving 50 miles, the cellphones of Democratic leaders statewide began to buzz.

headline: Cogito Ergo Sum
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Confession: One of my favorite cuisines is Korean — I was introduced to it a while back when I was studying a Korean martial art — and I briefly entertained the idea of starting a blog about Korean cooking that I was going to call “SEOUL Food.”

headline: The Population Bomb?
text: In the 1960s, fears of overpopulation sparked campaigns for population control. But whatever became of the population bomb?

headline: The Unrealized Horrors of Population Explosion
text: The second half of the 1960s was a boom time for nightmarish visions of what lay ahead for humankind. In 1966, for example, a writer named Harry Harrison came out with a science fiction novel titled “Make Room! Make Room!” Sketching a dystopian world in which too many people scrambled for too few resources, the book became the basis for a 1973 film about a hellish future, “Soylent Green.” In 1969, the pop duo Zager and Evans reached the top of the charts with a number called “In the Year 2525,” which postulated that humans were on a clear path to doom.

headline: A House Is a Spinning Dome
text: It takes only a motor the size of a lawn mower with the strength of a blow dryer to rotate a 2,500-square-foot house in New Paltz, N.Y.

headline: Federal Investigators Fault Medicare’s Reliance on Doctors for Pay Standards
text: WASHINGTON — The government relies too heavily on advice from the American Medical Association in deciding how much to pay doctors under Medicare, and the decisions may be biased because the doctors have potential conflicts of interest, federal investigators say in a new report.

headline: Saudis Turn Birthplace of Wahhabism Ideology Into Tourist Spot
text: DIRIYAH, Saudi Arabia — More than 250 years ago, in this sunbaked oasis of mud-brick houses and ramparts, the ancestors of the Saudi royal family and an outcast fundamentalist preacher formed an alliance that has shaped this land ever since.

headline: Families of 1972 Munich Victims Find New Hope for Remembrance
text: For 43 years, the families of the victims of the terrorist attack at the 1972 Munich Olympics have pushed and lobbied the German government and the International Olympic Committee for some kind of official acknowledgment to publicly honor those killed in the massacre.
